headline: Spaghetti Farming
text: I love this. On April 1, 1957, the British show “Panorama” pulled a fast one on viewers with this little news report on the Swiss “spaghetti harvest.” According to the blog Food Section, hundreds of viewers contacted the BBC after they watched it to find out where they could buy such a plant.

headline: Richard Feynman, the Thinker
text: In the heyday of the physicist Richard P. Feynman, which ensued after his death in 1988, a publishing entrepreneur might have been tempted to start a book club of works by and about him. Offered as main selections would be Feynman’s autobiographical rambles (as told to Ralph Leighton), “ ‘Surely You’re Joking, Mr. Feynman!’ ” and “ ‘What Do You Care What Other People Think?’ ” For alternate selections, readers could choose from his more serious works, like “QED: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter” — a spirited account of the counterintuitive behavior of the quantum world — and the legendary “Feynman Lectures on Physics.” Whatever the man said had swagger. For those who would rather listen, there are recordings of the lectures and of Feynman playing his bongos.

headline: An Enclave With Rustic Charm
text: IT’S not hard to understand why Puritan settlers in Connecticut slapped the Devil’s name on so many ridges, rivers and gorges. These barren areas were probably so difficult to farm or even traverse that they might have seemed cursed.

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds Buy Stake in TPG
text: The private equity firm TPG has agreed to sell nearly 5 percent of itself to two sovereign wealth funds in a transaction that values the firm at about $10 billion, according to a person briefed on the deal.

headline: Jewish Refugees in the Eternal City
text: It’s not easy for a refugee to retain his dignity, nor is it necessarily a goal. Like a hermit crab that has outgrown its shell, a refugee must seize the best shelter he can before another needy creature is able to grab it. Nevertheless, in David Bezmozgis’s first novel, “The Free World,” set in Rome in 1978, a proud Soviet Jewish émigré couple, seeking visas, take offense when a clerk in the briefing department asks for their “Persecution Story.” “What do we need this for?” the wife asks. “Nobody’s saying you need it,” the clerk explains. “The Americans need it. You’re claiming refugee status. To be a refugee you need to have been persecuted.” To which the wife indignantly retorts: “The entire country was persecuted.”

headline: Les Murray and the Poetry of Depression
text: The signature quality of a Les Murray poem is anger — a visceral smoldering that freshly lights up the tired old landscape and turns conventional pieties inside out. A lifelong outsider and champion of the underdog, Murray grew up among impoverished farmers in rural Australia, where, as an overweight “redneck” teenager, he was mercilessly tormented at school. Today he is the closest thing Australia has to a national poet. A sui generis autodidact (he now suspects he has Asperger’s syndrome) equipped with a fierce moral vision and a sensuous musicality, he writes subtly about post­colonialism, urban sprawl and poverty and, in his most intimate poems, reminds us of the power of literature to transubstantiate grievance into insight. (His admirers have argued he ought to be considered for a Nobel.) But he is equally capable of writing emotionally simplistic and strangely soured poems in which the enraged adolescent emerges all but unmediated. This mercurial doubleness can make his work hard to categorize or describe: this is a mind at once revolutionary and reactionary. Or maybe just a poet who’s willing to show more id than most.

headline: Casualties of China’s One Child Policy
text: In 1989, the Chinese writer and broadcaster Xinran was in a remote mountain village in Shandong Province having dinner with the headman when she heard cries from an adjoining room, where his daughter-in-law was giving birth. A while later, as the midwife collected her fee, Xinran noticed a movement in the slops bucket. “To my absolute horror,” she recalls, “I saw a tiny foot poking out of the pail.” But she was the only one who was shocked. “It’s not a child,” the headman’s wife told her. “If it was, we’d be looking after it, wouldn’t we? It’s a girl baby, and we can’t keep it.”

headline: Helping Refugees After World War II
text: Military victory — to adapt Oscar Wilde — is rarely pure and never simple. The Allied triumph in Europe at the end of World War II was a case in point. The war and the Holocaust forced millions of civilians across national frontiers. Afterward, multitudes of ethnic Germans were expelled from Eastern Europe and many of the Jews in Poland fled from a new wave of persecution there. Those lucky enough to survive these migrations faced months and years in limbo as the authorities wrestled with the logistical, political and moral difficulties involved in returning them home — or in finding them a new one.

headline: Our False Beliefs About Language
text: For nearly a century, linguists have been struggling to unseat the accumulated dogma that “masquerades as common sense,” as the American linguist Leonard Bloomfield put it in 1933. That’s the challenge that faces every developing science, but linguistics seems to have had a harder time than most. People who readily accept the principles of modern economics, psychology and biology still cling to notions about language that are as antiquated as a belief in physi­ocracy or leeching.

headline: Julia Child’s Life as a Spy
text: In late August 1945, with the work of the Office of Strategic Services, the United States’ wartime intelligence agency, winding down, Col. John Coughlin, commander of the O.S.S. detachment in Ceylon, called a field agent named Jane Foster to his bungalow. Foster assumed she was in trouble, since she usually was. (She liked to say she was the organization’s “most-threatened-with-court-­martial person.”) Instead Coughlin poured her a drink and asked if she would volunteer to report on the postwar transition in Java. Wouldn’t she! Foster, who spoke Malay and had lived in Batavia, had already told a friend about her “confidential plan” to infiltrate a small Indonesian island and emerge as “the Great White Queen of Bali.” The friend half-believed her. With Foster, she recalled, “you could never tell.”

headline: A Woman Goes Missing in Seoul
text: “Please Look After Mom,” by the South Korean writer Kyung-sook Shin, opens with a family in disarray. Mom is missing, separated from Father by the closing doors of a subway car in a busy train station in Seoul. A day, a week, then nearly a month goes by. Mom’s husband and adult children are not only worried, but crippled with guilt and regret, fumbling “in confusion, as if they had all injured a part of their brains.” Are you punishing me? each privately wonders.

headline: Katherine Kempner, Robert Miller
text: Katherine Lauren Kempner and Robert Bennett Miller were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Lawrence M. Schuval officiated at the Smith & Wollensky restaurant in Miami Beach.

headline: Jessica May, Carl Gold
text: Dr. Jessica Lynn May and Carl Aaron Gold were married Saturday evening in Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Dennis Eisner officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Scottsdale at Troon North.

headline: Jillian Borman, Jason Hochfelder
text: Dr. Jillian Leigh Borman and Dr. Jason Patrick Hochfelder were married Saturday evening at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Susie Heneson Moskowitz performed the ceremony.

headline: Emily Israel and James Pluhar
text: Dr. Emily Frelinghuysen Israel and James Andrew Pluhar were married Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House and Peterson Hall, an event space in New York. The Rev. Mark Bozzuti-Jones, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Joanna Baker, Peter de Neufville
text: Joanna Johnson Baker, the daughter of Marianna Johnson Baker of New York and the late George F. Baker III, was married Saturday evening to Peter Bayon de Neufville, a son of John P. de Neufville of Mendham, N.J., and the late Suzanne Bayon de Neufville. The Rev. Kirkland H. Russell Jr., an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at St. John’s Anglican Church on Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

headline: Going Green for Spring With Chard
text: Chard is a leafy green vegetable that’s hearty enough to withstand the cold of a chilly spring, but more delicate in flavor than kale and collards, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Michele Siegel, Joshua Rosenblum
text: Michele Terry Siegel and Joshua Daniel Rosenblum are to be married Sunday evening at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi William M. Plevan is to officiate.

headline: Stephanie Miller and Jonathan Peled
text: Stephanie Elena Miller and Dr. Jonathan Uriah-Chaim Peled are to be married Sunday by Rabbi William Berman at Temple Chaverim in Plainview, N.Y.

headline: Up Front: Meghan O’Rourke
text: This week, Meghan O’Rourke reviews two new books — a poetry collection and a memoir of depression — by the Australian poet Les Murray.

headline: Our Predictions for the 2011 Season
text: While Tyler Kepner, who covers baseball for The Times, made his American League picks and National League picks last weekend in his league outlooks, and selected the Boston Red Sox to beat the San Francisco Giants in the World Series, Ben Shpigel, who covers the Yankees, and David Waldstein, who covers the Mets, join him out on the limb today.

headline: Inside the List
text: GOING HAWAIIAN: Sarah Vowell hits No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list with “Unfamiliar Fishes,” her wry account of the annexation and Americanization of Hawaii. What other writer would describe the first encounters between Hawaiians and missionaries as like “some sort of clunky prequel to ‘Footloose’ ”? Vowell also includes an exegesis of the cheesy 1987 surf flick “North Shore,” but insists she approaches wave-riding as a purely spectator sport. “I do love watching surfers,” she said in an e-mail. “I’m especially entranced by that moment they gather together offshore waiting for a wave. Maybe they’re out there talking trash, but from the sand it’s the perfect image of camaraderie. In the book I quote a hula scholar friend who calls surfing, like hula, quintessentially Hawaiian. The missionaries thought hula was ‘satanic.’ They were less offended by surfing. I read one missionary diatribe that predicted it would die out once the Hawaiians became accustomed to being fully clothed.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: GREAT SOUL: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India,  by Joseph Lelyveld (Knopf, $28.95.) While Gandhi’s tenets (a Muslim-Hindu alliance, an end to untouchability) remain largely unfulfilled, it is his role as a social reformer that most interests Lelyveld.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A TICKET TO THE CIRCUS: A Memoir,  by Norris Church Mailer (Random House, $15.) The author, who died of cancer in 2010, was a 26-year-old high school art teacher and divorced mother named Barbara Jean Davis when she met Norman Mailer in 1975. With candor and wit, she reflects on her Arkansas upbringing and on becoming Mailer’s sixth wife: managing his career and family life over three decades (Mailer died in 2007 at 84) while carving out her own niche as a writer.

headline: Marie-Adele Sorel and Jeremy Kress
text: Dr. Marie-Adele Sorel and Jeremy Coltan Kress are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Eytan N. Kenter at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

headline: Katherine Boone, Joshua Geltzer
text: Katherine Nancy Boone and Joshua Alexander Geltzer were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at White Oak Plantation in Yulee, Fla. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated.

headline: Paul Kim and Derek Brown
text: Derek Allen Brown and Paul Kang Yoo Kim were married Saturday morning at Meridian Hill Park in Washington. Hayden E. Windrow, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Popcast: Portuguese Fado, Britney Spears and More
text: This week: Larry Rohter talks to Ben Ratliff about the new wave of Fado music from Portugal; Jon Caramanica on Britney Spears’s new album “Femme Fatale”; and Nate Chinen on jazz trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire.A new wave of old-style Portuguese music; a new album from Britney Spears (mp3)

headline: TimesCast | Libyan Envoy in London
text: April 1, 2011 - Mohammed Ismail, a senior aide to Seif al-Islam, one of Colonel Qaddafi's sons, held secret talks in London with British authorities.

headline: Way Back in Time With Two Friends Who Go Way Back
text: IN the 15 or so years it took them to get from Winston-Salem to Hollywood, Danny McBride and David Gordon Green found ways to pass the time. Since meeting as undergraduates at the North Carolina School of the Arts, Mr. McBride, who plays the mullet-haired, showboating pitcher Kenny Powers on HBO’s “Eastbound & Down,” and Mr. Green, the director whose films include the stoner comedy “Pineapple Express,” have established a tradition of brainstorming preposterous titles for hypothetical film and television projects, then inventing premises to fit those titles.

headline: The Definitive Slang Dictionary
text: Back in 1937, when Eric Partridge’s groundbreaking “Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English” was first published, The New York Times Book Review ran a glowing notice. “The lost words of the language have finally come to roost,” it began. “The unmentionables are mentioned and carefully placed in proper alphabetical form.”

headline: On the Street | Springtime Fox Fur Scarf
text: Out of the past comes the springtime fox fur scarf, which glamorized fashion from 1910 to 1950, when the show was stolen by the mink stole.

headline: What Comes Next in the Battle for NYSE
text: Nasdaq OMX’s not-so surprising proposal to acquire NYSE Euronext sets off an intricate series of decisions that the NYSE Euronext board must make in the coming weeks.

headline: Family Lines Meet in a Cube
text: IF you ask a young man to name a possession he is extraordinarily fond of, you will be surprised how often the answer is something that belonged to his grandfather: a gold watch, a fur-felt fedora, a dresser box for collar stays.

headline: Oregon Frontier, From Under a Bonnet
text: IN 1845 a new trail across the wilds of Oregon was blazed by a wagon train under the guidance of one Stephen Hall Meek. Or to put that another way, in 1845 desperate settlers followed a notorious mountain man on a journey marked by death, confusion and varying degrees of upheaval. The route came to be known as the Meek Cutoff (a k a “shortcut”), but a new film by Kelly Reichardt inspired by the events joins the travelers midjourney, when the outcome remains in terrible doubt.

headline: Big Deal | A ‘Prized Piece of Art’ for a Buyer to Call Home
text: To hear Robert Marc, the luxury eyewear designer whose sunglasses are worn by a host of celebrities, talk about his apartment at 165 Charles Street, it’s a little hard to understand why he is selling. He bought the three-bedroom on the 10th floor of the 16-story Richard Meier tower five years ago for $7.32 million. Now he is listing it with John Burger of Brown Harris Stevens for $7.95 million.

headline: A Drink With a Kick, but No Alcohol
text: More than a dozen competing trays of chili were laid out, smackdown style, at last weekend’s Grillin’ on the Bay event in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. To drink with their bottomless bowls, many folks snagged a pint cup of beer. But others crossed over to the City ‘Lasses table, which featured its new drink, the switzel.

headline: Who is Gabriel Osmonde? A French Literary Mystery is Solved
text: PARIS – Andrei Makine, one of France’s most celebrated novelists, whose books, including “Dreams of My Russian Summers,” have been translated into English, revealed this week that he has published four novels under the name Gabriel Osmonde, the newspaper Figaro reported.

headline: Who’s Got the Best April Fool’s Pranks?
text: Ah, it’s April Fool’s Day. You’d think the Web world would run out of clever ideas for pranks after all these years, but no such worries; the 2011 assortment is hilarious.

headline: Microsoft’s Antitrust Volley and Google’s Way Forward
text: Business and law are pragmatic vocations. So where a company stands on some principle typically hinges on the circumstances in which it sits. Just ask Microsoft, long the world’s No. 1 antitrust defendant, that on Thursday filed a formal antitrust complaint in Europe against Google, as we reported.

headline: Downsizing Made Easy: Increase Size, Power and Space
text: RISING fuel prices and earthly calamities have many citizens donning Jimmy Carter’s metaphorical cardigan, facing up to energy conservation as they rarely have since the 1970s.

headline: In Every Way, This Buick Is a Family Car
text: WHEN Joseph La Vache, known to everyone as Lenny, bought a Buick Wildcat coupe in 1963, he made a promise to his bride-to-be, Maria.

headline: The K-Car as a Limousine? That’s a Stretch
text: WHAT WERE THEY? 1983-86 Chrysler Executive Sedan and Limousine.

headline: Napolitano Defends Administration on Border Enforcement
text: Obama administration officials, embattled on all sides on immigration, are pushing back to defend their record on border enforcement and deportations of illegal immigrants.

headline: Patrice Covington and Elijah Bland
text: WHEN Patrice Covington tells people she found her husband on Craigslist, she is quick to clarify that it was on “Gigs” and not “Men Seeking Women.”

headline: Inflation and Reality
text: The Off the Charts column this week takes a look at inflation and tries to adjust the reports by including home prices. Existing indexes estimate the housing costs for homeowners by measuring the rental value of their homes, not their prices.

headline: Look of The Moment | Katie Holmes
text: The Look: Polished Prairie — a chic spin on the new homespun trend.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Super-Hero Central
text: No. 1 on our hardcover list this week is “Justice League of America: Dark Times,” written by James Robinson and illustrated by Mark Bagley. It features a matchup between two teams of costumed heroes: the Justice League and the Justice Society of America. This adventure has links to “Brightest Day,” the latest event story from DC Comics about 12 resurrected heroes and villains. One of those heroes, Jade, has ties to both teams. She is the daughter of the Golden Age Green Lantern, one of the founders of the Justice Society, the first comic-book super-team who have had adventures since 1940. Jade was also the significant other of a modern day Green Lantern (Kyle Rayner), a former member of the Justice League.

headline: Protesters Rally Into Night in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Hundreds of demonstrators calling for reform rallied late into the evening in the Jordanian capital on Friday, a week after riot police officers and government supporters violently broke up a rally and a protest camp, leaving one man dead and scores injured.

headline: Calorie-Counting Rule to Leave Out Movie Theaters
text: Movie theaters don’t hesitate to wag a stern finger at their patrons: Shhh! Turn off your cellphone. Don’t talk during the movie.

headline: Pole Dancing With a Big Difference: The Clothes Stay
text: The link was sent to me last week by my friend Rachel, a civil liberties lawyer. I clicked on it and found a local TV news report.

headline: The Battle Over the Budget Continues
text: Jennifer Steinhauer, a Times reporter covering Capitol Hill, discussed whether both political parties can deliver the votes to finalize a deal and avert a government shutdown a week from Friday.

headline: Video: Budget Battles on Capitol Hill
text: Read Jennifer Steinhauer’s related story, “As Budget Talks Continue, Hard-Liners Get Support From Tea Party,” published in Friday’s Times.

headline: Diane Gives a Party
text: SHANGHAI — Last December, the American fashion designer Diane vonFurstenberg promised to give an outrageous Red Ball in China thisyear, just ahead of her retrospective art and fashion show, “Journey ofa Dress,” which opens this Saturday at Pace Gallery in Beijing.

headline: 2 Rig Firm Workers Decline To Appear at Oil Spill Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Two employees of Transocean are refusing to appear before a federal panel investigating last year’s Deepwater Horizon blowout and oil spill, federal officials and lawyers for the company and its employees said on Friday.

headline: The Dulpickles and Nigmenogs of 1699
text: In this week’s Book Review, I consider the most recent — and most ambitious — effort to compile a dictionary of English-language slang. But such efforts have been underway for centuries. Several months ago, Oxford University’s Bodleian Library republished the earliest known foray: “The First English Dictionary of Slang, 1699,” with an introduction by John Simpson, chief editor of the Oxford English Dictionary. (To see a facsimile of the original edition, please click here.)

headline: Material Man
text: The fashion designer Reed Krakoff tends to wear his interests in art, architecture and design on his sleeve. His love for the work of Le Corbusier, for example, finds direct translation in his recent collections. Here, Krakoff gives T a list of the books and films that have lately caught his eye.

headline: Dolce and Gabbana Tax Case Is Dismissed by Judge in Italy
text: MILAN — A judge ruled Friday that two fashion designers, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana, would not have to stand trial for tax evasion and fraud.

headline: A Proper Name for a Wayward Cobra
text: Sneaky. Skippy. Slinky. Runaway Sue. SSSSSSSybil. Asperanza the Asp. Heidi (get it?). Tahrir — for an Egyptian who clearly values her liberty.

headline: Disparities: Illness More Prevalent Among Older Gay Adults
text: Older lesbian, gay and bisexual adults in California are more likely to suffer from chronic physical and mental health problems than their heterosexual counterparts, a new analysis has found. They also are less likely to have live-in partners or adult children who can help care for them.

headline: Strongman and Stability Guide Kazakhs in Vote
text: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — On the eve of a presidential election in this oil-rich Central Asian nation, students and faculty at the Kazakh University of the Arts filed into an auditorium for a meeting that was, according to fliers posted in the hallways, “strictly mandatory!!!”

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Latest Setback
text: Morgan Stanley’s turnaround story has encountered another setback.

headline: The Royal Wedding
text: The Times' Christine Haughney talks with British expatriates and New Yorkers about the upcoming royal wedding.

headline: Kazakhs Schedule a Rare Presidential Vote
text: During a season of collapsing authoritarian regimes, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, Kazakhstan’s 70-year-old president, stands as testament to the forces protecting the strongmen of the former Soviet states.

headline: A Royal Wedding? She’s Been There
text: “IT is dreadful,” declared India Hicks, the model and former “Top Design” host, in a supremely proper English accent that made the phrase a symphony of syllables. She was sitting in a room at the Mark hotel on the Upper East Side, gazing out her window at rain squalls so thick they disguised the adjacent maze of apartment buildings.

headline: A Long, Slow Slog Back to Normal
text: While the 216,000 net jobs that the economy added last month were certainly welcome, the growth wasn’t nearly fast enough to get the country back on the path to full employment anytime soon.

headline: Slow Compounding
text: American Express has a full-page ad in today’s Times offering a savings account yielding 1.15 percent.

headline: State Police Investigating E-Mail to Lawmakers
text: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | ALBANY — The State Police are investigating a threatening e-mail sent to several state lawmakers on Friday that promised violent attacks on state officials, schoolchildren and journalists.

headline: New York Theater Workshop Announces Two More Productions for 2011-12 Season
text: Off Broadway’s New York Theater Workshop on Friday announced two additional productions for its 2011-12 season: a play about a Palestinian family preparing for a wedding in the politically volatile West Bank, and a modern retelling of Homer’s “Illiad” that will feature, on alternating nights, the Tony Award winners Denis O’Hare (“Take Me Out”) and Stephen Spinella (“Angels in America”) as the piece’s sole actor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Ivory Coast, Libya and Egypt.

headline: In Hong Kong, in Pursuit of the Perfect Dress
text: CHEONGSAMS have long captivated me.

headline: Restaurant Review: Mesob, in Rome
text: In a spruced-up former garage on a bleak section of the Via Prenestina in Rome, diners use injera, the traditional Ethiopian sourdough bread, to scoop up richly spiced stews. Is it an atypical Roman meal? Yes and no.

headline: On the Island of Jersey, Fortifications Turned Lodging
text: “IT’S in the details,” said Dave Bull, the caretaker of a former military bunker on the island of Jersey in the English Channel. He heaved open a cast-iron door and ran a hand over its bolts and heavy wrench-like handle. “This was all built by slave labor, by prisoners the Nazis marched here from Europe.”

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Seven in Paris
text: BASICS

headline: Four Paris Restaurants Worth a Metro Ride
text: FOUR years ago, writing in these pages about Paris restaurants, I mentioned one called Au Boeuf Couronné, called it “terrific” and added that traveling to its location in the 19th Arrondissement was “the rough equivalent of going deep into Brooklyn.”

headline: Why We Travel
text: IN the bungling and bellicosity that constitute the back and forth of history, worsened by natural disasters and unprovoked cruelty,  humble citizens pay the highest price. To be a traveler in such circumstances can be inconvenient at best, fatal at worst. But if the traveler manages to breeze past such unpleasantness on tiny feet, he or she is able to return home to report: “I was there. I saw it all.” The traveler’s boast, sometimes couched as a complaint, is that of having been an eyewitness, and invariably this experience — shocking though it may seem at the time — is an enrichment, even a blessing, one of the life-altering trophies of the road.

headline: Riverside Lynchburg, Va., Builds on Its History
text: Developers have preserved the historic feel of the downtown area, as new loft apartments, art studios, restaurants and a tearoom now fill the hulking warehouses and factories along the banks of the James River.

headline: On an Island East of Bali, a Backpacker’s Hideaway Goes Upscale
text: THE blaze of white sand licked by the surf was dotted one recent sunlit afternoon with fishing boats and their local owners, a pack of bored men in flip-flops who each kept one eye on their hand of cards and the other on the pale tourist cargo streaming from the docked speedboat onto the main road of the island of Gili Trawangan, east of Bali, in search of beach, beer and bungalow.

headline: Traveling When Some Say ‘Stay Home’
text: Throughout history, the traveler has been forced to recognize that the fact of leaving home means encountering uncertainty.

headline: Glorious Gili Trawangan
text: Luxury villas spring up on an island once more famous for its magic mushrooms.

headline: Letters: Seeing Asia in Detail
text: Seeing Asia in Detail

headline: Good Value in Northeast Paris
text: Mark Bittman explores dining alternatives in far-flung neighborhoods.

headline: College Plans You Thought Were Safe
text: The predicament of state workers has drawn a great deal of attention recently, and rightly so. The health of their pension plans and their right to organize are fundamental issues.

headline: The House Next Door
text: Paul Graziano had long admired the house next door in Flushing, Queens. He bought it and its eclectic contents and is now restoring it.

headline: The Mars Connection
text: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from New Mexico, where he is measuring sand particle sizes, layer thicknesses and angles to address questions about volcanoes and rock patterns on Mars.

headline: Concerning ‘St. Jeter’
text: Sam Anderson’s Riff column this week addresses the canonization of the New York Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter in five parts, without disparaging ol’ flat-top. Instead, it turns a spotlight on the news media and on the Yankees fans who have built him up to mythic proportions without any help from Jeter, who has always behaved as a baseball player, first and only. The 459-word final part is as creative as anything I have read since I’ve been here.

headline: A Queens Home Wallpapered With Memories
text: FOR 86 years the white colonial with the black trim on 32nd Avenue near 146th Street in Flushing, Queens, was known as the Bruce house. The two-story house had been built in 1923 by Thomas Atkinson, a master plasterer, and his son-in-law, John Bruce, a carpenter. John’s son, John David, known universally as Bud, moved in with his parents as a child of 9.

headline: For 9/11 Museum, Dispute Over Victims’ Remains
text: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains — mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation — are still being sorted through by the city’s medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009.

headline: Councilwoman’s Newest Constituent
text: On Monday and Tuesday, Jessica Lappin, a member of the City Council, was making last-minute calls urging that the Albany budget deal would, indeed, provide the money to keep 105 senior centers in New York open.

headline: When the Fortunate Can Help Those Less So
text: There’s certainly been a lot written about the troubled finances in many states. Programs that help the needy are among those at risk. In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about a new book “Give Smart” that examines ways that wealthy philanthropists can help when governments no longer can.

headline: An Entreaty to Readers: Your Stories
text: In this weekend’s Travel section, author Paul Theroux writes about traveling to unconventional places, and to conventional places at unconventional times:

headline: The Caucus Click: Mitt Romney in North Las Vegas, Nev.
text: “Is it April Fool’s Day?” Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, asked as he signed an autograph at his first public appearance in a month. Asked what he made of that, he grinned and said, “I’m here!”

headline: Dear FloFab: A Customer Is Using My Restaurant As Her Office
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: African Leaders Pressure President of Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG — Zimbabwe’s neighbors, long accused of being soft on its autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, are putting an unusual amount of public pressure on him to halt the political violence, intimidation and arrests that have surged since his party began agitating for elections in recent months.

headline: How Bad Does a Song Have to Be Until It’s Good?
text: It’s Friday. Friday. Fun, fun, fun, fun.

headline: Satellite Operators May Not Renew YES and SNY
text: The Mets’ and Yankees’ networks are in parallel battles with satellite operators.

headline: This Weekend, Let the Rider Beware
text: Updated, April 3 | There are 24 subway lines in the city, counting shuttle trains. This weekend, 14 of them will be altering their regular routes in some way for repairs: the 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, A, C, D, F, G, J, Q and the Rockaway Park shuttle. Most notably, there will be no Q from Atlantic Avenue to 57th Street from midnight to early morning. Mta.info has the full picture.

headline: If Home Prices Counted in Inflation
text: A FEW years ago, the Federal Reserve remained complacent about inflation even as a housing bubble inflated. The Fed did not take the kind of action that would have seemed reasonable if it had been alarmed by rising prices.

headline: March Political Best Sellers
text: “Revolt!” by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann makes its debut at No. 4 on the political best-sellers list. The husband and wife team advises that Republicans use their power to force President Obama to accept their terms of debate and to insure that he doesn’t get re-elected in 2012.

headline: Pitt Criticizes Sokol’s Lubrizol Trades
text: Harvey Pitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, weighs in on David L. Sokol’s sudden resignation from Berkshire Hathaway and the quick criticism of Mr. Sokol’s investments in Lubrizol, a Berkshire target. On CNBC, Mr. Pitt called Mr. Sokol’s actions “terrible” and said his initial assessment was that the investments were not legal. He also criticized what he described as a “public relations campaign” to play down the seriousness of the allegations.

headline: With Sale, Orlando Station to Leave PBS
text: 6:25 p.m. | Updated The primary public television station in Orlando, Fla., WMFE-TV, said Friday that the station was being sold to an undisclosed buyer, in a sign of the continuing financial strains in public broadcasting.

headline: April Fool: From the Subtle to the Outrageous
text: The auto-themed April Fools’ Day pranks ranged from subtle to outrageous, with some actually capable of taking in the unwary or coffee-deprived. Perhaps the most elaborate was the convertible Volt from Road & Track, but others are scattered around the blogosphere. Here’s a summary:

headline: Don’t Just Throw Him Crumbs
text: BRIDEGROOMS often joke that in their own weddings their roles are blissfully simple: show up on time, in freshly pressed tuxedos. Please.

headline: Manning Marable, African-American Studies Scholar, Has Died at 60
text: Manning Marable, the author of a long-awaited new biography of Malcolm X to be published Monday and director of the Institute for Research in African American Studies at Columbia University, died Friday at the age of 60, his wife, Leith Mullings, has confirmed.

headline: Finding an Original Heroine
text: FOR a director who made his name with the literary adaptations “Pride and Prejudice” and “Atonement,” Joe Wright has a surprising view of the essence of cinema. “Drama can be presented onstage, and beautiful pictures can be presented in a gallery, but really action is pure cinema,” Mr. Wright said on the phone recently.

headline: Fighting Continues in Libya
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces stormed the western rebel outpost of Misrata with tanks and artillery on Friday, a Libyan rebel spokesman said, while insurgents marshaled defenses in their eastern heartland.

headline: TimesCast | April 1, 2011
text: At least 12 people are killed at a U.N. compound in Afghanistan; Syria's regime targets social media in an effort to quell dissent; and competing protests divide Yemen's capital.

headline: Big Deal | The White Gloves Are Off
text: Everyone loves a good rivalry, and in this case the competition has pitted one fancy New York City address against another: The mighty 15 Central Park West, a relatively new architectural star, and the Plaza Hotel Residences, which come with the white-glove cachet of being located at the century-old Plaza.

headline: ‘Idol’ Attracts 22 Million Viewers
text: Two finalists were eliminated from “American Idol” on Thursday, Naima Adedapo and Thia Megia, as a results episode of the Fox reality show attracted an impressive 22 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The audience for “Idol” lifted Fox far ahead of its network rivals on the night and provided a boost to Fox’s hidden-camera special with Howie Mandel, “Mobbed,” which delivered a solid 10.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. following “Idol.” ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (12.7 million) edged past CBS’s “CSI” (12.5 million) to lead that time slot, but CBS ranked second for the night over all, earning its best ratings at 10 with “The Mentalist” (13.9 million) and strong results at 8 and 8:30 for the sitcoms “The Big Bang Theory” (11.7 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (8.2 million). ABC was third as 6.3 million tuned in to “Wipeout” at 8 and 7.6 million at 10 for “Private Practice.” NBC placed a very distant fourth with mostly repeats of its comedy line-up. On Bravo on Wednesday, the eighth season finale of “Top Chef” delivered 2.8 million viewers, slightly more than the audience who watched the series’ prior season conclusion (2.7 million).

headline: Ilana Schachter and John Feuerstein
text: Ilana Lazar Schachter and John Meyer Feuerstein are to be married Sunday in Brooklyn. Rabbi Serge A. Lippe is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn.

headline: Kristen Carey, Thomas Rock
text: Dr. Kristen Nicole Carey and Dr. Thomas Andrew Rock were married Saturday afternoon at the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul in Philadelphia. The Rev. F. G. Hank Hilton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Michele Molochkovsky, Michael Cohen
text: Michele Molochkovsky and Michael Craig Cohen were married Saturday night by Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

headline: Janice Chyou, Matthew Tomey

headline: Kristin Fisher and Walker Forehand
text: Kristin Anne Fisher, a daughter of Dr. Anna L. Fisher and Dr. William F. Fisher, both of Houston, was married Saturday to Walker Harrison Forehand, the son of Margaret Peters Stalnaker of White Stone, Va., and Judge V. Thomas Forehand Jr. of Chesapeake, Va. The Rev. James H. Burch of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy City in Washington.

headline: Naomi Schneider, Adam Cohen
text: Naomi Susan Schneider and Adam Philip Cohen are to be married Sunday evening at Marina del Rey, a catering hall in Throgs Neck, the Bronx. Rabbi Yaacov Lerner is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Hanne Anderson and Jack Vaughn Jr.
text: Hanne Lynn Anderson and Jack Hood Vaughn Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. Max Cannon, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: A Thinking Woman’s Detective
text: Sergio Leone gave cinema the spaghetti western, but there isn’t yet an equivalent term for Scandinavian riffs on the classic hard-boiled detective yarn. “The Killing,” a fantastic new AMC adaptation of a popular Danish television series, certainly qualifies as a smorgasbord thriller. It’s unnerving how well the Nordic sensibility fits a genre that for a long time seemed indisputably and inimitably violent and American, particularly given that Sweden, Norway and Denmark have homicide rates that suggest that they have more mystery writers per capita than murders.

headline: All in the Family
text: Mary Jane La Vache of Brooklyn is now driving the 1963 Buick Wildcat her father, Joseph, owned when she was little.

headline: Will Jobs Come Back By the Time Obama Faces Voters?
text: As the unemployment rate ticks down — to 8.8 percent as of Friday morning — the 2012 clock on the wall of President Obama’s new campaign headquarters will soon start getting louder and louder.

headline: In the Mets’ Tradition, a Few Encouraging Words
text: Mets fans, I believe, are often misportrayed as hand-wringing pessimists who have been beaten down by years of incompetence to always expect the worst.

headline: Shutdown Watch: Seven Days Out
text: With seven days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, there appeared to be plenty of cautious optimism. Lawmakers headed home Friday and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, said he would not be in Washington over the weekend to continue negotiations. But both sides appeared less eager to call the other out.

headline: Stargazing
text: Since the jewels designed by Diane Kordas, based in London, began appearing on influential people across the pond (Madonna was her first client; a Rolling Stone is reportedly a fan), British stores like Dover Street Market and Matches can’t keep the delicate pieces in stock. Luckily, they’re now available stateside as well. This black gold and diamond ring, inspired by a shooting star, is about $2,200 at netaporter.com.

headline: Shiites in Iraq Support Bahrain’s Protesters
text: BAGHDAD — The violent suppression of the uprising in Bahrain has become a Shiite rallying cry in Iraq, where the American war overturned a Sunni-dominated power structure much like the one in place in Bahrain.

headline: Romney Talks Economy in Nevada
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. – Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts hailed the latest unemployment numbers as “good news,” but he said in an appearance here Friday that the nation’s economic picture is far gloomier than the 8.8 percent jobless rate would suggest.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Ivory Coast, Libya and Egypt.

headline: Obama Talks Up Clean-Energy Vehicles
text: LANDOVER, Md. — President Obama on Friday joined with U.P.S., FedEx and several other major companies whose vehicles are familiar sights on America’s roadways to promote a new administration initiative for encouraging businesses to build commercial fleets that burn less gasoline and diesel fuel.

headline: Holding Syria Together
text: My cigarette days are well over but the name Latakia still brings up physical memories of “Turkish” tobacco. The Syrian port city was part of the Ottoman empire, is very near the Turkish border, and has a long connection with the tobacco trade. It’s in the news now for protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad. Latakia is particularly interesting because the town and province are the heartland of the Alawites, a Shiite sect that produced the ruling Assad family and much of the current governing elite. (In the wake of the Ottoman collapse in the early 20th century, there was an on-again-off-again Alawite “state” based in and around Latakia until 1944, when it integrated with Syria.)

headline: Bribery and the Gathering Storm Over Compliance
text: While insider trading cases have been attracting much of the financial headlines, there is another issue that will have a much greater effect on corporate bottom lines: bribery.

headline: Tea Party Express Opens 2012 Campaign Against Obama
text: The Tea Party Express became the first organization to buy national advertising to oppose the re-election of President Obama, filing a report on Friday with the Federal Election Commission disclosing more than $40,000 in ad buys on Fox News Channel and Fox Business Network. The group, which became the largest independent backer of Tea Party candidates during last year’s election, also aired an ad opposing Obama in March on local television in Madison, Wis.

headline: Yankees’ Burnett Faces a New Set of Expectations
text: On April 2, 2001, the Florida Marlins were opening their season against the Philadelphia Phillies with a roster full of emerging stars, including a rotation with two potential aces in A.J. Burnett and Brad Penny, and a sense of hope missing since their championship run of 1997.

headline: Rude and Crude Behavior Stains Italian Parliament

headline: Now Online | Spring Design 2011
text: The spring issue of T Design celebrates the lived-in look, starting with the cover story, “Family Style,” in which a young family shakes up a grand English manor house. A Los Angeles garden designer sows the seeds of her fertile imagination in “Growth Industry,” and in “A Place for Everything,” a production designer shows us a few thousand of his favorite things. Plus, the up-and-coming designers Big-Game, Todd Bracher and Courtney Applebaum; Gerhard Steidl’s one-publisher town; and the Edible Selby at the Dock Kitchen. See more from the issue »

headline: Jazz Evangelists Borrow Some of Stevie Wonder’s Cool
text: It says a lot about SFJazz, the San Francisco-based organization, that its house band would make a project out of the music of Stevie Wonder. Not that jazz musicians haven’t long since gotten to Stevie Wonder as material: plenty have, from tentative, cred-building, bell-bottomed experiments by Ella Fitzgerald and Woody Herman, to newer and deeper versions of his songs by Marcus Strickland and Vijay Iyer. It’s that Mr. Wonder’s music is generally not part of an official representation of jazz, the kind of thing put forth by a performing-arts institution like SFJazz.

headline: What a Workout
text: I have a cordial relationship with my neighbor. She’s single with two young children, so she has her hands full; I’m a married woman with no children yet. Lately, every time she sees me, she comments about how often I go to the gym, and how infrequently she does. I feel as if she’s judging me. No matter what I say, she brings the conversation back to my gym-going. How can I change this?

headline: When DeMille Parted the Red Sea
text: CECIL B. DeMILLE would probably have approved of the concept behind Paramount Home Entertainment’s 55th anniversary gift set edition of “The Ten Commandments,” an appropriately colossal undertaking that includes three Blu-ray discs and three standard DVDs, a commemorative book, reproductions of the original program and assorted documents and costume sketches. It’s all packaged inside a dictionary-size box with a lenticular 3-D image of the Red Sea on the front; when the sea is “parted” on a built-in hinge, a plastic reproduction of DeMille’s sacred tablets rises majestically into view.

In warmer climates, tasty things are ripening, just waiting to be called lunch.

headline: Cocktails for Locavores or for Lovers of Honey
text: LOCAL lore suggests the cocktail was invented in Elmsford around the time of the Revolutionary War, when a barmaid would garnish drinks with the tail feathers of roosters from Loyalist chicken coops. And it’s a fact that Purchase has long been the United States base of the French spirits giant Pernod Ricard (Absolut, Beefeater, Kahlúa) and that New Rochelle is home to Sidney Frank spirits importer (Jagermeister). But despite Westchester County’s intoxicating background, there had been no alcoholic spirits distilled there since Prohibition. No legal spirits, at least.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 1
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 100th anniversary of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire, stargazing at the Columbia University Observatory, and a school’s fight for space.

headline: Vine Ripened
text: Sebastian Errazuriz, the Chilean-born designer and artist, became famous for his Bilbao shelf, in which a real tree branch was attached to a wall to create an organic display unit. In his latest design, the Metamorphosis shelf, Errazuriz really goes out on a limb. The inspiration for the limited-edition Baltic birch plywood shelf (which is hand-carved by the Italian company Horm) came from his grandmother’s ivy-covered garden. “The dark branches that crawled along the walls were so thick that I would use them as natural shelves for my garden toys,” Errazuriz said. Given the $75,000 price tag, however, your spade and trowel had better be by Fabergé.

headline: The Height of City Manufacturing
text: I’m guessing that not even the most hard-bitten or nostalgic New Yorker would want to travel back to the days when the city was choked with waterfront factories and industrial squalor. But “The Vertical Urban Factory,” a small, intriguing show at the Skyscraper Museum in Battery Park City, makes you wonder what was lost on the way to our greener, more stroller- and bike-friendly city.

headline: Odd Textures, Elegant Poses and Math’s Golden Mean
text: IN just a few days, Mark Chatterley will drive from his home in Williamston, Mich., to the Clay Art Center in Port Chester, his black Ford extension van filled with larger-than-life ceramic human forms packed, he said, “like cordwood.” Upon his arrival, Mr. Chatterley, an award-winning sculptor who has exhibited nationally and internationally, will arrange those pieces, along with some smaller wall works, in the center’s gallery, where his solo exhibition, “Mark Chatterley: Clay Dreams,” is set to open on Saturday.

headline: At Tulane, No Fireworks Over Airgas Case
text: NEW ORLEANS — If you were expecting fireworks on Friday about the Delaware Supreme Court’s decision in the Airgas case at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute, you were sorely disappointed.

headline: Clock Ticking on War Powers Resolution
text: President Obama’s legal team, having decided he could launch military strikes in Libya last month without congressional authorization, is now weighing a related question: What happens if Congress never votes to approve the operation, but hostilities are still underway in mid-May?

headline: As E-Waste Law Kicks In, the Ideal Option Varies
text: As I report in Saturday’s Times, a new state law took effect on Friday making electronics manufacturers responsible for offering free recycling programs. Many residents of New York City are likely to continue relying on so-called collection events to get rid of their e-waste, however.

headline: In Unfinished Mozart Opera, Berio Provides the Last Word
text: Luciano Berio, the Italian modernist composer who died in 2003, was exuberantly curious about all kinds of music. Madrigals, symphonies, opera, pop — you never knew what would hook him. He was particularly drawn to unfinished works by masters. Among those was Mozart’s incomplete singspiel “Zaide.” When the European Mozart Foundation asked Berio to compose a reconstruction, he leapt at the chance.

headline: Volvo Offers Free Access to Streamed Baseball Games in April
text: No one from Volvo has tossed out the first ball of the 2011 Major League Baseball season, but the car company is making an early pitch.

headline: Through the Prism of the Human Body
text: The human form is so pervasive in Western art that it is almost impossible to imagine our visual culture without it. The artists who gave us the Parthenon, the Mona Lisa and “Guernica” lived in vastly different worlds, yet they all channeled the essences of those worlds into their representations of the figure. There are no such epochal examples among the 43 works in “Human Connections: Figural Art From the Bruce Museum Collection.” But in this small, dense show, the Bruce asks us to think about the figure in art in a novel way. In most museum shows, we look at the subject — a painter or period or motif — through the lens of art history. Here, we are meant to see a range of artworks through the prism of the human body.

headline: Away From His Desk, Up on the Bandstand
text: Wynton Marsalis has been making albums for the last 30 years, since the release of his self-titled Columbia debut. Through all but the first six of those years, he has been not only a celebrated trumpeter and composer but also the public face of Jazz at Lincoln Center, an organization built around his vision, and in many ways still propelled by it.

headline: Orchestra and Violin, Matching Wits
text: Too numerous to count are the new works from major composers, involving prominent executants and unfurled with no small fanfare, that subsequently vanish once the final notes of the initial engagement (or engagements) has faded. Not so “In Tempus Praesens” (“In the Present Time”), the Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulina’s second violin concerto, which has an uncommonly steadfast advocate in Anne-Sophie Mutter, the violinist for whom it was written.

headline: Tip of the Week: Using Tech for Your Taxes
text: With just over two weeks left before Tax Day, many people have yet to deal with the annual ritual of preparing tax returns. In an attempt to make it quicker and more efficient, the Internal Revenue Service continues its Free File program for filing federal taxes online. Taxpayers with a gross adjusted income less than $58,000 can use free tax preparation software provided by the agency’s partners. People with larger incomes can use the Free File Fillable Forms, which are electronic versions of the traditional paper worksheets. Both options are available here.
