headline: A Place to Start Again
text: An ex-convict is the superintendent of a West Harlem apartment building that is home to many formerly homeless or incarcerated.

headline: Keys to a Castle
text: IN a nod to hue, not heft, Chris Carney christened his 600-pound Treadlok safe “the Leprechaun.” It is nearly the same color as the tattoo of a four-leaf clover on the knuckle of the middle finger of his right hand — a tattoo his mother threatened to scrub off with steel wool after he got it as a defiant ninth grader.

headline: Photo Replay: April 1
text: A look at the day in sports, from dreary Opening Day weather to fun in the sun in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: The Workout Begins When Pants Go Missing
text: I HAVE braved wars in the Caucasus, frothing-at-the-mouth nationalists in the Balkans, jihadi radicals and environmental sludge disasters. So I thought I could handle a workout at the Equinox gym near Columbus Circle.

headline: In a Broadway Role, Many Returns
text: “Lace curtain Irish” is an acid-tipped verbal dart when it zips from the mouth of Frances McDormand’s character, Margie, and hits Tate Donovan, as Mike, in the Broadway play “Good People.” Margie, bitter and unemployed, is stuck in Southie, a hardscrabble Boston neighborhood. Mike, a doctor, has left both her and the neighborhood behind.

headline: A Day to Design Collages
text: The professional portfolio of Richard Meier, 76, the Pritzker Prize-winning architect, includes dozens of geometric designs spanning decades and continents. On Sundays, he contributes to another body of work, using scraps of found paper to create collages, a collection of which will eventually appear in a book. Mr. Meier lives in a duplex on East 72nd Street and owns a house in East Hampton, N.Y. ELISA MALA

headline: Talking Work, or Escaping It
text: Since 1994, I Trulli has stood fast on East 27th Street as a destination for the food of Apulia — the heel of the Italian boot — even as the neighborhood has evolved from a nondescript mixed-use area into a hub for creative industries and trendy restaurants. With rustic wood floors, white marble counters, a wood-burning oven, a double-sided fireplace and a backyard patio, the restaurant and attached wine bar draw a mix of local office workers, residents and Italian tourists, said Nicola Marzovilla, the owner. On Wednesday, as Mr. Marzovilla’s mother, Dora, made fresh orecchiette at the front of the house — a skill that “even in Puglia is becoming a lost art,” Mr. Marzovilla said — two business partners stopped into their regular haunt for lunch by the fire.

headline: For Activists, Tips on Safe Use of Social Media
text: FROM Cairo to Madison, Wis., much has been made about the positive role technology has played in helping galvanize and organize populist movements.

headline: The World This Week
text: The art of the defection, a stalemate in Libya and clashes in Syria.

headline: Motion and Emotion Discover New Pairings
text: When springtime hits, student showcases are almost as ubiquitous as street fairs. And, yes, they can certainly be as annoying. But the Second Avenue Dance Company crowned its spring concert with a new work by the treasured minimalist choreographer Lucinda Childs that is optimistic, rigorous and, well, just a joy to behold.

headline: The Mural Vanishes
text: If you haven’t seen it yet, take a look at what is the most widely viewed mural in America at the moment.

headline: Goldman Gives Blankfein a $5.4 Million Cash Bonus
text: Cash is back.

headline: Making Ends Meet
text: Before

headline: As UConn Plays On, Once-Prized Recruit Can Only Watch
text: The former University of Connecticut basketball recruit Nate Miles is effectively homeless. He moves from friend’s couch to friend’s couch, still recovering from a violent assault that left him with a stab wound and a punctured lung and a monthlong stay in the hospital.

headline: Yankees Fans Sound Off About 2011
text: When the Red Sox signed Adrian Gonzalez and Carl Crawford, order in the American League East was jolted. Tremors from the move were felt well outside the Interstate 95 corridor, as nearly every expert (including the Times) is picking the Red Sox to finish atop the Yankees for the first time since 2008.

headline: Preparing to Defend Walker
text: HOUSTON — The veteran role players, not the superstar freshmen, have led Kentucky’s run to the Final Four. The junior guard DeAndre Liggins, the team’s best defender, is a prime example.

headline: Cuomo Stands Out Among Peers for Low Profile
text: When President Obama invited the country’s newly elected governors to Washington for lunch and a chance to rub elbows with cabinet secretaries and West Wing officials, Andrew M. Cuomo sent his regrets.

headline: Protesters Scold Egypt’s Military Council
text: CAIRO — Thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square on Friday for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.

headline: Bringing Skateboarders Doing 60 to a Halt
text: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. — Chance Gaul cannot drive a car yet. He is only 14. But he is already the fastest thing on wheels around here.

headline: Manning Marable, Historian and Social Critic, Dies at 60
text: Manning Marable, a leading scholar of black history and a leftist critic of American social institutions and race relations, whose long-awaited biography of Malcolm X, more than a decade in the writing, is scheduled to be published on Monday, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 60.

headline: A High School Poised at a Moment of Pride and Great Anxiety
text: On a cold, sunny Tuesday morning, the entrance to Rice High School in Harlem is bustling. Television reporters are milling about, waiting to talk to the school’s current and former basketball coaches about Kemba Walker, the Rice alumnus who will lead the University of Connecticut Huskies in the N.C.A.A.’s Final Four this weekend. The students are excited because a busload of girls from a Catholic school in Brooklyn have arrived for a pre-prom get-to-know-you in the gym. And President Obama is visiting the neighborhood later in the day.

headline: Job Growth Alters Playbook for Obama and His Critics
text: LANDOVER, Md.

headline: Lewis Holds Lead In L.P.G.A. Major; Wie Is in Contention
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Stacy Lewis’s first tournament as a professional was the 2008 United States Open. After holding the third-round lead and finishing tied for third, Lewis assumed the L.P.G.A. Tour would be a continuation of her college success.

headline: Calipari Acts as If He Has Been There Before
text: HOUSTON — The last question at Friday’s news conference for Kentucky Coach John Calipari drew laughter from some and astonishment from others. It seemed to draw a reaction from everyone but Calipari, who basically shrugged.

headline: ‘Polite Robber’ Is Given a 60-Month Sentence in Gas Station Holdup
text: Saying “please” and “thank you” is a virtue, but for a robber in Seattle, politeness went only so far.

headline: Podcast: Jobs, Wages and Middle-Class Costs
text: A drop in the unemployment rate and a jump in job creation must count as good news, but this is no time for celebration.

headline: Lawmaker Calls Bishop ‘Pedophile Pimp’
text: A top Republican in New Hampshire on Friday called Bishop John B. McCormack of Manchester a “pedophile pimp” on his Facebook page.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Rebel Attack on Brega Ends in Stalemate
text: BREGA, Libya — Libyan rebels resumed their offensive on Friday by massing heavier weapons in an attack on this eastern oil town, but were repulsed in the fading light of afternoon and backtracked along a main road under fire.

headline: New York’s High Court Attacks False Confessions
text: A young man of limited education and low I.Q. confesses to murder. His statement is a fine-grained picture of the crime: The victim had been dressed in a red-striped nightshirt, cooking chicken and mashed potatoes, when the attack began. He was stabbed 15 or more times with a 12-inch serrated knife. Later, the killer used a paper towel to clean a cut on his own hand and dabbed his wound with intensive-care lotion.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Lou Gorman, Whose Red Sox Lost to Mets, Dies at 82
text: Lou Gorman, who as general manager of the Boston Red Sox put the finishing touches on the 1986 team that came within one strike of bringing the franchise its first world championship in 68 years, only to have it snatched away by the Mets, a team he had also helped put together, died on Friday in Boston. He was 82 and lived in Weston, Mass.

headline: Jurors Side With Toyota in Lawsuit Over Crash
text: A federal jury in New York on Friday cleared the Toyota Motor Corporation in a civil lawsuit of accusations about unintended acceleration.

headline: The Census of Doom
text: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing; a lot of it can be deadly. Such was the case on the eve of the Civil War. Among all the events that touched off the great conflict — John Brown’s raid in 1859, Abraham Lincoln’s presidential victory in 1860 — there is one that has been strangely ignored by most historians. True, it was less dramatic than the others. It occurred when enumerators traveled from door to door throughout America, counting up Easterners and Westerners; Northerners and Southerners; blacks and whites; freemen and slaves. The numbers that they came up with helped to split apart the Union.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: ‘I Am In. I Am Going to College’
text: So much has happened over the past few months. My feelings throughout this crazy milestone we call the college admissions process have changed entirely so many times that it’s difficult to keep track of them all.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Finish by the Phillies Looks Familiar
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Phillies had four hits through eight innings Friday. Then they torched Brandon Lyon, Houston’s closer, for six in the ninth. To anyone who has paid any attention at all to the Phillies, neither of those things should come as a huge surprise.

headline: Butler Coaches Have a Child Entourage
text: HOUSTON – Tracy Stevens, the wife of Butler Coach Brad Stevens, summed up a second straight Final Four trip this way: “Insanity.”

headline: You’ve Passed the Interview. Now Give Us a Presentation.
text: This interview with  Chris Cunningham, co-founder and C.E.O. of Appssavvy, a social media-focused marketing firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. (The New York Times has an ownership stake in Appssavvy of less than 5 percent.)

headline: Excuses, Excuses, Excuses
text: Whenever the world’s greatest investor gets in a tight squeeze, he straps on his angel wings, readjusts his halo, and leans on his reputation for avuncular straight talk to make the problem go away.

headline: Fall on Subway Platform Severely Injures a Teenager
text: An 18-year-old high school student from the Bronx was seriously injured on Friday when he fell on a platform at the Union Square station and either struck his head on a stopped subway train or was hit in the head by one pulling in, the authorities said.

headline: Religious Radicals’ Turn to Democracy Alarms Egypt
text: NAHIA, Egypt — Abboud al-Zomor — the former intelligence officer who supplied the bullets that killed President Anwar el-Sadat and is Egypt’s most notorious newly released prisoner — waxes enthusiastic about ending the violent jihad he once led.

headline: ‘Malcolm X’
text: From Chapter 7, “As Sure as God Made Green Apples”

headline: On Eve of Redefining Malcolm X, Biographer Dies
text: For two decades, the Columbia University professor Manning Marable focused on the task he considered his life’s work: redefining the legacy of Malcolm X. Last fall he completed “Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention,” a 594-page biography described by the few scholars who have seen it as full of new and startling information and insights.

headline: To Improve, Rubio Needs to Come to N.B.A.
text: ATHENS — Outside of the N.B.A., the Euroleague is the best basketball in the world. For Ricky Rubio to lead a team of F.C. Barcelona’s caliber, at age 20, is a tremendous accomplishment. But he may have learned all he can by playing professionally in Spain, and if basketball is his first priority, it’s time to come to the N.B.A.

headline: Bonds Trial Damages a Family’s Ties
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Until Thursday, Barry Bonds’s mother, Pat, had shown little emotion during her son’s perjury trial in United States District Court.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Weirder
text: Donald Trump has run faux campaigns for president before, flirting with the Democrats and independents. This time, he’s playing a conservative Republican. By 2016, he’ll probably be talking about his affinity for the Alaskan Independence Party or the Whigs.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Budget
text: New York’s lawmakers passed a $132.5 billion budget before the April 1 deadline, a rare event. That is, on the whole, a political win for Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who cut $10 billion out of it.

headline: A New Tune for Egypt's Radical Muslims
text: Egypt's fundamentalist Muslims are preaching at universities, advertising on streets, and politicizing in five-star hotels. Their goal: to influence the Muslim content in Egypt's new constitution.

headline: Disney Said to Have Cleared Hurdle for Shanghai Park
text: It appears that the Walt Disney Company has cleared the final hurdle in its decades-long bid to build a theme park on the Chinese mainland.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 1, 2011

headline: Coaches Calhoun and Calipari Share a Genuine Dislike
text: HOUSTON — The contentious relationship between Connecticut’s Jim Calhoun and Kentucky’s John Calipari is perhaps the longest and most entertaining coaching feud in college basketball. It started so long ago that Calipari has held five jobs since.

headline: Girl, 11, Sues the Police, Claiming She Was Handcuffed
text: An 11-year-old Bronx girl has sued New York City, claiming that police officers overreacted last spring, handcuffing her after a fight with a third-grade classmate and denying her mother’s request to be present when they interviewed her.

headline: Salafi Movement Seeks a New Role in a New Egypt
text: Salafism, a radical Islamic movement in Egypt, attempts to gain a foothold in the burgeoning democracy that has emerged in the wake of former President Hosni Mubarak’s abdication.

headline: Paterson Teacher Suspended Over a Post on Facebook
text: A first-grade teacher in Paterson, N.J., was suspended on Thursday after she posted on her Facebook page that she felt like a warden overseeing future criminals, district officials said.

headline: Decades After Ban, Columbia Opens Door to R.O.T.C. Return
text: More than four decades after Columbia University, the heart of the Vietnam-era student movement, banned R.O.T.C. from campus in a moment of 1960s antimilitary rage, the University Senate voted overwhelmingly on Friday to support efforts to bring the group back.

headline: The Long Chill, by the Numbers
text: New Yorkers looked out the window with gritted teeth on Friday and endured another dreary day in a year that has seen plenty of them. The gloom was a sorry excuse for a date as promising as April 1, a flubbed herald for spring weather that seems as if it will never come. April Fool’s Day, right?

headline: Nassau Bus Riders May Get Reprieve on Service Cuts
text: State officials announced an agreement on Friday that could delay cuts to the Long Island Bus service in Nassau County that would have meant the end of trips for 16,000 of 100,000 riders.

headline: Air Traffic System Update Encountered Turbulence
text: Imagine an air traffic system where planes would no longer have to wait in long rush-hour lines before taking off, or have to circle the skies before landing. In this world, planes would be able to fly more direct routes and land along smoother glide paths.

headline: The Truth About American Muslims
text: At the Justice Department, it’s called the post-Sept. 11 backlash — the steady stream of more than 800 cases of violence and discrimination suffered by American Muslims at the hands of know-nothing abusers. These continuing hate crimes were laid bare at a valuable but barely noticed Senate hearing last week that provided welcome contrast to Representative Peter King’s airing of his xenophobic allegation that the Muslim-American community has been radicalized.

headline: Bloggingheads: Libya Now, Syria Next?
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Matt Welch of Reason debate whether Libya opens the gates for further military interventions.

headline: Mission Accomplished, Nonprofits Go Out of Business
text: A few nonprofit groups have recently announced plans to wind down, not over financial problems but because their missions are nearly finished.

headline: By His Own Reckoning, One Man Made Libya a French Cause
text: PARIS

headline: An Uncertain Future for a Mets Fixture
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — In 2003, Jose Reyes made his major league debut a day before his 20th birthday, playing shortstop in an interleague game in Arlington, Tex., for Art Howe, then the Mets manager. Nearly a decade later, Reyes is entering his eighth full season in New York. He has appeared in 924 games as a Met, is the senior member of the team in terms of service time and will now be playing for his fourth manager and general manager.

headline: More Than 50 Years of the Final Four
text: Correction Appended | Rich Clarkson has been a pivotal figure in photojournalism for the last half-century. While he was the director of photography at The Topeka Capital-Journal in Kansas, his staff of photographers — which included Brian Lanker, Jim Richardson and David Alan Harvey — produced groundbreaking news and documentary photography. He was also assistant managing editor for graphics of The Denver Post and director of photography of The National Geographic Society.

headline: Saturday: Ways of Charles de Gaulle
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I just don’t understand some people. If someone you know happens to be a practicing physician, wouldn’t you think that the last  thing they’d encourage you to consume is a crunchy, sticky treat? And yet, that’s just what Mark Diehl does today. Shame on you, Dr. Diehl. And you call yourself a dentist.

headline: Envoy Decides to Represent Nicaragua, not Libya
text: UNITED NATIONS — A former Nicaraguan foreign minister who had been appointed by Libya to be its envoy to the United Nations has changed his plans and will represent Nicaragua instead at the international body, diplomats said Friday.

headline: More Physicians Say No to Endless Workdays
text: HONESDALE, Pa. — Even as a girl, Dr. Kate Dewar seemed destined to inherit the small-town medical practice of her grandfather and father. At 4, she could explain how to insert a pulmonary catheter. At 12, she could suture a gash. And when she entered medical school, she and her father talked eagerly about practicing together.

headline: U.S. Starts Inquiry in Miami Police Shootings
text: MIAMI — The Justice Department has opened an inquiry into seven fatal shootings of suspects by Miami police officers since last July, according to a letter sent to a Miami congresswoman.

headline: It Only Looks Dangerous
text: MIXED martial arts is one of the fastest-growing sports in America. Yet for years the New York State Legislature has refused to sanction M.M.A. — making New York one of the last states holding out against the sport’s expansion. (Connecticut is a holdout, too.) After helping to block a clause in last year’s budget that would have legalized M.M.A., Bob Reilly, a state assemblyman, called it “a violent sport not worthy of our society.”

headline: Georgia: U.N. Court Rejects Claim of Ethnic Cleansing by Russia
text: The International Court of Justice on Friday rejected a claim by the former Soviet republic of Georgia accusing Russia of ethnic cleansing in two rebel enclaves. The court, the judicial arm of the United Nations, ruled that it had no jurisdiction to decide the case, but made no decision on the merits of the accusation. In a statement on its Web site, the court said Georgia violated procedure by failing to hold direct talks with Russia over the dispute before going to court. Georgia filed the complaint in the midst of its war with Russia in August 2008, accusing Moscow of complicity in the forceful expulsion of ethnic Georgians from Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Both sides leveled accusations of ethnic cleansing during the war, though there has been no independent legal confirmation that such crimes occurred.

headline: Satellite Subscribers Are Facing Loss of Mets’ and Yankees’ Programming
text: The Mets’ and Yankees’ networks are in parallel battles with satellite operators.

headline: Salvation Army Accuses Bank of Mismanaging Its Assets
text: The southern division of the Salvation Army filed suit against the Bank of New York Mellon on Friday for almost $22 million, contending that the bank had “grossly mismanaged” assets belonging to the charity by investing them in mortgage-backed securities and other risky investments.

headline: Cuts Leave Patients With Medicaid Cards, but No Specialist to See
text: LAFAYETTE, La. — Eight-year-old Draven Smith was expelled from school last year for disruptive behavior, and he is being expelled again this year. But his mother and his pediatrician cannot find a mental health specialist to treat him because he is on Medicaid, and the program, which provides health coverage for the poor, pays doctors so little that many refuse to take its patients.

headline: Arizona Asks to Set Fines for Health Risks
text: PHOENIX — Arizona’s Medicaid program, criticized last year when it halted some organ transplants to save money, has come up with another cost-saving measure that has people talking.

headline: In Egypt’s Democracy, Room for Islam
text: Cairo

headline: 2 More States Turn Over a Drug Used in Executions
text: Kentucky and Tennessee turned over their supplies of a drug used in executions to the federal authorities on Friday, weeks after Georgia’s supply was seized because of questions about how it had been imported.

headline: Vatican: Visitors Must Declare Cash
text: The Vatican put a new rule into effect on Friday requiring that anyone bringing 10,000 euros (about $14,000) or more into Vatican City declare it to Vatican authorities. The rule is part of new anti-money-laundering regulations aimed at bringing the Vatican in line with international standards on financial transparency and helping it shed its image as a tax shelter. Italian authorities are investigating the Vatican Bank for money laundering. The Vatican has denied wrongdoing.

headline: In Opener, Remade Mets Are Hardly a Hit
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — After an off-season of turmoil and transition that has provided a backdrop of uncertainty and concern, the Mets opened their 50th campaign against the dim expectations of a skeptical baseball world.

headline: Disagreements Persist on Plan to Avert Government Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress remained at loggerheads Friday over a plan to avert a government shutdown, with House Republicans digging in behind a bill that would make it the law of the land to cut $61 billion from current spending, despite the fact that the Senate has already rejected that idea.

headline: Don Hill, Nightclub Owner and Fixture of SoHo Scene, Is Dead
text: Don Hill, a music promoter whose club Don Hill’s, a stalwart of SoHo’s vibrant music scene, has brought together punks, drag queens and debutantes in the name of rock ’n’ roll for almost two decades, died on Thursday in Manhattan.

headline: Rangers Among 4 Teams Scrambling for the Playoffs
text: Only days ago the Rangers seemed a sure bet to make the N.H.L. playoffs, but now, in the next to last weekend of the regular season, it is anyone’s guess where they will end up.

headline: What Happened to ‘Zero Tolerance’?
text: A meeting of the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops is scheduled for June. It needs to repair the gaping holes uncovered in their “zero tolerance” mandate for priests suspected of sexually abusing children.

headline: What Does New York Smell Like to You?
text: New York smells like many things, and some of them are good: freshly baked bagels, a beer and a dog at Yankee Stadium, the salt air that blows in on a summer morning.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: TimesCast | Syria Continues Clampdown
text: The Syrian government condemns social media in an effort to quell dissent.

headline: TimesCast | Yemen's Dueling Protests
text: Pro- and anti-government factions divide Yemen's capital with competing protests.

headline: TimesCast | U.N. Workers Killed
text: April 1, 2011 - At least 12 people were killed after an angry mob demanding retribution for the burning of a Koran in Florida overran a United Nations compound in Mazar-i-Sharif.

headline: Red Bulls Acquire Veteran Midfielder
text: The Red Bulls acquired the veteran playmaking midfielder Dwayne De Rosario, 32, from Toronto F.C. for midfielder Tony Tchani, 21, defender Danleigh Borman, 26, and a 2012 draft choice. De Rosario, who is expected to be available or Saturday’s game against the Houston Dynamo, scored 15 of Toronto’s 33 goals last season.

headline: Three Games to Watch on Saturday
text: League play returns across Europe and M.L.S. teams return to full strength this weekend after a break for friendlies and Euro 2012 qualifiers. Several of the games have long-range title implications.

headline: Japan Struggles to Plug Leak as Radioactive Water Seeps Into the Sea
text: TOKYO — Highly radioactive water is leaking directly into the sea from a damaged pit near a crippled reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, Japanese safety officials said Saturday. The leak was the latest setback in the increasingly difficult bid to regain control of the plant.

headline: Protests Over Koran Burning Reach Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Violent protests over the burning of a Koran in Florida flared Saturday for a second straight day, with young men rampaging through the streets of this southern capital city, flying Taliban flags and wielding sticks.

headline: The Weekend Word: Spending
text: Today’s Times

headline: After ‘Much Shouting, Apologizing for the Shouting, Then Shouting Again,’ a Decision
text: About a year ago, there was a girl in my Spanish class who was a foreign exchange student from Santiago, Chile. She gave a brief PowerPoint presentation about her life back home, replete with pictures of mountain ranges and colonial architecture. During the Q. &A. session, one student asked, “How much is a year of college tuition there?”

headline: YES and DirecTV Extend Deadline
text: The YES Network extended the deadline to make a new deal with DirecTV until Thursday, giving Yankee fans who subscribe to the satellite service a reprieve.

headline: As Houston Hosts Final Four, New Orleans Gets Ready
text: As the college basketball world descends upon Houston this week for the men’s Final Four, preparations are under way for the 2012 edition in New Orleans. Next year will be the city’s first time hosting the event since 2003, which also means it will be the first time since Hurricane Katrina struck in 2005. The city has hosted major sporting events since Katrina — including the N.B.A. All-Star game in 2008 and N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games in 2007, 2010 and 2011 — but is just now getting back into the Final Four (and Super Bowl) rotation.

headline: More on 1921
text: In an earlier post, I noted that Warren Harding has become an unlikely hero of the right, with claims that his hands-off response to the 1920-21 recession was the right role model for our times. As I noted, even a quick look at the actual facts shows that 1920-21 bears no resemblance to 2008-?, and instead looks like 1981-82: a recession was brought on by tight monetary policy aimed at limiting inflation, and was followed by a rapid recovery when monetary policy was relaxed.

headline: The Pain Caucus of 1937
text: My friend and colleague Irwin Collier, of the Free University of Berlin, sends me a snippet from the Harvard Crimson, in 1937:

headline: Lollapalooza in Chile, a Different Chi-Town
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A franchise expands to an unlikely spot this weekend as Lollapalooza, the giant rock festival that has become an annual event in Chicago, opens a new front here in the capital of Chile.

headline: Former Steeler Starts Over as a Women’s Coach
text: The football players huddled on the sideline in the fading sunlight. Several looked out from under silver helmets at their 6-foot-3, 310-pound coach, Darnell Stapleton, in a gray sweatshirt with “Pittsburgh Steelers” emblazoned on the front.

headline: Keeping Score: The Traits of a Winning Team
text: In our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method,” we analyzed the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, to identify championship characteristics. Based on that research, we are again focusing on the factors that might help predict the winner of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. Last year’s analysis correctly predicted that Duke would win the championship, and that Butler would be a threat to Michigan State in the semifinals.

headline: Keeping Score: Statistic Combines Physics and Luck
text: Perhaps no aspect of baseball has received more statistical scrutiny over the last decade than pitchers’ control over the outcomes of balls in play. Ever since a paralegal named Voros McCracken posted a theory on the Internet in 1999 that pitchers could exert influence only on their strikeouts, walks and home runs allowed — leaving everything else up to fielders and luck — researchers have pored over a century’s worth of data on batting averages on balls in play. It turns out that McCracken and his detractors were partly right: although some pitchers are in fact more hittable than others, figuring out which ones they are while they are active is exceedingly hard.

headline: The Bank Run We Knew So Little About
text: IN August 2007, as world financial markets were seizing up, domestic and foreign banks began lining up for cash from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Gauging the Pain of the Middle Class
text: LIKE everyone else, government officials want to look good. That often leads them to enact policies that promote favorable movements in the indexes by which they are judged. But when those indexes are imperfect, bad choices often result. And that’s nowhere more evident than in economic policy.

headline: Jeff Banister: A Pirate Once, and a Pirate Still
text: Jeff Banister did not receive much of a signing bonus when the Pittsburgh Pirates drafted him in the 25th round in 1986. But the words of encouragement from the scout who signed him, Buzzy Keller, formed the basis of an unbroken relationship between an organization and a grinder.

headline: In Nascar, Paul Menard Is the Surprise of 2011
text: MARTINSVILLE, Va. — Paul Menard may be the only Nascar driver with a Facebook page devoted to his facial hair.

headline: On New Path, Leading to Frozen Four
text: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — Important conversations always take place at the kitchen table at the Frattin house in Edmonton, Alberta. The one Matt Frattin had with his parents in August 2009, when he was supposed to be preparing to play hockey at the University of North Dakota, could not have been more difficult.

headline: In New York, E-Waste Recycling Law Takes Effect
text: A state law took effect on Friday requiring electronics manufacturers to make it free and convenient for New York residents to recycle their old or broken computers, television sets and gadgets. Although the widespread efforts will begin right away, it may take a while for that convenience to kick in.

headline: Long Path to Final Four for UConn’s Okwandu
text: HOUSTON — As recently as four years ago, Charles Okwandu knew goaltending only as it related to his favorite sport, soccer, and his regular position, goalkeeper. Yet on Saturday, when Connecticut played Kentucky in the Final Four, Okwandu was expected to tend the Huskies’ goal as a defensive stalwart, a testament to Nigeria and basketball and one improbable outcome.

headline: Time Might Be Right for Derby Hopeful To Honor and Serve
text: INDIANTOWN, Fla. — It was a late Sunday morning, and the oval at Payson Park training center was deserted except for a trainer on horseback, a Hall of Fame one by the name of Bill Mott. Two of his horses came out of the far turn, the sound of their hooves drowning out the songs of redwing blackbirds. As they passed, Mott turned his pony and together they sauntered back to the barn.

headline: Who Took The Money Away?
text: Yep, my head will be talking tomorrow, on This Week.

headline: Madden Puts Concussions in New Light in His Game
text: Ever since the seriousness of concussions became apparent on a national scale, the primary message for young football players — if you get a concussion, get off the field for the rest of the day — has been one of the most difficult for youngsters to accept and execute. That reality will soon be aided by fantasy.

headline: A Quick Change in Heart Devices
text: With well-connected sales representatives and relationships with influential doctors, Biotronik, a small company, was able to become the main supplier of heart devices to one of Las Vegas’s largest hospitals — virtually overnight.

headline: Variety: A Cruising Diagramless
text: Administrivial Twitter Announcement: Wordplay now has its very own Twitter feed! Follow @nytimeswordplay for the nightly headlines and for announcements of all manner of things going on in the puzzle world.

headline: Spy Chief’s Tenure Is Extended in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government has given another one-year extension to the chief of its powerful spy organization, the Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate.

headline: When David Meets Goliath on the Hardwood
text: Houston

headline: NATO Airstrike Reportedly Kills Rebels in Libya
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — A NATO airstrike near the battlefront in eastern Libya killed 13 rebel fighters outside the pivotal port city of Brega, a rebel spokesman and wounded fighters said Saturday.

headline: Romney Explores a Run Without Saying So or Seeking the Spotlight
text: LAS VEGAS — Mitt Romney sightings have been hard to come by this year. But there he was on Saturday afternoon, riding an escalator at the Venetian hotel on the Las Vegas Strip after delivering his first public speech in a month.

headline: UConn’s Kelly Faris Has Been There Before
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Geno Auriemma loves to tease, to needle. He mocks because he must. He can be piercingly funny, drawing laughs the way nurses draw blood. But he did not bother kidding Connecticut guard Kelly Faris this season about reaching the women’s Final Four here in the city where she attended high school.

headline: After Scare, Southwest Grounds Planes
text: Southwest Airlines grounded 79 airplanes on Saturday after a piece of the fuselage on one of its Boeing 737s ripped open during a flight the day before, leaving a hole in the cabin ceiling and rapidly depressurizing the aircraft.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Disappearing Empire
text: A look at Woods’s golf course design business and its uncompleted ventures.

headline: For Tiger Woods, a Golf Course Design Business Is in the Rough
text: IN late June 2008, a week after he astonished the golf world by winning the United States Open while grimacing in pain on a torn left knee, Tiger Woods traveled to a craggy chunk of land on the Baja Peninsula in Mexico. It was a lunarlike landscape of dirt and rock, with an inactive volcano in the background. For several hours, he hobbled over the terrain, discussing with developers his vision for the golf course he would build there, while waves from the Pacific crashed onto the shoreline below. His knee, said one companion, rattled like tools in a tool box.

headline: Hundreds Killed in Ivory Coast Town as Conflict Intensifies
text: DAKAR, Senegal — As rebels swept across Ivory Coast in a rapid advance last week to oust the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hundreds of people were killed in a single town, the United Nations and aid groups said Saturday, in the worst episode of violence during the four-month political crisis that has plunged the country back into civil war.

headline: Celebrities Set the Record Straight
text: Stephen Fry is not an anti-Catholic bigot, the actor will have you know. And, Bianca Jagger insists, Billy Joel’s song “Big Shot” is not based on a bad date with her. Those and more celebrity protestations are the stock in trade of iCorrect, a new image-protecting Web site founded by Sir David Tang, a businessman and socialite in London. It charges $1,000 a year to post unlimited corrections, provided the subscriber submits proof of identity. Here are some of the corrections, excerpted. —TOM KUNTZ

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: A Lethal Sneeze
text: Humans are used to worrying that other species, like gorillas, might transmit their diseases to us. But should we be worried that we are transmitting our diseases to gorillas?

headline: Back Then: 2001
text: In August 2001, The Times’s Murray Chass recalled a conversation he had with Barry Bonds during spring training in 2000 about the explosion in home runs. Bonds is now on trial in federal court, accused of lying about using performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: V.C.U.’s Way to Keep Assistants in the Pipeline
text: With Virginia Commonwealth’s run to the Final Four, Coach Shaka Smart has been the smiling face of the midmajor program and its improbable journey, a celebrity made over two upset-filled weekends in March.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Darren Aronofsky, the director of the ballet movie “Black Swan,” last week rose to the defense of the film’s star, Natalie Portman, who stood accused by her body double, the ballerina Sarah Lane, of not having performed anything close to 85 percent of the dance sequences, as claimed by Ms. Portman’s fiancé, the choreographer Benjamin Millepied.

headline: Even More on 1921
text: A new paper by Daniel Kuehn. From the conclusion:

headline: Why Red Flags Can Go Unnoticed
text: IN the wake of recent disasters — from nuclear reactor failures to oil spills to the collapse of the subprime mortgage market — we have focused on which people and institutions might be to blame. How, we ask in hindsight, could people and institutions have failed to foresee clear signs of trouble — even in the face of warnings?

headline: Microsoft + Nokia = a Challenge for Apple
text: IPHONES and Android phones seem to be everywhere I look in Silicon Valley. The future is obvious, isn’t it? IPhone, Android and no one else. They will form an exclusive duo in smartphones, just as Windows and Mac have in personal computers.

headline: When the Data Struts Its Stuff
text: IN an uncharted world of boundless data, information designers are our new navigators.

headline: Doctors Who Want a Life
text: For years, medicine has been dominated by fiercely independent doctors who owned their practices, worked night and day, had comfortable incomes and rarely saw their families. But today, as Gardiner Harris writes, many new doctors are seeking a better way to balance the demands of work and family:

headline: Strike Kills Gaza Fighters, Spurring Hamas Warning
text: GAZA — Thousands of Palestinians attended the funerals on Saturday of three senior Hamas militants killed by Israel in an overnight airstrike in southern Gaza, and Hamas leaders warned that Israel would bear the consequences.

headline: A Club for the Women Atop the Ladder
text: ON the site of a 17th-century monastery in Cartagena, Colombia, a sort of Illuminati of the business and political worlds  gathered in February for their annual winter rites.

headline: Line Dancing With the Markets
text: NO one knows which way the world’s financial markets will move on any given day. No one can know.

headline: Don’t Let Bureaucracy Ruin Your Day
text: ALMOST every worker has been frustrated by bureaucratic obstacles at one time or another. Even with the best of intentions, organizations sometimes snag their employees in impossible tangles of rules and regulations, slowing innovation and productivity. These filter down to customers and suppliers, who run into dead ends as they try to navigate the maze.

headline: At Women’s Masters, Plunge in Poppie’s Pond Is Victory Lap
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The golfers stood on the 18th green of the Dinah Shore Tournament Course and plotted how to land in the water hazard.

headline: Mets’ Dickey Has Visions of Hurling Knuckleballs From on High
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — During the baseball season, R. A. Dickey’s job with the Mets requires ascending a hill only 10 ½ inches high, a modest summit from which he surveys the field and throws his knuckleball to batters.

headline: Where ‘Jasmine’ Means Tea, Not a Revolt
text: BEIJING — Over the nearly four decades since President Richard M. Nixon established diplomatic ties with Red China, American politicians have clung to the idea that the growing ranks of Chinese entrepreneurs and college-educated strivers would one day find electoral democracy irresistible. But a stroll through one of the capital’s upscale malls quickly demolishes such idealistic notions — and instead makes you wonder whether China’s autocrats have struck on a flexible model of long-lasting rule.

headline: Woods Is Vulnerable on the Course, Too
text: After each of Tiger Woods’s five tedious tournaments leading to this week’s Masters, he sounded like a recording when he spoke about how well he was progressing with his new golf swing. But his scores contradicted him.

headline: Colorless Food? We Blanch
text: WASHINGTON — Without the artificial coloring FD&C Yellow No. 6, Cheetos Crunchy Cheese Flavored Snacks would look like the shriveled larvae of a large insect. Not surprisingly, in taste tests, people derived little pleasure from eating them.

headline: In Search of the First Jump Shot
text: John Miller Cooper, who died last year at 98, once described his historic basketball innovation this way: “My feet left the hardcourt surface, and it felt good. It was free and natural, and I knew I had discovered something.”

headline: Bill White, Away From the Rat Race, Is Writing Bluntly About It
text: At the sight of Bill White, you are tempted to blurt out “Hey White!” as Phil Rizzuto, his broadcast partner with the Yankees, might have at seeing his old friend emerge from a thick, self-created cocoon. He is 77, powerful looking and back in the limelight after a long hiatus with an autobiography whose very title calls attention to itself: “Uppity.”

headline: Battling H.I.V. in Lesotho
text: Dr. Paul Young, an American pediatric H.I.V. specialist, is highly prized in a country with the world's third highest rate of H.I.V. infection.

headline: Doctors Go Far Afield to Battle Epidemics
text: MASHAI, Lesotho — At a clinic in the mountains, reached only by crossing a churning river in a rowboat, Dr. Paul Young, a pediatrician raised in the housing projects of Savannah, Ga., soothed a fussy baby. She stared at him, fascinated, as he made soft popping sounds with his lips and listened to her heart through a stethoscope.

headline: Design Well Within Reach
text: Every economic slump imprints itself on interior design, each in its own way. Seventy years ago, for instance, a generation of Americans responded to the Great Depression by adopting a functional European design style known as modernism. They bought Alvar Aalto chairs and Russel Wright dinnerware, or, more likely, low-cost alternatives that made their way into the mainstream. Either way, modernism expressed the frugal spirit of the day.

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Disaster Severs Town’s Economic Lifeline, Setting Evacuees Adrift
text: KAZO, Japan — Along with 1,300 other evacuees from a town two miles from Japan’s damaged nuclear plants, Kunikazu Takahashi and his elderly mother are crowded into an abandoned high school here, sleeping on donated tatami mats as they ask themselves whether it will ever be safe to return.

headline: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program, and Tries F1 Car
text: Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

headline: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program, and Tries F1 Car
text: Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

headline: When a Lawsuit Is Too Big
text: WASHINGTON — Can a class-action lawsuit be too sprawling to deliver old-fashioned justice?

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Wide-Open Chase for the Hart Trophy
text: No N.H.L. award is more prestigious than the Hart Trophy for the player judged most valuable to his team. But for the first time in memory, there are no clear-cut favorites for the honor. That was not the case earlier this season.

headline: Assessing the Radiation Danger, Near and Far
text: Assessments of the radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant by the Japanese authorities, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others.

headline: The RSA Hack: How They Did It
text: The hack last month at RSA Security has been shrouded in mystery.

headline: The Larger Game in the Middle East: Iran
text: WASHINGTON   —  On a Tuesday afternoon in mid-March in the White House Situation Room, as President Obama heard the arguments of his security advisers about the pros and cons of using military force in Libya, the conversation soon veered into the impact in a far more strategically vital place: Iran.

headline: With Bethany Hamilton
text: Bethany Hamilton was 13 when she was attacked by a 14-foot tiger shark while surfing off Kauai in Hawaii, on Oct. 31, 2003. She is the subject of a new movie, “Soul Surfer,” which opens nationwide on Friday. Hamilton, who has a cameo in the film, lost her left arm in the attack but returned to competitive surfing three months later. In 2005, she won her first national title in the 18-and-under division of the National Scholastic Surfing Association championships. Hamilton, who is now 21, lives in Kauai and surfs professionally. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI

headline: Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, Is Dead at 92
text: Stanley Bogdan, a maker of fly fishing reels so coveted that anglers were willing to spend years on a waiting list to buy them and then to pay far more than they would have for reels of only ordinary excellence, died March 27 in Nashua, N.H. He was 92 and a lifetime Nashua resident.

headline: Why Walk When You Can Stroll?
text: THE stroller is up on the shelf. When we moved to New York from Silver Spring, Md., not quite a year ago, I thought it would stay there. New York is a walking city and we had found an apartment four blocks from our son’s preschool. He was turning 3. The stroller — infernal, clunky, annoying thing — would go into semi-retirement in the coat closet.

headline: From Afar, a Vivid Picture of Japan Crisis
text: For the clearest picture of what is happening at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, talk to scientists thousands of miles away.

headline: Reader Comments on My Libya Column
text: My Sunday column argues that there are indeed lots of uncertainties and legitimate criticisms of President Obama’s operation in Libya — but weighed against it are the many lives that it has saved, and the prospect that it will ultimately remove Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. On balance, I think the intervention was not only essential but maybe a step toward the emergence of a bit more of an international conscience, the growth of the doctrine of the “responsibility to protect.” As for the argument that we’re inconsistent in our interventions: of course we’re inconsistent, but would you rather we consistently save no one?

headline: No to a New Tar Sands Pipeline
text: Later this year, the State Department will decide whether to approve construction of a 1,700-mile oil pipeline from Canada to the Texas Gulf Coast called Keystone XL. The underground 36-inch pipeline, built by TransCanada, would link the tar sands fields of northern Alberta to Texas refineries and begin operating in 2013. The department should say no.

headline: In Israel, Time for Peace Offer May Run Out
text: JERUSALEM — With revolutionary fervor sweeping the Middle East, Israel is under mounting pressure to make a far-reaching offer to the Palestinians or face a United Nations vote welcoming the State of Palestine as a member whose territory includes all of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Jordan Cameron, Fifth-Ranked Tight End
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This is the first entry in a series counting down his top five draft prospects at each position.

headline: As Busy an N.F.L. Draft as One Can Possibly Imagine
text: The N.F.L. draft is one of the most exciting events in a young player’s life. Soon, it may also become the most tiring.

headline: Sanitation Worker Is Attacked in Brooklyn
text: A city Sanitation Department worker was attacked and another was threatened after a motorist became angry when he could not pass their truck as they collected trash, the authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Cutting Out the Middleman
text: For six years, Doug Stafford was a lobbyist for the National Right to Work Committee, an anti-labor group financed by business and conservative interests. His job changed last year but his duties did not when he became the chief of staff to Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky. Mr. Paul is a chief sponsor of the National Right to Work Act, which he said would end forced unionization and “break Big Labor’s multibillion-dollar political machine forever.”

headline: Sunday Evening With Monday to Come
text: New York is a place people come to have jobs they can love. And yet a certain wistfulness always steals over Sunday evening. You can almost feel the people out on the streets — walking dogs, strolling home from dinner, running along the river — trying to make twilight last a little longer. Monday is gathering and they can feel it.

headline: What Would You Do With an Extra $70 Billion?
text: Defense Secretary Robert Gates has vowed that the days of profligacy are over and that the Pentagon will reform its bloated and often corrupt acquisition process.

headline: Is It Better to Save No One?
text: Critics from left and right are jumping all over President Obama for his Libyan intervention, arguing that we don’t have an exit plan, that he hasn’t articulated a grand strategy, that our objectives are fuzzy, that Islamists could gain strength. And those critics are all right.

headline: Mad Men and Mad Women
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Standards That Everyone Can See
text: LAST week The Times reached a strategic frontier with the full introduction of paid subscriptions for digital access to its content. Perhaps less visibly, but also importantly, the newsroom has moved toward a remarkable integration of its print and electronic operations. The organization has evolved to a new state, one that lives online and expects to be paid for it.

headline: Mother Nature’s Melting Pot
text: THE anti-immigrant sentiment sweeping the country, from draconian laws in Arizona to armed militias along the Mexican border, has taken many Americans by surprise. It shouldn’t — nativism runs deep in the United States. Just ask our non-native animals and plants: they too are commonly labeled as aliens, even though they also provide significant benefits to their new home.

headline: Romney to Obama: ‘Why Didn’t You Call Me?’
text: LAS VEGAS — President Obama frequently showers sardonic praise on Mitt Romney for the health care law he signed in Massachusetts, calling it a model for the national plan. On Saturday, Mr. Romney offered a new retort, saying: “If that’s the case, why didn’t you call me?”

headline: An Iowa Stop in a Broad Effort to Revitalize the Religious Right
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Hundreds of conservative pastors in Iowa received the enticing invitation. Signed by Mike Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor and 2008 presidential contender, it invited the pastors and their spouses to an expenses-paid, two-day Pastors’ Policy Briefing at a Sheraton hotel.

headline: Koran-Burning Pastor Unrepentant in Face of Furor
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — His church’s membership is down to just a few of the faithful. He is basically broke. Some of his neighbors wish him ill. And his head, he said, carries a bounty.

headline: Unpaid Interns, Complicit Colleges
text: ON college campuses, the annual race for summer internships, many of them unpaid, is well under way. But instead of steering students toward the best opportunities and encouraging them to value their work, many institutions of higher learning are complicit in helping companies skirt a nebulous area of labor law.

headline: We Work Hard, but Who’s Complaining?
text: Los Angeles

headline: Shutdown Watch: Six Days Out
text: With six days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, President Obama talked with congressional leaders as staff continued to work through the weekend on a compromise that could pass next week.

headline: Teenage ‘Sexting’: What Can Be Done?
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Obama Insider, Running the Race From Afar
text: CHICAGO — For two years, Jim Messina worked 41 steps from the Oval Office, a distance he counted when he first arrived at the White House. His next assignment — in an office 700 miles from President Obama — will test whether proximity is the key to power.

headline: Crackdown on Protesters Upsets Lives in Belarus
text: MINSK, Belarus — In more than 16 years in power, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the authoritarian president of this former Soviet republic, has often deployed the courts to persecute opponents, locking them away after the kind of show trials typical of the Communist era.

headline: Want to Increase Voting? Discounts Seem to Work
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Airstrike Reportedly Kills Rebels in Libya
text: A NATO airstrike intended to thwart Moammar Gadhafi’s forces killed 13 rebel fighters in eastern Libya instead, the opposition said Saturday, but they described it as an “unfortunate accident” and stressed it did not diminish their support for the international air campaign.

headline: Obesity and National Security
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
