text: To the Editor:

headline: Illinois Workers Find That a Death Penalty Ban Abolishes Their Jobs, Too
text: The day after the death penalty was abolished in Illinois in early March, Wendi Liss received a call from one of her clients, who was facing trial for murder and the prospect of being executed if found guilty.

headline: Ballot Subtext: Budget Crisis and Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
text: Focused on winning the mayor’s office outright, Rahm Emanuel mostly steered clear of the City Council races in the Feb. 22 election. The day after he was elected mayor, he turned to the 14 wards where no candidate for alderman won a majority, necessitating runoffs on Tuesday to complete the new 50-member Council.

headline: The Warehouse Cafe
text: Port Costa is generally a quiet hamlet, found at the end of a winding rural road in northern Contra Costa County.  But on weekend nights and Sunday afternoons — especially in the summer — it loudly revives itself. Visitors seek out the Warehouse Cafe, the town’s legendary watering hole.

headline: Two Emergency System Plans Gone Off Course
text: In the wake of the 9/11 attacks, government officials across the Bay Area scrambled to develop new emergency communications systems that would enable a coordinated response in the event of a major crisis. Federal dollars were available, and it seemed like an opportune moment to upgrade key infrastructure.

headline: Sara Ruddick, Gave Due to Motherhood, Philosophically, Dies at 76
text: Sara Ruddick, whose 1989 book, “Maternal Thinking: Toward a Politics of Peace,” laid the groundwork for a feminist approach to understanding and analyzing the practices and intellectual disciplines involved in rearing children, died on March 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

headline: In a Clubby World of San Francisco Mothers, Men Needn’t Apply
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Giving Rural Iowans a Taste of Italy
text: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa — When Giovanni Romano, a native of New York, first arrived in this strongly Christian patch of rural northwest Iowa, there was a battle among the local pastors for his soul. He was a recovering heroin addict and former convict, and everyone, it seemed, wanted to save him.

headline: Sunday: Triple Bonds
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — You will need your adding skills for this one. Oliver Hill and Eliza Bagg have crammed some phrases together for our amusement.

headline: Trump for President in 2012? Maybe. Trump for Trump? Without Question.
text: Something predictable happens to the ratings of Donald J. Trump’s “Celebrity Apprentice” on NBC when he hints at running for president: They rise.

headline: Three French Players Punished for Using Technology to Cheat
text: Cheating has become more common in recent years. But a recent French case is the most sensational, and the most troubling.

headline: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program
text: From our colleagues at Formula One:Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

headline: Is De Rosario the Final Piece in the Red Bulls’ Puzzle?
text: HARRISON, N.J. — If there was ever any doubt that the Red Bulls are a now team, that notion was dispelled Friday afternoon when the club announced the acquisition of the veteran midfielder Dwayne De Rosario from Toronto.

headline: Wide Support for Democracy Activist in Vietnam
text: BANGKOK — A prominent Vietnamese legal scholar and human rights campaigner who has called for multiparty democracy was due in court on Monday in Hanoi, facing up to 12 years in prison in a case that has mobilized unusually broad public support.

headline: Rangers Profess Confidence in Ability to Score More and Clinch a Playoff Berth
text: For the final 15 minutes of an hourlong practice on Saturday, the Rangers engaged in a 3-on-2 drill. This was not a repetition of odd-man rushes, but a test of what N.H.L. coaches often refer to as “battle level.” For 30 to 45 seconds each shift, all within the offensive blue line, three forwards would work the puck deep against two teammates and the goaltender Henrik Lundqvist. The drill would end with a goal, or at least a few quality scoring opportunities.

headline: Teacher Accused of Attack Threat
text: A teacher was arrested Friday after she threatened to carry out a mass shooting at the Brooklyn high school where she worked, the police said.

headline: Cashman Says Feliciano Was ‘Abused’ by Mets
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Over the last 25 years, there has been almost nothing that the Mets have done better than the Yankees. Yet one small item cropped up after the Mets decided not to re-sign the left-handed reliever Pedro Feliciano and allowed the Yankees to do so instead.

headline: Partners in Iniquity
text: Both professional historians and the general public have long explained America’s descent into civil war as the result of the economic divergence between an industrial North and an agrarian South.

headline: Caught Between Sidewalk and Street
text: THREE cyclists from two local racing clubs, defiant and ready to take a stand, rolled into Central Park near 110th Street, and were promptly arrested. It was a summer morning in 1881, and bicycles were not permitted in the city’s vast park.

headline: Mavericks Always Feel at Home
text: The importance of playoff seeding comes down almost entirely to home-court advantage. In the case of Dirk Nowitzki and the Dallas Mavericks, that may not be a cause for concern.

headline: Yankees Explain Why Employee Flashed Signs From Stands
text: The commissioner’s office called the Yankees on Saturday to ask why an employee was flashing hand signals toward the team’s players during Thursday’s game, a violation of Major League Baseball rules.

headline: Two Young Coaches Are Study in Contrast on Sideline
text: HOUSTON — Butler’s Brad Stevens and Virginia Commonwealth’s Shaka Smart are each up-and-coming coaches. But they could not be more different in how they go about actually coaching their teams.

headline: When It Comes to Marijuana, Willie’s Punishment Seems to Vaporize
text: Joe Nick Patoski wrote this column for The Texas Tribune.

headline: Certainties of 1970s Energy Crisis Have Fallen Away
text: Unrest in the Middle East, rising oil prices and frustration with federal energy policy — for Texans of a certain age, today’s headlines must seem like déjà vu. The current situation is far less severe than the aftermath of the 1973 Arab oil embargo. But the parallels are unmistakable.

headline: Texas’ Clout in Congress Rises Along With G.O.P.
text: Last year, with Democrats controlling the United States House of Representatives, Texas’ delegation of Republicans was largely shut out of power.

headline: In Final Four Spotlight, Shadows Follow Calhoun
text: HOUSTON – As Connecticut meets Kentucky in the second national semifinal Saturday night, perhaps the most interesting character is Jim Calhoun, UConn’s somewhat polarizing coach.

headline: Tipping the Odds for a Maker of Heart Implants
text: Las Vegas is a city of few sure bets. But there are overwhelming odds on one thing — the brand of heart device that patients at a major hospital get.

headline: The Texas Shuffle: The Month Ahead in Music
text: The month ahead in music.

headline: Head of U.N. Panel Regrets Saying Israel Intentionally Killed Gazans
text: JERUSALEM — The leader of a United Nations panel that investigated Israel’s invasion of Gaza two years ago has retracted the central and most explosive assertion of its report — that Israel intentionally killed Palestinian civilians there.

headline: Carolina Tops Isles to Gain on Rangers
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — By now, Rangers fans must be furious with the Islanders for complicating their playoff hopes.

headline: Assault in Greenwich Village
text: A police handout video of an assault in Greenwich Village that is being investigated as a hate crime.

headline: José Argüelles, New Ager Focused on Time, Dies at 72
text: José Argüelles, the father of the Harmonic Convergence, the mammoth New Age event that in 1987 drew thousands of humming adherents to sites around the globe, died in the Australian bush on March 23, not much more than a year before the world, in his view, might well have ended anyway. He was 72 and lived in Ashland, Ore.

headline: Anthony Shoulders a Load Stoudemire Used to Carry
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The constant in the evolving formula that N.B.A. teams hope translates into championships — mix a superstar or two with a superstar or two — is that there remains just one basketball to shoot or share.

headline: Burnett and Teixeira Show Their Strengths Early
text: Yankees starter A. J. Burnett left one game last season after injuring his hands by slamming them against the swinging doors of the clubhouse in frustration.

headline: A Little Clarity in Europe’s Biggest Races
text: The European club season runs, well, it seems like forever, so it is still too early for the league leaders to start planning parades and renting those open-top buses.

headline: Butler Earns Second Chance
text: HOUSTON — Back in the practice gym at Hinkle Field House, during Butler’s sweaty summer pickup games, the seeds for the Bulldogs’ latest run to the national title game were planted.

headline: Atop the Leader Board, Tseng Is Helping to Fill a Void on the L.P.G.A. Tour
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Friends were coming out of the woods to root for Yani Tseng at the Kraft Nabisco Championship. There was Tseng’s mother and her mother’s friends who are visiting from Taiwan and busloads of people from nearby Beaumont, where Tseng was briefly based as a teenager.

headline: A Pioneer of Music for Children Is Still Inspiring
text: Home of the blues. Laboratory for the skyscraper. Birthplace of atomic energy. And cradle of children’s music?

headline: New Lanes in the City Elicit a Split Reaction
text: San Francisco is poised to double the number of a long-neglected entertainment asset: bowling alleys.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 3
text: With the federal government’s next brush with shutdown less than a week away, the Sunday talk shows are focused on budget negotiations, featuring interviews with the lawmakers who will play a big role in making or breaking the deal.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photographs of news and features in business.

headline: When the Cupboard Is Bare in Washington
Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Translating Your Skills
text: MY father was in the military when I was growing up. I was just a baby when we lived in Alaska, so I have no memory of the dogsled rides my family took, or of seasons without darkness. We lived in Alabama during the civil rights movement, but I was too young to appreciate the historical significance. After that we moved to Germany.

headline: A Prank on the Mets, but SNY Isn’t Laughing
text: Through two late-season collapses in 2007 and 2008 and then the last two sub-.500 seasons, the Mets have endured plenty of criticism and no little bit of mockery.

headline: Student Who Fell on Subway Platform Dies
text: An 18-year-old high school student who collapsed on a Manhattan subway platform and was struck in the head by a train died on Saturday, the police said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 2, 2011

headline: Budget Battle to Be Followed by a Bigger Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Congress has yet to settle its first budget fight of the year but is already about to move on to an even more consequential fiscal clash.

headline: Trade Pays Off Immediately for Red Bulls
text: HARRISON, N.J. — It took Dwayne De Rosario less than two minutes to impose his personality on his new team, the Red Bulls, on Saturday night.

headline: It’s Early, but Mets Show a Flair for Late Dramatics
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Two games into the season, the Mets have already provided some compelling moments, good and bad, suggesting that perhaps the next 160 games just might be worth watching, too.

headline: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: April 2
text: A look at the Final Four matchups between Butler-V.C.U. and Connecticut-Kentucky.

headline: For V.C.U., Glow Fades to a Future Uncertain
text: HOUSTON — Shaka Smart and his Virginia Commonwealth players passed a legion of newfound fans as they walked off the court Saturday night and stepped into an uncertain future.

headline: Still Running, Still Stunning
text: HOUSTON — As the final seconds ticked away, Coach Jim Calhoun stalked the sideline for Connecticut, arms folded, gum churning in his jaw. His expression never changed, even as the Huskies burst into the championship game, on Monday against Butler, even as he moved closer toward the rarest air in his profession.

headline: Efforts to Plug Japanese Reactor Leak Seem to Fail
text: TOKYO — Workers’ struggle to plug a gush of highly contaminated water from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, using sawdust, shredded newspaper and an absorbent powder, appeared to be failing early Monday as the radiation threat from the crippled plant continued to spread.

headline: Chorus of Boos at Sheen Show in Detroit
text: DETROIT — About 30 minutes after Charlie Sheen took the stage at the Fox Theater here — the first stop on his “Violent Torpedo of Truth/Defeat Is Not an Option” tour — he posted a picture of the audience on Twitter accompanied by a message that read, “The most honest city in the world honors the most honest man in the universe.”

headline: Vows: Yoomi and Ben
text: Yoomi and Ben met at law school and seemed to hit it off, but it wasn't until after their bar exam when they traveled to South America together that they realized they had that special something.

headline: Spain’s Prime Minister Will Not Seek Third Term
text: Spain’s prime minister, José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, announced Saturday that he would not seek a third term in office, putting an end to months of speculation about his political future amid an economic downturn that had considerably undermined his chances of winning re-election.

headline: Lollapalooza Chile: All About the Details
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Twenty years after he started Lollapalooza, and six years after he settled it in Chicago each summer, Perry Farrell is an old hand at overseeing festivals. Lollapalooza Chile started with a professional sheen on Saturday, the latest festival to feature multiple stages, prominent sponsorships, environmental gestures, do-gooder information booths and a big crowd. A hint of the attention to detail: on entering, it’s hard to avoid being handed a sample cup of a sponsor’s cola. About 20 steps later, when most people have had their drink, smiling people appear with big plastic bags to collect the little cups for recycling.

headline: Teaching Gardeners About Birds (as in Chickens) and Bees (as in Hives)
text: Learning how to grow tomatoes in New York and can them is one thing. Finding out the best way to entertain a coop of chickens or when best to oust a queen bee from an urban hive falls into an entirely different realm of community gardening.

headline: At Berlin Festival, Music Hits the Big Screen
text: If you hear the strains of various musical genres at cinemas around Berlin, don’t be surprised. The annual In-Edit International Music Documentary Festival will take place from April 5 to 10 at Kreuzberg’s Moviemento (Kottbusser Damm 22; 49-30-692-4785; www.moviemento.de) and Mitte’s .HBC (Karl-Liebknecht-Strasse 9; 49-30-24-34-29-20; www.hbc-berlin.de). From electro to flamenco, an eclectic range of musical genres are represented in the lineup of 33 documentaries that feature artists like the White Stripes, Johnny Cash, Feist and Brian Eno.

headline: There Are Pitch Invasions, and Then There Are Pitch Invasions
text: The Egyptian powerhouse Zamalek was leading Club Africain of Tunisia, 2-1, on Saturday in their African Champions League match in Cairo when Zamalek appeared to score the goal it needed to advance three minutes into injury time.

headline: 8 Secrets to Perfect Pet Photos
text: Pets have such charm—why is it so few photos of them show it? In most snapshots, pets look stiff, posed and vaguely uncomfortable. Just — come to think of it — like most people in posed shots.

headline: The Asymmetrical Online War
text: In 1975, John Brunner wrote a science fiction novel, “The Shockwave Rider,” about a lone programmer who creates a computer worm that exposes a repressive regime’s secrets and ultimately undermines a tyrannical government.

headline: For New York’s Well-to-Do, What to Do With Tax Windfall?
text: Some of the New Yorkers who stand to benefit most from Albany’s decision to kill the temporary income tax surcharge on the state’s high earners — the so-called millionaires’ tax — do not feel like millionaires.

headline: 2 Qaddafi Sons Are Said to Offer Plan to Push Father Out
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — At least two sons of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are proposing a resolution to the Libyan conflict that would entail pushing their father aside to make way for a transition to a constitutional democracy under the direction of his son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a diplomat and a Libyan official briefed on the plan said Sunday.

headline: Cricket Victory Brings Relief From Scandal in India
text: MUMBAI, India — India has had plenty of downbeat news in recent months: a litany of tawdry scandals, an unexpected sharp decline in foreign investment, the ineffectiveness of a bickering Parliament. A nation once brimming with confidence and global aspirations has seemed to stumble.

headline: William Young, Who Helped U.S. Organize Secret War in Laos, Is Dead at 76
text: CHIANG MAI, Thailand — William Young, a missionary’s son who mixed evangelical zeal with covert missions for the C.I.A. in Southeast Asia and who helped organize the “secret war “ in Laos for the United States during the Vietnam War, died on Friday at his home here in northern Thailand. He was 76.

headline: Schott Op-Chart: Pluviocabulary
text: “April showers bring forth May flowers” – that much is uncontested. But the variety of wet weather with which spring confronts us would test even an Eskimo’s powers of description. To aid the discussion of precipitation, we present some of pluvial terms to be found in the inestimable “Oxford English Dictionary.” Click here for the Pluviocabulary.

headline: For Qatar, Libyan Intervention May Be a Turning Point
text: DOHA, Qatar — Friendly to Iran even as it serves as a base for the American military, Qatar has long had one of the most creative foreign policies in this unstable region. But now, by sending its tiny air force to fly missions over Libya and granting other critical aid to the Libyan rebels in their fight for freedom and democracy, this very rich Persian Gulf emirate is playing a more ambitious and potentially more risky role.

headline: French in Control of Ivory Coast Airport
text: PARIS — French forces in coordination with the United Nations took over the Ivory Coast’s primary airport in the main city of Abidjan on Sunday so that planes could land and foreigners could be evacuated as fighting between the forces of rival presidents showed no sign of abating.

headline: Dino Anagnost, Who Led Little Orchestra Society, Dies at 67
text: Dino Anagnost, the longtime conductor of the Little Orchestra Society, the highly regarded New York chamber orchestra that presents concerts for children and adults, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: In the Mountains of Patagonia, a Harbinger of a Rising Ocean
text: Land ice is melting virtually everywhere in the world, one of the central pieces of evidence that the earth is warming. Scientists have long known that this synchronized ice melt seemed to be picking up speed in many places, but detailed measurements for individual glaciers and ice fields have been hard to come by.

headline: Ask About Alzheimer’s Disease
text: The two largest studies ever of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of five new genes that increase risk of the disease, Gina Kolata reports in today’s New York Times. There are now 10 genes that are known to increase the risk of Alzheimer’s in old age.

headline: Vast Gene Study Yields Insights on Alzheimer’s
text: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of no fewer than five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why the disease strikes and how it progresses.

headline: Afghans Protest Koran Burning for Third Day
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Afghan protests over the burning of a Koran in Florida continued Sunday for a third day, with three more people killed here.

headline: In Kazakhstan, President Appears to Have Won Easily
text: SEMEY, Kazakhstan — This spring’s hasty campaign season in Kazakhstan has sometimes felt like a pep rally for Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the steelworker-turned-Communist-Party-boss who has ruled the country since 1989. That impression was heightened on Sunday when one of the president’s three challengers acknowledged that he, too, had voted for Mr. Nazarbayev.

headline: Israel Grapples With Retraction on U.N. Report
text: JERUSALEM — Israel grappled on Sunday with whether a retraction by a United Nations investigator regarding its actions in the Gaza war two years ago could be used to rehabilitate its tarnished international image or as pre-emptive defense in future military actions against armed groups.

headline: Born of Pirate Radio, Seeking a Spot on British Dial
text: Blair Munyan, a former United States Navy officer who served aboard a submarine off the coast of England in 1965, was reading an article about abandoned sea forts recently when he was flooded with memories of Radio Caroline, the offshore pirate radio movement known for breaking the British government’s stranglehold on radio.

headline: China Takes Dissident Artist Into Custody
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities on Sunday detained Ai Weiwei, a high-profile artist and stubborn government critic, as he tried to board a plane for Hong Kong, his friends and associates said. Mr. Ai’s wife, his nephew and a number of his employees were also taken into custody during a raid on his studio on the outskirts of the capital.

headline: BP Seeks to Resume Drilling in Gulf of Mexico
text: LONDON — BP has asked United States regulators for permission to resume drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, two company officials said on Sunday, creating a delicate situation for the Obama administration as it seeks to balance safety concerns with a desire to increase domestic oil production.

headline: Upsets Attest to Vitality in Women’s Game
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Lance Kendricks, Fourth-Ranked Tight End
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at each position.

headline: Diminished Individualism Watch
text: A few weeks back I commented on a George Will column in which he said that

headline: Summer Concert Series May Find New Home
text: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, may move one of his long-running concert series this summer because of opposition over the shows’ noise and a proposal for a huge new amphitheater there.

headline: Belligerent and Boozy, and That’s Just the Audience
text: DETROIT — Charlie Sheen chose Detroit as the starting point for his “My Violent Torpedo of Truth/Defeat Is Not an Option” live performance tour. Before his show at the Fox Theater here on Saturday night you could speculate on a metaphorical link between the city and the star: phoenix rising from the ashes or shattered wreck of former glory. Either one might have seemed appropriate.

headline: Chaos and Confusion
text: March 30 – April 5, 1861

headline: Proceeding Nacho Duato-Style, Like Fish Darting Through Water
text: The choreographer Nacho Duato ran the Compañía Nacional de Danza in Spain and its associated junior troupe, CND2, for 20 years until — in a storm of recriminations with the Spanish government —  he left last year. Unsurprisingly, the companies won’t retain the extensive repertory he created for them. At the Skirball Center on Friday night CND2 presented three pieces by Mr. Duato on a program that is part of a final tour of his work.

headline: For Healing, Not Words but Bodies in Motion
text: “Fall and Recover,” a production by the Irish contemporary choreographer John Scott, is named after Doris Humphrey’s concept of fall and recovery in dance, essentially when the body is caught between two worlds. In this place one can express the tension between lightness and weight.

headline: The Night They Called It a Day
text: “Tomorrow Morning,” a musical by Laurence Mark Wythe, keeps its focus on the big emotional moments of ordinary lives: marriage and divorce, love and commonplace heartache. But that title is not the only thing that feels flat about this show, a York Theater Company production at the Theater at St. Peter’s.

headline: Identities as Elements to Play With and Juggle
text: “Who but De Palma would think of using old-movie trash, and even soft-core pornos, to provide ‘heart’ for a thriller?” Pauline Kael asked in her rave review of Brian De Palma’s “Carrie.”

headline: Another Outing for This Gambling Tale? What Are the Odds?
text: In this age of short-attention-span audiences, if you’re going to perform an old-fashioned play the old-fashioned way — that is, with two intermissions — you’d better have a spark to inject into that third act to make audience members glad they stayed around. The Actors Company Theater, in its pleasant production of “Three Men on a Horse” at the Beckett Theater, has one, and his name is James Murtaugh.

headline: Cabrera Tries to Keep Focus on the Field
text: Last season, when Texas won the American League pennant, Josh Hamilton of the Rangers was the league’s most valuable player. Hamilton, a recovering alcoholic and drug addict, traveled most of the time with Johnny Narron, a personal coach assigned to monitor his behavior and be his companion.

headline: A Reality Check for Steinbeck and Charley
text: In the fall of 1960 an ailing, out-of-sorts John Steinbeck, pretty much depleted as a novelist, decided that his problem was he had lost touch with America. He outfitted a three-quarter-ton pickup truck as a sort of land yacht and set off from his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y., with his French poodle, Charley, to drive cross-country. The idea was that he would travel alone, stay at campgrounds and reconnect himself with the country by talking to the locals he met along the way.

headline: Producer Who Did It All, Not in a Shy Way
text: “His Way,” an HBO documentary on Monday night about the veteran manager, promoter and producer Jerry Weintraub, is a nose-pressed-to-the-glass experience. It’s as if Graydon Carter — one of the film’s producers — has allowed you into the bar at his Waverly Inn just to gawk at the more privileged people being led into the back room.

headline: Fulham Pays Tribute to King of Pop
text: Cue the music. Fire up your favorite “Thriller” videos. A statue of the pop star Michael Jackson was unveiled outside Fulham’s Craven Cottage stadium in London on Sunday.

headline: Reflections of Sacred Harmonies From Spain
text: The exquisitely ornate sacred works of the Spanish Renaissance composer Tomás Luis de Victoria have long been a staple of church choirs, at least in New York, around Christmas and Easter, but they turn up too rarely in concert performances. Perhaps that will change this year, the 400th anniversary of Victoria’s death. The Miller Theater helped get the commemoration under way on Saturday evening when it presented the Tallis Scholars in an all-Victoria program as part of its early-music series at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

headline: House Republicans Propose $4 Trillion in Cuts Over Decade
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans plan this week to propose more than $4 trillion in federal spending reductions over the next decade by reshaping popular programs like Medicare, the Budget Committee chairman said Sunday in opening a new front in the intensifying budget wars.

headline: Operatic Slugger Drives Some Pop
text: Nathan Gunn commands an operatic baritone whose mighty heft and richness confer an outsize authority on everything he touches. When he dips into popular music, he suggests a vocal Babe Ruth aiming for the fences, all the while maintaining a hero’s confident stance. At the Café Carlyle, where he opened “An Evening With Nathan Gunn” on Tuesday evening, he belted it out of the ballpark four times. There were also singles, doubles and a couple of strikeouts.

headline: Close Is No Longer Good Enough for Butler
text: HOUSTON — Butler was a halfcourt heave away from beating Duke for last year’s national championship. That fact has not escaped the current Bulldogs players as they prepare to play Connecticut on Monday in the title game.

headline: Vivendi to Buy Vodafone’s Stake in SFR for $11.3 Billion
text: 9:08 p.m. | Updated

headline: At the Jacoby, Some Trickery Helps Out the Winners
text: The winners of the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams at the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., last month were Greg Hinze of San Antonio; David Yang of Darien, Ill.; Jacob Morgan of Madison, Wis.; Michael Polowan of New York; Dan Morse of Houston; and Steve Shirey of Fort Worth.

headline: ‘Hop’ Is Off to a Surprisingly Robust Start
text: The Easter bunny was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend as the animated and live-action hybrid “Hop” sold an estimated $38 million in tickets, performing far above expectations. The release from Universal Pictures cost $63 million to make, and audience-interest surveys indicated it would open to about $25 million in ticket sales. But a strong, whimsical marketing campaign did the trick, aided by the comedian Russell Brand, who gave voice to the main character, the Easter Bunny’s teenage son, right. Teenage girls, it turns out, find Mr. Brand as hilarious as many adults find him irritating. Summit Entertainment’s “Source Code,” an action thriller starring Jake Gyllenhaal, was second with about $15 million in ticket sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. “Insidious,” an extremely inexpensive horror film from FilmDistrict, was third with about $13.5 million in sales. “Insidious” cost only $1 million to make, according to Jason Blum, a producer of the film. “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules” (20th Century Fox) was fourth with about $10 million, lifting its two-week total to $38.4 million. “Limitless” (Relativity Media) was fifth, selling roughly $9.4 million in tickets for a three-week total of $55.6 million.

headline: Steinberg Prize Awarded
text: “Nine Circles,” a play by Bill Cain, is the winner of the 2011 Harold and Mimi Steinberg/American Theater Critics Association New Play Award. This year’s $25,000 prize, which honors a playwright for work that had its premiere outside New York City in the previous year, was presented to Mr. Cain on Saturday at the Actors Theater of Louisville during the Humana Festival of New American Plays. “Nine Circles” tells the story of a young American soldier accused of an atrocity in Iraq; it was originally produced at the Marin Theater Company in Mill Valley, Calif. This is the second straight year that Mr. Cain, who is also a producer and director, has won the award. Last year his play “Equivocation” took the honors following a run at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. It then was staged at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles and the Manhattan Theater Club at City Center. Two other playwrights were honored with citations and prizes of $7,500 each: Kathryn Grant for “The Good Counselor” and David Bar Katz for “The History of Invulnerability.”

headline: Dueling Snow Whites
text: The actress Lily Collins (“The Blind Side”), below, looks likely to be the fairest of them all in Relativity Media’s 3-D film adaptation of the Brothers Grimm story “Snow White,” Variety reported. If talks with the producers go well, Ms. Collins, the daughter of Phil Collins, will join a cast that includes Julia Roberts as the evil queen and Armie Hammer (“The Social Network”) as Prince Andrew. Tarsem Singh (“The Fall,” “Immortals”) is set to direct the film. Production begins in May, with a release scheduled for June 29, 2012, six months before the arrival of “Snow White and the Huntsman,” Universal Studios’ take on the fairy tale, starring Kristen Stewart and Charlize Theron.

headline: UConn Gets Ready to Cheer on UConn
text: HOUSTON — Kemba Walker and the Connecticut Huskies had plans for Sunday night: watch Maya Moore and the Connecticut Huskies.

headline: Tina Fey Is Greek and Also Teutonic, but She Isn’t a Troll
text: “Tina Fey is an ugly, pear-shaped, bitchy, overrated troll.” Somebody once wrote that on a mean-spirited Web site, whence it could have vanished into oblivion. But Ms. Fey liked the remark too much to let it go.

headline: At the Garden, a Retirement and a Resuscitation
text: Over the weekend at Madison Square Garden they came to bury the first decade of the 2000s. On Friday night it was the Strokes, once the catalysts for multiple revivals: of New York City rock, of the more dissolute strains of late 1960s and 1970s rock, and of the idea of hype band as transgressor. One night later came LCD Soundsystem, which had been central to indie rock’s move to the dance floor, and which called to mind the sorts of bands that tried to render irrelevant the sorts of bands called to mind by the Strokes.

headline: Pay of State University Presidents Holds Steady Despite Cuts
text: In a year in which state universities often absorbed sharp budget cuts and raised tuition, the salaries of the presidents of those institutions largely held steady, according to a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education released Sunday night.

headline: Monday: Charged Particles
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There is something comforting about Monday puzzles. It’s like waking up slowly, to the aroma of a well-brewed cup of coffee. Gimmes galore, and as your brain awakens, the mild challenge of a clever theme that is not too challenging at the same time. A perfect way to prime the mental engine for what comes later in the week.

headline: Rebel Leadership in Libya Shows Strain
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — With the rebels’ battlefield fortunes sagging, the three men in charge of the Libyan opposition forces were summoned late last week by the ad-hoc leadership of their movement to a series of meetings here in the rebel capital.

headline: Rangers Find a Way to Avoid Repeating History
text: PHILADELPHIA — Yes, Henrik Lundqvist had a flashback, too. Exactly 51 Sunday afternoons after losing a shootout on the final day of the regular season, ending the Rangers’ playoff hopes, Lundqvist stood at the same spot on the ice in this big arena, sizing up another moment of high drama.

headline: CND2
text: Photos of a performance by the junior company of the Compañía Nacional de Danza from Spain.

headline: Minmetals Resources Bids $6.5 Billion for Equinox Minerals
text: 9:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Rail’s Derby 10
text: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

headline: Burying the First Decade of the 2000s
text: Photos from concerts by the Strokes and LCD Soundsystem.

headline: Tense Calm Prevails in Syria as Latest Crackdown Victims Are Buried
text: CAIRO — Thousands of Syrians marched through the shuttered streets of Douma, just outside Damascus, on Sunday, chanting antigovernment slogans as they buried at least eight victims of the crackdown on Friday’s protests, according to witnesses and human rights activists.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review ‘Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo’
text: A “smart, savagely funny and visionary new work of American theater, whose presence on Broadway invites fanciful comparison to the titular beast.” That’s how Charles Isherwood describes Rajiv Joseph’s play “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” which opened at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Thursday in a production starring Robin Williams. Readers were a little less generous with the superlatives. Following are excerpts from several readers’ reviews posted on the theater section of NYTimes.com.

headline: ‘Fall and Recover’
text: Photos from a production by the Irish contemporary choreographer John Scott.

headline: Mets Feel Momentum With Road Series Win
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Among the many problems that beset the Mets last year, perhaps the most confounding was their inability to win on the road, and particularly here against the Florida Marlins.

headline: Blast at Pakistan Shrine Kills Dozens
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Two suicide bombers set off an explosion on Sunday evening at a Sufi shrine compound in Pakistan, killing at least 42 people, police officials said. More than 100 people, including women and children, were wounded.

headline: Bring Donors Out of the Shadows
text: THE billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch have drawn sharp criticism for their extensive giving to libertarian causes. Though some of their organizational ties are public, many are unknown, thanks to a provision in the tax code that allows the Koch brothers and other donors, on both the left and the right, to conceal the recipients of their largess, even as they get to write it off on their taxes.

headline: With Stakes High, N.F.L. Relies on a Star Lawyer
text: Last week, during a lecture at the Yeshiva University Cardozo School of Law, David Boies was reviewing the case he helped argue against California’s Proposition 8 in that landmark same-sex marriage trial when he paused for a moment to compose himself. Earlier in the evening, Boies had called the fight for equal rights for gays the next step in moving closer to the ideals of the country’s founding fathers. As he recalled asking the four plaintiffs in the case why they wanted to marry, he was briefly overcome by what he remembered as the pain and despair in their responses.

headline: Teenagers Speak Up for Lack of Faith
text: PANAMA CITY, Fla. — Every other Wednesday, right after school at 2:45, the newest club at Rutherford High, the atheist club, meets in Room 13-211.

headline: G.O.P’s 2012 Strategy Puts Focus on Timing
text: WASHINGTON — The last time Republicans challenged an incumbent Democratic president, they were simultaneously running a Congressional revolution.

headline: An Accompaniment Moves Beyond the Bagel
text: IN the 1980s, when the bagel began its ascent from a specialty item served primarily in delis to a staple in chains like Bruegger’s, and eventually even in McDonald’s, it was an auspicious time to be in the cream cheese business. So in commercials for Philadelphia cream cheese over the last few decades, bagels have played a starring role as a platform for the spread.

headline: Microlender Focuses on Hospitality Businesses
text: Four years ago, Riccardo Romero could not find a bank to finance his first restaurant, so he ended up opening the Arepas Cafe in Astoria, Queens, with money from friends and a $10,000 loan from Acción, a nonprofit microlender that has seeded small businesses across the country.

headline: U.S. Shifts to Seek Removal of Yemen’s Leader, an Ally
text: SANA, Yemen — The United States, which long supported Yemen’s president, even in the face of recent widespread protests, has now quietly shifted positions and has concluded that he is unlikely to bring about the required reforms and must be eased out of office, according to American and Yemeni officials.

headline: Senior Centers in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Longer Shackled by AOL
text: In 2005, Jim Bankoff was working at AOL as executive vice president in charge of products and programming. He decided that AOL needed to move aggressively into news if the business, then still a portal clinging to dial-up customers, was to survive the shift to broadband and the onslaught of new digital sites.

headline: Duke Law Students Give Musical Nod to Nixon
text: DURHAM, N.C. — His name is not on any campus buildings. His only portrait is stored in a locked closet. And after his scandal-driven downfall, Richard M. Nixon was so stigmatized here at Duke University — where he earned a law degree — that the faculty rejected a proposal to house his presidential library.

headline: City Pension Proposals
text: To the Editor:

headline: The One That Got Away Is Still a Yankees Fan, and a Hot Pitching Prospect
text: LOS ANGELES — The best amateur pitcher in the country stepped off the rubber at cozy Jackie Robinson Stadium on Friday night, a roaring locomotive screeching to a stop. Gerrit Cole had two strikes on the hitter, with two outs in the ninth inning, and the 675 fans beneath the eucalyptus trees had started to stamp and clap and chant for U.C.L.A. to finish off Washington.

headline: Fox Chief Seeks to Temper Theater Owners’ Furor Over On-Demand Films
text: LOS ANGELES — Jim Gianopulos, a chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, has a thought for theater owners who rebelled last week against a plan by his studio and others to allow home viewing of some movies just two months after they open:

headline: For Illumination Entertainment, Animation Meets Economic Reality
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Hollywood’s cartoon kings typically work in splendorous surroundings. Jeffrey Katzenberg runs DreamWorks Animation from a Mediterranean-style campus replete with olive trees and fountains. At Pixar’s glistening complex, John Lasseter has an Olympic-size swimming pool.

headline: Cutting the Budget
text: To the Editor:

headline: Change in Chinatown

headline: Jazzy Funeral Parade Marks Coney Island’s Death and Rebirth

headline: Spring’s Awakening?
text: There are encouraging signs in the March jobs report, but for each hopeful development, there is a caveat. The economy added 216,000 jobs last month and marked the 13th straight month of private-sector job gains — but the growth is still weak. At a comparable point in the recoveries from other severe recessions, the economy was adding about 400,000 jobs a month.

headline: Hole in Southwest Jet Attributed to Cracks
text: The five-foot hole that ripped open midflight Friday in the roof of a Southwest Airlines jet and terrified passengers on their way to Sacramento from Phoenix was caused by fatigue cracks in the aluminum underskin of the lap joints, the National Transportation Safety Board said Sunday.

In addition to the ongoing crises of homelessness and cholera, a chronic emergency of sexual violence prevails in the settlements where hundreds of thousands still live, well over a year after the disaster.

headline: Gains and Losses
text: After a long, scentless winter, apart from the tang of woodsmoke in the air, you could suddenly smell the earth again early one morning last week. It seems odd to call the scent fresh — it was darker and mustier than that — but fresh is how it felt, hovering like a ground fog above the last banks of snow. A whole field of clover could grow in that smell alone.

headline: Lesson in Being a State Company
text: Last week’s ouster of the chief executive of Vale, the mining giant based in Rio de Janeiro, sends a terrible signal to the markets about the Brazilian government’s intentions. The executive, Roger Agnelli, resisted the state’s designs to push the $180 billion company into lower-return, if labor-intensive, activities. With President Dilma Rousseff’s government forcing his departure, investors must brace for a strategy that favors jobs over profit — in the fashion of Pemex instead of BHP Billiton.

text: With five days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, Democrats and Republicans took to the Sunday talk shows. Lawmakers from both sides expressed optimism that a government shutdown was not likely, though they agreed that a deal was not yet done.

headline: Edwin Gaustad, Religious Historian, Is Dead at 87
text: Edwin S. Gaustad, who took his place in the front rank of American religious historians with seminal works on the religious ideas of the founding fathers, especially Thomas Jefferson, and the arguments about church versus state that evolved from the dissenting sects in colonial America, died on March 25 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 87. The death was confirmed by his daughter Susan.

A more compact five-shot revolver is less visible, strapped to his ankle. It seems borrowed from the New York City Police Museum.

headline: Web Shoppers Show a Cautious Trend

headline: ‘I Stink!’ Illustrator Shows Elegant Work
text: Parents of small children probably know James McMullan as the creator (along with his wife, Kate) of the popular picture book “I Stink!” about the nightly rounds of a profoundly disgusting but hard-working New York City garbage truck. He is also enshrined in disco lore for the paintings he did more than 30 years ago for New York magazine that became the visual inspiration for “Saturday Night Fever.” But these days Mr. McMullan is much better known for the elegantly expressive show posters he makes for Lincoln Center Theater. Last week a large selection of those posters — for plays and musicals like “Ah! Wilderness,” “Carousel,” above, and “South Pacific” — went on display near the theater they helped promote, at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. The posters and other work will remain on view at the library through June 11. On Monday Mr. McMullan will join a fellow theatrical graphic artist, Frank Verlizzo, known as Fraver, at the library for a discussion about poster making.

headline: Porto Celebrates in the Dark at the Stadium of Light
text: Porto clinched its 25th Portuguese championship with a 2-1 victory over Benfica on Sunday. The evening was especially delicious for Porto and its fans because they were able to wrap up the title inside  Benfica’s stadium, the Estádio da Luz in Lisbon.

headline: Lollapalooza Chile: A World-Class Party Band
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Lollapalooza Chile has introduced me to a world-class party band: Chico Trujillo, a local favorite who had a huge crowd shouting along. Every party band needs a rhythm, and Aldo Asenjo, the band’s leader and singer, relies on cumbia, the beat heard in countless variations across Latin America. Cumbia often trots calmly, but Chico Trujillo’s version gallops, bounding along; now and then, the music switches into rumba, equally upbeat. Mr. Asenjo sings lyrics as chattery and percussive as some hip-hop, taking on the ups and downs of love and life, with his voice answered by chortling horns — did he borrow the arranging idea from ska bands? — and a tootling, circusy organ. Syncopation, momentum and a way of romping through pain — a party band needs them all, and Chico Trujillo has them.

headline: Biden to Discuss New Guidelines About Campus Sex Crimes
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is urging the nation’s schools and colleges to do more to prevent sexual violence, saying campus sex crimes often go unreported because victims fear that universities will not discipline offenders.

headline: Who Really Freed the Slaves
text: If you enjoyed the story about Maj. Gen. Benjamin F. Butler and how he came to shelter fugitive slaves within Fort Monroe (an excerpt from Adam Goodheart’s book “1861: The Civil War Awakening”)  in the April 3 issue of the magazine, you may be interested in a column Goodheart wrote a few weeks back for the Opinionator, which reminds us how much Butler’s position went against the conventions of the time. headline: Breaking Records (of Sorts) With Toyota Prius
text: Large corporations and wacky marketing campaigns can make for some cringe-worthy viewing. Held in cooperation with the grandiose-sounding and entirely irreverent Universal Record Database, the goal was to establish at least 200 bizarre Prius-related records over two days.

headline: The Growing Business of Online Reputation Management
text: Over the weekend I wrote an article for Sunday Styles about new Web services that deal with a new problem — online reputation management. These businesses have cropped up over the past few years to address one major negative aspect of our online world: As quickly as images, blog posts, commentary, status updates and photos are posted on the Web, they are replicated by algorithms and search engines, and dissipate like an airborne virus. The Internet is a permanent record of our past, and it never forgets anything posted online.

headline: Shakespeare in Left Field
text: Bill James is rattling his sabremetrician-ness again. On Wednesday, he published an essay in Slate, “Verlander and Shakespeare.” It’s pretty great for reasons highlighted by its subtitle, “Why are we so good at developing athletes and so lousy at developing writers?” Throw a brush-back pitch like that and you’re sure to start a conversation. So much to argue with! The premise itself. Two gross assumptions underlying the premise. Then, another level down, the issue of what “developing” means. And “good.” And “lousy.” And “we” — who does that refer to, exactly? Just wait till you get to the actual arguments.

headline: Regular Old Twins
text: This Sunday’s Lives column by the novelist Samantha Hunt is not about twiblings; that was the subject of the cover article by Melanie Thernstrom a few months ago, about having two babies born five days apart to two surrogate mothers. And it’s not about I.V.F.-produced multiples of any kind. It’s about good old-fashioned twins, the idea of which, not to mention the physical space they take up inside their mothers-to-be in the last weeks before birth, apparently creeps some people out. A different sort of creepiness can be found in Hunt’s short story “The Yellow,” which was published by The New Yorker in November. You’re advised to check it out.

headline: In Xinjiang, Exploring a Changing Story
text: Carolyn Drake could probably stop now. Her project on the Uighurs, a group of Turkic-speaking Muslims in western China, started in 2007 on her first trip to Xinjiang Province. Her most recent visit was in February. The images she has captured are vibrant, poetic and incredibly varied in scope.

headline: Lollapalooza Chile: Tough Female Rappers, Jane’s Addiction and Polite Dancers
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Latin America loves smart, tough female rappers: Anita Tijoux on Saturday and, on Sunday afternoon, Mala Rodríguez from Spain. Ms. Rodríguez performed wearing a kind of corset, along with pink knee socks, but in her songs she is no bimbo. Her delivery — mostly rapped, occasionally sung — is rapid-fire enough to leave most rappers breathless; her message is self-realization without apologies, limits or inhibitions. It’s bragging, flirting, philosophizing and flinging ultimatums. When she called for the crowd to join in, it was to chant “Fuerte!” — “Strong!”

headline: Monday Reading: I.R.S. Offers Free Tax Software
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Desserts for the Conscientious
text: What is a healthy dessert? For starters, I think that a dessert can be healthy if it has some nutritive value — if sugar, butter and refined flour aren’t at its core. Certainly fresh fruit qualifies on this score, and two of the best for desserts, apples and pears, are readily available even now, when spring has barely begun.

headline: Expedia Adds App for Hotel Bookings
text: Expedia.com is joining the ranks of Priceline and Hotels.com  by offering travelers the ability to book hotel rooms through a free app. The Expedia Hotels app — due on iTunes for iPhone and iPod Touch early this month and for Android devices a few weeks after that —  allows travelers to reserve rooms in 130,000 hotels in more than 200 countries.

headline: Numberplay: Circular Logic
text: “A manhole would never fall on someone. That’s not why they’re round. You’d never put a manhole cover on the hole when someone’s in there. Not even as a prank. And it’s not going to just slide over by itself.”

headline: F.A.A. to Order Airlines to Inspect 737s for Cracks
text: The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Monday that it would require extensive inspections of some older-model Boeing 737s for cracks in the planes’ fragile skin that can be caused by pressurization and depressurization of the cabin over tens of thousands of takeoffs and landings.

headline: ‘Disaster Memory’ and the Flooding of Fukushima
text: 2:50 p.m. | Updated below with astounding video from Kesennuma, Japan |Over the weekend, I mused on a question that’s bothered me since I read Roger Bilham’s report on the great earthquake and tsunami of March 11: Given the history of devastating tsunamis not far away, how could it have taken until 2006 for the word “tsunami” to show up in government guidelines related to the Fukushima nuclear complex? (For instance, in 1933 a tsunami more than 90 feet high erased coastal villages along part of the same stretch of Honshu coast devastated on March 11.)

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: More than 1,800 health care company leaders and top government officials are expected at the 8th Annual World Health Care Congress in Washington Monday through Wednesday.

headline: Leading Vietnamese Dissident Sentenced to Prison
text: BANGKOK — A prominent Vietnamese legal scholar who sued the prime minister and called for multiparty democracy was convicted of propaganda against the state Monday and sentenced to seven years in prison and another three years under house arrest. The case was one of the most highly charged political trials in Vietnam in years.

headline: Google Bidding on Nortel Patents
text: Google said Monday it is bidding $900 million on the patent portfolio of Nortel, the communications technology company that filed for bankruptcy in 2009.

headline: Where Are The Shakespeares of Topeka?
text: I was going to write a response to the baseball savant Bill James’s peculiar Opening Day reflections on why America is (supposedly) better at developing athletic talent than literary talent, but happily Alan Jacobs beat me to it. James’s piece begins by noting that the population of a city like Topeka, Kan., is roughly similar to the population of London in the age of Shakespeare, and then suggests the absence of a Topekan Shakespeare is evidence that Elizabethan England was better at cultivating men of letters than contemporary America — whereas we’re better at cultivating professional athletes:

headline: Nice House, Quiet Block, Grisly History
text: At first glance, it would seem peculiar that someone has not already snapped up the century-old brick home for sale at 21 Howard Place in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. It has sun-filled rooms, a stately porch, proximity to Prospect Park and a front yard where a salmon-colored impatiens bush, stacks of flower pots and a statue of St. Francis with a squirrel on his shoulder hint at the urban gardening possibilities.

headline: Leading Off: Butler Spreads Underdog Fever
text: The Butler men’s basketball team has accomplished something truly amazing and no, we’re not even talking about the stupendous achievement of making two straight N.C.A.A. championship game appearances. No, Butler has gone and turned an entire sport on its head.

headline: The Grapes of Wrath, in Burgundy
text: It’s a great and twisted yarn, a little too dark for Peter Mayle, but perhaps just macabre enough for Roald Dahl. Somebody was poisoning the great pinot noir vines of Romanée-Conti, the nonpareil grand cru vineyard of the Domaine de la Romanée-Conti. Only, this was not a short story, it actually happened.

headline: Zambia Drops Case of Shooting by Chinese Mine Bosses
text: JOHANNESBURG — In what could be a politically explosive decision, prosecutors in Zambia have decided not to pursue a case against two Chinese supervisors who shot 13 coal miners last year during a wage protest, the managers’ lawyer said Monday.

headline: Bosie Tea Parlor Is Opening in the Village
text: Nicky Dawda rented a nice storefront in Greenwich Village, planning to do some renovations and open a tearoom with the tea expert Kiley Holliday. Simple enough? That was 18 months ago. Now after dealing with city codes, their tearoom, Bosie Tea Parlor, will open on Thursday with about 100 of Ms. Holliday’s hand-selected L’Âge de Thé teas in golden canisters on the shelves.

headline: Would You Buy a House Where Someone Was Killed?
text: For decades, Howard Place in Brooklyn was a quiet block in Windsor Terrace where the biggest news took place when Helen Hunt filmed shots there for the 1997 movie “As Good as It Gets.” That changed on Dec. 13, when Ryan Devaney, a troubled resident, tried to kill his parents in their home at 21 Howard Place, and then tried to kill himself by throwing himself in front of a G train. His mother died. Mr. Devaney awaits trial, and his father, who survived, has moved.

headline: It’s All Him | Jerry Weintraub
text: Monday night at 9, HBO will broadcast “His Way,” a new documentary about the Hollywood producer Jerry Weintraub. The guy is beyond a legend. His recent film credits include “Ocean’s Eleven,” “Ocean’s Twelve,” and “Ocean’s Thirteen,” and go back to “The Karate Kid,” and Robert Altman’s “Nashville.” Before devoting himself to making movies, he managed and/or promoted musicians like John Denver, Elvis Presley, Led Zeppelin, the Carpenters, Frank Sinatra and Neil Young.

headline: In a Reversal, Military Trials for 9/11 Cases
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, ending more than a year of indecision with a major policy reversal, will prosecute Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other people accused of plotting the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks before a military commission and not a civilian court, as it once planned.

Although V.C.U.’s run ended with a loss to Butler in Houston on Saturday, the feat ranks right among anything else accomplished over the course of a single N.C.A.A. tournament; it was about as unlikely as Villanova winning the national title, as a No. 8 seed, in 1985.

headline: Katie Couric Has a Few Regrets
text: When you started hosting the “CBS Evening News” in 2006, there was a lot of talk about mold-breaking. Now the show looks very much like the other network broadcasts.  In retrospect I would have given people what they were used to, a traditional newscast. And then as they got to know me and got more comfortable, then I would’ve started toying with the format and trying new things. I think we were overly ambitious. We probably would have been better off playing it a little safer.

headline: Now, Hit ‘Play’ if You Want a Fanta
text: In the late 1960s, PepsiCo sold its flagship soft drink with a slogan that proclaimed, “Taste that beats the others cold, Pepsi pours it on.” These many years later, it is the PepsiCo rival, the Coca-Cola Company, that seems to be letting loose.

headline: President Obama's Re-Election Effort

headline: Country Music Awards Lift CBS in Ratings
text: The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with “60 Minutes.” ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched “Secret Millionaire” at 8, followed by “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million) and “Body of Proof” (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million) and “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

headline: Empire Building | Paige Novick
text: “Architecture has always been my inspiration,” says Paige Novick, who has been designing her eponymous line of costume jewelry for the past four years. This fall she will unveil Phyne, her first fine jewelry collection, adding precious stones into pieces made from metals like sterling silver alloy, more often found in factories than in your mother’s jewelry box. The delicate black rhodium and diamond speckled octagonal rings, geometric earrings spiraling with precious stones and metal and gem-tiered cuffs were created, she says, with the Empire State Building in mind, but there may be another muse who deserves some credit here. “My mother is a fine jeweler,” Novick explains with a smile. “It’s in my DNA.”

headline: Multitude of Species Face Climate Threat
text: Over the past 540 million years, life on Earth has passed through five great mass extinctions. In each of those catastrophes, an estimated 75 percent or more of all species disappeared in a few million years or less.

headline: Small Banks and Small Businesses Battle Over Swipe Fees
text: Last week was a busy one for those following the battle over rules limiting the fees banks can charge to process debit card transaction. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, acknowledged that the board, swamped by public comments on its proposed rules, would miss its deadline for completing those rules. Meanwhile, some senators are trying to legislate a further delay in carrying out the rules with two more years of study on the issue, and grocery and convenience store owners have converged on Washington to try to keep efforts to delay, or repeal, the new rules at bay.

headline: Obama Invites Boehner for a Budget Talk
text: President Obama invited the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, and three other Congressional leaders to the White House on Tuesday in hopes of wrapping up a bipartisan agreement on federal spending for the rest of this fiscal year and avoiding a shutdown of the government.

headline: Maine Museum to Get Newly Discovered 1840s Murals
text: Newly discovered 1840s murals of inlets, willows, lighthouses and sailing ships are being extricated this week from a house in East Baldwin, Me., for transfer to the Rufus Porter Museum and Cultural Heritage Center in nearby Bridgton. The owners have donated three roomfuls of the scenery, painted by the muralist Rufus Porter’s nephew Jonathan Poor, along with underlying layers of plaster and lath, fireplace mantels and an entire staircase. The museum is raising $60,000 for the dismantling work, by the salvager David Ottinger, and is renovating an 1830s house that will accommodate the acquisition. Poor died in his early 40s, soon after completing the work for a local physician, perhaps because mural painting was a hazardous profession. “My supposition is that all the materials they worked with were poisonous,” Julie Lindberg, the Porter museum’s curator, said.

headline: Prosecutor Says Profit Was Behind Deutsche Fire
text: A prosecutor at the trial of three construction supervisors charged in the deaths of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank building told the jury on Monday that the defendants had “put profit over people,” a decision that led to the deaths and put the lives of hundreds of firefighters, inspectors and workers at risk.

headline: Jeffrey Katzenberg, DreamWorks Chief, Joins Zynga’s Board
text: Bound by a mutual love for animated animals — and profits — Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, has joined Zynga’s board, the company announced Monday.

headline: When Katie Couric Met Andrew Goldman
text: Apparently, it’s official: Katie Couric will no longer anchor the “CBS Evening News.” It’s hardly a surprise. She has been hinting at a move for ages, and speculation that she wouldn’t last has been gurgling pretty much since her first day in the anchor’s chair five years ago. But rarely was she ever so open with her ambivalence about the job as she was in an interview with Andrew Goldman, which appears in the April 10 issue of the magazine but which we’re publishing online now. Goldman conducted it on Friday, March 25, the day before Couric took off for a pre-big-news vacation to Turks and Caicos. Although she wouldn’t confirm that she was leaving the show — she was more interested in discussing her new book, “The Best Advice I Ever Got: Lessons From Extraordinary Lives” — she expressed some regrets about trying to push the nightly-news genre too far too fast and she floated a theory (though she wouldn’t put her name behind it) that CBS’s local news lead-ins might have kept her mired in third place.

headline: Police Raid Shanghai Gay Bar and Detain More Than 60
text: BEIJING—More than 60 patrons and employees at a gay bar in Shanghai were swept up in a police raid early Sunday morning and held for more 12 hours, according to the state media and several of those detained.

headline: After Breach, Companies Warn of E-Mail Fraud
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Security experts said Monday that millions of people were at increased risk of e-mail swindles after a giant security breach at an online marketing firm.

headline: Sale Sets Record for Living Chinese Artist
text: SHANGHAI — A triptych oil painting by Zhang Xiaogang sold for $10.1 million on Sunday at a Sotheby’s auction in Hong Kong. The sale broke the record for a piece by a living Chinese artist, and was the latest sign of China’s phenomenal ascent in the global art market.

headline: On Our Radar: Salazar Slams Transocean Over Bonuses
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar criticizes Transocean, which operated the Deepwater Horizon rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico last year, killing 11, for awarding executives bonuses for the “best year in safety performance in our company’s history.” Mr. Salazar says the company was “at least at some fault” for causing the catastrophe. “In my own view, 2010 was probably the greatest year of pain in terms of oil and gas development in the deep water all across the world, especially in the Gulf of Mexico,” he said. [Reuters]

headline: David Foster Wallace’s Unfinished Novel — and Life
text: Every writer dies, probably, still intending to write something. It’s a basic fact of (to put it slightly trivially) scheduling: the time lines of mortality and ambition rarely coincide. Thomas Aquinas finished only the first two sections of his “Summa Theologica” — a work that would loom over philosophical thought for centuries — before (according to some biographers) he hit his head on a branch while riding a donkey and plunged into his final illness. Walter Benjamin worked for 13 years on his magisterial “Arcades Project” but left it unfinished when he committed suicide to avoid falling into the hands of the Nazis. The list could go on almost indefinitely, with works snuffed out by illness (Flaubert’s “Bouvard and Pécuchet”) and genocide (Némirovsky’s “Suite Francaise”) and alcoholic dissipation (Flann O’Brien’s “Slattery’s Sago Saga”). The loss is particularly hard when an author seems to have been really humming along — when the last big thing was a masterpiece and the next one promised to be another. “Dostoyevsky,” the novelist Norman Rush has said, “died still intending to write another volume of ‘The Brothers Karamazov.’ It’s like a knife in my heart that he didn’t.”

text: Diabetes has long been associated with a host of serious health problems, including increased risk of vision loss, kidney problems, heart attack and stroke. Now a growing body of research shows that diabetes also increases risk for deadly cancers.

headline: Perot Family Gave to Tea Party Candidates in 2010
text: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who received nearly 19 percent of the vote for president as an independent candidate in 1992, did not go out of his way to align himself publicly with the Tea Party movement during the 2010 midterm elections, despite the fact that the movement is organized around the principles of small government and fiscal restraint on which his campaign was based. But during six days leading up to the November elections, members of the Perot family contributed $172,000 to 22 Republicans running for the House, many under the Tea Party banner.

headline: Quora Makes Changes Aimed at Doctors and Lawyers
text: Since Quora, a question-and-answer start-up , was first introduced last June, it has become something of a Web darling among tech denizens, engineers and early adopters. But the conversations on Quora have quickly fanned out beyond new media and technology. A spin through the site reveals a wide range of topics currently under discussion, including white chocolate, the rapper Lil Wayne‘s ascent to stardom and ways to alleviate car sickness in babies.

headline: Notes From the Underground | o.F.F.
text: The Berlin-based French musician known as o.F.F. performed his brand of sensitive, semi-ambient electronic R&B for a small crowd in at Faktory in Reykjavik, Iceland, last week. Shrouded in a yin yang patterned scarf tucked into his baseball hat, o.F.F. crooned of lost loves and their workings on his heart, while Kira Brekkan, his special guest for the evening, writhed stage left, contributing soft sound effects. o.F.F. wandered into the crowd, presenting red roses to select beautiful young Icelanders, delicately painting a picture of himself as a lover, not a fighter.

headline: Can the iPhone Revive the Home Movie?
text: On Saturday evening, I, along with thousands of other fervent music fans, was jammed into Madison Square Garden in New York, helping bid LCD Soundsystem adieu when I noticed a fellow concertgoer filming part of the show with his smartphone. I stopped bouncing for a few minutes to watch him record when I realized that the application capturing the action on stage was using a filtered lens, much like the ones that help give photos snapped with Instagram and Path their vintage veneer.

headline: Winter, a Guru of Offense, Ends Wait to Join the Hall
