headline: The Materiality of Merger Negotiations
text: Have you heard this one recently: A senior executive buys shares in a company that he may recommend be the target of a takeover, giving him a significant profit if the deal goes through. When the trading becomes known, questions arise whether the Securities and Exchange Commission views the information as material for possible insider trading charges.

headline: Water Barriers Mulled (Belatedly) at Leaking Nuclear Complex
text: As I read reports about the release of more than 11,000 tons of radiation-laced water into the sea from the damaged nuclear plant in Japan, I recalled reporting I did more than a decade ago on the many uses of silt barriers — essentially curtains suspended in water — to hold back everything from oil slicks to the bursts of polluted runoff flowing into coastal waters from city storm drains after heavy storms (the water can be pumped and treated once the system is not overloaded).

headline: Photo Replay: April 4
text: A view of the day in sports included a long walk in the desert, practice in the sand in Augusta, Ga., and some much cooler curling gear.

headline: Back to Work and Life, With a Fresh Perspective
text: I was in the car with Ruth, headed home from one of her last radiation treatments at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

headline: The Bidding Over Blockbuster
text: Investors like Carl Icahn, Dish Network, Monarch Alternative Capital and SK Telecom are looking at the assets of Blockbuster in bankruptcy. The company’s fate may be decided in court late Monday.

headline: TimesCast | April 4, 2011
text: April 4, 2011 - At least 10 killed at a protest in Yemen; and the United States backs away from its support of Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh.

headline: Poll: More Democrats than Republicans Favor Compromise on Budget
text: Just days away from a potential government shutdown, a majority of Democrats and independents say lawmakers with whom they share views should be more willing to compromise even if that results in a budget they disagree with. But fewer Republicans, especially those that agree with the Tea Party movement, say the same, according to a new poll by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Popular Carnival Singer Is Elected President of Haiti in a Landslide
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — One of Haiti’s most popular entertainers, a provocative Carnival singer previously best known for disrobing and swearing on stage, was elected president in a landslide, according to results announced Monday, placing him at the helm of a nation still struggling to recover from last year’s earthquake, a cholera epidemic and chronic poverty.

headline: I Think Pawlenty Misunderstands Me
text: Wow. So Tim Pawlenty is using something I said on yesterday’s This Week in a new ad.

headline: Overcoming a Parenting ‘Sabbatical’
text: Barbara Hannah Grufferman was in her late 30s when she married and had children. She was in her mid-40s when she made what she describes as the “heart- and stomach-wrenching decision to quit my job as president of a small but growing international conference company to be a full-time mother of two daughters.” Seven years later she looks back on the decision and says: “The challenge … that many women — including me — didn’t think through was this: If I decide to remove myself from the workforce for a period of time, will I be  able to get back in?”

headline: Lean Cuisine | Paris’s Tiniest Kitchen
text: “The only place I don’t cook in is my bathtub,” Rachel Khoo marvels. A trained pastry chef, twice-published author and self-christened food creative, Khoo hosts lunches at La Petite Cuisine à Paris, or the Little Paris Kitchen, in her 226-square-foot apartment in Paris’s Belleville neighborhood. The “little kitchen” concept might be a considerable hindrance to most chefs, but Khoo has made the most of it. “It’s like I’m on a constant camping holiday,” she says of the two gas rings and toaster oven at her disposal, and the resourcefulness that has sprung from them. She has whipped up Eton mess à la française, lemon and lavender roast chicken, tonka bean soufflé, and croque madame muffins. Khoo’s favorite dish so far, pot au feu fajitas (melt-in-your-mouth beef stew and fresh vegetables in a tortilla with sauce from the pot au feu), summarizes the spirit of her book: “It’s not quite French, but it takes on the initial French flavors.”

headline: Texas Instruments to Buy National Semiconductor for $6.5 Billion
text: Texas Instruments said on Monday afternoon that it had agreed to acquire National Semiconductor for $6.5 billion in cash.

headline: Paths of Discovery, Lighted by a Bug Man’s Insights
text: About three months ago, Thomas Eisner of Cornell University, a towering figure in the fields of biology, ecology and evolution, and a promoter of the class Insecta and related arthropod throngs so thermodynamically persuasive you kept expecting a pair of antennae to sprout from his forehead, sent my 14-year-old daughter, Katherine, a wonderful, miserable gift.

headline: A Man Who Loved Insects
text: Photographs by Thomas Eisner, a professor of chemical ecology at Cornell University known for his in-depth studies of insects and other arthropods.

headline: Lollapalooza Flies South
text: Lollapalooza Chile, which took place in Santiago last weekend, was the first installment of the festival outside the United States.

headline: Five-Time World Champion, and Struggling to Fit In
text: I’M lucky because I usually fly first class, and have been doing that for the last 16 years.

headline: Sixers Face Trouble Without Williams
text: With their win over the Nets Friday, the Philadelphia 76ers clinched a playoff berth. Yet by Sunday, their playoff chances -– already slim, given the strength of Philadelphia’s likely first-round opponent, Miami or Boston –- had taken a significant hit with Lou Williams’s strained right hamstring. Williams was forced to leave the Sixers’ game against the Bucks during the third quarter, and an already limited Philadelphia team had one less scoring option. According to Kate Fagan of the Philadelphia Inquirer, Williams has been ruled out for the remainder of the regular season and is left hoping to be healthy enough to suit up for the playoffs.

headline: TimesCast | Radioactive Water Released
text: April 4, 2011 - Japan began dumping radioactive water from the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean to make room for more contaminated water. Ken Belson reports.

headline: Follow the Turks
text: If ever there was a man whose character finds opportunity in crisis, that man is Ahmet Davutoglu, Turkey’s foreign minister. Like Turkey itself, he finds his natural role sandwiched between powers, managing conflict and building relationships. Where does it hail from, that hospital ship bearing the wounded away from besieged Misrata, Libya? It hails from Turkey, of course, and is named after the capital, Ankara. What country has both urged Qaddafi to go, yet maintained a very active embassy in Tripoli? Turkey again. (It was also a crucial go-between in aiding in the release of our own Times colleagues from Libyan captivity the other week.) Which country (and major NATO member) has performed the trick of strongly opposing NATO involvement in any Libyan action — then embracing exactly that? And so on.

headline: Poised for Releases: 2 New Screens at Lincoln Center
text: The construction on the south side of West 65th Street is almost finished, the first movie has been booked and a programming consultant with long experience in independent films has been hired. After nearly four years and an investment of $41 million, the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s new theater complex, the group’s most significant undertaking in years and one that could prove a boon for lovers and distributors of art house films, now has an opening date.

headline: Drugs’ Cost and Safety Fuel a Fight
text: After weeks of controversy, federal health officials announced last week that they would not stop pharmacies from making a cheaper alternative to a costly drug given to prevent premature birth. And separately, they investigated the deaths of nine Alabama hospital patients who received a nutritional supplement contaminated with bacteria.

headline: Neediest | New House, New Beats
text: Jason Celik, a young musician with Duschenne's muscular dystrophy, makes hip-hop beats for his brother Peter's raps. The Neediest Cases Fund helped make his family's home wheelchair-friendly.

headline: Neediest | Working Together
text: Assistance from the Neediest Case Fund helped Desiree Whitlow pay bills and gave her time to look for a job.

headline: Neediest Cases | A Changed Man
text: William Mobley shares how he has overcome addiction and stays focused on the future.

headline: Neediest | An Independent Life
text: After deciding to live independently from the family and religious community that raised her, Diana Rutherford ended up at Covenant House and started a career as a chef.

headline: Neediest | A New Beginning
text: After months of unemployment, Khalilah El Amin reached out to Brooklyn Community Services for help getting her sons coats for the winter and a laptop so she could pursue her BA online.

headline: Neediest | Creating Artists
text: After years of providing art classes for students at P.S. 142, The Educational Alliance after-school program had to cut enrollment because of lost funding. The Fund supplied an additional teacher.

headline: Battle for Libya | April 4, 2011
text: Rebels Fight for Control of Brega.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and Ivory Coast.

headline: Greek Tablet May Shed Light on Early Bureaucratic Practices
text: An archaeologist digging in the rubble of a distant past counts on the conqueror’s havoc, nature’s upheavals and plain human negligence to have left legacies of unintended value — like a fragment of a clay tablet bearing archaic writing from an early period of state formation in Greece, more than 3,400 years ago.

headline: Harvick Keeps Earnhardt Out of Victory Lane
text: Kevin Harvick chased down Dale Earnhardt Jr. with four laps left in the Goody’s Fast Relief 500 at Martinsville Speedway in Virginia on Sunday, and went on to score a fairly unpopular victory. Earnhardt is often voted Nascar’s most popular driver; Harvick heard plenty of boos in Victory Lane after the race.

headline: From Two Stars, Handel’s Sober Side
text: Nearly 50 years in, the early-music revolution has been largely won. The music of the 17th and 18th centuries is no longer esoteric; on a random night in New York there’s as much Monteverdi as Mahler. Audiences are still eager to learn the great lesson of the Baroque, that emotion is focused rather than blocked by the restraints of form.

headline: Patterns: Long Hours May Add to Heart Trouble
text: When assessing a patient’s risk for heart disease, doctors take into account such factors as age, cholesterol and smoking status. A new study suggests an additional measure: long working hours.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and Ivory Coast.

headline: Directly Confronting the Appalling
text: Anna Politkovskaya, the fearless Russian journalist who was shot and killed by an unknown assailant in Moscow in 2006, wrote about the dark side of Vladimir V. Putin’s reign: the brutal war in Chechnya; the top-to-bottom thuggery and corruption; the lack of an independent judiciary; the “bureaucratic black magic” that could poison, or snuff out, a life at a moment’s notice.

headline: Strikes by U.N. and France Corner Leader of Ivory Coast
text: AXIM, Ghana — The United Nations and France went on the offensive Monday against Ivory Coast’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, striking targets at his residence, his offices and two of his military bases in a significant escalation of the international intervention into the political crisis engulfing the nation.

headline: A Comedic TV Talent Turns the Tables on Oprah
text: Meet Zach Anner, a 26-year-old filmmaker from Austin, Tex., who just won his own television show on Oprah Winfrey’s new network. He’s handsome, smart and funny — oh, and he gets around in a wheelchair. Mr. Anner has cerebral palsy, “the sexiest of the palsies,” as he puts it in his audition video.

headline: Opposition in Azerbaijan Vows to Step Up Protests
text: MOSCOW — Opposition leaders in Azerbaijan vowed Monday to step up a nascent protest campaign against the authoritarian government of the former Soviet republic, despite a recent police crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.

headline: Obscure, and Often Devastating
text: It is classified as a rare disease, but the chronic condition called Charcot-Marie-Tooth is one of the most common inherited nerve-related disorders, with an estimated 150,000 patients in the United States. It can be devastating to patients and their families, with crippling effects on balance and the ability to walk and grasp objects. Nor does it help that few people have heard of it, unless they are directly affected.

headline: Measuring Radioactive Elements and Their Effects on Human Cells
text: The damaged nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant in Japan have been releasing radioactive elements into the air and water around the plant. Those elements are dangerous because they are made up of atoms with unstable centers, or nuclei. Seeking greater stability, they constantly emit energy as radiation, in the form of waves like gamma rays or X-rays, and as particles smaller than atoms.

headline: Shutdown Watch: Four Days Out
text: With four days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, the talk grew somewhat more pessimistic on Monday as Republicans declared themselves not satisfied with what Democrats in the Senate were offering. At the same time, President Obama invited lawmakers from both parties to the White House on Tuesday for a last-ditch effort to reach an agreement.

headline: Author’s Heirs Uncensor a Classic War Novel
text: When the classic novel “From Here to Eternity” was published in 1951, a few things were gone that had been in the original manuscript: explicit mentions of gay sex and a number of four-letter words.

headline: Radiation Is Everywhere, but How to Rate Harm?
text: Since the first reports last month of damage to nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the lingering question has been whether drifting plumes of radioactive elements from the plant will harm people in Japan or other parts of the world. For many people, the biggest fear is cancer.

headline: Wolf Crosses the Lake Superior Ice to Become Leader of the Pack
text: In Ontario, in the winter of 1997, a particularly virile male wolf stepped onto the ice of Lake Superior and headed toward Isle Royale, an island about 15 miles offshore. There he radically changed the genetic makeup of an isolated group of wolves that had lived there since the late 1940s.

headline: A Swagger and Some Bluster for the Sake of Telling Stories
text: That the tenor Matthew Polenzani sang Schubert’s song cycle “Die Schöne Müllerin” so beautifully on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall was no surprise. This fine American artist, a regular at the Metropolitan Opera, most recently as Ernesto in Donizetti’s “Don Pasquale” opposite Anna Netrebko, has long been admired for the refinement and expressivity of his singing.

headline: Detained Chinese Artist’s New York Project Will Go On
text: A large-scale public art project by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, to occupy the Pulitzer Fountain outside the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan starting early next month, will go forward even if Mr. Ai, who was detained by Chinese authorities on Sunday, is unable to be present.

headline: 40 Stitches Near His Eye Sideline Bruins’ Thornton, but He Won’t Back Down
text: Boston Bruins forward Shawn Thornton hardly seems fazed by the J-shaped gash over his right eye, or the 40-plus stitches it took to close it.

headline: Detroit’s Orchestra Tentatively Has a Deal
text: Musicians and management have reached a tentative agreement that could end a bitter six-month strike at the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Rental Car Industry Urges Two-Tier System for Vehicle Recalls
text: The American Car Rental Association wants the government to adopt a new system that would designate some recalls as so serious that a vehicle should no longer be driven while others would allow cars to be driven and repaired later.

headline: Louisville Dreaming: Characters Exploring Boundaries
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The American dream is not just a matter of fancy cars, sweet suburban vistas and, as it is imagined today, the prospect of your own reality television show or legion of Twitter followers. Maybe more bewitching is the simple possibility of escaping into a life other than the one you wake up to in the gray dawn. Surely a country founded on the bright hope of man’s infinite potential should allow its citizens the chance to slip into a new identity, a more fulfilling way of being?

headline: Fielder’s Choice (1 Letter)
text: Overstimulated

headline: Lollapalooza Debut in Chile, Speaking Many Tongues
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — National pride and brand expansion made a happy alliance at Lollapalooza Chile, this country’s first full-scale international rock festival and the first Lollapalooza festival held outside the United States.

headline: Liveblogging Bob Hall (Serious Wonks With Paid Subscriptions Only)
text: Update: Here’s the paper (pdf).

headline: Nuclear Reactions (3 Letters)
text: Nuclear Reactions

headline: Overstimulated (1 Letter)
text: Overstimulated

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: KATY B

headline: Claremont Prep Is Sold to For-Profit Firm
text: Claremont Preparatory School, a six-year-old institution in Lower Manhattan that has had difficulty fulfilling its ambitions, is being sold to a private-equity-backed firm, in a sign of growing investor interest in private schools in New York City.

headline: Following Eminem’s Lead, Estate of Rick James Looks for Higher Pay-Out
text: Following a recent court decision that gave Eminem and his producers a higher royalty rate for digital music, the estate of Rick James has filed a class-action suit against the Universal Music Group, saying that the company has failed to properly account for royalties and may owe its artists “tens of millions of dollars.”

headline: N.F.L. Says Second Lawsuit Is Unlikely to Succeed
text: Two days before a hearing on the request for an injunction by players to stop the lockout, the N.F.L. responded Monday to a second antitrust suit filed against it by retired and yet-to-be-drafted players, arguing that it suffers the same “legal deficiencies” as the original request.

headline: Pasta With Fish Sauce
text: Adapted from “Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking” by Marcella Hazan

headline: Cod Optimization, From Head to Tail
text: FROM 2006 to 2009 my family food budget was governed by the convergence of two troubling and important phenomena:

headline: The Rush to Boutique
text: Hotel experts have all sorts of definitions for boutique hotels. “Not cookie cutter,” one said. “Chic,” said another. “100 rooms or less,” said a third.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The French Connection'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at William Friedkin's 1971 drama starring Gene Hackman.

headline: Experienced, Homegrown Educator Leaves City Schools
text: One of the last high officials at the City Department of Education to ascend through the ranks the old-fashioned way — from New York City public school student to teacher to principal to superintendent to deputy chancellor — resigned on Monday after 22 years in the school system.

headline: Q.& A. With Julius Erving
text: Blake Griffin is the reigning dunk champion of the N.B.A., but Julius Erving was the innovator. With his array of spins, leaps and gravity-defying dunks, he won three championships, one in the N.B.A. with the Philadelphia 76ers and two in the American Basketball Association with the Nets. He also won four Most Valuable Player awards in the two leagues and two A.B.A. scoring titles. Erving, who retired in 1987, was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993. Erving, who was honored recently at the Thurman Munson awards in Manhattan, turned 61 earlier this year.

headline: Private Jets Warming Up for Presidential Campaign
text: NOW that President Obama has announced his candidacy for re-election, you can almost hear the jet engines starting to rev up around the country as the most brutal form of business travel — campaigning for president — stirs to life.

headline: Years After Last Call, Keeping a Bar’s History Alive
text: They’ve been shooting at Dermot McEvoy’s regiment for a while. Their aim is now getting distressingly good.

headline: Lacking Big Names, but Not Importance
text: Indianapolis

headline: Amid Rumors She’s Leaving CBS, Couric Heads to Iraq
text: As reports continue to swirl about an impending departure from her anchor position at CBS News, Katie Couric is to embark Tuesday morning on a long-planned trip to Iraq, where she will report on the military and political situation eight years after Baghdad fell to invading American forces.

headline: Cowardice Blocks the 9/11 Trial
text: Last year, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. described a federal court trial for the self-professed mastermind of Sept. 11 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, as “the defining event of my time as attorney general.” On Monday, Mr. Holder’s dream for demonstrating the power of the American court system crumbled when he announced that the trial would take place not in New York City or anywhere in the United States but before a military commission at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prison camp.

headline: Lesbian Judge Chosen for Top Massachusetts Court
text: BOSTON — Gov. Deval Patrick on Monday nominated a lesbian who is married to her partner to serve on the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,506 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: No Party Rentals in Miami Beach? Really?
text: MIAMI BEACH — In this decadent, hard-partying playground, Kirsty Bertarelli’s 40th birthday celebration rivaled the best of them. More than 200 guests flew in from Europe. A caravan of limousines ferried them to the site, a flashy waterfront home. The party rocked until 4:30 a.m. It cost $3 million.

headline: Speedy Trials Sought in Texas Rape Case
text: LIBERTY, Tex. — A state judge said Monday that he would push to hold trials in late July for 14 men accused of repeatedly raping an 11-year-old girl last fall in Cleveland, Tex.

headline: To Cut Smog, Navistar Blazes Risky Path of Its Own
text: MELROSE PARK, Ill. — In a testing cell tucked deep in the bowels of Navistar’s engine plant and technical center here, a hulking prototype of a truck engine sits behind a large glass window like a patient on an operating table. A snarl of sensors and wires is attached to nearly every part of the humming engine, feeding reams of data to a battery of computers and watchful engineers in the adjacent control room.

headline: Google Executive Says Goodbye as Page Says Hello
text: Monday was Larry Page’s first day back as Google’s chief executive, and the management shake-up at the top has already begun.

headline: OMG!!! OED!!! LOL!!!!!
text: It’s wonderful to experience the ongoing corruption and evolution of the English language. Last month, OMG and LOL were inducted into the Oxford English Dictionary, along with the heart symbol — the first time a meaning enters our most exalted linguistic inventory via the T-shirt and bumper sticker.

headline: Mandi Schwartz, Athlete at Center of Marrow Drive, Dies at 23
text: Mandi Schwartz, the Yale hockey player whose struggle with leukemia inspired thousands of people to volunteer to be bone marrow donors, died Sunday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 23.

headline: Court Rejects Suit on Net Neutrality Rules
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Monday rejected as “premature” a lawsuit by Verizon and MetroPCS challenging the Federal Communications Commission’s pending rules aimed at keeping Internet service providers from blocking access to certain Web sites or applications.

headline: Vice Media Empire Is Near a Big Infusion of Cash
text: Vice was born in 1994 as an underground magazine in Montreal, financed by a government subsidy and run by three friends who started their own company because no one else would hire them.

headline: The Mets' New Ace
text: Johan Santana, the premier pitcher in baseball and the new ace of the Mets, dominates the game with a changeup that makes batters bend and buckle.

headline: Feliciano Stung by Mets Pitching Coach’s Comments
text: Pedro Feliciano, the most used pitcher in baseball over the last three seasons, politely disagreed with the assertion of Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman that the Mets “abused” him, but he could not hold back his irritation about the rebuttal from his former pitching coach, Dan Warthen.

headline: Midmajors Find Common Ground, No Matter the Sport
text: HOUSTON — From Butler in basketball to Boise State in football, the so-called midmajor programs of college sports have experienced recent uprisings, challenging the blue-blood programs that have reigned for years.

headline: Knicks Greet the Playoffs With a Sigh of Relief
text: Greenburgh, N.Y.

headline: Talking to No Purpose
text: On Saturday, during halftime at the NCAA semi-finals, a reporter asked the Connecticut coach Jim Calhoun how his team had managed to build up a 10-point lead. He replied, more or less, We played good defense, although we didn’t get enough rebounds. What will you have to do in the second half?, the reporter queried brightly. Add rebounds to the good defense was the answer.

headline: In Race With Groupon, LivingSocial Raises $400 Million
text: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg NewsTim O’Shaughnessy, chief executive of LivingSocial.

headline: 3 Months In, 17% Approval for the Schools Chief
text: Concern about the appointment of Cathleen P. Black as the New York City schools chancellor does not appear to be easing as she approaches her 100th day in office, according to an NY1-Marist poll released on Monday.

headline: Faldo Predicts Success for a Daring Group of Europeans
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Time alternates between standing still and whizzing past in this home of the Masters. It seems like yesterday that 11 European wins from 1980 to 1999 set off a great debate about Europe’s dominance of the tournament.

headline: Sanctions Are Dropped Against Libyan Defector
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration dropped financial sanctions on Monday against the top Libyan official who fled to Britain last week, saying it hoped the move would encourage other senior aides to abandon Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the country’s embattled leader.

headline: Obama Invites Republicans to Meet on Budget
text: WASHINGTON — Trying to head off a crisis, President Obama invited Congressional leaders to the White House for a meeting Tuesday to try to resolve the impasse that is threatening to shutter a large part of the federal government as of Saturday.

headline: U.N. Plane Crashes in Congo, Killing 32
text: LIRA, Uganda — A United Nations plane crashed as it was landing in Kinshasa, Congo, on Monday, killing 32 of the 33 people aboard, United Nations officials said.

headline: UConn Beats Butler to Win N.C.A.A. Title
text: Kemba Walker scored 16 points and Alex Oriakhi added a double-double as the University of Connecticut captured the men’s N.C.A.A. championship with a 53-41 win over Butler. The victory gave Huskies Coach Jim Calhoun his third N.C.A.A. championship and his first since 2004.

headline: Wisconsin Election Is Referendum on Governor
text: MEQUON, Wis. — Until a few weeks ago, this state’s election on Tuesday for a justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court was widely expected to be dull and predictable.

headline: TV Ratings for Men Are Highest Since 2005
text: More people watched the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament through Saturday’s Final Four than in any year since 2005, which makes sense. For the first time, four networks — CBS, TNT, TBS and truTV — have been carrying the tournament, instead of just CBS, as a result of a new CBS-Turner deal that goes through 2024.

headline: After Rape Report in Libya, Woman Sees Benefit in Publicity
text: TRIPOLI — Eman al-Obeidy says the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi victimized her twice. First members of his militia kidnapped and repeatedly raped her. Then his state television network attacked her as a thief and a prostitute.

headline: Back for More, Just Not More of the Same
text: When Brian Duensing did his running last off-season, at home in Omaha, he thought about the Yankees. Naturally, Duensing ran on a treadmill, which is how it must feel sometimes to play for the Minnesota Twins.

headline: To Cut the Deficit, Look to Social Security
text: Chestnut Hill, Mass.

headline: Power Authority Approves Revised Plan for Hudson Cable
text: With a trustee newly appointed by the governor taking the lead, the New York Power Authority on Monday hurriedly approved a revised deal for the construction of an $850 million cable that would carry electricity to Midtown Manhattan from New Jersey.

headline: Israel Indicts Gaza Man on Terror-Linked Counts
text: JERUSALEM — Israel on Monday handed down an indictment against Dirar Abu Sisi, the Gaza engineer who vanished from a train in Ukraine in mid-February, then surfaced in an Israeli prison. He stands accused of developing rockets and missiles on behalf of Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, for use against Israeli civilians and soldiers.

headline: Discovery of 3 More Sets of Remains Adds to L.I. Mystery
text: Investigators on Long Island discovered the remains of three more people on a barrier beach on Monday, bringing the number of remains found nearby to eight since the police began searching for a missing prostitute late last year.

headline: Clemens and Accuser Scolded for Interviews
text: A federal judge scolded Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer Monday for speaking to the news media about Clemens’s pending perjury trial and reminded all parties that they were not to comment publicly about the case.

headline: Fed Help Kept Banks Afloat, Until It Didn’t
text: WASHINGTON — During the frenetic months of the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve stretched the limits of its legal authority by lending money to more than 100 banks that subsequently failed.

headline: Unfair to Immigrants, Costly for Taxpayers
text: EVERY year thousands of immigrants being held on Rikers Island are transferred to federal custody and deported. Only about half of them have a criminal record, many of them are here legally, most of them have their due process rights violated and all of them are subjected to substandard conditions before being returned to their countries of origin.

headline: Hoosier Family Fills Fieldhouse With Pride
text: INDIANAPOLIS — They came to chant, dance, sing, stamp and stand for as long as they believed. They raised their arms for jump shots and free throws as if they were sitting behind the basket in Houston and sounded louder than the crowd in the antiseptic domed football stadium.

headline: Buffett’s Ruthlessness Is Oddly Absent on Sokol
text: Warren E. Buffett has been strangely quiet as speculation of insider trading swirls around his onetime heir apparent, David L. Sokol. Here are some questions.

headline: Ned McWherter, Former Tennessee Governor, Dies at 80
text: Ned McWherter, a sharecropper’s son who as governor of Tennessee cajoled the legislature into passing a sweeping health care overhaul, making it the first state to offer health insurance to every uninsured person who wanted it, died on Monday in Nashville. He was 80.

headline: With Its Move to Coney Island, Flea Market Is Sprucing Up
text: Debbie Quintana-Stiefel knows it is time to expand her palette. Beyond the brown and deep-red lipsticks she carries, she must now add fuchsias and oranges and complementary foundations to satisfy her new customers.

headline: Google Bids $900 Million for Nortel Patent Assets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has bid $900 million for the patent portfolio of Nortel Networks, the Canadian telecom equipment maker, as part of a strategy to defend itself against patent litigation.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 4, 2011

headline: G.O.P. Blueprint Would Remake Health Policy
text: WASHINGTON — The proposal to be unveiled by House Republicans on Tuesday to rein in the long-term costs of Medicaid and Medicare represents a fundamental rethinking of how the two programs work, an ambitious effort by conservatives to address the nation’s fiscal challenges, and a huge political risk.

headline: Who Could Blame G.E.?
text: With tax day fast approaching, many Americans are thinking hard, and perhaps a little creatively, about finding deductions to help lower their tax bills. Nobody, after all, likes paying more taxes than they have to. So why in the world should we expect the mighty General Electric to act any differently?

headline: Expedia and American in a Fare Agreement
text: Consumers searching for flight information will once again be able to find American Airline fares on the Web sites of Expedia and its affiliate, Hotwire — effective immediately — now that the two companies have ended a standoff over fees and how the travel information should be delivered.

headline: At Age 84, a City’s Last Geisha Defies Time and a 4th Tsunami
text: KAMAISHI, Japan — The requests to see her perform had dwindled over the years. But when the earthquake struck at 2:46 p.m. on March 11, this city’s last geisha was, fittingly, at home getting ready to sing that night at Kamaishi’s 117-year-old ryotei, an exclusive restaurant featuring fine food and entertainment where she began working as a 14-year-old seven decades ago.

headline: Men at War
text: Most historians now argue — and contemporary documents bear them out — that the leaders of the Confederacy were, above all, motivated by a desire to protect their system of slavery. Leaving the Union, they believed, was the surest way to preserve an institution that was now threatened by the newly-elected, and self-proclaimed anti-slavery, president, Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Hard Times for Recess
text: More than 150 years ago, Charles Dickens published “Hard Times,” a novel centered around the students of an English schoolmaster named Thomas Gradgrind, who had no use for play or any sort of imaginative pursuit. For Gradgrind, if something did not demonstrably add to the productive capacity of the nation and could not be justified with facts and statistics, it had no place in a child’s education.

headline: Israel and Gaza, 2 Years Ago and Today
text: To the Editor:

headline: West Bank: Actor-Activist Killed by Militants
text: An Israeli-Arab actor and political activist who directed a children’s theater in the West Bank city of Jenin was shot dead in his car by Palestinian militants, the police said. The man, Juliano Mer-Khamis, 52, who led the Freedom Theater in Jenin, was born to an Israeli Jewish mother and a Palestinian Christian father. Although he was an Israeli citizen, he had lived in Jenin for the past seven years. Mr. Mer-Khamis’s mother, a peace activist, had founded the theater. He produced a film in 2004 on his mother’s work called “Arna’s Children,” which was widely praised internationally. The police said they were investigating the attack.

headline: Obama Opens 2012 Campaign, With Eye on Money and Independent Voters
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama did not directly ask supporters to send contributions as he formally opened his re-election bid on Monday. But to build the grass-roots network that he believes is essential to winning a second term, he is preparing to undertake the most ambitious fund-raising effort by a sitting president.

headline: Bikes and the City: Are Lanes the Answer?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Cigarette for 75 Cents, 2 for $1: The Brisk, Shady Sale of ‘Loosies’
text: By 8:30 a.m., amid the procession of sleepy-eyed office workers and addicts from the nearby methadone clinic, Lonnie Loosie plants himself in the middle of the sidewalk on Eighth Avenue in Midtown. Addressing no one in particular, he calls out his one-size-fits-all greeting: “Newports, Newports, packs and loosies.”

headline: Tuesday: What Hailstones Do
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You know that version of Murphy’s Law that says that if you don’t want it to rain, you should carry an umbrella with you at all times?

headline: Unrest in Yemen Seen as Opening to Qaeda Branch
text: WASHINGTON — Counterterrorism operations in Yemen have ground to a halt, allowing Al Qaeda’s deadliest branch outside of Pakistan to operate more freely inside the country and to increase plotting for possible attacks against Europe and the United States, American diplomats, intelligence analysts and counterterrorism officials say.

headline: Texas Instruments to Buy National Semiconductor for $6.5 Billion
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Texas Instruments said Monday that it planned to acquire National Semiconductor for $6.5 billion in a deal that places a big bet on the increasing need to translate the physical world of humans into the digital form of computers and then back again.

headline: Afghan Violence Over the Koran Burning in Florida
A Changed Landscape for Obama
text: A look at the challenges President Obama faces in many states, including those that he flipped from red to blue in 2008.

headline: In Rape Case, Court Is Told Police Officer Didn’t Have Sex
text: A police officer accused of raping a woman in her East Village apartment while on duty in December 2008 built a rapport with the woman during a discussion of alcoholism and had physical contact with her, but they did not have sex, his lawyer argued in court on Monday.

headline: Yankees Find Quality in a Rookie Starter
text: Six months later, the little things come easier for Ivan Nova. How to get to and from Yankee Stadium no longer vexes him. Figuring out what to pack is not a chore. And as a result, when big moments arrive — the sixth inning of the Yankees’ 4-3 victory Monday against the Minnesota Twins, for instance — Nova is better equipped to handle them.

headline: Prospal and Late Goals Boost Rangers’ Chances
text: Johnny Boychuk, a defenseman for the Boston Bruins, tried whisking the puck out of the goal before anyone could notice. He fooled no one. Michael Sauer’s third goal of the season counted, and the Rangers’ stunning, dramatic and last-ditch comeback was complete.

headline: Iraq: 4 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq
text: Four United States soldiers have been killed in Iraq in recent days, two from enemy attack and two from what the American military called a “non-hostile incident” in the north. Two were killed on Saturday from mortar or rocket fire. According to icasualties.org, 14 Americans have been killed in Iraq this year, eight of them from enemy fire.

headline: Russia: Rocket Launch Marks 50 Years of People in Space
text: Final preparations were underway Monday evening at the Baikonur space center to launch a rocket in honor of the 50th anniversary of the flight of the first person in space, Yuri A. Gagarin. Two Russian cosmonauts and an American astronaut are scheduled to ride the Yuri Gagarin rocket into orbit, on their way to the International Space Station; the honorary naming was a departure from the usual Russian practice of numbering rockets. The rocket, scheduled to launch before Tuesday, also has a portrait of Mr. Gagarin painted on the side. He was only 27 years old when he made his first and only journey into space, and he later died in a jet airplane crash. The Soyuz model booster was being fueled Monday evening on the same launch pad where Mr. Gagarin blasted off on his flight on April 12, 1961, which began with his words “Let’s go.”

headline: Conflicts of Interest in Medicine
Henry Taub, a Founder of a Payroll Firm That Became a Global Giant, Dies at 83
text: Henry Taub, a founder of the payroll company that grew into the global giant Automatic Data Processing, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

headline: Foreclosure Assistance
A Wonder on Two Wheels
text: When the Mets broke camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla., last week, they took with them the hope for a successful season, a remade bullpen, and a special rolling box replete with items from the vital to the absurd to go in that bullpen. Mr. Met has for decades been the lovable and irreplaceable symbol for the organization, but this year, the bullpen will have a mascot of its own, known affectionately as Stosh.

headline: Problems With Radioactive Water at the Plant
text: Radioactive water is leaking from the power company in Japan and there’s no place to store it.

headline: Moment of Truth
text: It was a season of fiscal perestroika. Last fall, the Simpson-Bowles deficit commission released a bold report on how to avoid an economic catastrophe. For a few weeks, the think tanks and government offices were alive with proposals to reduce debt and reform entitlements, the tax code and just about every other government program.

headline: Sokol’s Ways Questioned in Past Suits
text: Lawsuits involving David L. Sokol after he joined Berkshire Hathaway suggest that management had some warnings about his rules-pushing nature long before his resignation last week for buying stock in a company shortly before Berkshire acquired it.

headline: Union-Bashing, Now in Ohio
text: This is Ohio’s new concept of how to deal fairly with its public employees: Make them an offer, and if they don’t accept it, impose it anyway. There will be no appeal or arbitration. And unions will no longer be able to negotiate their health-care benefits or require the payment of dues from members.

headline: The Dollars and Cents of Bats and Farming
text: Putting a dollar value on nature and the services it provides isn’t easy. Such numbers can show how much our human economy depends on nature’s indiscernible economy. Take bats. A study in Science magazine reveals just how important they are to American agriculture.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Evil Yankees
text: Noam Scheiber, left, of The New Republic and Rich Lowry of National Review debate hating the New York Yankees.

headline: Small Airplane Lands in Waves on Beach in Queens
text: A small airplane made an emergency landing in the Rockaways on Monday night, touching down where the beach meets the water. No one was injured in the landing, and the plane was not damaged.

headline: Pressure on China to Release Dissident Artist
text: BEIJING — The United States, France, Britain and Germany on Monday called on China to release Ai Weiwei, an internationally known artist and increasingly vocal government critic. Mr. Ai was led away by police officers as he tried to board a plane at Beijing International Airport on Sunday morning and he has not been heard from since.

headline: UConn Men Top Butler to Capture Third Title
text: HOUSTON — Coming off a season in which it lost in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament, the Connecticut basketball team was under N.C.A.A. investigation, was picked to finish 10th in the Big East and had a roster filled with inexperienced and unproven players. When the Huskies finished ninth in the Big East, their star guard, Kemba Walker, joked that they had exceeded expectations.

headline: A Growing Population, and Target, for Marketers
text: IT has been said that in America, a minority group has not truly arrived until it has been marketed to. That was true for African-Americans, gay men and lesbians and, most recently, consumers who speak Spanish.

headline: In Ragged Finale, Walker Proves Good Enough
text: HOUSTON — After this college basketball season ended, Connecticut guard Kemba Walker climbed atop the stage on the court at Reliant Stadium. He danced. He clapped. He did the robot. Out poured all the emotion he had accumulated over the past month, the product of 11 wins in UConn’s final 11 games, of carrying a young team from a ninth-place Big East finish to the pinnacle of his sport.

headline: Antitrust Fears Slow Google Takeovers to a Crawl
text: Google has so far announced only $200 million of takeovers for 2011, the smallest sum since 2008. Acquisitions are being slowed by fears of antitrust regulatory delays.

headline: Frustrated Bulldogs Go Out With a Clang
text: HOUSTON — Butler arrived at the national championship stage because of its scrappy identity built on rebounding, defense and hard work. The Bulldogs were never that pretty. But they were never uglier than on Monday in the national championship game.

headline: Another Plane Mishap Forces Landing
text: A flight attendant was making the usual announcements about snacks and in-flight entertainment as United Airlines flight 497 soared past 4,000 feet flight early Monday morning. Suddenly the public address system went dead. And so did the lights.

text: A look at Connecticut’s 53-41 victory over Butler for the N.C.A.A. Division I basketball championship.

headline: Previewing the Champions League Quarterfinals
text: The UEFA Champions League returns this week with four first-leg quarterfinal matches. On Tuesday, Real Madrid hosts Tottenham and Inter Milan hosts Schalke. Wednesday’s games have Shakhtar Donetsk at Barcelona and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge to face Chelsea. All the games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern, and will be broadcast either on Fox Soccer Channel or Fox Sports Net.

headline: Ivory Coast Leader Swayed by Force as He Considers Exit
text: TAKORADI, Ghana — Holed up in a bunker under his residence, Ivory Coast’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, negotiated the terms of his potential surrender on Tuesday, as opposition forces closed in, his generals called on their forces to lay down their arms and French and United Nations negotiators demanded that he officially renounce control of the country.

headline: Regulators Set to Reject Merger of Singapore and Australia Exchanges
text: The $7.9 billion takeover of the Australian stock exchange by the Singapore Exchange teetered on the verge of collapse on Tuesday after Australia said it planned to block the deal, setting an ominous example for the big mergers currently under review in Europe and North America.

headline: Would People Join an ‘Atheist Club’ in Your School?
text: A recent article describes a high school in a Bible Belt Florida town that has an after-school club for atheists. The article also reports that atheist clubs have been springing up at more and more high schools. How do you think such a club would be greeted at your school? Would you attend any of the club’s events, or even become a member? Why or why not?

headline: Company Says Radioactive Water Leak at Japan Plant Is Plugged
text: TOKYO — The company that runs Japan’s crippled nuclear power plant announced Wednesday that it had stopped the leak of tons of highly radioactive water into the ocean discovered over the weekend. The news came a day after the company said the levels of radioactive material in the seawater near the plant were measured at several million times the legal limit.

headline: Who Made Those Chocolate Wrappers?
text: The story of Mast Brothers Chocolate is one of family and one of craft. Rick and Michael Mast, the young owners and proprietors of the company, make organic, artisanal sweets in their Brooklyn-based confectionery. They take great care with their ingredients (cacao beans imported directly from South America), their manufacturing process (time-honored techniques alongside custom-built machinery by a former aerospace engineer) and even their packaging.

headline: Kaiser Permanente Opens Clinic in Washington
text: Just days after the Obama administration unveiled regulations on how doctors and hospitals can band together to offer coordinated care, Kaiser Permanente will open on Tuesday a demonstration center near the Capitol Building to show what it believes such coordination should look like.

headline: More Body Armor for the iPhone
text: There must be an awful lot of klutzes out there, or a large number of fearful people, judging by the number of super-shock resistant iPhone cases now on the market. In addition to the Ballistic HC case reported by my colleague, Roy Furchgott, in March, as well as the rugged iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch Otterbox cases, comes a new entry from Griffin, a well-known maker of accessories for PCs, MP3 players and smartphones.

headline: Government Forces Fire On Protesters in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Security forces and armed men in civilian clothes clashed with antigovernment demonstrators in the city of Taiz on Tuesday, opening fire on crowds calling for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down, witnesses said. It was the third straight day of violence in Taiz, where more than 10 protesters were killed by gunfire on Monday.

headline: China’s Central Bank Raises Interest Rates
text: SHANGHAI — China raised interest rates on Tuesday for the fourth time in six months, the latest move aimed at reining in inflation and a looming property bubble and slowing an economy that is threatening to overheat.

headline: Endorse-It-Yourself Headphones
text: Plenty of people wear headphones endorsed by a celebrity. Now V-Moda has a customization program that lets you wear headphones endorsed by you.

headline: Anti-Intellectualism in America, Then and Now
text: As a quasi extension of our occasional What We’re Reading posts, I will report that just this morning I started “Anti-Intellectualism in American Life,” by the historian Richard Hofstadter, a book that won the Pulitzer Prize in 1964 and that seemed as if it might have a thing or two to say about the current moment. (Full disclosure: Lest I be accused of publicly putting on airs, I should also point out that I recently read “So Far …, ” the midcareer autobiography of Kelsey Grammer, a book that is definitely worth judging by its cover.)

headline: For Patients With Dementia, Hands-On Comfort
text: You can see the logic. Old people with dementia can become frightened and restless, angry or agitated. Reiki, a Japanese healing practice that supposedly channels a universal energy, is said to be soothing and deeply relaxing. So why not offer reiki to elderly dementia patients?

headline: Libya’s Rebel Forces Need More Than Just Weapons

headline: Groundhog Day on the Budget
text: Like Atrios, I am not looking forward to this. It’s going to be just like the Social Security fight, only worse: once again, Very Serious People will pretend not to notice that the Republican plan is a giant game of bait-and-switch, dismantling a key piece of the social safety net in favor of a privatized system, claiming that this is necessary to save money, but never acknowledging that privatization in itself actually costs money. And we’ll have endless obfuscation, both-sides-have-a-point reporting that misses the key point, which is that the putative savings come entirely from benefit cuts somewhere in the distant future that would, in all likelihood, never actually materialize. (What do you think will happen when retirees in 2025 discover that their Medicare vouchers aren’t enough to buy insurance?)

headline: Tuesday Reading: Rental Car Firms Seek Special Recall Rules
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Nobel Laureate Loses Last Legal Battle to Save Job at Bank
text: NEW DELHI — Muhammad Yunus, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and Bangladeshi microfinance pioneer who popularized the notion of giving tiny loans to the poor, lost his legal battle on Tuesday to hold on to his job as managing director of the bank he created more than 30 years ago.

headline: Statues of Limitations
text: Plenty of sports owners tell their fans to go to hell. But they tend to do it in some sort of euphemistic way — unloading a star, raising ticket prices, moving the team to another city under cover of the night. They don’t usually just say, “Go to hell.”

headline: Jürgen Mayer H. | Pattern Recognition
text: Jürgen Mayer H. has been on a roll. Ever since winning the prestigious Audi Urban Future Award last fall, the 45-year-old architect — who is based in Berlin and who is known for his sometimes challenging experiments (both visually and technologically) with shape and color — is racking up one plum commission after the other. There is the inauguration of a new airport in Mestia, Georgia (the country, not the state); a special line of asymmetrical eyewear (looks better than it sounds); and last week, after almost seven years of planning and construction and much political wrangling, the opening of his biggest project to date, the Metropol Parasol, a 150,000-square-foot mushroom-shaped, mixed-use public plaza in the heart of Seville, Spain. Made of polyurethane-coated timber, it successfully marries an archaeological site with a farmers’ market, multiple bars and restaurants, and a terrace with breathtaking views of the Andalusian capital.

headline: The Private Equity Parallels With Buffett
text: Since the story broke over questionable stock trades by David L. Sokol, a former top lieutenant to Warren E. Buffett, DealBook has heard from a range of people about the controversy.

headline: The Investor Who Missed Out on the Chip Deal
text: Shareholders of National Semiconductor are uncorking the Champagne after hearing the news that Texas Instruments has agreed to pay $6.5 billion for the company, about 78 percent above where its shares closed on Monday.

headline: Calling Dr. Fine: Sean Hayes to Play Larry in ‘Three Stooges’ Movie
text: It was always clear that Larry Fine was pretty good with a Stradivarius, but who knew he was a song and dance man too? Sean Hayes, the “Will and Grace” star, Tony Awards show host and Tony-nominated performer for last year’s revival of “Promises, Promises,” is set to play Larry, the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing member of the Three Stooges in a new “Three Stooges” movie to be directed by Bobby and Peter Farrelly (“There’s Something About Mary,” “Hall Pass”). The Hollywood Reporter said that Mr. Hayes will join Will Sasso, of “Mad TV” and “$#*! My Dad Says,” who is set to play the follicularly deficient Curly Howard. The  movie  is not a biographical film and will instead feature a slapstick trio in new comedy sketches based on the original Stooges.  It has already taken a few eye gouges en route to the big screen: at one time, the planned cast included Sean Penn as Larry, Jim Carrey as Curly and Benicio Del Toro as Moe, but that fell apart like a high-society pie dinner after Mr. Penn withdrew from the project. A new actor to play Moe and a release date for “The Three Stooges” ain’t yet soiten (and they haven’t been determined either).

headline: Supreme Court Issues Stay of Execution
text: The United States Supreme Court on Tuesday granted a temporary stay of execution to Cleve Foster, a former Army recruiter who was convicted of killing a woman he met in a Fort Worth bar.

headline: Facebook Effect
text: One of the most frequent questions on my book tour has been, “Do you think the increasing use of Facebook, texting and tweeting damages genuine social interaction?”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The French Connection’
text: This week A. O. Scott looks back at  “The French Connection. The 1971 film follows the New York City police detective Popeye Doyle (Gene Hackman) as he goes after Brooklyn drug dealers and uncovers an international drug ring. “The French Connection” was based on a real-life case that the director, William Friedkin, “stripped down and also opened up,” Mr. Scott said. “He focuses on the details of police work and puts together car chases that have become the stuff of cinematic legend.” Have you seen “The French Connection?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Highballs and High Art
text: The current fads for artisanal liquor, louche bars and everything ‘‘Mad Men’’ must have inspired ‘‘Cocktail Culture: Ritual and Invention in American Fashion, 1920-1980,’’ an exhibition that opens Friday (and continues through July) at the Museum of Art at the Rhode Island School of Design. It features more than 220 artifacts, including a Dansk ice bucket, a Norman Bel Geddes soda siphon, Paco Rabanne purses and lots of little black dresses (as well as the red one shown below, by Norman Norell). The show begins in the 1920s, when American cocktail culture was mostly confined to the home, and the French, with their beaded cocktail dresses and René Lalique Art Deco glass, set the standard for a night on the town. But the most durable pieces, the ones that you’d still want to break out for guests today, date from the 1950s, when every hour was happy hour and cocktail design was strained through a Modernist sieve. Consider Donald Colflesh’s 1959 silver-plated pitcher for Gorham (below), whose sleek form seems to respond only to one request, essential and elegant: martini, straight up.

headline: Economic Diversity at Harvard (Cont.)
text: Harvard officials have responded to The Chronicle of Higher Education’s recent chart on economic diversity at top colleges — which I wrote about last week — and have made some good points. The brief version: Harvard’s undergraduate student body is more economically diverse than The Chronicle’s numbers suggested. It’s still not very diverse, but it has become more diverse in the last few years.

headline: Budget Stances Harden as Deadline Nears for Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday flatly dismissed a short-term Republican plan to keep the federal government operating past Friday as Speaker John A. Boehner sought deeper spending cuts, putting Congress and the White House on a course toward a government shutdown.

headline: The House Republicans' 2012 Budget Proposal
text: The House Republicans’ budget blueprint for 2012, to be issued by the chairman of the Budget Committee, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, would slice more than $5 trillion from projected federal spending in the coming decade.

headline: The 2022 Medicare Crisis
text: Matt Yglesias has a very good point: the supposed transition strategy under the Ryan plan, in which everyone currently over 55 gets Medicare as we know it, while everyone younger than that gets vouchers that won’t be enough to buy adequate insurance, sets up an unstable political dynamic. In fact, we can be sure that whatever happens, it won’t be what the plan says will happen.

The area’s aquatic network has been designated one of the nation’s Great Waters by a consortium of conservation groups called the America’s Great Waters Coalition.

headline: Endgame in Ivory Coast on YouTube

headline: Strong Storms Sweep Across South, Killing at Least 9
text: At least nine people died and tens of thousands were left without power Tuesday as a result of powerful spring storms that swept through several Southern states.

headline: Composer’s Eiffel Tower Plan Is Approved
text: Dogged efforts by the composer Joseph Bertolozzi to turn the Eiffel Tower into one big musical instrument are paying off. Mr. Bertolozzi, who has created a piece of music by harvesting percussive sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said he recently received approval from the Eiffel Tower Operating Company (the Société d’Exploitation de la Tour Eiffel) to record samples from the tower. The samples would then be assembled into a piece of music, with the ultimate goal of performing it live on the tower itself. Mr. Bertolozzi traveled to Paris in the fall to present his project, and he received a letter of approval last month. The tower operating company said it was open to the idea of a live concert but was making no promises. Now, Mr. Bertolozzi said, all he has to do is raise the money. He said his aim was to have performances in 2014, the tower’s 125th anniversary.

headline: Live: the Blockbuster Auction

headline: Paul Ryan and the Triumph of Policy
text: You do not have to like the long-term budget that Paul Ryan and the House Republicans have released this morning. There’s plenty in the plan for liberals to hate, moderates to doubt, and conservatives to question. But you do have to respect it. As my colleague David Brooks writes today, it is “the most comprehensive and most courageous budget reform proposal any of us have seen in our lifetimes.” It puts flesh on the bones of the standard-issue conservative pledge to limit government’s growth, and it does so not with evasive pledges on process (like the risible idea of a balanced budget amendment) or dishonest suggestions that the deficit can be erased by defunding N.P.R. and slashing foreign aid, but by attacking entitlement spending deeply and directly. George W. Bush touched the third rail of American politics with his Social Security gambit, and lived to regret it. With their proposal to transform Medicare from an open-ended entitlement to a system that provides support for seniors’ premiums, Ryan and the Republicans are reaching out and grabbing it with both hands. In the process, they are being brutally honest with the American people, in ways that the Obama White House has repeatedly refused to be, about the scale of the deficit challenge and the scope of the reforms needed to address it.

headline: Britain Arrests 2 in Phone-Hacking Case
text: LONDON — Scotland Yard said Tuesday that two journalists had been arrested, questioned and released on bail in the renewed inquiry into a five-year-old case involving illegal hacking of celebrity voice mail by The News of the World, the gossip-driven tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch that is one of Britain’s most widely circulated newspapers.

headline: Remembering Larry Finch, Memphis’s Pivotal Figure

But when Finch would tell these stories, he was always laughing.

headline: The Problem With Deficit Solutions Like Representative Ryan’s
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan,  Republican from Wisconsin, released a dramatic new deficit-reduction proposal Tuesday, one that would slash $5.8 trillion from spending levels over the next decade. Among the more controversial highlights is a cap on Medicare and Medicaid spending, by giving individual Medicare recipients vouchers of a certain amount, and block grants to states for Medicaid. The pundit consensus seems to be that Mr. Ryan’s plan will be the framework for thinking about how to resolve budget issues — in David Brooks’s words, “the standard of seriousness for anybody who wants to play in this discussion.”

This is not the kind of gender gap that makes headlines in the West — related to jobs, salaries, and the like, but a more profound one. Read a Wall Street Journal blog post by Diksha Sahni for a solid review.

headline: Kate Bush Has Permission to Use Words of James Joyce
text: Molly Bloom’s wandering soliloquy in James Joyce’s “Ulysses” was the inspiration for “The Sensual World,” the title song from Kate Bush’s 1989 album, but at the time the Joyce estate would not give her approval to use the words in her lyrics. Now Ms. Bush has received the long-awaited permission to use the text, and she has rerecorded the song, which she renamed “Flower of the Mountain,” according to BBC News. Ms. Bush said she was “delighted” to have the chance “to fulfill the original concept.” The new track will be released in May on “Director’s Cut,” her first new album in six years.

headline: Stage Beauty | Tamaryn
text: The shoegazer singer Tamaryn, who started a North American tour with the Raveonettes last week, has learned a thing or two about stage makeup. “I don’t always use primer on my eyes, and I never wear powder — I like everything to be a little dewy and sexual looking,” said the singer during a pretour shopping spree in SoHo. (Stops included M.A.C. and Sephora.) She recently discovered Super, Dr. Nicolas Perricone’s new collection, at its flagship in Berkeley, Calif. — the band is based in San Francisco — and swears by the First Blush Brightening Serum: “I’ve been using it over makeup to set it and have a bit of a glow.” Other must-haves include Osis Mattifying Powder (“I sprinkle it in my hair and it looks teased”), Stila Kajal Eye Pencil in black (“looks better the next day”), Frederic Malle Une Rose (“androgynous but romantic — plus the traditional Goth girl scent is rose water”) and Tom Ford Bruised Plum Lip Color (“it’s like neu-Goth, because it’s sheer”). But the singer is always looking to evolve with her look: “I really want to start wearing brown lipstick. I’ve been watching a lot of ‘My So-Called Life’ lately, and they all have that brown lipstick! I think the ’90s are what it’s all about right now.”

headline: Teaching Women to Think Like Angels
text: The overwhelmingly male field of angel investing is about to become a bit more diverse. Ten women, including some business owners (TechCrunch has the full list), will soon learn the secrets of angel investing during the Pipeline Fund Fellowship’s inaugural six-month program for aspiring female angels. Beginning this month, the group, chosen from among 50 applicants, will attend monthly workshops on issues like due diligence and valuation, and will be paired with mentors who are seasoned male and female investors. The program, held in New York, will culminate with an investment by the group in a women-led, profit-making, socially conscious venture.

headline: Birthday Time
text: Let’s say it is your friend’s birthday. Should you ask her what she wants and simply buy her that present, or should you thoughtfully think of something yourself and surprise her? An article in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology suggests the first route is best. Francesca Gino and Francis Flynn conducted 5 separate studies and found that people were more pleased by gifts they explicitly requested. They were also quite pleased by gifts of cash. Givers believe that people like surprises but giftees just want what they want.

headline: ‘Dancing’ Carries ABC Again in Ratings
text: A two-hour installment of “Dancing With the Stars” attracted an average of 21.4 million viewers on Monday, lifting ABC to first place in the night’s ratings ahead of CBS and its college basketball coverage, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although final audience figures for CBS’s live broadcast of the N.C.A.A. men’s championship game were not immediately available on Tuesday, preliminary overnight estimates were down slightly compared with last year, when 23.9 million watched the title matchup on CBS. Despite that modest decline, the game’s ratings were still high enough that CBS might have led the night over all were it not for lower ratings preceding the basketball coverage for sitcom reruns at 8 and 8:30, “The Big Bang Theory” (9.6 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (7.4 million). The repeats lagged in comparison with ABC’s 10 p.m. audience for “Castle” (11.7 million) following “Dancing With the Stars.” NBC ranked third with “Harry’s Law” at 10 (7.4 million) following a rerun of “Chuck” at 8 (2.5 million) and “The Event” at 9 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of “House” (4.4 million) and “The Chicago Code” (3.9 million).

headline: The Course Is the Star of a Celebrity’s Game
text: As a multiracial American who likes golf, I once revered Tiger Woods from afar. Then, after meeting him and learning that he could talk about video games the way a normal dude does, I thought I actually liked him as a person. So when he humiliated his wife and family (not to mention himself) in front of the entire planet with his spectacular sexual self-immolation, I was as disgusted and disillusioned as any fan could be. Heading into this week’s Masters tournament, I am not rooting against him. But for whatever trouble he is having getting his game and his life back together, I, like millions of others, have zero sympathy.

headline: Growing Body Count, but Search for a Woman Goes On
text: It began as a simple search for a missing prostitute named Shannan Gilbert, who had disappeared in May, and has evolved into a grisly murder mystery. The remains of eight people have now been discovered on a several-mile stretch of the Long Island shore, and the search will continue on Wednesday — for clues, evidence and, her family fears, perhaps the body of Ms. Gilbert.

headline: New York Philharmonic Cancels Cuba Trip
text: The New York Philharmonic has yet again canceled a proposed trip to Cuba, and this time it may be for keeps. The orchestra was tentatively planning to go in June, but no charter planes big enough to take it were available, said the Philharmonic spokesman, Eric Latzky. In addition, the school year will have ended, making it too difficult to gather children for a planned youth concert, he said.

headline: Estrogen Lowers Breast Cancer and Heart Attack Risk in Some
text: In a finding that challenges the conventional wisdom about the risks of some hormones used in menopause, a major government study has found that years after using estrogen-only therapy, certain women had a markedly reduced risk of breast cancer and heart attack.

headline: Wind is Not For the Birds
text: The American Bird Conservancy has posted video of a vulture being struck and maimed by a wind turbine blade. The move is part of a campaign seeking “bird smart” design and deployment of this energy option.

headline: Twitter Lit
text: Marjorie Garber, a professor of English literature at Harvard, who, in addition to several books on Shakespeare, has given us critical studies on dog love, cross-dressing and sex and real estate, has a new book out about why literature matters. If the study of literature has come under fire of late (not least because of the critical practices of professors like Garber), in her latest, “The Use and Abuse of Literature,” she sounds much like the humanists of yore.

headline: Steinhardt Talks of Buffett’s ‘Snow Job’
text: Michael H. Steinhardt, chairman of Wisdom Tree Investments, describes Warren E. Buffett as a master of public relations, who has conned much of the public and the media. In an interview with CNBC, Mr. Steinhardt asserted that David L. Sokol’s resignation amid allegations of insider trading was a “common American practice,” but that it was rare for Mr. Buffett’s organization to be caught up in such an affair.

headline: 1099 Repeal Passes Senate, Heads to White House

In voting to approve the bill, the Senate agreed to adopt a House Republican measure that Democrats viewed as an effort to undermine their health care law. Nonetheless, the bill passed the Senate by a lopsided 87 to 12 — with most Democrats voting in favor. Shortly after the vote, the White House signaled that President Obama would sign the repeal.

text: WASHINGTON — Even as Wall Street churned out mortgage-backed securities and derivatives in 2006, the sellers of the often-convoluted packages sometimes knew that parts of the deals — namely those that they could not sell — were worth far less than face value.

headline: Mickelson Mourns a Storm Casualty on Magnolia Lane
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The entranceway to Augusta National Golf Club, known as Magnolia Lane, dates to the 1850s. And the 61 massive magnolia trees that flank the 330-yard road leading to the clubhouse were grown from seeds planted in the same antebellum period.

headline: George Hill and the Green Light
text: Within 15 seconds of entering Sunday’s game against the Phoenix Suns, George Hill had made his first basket. After 35 seconds more, he had made another. Minutes later, Hill was in the midst of a full-blown explosion, as he dropped a pair of pull-up three-pointers, hit a short jumper, and then successfully executed the patented, controversial “rip move” to earn three foul shots and pull off an 11-2 run all on his own. Toss in an extra basket and a technical free throw, and Hill concluded his six-minute stint in the first quarter with 16 points and spotless shooting from the field and the free throw line.

headline: Recipes for Ribs
text: Different flavors and preparations for ribs.

headline: Finding Many Ways to View One Myth
text: Handel liked the myth of Acis and Galatea so much that he set it to music twice, and did plenty of tinkering with both versions. As told in Ovid’s “Metamorphoses,” the story is simple and brief: the shepherd Acis and the sea nymph Galatea are happily in love, but the Cyclops Polyphemus loves Galatea too. When Galatea rejects him, Polyphemus squashes Acis with a boulder, whereupon Galatea transforms her lover into a fountain.

headline: Merkel's Coalition Partner Chooses a New Leader
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s center-right government received a much-needed boost Tuesday after the Free Democrats, her coalition partners, quickly ended an internal leadership feud and chose a popular young physician to revive the party’s standing in time for the next federal elections, in 2013.

headline: Discharges, Dropouts and Piles of Paperwork
text: When the state comptroller began an audit of the city’s high school dropout rate, there was some expectation that its findings would be explosive. It was started after allegations that the city might be artificially plumping up the graduation rate through a paperwork sleight-of-hand, classifying some students who had dropped out as “discharges,” meaning they simply left the school for another school. While dropouts are counted against the graduation rate, discharges are not.

headline: Old Hand and a New One Crossing Paths in Harmony
text: For those who have followed the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter since her days as a bright young protégée of the imposing German conductor Herbert von Karajan, watching her become a mentor and benefactor in her own right has a special resonance. Her own fame secure, Ms. Mutter, 47, is devoting time to fostering a new generation of musicians.

headline: Viewership Falls for Men’s N.C.A.A. Final
text: Connecticut’s 53-41 win over Butler in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship game Monday night attracted an average of 20.1 million viewers, down 19 percent from last year’s 23.9 million when Duke beat Butler by 2 points in a more compelling game.

text: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi battered rebel fighters on the road outside a strategic oil town Tuesday.

headline: Devilish Job, for a Slacker or a Schemer
