headline: Ban Is Proposed on Including Toys With Unhealthful Meals
text: Inspired by San Francisco’s “happy meal” ban on toys and other items from meals that don’t comply with certain nutritional standards, City Room reports, a City Council member from Queens is proposing that New York City restaurants not be allowed to offer such items with meals that have more than 500 calories and more than 600 milligrams of sodium, and that get more than 35 percent of their calories from fat. The meals would also have to include one-half cup of fruit or vegetables, or one serving of whole-grain products.

headline: Sandra Lee, Governor’s Girlfriend, to Sell Home Products Line
text: As her boyfriend, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, is busy preaching austerity and sticking close to home, the domestic goddess Sandra Lee is expanding her empire, which already includes a magazine, two Food Network television shows and 23 cookbooks. Next up: Sandra by Sandra Lee, a collection of home products that will be sold at Sears and Kmart stores next spring.

headline: An Academic Hit Man Brings More Bad News
text: This book began its life as a fizzy essay, published in The Atlantic Monthly in 2008, that contained at its core, like a radioactive pellet, a seemingly uncontroversial argument: Not every American kid is cut out for college.

headline: Hempstead, in Protest, Is Severing Ties With Chase
text: The village of Hempstead on Long Island is pulling its money from JPMorgan Chase and severing its ties with the bank to protest lending and foreclosure policies, according to local officials there.

headline: That ’80s Moment When Nothing and (Almost) Everything Mattered
text: Céline Danhier’s “Blank City” uses conventional documentary methods — talking-head reminiscences intercut with clips from the archives — to explore the work of a group of aggressively anticonventional artists. This is not a criticism. The movie is about the iconoclastic filmmakers clustered in the East Village and Lower East Side of Manhattan in the late 1970s and early ’80s. The chaotic, fast-moving, hazily remembered scene they created deserves and benefits from the scholarly consideration Ms. Danhier offers. A dogged journalist and a careful, enthusiastic cultural historian, she illuminates a hectic and fascinating place and time, bringing it back to life and tracing its continuing influence.

headline: Steven Sebring’s Downtown Faces
text: Fine art and fashion make a pretty agreeable cocktail. For the photographer Steven Sebring, each is an ingredient in a body of work that spans several decades and a multitude of photographic techniques. Mr. Sebring takes a painterly approach to portraiture in his current show of monumentally scaled images of American cultural icons — poets as he calls them — who have left indelible mark on the Manhattan’s downtown culture. Viewed at close range, his subjects radiate light like stained glass — hence the title of the show, “Illuminations,” at Milk Studios in Chelsea. At a distance, the features of his subjects — writers and musicians including Jim Carroll, Joey Ramone, Richard Hell and Patti Smith — seem almost animated, swimming into focus as the viewer backs away.

headline: After Months of Turmoil, Tiny Virginia Quarterly Review Is an Awards Finalist
text: The New Yorker received nine nominations for National Magazine Awards, the most for any publication this year, the American Society of Magazine Editors announced on Tuesday.

headline: Wasserman Schultz Picked as D.N.C. Chairwoman
text: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida was named Tuesday as the new chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, with President Obama selecting her to lead the party’s fund-raising and organizational efforts heading into the 2012 election cycle.

headline: Personal Worship
text: Kevin O’Callaghan, an instructor at New York’s School of Visual Arts, not long ago came across an auction on eBay at 3 in the morning for church pews and interior elements from a church in Newark. Any interested party had exactly 24 hours to bid or the items would be destroyed. On a whim, O’Callaghan put in a bid for $500 for the entire church interior and, to his surprise, he won. Within 24 hours, with the help of his students, he drove away with 32 pews in a 24-foot truck and brought them to a workshop at the school.

headline: Bed Check | Soho House Berlin
text: First timers to East Berlin expecting rough trade and post-communist punk life are in for a shock when they arrive in the gentrified orbit of Mitte. Now the neighborhood is crammed with fashion boutiques, gourmet coffeehouses and, most recently, high-style hotels. Casa Camper opened last January, with 51 brightly colored rooms, an Asian tapas restaurant and a 24-hour rooftop lounge. Then the Weinmeister came along afterward, with oversize beds and a crowd of hard-partying creative types.

headline: In Corporate Disclosure, a Murky Definition of Material
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Time for an Uprising by Cisco Shareholders
text: Cisco Systems makes a juicy target for an activist assault — and the chief executive, John T. Chambers, seems to know it. True, most presumptuous investors don’t have the means to build a significant stake in the $100 billion technology giant. But Cisco’s poor performance, valuable assets, cash pile and years of capital misallocation provide the kindling to spark long-suffering shareholders into an uprising.

headline: France's Military Lead
text: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen analyzes the possible reasons for President Nicolas Sarkozy's aggressive strategy in Libya and Ivory Coast.

headline: Champions League: Can Inter and Tottenham Survive?
text: Schalke and Real Madrid will be hard-pressed to squander their prodigious leads after the first leg of their quarterfinal series in the UEFA Champions League.

headline: Put Your Money Where Your Taste Is
text: THE other guy in LimoLand was named Alvaro, I think. That’s what it sounded like from inside the fitting room, where I’d heard him come into the store and begin asking about the brand. It was too youthful for him, he thought. Too colorful. By this time I’d gotten a glimpse: he was Balazs-like, crisp and certain, but taller. He had some time on his hands. He was curious. The woman behind the register pointed out a photo book that piqued his interest.

headline: Miles of Aisles, Endless Opportunities to Save
text: The neighborhood Gristedes, the local Food Emporium: they’re your enemies. The prices are inflated, the selection is limited. And those aisles! It’s as if they don’t want two perfectly reasonable people to peruse the cookies at the same time. (Um, I mean whole-grain cereals, of course. And fruit.)

headline: Signs of Repression in Tripoli on the Faces of Two Women
text: Since she was dragged away from foreign journalists in a Tripoli hotel ten days ago, Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan lawyer who wanted to tell the world that she had been gang-raped by government security forces, has become an icon of resistance to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s rule.

headline: A NASA Ode to a Color-Sensing Satellite
text: NASA has produced a very nice video tribute to the SeaWiFS orbiting sensor, which provided vast amounts of valuable data on Earth’s waters, plant life and weather from 1997 through 2010. The video is narrated by Gene Feldman, an oceanographer at the Goddard Space Flight Center:

headline: A Long Swim Looking for Laughs
text: “The Umbrella Plays,” as befits its title, is full of waterworks. There are, most arrestingly, the white plastic buckets of water that get dumped over heads and emptied sideways onto characters’ bodies. And then there are the tears, the oh so many tears: wracking sobs, misty eyes, messy heaves, all trickling and streaming out from one fraught encounter to the next.

headline: An Artist Takes Role of China’s Conscience
text: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, who disappeared into police custody in Beijing after he was detained on Sunday while trying to board a flight for Hong Kong, is a fully 21st-century figure, global-minded, media-savvy, widely networked. He is also the embodiment of a cultural type, largely unfamiliar to the West, that dates far back into China’s ancient past.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Wine Divorced From Food? Let’s Be Adults About It
text: WINE and food belong together. That’s always been one of my cardinal beliefs.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Oysters With a Cause

headline: La Silhouette
text: 362 West 53rd Street, Midtown, (212) 581-2400, la-silhouettenyc.com

headline: Thirstbaràvin
text: 629 Classon Avenue at Pacific Street, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 857-9227.

headline: A Kosher Chicken From Murray’s Coop
text: Murray’s chickens have been among the better birds around. They’re raised locally without antibiotics in certified humane conditions. But until now they haven’t been kosher. In response to customer demand, Fairway has arranged to have some chickens processed in a glatt kosher plant in Rockland County. Kosher chickens tend to have more flavor because they have to be salted. Simply roasted, with a piece of the fat from the cavity parked on the breast to melt for basting, it’s a very tasty chicken. I added no seasoning.

headline: When Class Meant Brie and Pears
text: SURELY it tells us something about the fickle nature of the American appetite that Harry & David is looking for ways to remind its customers of the existence of trees.

headline: At This Farm, It’s All Garlic and Eggplant
text: Locavores who criticize monocultural farming obviously do not have Patrick Salvati and Dorothy DeMarco in mind. Their Salento Farm in Shelton, Conn., may not be monocultural, but it’s close to it. They grow only garlic and eggplant. Their garlic is German hard neck, and they chop it up with garlic scapes, adding olive oil and Parmigiano-Reggiano to make a garlic pesto, so you can banish mint jelly forever for that spring lamb roast. They also dry and pulverize it to make first-rate pungent garlic powder to use in dry rubs, to season your pizza dough, and so forth. “Ours is all garlic, nothing else, not like the commercial brands,” Mr. Salvati said, as he won over a garlic powder skeptic at his new stand in the Greenmarket. Their tangy pickled eggplant is excellent on a bruschetta. In fall and winter, they sell the garlic heads, too.

headline: Ribs Without Smoke
text: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that pork ribs taste best when cooked outdoors on a grill or smoker. Conventional wisdom hasn’t experienced the sweet-sour balsamic-glazed St. Louis-cut spare ribs at Animal in Los Angeles. The restaurant’s chefs, Jon Shook and Vinny Dotolo, prepare them in a way that most barbecue purists would never order, much less eat: baked in the oven.

headline: Rib Heresies: The Bones That Got Away
text: I’ve spent a few weeks researching the fine points of pork ribs braised in the oven. But what about the most commonly braised bones of all, beef short ribs? My final indoor rib satori came from a neighborhood restaurant near where I live in Miami — a not infrequent source of weeknight carryout. Opened by two Mexico City-born restaurateurs, Lalo Durazo and Oscar del Rivero, Talavera in Coral Gables serves the sort of regionally inspired Mexican food rarely found in South Florida.

headline: Final Bidders for Blockbuster Include Icahn and Dish
text: Several bidders squared off on Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan in an all-day auction of Blockbuster, the long-struggling video-rental pioneer.

headline: Generational Divide Colors Debate Over Medicare’s Future
text: The Republican budget released on Tuesday is a daring one in many ways. Above all, it would replace the current Medicare with a system of private health insurance plans subsidized by the government. Whether you like or loathe that idea, it would undeniably reduce Medicare’s long-term funding gap — which is by far the biggest source of looming federal deficits.

headline: The Fickle Fashions of Food
text: Whenever I’m confronted with news about the latest diet to end all diets, I find my mind drifting back to the 1980s.

headline: Cephalon Rejects Valeant’s $5.7 Billion Takeover Bid
text: 8:49 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Inner Workings of Midlife Crises
text: It has been 18 years since an adventurous, autobiographical indie comedy called “My Life’s in Turnaround” — about the making of a movie called “My Life’s in Turnaround” — charmed critics and began the filmmaking careers of a cabbie named Eric Schaeffer and a bartender named Donal Lardner Ward. Now the two men have written, directed and starred in a sequel, “They’re Out of the Business.” Like their first film, it’s a fictionalized account of its own making, and it demonstrates that you should never underestimate the value of youthful energy.

headline: To Sell Cars, Ford Swaps Rides Once Again in Ad
text: The third and latest version of Ford’s “Swap Your Ride” advertising campaign premiered Tuesday night on network and cable television. The ads are part of a spring sales promotion.

headline: Nissan Wants Someone to Live the Glamorous Life of a Reporter
text: As if the hungry mob of reporters expected to attend press days at this year’s New York International Auto Show weren’t huge enough, Nissan wants to invite yet one more.

headline: Crisis Saddles Village With Unwanted Notoriety
text: IITATE, Japan — The mayor sprang into action the moment he heard that scientists from the International Atomic Energy Agency were in the village hall’s parking lot. He rushed outside to confront the group, three Europeans and a Japanese, who wore surgical masks and cloth booties as they waved around a Geiger counter.

headline: Vieira Likely to Leave NBC’s ‘Today’
text: Meredith Vieira, the co-host of NBC’s “Today” show, will probably leave the top-rated morning show this year, two people with knowledge of her deliberations said Tuesday.

headline: Bernard Clayton Jr., Cookbook Author, Is Dead at 94
text: Bernard Clayton Jr., a newspaper reporter whose love for fresh bread inspired him to master the art of baking and write several classic cookbooks on bread and pastry, died on March 28 in Bloomington, Ind. He was 94.

headline: Taliban Exploit Tensions Seething in Afghan Society
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — If the protesters who pushed this city to the brink last weekend were really worried about Koran burning, wondered Layloma Popal, the headmistress of this city’s biggest girls’ school, “then why did they try to burn down my school?”

headline: A Military Trial for the 9/11 Detainees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mexico: Two Americans Shot and Killed in Tijuana
text: Two American men were shot and killed in Tijuana as they waited in line to cross the border into San Diego, the Baja California State authorities said Tuesday. Kevin Romero, 28, and Sergio Salcido, 25, who lived near the beach outside Tijuana and worked at a brewery equipment company in San Diego, were shot before 3 a.m. Monday on their way to work. Matt Pelot, who employed the two men, said that Mr. Romero had told him he was living with a Mexican woman and hoped to adopt her son. Raúl Gutiérrez, a spokesperson for the state attorney general’s office, said the authorities believed that the killings were unlikely to have been tied to drug trafficking.

headline: Yankees’ Power Hides Top of Lineup’s Struggles
text: Power is a great equalizer. With a flick of the wrist, it can bail out poor pitching, erase deficits or pad leads. In the case of the Yankees, it can also minimize their deficiencies, like the slow starts by Brett Gardner and Derek Jeter atop their batting order.

headline: The Way We Eat, and the Colors We Like
Lobbyists on Capitol Hill
Married Gay Immigrants
France’s Role in Three Conflicts Displays a More Muscular Policy
text: PARIS — France on Tuesday found itself engaged in three shooting wars at once for the first time in memory, indicating a new muscularity in using power by the politically embattled French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: A Nun’s Book
The Light Bulb Debate
Ai Weiwei, Chinese Dissident Artist
text: Images of the artist, who was taken into Chinese custody on Sunday.

headline: The Phillies’ Four Aces
text: Just in case you missed it, this weekend’s Sunday Magazine profiled the Philadelphia Phillies’ talent-packed pitching lineup. And in an accompaniment to the article, Nate ranked the best four-man pitching rotations in Major League Baseball history.

headline: Connecticut and Butler Saved Worst for Last
text: It became all the rage at some point Monday night to proclaim Connecticut’s eventual 53-41 victory over Butler the worst championship game ever. Twitter, for one, was overrun with the idea. At halftime, CBS analysts took turns trying to top one another in describing how awful it was. Any real measurement of the awfulness involves aesthetics and statistics, and this game had a lot of both going against it.

headline: Democrats Get New Leader as Kaine Announces Run
text: Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced Tuesday that he would run for the Senate in Virginia, setting up a clash in 2012 between two former governors in an important swing state. George Allen, a Republican, is already running for the seat he held for one term before being ousted in 2006 by Senator Jim Webb. Later Tuesday, Democratic officials said President Obama had selected Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida to take over as committee chairwoman, leading the party’s fund-raising and organizational efforts heading into the 2012 election season. She would be the first woman to serve as the permanent head of the committee.

headline: Suit Over 109 Square Feet Ends in a $150,000 Settlement
text: A home-buying couple who sued a major Brooklyn developer in a dispute over 109 square feet agreed to settle the case for $150,000, but rejected the developer’s offer of an additional $20,000 to keep quiet about the agreement.

headline: From the Windows of Abidjan
text: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

headline: Ford Executive Charged With Drunken Driving
text: Elena Ford, director of global marketing, sales and service operations for the Ford Motor Company and a great-great-granddaughter of Henry Ford, will appear in court later this month on charges of drunken driving and child endangerment. Todd Flood, Ms. Ford’s lawyer, said she had waived an arraignment that had been scheduled for Tuesday in Ferndale District Court.

headline: Syrian Rights Groups Raise Toll From Unrest
text: CAIRO — Human rights groups on Tuesday raised their estimates of the death toll from unrest in Syria, as protest organizers there continued their call for more demonstrations against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Go Philly!
text: Foodwise, among the most progressive cities in the country right now is Philadelphia, where the alliance of a forward-thinking mayor and a 19-year-old non-profit is moving things forward. Within a year or two, Philly might be funding better access to real food for its poorest citizens by taxing soda. And if you accept the notion that childhood obesity and the accompanying Type 2 diabetes are big problems, and you’re aware that soda is a major cause, you’ll agree that’s a huge step in the right direction.

headline: Intel Unveils Chips for ‘Mission Critical’ Server Tasks
text: Generating buzz for a new microchip — one that is for servers, no less — is challenging. But Intel gave it a try with its latest line of microprocessors, the Xeon E7, unveiled on Tuesday, by renting a former bank and briefing reporters in the vault.

headline: Better Cleanup Planned at Former Chrome Plant
text: JERSEY CITY — Some 25 years ago, Ellen Wright was driving home through her neighborhood of single-family wood-frame houses here when she noticed that the streets were slick with “green water.”

headline: Across the Great Football Divide
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: At Particle Lab, a Tantalizing Glimpse Has Physicists Holding Their Breaths
text: Physicists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory are planning to announce Wednesday that they have found a suspicious bump in their data that could be evidence of a new elementary particle or even, some say, a new force of nature.

headline: White House Assails Pakistan Effort on Militants
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday gave Congress a harshly critical assessment of Pakistan’s efforts to defeat Al Qaeda and other militants, saying that after years of work with the Pakistani military “there remains no clear path toward defeating the insurgency” that thrives in the country.

headline: From Where They Stand, It Looks Easier
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: Time’s Up, Qaddafi
text: Tripoli, Libya

headline: Short Game Gives Mickelson an Edge
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — To know more about why Phil Mickelson has emerged as the favorite to win the Masters for the second straight year, consider one minor incident from his transcendent weekend at the  Houston Open. Hint: it has nothing to do with how far down the fairway he was blasting his drives.

headline: As Shutdown Looms, Agencies Brace for Its Impact
text: WASHINGTON — The National Zoo would close, but the lions and tigers would get fed; Yellowstone and other national parks would shut down. The Internal Revenue Service could stop issuing refund checks. Customs and Border Patrol agents training officials in Afghanistan might have to come home. And thousands of government-issued BlackBerrys would go silent.

headline: Servicers Said to Agree to Revamped Foreclosures
text: The nation’s top mortgage servicers are expected to sign legal agreements by the end of this week compelling them to change their foreclosure procedures, regulatory officials said Tuesday.

headline: Estimating Medicare Taxes Versus Benefits
text: My column this week describes some work by Stephanie Rennane and Eugene Steuerle examining the total amount of money people pay in Medicare taxes over the course of their lives, as well as the total benefits they receive. For every cohort of workers, going back to the founding of Medicare in the 1960s, the benefits exceed taxes.

headline: The Budget Battles: Republicans Maneuver Toward a Shutdown
text: The House Republicans on Tuesday made it clear to anyone who had missed it that they are not interested in a deal on the current federal budget. In a meeting at the White House, they rejected a deal to get through the next six months. President Obama, silent for too long on this fight, emerged from the meeting to say that he would tolerate no more ideological gamesmanship. But the Republicans, if anything, only increased their demands, and a government shutdown seemed likely to begin on Friday.

headline: CBS Executive Denies Being F.B.I. Informant
text: A CBS News executive angrily denied reports that he was a government informant during the Oklahoma City bombing investigation, saying Tuesday that reports that he had cooperated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and named a confidential source were “outrageous and untrue.”

headline: When a Punch Line Is No Longer a Lifeline for Egyptians
text: CAIRO — The jokes have stalled, another sign that Egypt’s revolution has too.

headline: The Budget Battles: The Threat to Medicaid and Medicare
text: Representative Paul Ryan’s proposals to reform Medicare and Medicaid are mostly an effort to shift the burden to beneficiaries and the states. They have very little reform in them.

headline: A Passageway for Prisoners, 40 Feet Below
text: Here is a small strip of Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, and what lies beneath this ordinary patch of asphalt and concrete is a 40-yard boulevard dedicated to murderers, gangsters, villains, thieves, scoundrels.

headline: Virginia’s Bad Old Man
text: It was two days after the presidential inauguration, and the Virginia secession convention was in an uproar. The pro-secession minority insisted that Abraham Lincoln’s Inaugural Address was a declaration of war against the South. But the delegate from rural Franklin County, Jubal Early, nicknamed the “Bad Old Man” for his stubborn attitude and imposing figure, would have none of it.

headline: A Noisy Casting Call as Thousands Quack for Aflac
text: IT sounds like the setup for a punch line: A man walks into a room and quacks like a duck, then so does another and another and. ...

headline: U.S. Sees Array of New Threats at Japan’s Nuclear Plant
text: United States government engineers sent to help with the crisis in Japan are warning that the troubled nuclear plant there is facing a wide array of fresh threats that could persist indefinitely, and that in some cases are expected to increase as a result of the very measures being taken to keep the plant stable, according to a confidential assessment prepared by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

headline: Hunting Birds of Paradise
text: You know those moments when You Just Want to Die?

headline: Through Political Prism, Iraqis Grieve
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — The people in the offices waited to die as the gunmen, wearing police uniforms and suicide vests, went door to door, tossing hand grenades and spraying gunfire. Days later, the provincial council headquarters here was a charnel house of smeared blood and burned flesh.

headline: The Budget Battles: Prosperity for Whom?
text: If the House Republican budget blueprint released on Tuesday is the “path to prosperity” that its title claims, it is hard to imagine what ruin would look like.

headline: Twitter’s Tax Break Clears One Hurdle
text: Twitter is well on its way to getting a tax break in San Francisco after threatening to leave the city for the suburbs.

headline: Rebuilding Downtown From the Ground Up
text: QUINCY, Mass. — Barring a catastrophe, few cities get the chance to totally rebuild their downtowns, from the sewer lines deep underground to the sidewalks, buildings, parks and lighting above. But an unusual public-private partnership is allowing this city of 91,000, first settled in the early 17th century and famed as the hometown of the Adams presidents, to try to do just that.

headline: 2 School Custodians Accused of Fake-Job Scheme
text: Two school custodians in the Bronx cheated the city out of more than $500,000 by creating no-show jobs and using school money to pay no-show workers to maintain private properties one of them owned in Queens, city investigators charged on Tuesday.

headline: Recent U.N. Actions Show Policy Shift, Analysts Say
text: UNITED NATIONS — The unusual military strikes by the United Nations against military bases of the Ivory Coast’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, represent a seminal moment in which an organization generally disinclined to intervene forcefully in the affairs of member states is showing a new willingness to take bold action to save lives, diplomats and analysts said.

headline: A Conservative Vision, With Bipartisan Risks
text: WASHINGTON — The audacious long-term budget path that House Republicans outlined on Tuesday is not going to become law anytime soon, if ever. Senate Democrats and President Obama will see to that.

headline: Contrarian Adding Bets in Mideast
text: When it comes to investing in the Middle East, Thomas J. Barrack Jr. takes the long view. Very long.

headline: Callahan Is Out With a Broken Ankle
text: Ryan Callahan, a 26-year-old forward who does a little of everything for the Rangers, fractured his right ankle while trying to preserve his team’s stirring victory Monday over Boston, the Rangers said. Callahan will be sidelined indefinitely.

headline: Brazil Rejects Panel’s Request to Stop Dam
text: SÃO PAULO — Brazil’s government emphatically refused on Tuesday to suspend work on a huge hydroelectric dam in the Amazon, despite pleas that the project could displace tens of thousands of indigenous people and cause environmental harm.

headline: Inquiry Into Payments by Device Maker
text: Nevada state officials have begun an investigation to determine if payments to cardiologists there by a little-known heart device company were legitimate consulting fees or inducements to the doctors for using its products.

headline: States Fear Local Effects if Shutdown Cuts Off Cash
text: Already straining to make ends meet as the longest downturn since the Great Depression grinds on, state and local governments are now facing a new, unwelcome question: What would a shutdown of the federal government mean for their struggles to balance their budgets?

headline: Unable to Swing, Bay Is Unlikely to Return Soon
text: PHILADELPHIA — It just wouldn’t be the Mets if there weren’t some lingering injury problem to frustrate them.

headline: Witnesses in Police Rape Trial Outline Evening of Drinking
text: By the time Kofi Owusu pulled his yellow cab up to the front of an East Village apartment building early one December morning in 2008, the passenger in the back seat had already vomited twice — once inside the taxi, he said in court on Tuesday.

headline: New Haitian Leader Pledges Reconciliation
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — It was a new stage on Tuesday for Michel Martelly, the former hit-maker who nicknamed himself “president” in song and is now on the verge of serving as the real thing in this devastated country.

headline: A Beach Landing? Well, He’d Seen It on TV
text: These things look so easy in Alaska.

headline: More Pupils Are Learning Online, Fueling Debate on Quality
text: MEMPHIS — Jack London was the subject in Daterrius Hamilton’s online English 3 course. In a high school classroom packed with computers, he read a brief biography of London with single-paragraph excerpts from the author’s works. But the curriculum did not require him, as it had generations of English students, to wade through a tattered copy of “Call of the Wild” or “To Build a Fire.”

headline: Once a Great Flop, Now Sold for Billions
text: In announcing the sale of Pringles on Tuesday, Procter & Gamble concluded what had been a tumultuous, sometimes zany, 50-year experiment in engineered food.

headline: Wednesday: Took by the Hand
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to Wednesday, where the wordplay ramps up just a bit, and there may or may not be a twist in the theme. I wouldn’t call today’s debut puzzle by Gareth Bain twisted, but it is a fine theme that works very well. Add to that a bit of misdirection in the cluing, and we’ve got a very clever puzzle to get us through that midweek slump.

headline: In New Jersey, Ex-Prosecutor Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
text: NEWARK — A fixture in legal and political circles, Clifford J. Minor has been a police officer, judge, prosecutor, defense lawyer and mayoral candidate. On Tuesday, he added an unflattering entry to his résumé: confessed felon.

headline: Screening the Day’s Catch for Radiation
text: Eric Ripert, the chef of Le Bernardin, the high temple of seafood in Manhattan, bought a new kitchen gadget a few days ago: a radiation detector.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 5, 2011

headline: Standpipe ‘Irrelevant’ in 2 Deaths, Lawyer Says
text: Lawyers for three construction supervisors charged in the deaths of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank tower challenged on Tuesday one of the central assertions made by prosecutors: that the removal of a section of standpipe in the basement had prevented the firefighters from obtaining water that could have saved their lives.

headline: Knicks Enjoy a Rare Laugher
text: Carmelo Anthony was seated comfortably next to Amar’e Stoudemire, each of them wrapped in big towels and broad smiles. Anthony muttered something, Stoudemire laughed and a few feet away, Anthony Carter hit a running, two-handed layup — all unmistakable signs of a rout.

headline: ‘Marie and Bruce’
text: Images from the revival of Wallace Shawn’s 1979 portrait of marital misery at the Acorn Theater.

headline: There’s Room for Everyone Aboard a Marital Misery Tour
text: “Marie and Bruce,” Wallace Shawn’s 1979 portrait of a festering marriage, is just the show to see when you’re in a really, really bad mood. Not that Mr. Shawn’s play, which has been revived in high style on Theater Row by the New Group, is likely to pull you out of that mood.

headline: Young Does It All for Mets in Debut
text: PHILADELPHIA — When the Mets signed Chris Young during the off-season, they projected a pitcher who could excel at Citi Field, the Mets’ spacious home, where so many long fly balls turn into catchable balls in front of the imposing high walls.

headline: Shutting the Government Down
text: Details on the government shutdown.

headline: S.E.C. Weighs Trading Limits to Avert Extreme Volatility
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday that it would consider limits on the amount by which a stock’s price can move in any five-minute period, a fixture that would replace the single-stock circuit breakers installed after the so-called flash crash volatility on May 6, 2010.

headline: Dr. D.M. French Dies at 86; Treated ’60s Marchers
text: Dr. David M. French, who helped found an organization of doctors that provided medical care to marchers during the civil rights era and who later organized health care programs in 20 African nations, died on Thursday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 and lived in Barboursville, Va.

headline: Sewage Holding Tank Bursts, and Two Men Are Killed
text: Two workers died on Tuesday and millions of gallons of largely untreated sewage spewed into a river when a holding tank wall collapsed at a treatment plant in Gatlinburg, Tenn.

headline: Soriano Sets Up Yanks for Disappointment
text: Perhaps it is better this way. Perhaps it is better for the Yankees to discover now, in the fifth game of their season, that their bullpen is not invincible. That not all leads are safe, not even against the team that has tried and tried and failed to topple them.

headline: U.S. and Colombia Said to Reach Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will announce — perhaps as early as Wednesday — that it has reached agreement with Colombia on a free trade pact, a United States official said on Tuesday.

headline: Arizona: $10,000 Fine for Petroglyph Graffiti
text: A federal judge fined a North Carolina man $10,000 on Monday and sentenced him to five years’ probation and 100 hours of community service for scrawling his name into a well-known petroglyph while on a fishing trip on the Colorado River in Arizona last June. Trenton A. Ganey, 29, pleaded guilty to using a rock to scrape his first name into Indian rock art known as the “Descending Sheep panel,” believed to be more than 1,000 years old, the authorities said.

headline: Aggies Beat Irish for First N.C.A.A. Title

headline: Soldier of Fortune: Collecting Receivables
text: There are many bumps in the road on the way to building a successful business. Many of the challenges are right in front of you — like finding business, delivering the product or service on time, hiring the right people, and financing the whole to-do. One of the most surprising, upsetting, and dangerous challenges is trying to collect money owed (as we discuss in a small-business guide published today). If you own a cash business, this should not be a problem. If you are in a business that has to extend credit, it is a problem that can have disastrous consequences.

headline: The Truth About Sex and Exercise
text: Let’s be clear about this at the start. Vigorous sex will not inevitably cause your heart to stop, and neither will jogging. But you could be excused for believing that both activities are lethal if you relied on some of the coverage of an important new article published last month in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: Belated Realism on Yemen
text: The Obama administration is doing the right thing by trying to ease President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen from office. It should have started weeks ago, after Mr. Saleh’s supporters opened fire on protesters and more than 50 people were killed, turning most of the country against him. With the civilian death toll mounting and the military too divided and preoccupied to pursue a dangerous Al Qaeda affiliate, Mr. Saleh’s swift departure is essential.

headline: Mort Sahl, Tammy Wynette and Captain Beefheart Added to National Recording Registry

headline: Wayne Rooney Runs on Rage

The injuries and the media scandals in his private life appeared to have taken their toll on Manchester United’s star striker, both mentally and physically. Critics and fans were assured that he would return to his best soon enough, but until the start of 2011, evidence of such a recovery was scant.

headline: Bonnard’s Time in Normandy on Show in Giverny
text: The painter Pierre Bonnard lived in the lovely Normandy town of La Roulette from 1911 until 1938, charmed by its rustic beauty and its proximity to the home of his friend Claude Monet in Giverny. Already established as an artist, he would develop there into one of the most popular of the Impressionists.

headline: Seeking Your Questions on the Big Decision

Now that the colleges have made their decisions — accept, reject or defer — the choices, for the most part, rest with applicants and their families. A decision, usually in the form of a deposit, is due May 1.

headline: Introducing Sustainable Profits: Turning Waste Into Profit
text: My company, TerraCycle, has a very unusual business model. We turn the world’s waste into new products. We collect non-recyclable waste, some straight from manufacturers and some from schools, charities and other community groups, and we partner with other manufacturers to recycle or “upcycle” that material into new products — like plastic lumber from juice pouches and shower curtains from sewn-together granola wrappers. My channel on this blog will be a diary of our experiences and decisions, our lessons learned and opportunities missed.

headline: The Newcomer’s Guide to Wireless Tethering
text: What it is: Your smartphone has a high-speed, 3G data connection. Your laptop may only have Wi-Fi. Tethering turns your smartphone into a wireless router, sharing the phone’s 3G connection with other devices over Wi-Fi. No more wireless data cards for laptops, and devices like Wi-Fi-only iPads can get on the Internet via a phone.

headline: The Fragile Success of School Reform in the Bronx
text: On a recent morning, Ramón González, the principal of M.S. 223, a public middle school in the South Bronx, arrived at work as usual at 7:30, stripped off his coat and suit jacket, deposited his tea and toast from a nearby diner on the cluttered conference table in his office and hustled down the hallway to the school’s back door to greet arriving students. González had a busy agenda for the day. Among other things, he needed to get to work on a proposal for the city’s Department of Education to expand 223 into a high school.

headline: Out There in the Dark, All Alone
text: LAST month, in response to an aside I made about Americans no longer being the avid moviegoers they once were — comparing the 90 million who went to the movies each week in 1948 with today’s audience, which hovers around 23 million — Matthew Sigman, a self-confessed “big-screen film fan” from New York, wrote in with a quibble. “I do beg to differ on the statistical basis of your statement suggesting Americans don’t love movies as much as they used to because annual attendance has dropped,” Mr. Sigman wrote.

headline: Remembering Don Hill
text: When Don Hill, who opened his eponymous downtown club in 1993 (and before that, the Cat Club and Kenny’s Castaways), died last Thursday, social media were buzzing with words of remembrance. Many people knew him as the man at the end of the bar, drinking tequila and Heineken, occasionally playing video games. “We did parties last month for the First Precinct and the Hells Angels,” said Paul Sevigny, who, along with Nur Khan, began working with Hill about seven months ago to bring some new blood to the place. “That’s how universally loved he was.” Loved, yes, but also a mystery even to those who knew him — details about his family and childhood remain fuzzy. “You’d go in there with someone who’d never been and you’d be like, ‘Oh, there’s Don!’ And people would be like, ‘There’s actually a Don Hill?’” said the makeup artist Mike Potter. “People didn’t know he was a real person.” Like many, Potter, a club regular in the ’90s, has Don Hill’s to thank for his career: After John Cameron Mitchell recognized him from the SqueezeBox party, the two became friendly, which led to Potter doing the makeup for “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.” Brendan Manning, of the New York City chapter of the Hells Angels, points out that Hill, whose memorial service is tonight at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in NoLIta, had booked — for $200 a week — “a guy named Bruce Springsteen,” back in the Kenny’s Castaways days. The Moment asked a few who knew Hill personally to tell us about him (in more than 140 characters).

headline: ‘NCIS,’ New and Old, Lifts CBS in Ratings
text: A new installment of “NCIS” topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of “NCIS: Los Angeles” (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.6 million). ABC’s new series “Body of Proof” won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.6 million) and “Parenthood” on NBC (4.7 million). ABC’s “No Ordinary Family” (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBC’s “Biggest Loser,” which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox.

headline: Dog’s Best Friend?
text: Man has very little to do with the well-being of dogs in two new, very funny books about our pets and the company they keep. “Say Hello to Zorro!,” by Carter Goodrich, observes the relationship between old dog and new, while “Scritch-Scratch a Perfect Match,” by Kimberly Marcus, considers the relationship between dog and flea. Neither twosome forms a fast or easy friendship.

headline: Hawk Cam | Live From the Nest
text: Update, May 11 | A red-tailed hawk hatchling emerged May 6 in the nest of Violet and Bobby, high above Washington Square Park. But Violet has a badly injured leg that is imperiling her life. Rehabilitators will be at N.Y.U. on Thursday to capture her, treat her and, hopefully, return her immediately to the nest. For the latest (along with this video player) go to: Hawk Cam | Updates From the Nest.

headline: Hawk Cam | Watching Bobby and Violet
text: Who knew the spectacle of a bird sitting on a nest could be so gripping?

headline: Gross? Maybe. But It Got Me on TV, Right?
text: It’s almost impossible to watch “Gigolos,”  a bluntly pornographic Showtime reality series about male prostitutes who cater exclusively to women and not be distracted with illicit thoughts of ... release forms.

headline: Ovation Cable Channel Is Ready to ‘Dance’
text: For years, cable channels have filled their programming schedules with repeats of popular series from broadcast networks, everything from “I Love Lucy” to “The Golden Girls” to “Law & Order.” Now, a new generation of cable channels is picking up some nontraditional network fare.

headline: A Homage to a Homage, Destruction at Its Core
text: JEAN TINGUELY’S “Homage to New York” was billed as the ultimate homemade gadget — a towering contraption composed of found junk, dismembered bicycles, dismantled musical instruments, glass bottles, a meteorological balloon and electric motors in questionable condition. It was slated to come to life and spectacularly self-destruct in a one-night-only performance for some 250 patrons and reporters in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Modern Art on March 17, 1960. And self-destruct it did, but not quite according to plan.

headline: Britney Spears, One More Time at No. 1 With ‘Femme Fatale’
text: Britney Spears is still hot. But how hot?

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. A crew of seniors pulls pranks on young folk: the premise of Betty White’s coming hidden-camera show ... or the politicians’ promise to keep Social Security intact?

headline: Amateurs Face Unkindest Cut at Augusta
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — An amateur has never won the Masters. An amateur has not threatened to win the Masters since Charles Coe finished tied for second in 1961. In the last 10 years, only 8 of the 48 amateurs in the field have made the cut. Other tournaments might consider changing their policy on amateur exemptions when 84 percent of them miss the cut over a decade.

headline: Culture in 3-D
text: The first art-house film in 3-D opens today in Paris and is scheduled for release in the United States later this month. “Pina,” a collaboration between Pina Bausch’s Tanztheater Wuppertal dance troupe and the German director Wim Wenders, is a stunning use of the 3-D medium to convey the emotional impact of Bausch’s art to her fans and new audiences alike — and it’s beating out the Royal Opera House’s “Carmen in 3D” by a matter of weeks.

headline: Will It Happen Again? Examining Mass Extinctions on Earth
text: Overview | What is a mass extinction, and why do some scientists think human beings may be responsible for the next one? What do we know about the past extinctions, including their likely causes? In this lesson, students learn about mass extinctions, map extinction events to a geologic timeline, and explore current ideas about whether human influences may lead to another major extinction event.

headline: How Old Is Your Plane?
text: That is the question on some travelers’ minds following the fuselage rupture on a Southwest flight on Friday that that prompted the carrier to temporarily ground part of its fleet  and led the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a directive calling for inspections of some older-model Boeing 737s for similar cracks.

headline: Only One Vegetable Can Be the ‘Official’ One
text: ALBANY — First came the budget fight. Now it looks as if it will be the food fight.

headline: Learn How to Collect From Slow Payers
text: SMALL-BUSINESS owners know it is cash flow or die. While the recession officially ended in June 2009, many companies are still reeling. Credit can be hard to come by, and profits have not completely bounced back. On top of that, many customers are taking longer than ever to pay their bills.

headline: As It Wraps Up Galleon Case, Prosecution Revises Its Math
text: The indictment of Raj Rajaratnam charged the hedge fund manager with earning $45 million by trading on inside information.

headline: J. J. Abrams Collaborating on Novel for Little, Brown
text: J. J. Abrams is not a big fan of disclosing the plot details of new films he’s directing (see “Super 8″) or producing (“Cloverfield”) before they’ve been released, so don’t expect any spoilers — or even a title — for a new novel on which he’ll be collaborating. The publisher Little, Brown said on Wednesday that it had acquired a book that Mr. Abrams, the director of “Star Trek” and a creator of the television series “Lost,” “Alias” and “Felicity,” had conceived and will be written by Doug Dorst, the author of the supernatural crime novel “Alive in Necropolis.” A release from the publisher happily cited Mr. Abrams’s film and television credits and mentioned that Mr. Dorst is a graduate of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and a three-time “Jeopardy!” champion. And Mr. Abrams said in a statement that “Doug is a genius,” adding that he “could not be more excited to collaborate with him on this completely original project.” Just what that project is neither Mr. Abrams nor Little, Brown is indicating, except to say that it is planned for a fall 2012 release on the Mulholland Books imprint. Watch for further clues as soon as we know where to find them.

headline: Bugs and Brains
text: Some researchers subscribe to what is known as the parasite stress hypothesis. This holds that over the course of evolution the body faced a trade-off between maximizing intelligence and maximizing the power of the immune system. To test this Christopher Eppig, Corey Fincher and Randy Thornhill compared the IQ levels and disease stress in various American states. Sure enough, states where people have to guard against more infectious diseases (presumably because of climate) had lower average IQs. This is one of those studies where it is important to remember that correlation is not causation. Still, the researchers did find that after controlling for education and wealth, disease stress was the best predictor of state IQ.

headline: Grammys Cutting More Than 30 Categories
text: The Grammy Awards have gotten a trim.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Virgil Green, Top-Ranked Tight End
text: 1.Virgil Green, Nevada (6-3, 249)The safest tight end in this draft is Notre Dame’s Kyle Rudolph. So if you’re looking for surer things, he has the combination of blocking skills, receiving and toughness after the catch that should earn him a starting opportunity within the first 12-18 months of his N.F.L. career.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Dukakis Problem
text: The Republican Party’s presidential-nominating process has always been run by elites. Oh, the voters have their brief moments of triumph, hoisting up an unelectable right-winger (i.e., Pat Buchanan) or an uncontrollable moderate (John McCain, the circa-2000 version). But the establishment always wins. Meeting in their K Street offices and communicating through organs like George Will’s column and National Review, the main financers and organizers settle upon a useful frontman, a reliable vessel for the party’s agenda who — and this is the crucial part — is blessed with the requisite political talent. Democrats have been known to mess that last part up and nominate a dweeb, but Republicans have generally understood that an agenda tilted toward the desires of the powerful requires a skilled frontman who can pitch Middle America. Favorite character types include jocks, movie stars, folksy Texans and war heroes.

headline: The Surge in Data Processing
text: Computer users often feel awash in data. It turns out, so does the whole world.

headline: Other Carriers Follow Southwest and Inspect 737s
text: Inspections of Boeing jets widened on Wednesday as Asian and European carriers said they would examine some aircraft as a precaution after cracks expanded into a hole on a Southwest Airlines jetliner last week and forced it to make an emergency landing.

headline: A Publicist Who Sees No Need to Duck Calls
text: LOS ANGELES — Not many years ago, the top players in Hollywood publicity called back when they were good and ready. It was all about access — or the refusal to give it.

headline: For Former Notre Dame Hockey Coach, a Special Trip Home
text: For the past few years, Charles W. Smith Jr., the beloved former Notre Dame hockey coach, has had a standing offer from the current coach, Jeff Jackson. Any time Smith feels like traveling with the team, he sends word to Jackson and it is done.

headline: Seeking Sobriety in Brooklyn
text: ON a recent evening in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, several roommates gathered in the loft they share. Some were eating a dinner of grilled vegetables and pizza; others discussed the meltdown of Charlie Sheen, sitcom star turned cautionary tale of drugs, sex and violence.

headline: Rosenberg Son Says Father Was Guilty of Spy Charge
text: The younger son of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg acknowledged on Wednesday that his father deserved to have been convicted of the legal charges that led to his parents’ execution.

headline: Frocks and Downtown Friends
text: I noticed on Deadline Hollywood Tuesday night that R.J. Cutler, the director of “The September Issue,” has signed to make a feature film of Lee Tulloch’s “Fabulous Nobodies,” a satiric novel set in the New York of the late ’80s, when fashion and clubbing were the main events. Ms. Tulloch, who has lived between Australia and New York, went on to write other books, but “Fabulous Nobodies” seemed to strike a chord with people who were in New York (or wanted to be) at that time. More interesting to me is how difficult it has been for a filmmaker to capture the fashion scene. What are the great fashion films? The producers for the “Fabulous Nobodies” adaptation are Julie Anne Quay, the former executive editor of V magazine; Gail Lyon (“Erin Brockovich”); and Mr. Cutler.

text: Death rates from lung cancer have begun to decline for the first time among women in the United States, falling almost 1 percent a year from 2003 to 2007, according to a new report.

headline: Risks: Focus on Heart Deaths in Student-Athletes

headline: A Little Kick From the Mideast: Folk Spices the Jazz
text: The Israeli pianist Omer Klein works in a modern-jazz mode, brisk and borderless, and yet his music vibrates with cultural specificity, projecting a sense of place. He’s among the current bumper crop of adaptable transplants from Israel to New York, like the saxophonist Eli Degibri, the multireedist Anat Cohen and her brother Avishai Cohen, a trumpeter. Unlike some of these peers Mr. Klein uses Middle Eastern folk elements as a patently important part of his platform, maybe the most important part.

headline: Poll: Blame for a Government Shutdown Will Get Spread Around
text: As the nation inches closer to the possibility that the government may shut down tomorrow at midnight, the public is divided in apportioning blame for the situation, according to a new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll.

headline: Classical-Music Station Sponsors a Week of Chamber Works, On and Off the Air
text: Strange but true: Schubert’s “Trout” Quintet is nowhere to be found among the concerts of Trout Week, a chamber-music festival now being presented by the classical radio station WQXR-FM (105.9 in New York). The one sure place to hear the work during this series, which officially started with a Saturday broadcast, is on “Exploring Music,” a late-night show hosted by Bill McGlaughlin.

headline: As Mammals Supplanted Dinosaurs, Lice Kept Pace
text: Biologists have found a new way to peer back 130 million years in time, illuminating the catastrophic period in which the dinosaurs perished and birds and mammals arose.

text: In the 1990s, Bill Miller, chairman and chief investment officer of Legg Mason Capital Management, earned accolades for his fund’s performance, and was even called the “Greatest Money Manager” of the decade by Money magazine. Mr. Miller discusses why he is now bullish on sectors like financials and energy, in an interview with CNBC.

text: Leigh Morse, a former Upper East Side art gallery director, was convicted on Wednesday on charges of cheating the estates of four artists out of about $5 million.

text: In a letter to President Barack Obama on Wednesday, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi called for an end to airstrikes on his forces and addressed the American leader as “our son,” apparently referring to Mr. Obama’s African heritage.

headline: The Budget Battles and Beyond
text: David Brooks: Gail, what do you think of Paul Ryan’s budget proposal and the budget fights of the next year? I don’t expect that you’ll like the specifics of his Medicare and Medicaid reforms. But do you admire him for having the guts to not only touch the third rail of American politics but to sort of cover himself in copper and wallow around on it?

headline: New Program at Stanford Focuses on the Automobile
text: Stanford University has founded a program for the study of the automobile. Called Revs, the program is a multidisciplinary approach intended to combine the Silicon Valley university’s high-tech credentials with cultural analysis of the car in literature, film and music.

headline: Nearing End of Office, Gates Visits Iraq

headline: Not Disneyfied Enough? Mickey Mouse’s Cruises Are Coming
text: Visitors who do not believe the Times Square area has been Disneyfied enough will soon be able to put on their mouse ears, head a few blocks west and board a Disney Cruise Line ship to a Disney island.

headline: Notes on the Ryan Budget
text: As promised, after yesterday’s praise, a few initial criticisms. The basic architecture of the budget, I think, is exactly right: It means-tests Medicare and shifts the program from an open-ended entitlement to a defined benefit; it block-grants Medicaid to the states (something that governors of both parties have wanted for a long time); and it promises to lower tax rates while broadening the tax base, which is the essence of any good tax reform. But inevitably, there are devils in the details. Here are three obvious problems.

headline: A Slam Try and a Possible Way to Resist It
text: To begin today, look at only the West hand in the diagramed deal. What would you lead against six hearts?

headline: Ambition Doth Curse All Makes of Men
text: That ambition can poison the hearts of small spirits as thoroughly as great ones is the unsettling message of the director Declan Donnellan’s intimate, streamlined new production of “Macbeth” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. As portrayed by the compelling actor Will Keen, Shakespeare’s Scottish general is less a man of great distinction undone by the pursuit of immoral ends than an average fellow caught in a trap of someone else’s making, rattled with nervous laughter at the horror of what he has become.

headline: Start-Ups: Founders on Funding
text: In the current boom of social and mobile start-ups, four Silicon Valley entrepreneurs discuss their experiences attracting investments for their companies.

headline: Back-to-the-Land Life Recalled in Dark and Light
text: Melissa Coleman was born in 1969 to parents who were hippie pioneers. In 1968 they had moved to Cape Rosier, Me., to start an organic farm and devote every waking hour to its upkeep. They had gone there as protégés of Helen and Scott Nearing, whose books, most notably “Living the Good Life,” inspired a back-to-the-land movement predicated on hard work and strict discipline. Their goals reflected Thoreau’s determination “to live so sturdily and Spartan-like as to put to rout all that was not life.”

headline: The Flora-Bama Interstate Mullet Toss
text: DEADLIEST THROW – Inside the Flora-Bama Insterstate Mullet Toss from UM Media Documentary Projects on Vimeo.

text: Look out people of the Internet, there’s another social network on the horizon! But this new network isn’t designed to compete with Facebook, Twitter or MySpace; instead, it’s intended for the people who build these services.

headline: To Renovate, and Surpass, City’s Legacy
text: NEW ORLEANS — As Democrats and Republicans continue to feud over the budget, and the federal government prepares to shut down, the effect of the budget war on the fate of a single proposal for the renovation of a dilapidated public housing project in New Orleans may seem inconsequential.

headline: In Time for Opening Day, an At Bat 11 With Sweeteners
text: The top-grossing app on iTunes last year wasn’t Angry Birds, Cut the Rope or any of the other cheap blockbuster games gobbled up by the masses. Instead, it was a $15 app, MLB.com’s At Bat, aimed at big children who would rather watch a game than play one.

headline: Texas Tech Redeems Itself With Final Four Chess Victory
text: Texas Tech University is at the top of a new college pecking order.

headline: Changing Libyan Tactics Pose Problems for NATO
text: PARIS — Angry charges by Libyan rebels that NATO has failed to come to their aid point up a question that has haunted the Western air campaign from the start: how to avoid a stalemate and defeat the Libyan leader without putting foreign troops on the ground.

headline: The Long and Wireless Road to a Home Router
text: Buying a home wireless router is about as chaotic and confusing a shopping experience as you will ever encounter.

headline: It’s Nick Cave’s World; They Just Dance in It
text: There’s a visceral thrill to Stephen Petronio’s choreography that is unlike anything offered by other contemporary choreographers.  Legs whip round bodies with razor-edged ferocity; high, flying jumps erupt into the air; pelvises and torsos ripple through abrupt, unpredictable changes of direction, shifting from vertical to horizontal and back in the blink of an eye. The movement, with its improbable juxtapositions, seems to pour across the stage in an unquenchable flow, and yet it’s rarely too much for the eye to absorb.

headline: Owning George Washington: The Auction
text: Growing up in the tiny town of Ephrata, Wash., Tom Washington and his older brother Nat, blood relatives of George (yes, that George) were surrounded by family lore. There were more tangible connections as well: family papers going back to 1662, tools George Washington used in his early years as a surveyor, even bits of his coffin. Now, after generations of safekeeping, the family is selling its treasures at auction starting Thursday, creating a buzz of excitement among Americana experts.

headline: Excerpt: 'Anything Goes'
text: Sutton Foster and Colin Donnell sing the number "You're the Top" from the Roundabout Theater's revival of "Anything Goes." (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Inside Marwencol
text: A look at the photographer Mark Hogancamp’s home and the tiny universe he has created there.

headline: Nu? Is This 2nd Ave.? No, It’s Lincoln Center
text: In everything he does, from conducting the San Francisco Symphony to spearheading that orchestra’s multimedia educational project “Keeping Score,” Michael Tilson Thomas brings thorough musicianship sparked with theatrical flair. On Tuesday night an audience that packed Avery Fisher Hall learned about the roots of Mr. Thomas’s theatrical instincts when the New York Philharmonic presented “The Thomashefskys: Music and Memories of a Life in the Yiddish Theater,” directed by Patricia Birch, in the first of two performances.

headline: Baruch Blumberg, Who Discovered and Tackled Hepatitis B, Dies at 85
text: Dr. Baruch S. Blumberg, the Nobel Prize-winning biochemist and medical anthropologist who discovered the hepatitis B virus, showed that it could cause liver cancer and then helped develop a powerful vaccine to fight it, saving millions of lives, died Tuesday in Moffett Field, Calif. He was 85 and lived in Philadelphia.

headline: What a Drag: Broadway Revival of ‘La Cage aux Folles’ Is Closing
text: They built a dress for Harvey Fierstein, but alas, audiences did not come in numbers substantial enough to keep the Broadway revival of “La Cage aux Folles” running: that musical’s producers released a statement on Wednesday evening saying that it would close on May 1: “We’re sorry to have to announce the final weeks of this exuberant production, which has brought great joy to audiences for the last year, as well as to everyone who has worked on the show, on stage and off.”

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Robots
text: For situations that are too deadly for humans, robots can come in mighty handy. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, J.D. Biersdorfer speaks with Tim Trainer of iRobot about the four robots the company has sent to Japan to help with relief efforts. Mr. Trainer, vice president for operations in iRobot’s government and industrial division, said the military and industrial robots would be used to control the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors damaged by earthquake and tsunami. iRobot also makes consumer products like the Roomba vacuum cleaner.

headline: Shopping Picks for April 7
text: Burkman Bros for the SoHo sportsman; soft stripes for springtime; animal prints come alive with Burberry Exotics and more.

headline: High-Level Departures Continue at City Schools
text: John White, a deputy chancellor of the New York City Department of Education, will resign to oversee struggling schools in Louisiana, the city announced on Wednesday. It was the latest in a series of high-level departures from the department since the appointment of Schools Chancellor Cathleen P. Black late last year.

headline: Council Approves Bills to Improve Snow Response
text: Three months after a powerful blizzard revealed startling weaknesses in the city’s chain of command, the City Council voted on Wednesday to overhaul the way the city responds to snowstorms.

headline: Japanese City’s Cry Resonates Around the World
text: MINAMISOMA, Japan — It was a desperate plea for help, spoken into a small digital camcorder by the mayor of this seemingly forsaken city, and posted on the Internet like a bottle tossed into a digital sea.

headline: Star Designer Leaves Balmain Fashion House
text: Balmain, a 66-year-old French fashion house that recently engineered a comeback with skimpy dresses and spray-on jeans that were shockingly priced, announced on Wednesday that its star designer, Christophe Decarnin, had left the company. His departure is the latest in a string of shake-ups that suggest, after the John Galliano debacle at Dior, that luxury fashion houses are becoming less interested in promoting lively personalities than in protecting their own brands.

text: Aerials of the remote Monegros region of northeastern Spain.

headline: Clean Energy Is a Target of Ryan Budget Plan
text: A long-term Republican budget plan released this week by Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin calls for drastic cuts in federal spending on energy research and development and for the outright elimination of subsidies and tax breaks for wind, solar power and other alternative energy technologies.

headline: Transocean Bonuses Reflect a Tin Ear
At Frozen Four, a Little Sibling Rivalry
text: ST. PAUL — Logistically, Betsy and Steve Rust — whose sons, Matt and Bryan, play on different teams in the Frozen Four — are running this down the middle. They booked a room at the same hotel as Michigan, where Matt is a senior center. But for Thursday’s national semifinals at the Xcel Energy Center, they will sit with other parents from Notre Dame, where Bryan is a freshman right wing.

headline: Skin Deep: Slicked-Back Hair

headline: A More Grown-Up Look for a Minimalist Time
text: BEDAZZLED hair clips and ponytail elastics suddenly seem childish. Quite a few spring fashion shows, including those of Bill Blass, Erin Fetherston and Dries Van Noten, featured a more sophisticated slicked-back alternative. And no matter what your hair texture or length, you need only a good blow dryer, volumizer and holding spray to pull it off.

(Mr. Cooper liked the original store so much, he hired the owner, Sean Scherer, to design his apartment across town.)

headline: Rewiring an Old Lamp

headline: Sales at Odegard, Desiron and Others
text: During the Odegard warehouse sale, through Sunday, samples, overstocked and discontinued items, and one-of-a-kind rugs, furniture and accessories are marked down as much as 70 percent (6-by-9-foot rugs, regularly $3,024 to $7,182, are $1,058 to $2,532; 9-by-12-foot rugs, regularly $6,048 to $14,364, are $3,024 to $5,065); 30-30 47th Avenue, Long Island City, N.Y., (718) 784-1704 or odegardinc.com/warehouse.

headline: A Collection That Reveals William Sofield’s Softer Side
text: William Sofield’s new collection from McGuire furniture is a stylistic departure from the sleek contemporary pieces for which he is known. The line, introduced last month, celebrates such seemingly un-Sofield materials as rattan, rawhide, Danish cord and coconut shell.

headline: A New Look for the Rolling Pin
text: Tahir Mahmood, a Toronto designer born in Pakistan, made 10 versions of his rolling pin before he found one that was modern enough to suit him.

headline: Susan Roy on Cold War Housekeeping
text: “Bomboozled: How the U.S. Government Misled Itself and Its People Into Believing They Could Survive a Nuclear Attack,” out this month from Pointed Leaf Press, is a mouthful of a title for an enticing visual history of the fallout shelter, which allowed cold war anxiety to be cheerfully reconfigured as a home story and gave the phrase “nuclear family” new meaning.

headline: In a Tiny Universe, Room to Heal
text: MARK HOGANCAMP died 11 years ago tomorrow, when five men kicked his head in outside a Kingston, N.Y., bar in the early morning hours. He was reborn months later, after he awoke from a nine-day coma, his memory wiped nearly clean of the details of his life — his early marriage, girlfriends, family, Navy service, thundering alcoholism, homelessness, jail time — and he had to relearn how to eat, walk and think at age 38. Feeling shunned by the outside world, he created his own world, a tiny society called Marwencol.

headline: In New Orleans, a Place for the Imperfect

headline: In South Delhi, a Home for Three Generations
text: NEW DELHI — From the moment they decided to build a house on a wide dusty street lined with eucalyptus trees in this teeming city of about 17 million people, Manit and Sonali Rastogi knew it would have to meet the needs of not only six different people, but three different generations.

headline: A Collector of People Along With Art
text: LIKE a Zelig of the art world, Sam Green was seemingly always there, filling a space in the social picture that no one quite realized was empty. Over five decades Mr. Green played pivotal roles, first as a curator, then as an art dealer, a municipal adviser and finally as a society gadabout and preservationist whose scope took in the more remote corners of the planet.

headline: All-Night Sendoff for a Clubland King
text: THERE were no guest lists, V.I.P. lines or finicky doormen at Don Hill’s the night of March 31 — but such an uncouth departure from the nightlife pecking order was forgivable. Earlier that day, Don Hill himself, a legendary fixture in New York’s clubland who presided over three decades of underground culture bridging punk, glam-androgyny, indie rock and electronic dance, passed away abruptly in his mid-60s.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,436 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,508 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Haitian Deportations to Resume
text: After a two-month pause, immigration authorities will resume the deportations of Haitians who have been convicted of crimes in the United States. Immigration and Customs Enforcement began deporting Haitians in January, removing 27 that month, but stopped after one deportee died of choleralike symptoms shortly after arriving in Haiti and others fell ill. In new guidelines issued last Friday, the agency said it would limit deportations mainly to Haitians convicted of violent crimes and repeat offenders, who had also been ordered removed by an immigration court. Agency officials said they would not place a priority on deporting Haitian criminals who require medical treatment in this country. Catholic advocates said many of the first deportees had served their sentences and had been living without incident for years. The agency suspended the deportations after a Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Bid for State of Palestine Gets Support From I.M.F.
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority, which is working toward global recognition of its statehood in September, got an endorsement on Wednesday from the International Monetary Fund, which said that the authority was fully capable of running the economy of an independent state.

headline: Scene City: A Laid-Back Party for Keanu Reeves
text: Mr. Reeves plays nice at an indie film party on Monday.

headline: The Monolinguist's Crutch
text: Smartphones mean that it's easy to carry around a pocket-sized translator. But translation apps are still a work in progress.

headline: A Cozy Premiere for Keanu Reeves
text: KEANU REEVES likes to play the nice guy. “They’re not always easy characters, but they’re a pleasure to play,” he said Monday night during a screening for his new movie, “Henry’s Crime,” a comedy about a bank heist in which he plays the title role. “There’s a feel-good element to it.”

headline: Soriano Apologizes for Absence After Loss
text: Not long after Rafael Soriano imploded in the Yankees’ 5-4 loss to Minnesota on Tuesday night, his cellphone rang. It was his mother calling from the Dominican Republic. He did not answer.

text: LOS ANGELES — This was once a place for the famous, or at least those who wanted to be. There were ballroom dances and Champagne toasts, a welcoming place for the star-struck ladies who lunch.

headline: As China Ages, Birthrate Policy May Prove Difficult to Reverse
text: YICHENG, China — Under China’s family-planning regulations, most couples are barred from having more than one baby. Wang Hong and her husband, Zhang Jingfeng, are among those who were granted a second chance — and decided against it.

headline: Building a Stage for Mideast Peace Before the Final Curtain
text: JENIN, West Bank — Juliano Mer Khamis lived a paradox. The internationally renowned actor, director and political activist, who was killed here this week, was both an Israeli and a Palestinian, born to a Jewish mother and an Arab Christian father in the Israeli Arab town of Nazareth.

headline: A Survivalist Sees Profit in Helping Others Prepare
text: MESA, Ariz. — Swimming pools are one way of surviving Arizona’s sky-high temperatures, which hit triple digits in a recent uncharacteristically early burst of heat. But Dennis McClung’s pool, in the Phoenix suburb of Mesa, has been redesigned into a survivalist refuge of an entirely different sort.

headline: As Days Grow Longer, So Do Hems
text: FASHION happens by degrees. No banner headlines announce its arrival. (Make way for the mini! Salute the trapeze!) It appears by stealth, like the wisp of cloud that heralds summer showers.

headline: Longer Hemlines Sweep the City Streets
text: A year ago, a movement toward sweeping skirts was just starting. This spring, long skirts and dresses are a full-on trend.

headline: Borders Plan for Recovery Is Described as Doubtful
text: Borders presented a restructuring plan to its creditors on Wednesday that promised publishers and landlords a sleeker, more efficient company poised to emerge successfully from bankruptcy through increased online sales and revamped stores.

headline: A 45-Year-Old Apprentice, Holding Her Own
text: Monique Faatimah Lee is proof that late bloomers can find career nirvana. Ms. Lee, 45, waited until her 30s to attend college (she graduated from Howard University in 2003 with an anthropology degree), then worked as a personal trainer until she decided to try carpentry. She is in the third year of her union apprenticeship, with one more to go before she is certified as a full-fledged “mechanic” of her trade. She lives in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx.

headline: Bahrain’s Rulers Tighten Their Grip on Battered Opposition

headline: Syria Tries to Placate Sunnis and Kurds

headline: Despite the Chatter, a Wide-Open Masters

headline: Gung-Ho for Big Cuts in Spending, Less Fond of the Ones That Hurt Back Home
text: WASHINGTON — As a candidate, Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler denounced stimulus spending and, once elected, voted for a Republican budget bill that would make $61 billion in cuts to a vast array of programs this year.

headline: Gitmo Fatigue at the Supreme Court
text: Is the Supreme Court finally finished with Guantánamo?

headline: Trading Up: Varsity Jackets
text: For the big man off campus, the varsity jacket.

headline: This Championship Season
text: GIVEN the continuing demand for people who can write code in their sleep, it’s safe to say the gaunt, spectacled look known as geek chic isn’t going anywhere soon. But its old rival, the ruddy, broad-shouldered B.M.O.C., is showing at least one sign of life: the varsity jacket, the 1950s favorite that turned up in a slew of fall fashion collections.

headline: Critics Call Terrorism Hearing in Manhattan Anti-Muslim
text: A state senator has scheduled a daylong hearing for Friday on terrorism preparedness in New York City, featuring an array of experts in law enforcement, emergency response and counterterrorism.

headline: Libyan Rebels Don’t Really Add Up to an Army
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Late Monday afternoon, as Libyan rebels prepared another desperate attack on the eastern oil town of Brega, a young rebel raised his rocket-propelled grenade as if to fire. The town’s university, shimmering in the distance, was far beyond his weapon’s maximum range. An older rebel urged him to hold fire, telling him the weapon’s back-blast could do little more than reveal their position and draw a mortar attack.

headline: Mets Get a Look at a Pitcher They’d Rather Not See
text: PHILADELPHIA — Just three days after his San Diego Padres were eliminated from postseason contention last year, Chris Young was not particularly enthusiastic about settling in to watch games that he had expected to play in himself.

headline: At N.F.L. Hearing, Judge Urges, but Doesn’t Compel, a Return to Talks
text: ST. PAUL — The N.F.L. will probably remain dormant for at least a while longer, after United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson said Wednesday that she would take “a couple of weeks” to decide whether to grant the players’ request for an injunction to lift the lockout.

headline: Bloggers Challenge President on Standardized Testing
text: Does President Obama believe standardized testing has gone too far?

headline: Obama Takes Aim at Inequality in Education
text: Describing education and education equality as the “civil rights issue of our time,” President Obama called Wednesday for a renewed effort to eliminate the achievement gap between African-American students and others.

headline: Out of Context
text: THE 9/11 memorial in New York, still being planned, is to be dedicated on the 10th anniversary of the attack. Intended as a place for commemoration, reflection, education and solace, the memorial and museum will serve as a repository for the remains of the victims.
