headline: Rush to Use Crops as Fuel Raises Food Prices and Hunger Fears
text: The starchy cassava root has long been an important ingredient in everything from tapioca pudding and ice cream to paper and animal feed.

headline: Beck and Fox End Relationship Grown Cold
text: The negotiations that led Glenn Beck to announce his departure from the Fox News Channel on Wednesday ended with an expression of “let’s part as friends,” according to several people with knowledge of the talks. But behind that moment was a torrent of acrimony that underscored just how fractious the relationship between Mr. Beck and the network had become during his three-year run on Fox.

headline: Small Carrier Gets Big Tailwind From Social Media
text: THE popularity of Richard Simmons, the fitness guru known for his big personality and tiny shorts, peaked sometime in the 1980s, but on YouTube he is enjoying something of a Justin Bieber moment.

headline: Senate Rejects Bills to Limit E.P.A.’s Emissions Programs
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday rejected efforts to block the Environmental Protection Agency’s program to regulate greenhouse gases, defeating four bills that would have limited the agency’s attempts to address global warming.

headline: Medicine on the Move
text: Sometimes you really do want to tell the medical profession to just make up its mind.

headline: Disabled, but Looking for Work
text: BATESVILLE, Ark. — Christopher Howard suffers from herniated discs in his back, knee problems and hepatitis C. As a result, Social Security sends him $574 every month and will until he reaches retirement age — unless he can find a job.

headline: Why Pay Congress?
text: If we careen over a cliff on Friday and the American government shuts down, hard-working federal workers will stop getting paychecks, but the members of Congress responsible for the shutdown are expected to be paid as usual.

headline: Europeans’ More Open Approach Wins Fans
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: Wal-Mart v. Women
text: The employment discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart, which the Supreme Court heard last week, is the largest in American history. If the court rejects this suit, it will send a chilling message that some companies are too big to be held accountable.

headline: Dust Is Gone Above the Bar, but a Legend Still Dangles
text: On Sunday morning, before the ancient doors of McSorley’s Old Ale House opened once again to spill that beer-and-sawdust aroma upon an East Village sidewalk, the owner took on a sorrowful job that in good conscience he could not leave to any of his employees. Too close to tempting the fates.

headline: No Najar? No Big Deal.
text: The kneejerk reaction to Andy Najar’s decision to play his international soccer with his native Honduras rather than his adopted country, the United States, is that it’s another humiliating blow for a United States national team that keeps losing its most talented immigrants.

headline: Better Protecting Prisoners
text: The Justice Department is finalizing new rape-prevention policies that will become mandatory for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal money. The rules, based on recommendations from a Congressionally mandated commission, would be a major improvement. But the department needs to remedy several weaknesses before it issues final regulations.

headline: A Temporary Reprieve for Nassau Bus Riders
text: A late infusion of cash from Albany has postponed the plan of the Nassau County executive, Edward Mangano, to cripple his county’s bus service, but only until the end of the year.

headline: George Tooker
text: “Government Bureau,” a 1956 painting by George Tooker, was inspired by his maddening encounter with the New York City Building Department. Most people who waste hours in line just end up with sore feet and headaches. Mr. Tooker, who died on March 27, emerged with one of the best-known depictions of modern alienation and despair.

headline: State’s Judges Told to Shut Courtrooms Earlier to Cut Costs
text: Judges across New York State were told on Wednesday to shut down their courtrooms a half-hour earlier every day in an effort to cut back on overtime paid to staff members like court clerks and court officers.

headline: Rifts Within Both Parties Test Leaders in Budget Fight
text: WASHINGTON — On one level, the budget showdown that continued to play out here on Wednesday is all about the balance of power between the two parties, a question of whether President Obama has regained his footing and can still control the direction of the country or whether Speaker John A. Boehner and the Republicans are now calling the shots.

headline: Obama Is Set to Redo Team on War Policy
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama assembled his first national security team, it was quickly dubbed, not always accurately, the “Team of Rivals.” Now that some of its key members are heading for the exits, the question is whether his next war council could be named the “Corps of Consensus.”

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: Labor Panel to Press Reuters Over Reaction to Twitter Post
text: In what would be the first government case against an employer involving Twitter, the National Labor Relations Board told Thomson Reuters on Wednesday that it planned to file a civil complaint accusing the company of illegally reprimanding a reporter over a public Twitter posting she had sent criticizing management.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Haiti Winner Claims Wider Vote Edge Than Reported
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Michel Martelly, the presumed president-elect of Haiti, said Wednesday that his landslide showing in an election runoff was actually stronger than was indicated by results released Monday. He said it pointed to a mandate that a “very weak” opposition needed to respect as he moved to rebuild the shattered country.

headline: Obama Meeting Fails to End Stalemate Over Federal Budget
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional leaders said Wednesday that a late-night White House bargaining session produced no budget breakthrough that would avert a government shutdown this weekend but agreed the two sides had narrowed the issues in efforts to strike a deal.

headline: Thursday: Source of Venom
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — At first, I thought I had forgotten how to read. Then, I thought I had forgotten how to solve a crossword puzzle. You might catch on faster than I did but hold onto your hats, folks: we’ve got us a Henry Hook puzzle that blows a longtime crossword cluing convention out of the water. I am a subversive of the first order, and so I loved this puzzle.

headline: Audit Finds L.I. School Overbilled the State
text: A state-supported school for disabled students on Long Island overbilled taxpayers by $835,074 over two years, with some of the money going toward an executive’s salary and the lease on his Lexus, the state comptroller’s office said in an audit released on Wednesday.

headline: Knicks Move Up a Notch, but Are Bruised in the Process
text: PHILADELPHIA — In another week, the Knicks may learn what they gained or lost in a late-season battle for playoff position with the Philadelphia 76ers. As they departed the Wells Fargo Center late Wednesday, they only could contemplate what they might have lost in the pursuit of one more win.

headline: Father Finds Son and Another Man Shot to Death in a Brooklyn Basement
text: Two men were found bound, gagged and shot to death in the basement of a home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn on Wednesday, the police and relatives said.

headline: Mourning the Short Life of a Beaten Toddler
text: Three simple sentences offered by a priest on Wednesday came closest to conveying the senselessness of the act that brought strangers together inside a Roman Catholic church in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Pelfrey’s Problems Show Mets Are Missing an Ace
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Johan Santana had shoulder surgery last September, the Mets knew he would be unavailable to them until the middle of the 2011 season, at best. So for the first three months of the season, the Mets would need an interim ace.

headline: Trial Looks at Conditions Faced by Firefighters in Deutsche Bank Blaze
text: When Firefighter Robert Brown entered the former Deutsche Bank building as it was being consumed in smoke and flames in 2007, he said, he quickly realized it was one of the worst fires he had ever experienced.

headline: Federal Departments Lay Out Plans in the Event of a Government Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — With the possibility of a government shutdown looming, Obama administration officials raced Wednesday to identify essential government services that would have to be provided if the government ran out of money.

headline: A Freak Accident at the Queensboro Bridge, Until It Happens Again
text: It seemed a grisly freak accident: a small sedan, navigating a curvy Queensboro Bridge off-ramp early one morning last week, careened off the road and smashed into a Long Island City storefront, severing the arm of the driver and injuring his female passenger.

headline: Freshman Voices in the Budget Fight
text: The freshman class of the 112th Congress is taking a hard line on government spending.

headline: Dot-com Boom, Then And Now
text: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social-media companies like Facebook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom - and subsequent bust - reverberate among investors.

headline: Police Lesson: Social Network Tools Have Two Edges
text: Officer Trey Economidy of the Albuquerque police now realizes that he should have thought harder before listing his occupation on his Facebook profile as “human waste disposal.”

headline: Rangers Not Backing Down on Approach to Blocked Shots
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Ryan Callahan, his broken right ankle in a surgical boot, used crutches to get around the Rangers’ dressing room Wednesday. Callahan is out indefinitely, but he promised that his teammates would be as fearless as he is, as fraught with peril as that can be.

headline: Shooting at College in Alabama Kills a Woman and Wounds 3
text: ATLANTA — A woman was killed and three other people, including a woman believed to be in her 90s and a 4-year-old girl, were wounded on Wednesday afternoon when a man with a gun walked onto the campus of a community college in Opelika, Ala., and began firing, the police said.

headline: W. H. Prusoff, Who Developed AIDS Drug, Is Dead at 90
text: William H. Prusoff, a pharmacologist at the Yale School of Medicine who, with a colleague, developed an effective component in the first generation of drug cocktails used to treat AIDS, died on Sunday in New Haven. He was 90 and lived in Branford, Conn.

headline: Odd Exceptions in the Family Planning Rulebook
text: BEIJING — A corps of 500,000 bureaucrats enforces China’s family planning regulations, a sometimes-bewildering rulebook that includes more than 20 exceptions to the one-child-per-family guideline.

headline: Oil Spills May Leave More Emotional Than Physical Scars, Study Finds
text: NEW ORLEANS — In a review of past oil spills as well as the available data from last year’s BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico, doctors found that adverse health effects from oil and chemical exposure are less likely than behavioral and mental health issues to pose significant long-term risks for most gulf residents.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — In a move that could shake up the American solar industry, General Electric plans to announce on Thursday that it will build the nation’s largest photovoltaic panel factory, with the goal of becoming a major player in the market.

headline: Virginia Lawmakers Limit Insurers’ Abortion Coverage
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Lawmakers in Virginia approved an amendment Wednesday that would ban private insurance plans from covering abortions if they participate in a state health care exchange under President Obama’s new health care law.

headline: At 0-5, the Red Sox Are Scrambling
text: CLEVELAND – Daisuke Matsuzaka had done his usual flirtation with the strike zone (96 pitches, 54 strikes), and it was time for a relief pitcher in the sixth inning at Progressive Field on Wednesday night. Terry Francona, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, looked at the Cleveland Indians’ lineup and chose Dennys Reyes, figuring Reyes could stay in for a while against a left-leaning order.

headline: The Money Network
text: Facebook, Zynga, Groupon, Twitter and LinkedIn have come to define the social Web. Founded within the last five years, the quintet of start-ups is now estimated to be worth more than $71 billion.

headline: Deal Mashup
text: So many words come to mind as Wall Street deal makers pursue mergers and acquisitions and venture capitalists fund start-ups. Here are just a few of them.

headline: Scarred by the Dot-Com Bust, Reinvented for Social Media

headline: The Valley’s Banker Returns to the Top

headline: The Dot-Com Boom, Then And Now
text: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social media companies like Facebook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom — and subsequent bust — reverberate among investors. DealBook spoke to Michael Holland, chairman of Holland & Company, and John C. Coffee, a professor at Columbia Law School, about the structural differences that exist between the dot-com boom of the 1990s and the social media boom of today.

headline: Founders Now Take the Money and Maintain Control
text: In a small office in San Francisco, electronic music blared as several programmers loomed over two computers. David Morin, the founder of Path, a social network start-up, gave the signal and the company’s site and iPhone application went live.

headline: Mario Cuomo Still Believes
text: You would think that Mario Cuomo would have been proud to watch his son Andrew sworn in as governor of New York last New Year’s Eve, ascending to the job his old man held for 12 years. Apparently, you would be wrong.

headline: Bank of Japan Pledges Aid for Rebuilding From Quake
text: HONG KONG — The Japanese central bank announced measures Thursday to help reconstruction efforts in areas affected by the devastating earthquake and tsunami last month but held off deploying any more sweeping measures in its economy-stimulating arsenal.

headline: News Quiz | April 7, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 7, 2011
text: Test your proofreading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “Newly Homeless in Japan Re-Establish Order Amid Chaos.”

headline: French Forces in Ivory Coast Rescue Japanese Diplomat
text: ACCRA, Ghana — Helicopter-borne French special forces staged a dramatic nighttime rescue of a Japanese diplomat caught up in the fighting in Ivory Coast on Thursday, as opposition forces besieged the residence of the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, for a second consecutive day, seeking to end his disputed claim to power.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Psychogony
