headline: Goldman Moves to Buy All of Australian Venture
text: Goldman Sachs said on Thursday that it had offered to buy all of its joint venture in Australia and New Zealand for an undisclosed sum, driving further into a dynamic regional economy buoyed by commodities prices.

headline: Powerful Aftershock Complicates Japan’s Nuclear Efforts
text: TOKYO — The strongest aftershock to hit since the day of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan rocked a wide section of the country’s northeast on Thursday night, prompting a tsunami alert, raising fears of new strains on the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant and knocking out external power at three other nuclear facilities.

headline: Is Online Learning as Good as Face-to-Face Learning?
text: Some experts estimate that more than a million students in the United States, from kindergarten through 12th grade, are taking courses online. Have you ever taken a class for credit online? What was the experience like? In general, do you think K-12 students can learn as much in an online course as they can in a traditional class? Why or why not? What makes for a good online course, in your opinion?

headline: Big Banks Have a Powerful New Opponent
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Without People, the Power of Place
text: When global decision makers discuss whether to enter into war, or where to hold the next World Cup, they are often sitting in beautifully lit, well-designed rooms.

headline: Gates, in Iraq, Talks of Effects of Budget Fight
text: BAGHDAD — On what he described as probably his final visit to Iraq, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday turned from eight years of war here to the fight raging at home. If the United States government shuts down this weekend and into next week, he told American troops, there would be a delay in their pay.

headline: N.Y. Fed Raises $1.3 Billion From First A.I.G. Bond Sale
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold $1.3 billion worth of mortgage-backed securities on Wednesday that it had acquired in the bailout of American International Group, the first of several sales it plans.

headline: Training in the Heat of the Race in Malaysia
text: SEPANG, Malaysia – I can see the Petronas Twin Towers from my hotel window in Kuala Lumpur. This morning rather than taking three different public transportation lines – a monorail, a train and a metro – to get to the train that takes me to the airport where the race track is located, I decided I would simply walk towards the Twin Towers, where I knew there would be a direct line to the train to the airport.

headline: Training in the Heat of the Race in Malaysia
text: SEPANG, Malaysia – I can see the Petronas Twin Towers from my hotel window in Kuala Lumpur. This morning rather than taking three different public transportation lines – a monorail, a train and a metro – to get to the train that takes me to the airport where the race track is located, I decided I would simply walk towards the Twin Towers, where I knew there would be a direct line to the train to the airport.

headline: An Agonizing Wait Prolonged by a Cellphone Internet Hookup
text: It seems that I am always fated to learn about my critical admissions decisions on the slowest possible Internet connection — the one on my cellphone.

headline: New Night-Life Spot in Berlin Is About More Than Parties
text: A new club and performance space is flourishing in Kreuzberg’s Kottbusser Tor area, a bohemian neighborhood in Berlin. In the shadow of a former housing project, Südblock (Admiralstrasse 1-2; 49-30-609-418-53; www.suedblock.org) opened in December with a lineup as diverse as its surroundings. On any given night, one might stumble in to find a video installation, a record release concert, or an evening of Israeli pop for gay partygoers.

headline: The Early Word: One More Day
text: In Today’s Times:–The federal government continues to move toward a possible shutdown after a late-night meeting at the White House between President Obama and congressional leaders failed to produce anything more than a pledge to keep negotiating. Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes report that the House is scheduled to vote today on a stop-gap measure to fund the government for one more week until a budget can be passed, even though Democrats have said the bill would dead-on-arrival in the Senate. If the lawmakers fail to strike a deal, the government will effectively shut down when the clock strikes midnight Saturday.

headline: 2010 Falcons: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. Today, we complete our look at the N.F.C. South:

headline: Q&A: Supersize Cut-and-Paste in Microsoft Word
text: Q.

headline: New Test Appears to Back Range Claim for Battery
text: Makers of batteries for plug-in vehicles are in something of a tight spot. They are under considerable pressure to improve their products so that electric vehicles will be attractive to more drivers. But if they actually manage to come up with a radically improved battery, their breakthrough is likely to be met with skepticism — perhaps dealing a permanent blow to their reputation.

headline: Wow, Mom: It’s an Ambigram!
text: Wow, mom.

headline: A Tough Time to Time the Sale of a Business
text: As with most economic news of late, there are mixed signals right now in the business-for-sale marketplace. Some folks say now is great time to sell — or, at a minimum that the market is better than it has been over the last two years — while others disagree. Where can a business owner turn to get clear direction? Since the dartboard has been used famously for picking publicly traded stocks, let’s ask the Magic 8 Ball a few questions about selling a small business.

headline: Is a Well-Rested Doctor a Better Doctor?
text: Recently, I saw a young friend who is training to be a surgeon. Extremely bright and the recipient of numerous medical school awards for her work with patients, she had been anxious as a student about the grueling hours she would face once she began working as a junior surgeon on the wards.

headline: European Bank Raises Rate for 1st Time Since 2008
text: FRANKFURT — Defying critics and breaking ranks with its counterparts in the United States and Britain, the European Central Bank moved on Thursday to slay what some economists say they believe is an imaginary inflation threat, raising the benchmark interest rate in the euro area for the first time since 2008.

headline: The Wizard of Offal
text: At 40, Julien Fouin is working on his fourth, maybe fifth career. He was first known as a journalist and an author, then as the editor of Régal (“Feast”), which was unquestionably France’s best culinary magazine. More recently, he opened two restaurants in Paris, and he has also helped write two books that are being published this year, the first of which, “Cuisines Paysannes,” which roughly means “cooking from the farm,” has just been released. (The other one comes out this fall.)

headline: A Common Infection, Commonly Overtreated
text: “As people get more frail and old, physicians tend to do more, when often we should do less.”

headline: Chelsea Doomed by In-the-Box Thinking
text: London

headline: Taliban Attack a Police Training Center in Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents carried out a deadly two-stage attack in this southern capital on Thursday, using an ambulance packed with explosives to bomb a police and military training center that had just been assaulted by heavily armed insurgents wearing suicide vests.

headline: Rio Tinto Names Riversdale Directors
text: With its stake in Riversdale Mining now approaching 50 percent, Rio Tinto added three directors to the company’s board.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Morning Buzz | Cuomo’s Different Approach
text: April will continue to come in like a lion on this overcast day, with highs reaching the mid-50s and rain a possibility.

headline: Cheers for the Hero, Followed by an Opera
text: James Levine has been given countless ovations during 40 years with the Metropolitan Opera. But the enthusiastic round of applause and bravos he received from the audience at the Met on Wednesday night when he appeared in the pit to conduct the season’s first performance of Alban Berg’s “Wozzeck” must have been especially gratifying. He had last performed at the house nearly two months before, conducting Donizetti’s “Don Pasquale,” and it was a relief to all, it seemed, to have him back in action.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Debate Over Physician Fatigue
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Case for Having More Kids
text: Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason, is the author of “Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids,” which will be released this week. Mr. Caplan doesn’t believe everyone should have a lot of children. But he does say many parents and future parents should consider having more children than they are currently planning.

headline: Ciao, Bella
text: Giulietta, which had its debut in a whitewashed loft during New York Fashion Week, is helmed by Sofia Sizzi (above, center), a Florentine-born Manhattanite who is driven by a love for lavish Italian fabrics. “Is that really double-knit?” one observer whispered of a black wool suit consisting of skinny flared trousers, a hip-length narrow-lapeled jacket and a long fitted vest that could serve as a minidress to nouveau Twiggys. The 24-look collection includes a black wool sateen dress accented with a Peter Pan collar, a handmade lace widow skirt and a saffron printed pantsuit based on Sizzi’s sketch of a Baroque cathedral ceiling. The shoes — velvet, satin and felt wedges and heels (all vegan, to match the 33-year-old’s lifestyle) in salmon, saffron and cardinal red — attest to what Sizzi learned while working as an accessories designer at Gucci, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan. Clever ’60s proportions and mod collaborations with the milliner Patricia Underwood and the jeweler Thomas Bliven add a bit of nonecclesiastical zing. From $435 at Barneys New York.

headline: Chinese Defend Detention of Artist on Grounds of ‘Economic Crimes’
text: BEIJING — The investigation of the celebrity artist and social critic Ai Weiwei on suspicion of “economic crimes” is in keeping with “the rule of law” in China, a Chinese official said Thursday, defending Mr. Ai’s detention in the face of growing condemnation by foreign nations and liberal Chinese of the detention.

headline: Markets Turn Lower, and Oil Prices Rise Again
text: Oil prices rose to their highest level in more than two years on Thursday, while Wall Street erased gains prompted by better-than-expected economic data after reports of another earthquake in Japan.

headline: Is Nuclear Power Simply Too ‘Brittle’?
text: Despite the public focus on radiation risks, cost has long been the main obstacle to a substantial expansion of nuclear power generation, and will be even more as a result of Japan’s still-unfolding effort to secure the wave-ravaged Fukushima Daiichi complex.

headline: Loosies
text: Cigarettes sold individually.

headline: Jefferies to Buy Prudential Bache Commodities Business
text: Jefferies said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Prudential Bache’s Global Commodities Group from Prudential Financial for $430 million.

headline: Will Members of Congress Get Paid in a Shutdown?
text: The new moral high ground in Washington as Congress careens toward a complete budget impasse is not “We shouldn’t shut the government down.” It appears to be: “Don’t pay us if we do.”

headline: Peeling Away Multiple Masks
text: He was a master of reinvention who had as many names as he did identities: Malcolm Little, Homeboy, Jack Carlton, Detroit Red, Big Red, Satan, Malachi Shabazz, Malik Shabazz, El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz and, most famously, Malcolm X. A country bumpkin who became a zoot-suited entertainer who became a petty criminal who became a self-taught intellectual who became a white-hating black nationalist who became a follower of orthodox Islam who became an international figure championing “life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness for all people.”

headline: Poetry Pairing | April 7, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: French Strike Gbagbo Defenders During Rescue of Japanese Diplomat in Ivory Coast
text: As my colleagues Adam Nossiter and Alan Cowell report, a French special forces team rescued Japan’s ambassador to the Ivory Coast before dawn on Thursday after his compound was stormed by members of a militia loyal to the self-appointed president, Laurent Gbagbo.

headline: Alec Baldwin Calls for ‘Five More Seasons’ of ’30 Rock’
text: After remarks by Alec Baldwin on Monday night suggested that the end of “30 Rock” was in sight, causing apoplectic fans to threaten to cancel their subscriptions to Kabletown, he has dialed back his comments, saying that he hopes the NBC comedy series will continue, but implying that his own time on the show was winding down.

headline: Davis Polk Names Thomas Reid Managing Partner
text: Davis Polk & Wardwell announced on Thursday that Thomas J. Reid had been elected managing partner, the first non-American-born head of the New York law firm.

headline: PNC Increases Dividend 250%
text: The PNC Financial Services Group announced on Thursday that it had raised its quarterly payout to 35 cents a share from 10 cents, a fresh sign that banks are looking to put the financial crisis behind them.

headline: ‘American Idol': Top 9 Overshadowed by Weirdness
text: Scotty McCreery > Jacob Lusk > Haley Reinhart > Paul McDonald > Lauren Alaina > Pia Toscano > Stefano Langone > Casey Abrams > James Durbin

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

headline: Co-Leaders’ Short Games Go a Long Way
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Rory McIlroy and Alvaro Quiros advanced golf’s youth movement and its global reach in a major way on a sunny Thursday at the Masters. First it was McIlroy, the 21-year-old prodigy from Northern Ireland, who went out early and shot a seven-under-par 65 that gave him almost an entire day as the youngest first-round leader in the 75-year history of the tournament.

headline: Reid Says Government Shutdown More Likely
text: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the top Democrat in the Senate, said Thursday morning that he was “not nearly as optimistic” about avoiding a shutdown as he was after a Wednesday night Oval Office meeting, saying “it looks like it’s headed in that direction.”

headline: On Average, Europe Is Doing Fine
text: “If you take the euro area as a whole . . .”

headline: On Average, Europe Is Doing Fine
text: “If you take the euro area as a whole . . .”

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic: Eat Your Way Down the L Line
text: The electronic postman delivered messages from people who will be staying deep in Brooklyn for a weekend, from a devoted child looking to blow his parents’ minds, and from an old college friend seeking guidance for a catch-up lunch on the East Side. My responses are below. You can as always ask me your own questions, at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: Cities, Soda Taxes, Obesity and More
text: Some reflections after my column about Philly:

headline: Cathleen Black Is Out as City Schools Chancellor
text: Read the final version of this article that ran in the newspaper, as well as a profile of Dennis M. Walcott and an analysis of the mayor’s attempt to cut his losses.Updated, 6:02 p.m. | Cathleen P. Black, a magazine executive with no educational experience who was named New York City schools chancellor last fall, stepped down Thursday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced.

headline: Chinese Warship May Be Nearly Ready
text: BEIJING — The Chinese state news agency has posted photographs of an aircraft carrier under reconstruction that appears to show the warship near completion. Captions with the photos said that the work would end soon and that the carrier was expected to sail later this year.

headline: Will Trump Run? Christie Doubts It
text: Is Donald Trump really running for president? Chris Christie, who calls Mr. Trump “a really good friend of mine,” doesn’t think so.

headline: Ballet Theater’s Gala Plans Have a Cuban Feel
text: Thanks to the Si Cuba festival, music and dance from the island are everywhere in New York this spring, and though American Ballet Theater isn’t on the festival program, it feels as if the company were doing its part to add to the mix. Its annual spring gala, set for May 16, will feature a tribute to Jose Manuel Carreño, the retiring principal dancer who was born in Cuba, and a one-night-only performance of the Cuban choreographer Jorge Garcia’s “Majisimo.” Cuban-born dancers will be featured in the work, including Xiomara Reyes of Ballet Theater and the sisters Lorena Feijoo (San Francisco Ballet) and Lorna Feijoo (Boston Ballet). Honorary chairs for the evening, which will also feature highlights from the coming spring season, are Michelle Obama, Carolina Herrera, Caroline Kennedy and Blaine Trump. Tickets (starting at $25) to the performance only are available at metoperafamily.org.

headline: Your Rib Questions, Answered
text: Fresh from his investigation into the secrets of oven-baked ribs, Steven Raichlen is answering readers’ questions. If there’s anything that the author of “Planet Barbecue” and the host of “Primal Grill” can elucidate for you, leave a question here.

headline: How Kind Are We
text: There’s been a shift in how we think about human evolution. Years ago, people tended to see evolution as a competition for survival of the fittest. But now there is more emphasis on the gentler virtues. People survive because they are really good cooperators. Research into hunter-gatherer cultures has contributed to this new understanding. People once believed that early humans lived in small kinship circles and fought to pass along their common genes.

headline: Political Divide Poses Risks for Portugal in Bailout Talks
text: LISBON — Portugal’s request for an international bailout puts European leaders in the difficult position of drafting a package of austerity measures and financial aid that will survive the country’s caretaker government.

headline: Even More Ryan Ridiculousness
text: Here’s the table from the CBO report you really want to focus on:

headline: Moving From Disability Benefits to Jobs
text: In an article today, I explore why Social Security is strained by the number of workers who now collect disability benefits, and why it is so difficult for these beneficiaries to go back to work.

headline: Old Village Hall | What’s Old Is New Again
text: Scott Hill couldn’t have guessed that the souvenir balsam pillow he purchased on a trip to Maine would be the first step toward opening his shop. But the modest keepsake became a retail catalyst when Hill contacted the manufacturer and custom ordered 50 “Greetings from the Catskills” pillows, which he arranged to sell in a friend’s shop near his country home in Andes, N.Y. Encouraged by the demand for memorable gifts, Hill opened two seasonal stores of his own in Andes, before establishing a permanent East Village flagship.

headline: Donors Asked to Withhold Aid Over Proposed Law in Cambodia
text: BANGKOK — A proposed law to control nongovernmental groups in Cambodia threatens to silence some of the last independent voices in an increasingly repressed nation, a group of leading international human rights agencies said Thursday.

headline: Sharjah Biennial Director Fired Over Artwork Deemed Offensive
text: 6:42 p.m. | Updated The Sharjah Biennial, a sprawling art event in the United Arab Emirates that began in 1993 and is now in the midst of its 10th iteration, has been celebrated as a pioneer in bringing ambitious contemporary art to the Middle East. But its delicate balancing act — allowing artists freedom of expression while respecting a host of cultural and religious sensitivities — seems to be proving harder to maintain.

headline: F.B.I. Files Reveal Details of Investigation of the Notorious B.I.G.’s Killing
text: The F.B.I. spent nearly two years investigating the 1997 killing of the hip-hop artist the Notorious B.I.G., focusing on a man the bureau suspected may have been the rapper’s assassin, but ended its inquiry in early 2005 after prosecutors decided there was insufficient evidence to pursue a case, according to recently released F.B.I. records reported on by The Associated Press.

headline: Selection Near on Overseer Of the 9/11 Health Fund
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is nearing the appointment of a special master to administer a multibillion-dollar fund created to provide financial compensation for rescue workers and others who became sick from toxic fumes, dust and smoke from ground zero after the 2001 attack, according to Congressional officials who are monitoring the deliberations.

headline: The Perfect Family
text: A boy and a girl. The ideal family, right?

headline: Libyan Rebels Say Airstrikes Killed 5
text: ZUEITINA, Libya — The commander of the rebel army said it was “likely” that NATO warplanes conducted an airstrike against a convoy of rebel tanks early Thursday, killing at least four people in the second case of friendly fire in less than a week.

headline: Companies to Offer Plug-In Conversions
text: Electric cars will play a starring role in many automakers’ lineups for the next few years. But what about the vehicles already out there, burning gasoline and diesel? ALTe Powertrain Technologies, founded by three former Tesla Motors executives, aims to convert those vehicles by the thousands to operate as plug-in hybrids.

headline: Cuomo the First
text: My interview with the political legend Mario Cuomo in this Sunday’s magazine just went live on The Times’s Web site. In doing some research for the article (I was trying to compare Mario’s inaugural address with his son Andrew’s), I made one of those minor discoveries that leave you feeling so lucky to be living in the Internet age. It turns out that the State of New York recently posted video from the first Governor Cuomo’s inaugural address in 1983. It’s only a few minutes, unfortunately, but it’s still fun to watch if you’re someone who likes political history, if only for the outsize presence of the interpreter for the deaf. (This is before the advent of text crawls.)

headline: Zetterberg Injury Throws Scare into Red Wings
text: There’s never a good time to lose a superstar player, but the eve of the N.H.L. playoffs might be the worst time.

headline: L’eggs Returns to TV Advertising
text: An apparel brand that was once one of the most visible in mainstream media is making a comeback.

headline: U.S. Retailers Report a Surprising Rise in March Sales
text: March was expected to be a poor month for retailers, who were hit by the triple whammy of unspringlike weather, a late Easter holiday and rising gas prices.

headline: The Farewell Concert as Filibuster
text: Last Sunday, the day after LCD Soundsystem’s final concert at Madison Square Garden, I ran into a friend who attended the show and asked him for his opinion of it. I had seen some effusive posts on Twitter from people at the show, and I read some positive reviews afterward, from sources I had previously heard of and some I hadn’t.

headline: With Rule Revision, Golf Gives Back What Cameras Take Away
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — With high-definition television and super-slow-motion replays increasingly playing a role in how golf’s rules are implemented, the sport’s governing bodies took a step back Thursday, revising a rule so that some golfers in unique situations would be only penalized, not disqualified.

headline: Missile From Gaza Hits School Bus
text: JERUSALEM — A 16-year-old Israeli boy was critically wounded on Thursday when an antitank missile fired out of Gaza struck a school bus in southern Israel, according to military officials, setting off a new round of hostilities along the Israel-Gaza border.

headline: The Gas Age
text: The Energy Information Administration has released “World Shale Gas Resources,” an important commissioned report providing an assessment of how much natural gas is locked in shale deposits in 14 regions around the world. (Here’s its overview of shale gas in the United States.) Here’s a map of the surveyed regions:

headline: U.S. Fails to Qualify for U-20 World Cup
White House Meeting on Budget Fails to End Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama's third attempt in 24 hours to end the budget standoff on Thursday night did not produce a deal to fend off a shutdown of the federal government, but negotiators issued a statement saying they had "narrowed" the issues significantly.

headline: As China Grows, So Does Its Appetite for American-Made Products
text: SHANGHAI — America’s huge trade deficit with China has raised concerns about American competitiveness and jobs moving overseas. But a new study offers a glimmer of hope to Americans: Last year, American exports to China soared 32 percent to a record $91.9 billion.

headline: Are You Smart Enough to Eat Here?
text: A few weeks ago, on Twitter, a friend raved about a wonderful meal he had just finished. Intrigued, I asked what restaurant he had just come out of. In response, I was directed to the Web site of an operation called the No. 68 Project, a “cultural dinner series.” A button marked “Request an Invitation” beckoned from the top right corner of the page.

headline: Same As He Ever Was
text: A correspondent asks how it’s possible that Paul Ryan would release such an extreme, unprofessional plan.

headline: Citi’s New Policy May Mean Fewer Bounced Checks
text: Citibank says it will change the way it processes customers’ checks, a move that could result in fewer fees for bounced checks for account holders.

headline: Judge Approves Dish’s $320 Million Deal for Blockbuster
text: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved Dish Network’s $320 million purchase of Blockbuster, paving the way for the troubled retailer to exit Chapter 11 protection.

headline: Trailer: Midnight in Paris
text: A trailer for "Midnight in Paris," a film by Woody Allen starring Owen Wilson, Marion Cotillard, Rachel McAdams, Léa Seydoux, Kathy Bates and Carla Bruni.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Joys of Feel-Bad Drama
text: An acridness hung in the air during the New Group’s revival of Wallace Shawn’s “Marie and Bruce” the other night, something I don’t often experience at the theater. It was the thick, curdled aura of an audience’s collective discomfort.

headline: Hughes Is Working on His Velocity Problem
text: Manager Joe Girardi may not like people talking about the right-hander Phil Hughes’s missing velocity, but Hughes isn’t hiding from it. With his second start of the season Friday in Boston, he knows he will need his fastball to pick up the couple of miles per hour it was missing in his 2011 debut.

headline: Mexican Authorities, Investigating Hijacking, Find 59 Bodies
text: MEXICO CITY — The discovery of 59 bodies buried in mass graves in northern Mexico led officials on Thursday to acknowledge that criminal gangs had begun to inflict a new form of terror: stopping buses and removing passengers, some never to be seen again.

headline: U.S. Seeks HSBC Customers’ Names as Part of Tax Inquiry
text: Switzerland. The Caribbean. India?

headline: Gunman Opens Fire at School in Brazil, Killing 12 Children
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — As family members mourned their loved ones and kept vigil at hospitals for the injured, this city searched for understanding Thursday after a shooting at a public school left 12 students dead and 12 others wounded.

headline: Confronting an Enduring Taboo
text: LOS ANGELES — In the past couple of weeks, a Web site called Outsports.com has written about a gay Brigham Young athlete who abided by the university’s honor code, published an essay from a lesbian basketball player at a Catholic girls school in California, and featured the Miami (Ohio) hockey team a year after the death of the openly gay student manager Brendan Burke, a son of Toronto Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke.

headline: Undecorate
text: A post-recessionary approach to interior design, where “anything goes.”

headline: Popcast: LCD Soundsystem, the Strokes and Bill Callahan
text: On this week’s Popcast, Jon Caramanica tells of two consecutive nights spent at Madison Square Garden, hearing the Strokes and LCD Soundsystem: New York City in excelsis! And Jeremy Egner speaks to Ben Ratliff about the slow but thorough evolution of the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan, who once performed as Smog, and his new album, “Apocalypse.” Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Kirkuk Tensions Highlight Concerns Over U.S. Troop Exit
text: BAGHDAD — Last summer, when the American military drew down to fewer than 50,000 troops here — from a high mark of more than 160,000 during the surge — commanders stressed that effectively nothing would change in terms of U.S. operations on the ground.

headline: App Smart Extra: Baseball Scorecards
text: MLB at Bat 11 is the app of choice for baseball spectators this year, as my App Smart column this week points out.

headline: 90 Minutes of ‘Idol’ Can’t Help ‘Breaking In’
text: A 90-minute edition of “American Idol” lifted Fox to first place in the ratings on Wednesday, but the network struggled to keep many of those viewers tuned in at 9:30 p.m. for its new sitcom “Breaking In.”

headline: Styled to a T | Léa Seydoux
text: The Trend

headline: A Fake Tax Rattles Classic Car Buffs
text: As April Fool’s gags go, the Shelby American Automobile Club’s 2011 spoof did not seem especially convincing. Until, that is, hundreds of classic car lovers across the country were duped, became enraged and started to organize against a nonexistent threat.

headline: Galloping Food Price Index Shows First Dip in Months
text: In Thursday’s Times, I write about the impact that cultivating food crops to manufacture biofuels has had on food prices, which have been at or near record highs over the last six months, On Thursday, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization released its latest Food Price Index, which showed a slight decline for the month of March.

headline: Video of Aftershock Shaking Japan
text: As my colleague Andrew Pollack reports, a 7.1 magnitude aftershock struck off the east coast of Japan on Thursday.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Reveals A-Class Concept Car
text: Mercedes-Benz has revealed the concept version of its new A-Class, set for display at the coming Shanghai and New York auto shows. The smallest car in the German automaker’s line, the A-Class is a far cry from the original of 1997. That model’s novel architecture set passengers above the drive train, lending it a podlike quality and a resemblance to the cars of the Smart brand owned by Mercedes.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: This week, we’re going off-road. The hint: This city was the site of the first leg of a race in the World Rally Championship last month.

headline: A Fake Tax Rattles Classic Car Buffs
text: From our colleagues at City Room:

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Torrey Smith, 5th-Ranked Receiver
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at each position. 5.Torrey Smith, Maryland (6-0, 204)

headline: From Behind the Scenes, an Influential Adviser Speaks Out
text: Roger C. Altman — whose Evercore Partners has had advisory role in some of the latest big deals, including Nasdaq’s play for the New York Stock Exchange, AT&T’s proposed acquisition of T-Mobile USA, and Berkshire Hathaway’s bid for Lubrizol — talks to CNBC about the budget battle, issues with the AT&T deal, and the insider trading speculation about David L. Sokol, who recently resigned from Berkshire.

headline: Instant Loops of Images, From an iPhone App
text: An animated GIF created with the 3Frames app. If the animation is driving you batty, then this post may not be for you.

headline: Putting the Juice in ‘Jerusalem’
text: DURING rehearsals in 2009 for the London production of “Jerusalem,” Jez Butterworth’s play about outcasts in modern England, the actor Mark Rylance drove one Sunday to the rural village of Pewsey to look up Micky Lay, a retired builder who was the inspiration for Rooster Byron, Mr. Rylance’s drug-dealing, authority-defying character. The encounter did not go well. Mr. Rylance walked past the wrecked cars in Mr. Lay’s yard and knocked on his front door, where wood had been nailed over shattered glass. Mr. Lay answered with an “Awww what’a ye want?” said Mr. Rylance, who identified himself and asked for a word. In colorful profanity, Mr. Lay told him to go away.

headline: Microsoft to Produce Telematics System for Toyota
text: Toyota and Microsoft this week announced a partnership that will expand Microsoft’s penetration in automotive telematics, while providing Toyota with on-board communication, control and entertainment electronics. While this marks the first time the two companies have joined forces to develop in-car systems, they have worked together for more than 10 years on a mobile Internet project for Japan.

headline: City Shuts Fatty ‘Cue After It Gets 115 Violation Points
text: Even some of the best restaurants in town have had trouble passing health inspections. But Eater reports that Fatty ’Cue, Zakary Pelaccio’s very popular Asian barbecue restaurant in Brooklyn, has been shut down by the city health department after it rang up 115 violation points in an inspection on Monday. (You need fewer than 14 points to get an A, and fewer than 28 to get a B.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Iraq and Japan.

headline: OMG!!! Exploring Slang
text: Overview | What role does slang play in our language? How does slang both shape and reflect culture? In this lesson, students consider the slang words they use daily and the role slang plays in our culture. Then, they explore the etymologies of these and other slang words and display their findings in a visually interesting way, as well as compile a class dictionary.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Hanna’
text: In the action thriller “Hanna,” Saoirse Ronan plays a teenager who was raised in an isolated environment in Finland and trained to be an assassin. This scene is set in Morocco and shows her coming into contact with modern technology for the first time. The director Joe Wright discusses some of the ideas behind the scene and the techniques he used to bring its objects to life.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Hanna'
text: The director Joe Wright narrates a scene from the action thriller "Hanna," starring Saoirse Ronan.

headline: The GoSmart Clip: A Well-Made Bad Idea
text: The GoSmart Clip is the best engineered bad idea I’ve seen in a long time.

headline: House Leaders Exchange Barbs as Government Shutdown Looms
text: Passions were running high in the House on Thursday morning as a federal government shutdown loomed and members of Congress began to get queasy about the prospect of being blamed for the ensuing disruptions.

headline: Justice Memo Upholds Libya Strikes
text: President Obama had the constitutional power to lawfully launch military strikes in Libya without permission from Congress because he “could reasonably determine that such use of force was in the national interest,” the Justice Department concluded in an internal memorandum released on Thursday.

headline: Disney Cruises Adds New York as Port of Call
text: Most destinations for the Disney Cruise Line promise sun and sand (the Bahamas, Grand Cayman) or stunning scenery (Alaska, the Mexican Riviera). But a different set of attractions — and perhaps a little big-city attitude — characterizes the newest addition to its lineup of ports of call: New York City. Starting in May 2012, the Disney Magic cruise ship, which accommodates about 2,700 passengers, will sail 20 cruises, departing from the Manhattan Cruise Terminal on the Hudson River.

headline: The High (G)Low | NOOKA Zub Zirc Watch
text: What: NOOKA Zub Zirc low watch

headline: Video Interview With Woman Who Said She Was Raped by Qaddafi Forces
text: Over the objections of Libyan information ministry officials, but with the support of Saadi el-Qaddafi, one of the Libyan leader’s sons, on Thursday CNN broadcast an on-camera interview with Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan lawyer who was dragged away from foreign journalists nearly two weeks ago, after she said that she had been gang-raped by government security forces.

headline: The Caucus: Budget Negotiations Falter
text: April 7, 2011 - Jennifer Steinhauer reports from Capitol Hill where Democrats and Republicans remain far apart on a budget deal to avert a government shutdown on Friday night.

headline: Towards a Talking Newspaper
text: A recently developed app uses an iPhone’s computing power to recognize an image and insert a video matching the photo onto the screen, for instance, creating a moving image inside a newspaper.

headline: Surprise in Kidnapping Case: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
text: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — Phillip Garrido, the convicted sex offender accused of kidnapping and holding Jaycee Dugard captive for 18 years, pleaded not guilty on Thursday as his lawyer challenged the composition of the grand jury that indicted him and his wife last fall.

headline: Facebook Opens Up Its Server and Data Center Designs
text: In the movie “Fight Club,” Tyler Durden, the character played by Brad Pitt, says, “The first rule of fight club is you do not talk about fight club.”

headline: Four Foreign Journalists Held in Libya
text: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi have detained four foreign journalists in Libya, the GlobalPost news organization said Thursday, among them one of its contributing reporters, James Foley.

headline: Garden Shop | Marni
text: The Salone del Mobile design fair in Milan starts this week, and every year it’s a similar story: chairs and sofas as far as the eye can see and yet not so many places to sit and relax. In a nod to the once-abundant greenery in this city, Marni has installed a courtyard oasis in front of its shop at Via Spiga 50.

headline: The Scooba Robot Also Mesmerizes Children
text: When I was young, I always thought “robot” meant something with arms and legs and a head. I can still remember feeling cheated when I saw an automotive factory “robot” on TV that was nothing more than an arm that drilled holes. And I’ll bet I’m not alone. I’ll bet all kinds of children encounter that moment of disillusionment when they first encounter robot inflation.

headline: The Good Girl
text: It’s a shame that the snarky characters on “iCarly” don’t measure up to the actress Miranda Cosgrove as good role models. The show’s humor is often based on teasing, harsh sarcasm and destructive practical jokes. The character of Sam boasts about her multiple arrests. As I tell my sons: In real life, no one would laugh.MELISSA JANOSKI,Dallas, Pa., e-mail

headline: The Seekers
text: As a young female graduate student in the sciences, I take issue with your description of Bridget Moynahan’s character in “I, Robot” as “the impossibly gorgeous scientist.” I don’t think that it’s acceptable to propagate wrongful stereotypes. This may seem like a minor note, but it’s these small mistakes that can lead to people holding unconscious and damaging attitudes toward us.MARGARET HO,Pasadena, Calif., e-mail

headline: The Soloist
text: Although I applaud Tim Crothers for featuring the talented Indi Cowie, it’s unfortunate that his article implied that the students of Green Hope High School are unimpressed with her skill. As a student myself, I would have encouraged Crothers to interview a student, as he would have found a welcoming group who wish her nothing but the best. While it nicely portrayed Cowie as an afterthought, the misspelling of her name in both our talent-show program and school newspaper were mistakes. The article left the reader with an impression that Cowie is surrounded by people who are unwelcoming or prone to jealously, which is simply not the case.

headline: A Year After G.M. Unloaded It, Saab Is in Trouble Again
text: Little more than a year after General Motors engineered a sale that saved Saab from oblivion, the carmaker is facing a fresh bout of financial troubles that threaten to spread pain across Sweden.

headline: Battle Starts Over British Bank Rules
text: As Wall Street banks fight to fend off further regulation, the battle in Britain over how best to manage financial institutions considered too big to fail is just beginning.

headline: Among the Guerrillas
text: Bill Keller’s statement that The Times “pretty much overlooked the Holocaust as it was happening” is an understatement. Burying news of mass genocide deep in the back pages of a trusted news source is burying it — much as the paper’s co-opting and continuous use of the term “ethnic cleansing” (eventually even omitting the quotation marks) has sanitized news of mass genocide and slaughter.

headline: Just Add Water
text: “Since I was a little girl, I’ve been collecting flowers and floral fabrics,” says Emilie Bon, the swimwear designer behind the year-old lingerie-inspired line Lilibon. The latest collection of eight petal-printed items includes bandeau and pinup-style maillots and bikinis trimmed in lace and tulle. Bon’s inspiration? A pressed anemone she found among her childhood keepsakes.

headline: How to Cook a Screaming Eagle
text: Funny to see this article on the same day that many students received their acceptance packets from colleges for the Class of 2015. Congrats to future consumers of greasy, cheesy, crusty sandwiches at college campuses everywhere. You’re all about to make some great college dining memories.

headline: ‘Girl With the Dragon Tattoo’ Sells More Than 1 Million Digital Copies
text: In what is believed to be a first for an e-book, “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” by the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has sold more than a million copies in its digital format, Knopf said on Thursday. Knopf, part of Random House, said the combined digital sales for all three books in the blockbuster “Millennium” series, which includes “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” is now more than three million copies. The trilogy is selling at a clip of more than 500,000 copies a month in all formats. “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” which went on sale in the United States in September 2008, has sold more than 300,000 copies in hardcover.

headline: Showtime Orders New Series Starring Don Cheadle and Claire Danes
text: Once the network of female protagonists in unexpected professions and/or  life-or-death situations, Showtime continues its transition to the network of offbeat celebrity casting that we’re willing to at least give a chance. (And also “Gigolos.”) Adding to a roster of original programming that includes “The Borgias,” “Shameless,” “Weeds” and “The Big C,” Showtime said on Thursday it had picked up the first seasons of two new series: “House of Lies,” a comedy starring Don Cheadle and Kristen Bell, and “Homeland,” a drama starring Claire Danes, Damien Lewis and Mandy Patinkin.

headline: Inquiry Finds No Evidence of Undue Influence on Safety Agency
text: There is no evidence that safety investigations conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration have been influenced by former agency officials who now work for automakers or the former auto officials who work for the agency, said a report released on Thursday by the Office of the Inspector General for the Transportation Department, which oversees N.H.T.S.A.

headline: Feeding Your Family From a Dumpster
text: Two years ago, Corbyn Hanson Hightower was earning six figures. Then the Great Recession hit, and Ms. Hightower and her husband sold their car, found a cheaper, draftier home, canceled cable and Internet, worked odd jobs, depleted their savings and “stripped ourselves to the bare minimum” while supporting three children.

headline: R.A. Dickey Ready for Home Opener … Again
text: PHILADELPHIA – R.A. Dickey will make his second start in a home opener Friday, but his first as a primarily knuckleball pitcher.

headline: Video: Government Shutdown Nears as Budget Negotiations Falter
text: Read Jennifer Steinhauer’s related story, Gung-Ho for Big Cuts in Spending, Less Fond of the Ones That Hurt Back Home, published in Thursday’s Times.

headline: City to Appeal Order to Release Police Shooting Data
text: In February, a Manhattan judge gave the city 60 days to turn over 13 years of the internal documents generated whenever a city police officer opens fire on a civilian.

headline: Brooklyn Bridge, 12:07 P.M.
text: In some countries, couples put padlocks on bridges and throw the keys in the river to symbolize their enduring love. Including this one.

headline: After Cathie Black
text: The big news of the day, at least in the realm of education, is that Cathleen Black is stepping down after just a few months as New York City’s schools chancellor. To the opponents of education reform who vilified her — and who are now most likely celebrating her departure — Black was a perfect emblem of the reform movement’s arrogance, a power-suited publishing executive who had never attended, let alone worked at, a public school. To the reformers, this was at least part of her virtue. She was further proof that what is needed to repair our badly broken public schools is the fresh perspective of an outsider.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Iraq and Japan.

headline: Bob Dylan’s Legal Fan Club
text: It’s been a big week for Bob Dylan news.

headline: TimesCast | April 7, 2011
text: David D. Kirkpatrick reports on recent NATO airstrikes and the disorganized rebel forces in eastern Libya.

headline: Gay Couples Closer to Receiving Medicaid Spousal Protections
text: Same-sex couples are one step closer to receiving protections that heterosexual married couples get when they receive long-term care through Medicaid — that is, the healthy partner will be able to keep some of the ailing partner’s money and remain in their home.

headline: Kultur Shock Plays the Balkans
text: A Gypsy punk metal band from Seattle provided a few hours’ relief from the ethnic, political and social tensions in Bosnia.

headline: A Grand Transformation in 'Arthur'
text: Jason Winer, the director of "Arthur," narrates a look at a scene shot inside Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Can Obama Leave Washington With Budget Unresolved?
text: Will President Obama leave Washington in the hours before a possible government shutdown?

headline: O Pioneers! | Kelly Reichardt’s Anti-Western
text: The director Kelly Reichardt is one of very few women in American independent cinema who has managed to have a sustained career making full-length features. Her small-scale, slow-burn tales of the lost and dispossessed, like “Old Joy” and “Wendy and Lucy,” have garnered critical acclaim for their larger social and political relevance. In her latest film, “Meek’s Cutoff,” opening Friday in New York, the lost are a group of pioneers crossing the Cascade Mountains in 1845, who find themselves wandering the high plain desert after they decide to take a shortcut. Here, Reichardt discusses her unorthodox take on the Western genre, starring her frequent collaborator Michelle Williams.

headline: Hugh Grant Pays Back The News of the World, In Kind
text: The New Statesman has published an article by the actor — and tabloid victim — Hugh Grant, who managed to secretly tape a former News of the World journalist (now a pub owner, how perfect) saying that the News of the World’s editor at the time knew all about the phone hacking going on at the paper. You can read a little bit of the story on the New Statesman’s Web site — the rest is behind its pay wall (enough said) — but The Guardian spills most of the beans. And this is a good moment to have another look at our magazine’s excellent piece on the hacking scandal.

headline: Other Than That, We Loved the Place
text: My wife went to New York City last week to see a show. Afterward, she went to dinner with some friends who ran into some other friends and they all dined together.

headline: Of New Albums and Old Friends
text: Rolling Stone’s Web site has a free stream of Robbie Robertson’s new album, “How to Become Clairvoyant,” his first since 1998.

headline: State Education Chief to Step Down
text: The New York state education commissioner, David M. Steiner, said Thursday that he would be resigning from his position in August.

headline: Bellini Work at Frick Is Seen in a New Light
text: Since 1915, when Henry Clay Frick bought Giovanni Bellini’s “St. Francis in the Desert,” that Renaissance painting has hung in the grand Living Hall of the Frick Collection, in the company of works by El Greco, Holbein and Titian.

headline: Twins’ Misery Against Yankees Is Compounded by Injury
text: It is a remarkably common bit of baseball. The second baseman fields the throw from the third baseman and fires the ball to first to try to record a double play. The runner slides aggressively, barreling into the second baseman in an effort to disrupt his throw. There is a collision. Sometimes the runner succeeds in breaking up the double play. Sometimes he does not. Both players dust themselves off and go about their business.

headline: And the Cobra’s Name Isssssss …
text: Mia.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 7, 2010
text: For the second time in less than a week, rebel fighters say NATO warplanes mistakenly attacked their troops.

headline: Here Comes the Bride, a Wedding Crasher in Pursuit
text: “Babies with money” is one character’s all-too-accurate description of the guests at the Long Island wedding of Zoe (Uma Thurman) and Whit (Lee Pace) in Max Winkler’s romantic comedy “Ceremony.” The willowy bride-to-be certainly acts like an infant. Throughout the movie, Ms. Thurman’s facial expressions suggest a peevish spoiled child about to stomp her feet and throw a full-scale tantrum.

headline: Augmented Reality Comes Closer to Reality
text: Last week I wrote about how cyber politics and crime on the Internet had been foreseen with eerie accuracy by science fiction writers. For example, the computer scientist Vernor Vinge’s classic 1981 novella “True Names” described the impact of the Net long before most people had personal computers, let alone an Internet connection.

headline: A Bar That Counts on Its Regulars
text: IN the universe of academic disciplines, one of the easiest to master is tavern math.

headline: Golfing in New York
text: Images of some of the golf courses in the city.

headline: Fairways Where Golf Becomes the City Game
text: LET’S get this out of the way: The golf courses in New York City will never be confused with Pebble Beach, Bethpage Black or any of America’s great public courses. If you want a four-and-a-half-hour round, meticulously manicured greens or even an unfailingly polite playing partner, consider going elsewhere.

headline: The Anguish of Identity
text: “To Die Like a Man,” a ruminative exploration of gender identity, desire and aging, begins with a close-up of a young man’s face being daubed with camouflage paint by a fellow soldier in preparation for a training mission. For the rest of this melancholic film by the Portuguese director João Pedro Rodrigues that image lingers as a mental double exposure with the visage of the movie’s protagonist, Tonia (Fernando Santos), a fading drag queen in 1980s Lisbon. The war paint and makeup worn by Tonia, who appears in various stages of drag, are both disguises.

headline: Expedia Plans to Split Into Two
text: TripAdvisor would become a separate, publicly traded company under the plan.

headline: Theater Listings: April 8 — 14
text: Theater

headline: Hazards: For Children in E.R., a Big Increase in CT Scans
text: The number of computed tomography scans performed on children visiting hospital emergency rooms has increased fivefold in recent years, to 1.65 million in 2008 from 330,000 in 1995, a new study has found.

headline: Man Needs Caffeine Jolt or Reversal of Fortune
text: There are movies that are so low key they risk enervation. If the movie is purposely chill, you may be able to go with the relaxed flow; but if it’s too subdued, you might feel like slapping it (or yourself) awake. “Henry’s Crime,” a muted comedy with Keanu Reeves, is a painless, at times likable, drifty comedy. But its mood is so muffled and point so submerged, it’s difficult to see why Mr. Reeves and the rest of the cast pooled their talents to make a movie about a nowhere man going no place in particular in Buffalo.

headline: Conyers Releases Report on Panther Case
text: The ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, Representative John Conyers of Michigan, on Thursday released a 78-page Justice Department report about a much-disputed voter-intimidation case involving the New Black Panther Party, a radical fringe group.

headline: A Fresh Take on Sea-Level Rise
text: For readers who are following the science of sea-level rise, a new overview paper has been published that makes indispensable reading. One of the great experts in the field, John A. Church of Australia, and his collaborator Neil J. White analyze records from instruments called tide gauges, starting in the 19th century and running into the 21st, and they also incorporate the satellite measurements of sea level that have been available since 1993.

headline: Vessels of Clay, Centuries Old, That Speak to Modernity
text: More than most other kinds of art or craft, ceramic works can seem unbound by time. A vase might be hundreds of years old and yet look as if it were made only decades ago. That is partly because glazed and fired clay does not show its age the way paint, canvas, wood and even stone do. And it is partly because some styles practiced in the past by forgotten artisans embody feelings of liveliness and immediacy that modern artists love to emulate.

headline: House Votes to Bar E.P.A. From Regulating Industrial Emissions
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted 255 to 172 on Thursday to halt the Obama administration’s program to regulate industrial air emissions linked to climate change, delivering a rebuke to a central tenet of the president’s energy and environmental policy.

headline: Gleaning the True Identity of an Enigmatic Forger
text: Elmyr de Hory, a Hungarian-born painter known for forging works by Picasso, Modigliani and Matisse, was the subject of biographies and documentaries full of his own lies about his background. In 1976, while under investigation for art fraud, he committed suicide by overdosing on sleeping pills, leaving behind boxes of paperwork that are now yielding some truths.

headline: Keeping Score: Underdogs Have Little Bite in N.B.A. Playoffs
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: 2011 Masters Replay: Day 1
text: After Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus teed off, the first round of the 2011 Masters was under way.

headline: Now, Chinatown Has Its Own Blog
text: A group of Asian-American journalists has started a new blog, Our Chinatown, that seeks to bring comprehensive and immediate news coverage to a complicated and intriguing city neighborhood that is often overlooked by reporters.

headline: After Final Entreaties, Jury Gets Bonds Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Federal prosecutors gave one final appeal to jurors in Barry Bonds’s perjury case Thursday, asking for them to find Bonds guilty and emphasizing how simple it would have been for him to avoid this trial.

headline: Gallantry in Real Estate
text: IT started as just another Chelsea studio, a space being offered by Citi Habitats for $1,700 a month. But for Jason Saft, one of the agency’s brokers, this little apartment with the puce-colored wall and worn floors turned into the ultimate object of desire.

headline: Two ‘Jersey Shore’ Spin-Offs Set for 2012
text: When the cast of “Jersey Shore” gets back from Italy later this year, three of the cast members will start work on their own reality shows. MTV said Thursday that it had ordered two such spin-offs, one featuring Paul DelVecchio, known as DJ Pauly D, and the other featuring Nicole Polizzi and Jenni Farley, known as Snooki and JWoww.

headline: A Lush Life Revisited, With Nanny on Board
text: It would be conventional to describe “Arthur” as a vehicle for the talents of Russell Brand, who plays the boozy billionaire of the title, but that would be to get it backward. Mr. Brand, with his stringy hair, stretched-out body and nutty British demeanor, is more like the beast of burden, charged with hauling this grim load of mediocrity to the box office. The film, directed by Jason Winer and based on a fondly recalled 1981 comedy of the same name starring Dudley Moore, has been made according to a lazy and cynical commercial blueprint. You’ve seen it in the lesser work of Will Ferrell, Adam Sandler and most other male comedians who walk the line between popularity and overexposure. The star does his patented shtick, supported by a handful of blue-chip supporting performers, as the story lurches through contrived, seminaughty comic set pieces toward a sentimental ending.

headline: Avoiding Refinancing Costs After Divorce
text: DIVORCED homeowners wrangling with the task of removing a former spouse’s name from the mortgage after buying out his or her equity stake in the marital house may think that refinancing is the only choice.

headline: It’s Yale Glee Club’s Year to Look Back, and Ahead
text: They came in bow ties and crimson gowns, spry of step or aided by walkers, their college memories more or less intact. On Feb. 12, nearly 650 members of the Yale Glee Club, past and present, poured into Woolsey Hall on the university’s campus in New Haven with a singular purpose: to celebrate the ensemble’s 150th anniversary. And naturally, to sing.

headline: 36 Hours in Abu Dhabi
text: Once aloof from the spendthrift ways of neighboring Dubai, Abu Dhabi is now ticking off items on a five-star shopping list.

headline: In Macaques, Familiarity Breeds...More Macaques?
text: Among rhesus macaques, a female’s face becomes darker when she ovulates, and males can pick up the signal — but some males get the message more clearly than others.

headline: Another Financial District Building Converts to Residential
text: JOHN STREET, a narrow sliver that runs just eight blocks from Broadway to the South Street Seaport, has been the site of a large number of the office-to-residential conversions in the financial district. Now, one of its last remaining office towers has been tapped to become a rental building.

headline: 36 Hours in Abu Dhabi
text: WHAT would you do with $600 billion in cash? If you’re the capital of the United Arab Emirates, rich in oil, the answer is easy: go shopping. Once aloof from the spendthrift ways of neighboring Dubai, Abu Dhabi — which, so far, has not experienced the unrest many Arab countries are facing — is now ticking off items on a five-star shopping list. Top-notch museums? New branches of the Louvre and Guggenheim are rising from the sands. High-profile events? The Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, Abu Dhabi Film Festival and Gourmet Abu Dhabi have made their debuts in recent years. Toss in a multibillion-dollar hotel project and a stunning new mosque and you have one of the world’s most ambitious new destinations.

headline: At Least He Won’t Cost a Meal
text: A close friend is getting married. When he invited us, I was pregnant and said, “I hope we can come, but it depends how new parenthood is treating us.” Since then, we’ve accepted and booked nonrefundable plane tickets. Now it occurs to me that our baby might not be welcome at the wedding. But I’m afraid to ask, because if we can’t bring him, we’ll have to miss it and eat the cost of the tickets. My plan is to feign ignorance, bring the baby and hope for the best. Is that wrong? Melanie, Boston

headline: JPMorgan Paid Dimon $20.8 Million in 2010
text: JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, a total of $20.8 million last year, a substantial increase from $1.3 million he received in 2009, the bank disclosed on Thursday afternoon in a regulatory filing.

headline: Daddy’s Lethal Girl Ventures Into the Big, Bad World
text: In the last “Rocky” flick, a boxing guru tells the tired, sexagenarian fighter played by the tired, middle-aged Sylvester Stallone that he’s a wreck, with arthritis in his neck and calcium deposits in his joints. Rocky has to get in shape if he wants to ascend the stairs of victory again, so the trainer recommends that they employ “good old-fashioned blunt force trauma” and “start building some hurtin’ bombs!” The spookily pale and pretty underage killing machine in “Hanna” played by Saoirse Ronan, then 16, doesn’t have a couple of bombs that hurt: she has a veritable nuclear arsenal of pain at her quick, kinetic disposal.

headline: Base Camp in a Bomb Crater
text: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

headline: The Uncertain Fate of an Ex-Department Store
text: IT’S more than odd; it’s wonderfully bizarre: the round-cornered, Pepto-pink loft building at Grand and Orchard Streets. This ancient, creaky thing from 1886 is one of the oldest department store structures in New York, the last traces of Ridley’s, once famous but now a dot at the end of a footnote. The question at hand: Is it a landmark, or a development site?

headline: Bacterium Puts Insect on Evolution Fast Track
text: It appears to be a case of high-speed evolution.

headline: Sharing the Shame After My Arrest
text: WE had been married for just over a year when the F.B.I. showed up at our house at 6 a.m. and arrested me. They arrested my husband, too, although at the time that seemed beside the point. A stickler for rules who had never even gotten a speeding ticket, I was handcuffed in my mismatched pajamas and hauled away. My teeth weren’t even brushed.

headline: Pablo Picasso’s Blue Pajama Period
text: Photograph by Taea Thale. Fashion editor: Jason Rider. Fashion assistant: Elena Hale. Grooming by Andre Gunn at the Wall Group.From left, on Keegan Monaghan: Michael Kors jacket, $495, and pants, $295. Go to saks.com. Headtrippaz LTD T-shirt, price on request. Go to headtrippaz.com. On Darius Greyson: N. Hoolywood shirt, price on request. Go to n-hoolywood.com. On Oto Gillen: Marc by Marc Jacobs shirt, $168. Call (212) 929-0304. Marni trunks, $297. Go to marni.com. On Eugene Wasserman: Band of Outsiders shirt, $200, and pants, $225. For shirt, go to shopconfederacy.com. For pants, go to contextclothing.com.If you want to listen to Pablo Picasso’s first record, go to the band’s Web site and download it for free. It was meant to be consumed that way — no record label, no distribution, no expensive studio time, just free MP3s. “I don’t really have much hope of making money from our music,” says Eugene Wasserman, the band’s guitarist. “And we just thought it would be better to do it ourselves.” The band — Wasserman, Darius Greyson (vocals), Keegan Monaghan (bass) and Oto Gillen (drums) — recorded the whole thing in their New York practice space. “I think the live show is the most important thing anyways,” Greyson adds. “The record just sounds the way we play them onstage.”

headline: Fatty ‘Cue Reopens
text: Fatty ’Cue, which was shut down by the city health department on Monday, just reopened after a reinspection Thursday afternoon.

headline: For Obama, a Mini-Vacation Is in Limbo
text: President Obama has some real motivation for getting a budget deal: his family vacation.

headline: Slaughterhouse Shortage Stunting Area’s Eat-Local Movement
text: One might expect the Bay Area — as the epicenter of the eat-local movement and a region with a long tradition of cattle ranching — to be a mecca for producers of organic and grass-fed beef. But there is a problem: a shortage of slaughterhouses is so acute that it is stunting the growth of this emerging industry.

headline: ‘Rooms With a View’
text: Images from the exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Romantics Shining Clear Light on Daily Existence
text: The first thing that distinguishes “Rooms With a View: The Open Window in the 19th Century,” a compact, quietly splendid exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is simply this: Its galleries have been painted a wonderful shade of oyster-grayish white. In the context of the Met, where the walls of special exhibitions tend toward plum, russet or evergreen, this pale, elegant hue is the visual equivalent of smelling salts.

headline: A Cozy Studio in a Presentable Building
text: BENJAMIN BILBAO knew a nice apartment in his native borough of Queens was well within his reach. But Manhattan had been his home for most of his adult life, and even with its higher price tag, that is where he wanted to be.

headline: Megacarats From Menus of the Rich
text: “The recipe for making an exquisite piece of jewelry is akin to haute cuisine: masters employ special techniques to mix and adorn top-quality ingredients, creating something that is far greater than the sum of its parts.” So says the unctuous wall text introducing “Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels,” a banquet of the most distasteful variety at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Film can take us anywhere we want to go, and sometimes to places we don’t. Luckily, the hosts of the movies featured in this week’s column aren’t charging much for transportation.

headline: Guitar Rock, Stretched on the Canvas of a Big Stage
text: The movie-palace splendor of Radio City Music Hall made an appropriately majestic backdrop for Explosions in the Sky, an instrumental rock band from Austin, Tex., whose music can swell to fill any grand space. The group was headlining a triple bill — with the band Low and a solo-piano set by Eluvium, a k a Matthew Cooper — that elevated modest brooding to monumental scale. The big-hall concert was in part a reward for indie-rock perseverance: Explosions in the Sky released its first recordings in 2000, Low in 1994.

headline: How Secrecy Undermines Audit Reform
text: For the auditing industry, the financial crisis was really not that bad.

headline: Ever-Growing Image of a Stumbling Third Term for Bloomberg
text: In selecting Cathleen P. Black as schools chancellor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was, in many ways, playing to type: a man famous for ignoring advice, relying on his own instincts and doing the opposite of what an ordinary politician would do had chosen as leader of the nation’s largest school system a woman with no relevant experience whom he knew socially.

headline: Time Warner Cable and Viacom Seek Ruling on iPad App
text: Time Warner Cable and Viacom each filed lawsuits on Thursday that seek to resolve a stormy dispute in the television business over the right to stream channels to new devices like iPads.

headline: After Quick Start, Mets’ Trip Ends Badly
text: PHILADELPHIA — What began with so much promise and a little surprise ended with a flattening thud Thursday. After starting the season with victories in three of their first four games, raising expectations that they could return home as unexpected conquering heroes, the Mets lost the final two games of their season-opening trip and went home with a modest 3-3 record.

headline: Like Old Times, Almost, in an English Household
text: There is a sly grace note tucked into “Upstairs Downstairs,” the sequel to the legendary series of the 1970s. The parlor maid Rose Buck (Jean Marsh) is back in service at 165 Eaton Place, and she worries that her new mistress considers her over the hill.

headline: Blazing a Trail
text: Images from Kelly Reichardt’s “Meek’s Cutoff.”

headline: Trump Plans Meeting on Arizona Birth Bill
text: Donald Trump is investing more in the conspiracy theories about President Obama’s birth certificate as he explores his own bid for the presidency.

headline: Attitude and Hip-Hop for the Naughty Sides, Ballet for the Nice
text: It’s harder to put together a well-balanced program of dances than most audiences realize. Artistic directors have to consider each piece’s mood, dance style, music and general aesthetic, then layer the works in a way that builds to a satisfying conclusion. It’s even harder when the company is a junior troupe like Ailey II, the younger branch of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater that offers a bridge between student and professional years.

headline: Out on the Frontier, Bringing All That Baggage With Them
text: The first thing you see in “Meek’s Cutoff,” after a hand-scrawled title card placing the action in the Oregon Territory in 1845, is a small group of settlers fording a river. It’s a treacherous, tedious undertaking, and Kelly Reichardt, the director of this tough, quiet revelation of a movie, films it in an uninflected style that makes everything feel at once mundane and mysterious. We are seeing the world more or less exactly as it looked to those hardy, foolish souls on screen (and almost forgetting to notice that most of them are actors we recognize from elsewhere). The way that world looked to them was unimaginably strange, every hill and rock loaded with portent, promise and menace.

headline: House Tour: Saugerties, N.Y.
text: A five-bedroom house on 12 acres overlooks the Hudson River in Saugerties, N.Y.

headline: Furlough Notices Arrive for Federal Workers
text: A government shutdown may yet be averted, but a last-minute deal by President Obama and Congressional leaders will come too late for some of the most fragile egos in Washington.

headline: House Tour: Saugerties, N.Y.
text: WHAT Five-bedroom house on 12 acres overlooking the Hudson River

headline: Good News for Spouses of Reverse Mortgage Holders
text: In the face of a lawsuit from the AARP Foundation, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has backed off an apparent policy change that was putting some widows and widowers on the brink of foreclosure.

headline: Mitchell C. Hochberg
text: Mr. Hochberg, 58, is the managing principal of Madden Real Estate Ventures, a real estate investment, development and advisory firm specializing in hospitality and residential projects.

headline: Ellsworth Kelly
David Altmejd
text: Andrea Rosen Gallery

headline: Stuart Brisley

headline: Preserving the ‘Gems’ of the Gold Coast
text: THOUGH lovingly restored in the last eight years, Salt Meadow, the circa 1846 colonial in the tony Harriman Estates section in Sands Point, hardly compares to the newer and more ostentatious mansions nearby. Its owners, Arlene Getz and Rob Schapiro, admit that it’s the runt of the block — albeit a runt with a vineyard and 2.7 acres.

headline: New Projects, at last, for Mount Vernon
text: MOUNT VERNON, all but bypassed in recent years as developers set their sights on cities like White Plains and Yonkers, now has two residential projects under way: market-rate condominiums and a mixed-use rental complex to include moderately priced housing and units for retirees.

text: A closer look at Bellini’s painting at the Frick Collection in New York.

headline: Before Going Dark, One Last Attempt at Explaining New York City
text: Eons ago, the student newspaper that I wrote for and edited at City College of New York had a tradition for former editors who were graduating. It gave them a final crack at the typewriter to produce what we called a Thirty column.

headline: They Huffed and Puffed and Waited to Exhale
text: It may be that “Your Highness,” a self-conscious, sometimes overly self-satisfied goof about ye olde high times, may be better enjoyed in an herb-enhanced condition. Getting stoned is, after all, a running joke in this comedy, which is as thin as rolling paper and just as ephemeral. Certainly its milieu — a fantasy past filled with mythical beasts, a dwarf kingdom and bare-breasted wild women smeared in white who look as if they stepped off the cover of a classic punk album by the Slits — seems to have been hatched in an altered state. Conjoined laughing and groaning is often the point when jokes are calibrated to go up (or down) with smoke.

headline: A Bar That Counts Its Regulars
text: IN the universe of academic disciplines, one of the easiest to master is tavern math.

text: THE GIST Older parents are happier than younger parents.

headline: Success in These M.&A. Deals Appears on a Report Card
text: Tina Fineberg for The New York TimesChristina Feng, standing, teaches a high school class on Wall Street deals.

headline: As Standoff Continues, a Bleaker Outlook for Ivory Coast
text: ACCRA, Ghana — Surrounded, outnumbered and under repeated attacks, the Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo has held out against all odds, refusing to budge from the presidential residence in a last stand that has both befuddled and infuriated the international powers that are demanding his surrender.
