headline: Spoiler Alert: It Hits an Iceberg
text: THERE are two kinds of spoilers at the movies: The kind where someone gives away the plot point upon which the entire moviegoing experience rests, that ruins the movie before it’s even begun, that makes you say “I might as well stay home.” And the type where someone tells you the ship sinks in “Titanic.” One can never be too careful. After all, it’s been at least a decade since “The Sixth Sense” (1999), “The Crying Game” (1992) or “The Others” (2001) were first released, yet each contains a payoff that friends still won’t reveal to friends, lest the experience be ruined. Such indiscretions can have lifelong effects.

headline: Sentence of the Week: The Pale King Edition
text: This edition of Shamblanderson’s Sentence of the Week comes front-loaded with a giant chunk of David Foster Wallace. (Not to get into a big publishing-industry back story that nobody cares about, but this is because I was forbidden to tweet sentences from “The Pale King,” D.F.W.’s unfinished novel, as I read them, because of a nondisclosure agreement the publisher forced all reviewers to sign. Which later turned out to be a specious pseudo-embargo that enraged booksellers across America. So I had to wait and tweet them all at once.)

headline: Red Sox Rough Up Hughes For First Win
text: BOSTON — To get an idea of what Phil Hughes has felt like in his two starts this season, imagine pointing a gun at a target. Pull the trigger, and then a cartoon flag that says “Bang!” shoots out. On Friday afternoon at Fenway Park, Hughes essentially came unarmed to a duel. His diminished fastball and erratic control were no match for the Red Sox, who knocked him out after two innings, scoring six runs en route to a 9-6 victory against the Yankees.

headline: Matzo Brei Teams Up With Lox and Eggs
text: OF all the recipes in the Passover canon, one of the simplest is matzo brei. Soak matzos in egg and maybe a little milk or water until softened, fry in butter or oil. Top with powdered sugar or maple syrup if you like the sweet side of things, or salt and pepper if you have more savory hankerings.

headline: Los Angeles, Perhaps, but Brooklyn Is Forever
text: TV ON THE RADIO has made no secret of its catholic taste. Since 2001 this Brooklyn band — Tunde Adebimpe, Dave Sitek, Kyp Malone, Jaleel Bunton and Gerard Smith — has made ambitious rock with shades of post-punk, electronica and psychedelic jazz, and lyrics about global politics, love and language. The group made its latest album, “Nine Types of Light” (out Tuesday on Interscope), in Los Angeles, where Mr. Sitek now lives, its first recording outside New York; on Wednesday, the band will make its debut as headliner at Radio City Music Hall. But its members have not given up the indie ethos of the Brooklyn community that nurtured them. The band has already made videos for each song on the album, to be released both individually and edited into a film. “We as a band always have so many ideas for things that aren’t just musical,” Mr. Adebimpe said. “And for less than the price of a Maroon 5 video you can make a full-length feature.”

headline: A Heroic Fantasy for Skeptics
text: BEFORE he published “A Game of Thrones,” the first in his series of best-selling novels set on the mythical continent of Westeros, George R. R. Martin spent about a decade in an all-too-real place called Hollywood. For five years he happily wrote for television series with supernatural themes, like “The Twilight Zone” and “Beauty and the Beast”; and for five more he toiled discontentedly on television pilots and movie scripts that never made it, usually because an executive or producer decided they were too ambitious.

headline: This Sunday’s Magazine: A Note from the Editor
text: As a new weekend ritual here on The 6th Floor, I’m going to post an editor’s letter about the issue of the magazine that arrives with your Sunday newspaper. It’ll be something like the editor’s letters that other magazines publish, except less formal and, because of the surprisingly strong views of my staff, with no pictures of me. I’m just going to give you a sense of what went into making the magazine and leave it at that. You’ll have to imagine how I look in an expensive suit.

headline: Norwegian Pianist Takes a Deeper Dip Into Beethoven

headline: A Little Kick From the Middle East: Folk Spices the Jazz
text: The Israeli pianist Omer Klein works in a modern-jazz mode, brisk and borderless, and yet his music vibrates with cultural specificity, projecting a sense of place. He’s among the current bumper crop of adaptable transplants from Israel to New York, like the saxophonist Eli Degibri, the multireedist Anat Cohen and her brother Avishai Cohen, a trumpeter. Unlike some of these peers Mr. Klein uses Middle Eastern folk elements as a patently important part of his platform, maybe the most important part.

headline: Limits to ‘Disaster Memory,’ Even Etched in Stone

headline: TV on the Radio Makes a Film
text: D.I.Y. culture is hard to shake, or at least it is for TV on the Radio, the critically-beloved Brooklyn art rock band. As a companion to its fourth studio album, “Nine Types of Light” (out Tuesday from Interscope), the group created a feature-length movie, built from videos for each of the album’s tracks. “We as a band always have so many ideas for things that aren’t just musical,” Tunde Adebimpe, one of the band’s vocalists, said in an interview. “And for less than the price of a Maroon 5 video, you can make a full-length feature.”

You leave feeling slightly shaken: excited by the play’s formal invention, moved by its coiled emotional power.

headline: Unearthing a Celluloid Artifact of the ’60s
text: In the 1960s, the Pop artist Wynn Chamberlain often toyed with making a movie and spent time visiting various avant-garde filmmakers on their sets. headline: No Breakfast, but Bagels for Lunch
text: The founder and chief executive of Teach for America, Wendy Kopp, 43, is also the author, most recently, of “A Chance to Make History: What Works and What Doesn’t in Providing an Excellent Education for All,” written with Steven Farr (PublicAffairs, 2011). She is half of an education “power couple”: Her husband, Richard Barth, 44, is president and chief executive of the KIPP Foundation. They live on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with their four children: Benjamin, 11; Francis, 9; Haddon, 7; and Georgina, 3. How does she do it all? Here’s a clue: “Sleeping in” means rising at 6. ELISSA GOOTMAN

headline: Real Estate Debacle as Window Into Past
text: WHEN life hands you lemons, the old saw goes, make lemonade. Katharine Greider has gone the saying one better, providing refreshment and nourishment without any sour aftertaste. After she and her family were suddenly forced to abandon their apartment in Alphabet City a decade ago, she transformed her personal real estate debacle into an adventure in urban anthropology. The result:  “The Archaeology of Home: An Epic Set on a Thousand Square Feet of the Lower East Side” (PublicAffairs, $26.99).

headline: U.S. to Keep 3 Brigades in Europe
text: President Obama has revised a Bush administration plan from 2004 that would have halved the number of Army combat units deployed in Europe, and will instead retain three of the four brigades. Stationing three brigade combat teams in Europe beyond 2015 will allow the American military “to maintain a flexible and rapidly deployable ground force” in support of NATO, as well as to “meet a broad range of 21st century challenges,” the Pentagon said Friday in a statement. A brigade traditionally has 3,000 to 5,000 soldiers.

headline: Georgia: Shootout in Abkhazia
text: A Russian border guard and two Georgians were killed in a shootout in Abkhazia, a breakaway Georgian territory, Russia’s Federal Security Service said Friday. Russian border guards were inspecting an abandoned house when they were attacked, a spokesman told the Interfax news service. The security service said the two Georgians had been identified as officers from the Georgian Interior Ministry. A spokesman for Georgia’s Interior Ministry denied that, saying one of the Georgians had been wanted by the police and the other was an area resident. Russian guards began patrolling the boundaries of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, a second enclave, after the 2008 war between Georgia and Russia over the territories.

headline: Japan Cargo Is Screened at U.S. Ports

headline: Allies of Zimbabwe’s President Push for Quick Vote
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — As Zimbabwe hurtles into another violent political season, President Robert Mugabe’s party is fiercely pushing for a quick election this year because of fears that the president’s health and vigor are rapidly ebbing, senior party officials said.

headline: Snookinomics: Profits From a Tan
text: THIS week, media outlets everywhere mocked Rutgers for paying Nicole (Snooki) Polizzi $32,000 to talk about drinking and tanning on March 31. That was $2,000 more than what the Nobel laureate Toni Morrison will receive for the school’s commencement speech next month.

headline: Woods Fights Way Onto Leader Board of Next-Generation Names

text: WASHINGTON — With tensions rising over China’s crackdown on dissent, the Obama administration is about to lose three of its most prominent players on China policy — a shake-up that could reinforce its efforts to cultivate other Asian countries to counterbalance an increasingly assertive Beijing.

headline: Serial Killer in L.I. Case Is Seen as Versed in Police Techniques
text: Whoever killed four prostitutes, and possibly four other people, and then dumped their bodies in heavy underbrush along a beachfront causeway on Long Island appears to have a sophisticated understanding of police investigative techniques, according to people briefed on the case.

headline: Out of Camera’s View, Ad-Libs to Augusta’s Rituals
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Every year in early April, people tune in to the Masters for a dose of familiarity. The golf course is instantly recognizable. The color of the fairways and the flora always seem the same. The greens, and their unique features, are like old friends. From the plantation-style clubhouse to the famed stone bridges, golf fans feel they know Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Russians Riled by Attacks on Blogging Service

headline: Rights Abuses Extend Across Middle East, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Dire abuses of political and social rights that fueled popular uprisings in the Arab world and a war in Libya are continuing and have in some cases worsened in countries important to American security, including Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Yemen and Pakistan, the State Department said on Friday in its annual report on human rights.

headline: Abortion Opponents Use Health Law to Put Restrictions in Private Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — As more states begin setting up health care exchanges for individuals to buy insurance under the new health care law, abortion opponents are using the opportunity to try to restrict abortion coverage in private insurance plans.

headline: In Helping Others, Finding What Was Never Truly Lost
text: After she had unpacked, and her toothbrush was on the sink, the woman realized something was missing. She turned to John Sullivan, the tall, smiling social worker who had discovered her on a bench in the Broadway median. The woman was a nurse who had lost her grip and had been living in a tent on the Upper West Side, until Mr. Sullivan coaxed her off the street. She was delighted to be in an apartment of her own.

headline: On the Street | The Renewal of Fashion
text: The parks glow with cascades of forsythia and fields of daffodils, and fashion is at last stepping out of its winter cocoon.

headline: Before Deal, Angst Over Effects of Shutdown

headline: With Friends Like These …
text: Lucretia Mott, the Philadelphia Quaker famous for her work in the abolition and women’s rights movements, never met Abraham Lincoln. But Mott and many of her faith thought they knew him well enough to be wary: though the South was up in arms over his antislavery statements, he was nowhere near radical enough for Mott’s small but influential religious community. Indeed, by March 1861, the views of Mott and other Quakers provide a trustworthy indicator of how Northern radicals saw the possibility of sectional conflict on the eve of the Civil War.

headline: A Classic Theater Is Renovated and Reimagined
text: SIBBY HARRISON and Joan McCartney are, at age 82, among the older and wiser habitués of the landmark Picture House in Pelham. So it was with a special knowingness that they lamented the state in which they had, on their most recent visits, found the theater: the sticky floors, the shaky seats, the roof worn so thin that a hard rain drowned out on-screen dialogue.

headline: Catering Hall’s Plan for a Hotel Upsets the Neighbors

It’s a question that hovers around the career retrospective “Rebecca Salter: Into the Light of Things” at the Yale Center for British Art and the pendant show “Rebecca Salter and Japan” at the Yale University Art Gallery.

headline: Late Clash on Abortion Shows Conservatives’ Sway

headline: Bidding Frenzy for Tickets to Eat at Next in Chicago
text: Taking equal inspiration from Wrigley Field scalpers and the city’s grittiest pawn shops, food- and cash-obsessed Chicagoans have started a vibrant trade in tickets to a new restaurant, with bidding in one case hitting $3,000 for a group of seats overlooking the kitchen.

headline: N.C.A.A.’s Double Standard

headline: Report Says Coast Guard Was Unprepared for Spill
text: NEW ORLEANS — An internal review of the Coast Guard’s performance during the BP oil spill cleanup last year has concluded that the agency was caught badly unprepared and that the response operation was dogged from the beginning by significant planning failures.

headline: Manny Ramirez Retires After Testing Positive
text: Manny Ramirez, one of the greatest hitters in baseball history, retreated into retirement Friday, opting not to serve a 100-game suspension after he tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug for the third time in his career.

headline: The World This Week

headline: In City School System, Hopes That New Leader Can Steer Right Course
text: At dozens of struggling schools, New York City education officials have yet to apply for federal money that could help turn them around. Some principals are complaining about reorganizations that have left them without sufficient guidance. Charter school leaders are upset about fights sparked by where the city is placing them. A new teacher evaluation system, long discussed, is mired in negotiations with the teachers’ union, and its point person has just resigned.

headline: Saturday: What a Crystal Ball Gazer Sees
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The nice thing about Saturday puzzles is that, despite their difficulty level, they tend to give us some of the best cluing of the week. It’s not always the most clever; it’s not always the most punny. But it definitely goes off in a much different mental direction than, say a Wednesday puzzle. That’s what we have here.

headline: Loopy and Profound, Show Tells the Drama of Missionaries’ Work
text: Midway through the first act of “The Book of Mormon,” the acclaimed new Broadway musical, a warlord swaggers into a Ugandan village. Bedecked in ammo belts, brandishing an assault rifle, he demands surrender and announces his intent to sexually mutilate all the local women.

headline: On Incoming Chancellor’s First Day, a Hot Seat Before the City Council
text: Dennis M. Walcott started his first full day as the city’s chancellor-appointee walking his grandson into Public School 36 in St. Albans, Queens. Less than two hours later, he was greeted with hugs and congratulations when he appeared at a City Council budget hearing.

headline: Three Men in a Room
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has vowed to push the Legislature to adopt real ethics reform. Albany desperately needs tougher rules to end the pay-to-play culture and deep-rooted corruption. But we would feel a lot better if his negotiations weren’t going on behind closed doors.

text: MEXICO CITY — They were young men, traveling by bus to work in the fields and factories of northeastern Mexico, or perhaps hoping to get across the border to a job in the United States. Somewhere along the way, they vanished.

headline: How Much of a Threat?
text: Thousands of Japanese citizens are dead or missing after last month’s devastating earthquake and tsunami, hundreds of thousands have lost their homes and Japan’s government and power company are still struggling to control three badly damaged nuclear power reactors.

headline: Cue the Obama Money Bundlers
text: President Obama’s campaign machine is telling its chief money raisers to go all out in the big-dollar political art called bundling. The goal is to enlist 400 or more bundlers — specialists in packaging contributions from deep-pocketed supporters — to pledge to raise $700,000 each for the 2012 campaign.

headline: The Vocal Stylings of New York City Transit
text: New York City is a very up close and personal sort of place. But we’ve been struck recently by the number of automated voices we hear. Commuters, in particular, travel to the backdrop of those voices. The accents often sound homegrown. But there is often something just slightly, deliciously off.

headline: 7,000 Private School Applicants Got Incorrect Scores, Company Says
text: More than 7,000 students were incorrectly graded on the standardized test required for admission to most New York City private schools, the test company confirmed on Friday.

headline: Tweaks Aside, Rangers Can Only Wait and See

headline: New York Subpoenas 2 Foreclosure-Related Firms

text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Phillip Burton Federal Courthouse is an imposing edifice, built in the 1950s of concrete and glass and looking every bit a relic from its era.

headline: Bosko Radonjic, Gambino Family Ally, Dies at 67
text: Bosko Radonjic, a Serbian nationalist émigré who participated in the bombing of a Yugoslavian diplomat’s home in suburban Chicago in 1975 and who later became an associate of the Gambino crime family boss John Gotti, died on March 31 in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 67.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 8, 2011
text: Libyan rebels struggled to maintain their presence in Ajdabiya on Friday as Qaddafi government forces launched artillery barrages against the city’s western gate.

headline: HSBC Told to Disclose Records of Possible Tax Cheats
text: A federal judge has approved a government request for permission to force HSBC, one of the world’s largest banks, to turn over the names of scores of Indian-American clients suspected of tax evasion through the bank’s operations in India. The approval, by Judge Phyllis J. Hamilton of Federal District Court in Oakland, Calif., became public on Friday and mirrored the speed with which a similar request regarding the Swiss bank giant UBS was approved, by a different judge, in 2008. That request was later dropped when UBS disclosed 4,450 American client names, a watershed in Swiss bank secrecy. Investigators suspect that HSBC, which is based in London solicited Indian-American clients through representatives’ offices in New York and Fremont, Calif.

headline: L. J. Davis, Journalist and Novelist, Is Dead at 70
text: L. J. Davis, a journalist and novelist who wrote about money and business, real estate and home renovation, the Industrial Revolution and his beloved Brooklyn, often with wry or sardonic humor, was found dead in his Brooklyn home on Wednesday. He was 70.

headline: The College Decision From The Professors’ Perspective
text: As the next class of college freshmen weigh their choices, I asked Lynn F. Jacobs and Jeremy S. Hyman, authors of The Secrets of College Success, to compile some tips for readers of The Choice. What follows are excerpts. –Jacques Steinberg

headline: “Serious”
text: I’m in an airport lounge, for my sins, and there’s no avoiding the TV running CNN. And there’s David Gergen, telling me that the Ryan plan, whatever its flaws, is “serious”. So I guess that’s the Very Serious People line.

headline: Violence Rises as Israel and Hamas Trade Blows
text: GAZA — A surge in fighting between Israel and Hamas continued for a third day on Saturday, with Israeli aircraft and artillery killing three more militants, including a senior commander. At least 18 people have been killed since Thursday, Palestinian officials said.

headline: Vettel Finds the Speed When He Needs it, and Scores Pole
text: As Sebastian Vettel said himself, he managed to find the speed he needed at just the right moment: As the last contender across the line in his last lap in qualifying for the Malaysian Grand Prix. That’s when the Red Bull driver snapped the pole position out of the grasp of Lewis Hamilton, of McLaren Mercedes.

headline: Vettel Finds the Speed When He Needs it, and Scores Pole

That’s when the Red Bull driver snapped the pole position out of the grasp of Lewis Hamilton, of McLaren Mercedes.

headline: Urban Forager | Irish Moss, on Our Shores but Vanishing
text: A friend and I recently took a stroll along the rocky shoreline of Pelham Bay Park, where, among the treasures of low tide, we noted bulging clam beds, oyster shells and an effusive crop of bladderwrack seaweed fronds waving from the shallow depths of the Long Island Sound. Near my boots, next to a partially opened bivalve making bubbles in the water, was a reddish-brown tuft of alga about the size of my palm. Flat, cool and smooth to the touch, the seaweed had a distinctly briny odor.

headline: Q. and A.: Taking On Climate Skepticism as a Field of Study
text: Andrew J. Hoffman, the Holcim professor of sustainable enterprise at the University of Michigan, has spent the last year or so applying his tools as a social scientist to researching the cultural and social underpinnings of the backlash against climate change science.

headline: Adversity Nothing New as W.P.S. Enters Third Season
text: Women’s Professional Soccer is set to begin its third season on Saturday when the Atlanta Beat host the Boston Breakers. The top-flight women’s pro league emerges from a turbulent off-season leaner and battle-worn, but ready to play on.

headline: Obama, Searching for a Vision
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama emerged from spending talks last Thursday night, he went before cameras to insist that an agreement was needed to avoid a government shutdown that he warned would damage the country. What he did not do was make a public case for what should be in the agreement itself.

headline: Some Democrats Complain About Budget Compromise
text: 1:59 p.m. | Updated  President Obama hailed the late-night budget deal that averted a government shutdown on Friday as “good news for the American people,” but members of his own party seemed less convinced.

headline: Enriching a Few at the Expense of Many
text: SOME people say it doesn’t really matter how much companies pay their executives, at least as far as the shareholders are concerned. Whether investors prosper depends on the executives’ management skill, not on penny-ante items like pay, this argument goes.

headline: The Shutdown That Wasn’t
text: I would like to thank John Boehner, Harry Reid and President Obama for vindicating my decision not to write about the budget negotiations this week, on the assumption that the talk of a shutdown was mostly sound and fury, and then when the deadline hit a deal of some sort would be struck. I based that assumption primarily on my reading of the Speaker of the House, who made it abundantly clear — in word, deed, and especially body language — that he wanted the government shut down about as much as Indiana Jones wants to be locked in a room full of cobras. Given that the two sides weren’t that far apart in the closing days, in Boehner I trusted, and he didn’t let me down.

headline: The Last Word: Sidney Lumet
text: Sidney Lumet was one of America's most prolific filmmakers. Here he discusses his career, his gritty New York films and his legacy.

headline: A Director of Classics, Focused on Conscience
text: Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience — “12 Angry Men,” “Serpico,” “Dog Day Afternoon,” “The Verdict,” “Network” — became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Your Thoughts on Director Sidney Lumet
text: Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience — “12 Angry Men,” “Serpico,” “Dog Day Afternoon,” “The Verdict,” “Network” — became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: McIlroy Continues to Set Pace, and Field Struggles to Keep Up
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland moved one step closer to ushering in a new era in golf on Saturday at the Masters, shrugging off the immense pressure of playing with the tournament lead, distancing himself by four strokes from his closest pursuers and closing in on his first major championship.

headline: In Libya, an Odd-Couple Alliance
text: WASHINGTON — At home in France, he has long been called “Sarko l’Américain.” But it took an American president and the threat of a massacre in Libya to give President Nicolas Sarkozy the chance to channel his inner American. With his call for military action against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his recognition of the rebels and his readiness to arm them, Mr. Sarkozy has looked every inch the swaggering world leader, less a latter-day Charles de Gaulle than a Gallic Ronald Reagan.

headline: As Qaddafi’s Troops Move In, a Seesaw Battle for Rebel City
text: AJDABIYA, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pressed a coordinated ground attack on Ajdabiya on Saturday, bringing the front lines of the battle with the Libyan opposition forces back to the doorstep of this strategically vital rebel city.

headline: Hard Knocks and High Hopes

text: BARGAIN hunters have swooped in to strengthen the municipal bond market after a major skid between mid-November and mid-January. But specialists say they think the prospects are still bright for income-seeking investors.

headline: Get Rich Quick, but Make Sure It’s Legal
text: AS our nation’s economic blues wear on, many of us are looking for unconventional avenues to achieve the riches so tantalizingly out of reach. We’ve read the investment guides and watched the fast-money yammerers on television. But the big score still seems no closer than the prospect of winning the lottery.

headline: Demystifying the Fund Universe
text: IT is amazing how little many of us really know about our mutual funds.

text: FEW paper chases can match the marathon that Americans must complete every tax season. Even so, the most financially savvy do not equate filing their returns with crossing a finish line.

text: THE housing market may be facing a prolonged dip in prices, but for real estate mutual funds the problem is very different: prices that have climbed so much that they may not be sustainable.

headline: Commodities’ Success Brings Calls for Caution
text: A PERFECTLY unfortunate combination of circumstances has been underpinning the global commodity markets. High fiscal deficits in the West and accelerating demand in emerging economies have created the sort of inflationary backdrop in which commodities thrive, as have out-of-the-blue events like political instability in the Middle East and in North Africa, snow in the American Plains and a cyclone in Australia.

headline: Variety: A Squeamish Acrostic

headline: Flexing After an Energy Boost

Only one of the three — the Fidelity Select Energy Portfolio— is, by charter, a dedicated energy investor. The others — the FPA Capital fund and the Metzler/Payden European Emerging Markets fund — have more freedom to roam, but their managers unearthed values in the sector and seized them.

headline: At Opposite Ends of Africa, Fear and Confidence in Markets

headline: Why So Many Serial Killers on Long Island?
text: Some towns and counties have cancer clusters. Others have high rates of traffic fatalities or foreclosures. In New York, Long Island has been grappling with its own disturbing demographic: Three serial killers who targeted the same type of victims have operated in the same tidy suburbs in the span of 22 years.

headline: Dodger Stadium Beating Highlights Fans’ Unease
text: LOS ANGELES — When fans around the country think of Dodger Stadium, many still picture a gracefully aging park with an easy atmosphere, where fans are known for arriving late and leaving early in hopes of beating the traffic, and where the soundtrack is still provided after all these years by the broadcaster Vin Scully.

headline: One Spooky Dude
text: Glenn Beck last week announced his departure from the Fox News Channel — meaning, among other things: goodbye, Spooky Dude. Here are excerpts from the dozens of times Mr. Beck has so characterized Mr. Soros on Fox. — TOM KUNTZ

headline: 2 Protesters Killed in Egypt’s Tahrir Square

headline: Again, a Star Is Prosecuted for His Unlikability

headline: Trying to Conquer a Course That Many Greats Could Not

headline: Republicans and Democrats Alike Claim Successes in Averting a Federal Shutdown

headline: Feel Like a Wallflower? Maybe It’s Your Facebook Wall

headline: Jobless Rate Is Not the New Normal
text: IT takes a while to match people with jobs, so even in normal times the unemployment rate is never zero. Before the recent recession, in the view of many economists, the lowest sustainable rate of unemployment in the United States — a level known as the normal or natural rate of unemployment — was around 5 percent.

headline: Should Catchers Moonlight?

Black, last week — “She wasn’t in the class for the full semester so it wouldn’t be appropriate for me to give her a grade,” said Michael Mulgrew, president of the United Federation of Teachers — it was hard not to wonder whether the debate over school reform has reached a point where debate is no longer possible.

headline: Celebrating Defeat

Yet that’s just what he did. More than that, he has now completely accepted the Republican frame that spending cuts right now are what America needs.

headline: The Women’s Health Initiative and the Body Politic

It was a milestone of sorts in women’s medicine, leading to crude hormone treatments and eventually commercially prepared drugs to relieve the symptoms of menopause.

headline: Landmarks From Two Decades of Study
text: 1991 National Institutes of Health embarks on a study of menopause hormones after observational data suggest that women who use hormones have lower rates of heart disease.

headline: Japanese Workers Braved Radiation for a Temp Job

Helmet in hand, he ran from a workers’ standby room outside the plant’s No. 3 reactor, near where he and a group of workers had been doing repair work. He saw a chimney and crane swaying like weeds. Everybody was shouting in a panic, he recalled.

headline: Our Lovable Government
text: And, yes, that’s meant ironically. My Sunday column argues that the latest budget battles have been a supreme example of dysfunction. At the last minute Friday night, the two sides agreed to a budget deal and averted a government shut-down, but this is still a wretched way to run a superpower. And while I particularly blame the Republicans for threatening to shut down the government (a threat that Democrats did not make during the Bush years), it’s also true that the Democrats are at fault for not passing a budget and spending bills when they should have last year before the fiscal year began, when they controlled both houses in Congress.

headline: Two Decades of Comedy Central
text: In the 20 years since Comedy Central began broadcasting, the network has helped launch the careers of a number of comedic talents.

headline: Text and Audio of Mubarak’s Self-Defense
text: As my colleague Ethan Bronner reports, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s former president, made his first public remarks since being deposed in February, in a recorded address to the Egyptian people broadcast by Al Arabiya, a Saudi-owned satellite network, on Sunday.

headline: True to Mission, Comedy Central Still Strong at 20
text: On television, the laughter is coming from every direction.

headline: Moving Between Two Worlds, Outsiders in Both
text: When encountering a first novel as self-assured, elegant, and perceptive as “The Free World,” David Bezmozgis’s intimate portrait of the Krasnanskys, a Jewish family from Latvia immigrating to the West in 1978, there’s a temptation to say that the author displays a maturity far beyond his years. But Mr. Bezmozgis, who is yet another vaunted member of The New Yorker’s “20 Under 40” group, was born in Riga, Latvia, in 1973, which makes him nearly the same age that Philip Roth and Leonard Michaels were when they respectively published “Portnoy’s Complaint” and “Going Places” in 1969. So it might be more accurate to say that Mr. Bezmozgis writes like someone exactly his age but from a previous generation.

headline: Schwartzel Charges to Victory at Masters
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Fifty years to the day after Gary Player, the godfather of South African golf, became the first international player to win the Masters, his countryman Charl Schwartzel won the 75th Masters on Sunday, breaking though a chaotic afternoon shootout by birdieing the final four holes at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Poland and Russia Spar Over Wording of Memorial
text: MOSCOW — Ceremonies on Sunday and Monday in memory of the president of Poland and dozens of the country’s top political and military leaders who died in an airplane crash a year ago are being overshadowed by a dispute between Russia and Poland over the wording of a memorial plaque.

headline: A Word From Those Who
text: I’ve been reading various “news analyses” of the Ryan plan, and I’m feeling depressed. In the past, I’ve complained about false equivalence — of “views differ on shape of the planet” type reporting. But what I’m seeing here is worse: supposedly objective, even-handed reporting that actually prejudges the issue according to current conventional wisdom.

headline: Age of Diminished Expectations
text: I’m sorry to say it, but I expect the worst from the upcoming presidential speech on deficit reduction. OK, maybe not the worst; I don’t think he’ll call for privatizing Medicare, but who knows? But I do expect a lot of preemptive concessions to the Republicans, which will, as usual, be the starting point for further concessions.

headline: Lessons From the Hormone Studies
text: For more than 100 years, women and doctors have been debating the safety and necessity of hormone treatments for women at the end of their reproductive years, as I report in the Week in Review section of Sunday’s New York Times.

headline: An Imbalanced Budget Deal?
text: There’s a pretty broad consensus that Republicans got the better of the budget negotiations that concluded late Friday. Here’s David Weigel of Slate making the point. Here’s Andrew Stiles of the National Review. And Richard Eskow of the Huffington Post. And Carl Cameron of Fox News. And Ezra Klein of the Washington Post.

headline: Grab Your Wolf Suits and Open Your Ears
text: The New York City Opera, struggling to close a $5 million deficit, has postponed its announcement of its next season, which is troubling news for opera buffs and supporters of this essential company.

headline: The Bollywood Treatment, for Husbands
text: You can’t step into the same river twice, but you can, it seems, watch the same Bollywood movie twice (or three or four times). “Thank You,” an Anees Bazmee comedy dedicated to the proposition that all men are dogs, hews so closely to tried-and-true formula that it could serve as a kind of template.

headline: British and Dutch to Sue Over an Icelandic Debt
text: LONDON — The British and Dutch governments are taking steps to sue Iceland to claw back the billions of euros they paid to depositors in their countries after Icelandic banks collapsed in 2008.

headline: Amid Catchy Choruses, Personal Tales of Life’s Brutal Verities
text: The perky refrains in the freaky existential cabaret written and performed by the playwright Young Jean Lee are probably not going to be squeaked out by Britney Spears, wailed by Mariah Carey or even bellowed by the freak-flag-waving Lady Gaga anytime soon.

headline: A Few Big Boards Decide a Junior Teams Title
text: The sixth White House Junior Teams tournament took place in the Netherlands late last month. Twenty-four teams from 20 countries (the Dutch had three teams competing and the Israelis two) played a 10-board round robin to qualify four teams for 24-board semifinals.

headline: Russell Brand Is Up and Down at Movie Theaters
text: “Hop” was No. 1 at North American theaters for a second weekend in a row, selling an estimated $21.7 million in tickets for Universal Pictures (for a total of $68.2 million). But it was one of those weekends when a flop was the news: “Arthur,” a $40 million Warner Brothers remake starring Russell Brand, right, was a distant second with about $12.6 million — a terrible result considering the studio’s considerable marketing campaign. Brand burnout may have played a role. Mr. Brand, the comedian, known for his fingernails-on-a-chalkboard voice, has made recent appearances to promote his films — he is also a prominent member of the “Hop” cast (as the voice of E. B., left) — on outlets as varied as “American Idol” and the “Kids’ Choice Awards.” “Hanna,” a Focus Features release about a 16-year-old assassin, was a stronger-than-expected third with $12.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket statistics. “Soul Surfer” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with about $11 million; this drama, based on the true story of a girl who returns to surfing after losing her arm in a shark attack, received positive scores in exit polls. “Insidious” (FilmDistrict) was fifth with about $9.7 million for a two-week total of about $27 million. Also notable: “Your Highness,” a stoner comedy starring Natalie Portman and James Franco that cost Universal about $50 million, was a bomb, opening in sixth place with $9.5 million.

headline: No Major Relics Stolen in Egypt
text: Of the roughly 1,000 relics stolen from museums and archeological sites in Egypt since the sweeping protests began there in January, none were items of major importance, said Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s minister for antiquities, Agence France-Presse reported. “There is an inventory of everything, and it will be difficult for the items to leave the country,” Mr. Hawass told the Spanish newspaper El Mundo on Sunday, adding that the thieves were probably looters who lived near the sites, as opposed to organized criminals, and that they probably had little knowledge of the value of the goods they had pilfered. Many of the relics were taken from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which houses much of the King Tutankhamen collection, as well as the tombs of Hetep-ka at Saqqara and Em-pi at Giza.

headline: Jackson Poetry Prize
text: James Richardson has received this year’s Jackson Poetry Prize, a $50,000 award presented to an American poet by Poets & Writers, a nonprofit organization for creative writers. Mr. Richardson’s latest collection, “By the Numbers: Poems and Aphorisms,” was released by Copper Canyon Press in November and was a finalist for the 2010 National Book Award. His previous collections include “Interglacial: New and Selected Poems and Aphorisms” (Ausable, 2004), a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and “Vectors: Aphorisms and Ten-Second Essays” (Ausable, 2001). The prize has been awarded since 2007 by a panel of three distinguished poets. This year’s panelists were Mark Doty, Rita Dove and Gerald Stern. Previous winners were Elizabeth Alexander, Tony Hoagland, Linda Gregg and Harryette Mullen.

headline: Some Fringe Encores
text: “Urinetown,” “Williamsburg: The Musical” and “Dog Sees God,” among several other shows, will return to the New York International Fringe Festival this spring and summer as part of a concert series to benefit the festival’s 15th anniversary season. Every Thursday for 15 weeks (May 5 through Aug. 11) at the Laurie Beechman Theater at the West Bank Cafe, the Alumni Association of the New York International Fringe Festival will present a performance, concert or reading of a show from the last 15 years of festivals. It is the first benefit for the organization. A schedule and casting details are at fringenyc.org.

headline: New Job, but Still Chasing Bad Guys
text: NBC is reintroducing “Law & Order: Los Angeles” on Monday with a premiere-worthy two-hour special, which is a bit like having a fancy formal wedding on the grounds that the first marriage was annulled so it doesn’t count. And as in the case with many a second marriage, the new version isn’t really different — it’s just a slight change in casting.

headline: Bids for Warner Suggest Faith in Industry’s Future
text: Could a record company still be a good investment? The bids for the Warner Music Group, one of the four major record companies, suggest that some people think so.

headline: Pairing Their Sounds and Sharing the Blues
text: Eric Clapton chose the songs and Wynton Marsalis laid out the musical territory for “Wynton Marsalis and Eric Clapton Play the Blues,” the Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater on Friday night, the first of two shows. It was a concert so fixated on elegant details that its blues were bloodless.

headline: New York’s Pioneering World Music Impresario Announces His Retirement
text: Since 1985 there have always been two things you could count on at a World Music Institute concert: stirring traditional sounds (and dance) from a faraway corner of the planet, and a dry yet thoughtful introduction by Robert Browning, the institute’s founder and executive director.

headline: Glancing Backward, Then Facing Forward
text: While museums engage in high-profile performance initiatives and debates, the dance world continues its method of preservation in the same quiet, humble way it has for decades, through a more mobile sort of archive: the body.

headline: Euro Divergence (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Just as a reminder that others have problems: Cezmi Dispinar points me to a post with an excellent chart about the problem of adjustment:

headline: Watching the Trees and Portraits Go By, on Wings of Violins
text: The Unsound Festival, a celebration of contemporary music with an emphasis on the avant-garde, has flourished in Krakow, Poland, since 2003, when it was started by Mat Schulz, an Australian writer who settled there in 1995. Last year Mr. Schulz brought an edition of the festival to New York, and it proved a lively addition to the city’s thriving new-music world, not least because of its focus on European electronica composers who are scarcely known here.

headline: Monday: Well, Whaddaya Know!
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome, my friends. Mr. Ian Livengood and I are so glad you could join us in his lair, I mean, puzzle. Don’t bother trying to escape; a good number of the villains of your cinematic and televised nightmares surround you.

headline: At Gannett, Furloughs but Nice Paydays for Brass
text: Just in case Gannett employees thought 2011 might bring better news after years of layoffs and furloughs, the year was just four days old when a note landed in the in-box of people who work for the community news division saying, once again, they were required to take an unpaid week off.

headline: Kneel Before Zod: Michael Shannon to Play ‘Superman’ Villain
text: Known for the unearthly menace he brings to the characters he portrays on television’s “Boardwalk Empire” and off Broadway’s “Mistakes Were Made,” it’s only natural that Michael Shannon would end up as an alien villain in Zack Snyder‘s new “Superman” movie. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Sunday that Mr. Shannon, an Academy Award nominee for “Revolutionary Road,” will play General Zod, an evildoer who comes from Superman’s home planet of Krypton. The studio said the film, whose previously announced cast includes Henry Cavill (“The Tudors”) as Superman and Amy Adams (“The Fighter”) as Lois Lane, will be titled “Man of Steel.”

headline: That Noisy Woodpecker Had an Animated Secret
text: LOS ANGELES — Sixteen years ago Tom Klein was staring at a Woody Woodpecker cartoon, “The Loose Nut,” when he started seeing things.

headline: Detroit Symphony Returns to a Giddy Reception
text: DETROIT — As the musicians took the stage, applause and cheering erupted. “We love you guys!” a concertgoer yelled. A violinist mouthed, “Wow,” another tapped her music stand with her bow in appreciation, and the awe-struck players stood facing a packed-to-the rafters audience for five minutes while the love flowed over them.

headline: Helping Fans Dress Like a Video Game Hero
text: PRODUCT placement within video games is common enough these days that gamers barely notice it, but when Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker was introduced last year, some players snickered when they saw its protagonist, Naked Snake, occasionally wearing a T-shirt with the a logo for Axe, the men’s grooming brand. The game, after all, is set in 1974 — nine years before Axe was introduced, in France, and 28 years before it gained prominence with its introduction in the United States.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 10, 2011
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s military forces appeared to falter in a second day of assault against Ajdabiya.

headline: Research In Motion Eyes a Rebound
text: WATERLOO, Ontario — In a rare interview last week, Mike Lazaridis, one of Research In Motion’s two chief executives, was the one asking questions:

headline: In Egypt and Tunisia, the Games Must Go On
text: The descent into chaos of last week’s African Champions League match in Cairo between Zamalek of Egypt of Tunisia’s Club Africain apparently will not delay the decisions by soccer authorities in both north African countries to resume league play on Wednesday.

headline: BP Fast Becoming a Takeover Target
text: BP, the British oil giant, should be on bid alert. It has many hallmarks of a target: a discounted share price, a strategic setback and a weakened management team.

headline: The Rail’s Derby 10
text: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the trade deficit for February and import prices for March (Tuesday); retail sales for March, business inventories for February, and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for March and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for March, industrial production and capacity utilization for March, and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

headline: Qaddafi’s Handling of Media Shows Regime’s Flaws
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Even the Qaddafi government escort could not contain his disbelief at the sloppiness of the fraud: bloodstains his colleagues had left on bedsheets in a damaged hospital room for more than a week as evidence of civilian casualties from Western airstrikes.

headline: Libyan Rebels Take Risks With Makeshift  Arms
text: In cheerful and crisp English, Adel Sanfad presented his new weapon, which was mounted on a welded frame to the back of his jeep near the front lines in eastern Libya. “These used to be for airplanes,” he said. Then he added, in a flash of pride that was undercut slightly with a wince: “But we modified them.”

headline: New Doubts About Turning Plutonium Into a Fuel
text: On a tract of government land along the Savannah River in South Carolina, an army of workers is building one of the nation’s most ambitious nuclear enterprises in decades: a plant that aims to safeguard at least 43 tons of weapons-grade plutonium by mixing it into fuel for commercial power reactors.

headline: A Symphony Returns
text: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra played its first concert of the season after a bitter months-long strike.

headline: ‘Catch Me if You Can’
text: Photos of the new Broadway musical.

headline: Holocaust Memories, via Cable
text: Comcast, the nation’s top cable company, is distributing 10 films about the Holocaust in a public service project it is calling “Days of Remembrance.” And it started with an unrelated telephone call to the directorSteven Spielberg.

headline: NYSE Euronext Chief Calls Nasdaq’s Bid ‘Inconsistent’ With Long-Term Strategy
text: In rejecting an $11.3 billion takeover bid by the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange, NYSE Euronext made a forceful case that a merger with Deutsche Börse was the real way to generate long-term value.

headline: Mike Campbell, Zimbabwean Farmer Who Fought Land Seizure, Dies at 78
text: JOHANNESBURG — Mike Campbell, a ferociously independent white Zimbabwean farmer who sued his country’s autocratic ruler, Robert Mugabe, to stop the seizure of his land and improbably won, only to lose the farm when the government defied the court ruling, died on Wednesday. He was 78.

headline: The Crisis Next Time
text: The federal government survived the hostage crisis created by House Republicans, but emerged staggering from the deal struck Friday night. The compromises were damaging, the amount of money cut from a sickly economy was severe, and the image of Washington as a back-alley dogfighting garage will not soon fade.

headline: John McCracken, Sculptor of Geometric Forms, Dies at 76
text: John McCracken, a West Coast artist who brought a New Age openness to Minimalist sculpture, along with a vocabulary of bright, sleek slabs, blocks and columns that balanced teasingly between painting and sculpture, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: The Clarion Notes of Defiance
Bay Area’s Little Leagues Overflow With Would-Be Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The good vibrations from the San Francisco Giants’ World Series victory last fall continue to reverberate in the Bay Area, where children inspired by the improbable success of the Giants’ assemblage of castoffs have overwhelmed local Little Leagues.

headline: New Rules for Mortgage Servicers Face Early Criticism
text: Federal banking regulators have not officially imposed their new rules for the top mortgage servicers, but criticism is already being heard. A wide coalition of consumer and housing groups is denouncing the legal agreements, which are likely to be published within a few days.

headline: City, Destroyed and Yet Hopeful, Begins to Move On
text: MINAMISOMA, Japan — After nearly four weeks of living in distant refugee shelters, or huddling indoors at home for fear of nuclear fallout, Toshie Nagasawa finally came here to say goodbye.

headline: Intel, on the Outside, Takes Aim at Smartphones
text: With an “Intel Inside” sticker affixed to their PCs, computer buyers in the 1990s could hardly avoid knowing whose microchip was making their machines work. The campaign made Intel one of the most recognizable brands and cemented its position in the PC industry.

headline: With Aid and Migrants, China Expands Its Presence in a South American Nation
text: PARAMARIBO, Suriname — The Foreign Ministry’s elegant new headquarters here is a gift from the Chinese government. Chinese signs on hundreds of businesses, from casinos to grocery shops and furniture stores, beckon the residents of this capital. Chinese work crews are paving roads cutting through the jungle.

headline: From Uncle Mo Show to Wide-Open Kentucky Derby
text: So much for the talk about Uncle Mo being the next Seattle Slew or the suspicion (or hope?) that he belonged in a different stratosphere from his fellow 3-year-olds. When Uncle Mo turned for home Saturday in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, Tom Durkin, the voice of New York racing, said what many were thinking: “It is the moment of truth for Uncle Mo.”

headline: France and U.N. Hit Ivory Coast Strongman’s Home and Palace
text: BOUAKÉ, Ivory Coast — French and United Nations helicopters fired missiles on Sunday at key positions held by forces loyal to the entrenched strongman Laurent Gbagbo in Abidjan, the country’s economic capital, partly destroying Mr. Gbagbo’s residence, according to one of his top aides.

headline: Israel and Hamas Consider Cease-Fire
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas signaled on Sunday that they were willing to restore calm after days of intense fighting, and while militants in Gaza fired about 10 rockets and mortar shells into southern Israel, most fell in open areas close to the border and Israel did not immediately respond.

headline: Celtics Creak Toward Postseason, Hoping They Have Legs for a Run
text: BOSTON — Only two games remain in what has been an extraordinarily trying season for the Boston Celtics. Then the playoffs arrive, and it remains to be seen which Celtics team will show up: the current unpredictable group that the former Celtic Kevin McHale called Sybil because of its multiple personalities, or the savvy, been-there, done-that group that can play at a high level any time it chooses.

headline: It Came Out of the Viral Media Swamp
text: LOS ANGELES — It seems fair to ask why Sidney J. Sheinberg, 76 years old and long retired as president of MCA Inc., the erstwhile parent of Universal Pictures, spent much of last May tromping through the swamps of Louisiana with the crew of a little monster movie called “Creature.”

headline: In Federal Court, a Docket Number for Global Terror
text: The indictments are all filed under the same basic docket number, 93 Cr. 180, an indistinct series of numerals and letters that reveals more with each new installment.

headline: A Sore Subject
text: The day after Derek Jeter told a few reporters that he “ain’t talking about” his retooled hitting mechanics anymore, Joe Girardi sounded as if he, too, had been growing tired of what has become a daily topic of discussion in his sessions with the news media.

headline: For Cowboy Poets, Unwelcome Spotlight in Battle Over Spending
text: ELKO, Nev. — This isolated town in the northeast Nevada mountains is known for gold mines, ranches, casinos, bordellos and J. M. Capriola, a destination store with two floors of saddles, boots, spurs and chaps. It is also the birthplace of the annual Cowboy Poetry Gathering, a celebration of range song and poetry that draws thousands of cowboys and their fans every January and receives some money from the federal government.

headline: Searching for Answers, Yankees’ Hughes Tinkers With His Motion
text: BOSTON — Phil Hughes has maintained that his struggles derive from a lack of arm strength, not flawed mechanics. But just in case, he tinkered with his motion during his bullpen session Sunday evening with the Yankees’ pitching coach, Larry Rothschild.

headline: Nationalist Candidate Appears to Be Leading in Peru’s Presidential Vote
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Peruvian voters cast ballots on Sunday in a presidential election notable for the surging candidacy of Ollanta Humala, a nationalist who is critical of the expanding influence of foreign companies in Peru’s booming economy.

headline: For Mets, Relievers’ Struggles Trump a Starter’s Strong Effort
text: Chris Young’s 108th and final pitch on an overcast Sunday afternoon was a deft split-finger fastball that dipped past Washington Nationals second baseman Danny Espinosa for a called third strike. Young, the towering new Met, was cheered as he strolled back to the dugout.

headline: McChrystal to Lead Program for Military Families
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who was relieved of command in Afghanistan after a magazine profile quoted his subordinates as disparaging senior civilian leaders, has been invited back to public service by the Obama administration to help oversee a high-profile initiative in support of military families, White House officials said Sunday.

headline: Actors in Smaller Studios, Making Pictures for the Smaller Screen
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — The film set was professional, even if the actors kept messing up the scene by laughing at the star, who was flailing in front of a green screen, pretending to be eaten alive.

headline: Eighth-Seeded Rangers Have Reasons to Like Their Chances Against Capitals
text: John Tortorella was defiant Saturday afternoon as he waited to learn the Rangers’ playoff fate.

headline: With a Spending Deal in Hand, Lawmakers Now Turn to the Details
text: WASHINGTON — As more details of the budget deal between President Obama and Congressional leaders trickled out on Sunday, lobbyists and lawmakers stepped up their efforts to secure or kill specific provisions benefiting wolf hunters in Montana, profit-making colleges and various public works projects.

headline: For McIlroy, a Collapse He Never Saw Coming
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Charl Schwartzel, the new Masters champion, had already been enveloped in applause and then whisked away for the traditional posttournament television interview in nearby Butler Cabin. Workers were beginning to line up five rows of chairs for the awards ceremony. Most of the crowd was walking to the exits.

headline: New York Terrorism Indictments
text: Five of 14 indictments that chart a history of terrorism conspiracies in New York City and elsewhere.

headline: JPMorgan Accused of Breaking Its Duty to Clients
text: In the summer of 2007, as the first tremors of the coming financial crisis were being felt on Wall Street, top executives of JPMorgan Chase were raising red flags about a troubled investment vehicle called Sigma, which was based in London. But the bank chose not to move out $500 million in client assets that it had put into Sigma two months earlier.

headline: Woods’s Tantalizing Surge Comes Up Short on the Back Nine
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods’s second shot to the par-5 15th green landed soft and rolled 4 feet past the hole. It was not long after the third-round leader Rory McIlroy’s implosion at the 10th hole, a triple-bogey that altered the course of the 2011 Masters. Passing a massive scoreboard that overlooks the 15th green, Woods peeked at the upheaval taking place on the leader board.

headline: With Shovels and Shears, Police Plod Through a Hiding Place for Bodies
text: JONES BEACH ISLAND, N.Y. — Thickets of bayberries, reeds and a type of vine called sea tomatoes crisscross the dunes off the northern edge of Ocean Parkway. Sowed early in the last century to accompany the Robert Moses-inspired roadway, the plants have grown into a greenish wall to shroud this barrier island and its mysteries.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 10, 2011

headline: Sensible Rules to Make Bus Travel Safer
text: Three major bus accidents in the Northeast, including the horrific crash on Interstate 95 in the Bronx that killed 15 passengers and critically injured several others, may finally spur Congress to mandate bus safety improvements.

headline: A Lawsuit’s Unusual Question: Who Is a Man?
text: What is a man? For El’Jai Devoureau, this is not a rhetorical question.

headline: Who Really Sent That E-Mail?
text: Americans are right to be concerned about a huge data breach at an online marketing company, Epsilon, which resulted in the theft of names and e-mail addresses for customers and employees of some of the nation’s largest businesses, including Citibank, Disney and Verizon.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Couric’s Rocky Five-Year Path to a Likely Parting With CBS
text: For Katie Couric, the offer in 2006 to become the anchor of “CBS Evening News” came with another incentive, one she prized almost as highly, according to two of her friends: the chance to report for “60 Minutes,” the newsmagazine that for Ms. Couric stood for the kind of serious journalism she had always aspired to.

headline: Bluefin Tuna Catch a (Small) Break
text: The numbers of endangered bluefin tuna are rapidly dwindling, due to vast overfishing fueled by Japan’s insatiable sushi appetite. The international body set up to conserve these fish has utterly failed to do its job. But a small and clever innovation may slow their decline: special hooks designed to help commercial fishing boats in the Gulf of Mexico avoid catching bluefin accidentally.

headline: Close-Knit, New to the House, and Resistant to Blending In
text: WASHINGTON — Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where the bonds of friendship form quickly and endure, the four Republican freshmen from South Carolina stand out.

headline: A City School’s Uphill Fight Over Sharing Space With a Charter
text: In a city where so many public schools are segregated by race and wealth, Public School 9 in Brooklyn is an exception.

headline: Marketer Puts Its ‘Chips’ on Times Square
text: The flavor of New York City would be different without Times Square. The Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo seems to agree.

headline: Scamming as Fast as He Can
text: As befits a lad of the 1960s with a talent for smooth come-ons, Frank Abagnale Jr. prefaces the story of his life with the promise that it will have “more curves than a Playboy bunny.” But as presented in the new musical “Catch Me if You Can,” which opened Sunday night at the Neil Simon Theater, this portrait of the con artist as a young man (portrayed by Aaron Tveit) seems to consist mostly of straight lines, like the kind you use to connect the dots in picture puzzles.

headline: Where School System’s Toughest Battles Are a Reality, Support for a New Leader
text: From the pulpit on Sunday, the Rev. Mark V. C. Taylor recounted how he had heard on the car radio that Dennis M. Walcott, the New York City deputy mayor, had been named city schools chancellor, and immediately made a mental note to place a congratulatory call once he got to work.

headline: Admission to College, With Catch: Year’s Wait
text: For as long as there have been selective colleges, the spring ritual has been the same: Some applicants get a warm note of acceptance, and the rest get a curt rejection.

headline: Unpaid Interns: Rewarded or Exploited?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks Are Assured a Winning Season After Anthony’s Key Shot and a Block
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Carmelo Anthony was down a superstar teammate and was playing with a banged-up wrist and foul trouble, but still found a way to push the Knicks past the Pacers, delivering a victory that had slipped past the Knicks the last time these teams met.

headline: Living, Dying and a Decision About Dialysis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unseen Woman’s Cries, Then a Fatal Stabbing
text: The woman’s screams for help began shortly after 2 a.m. on Sunday. Several people along Clinton Street, on the Lower East Side, flocked to their windows and peered out, seeing nothing.

headline: A Forecasting Expert Testifies About Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Transplants for Thousands
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medicaid and Pediatrics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: Stop Waiting for a Savior
text: Boston

headline: Charlie Davies Takes a Dive
text: Americans love a good comeback story, which is part of the reason so many American soccer fans root so hard for striker Charlie Davies.

headline: More Media Time, on Various Screens
text: Americans are spending about 20 percent more time consuming radio, television and the Internet than they were a decade ago, according to a survey by two media measurement firms.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: The President Is Missing
text: What have they done with President Obama? What happened to the inspirational figure his supporters thought they elected? Who is this bland, timid guy who doesn’t seem to stand for anything in particular?

headline: Prisoner of Damascus
text: Damascus, Syria

headline: Budgeting for Opportunity
text: When politicians are fortunate, they get to choose the goals their budgets set. In periods of recession, they can budget for growth. Facing huge deficits, they can budget for austerity. In times of plenty, they can budget for upward mobility and equality of opportunity.

headline: Abortion Limit Is Renewed, as Is Washington Anger
text: WASHINGTON — The sound and fury of last week’s budget debate came down to a dollar figure that some members of Congress could have covered by writing a personal check.

headline: Helping Immigrants Navigate Government
text: At a Haitian church in Canarsie, Brooklyn, officials from the mayor’s office spent a recent Saturday morning discussing food stamps and discrimination in the workplace, their words translated into Creole for an audience of some 50 people.

headline: Guards Block Female Reporter From Interview
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — A female reporter for The Record of New Jersey was prevented from entering the locker room at Augusta National Golf Club after the final round of the Masters on Sunday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: By Silencing Yankees, Beckett Provides Hope for Red Sox
text: BOSTON — Josh Beckett marked his territory early against the Yankees on Sunday night, firing four 94-mile-per-hour fastballs to Brett Gardner before fooling him with a curve. Derek Jeter tapped out to shortstop. Mark Teixeira stared at an unhittable pitch, a two-seamer that curled across the inside corner for strike three. So went the first inning for the Yankees, and the next eight were more of the same. A lineup that blistered Red Sox starters the first two games at Fenway Park looked modest and middling against Beckett, who silenced the Yankees in a 4-0 victory.

headline: Judge Blocks City’s Proposal for 2 Buildings in Brooklyn
text: The development of two buildings in Brooklyn has been temporarily blocked by a federal judge, who ordered Friday that the mid-19th-century structures be returned to a designation of federally protected parkland.

headline: How to Rebuild a War-Torn Nation
text: When trying to rebuild a war-torn nation, focus first on security, not economic development. Then make a few highly visible improvements, like free health care for small children or restoring regular electricity. Also, hire female police officers.

headline: Two Shows Share Diversity Award
text: The 22nd annual Glaad Media Awards, which were scheduled to be handed out at a ceremony Sunday night in Los Angeles, found Fox’s “Glee” and ABC’s “Modern Family” tied for outstanding television comedy. Amy Poehler and Rashida Jones of NBC’s “Parks and Recreation” were to host the second installment of this three-part ceremony sponsored by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Among the other honorees were Kristin Chenoweth, the actress and singer; Robert Greenblatt, the chairman of NBC Entertainment; and Bianca Peet, a 17-year-old from Corpus Christi, Tex., who rallied to start a Gay Straight Alliance at her high school after the group’s application was denied by the school district. More awards will be presented on May 14 in San Francisco; a third ceremony was held last month in New York.

headline: A New Push to Let H.I.V. Patients Accept Organs That Are Infected
text: David Aldridge of Los Angeles had a kidney transplant in 2006, but he will soon need another. Like many people living with H.I.V., he suffers from kidney damage, either from the virus or from the life-saving medications that keep it at bay.

headline: Truce Plan for Libya Is Rejected by Rebels

headline: What Can You Learn from ‘Teen Mom’?

According to a New York Times article, DVDs of the show, along with episode discussion guides are being used in schools, churches, medical clinics and by social workers and parents to “prompt discussion about sex education, family and romantic relationships and shattered dreams.” Do you think realities shows like “Teen Mom” and “16 and Pregnant” could be effective teaching tools? Why or why not?

headline: On the Road to Revolution

But one constant is the presence of the road, along which Libya’s revolution has traveled back and forth as each side advances and retreats, leaving behind a wake of destruction and death.

Perhaps that’s what attracts me to this video for Danish house band Kenton Slash Demon’s newest release, “Daemon.” The creators, Lasse Andersen and Rune Brink of the Scandinavian motion graphics studio Dark Matters, use light and string to create “classic computer effects without the computer.” Some of my favorite moments are when the designers’ fingers appear between the strings.

headline: Virtual Gold, Real Money
text: In June 2007, Julian Dibbell published an article in the Sunday Magazine about the shadow economy in virtual goods, focusing on “gold farmers” in China — workers hired by Chinese companies to play huge, multiplayer online games for the sole purpose of acquiring loot that could then be sold at a profit to regular players who didn’t have the time or the inclination to do it themselves and who use this purchased loot to increase their chances and status in these games. “For years now, the vast majority of virtual goods has been brought to retail not by players selling the product of their own gaming but by high-volume online specialty sites like the virtual-money superstores IGE, BroGame and Massive Online Gaming Sales — multimillion-dollar businesses offering one-stop, one-click shopping and instant delivery of in-game cash,” Dibbell wrote. “These are the Wal-Marts and Targets of this decidedly gray market, and the same economic logic that leads conventional megaretailers to China in search of cheap toys and textiles takes their virtual counterparts to China’s gold farms.”

headline: Endo to Acquire American Medical for $2.9 Billion

headline: Golden Oldies (Wonkish)
text: Mark Thoma jokes that “I’ve learned that new economic thinking means reading old books.” And Brad DeLong says that it’s no joke: the macroeconomics of 1936 — or even of 1873 — is a much better guide to current events and their policy implications than all the macro theory of the past few decades.

headline: A Hard Rain: Modest Turnout for Bob Dylan in Vietnam
text: Days after his historic and headline-generating concert debut in mainland China, Bob Dylan played his first performance in Vietnam on Sunday night, eliciting criticism but drawing only moderate crowds. BBC News reported that Mr. Dylan, whose Sunday show at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City was his first ever in that Communist country, once again played a set list that had to be approved by the government there, a stipulation he had agreed to with the Chinese government for his concerts in Beijing and Shanghai last week. (Sunday’s show included spirited tunes like “A Hard Rain’s a-Gonna Fall” and “Highway 61 Revisited,” but no obvious protest songs like “Blowin’ in the Wind.”)

headline: How I Finally Turned a Profit
text: Careful readers of my post on whether to buy a building might have noticed that my business reported a profit in 2010. Yup, it was right there on my 1120S: the company reported earnings of $92,155 on sales of $1,516,837. Which is a little bit of an accomplishment, considering all the years of losses and the terrible first quarter we experienced last year. I’ve been asked to provide some more information about this, specifically, what I did to turn things around.

headline: Be the Armchair Ethicist
text: April 11 update: Thanks to everyone who participated in Armchair Ethicist. This was our first live Web chat about a letter, and I think the results were tremendous — so many replies, and so much careful thought. (And so little screaming and name-calling — thank you for that!) Overall the deleters were in the majority, but the answers reflected a wide range of ideas and many subtle gradations of ethical thinking. I learned a lot, mostly about how seriously you all take these issues. What a great lesson! Let’s do this again soon. (And as for me, well, I’ll be publishing my thoughts in the magazine soon.)

headline: The ‘Wave’ of the (Car Engine) Future?

It’s a sure bet that despite the advent of pricey all-electric vehicles, internal combustion engines will still dominate for decades given the power density in liquid fuels. Mazdas still hum here and there but no new design has truly gone mainstream — yet.

headline: New Parents Don’t Exercise
text: I am practically giddy as I write this. I am seated at my regular coffee shop, the one where I came nearly every morning to work until about five weeks ago, when a bad fall more or less confined me to the couch. But broken bones heal, and while I am still on crutches, and not yet allowed to put weight on my left foot, I am now wearing jeans (rather than the yoga pants I wore for five weeks), with a shoe on my right foot (rather than a sneaker). Most exhilarating of all, I drove here on my own. For the first time in more than a month, I feel like ME.

headline: Bertolucci to Receive Honorary Palme d’or at Cannes
text: As a filmmaker, Bernardo Bertolucci has had a lasting impact on how audiences think of Asia and Africa, Buddhism and butter, but he has never won a Palme d’or – the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival. It is a gap on his trophy shelf that the organizers of the festival said they intended to correct at this year’s celebration. Mr. Bertolucci, whose films include “The Last Emperor,” “The Sheltering Sky,” “Little Buddha” and “Last Tango in Paris,” will be given an honorary Palme d’or at the opening ceremony of this year’s festival, it was announced on Monday. The festival has previously presented honorary awards to filmmakers including Woody Allen (in 2002) and Clint Eastwood (in 2009), and starting this year plans to make the distinction an annual tradition.

headline: Brown Rice, but Better

He writes, “Nobody fully understands just what they might be sowing, for the Chinese or for the rest of the globe, by continuing to insist that the Chinese consume more and more.”

headline: German Exchange Doesn’t Plan to Sweeten NYSE Offer
text: Deutsche Börse does not plan to sweeten the terms of its merger with NYSE Euronext, because top managers of the German exchange operator are convinced that a rival bid has little chance of success, people with knowledge of the transaction said Monday.

headline: Egypt Sentences Blogger to 3 Years
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian blogger was sentenced Monday to three years in prison for criticizing the military in what human rights advocates called one of the more alarming violations of freedom of expression since a popular uprising led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two months ago.

headline: A Generous Opening to the Lucerne Easter Festival
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — By now many music lovers, having heard critics grouse for years about the glut of Handel “Messiah” performances at Christmas, know that the work was written for Lent. But those listeners, critics included, may be hard pressed to name another Handel oratorio written for the Easter season.

headline: An Extended Farewell for Steve Carell at ‘The Office’
text: A quick departure for Michael Scott probably would be better for productivity at Dunder Mifflin, but NBC isn’t letting go of Steve Carell, who has played that beloved if inept character on “The Office” for seven seasons, that easily. On Monday the network said it would extend the running time of the April 28 episode of “The Office,” on which Mr. Carell bids farewell to the series, to run about 50 minutes total, including commercials; it will be followed by an extended 40-minute episode of “Parks and Recreation,” a regular 30-minute episode of “30 Rock” and zero minutes of “Outsourced.”
