text: Photographs from Ivory Coast, France, Libya and Yemen.

headline: A Tonsil Remedy Is Fitted for a New Century
text: The Tonsil Hospital is no more.

headline: Keeping Eyes on Distracted Driving’s Toll
text: While driving a car, have you ever:

headline: Italy Lashes Out at European Union Over Immigrants
text: ROME — Tensions rose between Italy and its European Union partners on Monday over how to handle an influx of immigrants from North Africa, prompting the Italian interior minister to question the utility of the European Union.

headline: Court Upholds Facebook Settlement With Twins
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, the Olympic rowers and identical twins who claimed that they, not Mark Zuckerberg, had the original idea for Facebook, have lost the latest chapter in their six-year legal feud. But it’s a loss that comes with a pretty nice consolation prize. And it may not be the end of the case.

headline: Stresscalation
text: The contagiousness of stress. (Originally, the ways in which people increase their own levels of stress.)

headline: Pakistan Tells U.S. It Must Sharply Cut C.I.A. Activities
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan has demanded that the United States steeply reduce the number of Central Intelligence Agency operatives and Special Operations forces working in Pakistan, and that it halt C.I.A. drone strikes aimed at militants in northwest Pakistan. The request was a sign of the near collapse of cooperation between the two testy allies.

headline: Gee, How Did That Towel End Up in My Suitcase?
text: Hotel guests may want to think twice now before walking off with that bathrobe. Linen Technology Tracking, a company in Miami, has patented a washable RFID chip that can be sewn into towels, robes and bed sheets, allowing hotels to keep track of their linens.

headline: Orszag Rebuts Criticism in New York Magazine Profile
text: Peter Orszag, the former White House budget director, describes himself in a New York magazine article as relieved to be out of the West Wing — a place he didn’t want to be in the first place.

headline: Commemorating the Civil War’s 150th Anniversary
text: Facebook Event | Adam Goodheart, Disunion writer and author of the book, “1861,” invites you participate in a lively chat on April 12 at 12 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, on the Disunion Facebook page to commemorate the start of the Civil War on April 12, 1861. So come one, come all! And bring your questions about Fort Sumter and the coming of the Civil War. Or just anything else you think needs saying. Adam Goodheart will be answering questions until 1 p.m, E.S.T.

headline: Defense in Insider Trial Seeks to Present Galleon as Disciplined
text: 9:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: More Speculation About Kate Middleton’s Dress
text: The May issue of British Vogue is all bridal in honor of the bride Kate —  er, sorry, Catherine — Middleton, whose wedding to Prince William on April 29 has everyone playing a daily guessing game about her dress and tiara. The magazine features three separate covers: Freja Beha Erichsen in a silk faille Oscar de la Renta gown; Lara Stone in a delicate Bruce Oldfield; and Natalia Vodianova in a draped Vivienne Westwood dress with a tulle bolero. Mario Testino photographed the piece, called “Wedding Belles.”

headline: Depressed About Allergies?
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores the link between allergies and depression.

headline: Video Captures Ordeal of Subway Riders Trapped in Elevator
text: Another day, another harrowing and viral YouTube video of a New York City mass transit nightmare.

headline: 3-D Avatars Could Put You in Two Places at Once
text: If Jim Blascovich and Jeremy Bailenson are right, here is what’s in store for you and your avatar very soon, probably within the next five years:

headline: Shake-Up at Renault Over ‘Chain of Failures’
text: PARIS — The French automaker Renault dismissed its chief operating officer and six others after internal and external audits showed a “chain of failures” in the events that led to the unjust accusations of spying against three of its employees.

headline: Studies Say Natural Gas Has Its Own Environmental Problems
text: Natural gas, with its reputation as a linchpin in the effort to wean the nation off dirtier fossil fuels and reduce global warming, may not be as clean over all as its proponents say.

headline: Numberplay: Tracking the Ball
text: Imagine that you and your best buddy are missile tracking engineers working for the Pentagon (nice steady job in these times!). The two of you played hoops for rival schools in your youth, and each of you believes he is better than the other. You challenge each other to a one-on-one grudge match in your backyard, the winner entitled to bragging rights forever. All your colleagues show up, some with video cameras to film the historic showdown. It’s an intense match, and both of you are giving it all you’ve got. The game goes right down to the wire. You are one point behind, and with just a few seconds to go, you uncork a buzzer beater. The ball travels in a graceful arc towards the basket. To your eyes, it seems certain to go in. At that very moment, a hefty twig descends from the tree above, strikes the ball and deflects it away. The buzzer sounds.

headline: Taking Out Tonsils Less Often
text: In today’s 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, writes about the declining popularity of tonsillectomies, which were once almost routine in pediatrics.

headline: No Taxation Without Calculation: Filling Out Tax Returns
text: Overview | How much of workers’ income goes to taxes? Why? In this lesson, students estimate how much various people would need to earn to cover their expenses, and then take into account their tax burden. After exploring the 1040 form, they work in groups to use mocked-up financial forms to fill out tax returns for taxpayers, then swap with another group to conduct an “audit.”

headline: What We’re Reading: China Finally Runs a Trade Deficit
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: A Vaccine for the Very Young Takes Aim at Bacterial Diseases
text: With help from international donors, Congo introduced a new vaccine this month in an effort to save more of its babies from pneumococcal disease.

headline: Renovation of a Terminal, Keyed to San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If the prospect of flying holds all the appeal of a cross-country bus trip, the $6,500, lipstick-red leather Egg chairs at San Francisco International Airport’s Terminal 2 are intended to return some long-lost glamour to air travel.

headline: David Foster Wallace, Self-Help Reader
text: “The Pale King,” David Foster Wallace’s posthumous novel about I.R.S. agents struggling against boredom, may be unfinished, but it is still 548 pages long. Fortunately for those Wallace fans who are too busy finishing their own taxes to start reading the book, some shorter bits of Wallaceana have been popping up.

headline: Coda Automotive Raising Money to Finish Electric Car
text: Coda Automotive, an electric vehicle developer in Santa Monica, Calif., with a battery joint venture in Tianjin, China, is seeking fresh capital to complete work on its first model, the electric Coda Sedan. Christopher Rose, the company’s senior vice president for corporate development, said on the sidelines of the Berkeley-Stanford Cleantech Conference in San Francisco last weekend that the $50 million investment the company was seeking would be used “to finish the car.”

headline: The Big Board’s Big Rejection
text: On Sunday, NYSE Euronext rebuffed an $11.3 billion bid from the Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange, reaffirming a proposed merger with Deutsche Börse. Duncan L. Niederauer, chief executive of NYSE Euronext, talks about why the Big Board turned down the Nasdaq deal in a video interview with CNBC.

headline: Blogger Jailed for Insulting Egypt’s Military
text: As my colleagues Liam Stack and Ethan Bronner report, an Egyptian activist who criticized Egypt’s army on his blog was sentenced to three years in jail on Monday by a military court.

headline: Giants Who Scarfed Down Fast-Food Feasts
text: Nothing in the dinosaur world was quite like the sauropods. They were huge, some unbelievably gigantic, the biggest animals ever to lumber across the land, consuming everything in sight. Their necks were much longer than a giraffe’s, their tails just about as long and their bodies like an elephant’s, only much more so.

headline: Consolidation of Trade Publications Nears
text: The long-planned consolidation of three familiar trade publications into one is beginning at Prometheus Global Media.

headline: Screening Prostates at Any Age
text: When, if ever, are people just too old to benefit from cancer screening?

headline: When Should Men Stop P.S.A. Testing?
text: Older men who often have the least to gain from prostate cancer testing are being screened at twice the rate of men in their 50s, Gina Kolata reports in today’s Science Times.

headline: Why Insider Trading Is Wrong
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the head of the Galleon Group, is defending himself against charges of insider trading by arguing that his trades were based on the so-called “mosaic theory,” which means his firm gathered information from every nook and cranny of the market to put together a picture of a company.

headline: Held at the Gate, in the Service of Tequila
text: I’M a bit of a nomad. I was born in New York, went to college in Ohio, worked in the Midwest and then moved to San Francisco during the first dot-com boom.

headline: A Condo, High-Profile Residents and a $40,000 Bill
text: Ken Nahoum has been known in downtown social circles for his celebrity photography and music videos; his companion, a Victoria’s Secret model; his great season seats at Knicks games; and his collection of penthouses at 95 Greene Street in SoHo.

headline: Level 3’s Bid for Global Crossing Could Lead to More Deals
text: 7:36 p.m. | Updated

headline: Jura Has Its Day in New York
text: It’s kind of a crazy Jura  day in New York today, what with all sorts of dinners and tastings going on and Jura producers here offering their wares. The level of interest in the wines of the Jura has grown outlandishly in the last few years. It’s still minute in the great scheme of things, but Jura producers traveling to New York for tastings? Unheard of until recently.

headline: Face Time | Mary Louise Parker and Charlie Mars
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: Embedistan: Unembedded vs. Embedded
text: PAKTIA, Afghanistan — I have spent six months in Afghanistan, 85 percent of it unembedded.

headline: TimesCast | April 11, 2011
text: Ivory Coast's former leader is captured by his political rival; and a French law banning the full-face veil leads to arrests and protests.

headline: Romney Makes It Official, Quietly
text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, quietly made his presidential ambitions official Monday by forming an exploratory committee to run for president in 2012 and declaring in a video that “it is time that we put America back on a course of greatness.”

headline: New Orleans Horns, Raw and Funky
text: The Rebirth Brass Band ended its full-throttle show at Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday night more or less swarmed, yielding the stage to an eager throng. This of course was a handy bit of showmanship, timed to coincide with several of the band’s best-loved New Orleans anthems (“Feel Like Funkin’ It Up,” “Cassanova,” “Do Whatcha Wanna”) and with the climax of accumulated energies in the room. But it was also an affirmation of core principles. A stage is little more than a platform for the Rebirth Brass Band, and the distance it imposes on an audience is a passing inconvenience, even on the road.

headline: Ancien-Régime Change
text: Until very recently, when people gathered to do the math on United Nations Security Council reform, it was always a given that France had the weakest claim to permanent membership on the council. The others on the so-called “P5″ — the United States, Russia, China and Britain — all made more sense. France’s membership as a “victor” of World War II was always questionable.

headline: The Many Paths of Japan’s Avant-Garde
text: One conclusion to be drawn from the New Juilliard Ensemble’s concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening is that there are few generalizations to be made about Japanese avant-garde classical music around the turn of the 21st century. The concert, among the last offerings of Carnegie Hall’s JapanNYC festival, featured six works by as many composers, all born after World War II and not very much alike.

headline: Mini Countryman Geared Up for Rally Racing
text: The Mini Countryman is grown up, gussied up and now ready to race.

headline: Is This the Poster Food for a Radiation Menace?
text: One of the many endearing things about my husband is that he has five Geiger counters.

headline: Now Reading | ‘American Fashion Travel’
text: “American Fashion Travel” (Assouline, $45) collects detailed questionnaires, personal photos and amusing anecdotes from both established and up-and-coming designers, who may live and work in America but whose wanderlust is in no way confined to the United States. We discover, among other things, that Alexander Wang prefers the George V in Paris. Francisco Costa considers Havaianas sandals to be the perfect souvenir — not entirely unexpected from a bona fide Brazilian. Tommy Hilfiger loves to dine at Bukhara in New Delhi. Cynthia Rowley’s favorite travel book is “Local Color,” by Truman Capote. Lisa Mayock of Vena Cava shares her carry-on essentials: “gum, a notebook and trashy magazines.” And Phillip Lim swears by Shiseido eye patches to cure jet lag.

headline: The Brahms Behind the Schoenberg
text: Whatever toll James Levine’s health problems have taken on his conducting schedule, and his career more generally, when he does mount the podium — as he did last week to conduct “Wozzeck” at the Metropolitan Opera, and again on Sunday afternoon, when he led the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall — his performances are invariably so finely polished and intensely communicative that you cannot doubt that he is at the top of his game.

headline: Still Tapping Into the Teenage Soul
text: Although the history of vocal groups from the golden age of doo-wop is strewn with one-hit wonders, Little Anthony and the Imperials are not among them. And at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency last week, where the group is playing its first New York nightclub engagement in more than three decades, the reasons for its staying power were evident.

headline: Rabbis Sound an Alarm Over Eating Disorders
text: In the large and growing Orthodox Jewish communities around New York and elsewhere, rabbinic leaders are sounding an alarm about an unexpected problem: a wave of anorexia and other eating disorders among teenage girls.

headline: Photo Replay: April 11
text: A look at the day in sports, including the view from a tennis tournament in Monte Carlo and an Olympic track star entering a much different race.

headline: OpenTable and Its Snail-Mail Rewards Checks
text: OpenTable certainly makes it painless to find a good restaurant and make a reservation. So why the heck can’t the company make it more convenient to redeem the rewards points you earn by using its service?

headline: A Bunker of History Begins to Open
text: The New-York Historical Society has long seemed like a remote fortress on Central Park West because of the stately but insular architecture of its stone building and a certain bumpiness in its public relations.

headline: Diving in Search of the ‘Great Vampire Squid’
text: In his 2009 Rolling Stone article about Goldman Sachs, Matt Taibbi called the firm “a great vampire squid wrapped around the face of humanity, relentlessly jamming its blood funnel into anything that smells like money.” Say what you will about that description, but it does express a clear point of view. The same cannot be said for William D. Cohan’s “Money and Power,” which invokes the “vampire squid” line twice but has no comparably bold attitude of its own.

headline: House Republicans Seek to Remove Federal Funding for Planned Parenthood
text: There has been a change of plans among Republicans in Congress concerning a measure that would seek to end funding for Planned Parenthood, the subject of a fierce battle between Republicans and Democrats that threatened to upend a plan last week to keep the government open.

headline: Seeking Bliss Among the Honks and Hisses
text: Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, 54, the Indian spiritual guru, said it was his first time in Times Square, as he walked up Broadway on Monday morning.

headline: Gullibility
text: It has been quite a spectacle watching most of the punditocracy go into a swoon over Paul Ryan and his plan, then — once a few of us pointed out what was actually in the plan (and equally important, what wasn’t) — watch some of them try to climb down without quite admitting that they had been taken for a ride. And my sense is that a fair number of people still can’t believe that such a thing is possible — that there must have been some substance there, that the whole cadre of Very Serious People couldn’t have been taken in by an obvious fraud. But I remember when:

headline: Appeals Court Rules Against Arizona Law
text: PHOENIX — The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled against the State of Arizona on Monday and let stand a lower court decision blocking the most contentious parts of the state’s immigration law from going into effect.

headline: Their Bright Teenager Is a Cannibal
text: Goodness knows Manhattan moms have ample reasons for anxiety about disappointing children. Why couldn’t little Justin rise to the occasion of his kindergarten interview? How is it possible for a 12-year-old to lose three cellphones in as many months? Was it really necessary for Pearl to cause such havoc at her play date?

headline: Judge Returns Players and N.F.L. to Mediation
text: The N.F.L. and its players, now a month into the lockout, on Monday were ordered back to the negotiating table with a mediator.

headline: Playoff Experience Is Not Rangers Defensemen’s Strong Point
text: Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers’ rookie defenseman, will enter his team’s best-of-seven first-round series against Alexander Ovechkin and the Capitals without any previous playoff series experience. This does not just mean professional hockey.

headline: Wrapping Up Life and Death in One Album
text: PAUL SIMON

headline: Taking a Second Look at Penguins’ Decline
text: The population of Adélie penguins in Antarctica has declined by 50 percent in recent years, and everyone who has watched a nature movie or television show knows that the reason is the rapidly melting sea ice that has limited the size of their winter habitat. But what everyone knows may be wrong.

headline: Masters Helps CBS Master Prime Time
text: CBS’s Sunday-afternoon coverage of the Masters golf tournament helped lift the network’s prime-time ratings as well, as CBS topped the night for the fifth consecutive Sunday. Although final audience figures for the Masters were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight estimates were the second highest in 10 years, behind last year’s broadcast. Following the final round of that tournament, CBS’s “60 Minutes” delivered the largest audience in prime time, garnering 13.1 million viewers in the 7 p.m. hour. CBS’s reality shows “The Amazing Race” and “Undercover Boss” each drew 10.7 million viewers, at 8 and 9, while CBS’s “CSI: Miami” won the 10 p.m. hour with 10.2 million. ABC finished second, earning its best ratings at 8 for “Secret Millionaire” (9.1 million), while two hours of “Brothers & Sisters” averaged 6.5 million from 9 to 11 and lagged behind “The Celebrity Apprentice” on NBC (8.1 million). NBC was third with 4.3 million for “Dateline” at 7 and only 3.5 million for “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8. Fox was fourth with its animated comedies.

headline: Prune and Almond Braised Short Ribs
text: Adapted from Tony Maws, Craigie on Main, Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Seder for Two, Please: Restaurants Court Tradition
text: WHEN Victoria Herrmann’s grandparents died in 2005, her family’s Passover Seder tradition passed away with them. Her parents never had a Seder. (And her siblings had converted to Christianity.)

headline: A Couple’s Knot, Tied Tighter by Dual Diagnoses
text: Until February, Nathan and Elisa Bond were about as ordinary a 30-something couple as you could find in Brooklyn. Mr. Bond, 38, was a teacher and an artist; Ms. Bond, 36, worked for a real estate broker; their daughter, Sadie, had turned 1 in the fall. The last thing on their minds was cancer.

headline: Stupak Signs On as a Lobbyist
text: Bart Stupak has become the latest lawmaker — and one of the biggest names — among those who left Congress last year to move to a lobbying job. Venable LLP, a Washington law firm and lobbying shop, announced that it had signed him to work on legislative and government affairs.

headline: For a Man’s Tie, a Woman’s Touch
text: Chiffon, organza and tulle — fabrics traditionally used in women’s fashion — can now be found in men’s neckties,  thanks to the nascent brand C.Chauchat. “We are going to put tutu fabric on men — and they don’t even know it,” boasts Curie Choi, one half of the female design duo that’s giving the classic men’s accessory a new feel. “Madame Chauchat is a lady who puts frenzy in the men around her,” Choi says about her brand’s namesake, a character from Thomas Mann’s “Magic Mountain.”

headline: Obama Favors University Setting to Deliver Policy Lectures
text: When President Obama decides that he wants to give a somber policy lecture about a big, tough-to-understand subject, he heads back to school — literally.

headline: Concert for Japan
text: A marathon benefit concert took place at the Japan Society.

headline: Obama Speech a ‘Curveball,’ Chambliss Says
text: ATLANTA – A Republican leader in a bipartisan Senate group negotiating a debt-reduction package said on Monday that President Obama “threw us a little bit of a curveball” with the weekend announcement that he plans to deliver a speech on the subject later this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Ivory Coast, France, Libya and Yemen.

headline: Adobe Goes After Tablets in Software Update
text: To many, tablet computers have one major weakness: It is hard to create original content on them. But on Monday, Adobe announced a series of updates to its software that might help address that.

headline: Hudson River Park, 4:47 P.M.
text: Hudson River Park, 4:47 P.M.

headline: Strum, Pluck, Rescue, Rebuild
text: The hair was a little grayer, and the chins were a little weaker, but early Saturday afternoon at Japan Society it was like the 1980s again. The performers — Philip Glass, Hal Willner, John Zorn, Laurie Anderson, Lou Reed — were the same ones you might have found together back then, joined now for the first part of a 13-hour Concert for Japan, one of several earthquake relief benefits organized by the tireless Mr. Zorn.

headline: Music With Texture, Shaking the Auditorium
text: Rumbles, thunderclaps and a baleful reading from the Old Testament prophet Amos — “I will slay the last of them with my sword” — opened the set by Lustmord on Sunday night at the Abrons Arts Center, the finale of the Unsound Festival of electronic and contemporary music and video. It was an extraordinarily rare live performance by the British musician Brian Williams, who has been recording as Lustmord since 1980 but has given only a handful of public concerts during his career, emerging for the Unsound Festival in Krakow, Poland, last year.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Passion of Joan of Arc'
text: A .O. Scott examines the currents of emotion in Carl Theodor Dreyer's 1928 film.

headline: Tough Call on Goldstone Retraction
text: In my column on Sunday April 10, I described the complex, fast-moving environment in which The Times’s foreign desk reports developments online and in print. A further challenge to journalists on the desk is deciding how to prioritize the news, especially given the volume and urgency of news in the current climate. While one might argue that in the digital medium there is unlimited space for news, in print the situation is different. The recent case of the retraction of a key assertion by Richard Goldstone, the South African jurist who led a panel investigating Israel’s invasion of Gaza two years ago, is a case in point.

headline: ‘Arthur’ Sells Fewer Tickets Than Predicted
text: LOS ANGELES— The weekend was even worse for Russell Brand than initially thought.

headline: The Science of the Spill
text: One year after the largest oil spill in the history of the Gulf of Mexico, scientists are trying to determine the long-term ecological effects.

text: Student loan debt outpaced credit card debt for the first time last year and is likely to top a trillion dollars this year as more students go to college and a growing share borrow money to do so.

text: The National Association of Black Journalists has pulled out of an alliance intended to improve minority representation in the media, saying the group’s conference no longer provided enough revenue to meet its goals.

headline: Amazon to Sell the Kindle Reader at a Lower Price, but With Advertising Added
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is shaving another $25 off the price of its Kindle e-reader, this time with the help of advertisers.

headline: More Remains Are Found on Long Island, This Time in Nassau
text: Hours after expanding the search to Nassau County on Monday, the police on Long Island discovered human remains in two more places along Ocean Parkway, only miles from where investigators in Suffolk County have found eight bodies and said they are on the trail of a serial killer.

headline: A Stingy Traveler Stung by Hotel Fees
text: I AM not so big on luxury travel. I’m simply too cheap, even when I’m traveling on the company dime.

headline: Eating Disorders Among Orthodox Jews
text: In the large and growing Orthodox Jewish communities around New York and elsewhere, rabbinic leaders are sounding an alarm about an unexpected problem: a wave of anorexia and other eating disorders among teenage girls, reports Roni Caryn Rabin in this week’s Science Times.

headline: Jonathan Alter Leaves Newsweek
text: Jonathan Alter, a long-time columnist for Newsweek, has left the publication after 28 years there.  Though his last day on the Newsweek payroll was over a week ago, Mr. Alter said he had not yet “completed my deal with my new employer.”

headline: Yakov Kreizberg, Orchestral Conductor, Dies at 51
text: Yakov Kreizberg, an internationally known conductor praised for the depth and intensity of his interpretations, died on March 15 at his home in Monte Carlo. He was 51.

text: Inside the chef’s new Japanese restaurant in TriBeCa.

headline: Marvell Co-Founders Sue Goldman Sachs
text: At the height of the financial crisis, two co-founders of Marvell Technology had to sell a big portion of stock in the semiconductor company after a margin call from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Giant Toys for Attracting Much Older Boys
text: AN unusual promotion planned for the Indianapolis 500 is based on the saying that the only difference between men and boys is the size of their toys.

headline: For Mourners of Knut, a Stuffed Bear Just Won’t Do
text: BERLIN — A polar bear died and the zoo’s director decided to stuff its body and put it on display in a museum. (The director prefers the technical term, dermoplastik, though to most people it’s stuffed.)

headline: Medtronic Bone-Growth Product Scrutinized
text: One of Medtronic’s most profitable divisions — selling bone growth products used in spinal fusion procedures — faces growing pressure amid a widening criminal investigation into the company’s marketing of one product and a rejection by federal regulators of another one.

headline: 10 Indicted in Conspiracy to Fix Games at San Diego
text: Two former University of San Diego basketball players and a former assistant were among 10 people indicted as part of a conspiracy to commit sports bribery, federal authorities said Monday. The conspiracy included the operation of an illegal sports bookmaking service and the distribution of marijuana.

headline: An Appalachian Radio Voice Threatened From Afar
text: WHITESBURG, Ky. — Rich Kirby, a part-time producer for WMMT3, the community radio station here, was interviewing two local aid officials the other day about the effect of Washington’s proposed budget cuts on this region, in the heart of Appalachia.

headline: Masters Ratings Slip
text: Charl Schwartzel’s stunning victory in the Masters generated a 10.4 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating Sunday on CBS — down from 12.0 last year when Phil Mickelson won and Tiger Woods returned to competitive golf. It was still the second-highest-rated final round in 10 years.

headline: Obama, the G.O.P. and the Budget Cuts
text: To the Editor:

headline: After a Long Wait, Brushstroke Is Poised to Open
text: Unlike an actual brushstroke, there is nothing spontaneous about David Bouley’s new Japanese restaurant of the same name. Brushstroke, which has been serving tryout dinners to invited guests in TriBeCa and will open to the public on April 20, took nearly a decade to develop. Even the name has been waiting in the wings since 2007.

headline: Mexico: More Bodies Found Near U.S.
text: Mexican authorities said Sunday that they had found 16 more bodies buried in mass graves in the northeastern state of Tamaulipas, raising the total to 88. The victims are believed to have been kidnapped from intercity buses traveling to the United States border. The United States Consulate in the border city of Matamoros said that an American citizen was among those who were reported kidnapped from a bus and was still missing.

headline: 88.7 on Appalachia’s Dial
text: WHITESBURG, Ky. — WMMT, at 88.7 on your FM dial or www.wmmt.org on the Internet, is a rural station that dishes up almost all original programming. Apart from all manner of music, the shows include “Holler to the Hood,” which plays hip-hop aimed at the growing prison population in the region. The show tapes and broadcasts messages from inmates’ far-away friends and families.

headline: Karzai Blames Western Firms for Kabul Bank’s Troubles
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As a delegation of Afghan officials traveled to Washington to present their plan to international financial authorities to dismantle Afghanistan’s largest private bank, President Hamid Karzai on Monday denounced Western accounting firms and advisers for corruption and failing to detect the bank’s troubles.

headline: Hedda Sterne, an Artist of Many Styles, Dies at 100
text: Hedda Sterne, an artist whose association with the Abstract Expressionists became fixed forever when she appeared prominently in a now-famous 1951 Life magazine photograph of the movement’s leading lights, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

headline: Iraq Steps Back Onto the Regional Stage
text: BAGHDAD — On Monday morning, the Iraqi foreign minister stood in a marble rotunda of Saddam Hussein’s old Republican Palace, once the heart of the American occupation, and noted that this was where the United States held sway when it “was trying to help us run our country.”

headline: Rematch That Has a Lot to Live Up To

headline: For Mets Manager, Adjustments Are Part of the Job
text: For Mets Manager Terry Collins, lineup tinkering is a way of life. He said Monday that he was not a big believer in the idea of leaving the previous game at the ballpark. Collins said he was still thinking about the next day’s lineup on his drive home, as his head hits the pillow and over his morning coffee the next day. If that sounds like a lot of work, there is a reason.

headline: After Bishops Attack Book, Gauging Bounds of Debate
text: Is God male? The Old Testament uses the masculine pronoun to describe him. Jesus refers to the divinity as Father. So does that make the creator a masculine force — and mean that men are more godlike than women?

headline: Britain: Sub Crewman Arraigned
text: A 22-year-old navy submarine crewman appeared in magistrate’s court in Southampton on Monday, charged with killing one of the vessel’s senior officers and wounding three crewmen in a burst of automatic rifle fire while the submarine was berthed in the city’s harbor last week. The suspect, Able Seaman Ryan Donovan, was not asked to enter a plea and will return to court on Wednesday. A police investigation has focused on the gunman’s motives, which British newspapers have reported as related to his having been denied use of a crew toilet and a request for shore leave. A navy inquiry is centering on how the seaman was cleared for high-security duty on the missile-carrying submarine despite postings on the Internet that revealed that he had legally changed his name to Reggie Moondogg before joining the navy and had written aggressive rap songs.

headline: A Dollar Is a Dollar: Elena Kagan’s Style
text: When Elena Kagan was nominated by President Obama to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court, some observers speculated that she might be the long-sought liberal counterweight to Antonin Scalia, noted for his intelligence, his wit and his prose style. Of course it’s too early to tell, but Kagan’s dissent (her first) in Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn would seem to give those distressed by the Court’s current direction some hope. (Scalia honed his rhetorical skills as a dissenter earlier in his career.)

headline: A Scorecard for Companies With a Conscience

People in the know, however, call it the Boone Pickens bill.

headline: Start the Presses
text: From handmade hair accessories to artisanal pickles, there’s a metaphorical back-to-the-land movement for every profession. For graphic design, it’s letterpress, a labor-intensive printing process that creative types are taking up as an antidote to days spent staring at their iMacs. Produced on antique presses and characterized by heavily impressed lettering on thick paper, letterpress cards and stationery — if you’ve received a wedding invitation from an even vaguely arty couple in the past few years, chances are it was letterpress printed — are the graphic design equivalent of slow food. For designers who want to unplug, literally, letterpress is a chance to spend time refining their craft using a method that was considered old-fashioned long before the days of Photoshop. “People miss the hands-on experience of printing,” says Daniel Gardiner Morris, a fourth-generation letterpress printer and the founder of the Arm, the Williamsburg studio where many local printers have learned the basics of handling Industrial Revolution-era machinery. “Even if you don’t know anything about the process, when you pick up something that was printed on a letterpress, you know there’s something different about it. It was touched by human hands.” Here, the lowdown on five printers who are getting their fingers inky.

headline: New Details Emerge on Sokol and Lubrizol Deal
text: 9:18 p.m. | Updated

headline: Crist Apologizes for Misuse of Talking Heads Song
text: Some days Charlie Crist is an ally of rock stars, and some days he is their adversary. On Monday, Mr. Crist, the former governor of Florida who, before he left office, helped champion a posthumous pardon for Jim Morrison, confirmed that he had settled a lawsuit with David Byrne after using a Talking Heads song in a campaign ad without permission, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Legislative Leaders Praise Cuomo, Tactically
text: ALBANY — The State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, patted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on the shoulder and then turned to a nearby lectern. “Governor, I congratulate you,” Senator Skelos said.

headline: Space Shuttle to Land in Manhattan
text: A space shuttle is coming to Manhattan, but not one of the three that have carried astronauts into orbit.

headline: Battle of the Baristas
text: On Sunday, Philip Search, an espresso and coffee consultant for Dallis Brothers Coffee, won the Northeast Regional Barista Competition, three days of competitive coffee held this year at Milk Studios in Manhattan. With the victory, Mr. Search earned a berth in the semifinals of the United States Barista Championship, to be held in Houston later this month.

headline: Activist Starts Hunger Strike in Bahrain
text: Updated | 2:21 p.m. After Bahrain’s interior ministry acknowledged that two political prisoners had died in custody last week, the daughter of a detained human rights activist began a hunger strike on Monday, calling on the authorities to release her father and other members of her family who have been arrested.

headline: A New Obstacle to College Appears
text: Before my extensive college marathon began, I thought there was only one barrier — an academic one, consisting of standardized tests and rigorous coursework — standing as an obstacle between me and going to college.

headline: Going to War: Part 2
text: HELMAND, Afghanistan — Where does a logistics unit like ours fit into a counterinsurgency fight? I put the question to my Marines and didn’t get much back, so my fellow platoon commanders and I dived into the topic more completely.

headline: Tracing Nitrogen’s Path Through the Ocean
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

text: Terms used in India to characterise the adoption of the material trappings of Western life without also embracing Western values of equality.

headline: In Rape Trial, Police Vernacular Slips Into 911 Call
text: Anyone can look at a homeless man sleeping in the hallway of an apartment building and describe him as “a homeless man,” but there is a certain subset of New Yorkers who see the same man and say, “male white.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Passion of Joan of Arc’
text: This week A. O. Scott looks back at the trial and execution of St. Joan as recounted in the silent classic by the Danish filmmaker Carl Theodor Dreyer in “The Passion of Joan of Arc” (1928). The film is based on the transcripts from the trial and explores it from a political and religious perspective. “There’s something powerful and mysterious about beholding the image of a human face,” Mr. Scott says about the film’s use of close-ups to build a kind of spiritual intensity. The entire first half is a succession of close-ups, which, Mr. Scott says, “create a feeling of intimacy and confinement. And the drama, even the narrative itself, are contained within these faces.” The film is ultimately more concerned with emotion than politics, making it that much more of a human story. “‘The Passion of Joan of Arc’ creates an uncanny, unforgettable, almost unique sense of connection to its main character,” Mr. Scott says. “We may not ultimately understand Joan, but we know her.” Have you seen the film? Please share your thoughts.

headline: Saudis Adjust Oil Production as World Demand Fluctuates
text: PARIS — Saudi Arabia has maintained its role this year as the world’s oil producer of last resort, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.

headline: Annals of Well, Duh (Commodity Prices)
text: The Chicago Fed has a new paper (pdf) showing that shocks to commodity prices do not, in fact, presage higher core inflation. Actually, it’s quite a good little piece — and kudos to Charles Evans, the Chicago Fed’s president, for putting his name on it in these days of fanatical inflation hawks.

headline: Selling Your Car? Try Making a Video
text: Thinking about selling your car yourself, instead of trading it in for credit toward a new one? Some amateur video recording and smart use of the Web may bring you more offers and a better price, advises the automobile site Edmunds.com.

headline: One, But Not Done: Perry Jones Stays in the Game
text: Perry Jones, the Baylor basketball player and subject of my March 13 cover article, is not by nature a contrary person. He likes to do what’s expected of him. It’s his strength — he’s coachable — but also a weakness. He’s compliant, sometimes passive.

headline: Solace in the Stadium as Baseball Resumes in Japan
text: CHIBA, Japan — The parking lots around QVC Marine Field were closed because the land underneath them liquefied in the March 11 earthquake. Some scoreboards were turned off to save electricity, and a new inning could no longer begin after a game was three and a half hours old for the same reason. Flags at the stadium were flown at half-staff, and players on one of the teams, the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, wore patches on their uniforms that in effect urged their fans to “stick with it.”

headline: Texas Governor to View Wildfire Damage
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is scheduled on Tuesday to take an aerial tour of areas damaged by wildfires that continue to burn hundreds of thousands of acres across the state, while rivers in North Dakota and Minnesota are generally receding, officials said, though the risk of flooding is expected to increase again by the end of the week.

headline: For Flip Video Camera, Four Years From Hot Start-Up to Obsolete
text: It was one of the great tech start-up success stories of the last decade.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Oh Land
text: The Danish recording artist Oh Land performed an hour or so worth of songs at a small gallery space on the Bowery. Hosted by VS magazine, the event was packed elbow to elbow with fans curious to hear the new artist’s work, including her hit single “Sun of a Gun.” Oh Land, a stunning blonde, led a minimal band — synth player, a percussionist and three classical musicians; she herself hit notes alternately on a xylophone, a drum machine and what looked like a vintage miniature finger organ. A cloud of white balloons behind her on the stage sometimes carried projections of her face. As sweet as she looks (she was dressed in a shirt adorned with plush toucans), she asked the crowd, earnestly, to keep it down during the quieter songs.

headline: Cisco Shutters Flip, Two Years After Acquisition
text: Cisco Systems — which heralded the $590 million purchase of Pure Digital Technologies two years ago — is closing the company, which makes Flip video cameras, as part of a broader effort to restructure its consumer business.

headline: A Display of Sportsmanship
text: As we wait for a jury in San Francisco to end the Barry Bonds trial, perhaps tolling the final bell on what we think of as the steroids era, it would be rather heartwarming if the city were the stage for the dawn of another era. How nice if we could use Monday’s events to begin an era of civility — although we’d settle for the Era in Which Fans Stopped Beating One Another Up — with the Giants dedicating the game against the Dodgers at AT&T Park to the recovery of Bryan Stow.

headline: Hope Sprouting Amid Italian Film Studio’s Decay
text: ROME — It was a sun-kissed spring day here, warm, with swarms of camera-toting tourists congregating in the Piazza del Popolo, fruit and vegetable vendors selling puntarelle at the market stalls in the Campo de’ Fiori, and Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi poised to go on trial for abuse of power and paying an underage girl for sex.

headline: No to Female Golfers, Maybe to Female Reporters
text: Within 30 minutes of the Masters Golf Tournament’s stirring conclusion on Sunday, eyewitness accounts rocketed around Twitter that Tara Sullivan, a columnist for The Bergen Record, had been denied access to the locker room at Augusta National Golf Club, where she was to interview Rory McIlroy, who had just posted the greatest last-day collapse in the tournament’s history.

headline: Energy Options and Polarized Politics
text: The Bipartisan Policy Center, as its name implies, tries to define a path on issues like energy that can work in a period of polarized politics and shrinking budgets. It’s a tough challenge. That’s why the new center’s latest effort, “An Open Letter to the American People and America’s Leaders: A New Era for U.S. Energy Security,” focuses arguments for action on oil mainly on the basis of economic and geopolitical conflict, with the environment and climate in the background.

headline: Making TV Safer: Chinese Censors Crack Down on Time Travel
text: BEIJING — In a bizarre move, China’s television censors have issued new guidelines that all but ban TV dramas featuring time travel.

text: ALBANY — Dennis M. Walcott came to the Capitol two months ago to shepherd around New York City’s new schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, and to sit by her side as she testified before lawmakers. On occasion, when lawmakers posed particularly technical questions, Mr. Walcott stepped in to answer.

headline: An Economist’s Argument for More Children
text: The title alone would make you buy this book, no? Called “Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids: Why Being a Great Parent Is Less Work and More Fun Than You Think,” it is written by Bryan Caplan, an economics professor at George Mason University. His goal is to persuade you that you are trying too hard to make your children turn out “good.”

headline: Political Disputes Cloud Portuguese Bailout Talk
text: LISBON — International creditors started discussing the terms of a bailout for Portugal on Tuesday amid concerns that their initial challenge would be to sort out the country’s political disputes rather than its financial situation.

headline: Huffington Post Is Target of Suit on Behalf of Bloggers
text: The Huffington Post is the target of a multimillion dollar lawsuit filed in United States District Court in New York on Tuesday on behalf of thousands of uncompensated bloggers.

headline: Pistons Closing With More Fireworks
text: A season of buffoonery is one step closer to a merciful end for the Detroit Pistons.

headline: School Janitor Charged in Rape of Student
text: Updated, 3:35 p.m. | A janitor at a middle school in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, was arrested Monday night on charges of raping a 13-year-old student, the police and an education official said.

headline: Kennedy Mania
text: If it seems to you that every time you pick up a copy of Vanity Fair, there’s an article about the Kennedys, you’re not far wrong. It turns out, according to Eliza Gray at The New Republic, that roughly “one third of the issues of Vanity Fair since 2003 have contained at least one article about a Kennedy, written by a Kennedy, or mentioning a Kennedy at least seven times.”

headline: Racing Around the World, Once Again
text: On Thursday morning the green flag will drop on the World Race 2011 as an eclectic group of cars and trucks leaves Times Square, bound for Paris. The event is meant to replicate a 1908 around-the-world race that was sponsored by The New York Times. That first event was won – six months later -– by George Schuster, a mechanic from Buffalo, in a machine called the Thomas Flyer.

text: 2:06 p.m. | Updated  And the year started out so very hopeful.

headline: Stolen King Tut Statue Returned to Cairo Museum
text: A gilded statue of Tutankhamun that was stolen from the Egyptian Museum in January has been returned, along with three other objects, Egypt’s minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, announced on Tuesday in a news release on his Web site. The figure is from a statue of the king standing in a boat throwing a harpoon. The looters had broken the figure of the king off the boat, which they left in the museum.

headline: Indulging in ‘Gone With the Wind’
text: Ardent fans of “Gone With the Wind” — called windies — are gearing up for the 75th anniversary of the book in Atlanta.

headline: Hospital Is Drawn Into Bahrain Strife
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — A handful of soldiers, their faces covered by black masks to hide their identities, guard the front gate of Salmaniya Medical Complex. Inside, clinics are virtually empty of patients, many of whom, doctors say, have been hauled away for detention after participating in protests.

headline: Part 3: Answers to Readers’ Decision-Time Questions
text: All this week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

headline: Memories From Big Pink: Robbie Robertson to Write His Life Story
text: In his lyrics and music Robbie Robertson,  the Band guitarist turned solo singer-songwriter, has told the tales of the Confederate soldier Virgil Cane and a mysterious new arrival to a town called Nazareth, but he has never fully unpacked his own life story until now. On Tuesday the Crown Publishers imprint of Random House said that it had acquired a memoir from Mr. Robertson, – one that he plans to write himself after a few curtailed efforts at collaborating on a biography with other writers and journalists.

headline: NASA Chooses Space Shuttles’ Retirement Homes
text: NASA’s space shuttles, which have been carrying astronauts aloft for 30 years, were assigned to their final destinations on Tuesday: one will head to the nation’s capital, another to Los Angeles, and the third from its current home at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to the center’s visitor complex next door.

headline: Play Along With Coltrane
text: Dan Cohen (don’t know him) posted a transcription of John Coltrane’s “Giant Steps” on YouTube that has the notes of the tenor solo pop up on the sheet music as they are played. As a semiretired sax player, I felt a wave of panic set in as the chord changes go flying past. (Thanks to Craig Pittman, author of “Manatee Insanity,” for posting this on his Facebook page, where I first saw it.)

headline: Fill-In | Long-Necked Sauropods

headline: Snapshot of a Fateful Conversation
text: It was 7 p.m. last Wednesday at the Pierre Hotel on the Upper East Side. As far as Cathleen P. Black knew, her future as the chancellor of New York City’s public schools was still secure.

headline: Ready or Not, Playoffs Await
text: Over the course of a few hours Monday evening, the Knicks learned their playoff position (sixth), their opponent (the Celtics) and their first-round disposition (likely testy).

headline: Capitals, in Familiar Spot, Look for Different Result
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Nobody has to tell the Washington Capitals that the Rangers mean trouble. New York won three of the four regular-season games against the Capitals. Two of those were Washington’s worst defeats of the year, including a 7-0 shutout on Dec. 12. When clubs last met on Feb. 25 the Rangers outscored the Caps, 6-0.

headline: The Problem With Multiple Chapter 11 Plans
text: Until October 2005, dueling Chapter 11 plans were a theoretical possibility, but a rare occurrence in reality. The Federal Bankruptcy Code contemplated that a debtor might lose its exclusive right to propose a plan, but bankruptcy courts routinely extended exclusivity and the debtor typically proposed the only plan in the case. The plan was often the result of negotiation and might look very different from the first plan proposed by the debtor, but there was only one plan.

headline: Police Officers in Swaziland Squash Rally for Democracy
text: JOHANNESBURG — The police in Swaziland, the last absolute monarchy in Africa, squelched a long-planned pro-democracy rally on Tuesday, firing water cannons and tear gas into crowds in Manzini, the nation’s largest city.

headline: Baryshnikov Strikes Gold With Art Sale
text: Mikhail Baryshnikov’s magic extended beyond the stage on Tuesday morning when a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg, Russia, by the 19th-century painter Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin sold at Sotheby’s for $746,500. The dancer bought the painting in 1978 and recently donated it to the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan, which he established in 2005. The buyer was an unidentified German collector bidding by telephone who paid well above the $500,000 high estimate.

headline: At JoeDoe, It’s Not Passover Without a Playlist
text: Jill Schulster, who owns JoeDoe in the East Village with her husband, the chef Joe Dobias, has shared the Passover playlist she put together for the restaurant’s seders. The list is on iTunes, where you can preview and download almost all of the tracks. Here, Ms. Schulster describes how the list was born.

headline: What’s With the Fish?
text: This photograph was taken at 9:20 a.m. Tuesday in New York City. Can you write a caption that explains what it depicts?

headline: We Shop in Public
text: When it goes live this month, Motilo.com will use features like videoconferencing to allow users to shop with friends and create complete outfits, even if the items are from different online stores. And thanks to social networking components, users’ shopping predilections will be broadcast to the world, allowing anyone to become a trendsetter. To kick-start the process, Motilo’s chief executive, Sofia Barattieri di San Pietro, commissioned a bevy of pretty young “It” girls and stylists, including Valentine Fillol-Cordier, Anna Dello Russo and the D.J. Bip Ling, to share their picks with Motilo’s users. “Soon we want to involve different women, with different backgrounds, ages and charisma,” Barattieri says. “It is only the beginning.” Above, Fillol-Cordier wears a Carven silk-bourette pantsuit and a Lanvin brushed-satin floral brooch, all available at Motilo.com.

headline: Barbour Decision on 2012 Presidential Race by End of April
text: There are a lot of people taking aim at Mitt Romney and his health care record these days. Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is not among them.

headline: LPSV
text: Initialism for the mother ships used by Somali pirates: Large Pirate Support Vessels.

headline: Mubarak Hospitalized in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Hosni Mubarak, the former autocratic president of Egypt forced out by the revolution two months ago, was abruptly hospitalized on Tuesday in the beach resort of Sharm el Sheik. The state-run daily newspaper Al Ahram said it happened after prosecutors had begun questioning him about charges of possible corruption and other crimes.

headline: At Galleon Trial, Flashes of Anger From the Defense
text: Even before the insider-trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam started for the day, members in the courtroom gallery witnessed a clash between the prosecution and defense on Tuesday.

headline: Ryan’s Five-Point Plan
text: I just did a taping for All Things Considered with Douglas Holtz-Eakin, and more or less on the spur of the moment came up with a simple description of the Ryan budget plan. Basically, the plan has five points — except that only two of those points are real, while the other three are fake.

headline: Brooklyn Bike Lane Is Scuttled (No, Not That One)
text: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | Cross one bicycle lane off the list.

headline: Call for Low Rates Is Lost on Euro Zone
text: The International Monetary Fund appeared to warn the European Central Bank on Monday against further interest rate increases, saying that the euro area is still in a fragile state. The warning may not have much effect, though. The European bank’s president, Jean-Claude Trichet, emphasized last week that the central bank will not be swayed by outside pressure.

headline: Excerpt: 'Happy Endings'
text: The ABC sitcom follows a jilted man, played by Zachary Knighton, and his friends.

headline: Gagarin Revisited
text: Tuesday is the 50th anniversary of Yuri Gagarin’s historic space flight. To mark the occasion, a groundbreaking biography of the space pioneer, published for the first time in the United States this month by Walker & Company, was recently excerpted in our men’s issue. Here, one of the book’s authors, Jamie Doran, revisits Gagarin’s legacy.

headline: Keeping Score on Nuclear Accidents
text: Now that Japan has raised its assessment of the Fukushima accident to a 7 on the International Atomic Energy Agency’s scale, equal to the 1986 accident at Chernobyl, it may be time to review past accidents. Thomas B. Cochran, a physicist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, just did that in preparing to testify on Tuesday afternoon before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee.

headline: U.N. Praises Palestinians’ Progress Toward a State
text: JERUSALEM — The United Nations praised Palestinian Authority efforts at strengthening its institutions in a report on Tuesday, describing aspects of its administration as sufficient for an independent state.

headline: Countering the Siege
text: WASHINGTON — Perhaps more than any other American, Gerald W. McEntee has surfed the rising tide of public sector unions to success and power. As leader of the largest union of state and local government workers for three decades, he has amassed enormous political influence and a huge campaign war chest that he has not hesitated to use to advance his union’s interests.

headline: G.M. Will Accelerate Malibu Production Schedule
text: The next generation of Chevrolet’s Malibu will apparently be in dealer showrooms sooner than expected. According to a story in Tuesday’s Detroit Free Press, production of the 2013 Malibu will begin in January, rather than in May 2012. In confirming the report, a Chevrolet spokesman, Dave Darovitz, said the accelerated program had been requested by Dan Akerson, chairman and chief executive of General Motors.

headline: Get With the Programs: Exploring the Implications of Federal Budget Cuts
text: Overview | What do federal budget cuts mean for your state and community? How should Congress decide which programs and services to cut and which to keep? In this lesson, students investigate and make presentations on programs whose financing may be cut in the federal budget. They then discuss and vote on whether these programs should be cut or maintained. Finally, they write letters to their United States representatives and senators.

headline: Swimming With the Beautiful People
text: COBI LEVY was greeting guests at the top of the stairs at Niko, his new restaurant in the second-floor space on Mercer Street that used to be Honmura An. He did so with cool professionalism, apparent disdain or bro-hugging intensity, as the situation demanded. His eyes scanned the room constantly, a driver watching his mirrors, keeping an eye on his gauges, going fast at night, destination certain.

headline: Reviewing Niko
A New Public-Private Partnership for Patients
text: Federal officials announced a new public-private effort called the Partnership for Patients: Better Care, Lower Costs on Tuesday in which hospitals, doctors, nurses, patient advocates, health plans and employers will work together to try to improve the quality of the nation’s medical care. The idea is to work together to save lives and money by reducing hospital errors, injuries and complications that could be prevented.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Libya, Italy and Japan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Libya, Italy and Japan.

headline: Islanders Erase Interim From Capuano’s Job Title
text: Jack Capuano was coaching a minor league team in Bridgeport, Conn., in November when the Islanders called and asked him to stabilize their team, which had lost its confidence, several players to injury and 10 games in a row. He did so well as their interim coach that Tuesday, the Islanders gave him the job for keeps.

headline: Texas Governor a Winner on School Funds
text: 4:33 p.m. | Updated Among the winners in Friday night’s federal spending agreement, count Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

headline: Boehner Warns Obama on Tax Increase
text: House Speaker John A. Boehner will issue a warning Tuesday to President Obama a day before the president is set to deliver a major speech on the nation’s deficit: Raising taxes is “unacceptable and a nonstarter.”

headline: A Look at the Nuclear Accident Scale

headline: Disclosure Sheds New Light on Sokol Timeline
