text: Don’t bogart that megawatt, my friend.

headline: The Secret History of Ads in Books
text: Amazon’s announcement that it will start selling an advertising-supported Kindle at a discounted price has provoked some grumbling about the commercialization of the reading experience.

headline: Creators of ‘Smash’ TV Pilot Are Waiting for the Show to Go On
text: The New York-based creators of “Smash” — an NBC fall season prospect about the making of a Broadway musical — have concluded filming and editing the one-hour pilot episode and expect to meet soon with their executive producer, Steven Spielberg, to finish a final cut to deliver to NBC, according to “Smash” head writer Theresa Rebeck.

headline: How to Take Home a Piece of Daniel Radcliffe (and Other Tales from Broadway Auction Season)
text: Anyone can buy a T-shirt from the Broadway revival of the musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” emblazoned with the face of its star, Daniel Radcliffe. But it takes a truly determined and deep-pocketed theatergoer to go home with a piece of clothing soaked with Mr. Radcliffe’s sweat.

headline: Mexicans Work the Longest Hours
text: According to a new report from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, people in Mexico spend more hours of their day working than the people of any other country.

headline: Opening Day in Japan
text: The return of baseball has been infused with meaning this year as Japan struggles to right itself after the earthquake and tsunami on March 11.

headline: Tourondel to Open a Midtown Brasserie This Summer
text: Laurent Tourondel is planning to open an American-style brasserie this summer in the new Cassa Hotel and Residences, 70 West 45th Street. Details of the restaurant, including its name, have not been decided, but there will be about 150 seats and it will be open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Mr. Tourondel was once a partner in the BLT restaurants but now remains involved only with BLT Market in the Ritz-Carlton Central Park. He also owns a burger place, LT Burger, in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Are Your Miles a Mess? Here’s How to Put Them to Use
text: I used to be a frequent-flier miles skeptic. The rewards system world seemed so overwhelming. Was it worth it to book a more expensive flight to gain miles? And where do I keep my membership number anyway? Do I use a credit card that promises a mile for each dollar spent or the one that gives me 1 percent pure cash back? How about dining in certain restaurants or sending packages by Federal Express just to gain miles?

headline: Political Conflicts, Family-Style
text: A cacophony of arguments adds up to chaotic noise. It’s the sound of no one being heard, until one voice cleanly breaks through to articulate a point about the Arab-Israeli conflict in 1948. Then that premise is quickly rejected, leading to another theory and counterattack.

headline: Before School Ends, Time to Make the Matzo
text: The children filed out of yellow school buses and descended the stairs to the basement of a Jewish community center in Queens, where they put on plastic aprons and paper chef hats in preparation for a lesson on how to make matzo.

headline: Eurofile | Bobo Heaven in Paris
text: Peruse the Paris papers these days and you’ll notice an obsession with bobos: no, they’re not a team of cheerleaders or a troupe of clowns, but rich, artsy types known as bourgeois bohemians, who are now pretty much the tip of Parisian tastemakers. So when friends who were recently staying in Saint Germain des Pres asked me where to go to people watch, I told them to head for the Ninth Arrondissement — citadel of bobo cool.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 12, 2011
text: France and Britain urged NATO on Tuesday to intensify airstrikes against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces.

headline: A Farce With Two of a Kind
text: If you’re not having fun at “The Comedy of Errors,” just wait. After a muddled start, this production, by the Acting Company, catches fire, delivering more than enough laughs to make up for its early lapses.

headline: Dark Lessons in the Classroom
text: Just when you thought Broadway and especially Off Broadway was suffering from a surfeit of solo shows, along comes “The Promise,” by Douglas Maxwell, to redeem the format. Thank the stage veteran Joanna Tope; her performance in this production — brought to the 59E59 Theaters by the Random Accomplice company from Glasgow — infinitely enriches a 90-minute parable already loaded with dramatic heft.

headline: Why Is This Trial Happening?
text: The insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam has confused me in the same way that it has confused my colleague Andrew Ross Sorkin, who writes in his column today that he would not want to be Mr. Rajaratnam’s lawyer.

headline: The World’s 50 Best Restaurants? Says Who?
text: IF you had called for a reservation at the restaurant Noma in Copenhagen on Saturday, April 24, 2010, you could have dined there that night. By the time it next opened, the following Monday, you would have faced competition from 100,000 people to get a table. In the intervening 48 hours, Noma had won the top spot on the San Pellegrino World’s 50 Best Restaurants list.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Nom Wah Tea Parlor
text: BACK in the day, when Chinatown was just three mean streets, Doyers was the kink in it, a dogleg alley barely 200 yards long, its tenements riddled with fan-tan houses and opium dens, its cobbles sweating whiskey and camphor. The tongs went at it down there with hatchets and snickersnees, rival gangs of fallen men with names like Mock Duck and Girl Face.

headline: Gin and Passover: No Longer Contradictory
text: Except for matzo, anything that’s made with grain is prohibited during Passover. That means the usual spirits distilled from rye, corn or wheat are off limits.

headline: Wine Prices Slashed; This Offer Won’t Last
text: WHAT do you consider a bargain in wine? Ten percent off? Twenty? How about 40? That was the discount that Wines Til Sold Out offered recently on 2006 Chateau Angelus, a top Bordeaux that was being sold for nearly $100 off its original price of about $250.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Baskets for a Cause

headline: Wise for Some Restaurants, Coupons Are a Drain at Others
text: MARC MURPHY, who owns four restaurants in New York, gets pitched by salespeople all the time. But these days most of them seem to be selling the same thing: online deal ploys.

headline: Mark Kurlansky Imagines a World Without Fish
text: In his histories of cod and oysters, Mark Kurlansky described how those species once thrived in the wild, and how they were depleted. His latest book casts an even wider net and, with the help of superb illustrations and an interwoven graphic novel by Frank Stockton, creates a compelling narrative for young people and adults. “World Without Fish” details how humans are destroying ocean life and how that destruction will affect the entire planet. It urges readers to be responsible consumers of fish and avoid threatened species. “Beware of fish that is very inexpensive,” he adds. “Cheap fish has usually been caught in careless ways.” The book includes the Monterey Bay Aquarium’s Seafood Watch chart on seafood to eat or avoid.

headline: Coffee Cakes With Mother’s Touch
text: In New York, a coffee cake is synonymous with babka, but in the Midwest, it is defined by streusel. A good example is the moist, square cinnamon cake (at left) strewn with streusel and raisins that Dave Evans, a native of Indianapolis, is baking according to the recipe of his mother, Connie Evans. The streusel is on the top and the bottom of the cake. If you serve the cake upside-down and warmed, the topping becomes nicely caramelized. Mr. Evans is also baking and selling his mother’s mellow carrot cake, studded with chocolate chips and drizzled with chocolate.

headline: For Walcott, a Fast Track to Certification
text: It is full steam ahead for the certification of Dennis M. Walcott to be the next schools chancellor of New York City.

headline: In F.D.I.C.’s Proposal, Incentive for Excessive Risk Remains
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Light Practice Puts Serena Williams on the Road Back
text: It is still a long way back to Wimbledon and the circuit she once ruled, but Serena Williams announced her return to the practice court Tuesday by posting a photograph on Twitter of herself serving in a pink body suit.

headline: No Halt to Planned Parenthood Fight
text: House Republicans may have lost their battle against Planned Parenthood in the compromise with Democrats on a spending bill agreed to last Friday, but they will continue to fight the war.

headline: Family of Slain Giffords Aide Pushing Restrictions on Ammunition
text: TUCSON — Kelly O’Brien lost her fiancé, Gabe Zimmerman, on Jan. 8 when a gunman opened fire at a constituent event held by Representative Gabrielle Giffords. Ross Zimmerman lost his son. The two appeared at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday to support legislation banning large-capacity ammunition magazines like the one used in the killing of six people that day.

headline: Take ‘Friends’ to Chicago, Then Hit Fast-Forward
text: In the pre-Facebook era of “Friends,” the American television audience more or less rolled with the idea that a group of six men and women in their 20s would spend all of their time in one another’s company, confined to a single living room and a cloyingly named coffee bar. By the time we were well into the new millennium, we knew better. Or rather we understood that the only condition in which we might be having dinner with the same people all of the time was if we were sequestered with them on a bizarre island after a suspicious plane crash. And so we watched “Lost,” with its CliffsNotes philosophies and an implicitly grim view of structured socializing that seemed perfectly suited to the virtual age.

headline: Looking Down the Barrel of a Debate
text: Barbara Kopple’s engrossing, frustrating documentary “Gun Fight” — it’s not liable to inspire happy thoughts in people on either side of the gun-control debate — begins with eerie cellphone video footage taken during the Virginia Tech shootings in April 2007, and the aftermath of that rampage provides the film’s emotional ballast.

headline: Small Players Offer Smart Cards, but Not Big Banks
text: You may have read in this newspaper about some Americans having problems  using their credit or debit cards overseas because the cards rely on older “magnetic stripe” technology. Many countries are switching to more fraud-resistant cards that use tiny chips to conduct transactions.

headline: Age Before Beauty? Giggs Gives Manchester United Both
text: Ryan Giggs once again proved that there is often no match for the guile of age — even on a soccer field populated by expensive, mostly young talent.

headline: With Season Still Uncertain, N.F.L. Schedules Preseason
text: The N.F.L. announced its preseason schedule Tuesday — for games that might never be played.

headline: S.B.A. Spared in 2011 Spending Deal
text: While many federal agencies will take a haircut in the spending bill negotiated last weekend between Senate Democrats and House Republicans — total nonmilitary discretionary spending will be cut by 7 to 8 percent from 2010 levels — the Small Business Administration has emerged from the negotiations largely intact.

headline: 5-Year Deadline Sought for Ridding Schools of PCBs
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency and the New York City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, are both calling for replacing school light fixtures that are leaking PCBs in five years or less, putting more pressure on the Bloomberg administration to speed up its planned time line of 10 years.

headline: Why Is This Trial Happening?
text: Floyd Norris of The New York Times examines some big questions about the Galleon case: Why is Raj Rajaratnam fighting against what seem to be high odds in his insider trading trial? And what does he have to lose? Read more »

headline: Video Shows Syria Clash From Two Angles
text: As unrest reportedly continued in Syria on Tuesday, dramatic video posted on YouTube appeared to show an attack on protesters in the southern city of Dara’a on Friday, during clashes that left at least 21 people dead.

headline: Q. and A. With Mark Kurlansky
text: Mark Kurlansky has described the pleasures and problems of seafood in his books “Cod” and “The Big Oyster.”

headline: Taking Off the Pounds to Chase a Sun-Powered Victory
text: Just a few days ago, the newest and best hope in American solar car racing improbably rested atop four laundry baskets.

headline: U.S. Lagging in Using Technology, Study Shows
text: The United States continues to lag other nations in its use of computing and communications technology, according to an annual study issued Tuesday by the World Economic Forum.

headline: Redirecting Cisco by Cutting Sprawl
text: Cisco’s chief executive, John Chambers, acknowledged last week that the company he has run for 16 years had lost its way. Now he’s putting some money where his mouth is and shutting parts of the overextended networking company’s shrinking consumer business. That’s sensible as far it goes. More will be needed to simplify Cisco’s sprawl and improve shareholder returns.

headline: Abernathy Takes Lead in P.R. League Tables
text: While league table talk tends to revolve around the banks and law firms that put together deals, there’s another important class of advisers: the public relations firms who promote the selling of those mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Senators Propose New Online Privacy Law
text: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and Senator John McCain of Arizona on Tuesday made a bipartisan call for new legislation to protect consumer privacy on the Internet.

headline: A Pool Man in Chad, at the Intersection of the Personal and the Political
text: The title figure in “A Screaming Man” never screams or shouts. He rarely raises his voice above the pleasantly conversational and sometimes hardly speaks at all, though his silences can be telling. He works as a pool man in a modest hotel in Chad, where, during the day, he watches over splashing children and lazily sunbathing adults and not much else. Come dusk, he gathers together the wet towels that have been discarded on the chaises and cordons off the pool. His employer calls him by his given name, Adam (played by Youssouf Djaoro, a tall and cool drink of water), but everyone else calls him Champ, a title reflecting a past glory that he wears as proudly as his dazzlingly white uniform.

headline: Recipes for the Passover Table
text: Matzo ball soup, short ribs, macaroons and more holiday recipes from The Times.

headline: First Family of Writers Grows by One
text: WASHINGTON — In the fall of 2007, while helping her ambitious older half-brother, Barack Obama, campaign for president, Maya Soetoro-Ng holed up in the basement of the Obamas’ Chicago home to pursue a long-held ambition of her own: writing a children’s book.

headline: TimesCast | Season Opener in Japan
text: Ken Belson reports on Japan's baseball season opening after a three-week delay.

headline: What to Do With Your Flip Now
text: Cisco’s announcement on Tuesday that it would stop making its easy-to-use Flip video cameras leaves something like two and a half million buyers wondering, “What now?”

headline: Republicans Scramble for Votes to Pass Budget Bill
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans scurried on Tuesday to secure the votes needed for a bill that would keep the government financed for the rest of the fiscal year, delaying action by one day to abide by their self-imposed rule to air all legislation publicly for three days before a vote.

headline: At What Price Beauty? Check Today’s Deal
text: JASMINE CHESS had long wanted to try eyelash extensions, but the high cost had kept them off her beauty shopping list. Then Ms. Chess, 25, saw an offer to buy the service at a reduced rate ($225 instead of the usual $450) on Gilt City, an online portal that sells vouchers to fitness boutiques and spas (along with restaurants and other attractions).

headline: Grammy Chief Defends Award Cuts
text: The decision by the group that organizes the Grammy Awards to eliminate nearly one-third of the award categories, announced last week, is meeting resistance from musicians and record producers. They complain that the changes were done behind their backs, are meant to cater to the interests of television and major record labels and that they discriminate against ethnic minorities and performers of genres outside the mainstream.

headline: Mixed Martial Arts Makes Inroads in Baseball Training
text: Mixed martial arts may be illegal as a competitive sport in some states, but several baseball players are incorporating its fighting methods into their training routines.

headline: Fears About Immigrants Deepen Divisions in Europe
text: ROME — Since the global financial crisis, the European Union has been deeply divided over economic policy. With the Libya intervention, it has split over foreign policy. But today few issues are proving more divisive within the bloc than immigration.

headline: Too Much of a Sweeping View Nudges Barcelona to Shed a Law
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Each year since 2004, Jacint Ribas has taken out his bicycle in March, and wearing nothing more than his salt-and-pepper hair, has pedaled it through the streets of this port city. By now he reckons he has covered about 4,800 miles, opening the season for going undressed in public.

headline: Budget Deal Deeply Cuts High-Speed Rail Program
text: President Obama’s fledgling high-speed rail program was dealt a serious setback by the budget deal that he struck with Republicans last week: new details released Tuesday showed that the agreement will not only eliminate financing for high-speed rail this year, but will also take back some of the money that Congress approved for it last year.

headline: Tales of Lives Extinguished All Too Soon
text: “What can you say,” Erich Segal asked in the first sentence of “Love Story,” his cathartic heave of a novel, “about a 25-year-old girl who died?”

headline: Yesterday’s Shocks, Sounding Lyrical Today
text: When we go to a performance of a once-controversial work, we naturally want to hear what all the fuss was about. A “Rite of Spring,” say, is “good” if it conveys some sense of why that ballet incited a riot back in 1913 in Paris.

headline: TimesCast | Demanding More From NATO
text: April 12, 2011 — John F. Burns and Eric Schmitt report on pressure from Britain and France for NATO to intensify attacks.

headline: Ovechkin Scores Less, but Capitals Aspire to More
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — It seems an odd thing to ask whether Alex Ovechkin is mentally ready for the playoffs, but that question was put to Washington Coach Bruce Boudreau on Tuesday on the eve of the Capitals-Rangers first-round series.

headline: Ex-Governor Apologizes for Using Song in Ad
text: Some days Charlie Crist is an ally of rock stars, and some days he is their adversary.

headline: Piece of the Empire State Building Could Be Yours
text: People who have always wondered what it might be like to dabble in a little New York real estate may soon be able to dabble in a lot of it — by buying a piece of its most famous skyscraper, the Empire State Building.

headline: Sampling New Work One Step at a Time
text: The subway ride from Bed-Stuy to Harlem is a long one, giving a dance critic ample time to anticipate nervously the emerging choreographer (that ridiculous term) sampler waiting at the other end. Showcases are not for the faint of heart.

headline: Turning 150, but Youthful as Ever
text: Since its founding in 1861, the Yale Glee Club has become one of the best collegiate singing ensembles, and one of the most adventurous. This is the kind of glee club that has been conducted by Krzysztof Penderecki; it is to the television show “Glee” approximately what the Metropolitan Opera’s National Council Auditions are to “American Idol.”

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Is Prominent in Mets Picture
text: For weeks, Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire hedge fund manager, has been a mysterious figure in the drama of the Mets, and their financially and legally beleaguered owners.

headline: Banks Gaining a Foothold in the Still-Fragile Economy
text: Just two years after the financial panic reached its nadir, the nation’s biggest banks have regained their footing.

headline: Take My Alewife, Please
text: Thank you all for your many dozens of entries on our “What’s With the Fish?” photo-captioning contest.

headline: Impatience Over Recovery at Morgan Stanley
text: A year and a half into a campaign to rebuild Morgan Stanley, some shareholders are losing patience with James P. Gorman, the firm’s chief executive.

headline: Overseas Banks Could Face Novel Penalty From U.S.
text: Amid their widening investigation into banks suspected of facilitating offshore tax evasion by wealthy Americans, the federal authorities are contemplating a novel punishment: a severe monetary penalty normally reserved for individual Americans.

headline: Rescuing ‘Ghost’ Brands From Grocery Limbo
text: What does Kraft Foods have in common with Dan Aykroyd, Ernie Hudson, Bill Murray and Harold Ramis? They are all ghostbusters.

headline: Rules for Mortgage Servicers Are Criticized as Ineffective
text: Hopes back in January that the troubled foreclosure process could be fixed with decisive and simple actions have disappeared with the ice and slush.

headline: Cinecittà: Rome’s Fabled Film Studio
text: Photographs of the Italian film studio where for generations some of the most memorable scenes in motion picture history were shot.

headline: Maryland: Bill Giving Tuition Breaks to Immigrants Is Sent to Governor
text: The General Assembly has approved legislation to grant in-state tuition to students who are illegal immigrants, opening new possibilities to them as other states consider legislation to restrict the rights of illegal immigrants. The bill would grant in-state tuition to students in four-year universities who had first graduated from high school in Maryland and then attended a community college for two years. They must also show that they or their parents have filed Maryland tax returns for all of those years. Gov. Martin O’Malley, a Democrat, is expected to sign the bill into law this month, making Maryland the 12th state to have such a provision, according to Casa de Maryland, an advocacy group for Hispanics.

headline: Murphy Returns to the Lineup, but the Mets Are Rained Out
text: Two starts in a row do not a regular job make, but Daniel Murphy was sure pleased to see his name on the Mets’ lineup card Tuesday for the second straight day. After delivering a few good at-bats and a couple of defensive gems in Monday night’s loss to the Rockies, Murphy was scheduled to play second base and bat No. 2 before Tuesday’s game at Citi Field was postponed because of rain.

headline: A New South City Looks to a Future Not Built on Banking
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Just a few years ago, this city had placed all its eggs in the banking basket, becoming a regional powerhouse and a symbol of the New South after a series of mergers and acquisitions that resulted in the financial titans Bank of America and Wachovia.

headline: Salvador Assael, 88, Dies; Coaxed Riches From Pearls
text: Salvador Assael, a titan of the cultured pearl business whose wares were prized for their size, hue and luminosity, died on April 1 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Group Faults the F.D.A. on Oversight of Devices
text: The Food and Drug Administration is allowing some high-risk devices like artificial hips to be sold without strenuous testing, despite promises that it would address regulatory issues affecting them, a federal watchdog group plans to testify on Wednesday.

headline: Diplomatic Breakdown Amid Bieber Fever in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The teenage pop idol Justin Bieber became embroiled in a diplomatic imbroglio on Tuesday when it emerged that plans for a meeting between the singer and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had been called off, with the sides differing over why.

headline: How to Save a Trillion Dollars
text: In the scheme of things, saving the 38 billion bucks that Congress seems poised to agree upon is not a big deal. A big deal is saving a trillion bucks. And we could do that by preventing disease instead of treating it.

headline: High Prices Sow Seeds of Erosion
text: When prices for corn and soybeans surged last fall, Bill Hammitt, a farmer in the fertile hill country of western Iowa, began to see the bulldozers come out, clearing steep hillsides of trees and pastureland to make way for more acres of the state’s staple crops. Now, as spring planting begins, with the chance of drenching rains, Mr. Hammitt worries that such steep ground is at high risk for soil erosion — a farmland scourge that feels as distant to most Americans as tales of the Dust Bowl and Woody Guthrie ballads.

headline: Syria Presses Crackdown in Two Cities on Coast
text: CAIRO — The security crackdown on Syria’s coastal region tightened on Tuesday, with checkpoints blocking off access to the city of Baniyas and its outlying areas and a violent raid by government security forces on the nearby village of Bayda, local human rights advocates said.

headline: Schneider Electric of France Begins Talks With Tyco
text: 9:32 p.m. | Updated  A French conglomerate, Schneider Electric, has begun takeover talks with Tyco International about a potential deal, according to people briefed on the matter, in what could be one of the biggest deals this year.

headline: Stravinsky Invades Mozart’s Turf
text: Mostly Mozart this summer will present a mini-series devoted to Stravinsky, as well as Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” with Ivan Fischer conducting the Budapest Festival Orchestra and Handel’s “Orlando” performed by the Philharmonic Baroque Orchestra under Nicholas McGegan, Lincoln Center said on Tuesday. The festival, which over the course of its 45 years has often featured composers not named Mozart, is planning nine events that somehow involve Stravinsky — a film program, concerts of his music, performances of works he inspired and a rendition of his “Renard” by the Mark Morris Dance Group. The International Contemporary Ensemble, a group of about 30 musicians based in Brooklyn and a rising presence on the new music scene, will have a prominent role in the festival, which will run from Aug. 2 to 27.

headline: 13 Former Campers Echo Senator Scott Brown’s Claim of Abuse
text: BOSTON — Thirteen alumni of a Cape Cod summer camp have reported being sexually abused there decades ago since Senator Scott P. Brown revealed that he was groped by a counselor there as a child, a lawyer said Tuesday.

headline: Reshaping Medicare Brings Hard Choices
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has deep disagreements with House Republicans about how to address Medicare’s long-term problems. But in deciding to wade into the fight over entitlements, which he may address in a speech Wednesday afternoon, the president is signaling that he too believes Medicare must change to avert a potentially crippling fiscal crunch.

headline: For Flushing and Its Waterfront, Time to Think Big
text: Flushing, Queens, home to one of the largest Asian populations in the United States, is one of the most crowded downtown areas in New York City. The Flushing Main Street stop on the No. 7 subway line was the busiest station outside of Manhattan in 2009, and 19 city bus lines stop downtown, where more than 40,000 people reside.

headline: Charles Laufer, Founder of Tiger Beat, Dies at 87
text: Charles Laufer, who as a high school teacher in 1955 despaired that his students had nothing entertaining to read and responded with magazines aimed at teenage girls desperate to know much, much more about the lives of their favorite cute stars, died April 5 in Northridge, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Bad X-Rays Found Again at a Brooklyn Hospital
text: Long after a major Brooklyn hospital said it had stopped over-radiating premature babies, state inspectors have found that some inappropriate X-rays were still being administered as recently as January, state records show.

headline: Suspected Point-Shaving Scheme Shows Gambling Remains Persistent Issue
text: For all of the suspensions, fines and N.C.A.A. investigations in the past year in college sports, few have posed a threat to the integrity of the games themselves like Monday’s announcement that two former University of San Diego basketball players and a former assistant  were among 10 people indicted in a point-shaving scheme.

headline: Social Security and Those Who Need It
Jury to Continue Deliberating in Bonds Perjury Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The jury in Barry Bonds’s perjury trial finished its third day of deliberations Tuesday, leaving the courthouse without giving any hints to which way it was leaning.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,437 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: ‘The Long Goodbye’
text: Chapter One: Love

headline: The Erratic Knicks Take the Playoff Stage
text: No matter how promising or miserable the Knicks have looked, the ultimate expectation has been that they would make the playoffs and probably lose in the first round. The Knicks have indeed made the playoffs, and they will be a heavy underdog when they play the defending Eastern Conference champion Boston Celtics in the first round.

headline: In Role as Teacher, Showalter Remains Student of Game
text: Buck Showalter was excited to be playing his first professional game in June 1977. He kept taking in all the sights at Bobby Maduro Stadium in Miami — including the strange half-field tucked alongside left field, the position he was patrolling.

headline: Suit Alleges Bias in Disability Denials by Queens Judges
text: The Queens office that hears appeals of Social Security disability cases is well known to lawyers, judges and many other New Yorkers as an inhospitable place to seek benefits.

headline: Imagining the End of the Bush Tax Cuts
text: My column this week examines the political challenge at the center of the deficit debate: the mismatch between the government services that voters want and the taxes that they are willing to pay. I suggest that a deadlock over the Bush tax cuts — expiring on Dec. 31, 2012, as prescribed by current law — may be one of the most plausible medium-term solutions.

headline: A New Catholic Mass: More Than Language at Issue
text: To the Editor:

headline: A High Cost, to Little Effect, for a Window Into the Mob
text: One day, after a bad couple of hours in court, the mob boss Joseph C. Massino turned to the marshals escorting him to a cell.

headline: The Sex Discrimination Lawsuit Against Wal-Mart
text: To the Editor:

headline: City Postpones Hiring 540 Police Recruits
text: The Bloomberg administration, laboring under continued budget troubles, said Tuesday that it was shelving plans to hire a 540-candidate Police Academy class that was to be sworn in this month, city officials said.

headline: Defense Keeps Its Focus on Galleon’s Research
text: Louis Lanzano/Bloomberg NewsRichard Schutte, former Galleon president, arriving at court on Tuesday.

headline: Lobbyists Won Key Concessions in Budget Deal
text: WASHINGTON — At a quarter till midnight last Friday, with a deal to avert a government shutdown barely an hour old, Senator Harry Reid phoned a fellow Democratic senator, Ron Wyden, at home and startled him with some bad news. “You lost free-choice vouchers,” Mr. Wyden recalls Mr. Reid telling him.

headline: Pace of Attacks in Libya Conflict Is Dividing NATO
text: WASHINGTON — With the United States limiting itself to a supporting role in the conflict in Libya, fissures opened among NATO allies on Tuesday over the scope and intensity of attacks against the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, officials here and in Europe said.

headline: Libyan Rebels Set to Talk, but Maybe Not With Qaddafi’s Ex-Ally
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Rebel leaders here said Tuesday that they were not ready to commit to talks with Moussa Koussa, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s former confidant who defected to Britain but left there for Qatar.

headline: Knicks and Celtics Renew Playoff Rivalry
text: Earlier this season, Boston’s Paul Pierce quickly and confidently dismissed any notion of a rivalry between his team and the Knicks. Pierce has been a Celtic his whole career, since 1998, and not once during that period had the two teams met in the postseason, when the stakes are higher and rivalries are born.

headline: Mixed Martial Arts: A Relatively Benign Sport?
State Liquor Laws: An Industry Response
‘How Manhattan Drum-Taps Led’
text: On the evening of April 12, 1861, Walt Whitman attended a performance of Gaetano Donizetti’s opera “Linda di Chamounix” at the Academy of Music, on 14th Street and Irving Place in Manhattan. Just before midnight he was walking down the west side of Broadway, toward the Fulton Ferry to return to his home, in Brooklyn. Suddenly, he later recalled, he “heard in the distance the loud cries of the newsboys, who came presently tearing and yelling up the street, rushing from side to side more furiously than usual.”

headline: Do-Nothing Congress as a Cure
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Art and Truth
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preseason Scheduled Despite Lockout
text: The N.F.L. announced its preseason schedule — for games that may never be played. With court proceedings and labor negotiations expected to last into the summer, training camp and the preseason could be wiped out unless the courts rule that the N.F.L. has to lift the lockout and begin the league year.

headline: Japan’s Reactors Still ‘Not Stable,’ U.S. Regulator Says
text: WASHINGTON — The condition of the damaged Fukushima Daiichi reactors in Japan is “static,” but with improvised cooling efforts they are “not stable,” the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a Senate committee on Tuesday.

headline: Pray. Hope. Prepare.
text: When I was in Cairo during the Egyptian uprising, I wanted to change hotels one day to be closer to the action and called the Marriott to see if it had any openings. The young-sounding Egyptian woman who spoke with me from the reservations department offered me a room and then asked: “Do you have a corporate rate?” I said, “I don’t know. I work for The New York Times.” There was a silence on the phone for a few moments, and then she said: “ Can I ask you something?” Sure. “Are we going to be O.K.? I’m worried.”

headline: Despite Poor Race, Uncle Mo Seems Fine
text: Uncle Mo is healthy despite his lackluster third-place finish in the Wood Memorial on Saturday. The colt’s owner and trainer are still mystified about why he suffered his first defeat in his final prep race before the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 12, 2011

headline: Giving Doctors Orders
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Spending Fallout Weakens Canada’s Prime Minister
text: OTTAWA — The two summit meetings of world leaders hosted by Canada last June might have enhanced Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s image as a world leader and bolstered his re-election prospects this year. Instead, the political fallout over the billion-dollar cost and how some of the spending benefited one of his allies threatens to undermine his campaign.

headline: Wednesday: Something to Reflect On
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This couldn’t have been an easy theme to polish up for publication, and leave it to Liz Gorski to succeed with it. I’m going to explain it here, so please avert your eyes if you do not want the theme spoiled for you.

headline: From Amphitheater Bit Player to God’s Errand Boy
text: David Greenspan plays a demon sent spinning through time on a mission of salvation in “Go Back to Where You Are,” his endearingly daffy new play at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Playwrights Horizons. This particular demon was originally a failed actor from ancient Greece named Passalus, and on his sojourn in the 21st century he finds it useful to transform himself into a genteel British matron and former actress named Constance Simmons. All of this whimsy means that Mr. Greenspan the playwright has concocted a honey of a part for Mr. Greenspan the actor, one that allows him to deploy multiple voices and display multiple facets of his baroque, androgynous stage persona.

headline: As the Mountaintops Fall, a Coal Town Vanishes
text: LINDYTOWN, W.Va.

headline: China: Monastery Sealed Off After Suicide Protest
text: Security officers have placed an important Tibetan monastery in Sichuan Province under lockdown after a young monk committed suicide by setting himself on fire on March 16 to protest Chinese policies in Tibetan areas, according to a report released late Monday by a Tibet advocacy group based outside China. The monastery, Kirti, is one of the most important centers of learning in the region. The report by the group, the International Campaign for Tibet, which has a network of contacts inside Tibetan areas, said that a barbed wire fence was being built behind the monastery, and that armed security officers inside the compound were preventing monks from leaving and food from being delivered.

headline: State Senator and 7 Others Plead Not Guilty to Corruption
text: State Senator Carl Kruger and seven other defendants pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to corruption charges in what federal prosecutors described as a “broad-based bribery racket.”

headline: $6.5 Million Settlement in Wrongful Conviction
text: Jeffrey Deskovic spent half of his life in prison for a rape and murder he did not commit, but it was only this week, four and a half years after his release, that he received some measure of justice: a $6.5 million settlement with Westchester County on a federal civil-rights lawsuit stemming from his wrongful conviction.

headline: Afghanistan: Envoy in Building as Bullet Hits Window
text: A bullet struck a window of the building in Kabul where the European Union’s ambassador to Afghanistan, Vygaudas Usackas, was working Tuesday. No one was injured, and although the bullet left a mark, it did not penetrate the window. European Union officials said they were not sure if the shot was intentional. An investigation is under way, according to a statement from a spokeswoman for the European Union that said the window was bulletproof.

headline: 4 Die in Smuggling Tunnel Under Gaza-Egypt Border
text: Four Palestinians died Tuesday in a smuggling tunnel beneath the Gaza-Egypt border, according to medics in Gaza. Authorities with Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, said the men suffocated while repairing the tunnel, which they said had been hit by an Israeli missile several days ago during a recent wave of violence. Some people have died in the tunnels in the past after being overcome by fumes while smuggling fuel to Gaza.

headline: Russia: Moscow Man Sought in Judge’s Killing
text: State investigators on Tuesday said the police were seeking to detain a 28-year-old Moscow man in the killing of Eduard Chuvashov, a judge who was despised by skinhead groups for his tough sentences in ethnic killings. Mr. Chuvashov was shot in the stairwell outside his apartment one year ago, after extremist Web sites called for his death. The suspect, Aleksei Korshunov, is in hiding, the Investigative Committee said Tuesday. Mr. Korshunov is believed to be a member of a neo-Nazi group called United Brigade-88, and may also be linked to the killing of a young reporter and a human rights lawyer who were shot as they left a news conference in January 2009, according to the Sova Center, a research group that tracks hate crimes.

headline: A Distinctive American Voice, Ever Yearning for Home Sweet Home

Along with “Home on the Range,” “Red River Valley” and Stephen Foster ballads, they seem somehow to have always existed.

headline: Urban Realist With a Humanist Streak
text: THE half-dozen great or almost-great New York movies Sidney Lumet directed from the late 1950s to the early ’80s — for the sake of argument, let’s specify “12 Angry Men” (1957), “The Pawnbroker” (1964), “Serpico” (1973), “Dog Day Afternoon” (1975), “Network” (1976) and “Prince of the City” (1981) — are hardly period pieces. But nowadays it is almost impossible not to look at them that way. These movies are such vivid time capsules of urban life and cinematic style that it can seem as if they must have been intended as such.

headline: Is Paul Ryan’s Budget Brave?
text: In the week since Paul Ryan’s budget proposal hit Washington, there’s been significant liberal pushback against the idea that Ryan and the rest of the House Republican leadership deserve to be called “serious” or “brave.” If Ryan and Co. were actually courageous, the liberal argument goes, they would have proposed raising taxes, or demanded Medicare cuts for current seniors, or otherwise taken on more conservative shibboleths and right-leaning interest groups. Political bravery, in this view, requires more than just proposing a more rigorous version of your own faction’s usual proposals. It requires breaking out of the partisan box completely, and risking the ire of your own side’s ideologues as well as the wrath of your political opponents.

headline: Asked and Answered | Ginevra Elkann
text: Ginevra Elkann is a filmmaker who is also the vice president of the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli, an art gallery in Turin, Italy. (The Agnellis were Elkann’s maternal grandparents.) And, as if she didn’t have enough on her plate, Elkann has edited a book called “May I Introduce You?: A Guide to Creative Talents,” which includes interviews with 25 innovators in fields including design (the architect Bjarke Ingels), fashion (Christian Louboutin; Carol Lim and Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony),  business (Henri Seydoux of the wireless device maker Parrot; Yoox’s Federico Marchetti), art (Pablo Bronstein) and journalism (Aatish Taseer). Sponsored by Stefanel and published by Electa, the book makes its debut Wednesday in Milan. Last week, Elkann took a few minutes to talk with T.

headline: Lucerne, a Wagner City, Engages in Yearlong Affair With Brahms
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — Lucerne is having a yearlong affair with Brahms. Through the various parts of the Lucerne Festival, Bernard Haitink has been conducting the Chamber Orchestra of Europe in a comprehensive Brahms cycle. During the piano festival in November, they presented the two piano concertos (with Emanuel Ax as soloist) and the two serenades. In the current Easter festival, they performed the second of three programs on Monday evening, and they offer the third on Wednesday. In the summer festival, in August, they will add two final concerts amid a smattering of Brahms performed by others (Claudio Abbado and the Lucerne Festival Orchestra, Christian Thielemann and the Dresden Staatskapelle).

headline: Samurai Shopper | Oil Gusher
text: A number of conventional beliefs simply don’t fly, like: political elections equal democracy, or you can’t time the stock market. Superstitions involving black cats are easily discredited, but still die hard. (If you step on a crack, you probably won’t break your mother’s back.) Then there’s fortune cookie-esque wisdom: a stitch in time saves nine, I guarantee it.  But slow and steady doesn’t necessarily win the race, especially if steroids are involved.

headline: Shining Strobe Lights on the City’s Dark Corners
The Gingrich State of Mind
text: With all the talk last week of a possible government shutdown and the ongoing chatter about which Republicans will decide to run for president in 2012, I was pleased to come across this Esquire profile from last summer of Newt Gingrich. What makes this piece compelling is the voice of Marianne Gingrich, Newt’s second wife (he left his first wife for her — going to the hospital where No. 1 was recovering from uterine cancer to bring her divorce terms). He has since left Marianne too — after an affair with his Congressional aide Callista Bisek, she became No. 3.

headline: Smoked Salmon Any Way You Slice It
text: In common usage, the terms “smoked salmon” and “lox” are pretty much used interchangeably, which is how I use them when I wrote about my matzo brei variation on lox, eggs and onions. Both refer to salmon that is cured and tastes good on a bagel. In fact, the word lox is probably derived from the Yiddish and German words for salmon, lachs (or laks).

headline: Asked and Answered | Zeina Durra
text: In Zeina Durra’s feature-length film debut, “The Imperialists Are Still Alive!” which opens in New York on Friday, the British director depicts the paranoid post-9/11 life of Arabs in New York City through the stories of a group of affluent but troubled Middle Eastern émigrés. Durra, a 34-year-old Londoner who studied film at New York University, says her own cultural influences — she’s of mixed Middle Eastern and Bosnian descent — inspired the film’s protagonist, Asya. Asya (played by the French actress Élodie Bouchez) is a downtown artist who has lumped together her Palestinian, Bosnian, Jordanian, Lebanese and Parisian heritages into some familiar Manhattan mystique.

Ms. Meara played the loud-mouthed Bunny Flingus, and Bunny’s fake fur coat was the boy’s earliest cue that this grown-up thing called work could include imaginary worlds and garish get-ups (see Zoolander, Derek).

headline: Thoughtless or Careless
text: Are bullies amoral or are they simply cruel? That is to say, do they bully others because they don’t know the difference between right and wrong, or simply because they don’t care about other people’s feelings? Gianluca Gini, Tiziana Pozzoli and Marc Hauser studied this question for the Journal Personality and Individual Differences. They studied 719 children between the ages of 9 and 13 and found that those who engaged in bullying had advanced moral competence. They could make sophisticated distinctions between moral and immoral conduct. They scored low on measures of compassion, though. This reinforces a growing body of research that suggests knowing right from wrong is not necessarily connected to behaving rightly or wrongly. Moral lectures don’t work well, but telling people stories designed to arouse compassion might.

headline: A Curmudgeon’s View of the Energy Challenge
text: One of the world’s great minds on issues of energy use, food production and the connection between them is a fellow named Vaclav Smil, of the University of Manitoba. Bill Gates reads him. He is No. 49 on Foreign Policy magazine’s list of the top 100 global thinkers. He is often a curmudgeon, but our editorial colleague Andrew Revkin recently pitted him against the environmental advocate Lester Brown on questions of future food supply, with Dr. Smil playing the optimist that time.

headline: Bomber Strikes at Meeting of Afghan Elders
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber on foot detonated his explosives on Wednesday as tribal elders left a meeting in a remote mountain village in eastern Afghanistan, killing one of the most senior local figures and 11 other people, including 5 schoolboys.

headline: Substance Abuse in Black and White
text: Anastasia Vogt Yuan studied substance abuse among blacks and whites. In the journal Sociological Spectrum, she reports that blacks have lower rates of drug use than whites during early adolescence, but this gap gets inverted as they age. That is to say, whites are more likely to age out of drug use—they stop as they get older. Blacks, perhaps because of work, economic and family conditions, age out less, so by middle age they are using drugs more than whites. This would seem to put a dent in the theory that blacks suffer higher rates of drug use because they are more likely to grow up in single parent homes. If that were true, you’d see the effects in early adolescence. The evidence would seem to point to broader social influences.

headline: Permira to Buy BakerCorp for $960 Million
text: Permira agreed on Wednesday to buy BakerCorp, which rents out pump, containment and filtration equipment to industrial customers, for $960 million.

headline: Songs About Myself
text: This result isn’t surprising or controversial, but it’s nice to have somebody rigorously confirm an impression many of us have formed. In an upcoming essay for the journal, Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity and the Arts, Nathan DeWall and others studied pop music lyrics between 1980 and 2007. They found that over these years lyrics that refer to self-focus and antisocial behavior have increased whereas words related to other-focus, social interactions and positive emotions have decreased. We’ve gone from “Love, Love, Love” to “F.U.”

headline: The Basics of Autism
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that one in 110 children in the United States has an autism spectrum disorder. There are no medical tests to diagnose autism. Therefore, it is critical that a child be given a developmental screening — as well as an screening for autism spectrum disorders — at specific ages during well-child doctor visits. Here are five things experts advise every parent should know about autism.

headline: Audi Pulls the Wraps Off Its New Q3
text: The official introduction of Audi’s new Q3 compact S.U.V. will take place next week at the Shanghai Auto Show. But subscribing to a practice that seems to be the new industry standard, Audi jumped the gun on Wednesday and released photos and substantial details.

headline: The 3 Biggest Tax Breaks — and What They Cost Us
text: If there is one big-ticket budget item on which Democrats and Republicans should be able to find common ground, it’s tax breaks. Each of the various bipartisan deficit panels has called for a big reduction, saying such breaks — exemptions, deductions, credits and other loopholes — are inefficient and unaffordable. All told, they cost the federal government about $1.2 trillion in lost revenue last year. As it happens, the budget deficit was $1.3 trillion.

headline: Republicans Against Cost Control
text: Many people are noting this CNN poll, which shows an overwhelming sentiment that Gallup describes as “don’t mess with Medicare”. What I find especially interesting isn’t just the fact that Republicans share that sentiment; it’s the fact that they are far more likely than Democrats to oppose any effort to control costs.

headline: Part 4: Answers to Readers’ Decision-Time Questions
text: All this week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

headline: Chinese Chess Phenom, After a Stumble, Roars Back
text: As China has climbed the ranks of the world’s chess powers (reaching No. 3 in the latest rankings), several of its players have also risen among the world’s elite. Currently, Wang Yue is No. 14 and Wang Hao is No. 20. Bu Xiangzhi, No. 63, was No. 26 as recently as October 2008.

headline: What to Ask About Autism
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening and, because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Lapel Invader
text: During the recent New York fashion shows, the blogger Hanneli Mustaparta posted a snapshot of Andreea Diaconu wearing a panda bear brooch that looked like a relic from the Atari age. After numerous Google searches (no luck), inquisitive e-mails (no luck) and one (lucky) Facebook search, we found the maker of the pin: 19-year-old Taj Melendez in Brooklyn, New York. “During art class in elementary school, we would do projects like these with perler beads,” says Melendez, who, like Space Invader, the street artist with a similar aesthetic, seems to shy away from attention rather than seek it out. He made his first pin, a replica of the men’s restroom icon, when he was 16. “I just wanted to start something, I wanted to stand out.” He sells his designs — bow ties, barrettes and an assortment of brooches like a thought bubble or a football — through his Web site ($55 to $75; go to bytaj.com). “I want to keep them special — that’s why I don’t create too many too fast.” When asked how Diaconu got her hands on that darling panda face, he shrugs with disbelief. “I have no idea,” he says. “But I sure was happy.”

headline: Teeing Off for Japan
text: The crisis in Japan, this coming weekend’s Health and Wellness Issue of the magazine and the singer Anne Murray: it sounds like a setup for one of Johnny Carson’s Karnak the Magnificent what-do-these-three-have-in-common? gags. But let’s take it two at a time. Murray, the Canadian “snowbird” who had a boatload of hits in the ’70s and ’80s, is one of many EMI artists taking part in a charity auction to help victims of the earthquake/tsunami/nuclear devastation in Japan. David Bowie is offering 35 signed albums, Norah Jones a signed guitar. What’s Murray’s contribution? Eighteen holes of golf with her at the Angus Glen Golf Club in Ontario.

headline: Bar Ice With a Pedigree
text: Anyone who has patronized Dutch Kills, the cocktail bar in Long Island City, Queens, has probably noticed the showy supporting role ice plays in its drinks. Long frozen spears skewer highballs.

headline: BP Scrambles to Salvage Rosneft Deal as a Deadline Nears
text: LONDON — BP struggled Wednesday to salvage its deal with the Russian oil company Rosneft before a deadline to complete the pact expired on Thursday.

headline: Webber to the Kings’ Rescue?
text: Things are looking dark in Sacramento, even for the most die-hard fans who hope the Kings will not move to Anaheim. Sacramento’s mayor and former N.B.A. player Kevin Johnson has likened the situation to a “slow death.”But could there be a last minute ray of hope, from an unexpected source? Former Kings All-Star Chris Webber, now an analyst for TNT, has indicated a willingness to invest in the team to keep it in Sacramento, according to the Sacramento Bee.

headline: When the Subject Owns the Image
text: Andrea Morales was born in Lima, Peru, and raised in Miami. She studied journalism at the University of Florida before pursuing a master’s degree at the Ohio University School of Visual Communication. In June, Ms. Morales will move to New York to intern in the photo department at The New York Times. Ms. Morales is the second of three summer photo interns to be featured on Turning Point.

headline: Advice From a Sticky Web Site on How to Make Yours the Same

headline: In Spain, a Home Nestles Into the Environment
text: VACARISSES, Spain — In fleeing urban life, Francesc Ortega and María Farriol took a leap of faith. They bought a mountain plot unmatched in its awesome views, but with a 45 degree slope, before checking if building a house there was even possible.

headline: A.I.G. Hires Morgan Stanley Banker as Internal Deal Maker
text: The American International Group announced on Wednesday that it had hired Peter Juhas from Morgan Stanley as its head of strategic planning.

headline: With Autism, One Size Doesn’t Fit All
text: David G. Amaral is the director of research at the M.I.N.D. institute at the University of California, Davis, and the principal investigator of the Autism Phenome Project, an early-phase research study comparing children ages 2 to 3 1/2 who have autism with their peers. The goal is to distinguish different types of autism based on extensive medical exams, gene and blood tests, immune measures, M.R.I. brain scans and other biomedical and behavioral markers. The researchers have recruited just over 300 families for the study and are recruiting additional volunteers.

headline: Have You Hired a Web Marketing Specialist?
text: In a small-business conversation we’ve just posted, Adriana Gardella asks Jay Bean, owner of a fast-growing Web marketing firm, what mistakes he sees small-business owners making in their marketing efforts. Mr. Bean, who has made his own mistakes as a small retailer, had this to say: “One is that, because one-third of mobile searches have local intent, a small business that doesn’t consider mobile will miss the boat. More generally, business owners spend more time building their businesses, and less on what they don’t understand, like Internet marketing. Small businesses think they can do it alone, but they can’t.”

headline: Selected Studies: Autism
text: Government agencies, universities, physicians and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Report Criticizes Banks for Handling of Mortgages
text: Banks did a poor job of handling the flood of foreclosures over the last several years, in some cases even moving ahead with evictions when they clearly should not have, according to a long-awaited report released Wednesday by federal regulators.

headline: Obama’s Debt Plan Sets Stage for Long Battle Over Spending

headline: Tender Bow Ties

The richly illustrated “Seeing Gertrude Stein” (University of California Press, $45), paired with a show coming to the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco, amounts to a visual history of the writer and art patron. It collects many of the sculptures and paintings she sat for, including that Picasso, along with her bohemian fashion statements: the vests, the brooches, even a custom Balmain frock.

text: The trainer Rick Dutrow was denied a racing license in Kentucky on Wednesday and cannot start horses in the state for the rest of the year.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Boosts CBS on Tuesday
text: “NCIS” delivered the largest audience in prime time on Tuesday as the procedural drama lifted CBS to No. 1 for the night even as the network trailed slightly during the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for “NCIS” on CBS; during the 9 p.m. hour, that network’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.3 million) finished just slightly behind ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.5 million). At 10,“Body of Proof” (11.3 million) on ABC edged “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.9 million). ABC placed second for the night, lagging behind at 8 with the second season premiere of “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” (5.3 million). NBC ranked third, averaging 7.2 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10, followed by “Parenthood” (5.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth among the networks with mostly reruns.

headline: Fear the Bond Market
text: James Carville famously said that if reincarnated, he’d like to come back as the bond market, since “you can intimidate everybody.”

headline: Finding (and Funding) an Internship for Junior
text: Britain’s Deputy Prime Minister, Nick Clegg, began his political career decades ago with an internship at a Finnish bank. He nabbed the slot with the help of his father — and now he is arguing that such “ins” should be banned (or, at least, sharply curbed).

headline: The Budget Speech
text: Style: I liked the way Obama made a case for government at the beginning. I liked the way he accused Republicans of pessimism, of abandoning a hopeful vision of America. Good that he went after the Ryan plan — and good that he went after the cruelty of that plan. If you ask me, too many percentages. Oh, and whichever speechwriter came up with “win the future” should be sent to count yurts in Outer Mongolia.

headline: Inside Obama’s Half-Sister’s Children’s Book
text: Barack Obama may be a polarizing figure on the grownup shelves at bookstores. But in the children’s books section, the president, first lady, the Obama girls and now, with the release of her first picture book, his half-sister, are greeted with near universal accolades and adoration. “Of Thee I Sing,” President Obama’s own picture book contribution, has already spent 20 weeks on our best-seller list.

headline: The Largest Tax Breaks for Individuals
text: The economist Eric Toder has pointed out that the largest corporate tax loopholes also happen to be among the most politically popular. They include the tax breaks for new machinery and for research and development. The policies don’t seem like corporate giveaways — though, to some extent, they are — as much as they seem like efforts to create jobs.

headline: Fed Report Notes That Economy Continues to Improve
text: Economic activity in the United States continued to improve over the last month, helped by the manufacturing and retail sectors, but the disaster in Japan and higher energy prices created new uncertainty about the outlook, according to a survey of the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts released on Wednesday.

headline: Light Headed
text: Baby-blonde hair may be all the rage, but it’s not for everyone. According to Marie Robinson, who counts Emma Stone, Naomi Watts and Michelle Williams among her pale-tressed clients, “It works best on women who are at least halfway there to begin with, and they need touch-ups every four weeks.” That said, its brightening effect on the skin is well worth the effort. “It’s rejuvenating,” says Chelsey Pickthorn, the Orlo Salon colorist who coaxed the model Abbey Lee Kershaw’s locks to the perfect platinum. “But you really need to assess the hair’s condition before starting and then proceed slowly, with great care.”

headline: A Mannequin in Every Sense
text: LITTLE more than a year ago, during a small posthumous presentation of the collection Alexander McQueen had been designing in the days just before he killed himself, Polina Kasina, one of his favorite models, appeared in a form-fitting coat made of thousands of gold-painted duck feathers, worn over a full white skirt embroidered with gold threads. It was the final look of what would be Mr. McQueen’s final show.

headline: New York Landmarks Panel Wants Changes in Plan for Former Bank
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has sent the owner of the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust building back to the drawing board yet again to revise its renovation plans for the interior of the building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street. The interior was designated a landmark in February; the exterior has had that status since 1997.

headline: ‘Anything Goes’ Extends Into 2012
text: Broadway’s revival of “Anything Goes” won’t be going anywhere any time soon. On Wednesday, Roundabout Theater Company announced that its production of that Cole Porter musical, starring Sutton Foster as the evangelizing nightclub singer Reno Sweeney and Joel Grey as the milquetoast gangster Moonface Martin, will extend its run by about six months. The revival, directed and choreographed by Kathleen Marshall, is now planned to play at the Stephen Sondheim Theater through January 8; it was originally scheduled to close after July 31. (That’s roughly 184 more performances of cruise-ship based musical farce, so let’s hope everyone packed some additional swim trunks.) Reviewing this production of “Anything Goes” for The New York Times, Ben Brantley wrote that it “exudes the effervescence of a freshly poured gin fizz,” adding that when Ms. Foster “turns her toothy, triumphant smile on the audience there’s no doubt that she’s made many converts.”

headline: The Price of Perception
text: RECENTLY, I joined friends at a lunch table where a lively discussion of college tuition was in progress. The question at hand was a chestnut: why does college cost so much, and why does the cost grow so alarmingly year after year? I interrupted my lunch mates. They — and most of the public — misconstrue the issue. They are really asking why the price of tuition is so high.

headline: Top 10 List: Where the Jobs Are
text: Looming worker shortage. That’s not a phrase one expects to hear at a time of high unemployment. But when experts look at the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ list of the fastest-growing occupations, that’s what they see: more than a million new jobs on the horizon by 2018, and a worker pool that may not be trained to fill them.

headline: Libya’s Revolution
text: Graffiti have been the elemental memes of political speech, from the walls of Pompeii to the New York subways to the Berlin Wall, in all the oppressed countries of this world. So it is all the more surprising that the epithet hurled by the Libyan “freedom fighters” to their former leader, and which graces the outer walls of the Benghazi Katiba in the photograph by Franco Pagetti that opens Robert F. Worth’s article, reads “el-Qaddafi walad al-Yahudiya,” or “Qaddafi, born Jewish.” In other words, Qaddafi the non-Muslim, the unclean. For a country that aspires to be democratic, old habits certainly die hard. It is a useful indication of the care to be taken in assuming that the so-called Arab Spring is a time of revolutionary social renewal.

headline: Montreux Jazz Festival Announces Lineup
text: The Montreux Jazz Festival has lined up Seal, Santana and Sting for its 45th annual concert in July, organizers announced Tuesday, two days earlier than planned after leaks of the lineup appeared online, Reuters reported. They will join Susan Tedeschi, B.B. King, George Benson, Diana Krall and Dr. John for the musical gathering in Switzerland.

headline: The Accidental Abolitionist
text: Adam Goodheart’s article (“The Shrug That Made History”) did a wonderful job of explaining the significance of little-known Fort Monroe to the outcome of the Civil War. I hope that despite current economic problems, Congress will see a Fort Monroe National Park as an opportunity to memorialize and celebrate the most resonant theme of our history, the desire for a more perfect union.

headline: Strikeout
text: The most interesting connection among the pitching rotations in Nate Silver’s “Vorping Their Way Into the Pantheon” is that none of the teams won the World Series. In fact, only one of the teams even made it to the World Series. While starting pitching is obviously very important, the other 21 members of the team largely determine the eventual winner.

headline: Study Finds Drop in Deadly V.A. Hospital Infections

text: DOHA, Qatar — NATO, Arab and African ministers agreed Wednesday “to work urgently” with the Libyan rebel leadership to set up a mechanism by which some frozen assets belonging to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family might be transferred to the rebel cause.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Vitamin E and açaí berries, two-well known antioxidants, have been cosmetics ingredients for years. Now it’s resveratrol’s turn. Some entrepreneurs are hoping that the chemical, found in the skin of grapes and in red wine — and considered a possible factor behind the so-called French Paradox (high-fat diet, relatively little heart disease) — can work through the skin as well as the digestive system.

headline: Bonds Guilty of Obstruction of Justice
text: 5:38 p.m. | Updated: Barry Bonds, the former outfielder who hit more home runs than anyone else in baseball history, was convicted Wednesday of single count of obstruction of justice, but a federal jury here could not reach a verdict on the question of whether Bonds had lied about never knowingly using steroids during his career.
