text: In Berkeley, Calif., a house with views of the San Francisco Bay; a duplex in a converted church in Newport, R.I.; and an oceanside cottage on Hawaii’s Big Island.

headline: Panel Unanimously Recommends Waiver for Walcott
text: A state-appointed panel of educators unanimously recommended on Wednesday that Dennis M. Walcott be allowed to become the next chancellor of the New York City school system, ruling that his background in education and public life compensated for his lack of formal training for the position.

headline: Moving From the Bridal Salon to the Red Carpet
text: LAST January, the “Glee” actress Lea Michele attended the Grammy Awards in a Romona Keveza navy one-shoulder frock with a fluttery feather-chiffon skirt. She couldn’t remember who designed the dress but offered a saucy excuse to the host Ryan Seacrest.

headline: CBPP Weighs In
text: Bob Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities — the single best source for serious budget analysis — weighs in. He finds the Obama plan still too weighted to spending cuts and with not enough revenue increases — and I will abide by his judgment:

headline: Scene City: Gwyneth Paltrow Celebrates Her Cookbook
text: The actress and singer, turned can-do celebrity chef, hosted a dinner party to celebrate her first cookbook.

headline: The Buzz
text: A preview of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

headline: She Acts. She Sings. She Cooks?
text: IT’S one thing to cook for your television fans. It’s quite another to cook for 60 of your closest friends, many of them stars themselves.

headline: Researchers Give the iPad Display Some ‘Depth’
text: When Apple added a front-facing camera to the new iPad, the company gave developers access to it with the hope that they would use it in new and innovative photo apps, or possibly even games.

headline: N.B.A. Fines Kobe Bryant $100,000 for Directing Gay Slur at Referee
text: The N.B.A. has fined Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers $100,000 for directing an anti-gay slur at a referee during Tuesday’s victory over the San Antonio Spurs. Bryant directed the slur at the official Bennie Adams, who had just leveled Bryant with a technical foul.

headline: James Taylor and Friends at Carnegie Hall
text: The composer and singer performed at a gala celebrating the 120th anniversary of Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Slave-Era Legacy Infuses a Brazilian Style With Fighting Moves
text: For better or worse, DanceBrazil has become something of a perennial at the Joyce Theater. The company, which opened a two-week season on Tuesday night, specializes in capoeira, the Brazilian form believed to have been started by slaves as a type of self-defense. Since it was prohibited, the movement form was disguised as dance.

headline: Bonds Guilty of Obstruction, but Not of Perjury
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Barry Bonds, the former outfielder who hit more home runs than anyone else in Major League Baseball history, was convicted Wednesday of a single count of obstruction of justice, but a federal jury could not decide on whether Bonds lied about using performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Dancing Under the Stars at Lincoln Center Begins in June
text: Get out those dancing shoes. Lincoln Center has just announced the lineup for Midsummer Night Swing, its annual salsa, swing, disco, tango, Gypsy jazz and folk dancing festival that takes place under the stars. This year a new dance floor has been installed at the band shell in Damrosch Park on West 62nd Street.

headline: The Delivery: Eccentric. The Attitude: Carefree.
text: Nearly 24 years have passed since I first saw the pop-soul singer Lonette McKee perform a cabaret act at the now-defunct Ballroom in Chelsea and had the kind of epiphany that a nightclub critic rarely experiences. Here was a performer with a stylistic fluidity that encompassed jazz, pop-soul and standards and a rangy voice with an emotional catch that brought you up short. At the time she seemed the most likely successor to Lena Horne.

headline: Muscularity and Grace in Sounds of Romance
text: The pianist Jon Nakamatsu plays with the calm assurance that comes of having both a solid technique and a gentle, introspective, interpretive spirit. On past encounters, that combination has made him sound unduly reserved. But at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening, Mr. Nakamatsu, who won the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in 1997, played works that demand both a graceful, singing quality and assertive muscularity, and he delivered as fully in the virtuosic passages as in the lyrical ones.

headline: How to Fix (or Kill) Web Data About You
text: As more of our social lives, shopping sprees and dating misadventures take place online, we leave behind, purposely or not, a growing supply of personal information.

headline: What You Get for ... $930,000
text: BERKELEY, CALIF.

headline: From a School: A Letter in Living Color
text: Birch Lane Elementary School in Davis, Calif., took issue with an article about picture books, and set out on a monthlong campaign to promote and read them. Read their scroll to the editor.

headline: Staging the Politics of Abortion
text: NEWARK, Del. — When the playwright Theresa Rebeck was writing for the ABC drama “NYPD Blue” in the 1990s, she proposed a story line in which a main female character considers an abortion — and then has one, a rare outcome on American television. But the idea was rejected as toxic for the character, she said. Ms. Rebeck later pitched an abortion-themed project to Lifetime, then known by the tag line Television for Women, but that cable channel passed, too.

headline: Writer in Residence
text: James Patterson has had his name on the cover of eight books on the hardcover fiction best-seller list over the past year.

headline: An Idle Star With Time for Trouble
text: Margarine and Jayne Mansfield were lesser substitutes that nonetheless filled a void — during World War II butter was rationed, and by the late 1950s and early ’60s Marilyn Monroe was often unavailable.

headline: Discord Among the Best of Married Friends
text: In Michael Frayn’s “Benefactors” the ties that bind also strangle.

headline: Choosing Between Leading Partner’s Suit or Your Own
text: You pick up A-9-5-4-3-2 of spades and 8-4 of hearts. Your lefthand opponent opens one club, which is either natural or a balanced hand with 12 to 14 points; your partner overcalls one heart; and the responder on your right jumps to three no-trump. What do you do, lead the heart eight or try a surprise attack with the spade four?

headline: O’Neill Theater Center Picks Eight Plays
text: Out of the nearly 1,000 plays vying to be developed by the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., eight have been chosen to undergo the expert development process during the center’s National Playwrights Conference in July. The winners, to be formally announced on Thursday, will take audiences from a movie set in Jordan, where a veteran relives the trauma of war, to a sleep-away camp in Maine, where the Nadelmans visit their hard-to-handle son. The plays, which will be performed at the conference, are: “The Nether,” by Jennifer Haley; “The Happiest Song Plays Last,” by Quiara Alegría Hudes; “Good Goods,” by Christina Anderson; “An Incident” by Anna Ziegler; “Acquainted With the Night,” by Keith Reddin; “Tell Us of the Night” by Keith Huff; “The Troublemaker Project” by Dan LeFranc; and “How We Got On,” Idris Goodwin. The O’Neill, which won the 2010 Tony Award for Regional Theater, has been a springboard for new works and artists to full productions on Broadway, Off Broadway and at major regional theaters.

headline: Adele Back on Top
text: Adele continues her run on the pop charts this week, returning to the No. 1 spot and displacing Britney Spears in the process, and becoming the first artist this year to rack up album sales of 1 million. Her “21” (XL/Columbia) sold 88,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, climbing two spots to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the fourth time in its seven weeks of release. The album has sold a total of 1.03 million copies. (The album with the second biggest sales of the year so far is another rootsy, critically respected British import: Mumford & Sons’ “Sigh No More,” on the Glassnote label, which has sold 645,000 copies in the United States and lands this week at No. 8.) Ms. Spears’s “Femme Fatale” (Jive) falls to No. 2 in its second week, with 75,000 sales, a 73 percent drop from its opening week. Radiohead’s “King of Limbs” (Ticker Tape) climbed three spots to No. 3 in its second week of wide release, with 67,000 sales. The rap/rock band Hollywood Undead is close behind with 66,000 sales of its new album, “American Tragedy” (A&M/Octone). On Billboard’s Digital Songs chart, the top three songs from last week hold steady: Katy Perry’s “E. T.” remains No. 1 for a fifth week, selling 323,000 copies, while the Black Eyed Peas hold at No. 2 with “Just Can’t Get Enough” and Rihanna stays at No. 3 with “S&M.”

headline: To Get Easter and Passover Celebrations Right, Use an App
text: For many Jews and Christians, the next two weeks bring opportunities to share meals and practice traditions whose elements never escape memory.

headline: The Obituary Writer Has the Upper Hand
text: As of Wednesday morning, it cost a total of 3 cents to buy used copies of all three of Timothy Schaffert’s previous novels from Amazon.com: “The Phantom Limbs of the Rollow Sisters” (2002), “The Singing and Dancing Daughters of God” (2005) and “Devils in the Sugar Shop” (2007). Yet each of these books is a quirky little gem, particularly the first one. Life is not fair.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Paul Reiser Show'
text: The comic stars as a version of himself in this new NBC comedy.

headline: Obama's Deficit-Reduction Speech
text: President Obama countered Republican budget plans on Wednesday with what he said was a more balanced approach.

headline: For Kors, the Glow Doesn’t Fade
text: IF 80 percent of success is showing up, to quote poor Woody Allen yet again, then maybe the other 20 percent is sticking around? Consider the designer Michael Kors, who recently commemorated 30 consistent if not generally spine-tingling years in the fashion industry with a disco-inflected runway show, a party at Bemelmans Bar well stocked with celebrities, and the opening of a gleaming new duplex flagship on Madison Avenue.

headline: One Big List
text: How the best sellers would rank if fiction and nonfiction titles were combined on a single list.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for April 14
text: Four questions for Billy Reid; Project Alabama, high-concept, high-priced label has become a mid-priced, wearable collection; and more items.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Browser Security
text: With malware, phishing schemes and other threats on the rise, many banks have been prodding customers to download security software. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Mickey Boodaei, chief executive of Trusteer, the company that makes the free software called Trusteer Rapport. The software is designed to protect you from malicious activity, like key-logging, by safeguarding your browser. It works in the background, Mr. Boodaei said, and can also be used at other sites where you might enter a credit card number or other sensitive information.

headline: A Dance of Death
text: “In the ghost town of Nuevo Laredo, an assassin, a New Age drug lord and La Santa Muerte (St. Death) deal in the day-to-day business of Death, Faith and Rehab.” Such is the succinct yet rather all-encompassing plot description in the news release for “Nuevo Laredo,” a production at Dixon Place by Gabriella Barnstone and El Gato Teatro. Given this summary, you could reasonably expect theatrical extremes, whether sublime or disastrous.

headline: Spotlight on San Francisco, and the New
text: Meet the Composer has always been devoted to making new music user-friendly by commissioning works and having the composers on hand to explain them to audiences. Now the organization is reconfiguring itself, and it has come up with a twist: instead of merely using its Web site to promote performances, it is staging a small festival to promote its Web site, or a section of it.

headline: A Funny Girl Strives to Survive
text: It’s to the credit of the actress Kimberly Faye Greenberg and the writer-director-arranger Chip Deffaa — with help from the passing decades — that the solo show “One Night With Fanny Brice” ducks the formidably long shadow of Barbra Streisand and “Funny Girl,” the 1964 Broadway musical about Brice, the vaudevillian, Ziegfeld performer, comedian and radio star. (The screen “Funny Girl” generated a sequel, “Funny Lady,” and now a 2012 Broadway revival is afoot.)

headline: A Film Angers an Emirate Festival
text: In retrospect, perhaps the curators of the Sharjah Biennial, the huge contemporary art event now under way in the Persian Gulf region, should have thought twice before inviting the participation of an Iranian-American filmmaker whose biggest hit to date — a quasi-documentary about himself was called "I Am a Sex Addict" and whose film before that followed along aimlessly while he tripped on hallucinogenic mushrooms.

headline: He’s Only Just Begun to Fight
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Italian Justice Legislation Could End Berlusconi Trials
text: ROME — The lower house of Italy’s Parliament on Wednesday approved a measure intended to speed up Italy’s notoriously slow justice system, bringing the country into line with European standards but possibly ending several trials pending against Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: The Czech President Pockets a Pen
text: While Vaclav Klaus, the Czech president, is not as well-known globally as his predecessor, Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright who led Czechoslovakia’s Velvet Revolution, in the past three days, nearly 5 million people have watched video of one of Mr. Klaus’s recent news conferences on YouTube.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Faces Indictment on Corruption Charges
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s attorney general on Wednesday announced his intention to indict the foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, on corruption charges, but said he would allow Mr. Lieberman a hearing to contest an indictment before issuing a formal charge sheet.

headline: PC Sales Slump Because of Quake and Tablets
text: Japan’s earthquake and subsequent tsunami contributed to the first decline in personal computer shipments since the end of the recent recession, according to two reports released on Wednesday.

headline: Celebrity Roast
text: Lamb traditionally appears on both Easter and Passover tables, though the latter most often in the form of a single symbolic shank bone. (In some Passover traditions, roast lamb itself cannot be eaten.) In my extensive experience, that shank is roasted to death and inedible; it’s symbolic, I know, but imagine how much Jews of my generation might have learned about cooking had it been properly braised! In my fewer but occasional Easter dinners, those with lamb — usually leg — were somewhat better, but as we all know religious or even quasi-religious meals are rarely occasions of culinary wizardry.

headline: 800 Civilians Killed This Year in Southern Sudan, U.N. Says
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — More than 800 civilians have died since January in fragmenting violence in southern Sudan, the United Nations said Wednesday, less than three months before the vast, impoverished, battle-scarred region becomes its own nation.

headline: As Generics Near, Makers Tweak Erectile Drugs
text: Facing generic competition for its “little blue pill,” Pfizer recently started selling a chewable form of Viagra in Mexico. It is called Viagra Jet, and Pfizer says it may also market it to other nations in the developing world, if not the United States.

headline: Warblers Have Ways to Resist Impostor Eggs
text: The cuckoo finch’s habit of laying its eggs in other birds’ nests provokes an arms race. The cuckoo finch finds better ways to mimic the host bird’s eggs, and the host bird responds with new methods of distinguishing the cuckoo finch’s eggs from its own.

headline: Treatment at a Carefree Hospital
text: In one of the seemingly endless dreamlike images in “Epona’s Labyrinth” at Here Arts Center, a frantic woman in a hospital chases the silhouette of a part of the male anatomy that is usually hidden. She swats at it with a broom, but the pesky thing floats away across the stage.

headline: Collectors May (or May Not) Have Chance to Buy Bertone Cars
Yankees Shuffle Bullpen
text: The primary consequence of Luis Ayala going on the disabled list with an injured muscle in his back could be an expanded role in the bullpen forBartolo Colon. Used only to back up Phil Hughes through the first two weeks, Colon will now be an option to pitch in shorter spurts — one or two innings — now that a true long man, Hector Noesi, has been promoted from Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes Barre to take Ayala’s roster spot.

headline: Yanks Use Hamilton Injury as Teaching Moment
text: Curtis Granderson had yet to watch the entire play that resulted in a broken right arm for Josh Hamilton of Texas. He had only seen footage of Hamilton’s headfirst slide into home plate.

headline: A Single European EV Charging Plug? Not Now.
text: As electric cars become more common, they’re still arguing in Europe about what kind of 230-volt charging plugs they’ll use — and it doesn’t appear that a single standard will be adopted in the near future. In the United States, that issue has long been resolved with a universal five-pin design, known as J1772.

headline: Shopping for Coin Banks With Brad Zizmor and Dag Folger
text: The principals of a+i architecture in Manhattan shopped for coin banks, in forms familiar (pig-shaped) and far more subtle.

headline: Views of, and From, Olana
text: Preserving the Hudson River School painter Frederic E. Church’s home also means preserving its sweeping views of surrounding landscape.

headline: A Personal Shopper, in Far-Flung Places
text: For those lacking the time or resources to embark on an international shopping expedition with an interior designer, One Kings Lane, the Web retailer, has an alternative: the online container sale. Every month or so, Susan Feldman, a founder of the company, will team up with a different designer to handpick furniture and accessories in a far-flung location, filling up a shipping container and offering those finds for sale. “We can go places not everybody has access to,” Ms. Feldman said, “where we think there are great and unique products.”

headline: Stools and Tables for the Modern Stone Age
text: Proving that stone furniture needn’t be clunky, the Kreoo collection from Decormarmi, an Italian company, looks remarkably light and sensuously sculptural. “In our market, you often see stone things that are functionally good, but aesthetically, the scale isn’t quite right or the little details aren’t there,” said Mark Whitfield, director of product management at Charles Luck Stone Center, which is selling the line in the United States. “Decormarmi has been able to get it right.”

headline: Sales on Pots and Pans, and Museum Pieces
text: A selection of All-Clad stainless-steel pots and pans is deeply discounted during the cookware sale at Broadway Panhandler, through Sunday (a 3.5-quart saucepan with lid, below, originally $180, is $100; a 12-inch fry pan with lid, originally $190, is $90); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway); (212) 966-3434; broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Inside Marwencol
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lot of Pomp for the Circumstance: A High-Tech Toilet by Kohler
text: If you’re the sort who must have the sleekest, slickest high-tech toy before anyone else — especially when the price tag makes others gasp — Kohler’s $6,390 Numi toilet (above), which is being introduced this month, is for you. Its features include not merely a bidet, environmentally correct dual flush, deodorizer and dryer, but also a foot-warmer and speakers that allow you to play a preprogrammed song. (It’s relaxing music, we were assured by the company’s president, David Kohler, which is good, because imagine what would happen if it made you want to get up and dance.) The user can also listen to a built-in FM radio or play her own music over the speakers.

headline: Heirloom Gardening
text: To the Editor:

headline: Piggy Banks
text: BRAD ZIZMOR and Dag Folger are the principals of a+i architecture, a Manhattan firm specializing in office and retail design. In the 16 years since they started their firm, their roster of clients has grown to include quite a few financial institutions.

headline: Carpentry for Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby on Seeking the Void and Then Filling It
text: Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby met when they were architecture students at the Royal College of Art in London, and founded their firm, Barber Osgerby, shortly after graduation, in 1996. Since then, they have quietly taken the design world by storm, winning numerous awards and creating products for the likes of Cappellini, Flos, Vitra, Established & Sons, Sony and even Coca-Cola, which commissioned them to design a new bottle.

headline: Looking Out for the View at Olana, Frederic Church’s Hudson Home
text: HUDSON, N.Y.

headline: John M. Johansen’s Plastic Tent House
text: A house in Stanfordville, N.Y., by the modernist architect becomes a Manhattan couple’s weekend home.

headline: Modular Light Fixtures That Go On and On
text: Endless, the latest fixture from the Brooklyn lighting company Roll & Hill, lives up to its name. Made from modular components, it can be ordered in any length, and configured as a straight or snaking line — potentially one that runs clear across a room. “It’s really a way to define space with light,” said Jason Miller, the company’s chief executive, who designed the piece.

headline: In the Shadow of ‘What If’
text: I GREW up in Buchanan, N.Y., a tiny, mostly working-class village in northern Westchester County, on the eastern shores of the Hudson, tucked into a crook where the river bends. My parents were public school teachers, and we lived in a split-level wood house near Lake Meahagh (pronounced MEE-haw), a manmade pond where my sister and I laced up our figure skates each winter and carved broad figure eights into its big, imperfect surface. Buchanan is a modest community (the village itself comprises less than two square miles); when people ask where I’m from, I usually say Peekskill or Croton, the two closest midsize towns. For the most part, Buchanan is known only to itself.

headline: The Serial Sleepover Artist
text: THE fitness fanatic in Columbus Circle flaked. So did the performance-artist couple in Greenpoint who said they practiced at-home nudity. Yet Kenya Robinson’s odyssey as a serial house guest has been smooth enough so far, and by and large her hosts — friends, colleagues and total strangers — have been happy to share their toothpaste with her.

headline: A Country Home, by a Modernist at Play
text: Stanfordville, N.Y.

headline: New C.I.A. Drone Attack Draws Rebuke From Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — C.I.A. drones fired two missiles at militants in Pakistan’s tribal areas on Wednesday, two days after Pakistan’s spy chief threatened to curtail the drone strikes and demanded more information about the Central Intelligence Agency’s operations there.

headline: Two Financial Crises Compared: The Savings and Loan Debacle and the Mortgage Mess
text: A comparison of prosecutions related to the savings and loan crisis and the current financial crisis.

headline: Microsoft Demonstrates Windows Phone Updates
text: Microsoft unveiled plans for the next version of its Windows Phone platform on Wednesday at MIX, the company’s annual developer conference in Las Vegas.

headline: ‘Sleep No More’
text: Photos from the interactive theater piece from the British company Punchdrunk.

headline: Flyers Goaltender Bobrovsky Lets Actions Do His Talking
text: VOORHEES, N.J. — An enormous black-and-white aerial photo of the Philadelphia Flyers’ most recent Stanley Cup parade hangs outside the double doors leading into the dressing room at their suburban practice center. It takes a sharp eye to notice the date on the photo: 1975.

headline: Pulling Out All the Stops to Push an Antigay Bill
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — They entered through Parliament’s gates, an eclectic group. Their leader, the Rev. Martin Ssempa, wore sunglasses and long black robes embroidered with matching red crosses and two campaign buttons. One said, “Debate Our Bill Now!” and the other, simply, “No to Sodomy.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'War Horse'
text: The actor Seth Numrich talks about performing with life-sized puppets in the play "War Horse" at Lincoln Center Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Naming Culprits in the Financial Crisis
text: A voluminous report on the financial crisis by the United States Senate — citing internal documents and private communications of bank executives, regulators, credit ratings agencies and investors — describes business practices that were rife with conflicts during the mortgage mania and reckless activities that were ignored inside the banks and among their federal regulators.

headline: Study Measures Ad Industry’s Impact on State Economies
text: THAT there are “mad men” in New York, the home of Madison Avenue, goes without saying. But who knew there were 2,216 mad men — and women — in South Dakota, 11,009 in Alabama, 1,165 in Vermont and even 1,391 in Alaska?

headline: Mets’ Young Has Biceps Tendinitis
text: Chris Young had been looking forward to the opportunity to pitch Friday, on Jackie Robinson Day, because Young wrote his dissertation at Princeton on Robinson and his role in breaking down cultural barriers.

headline: Standoff in Sacramento as Brown and G.O.P. Lock Horns Over Taxes
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Gov. Jerry Brown, seeking authorization to ask California voters to extend expiring taxes to avoid more draconian budget cuts, is fighting what increasingly appears to be an intractable battle.

headline: A Scroll to the Editor: We Love to Read!
text: We recently received, in a tube sent by postal mail, something new in our experience: a 15-foot-long scroll to the editor. We’ve received all kinds of mail in the past: books, manuscripts, CDs, even a hostile brick to the editor. Perhaps editors in ancient times received scrolls all the time — but not us.

headline: New Translation of Mass
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Links Found Between Bodies on L.I. and in South Jersey
text: The skeletal remains of eight bodies found off an oceanfront roadway on Long Island, including those of four prostitutes, bear no obvious connection to the bodies of four prostitutes found near Atlantic City in 2006, officials said Wednesday.

headline: H.I.V. Kidney Transplants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strongman Out, Ivory Coast Is Reviving
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — Fresh produce appeared on market stalls. Women carried sacks of grain on their heads. Children skipped rope in the street. Men sipped coffee in outdoor cafes.

headline: Wall Street and the Financial Crisis: Anatomy of a Financial Collapse
text: A report from the U.S. Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations two-year, bipartisan investigation into the origins of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Gerald A. Lawson, a Pioneer in Video Games, Dies at 70
text: Gerald A. Lawson, a largely self-taught engineer who became a pioneer in electronic video entertainment, creating the first home video game system with interchangeable game cartridges, died on Saturday in Mountain View, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: Defining a Dictionary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oversight of Aircraft Repairs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Lasting Imprint of the Civil War
text: To the Editor:

headline: My Civil War Centennial
text: I had a great Civil War Centennial. I was eight years old in 1961, and my parents took our family on trips to Gettysburg and Antietam and Manassas. I had blue and gray toy soldiers, and Civil War trading cards, and I watched Johnny Shiloh and Johnny Yuma. From this, a life-long interest was born.

headline: An Eye That Brides Rely On
text: A clotheshorse ever since he could toddle, Mark Ingram ultimately selected an item of clothing he will never wear himself — the wedding gown — as the focal point of his business, the Mark Ingram Bridal Atelier, in Midtown. Mr. Ingram, 52, opened his couture bridal shop in 2002 after accumulating 20 years of experience in the clothing industry. He lives in Hamilton Heights.

headline: F.A.A. Adding Controllers to Night Shifts
text: Twenty-seven airport towers will be staffed with a second employee on the overnight shift as the Federal Aviation Administration struggles to deal with a recurring problem of controllers sleeping on the job.

headline: New Grievances Broaden Syria’s Protest Movement
text: Syria’s growing protest movement broadened on Wednesday as Aleppo, one of Syria’s largest cities, had its first demonstrations against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, and a group of women from the coastal village of Bayda, where hundreds were detained this week, marched to demand the release of their husbands and sons.

headline: Detention of Immigrants in New York City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mississippi Grays
text: On March 28, 1961 a six-mile, two-hour parade wended its way through Jackson, Miss. — the largest public event in state history — to mark the centennial of Mississippi’s secession and the beginning of the Civil War. Tens of thousands of white Mississippians lined the route, greeting the festooned marchers with rebel yells of “Yiiiii Hoooaaah!” Women from the Mississippi Delta region, dressed in their Old South finery, rode on a float and sipped mint juleps as they toasted sending their men “off to war.” The South that day, noted the Jackson Clarion-Ledger, “rose again, in all its Confederate splendor.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Don't Cut Now
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Reihan Salam of Economics 21 debate the right time to cut the deficit.

headline: President Obama, Reinvigorated
text: The man America elected president has re-emerged.

headline: ESPN Issues New Rules for Announcers
text: ESPN announced a set of endorsement guidelines for its on-air announcers Wednesday that would have probably prohibited a deal made this year between Erin Andrews, one of its best-known reporters, and Reebok, and another one between Scott Van Pelt and Titleist.

headline: At a Mafia Murder Trial, a Lesson in Mob Jargon
text: With a clamor of jailyard voices echoing in the background, Joseph C. Massino asked his former crime family subordinate, Vincent Basciano, if he had used two men “to clip Randy.”

headline: Restoring Sendai’s Airport
text: On Wednesday, the airport in Sendai, Japan, reopened to commercial flights for the first time since the earthquake and tsunami struck on March 11.

headline: Pentagon Says It Has Kept Up Some Strikes on Libya
text: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials disclosed Wednesday that American warplanes had continued to strike targets in Libya even after the Obama administration said the United States was stepping back from offensive missions and letting NATO take the lead.

headline: This Army Unit Was Bogus, Prosecutors Charge
text: LOS ANGELES — To the Chinese immigrants he recruited, Yupeng Deng was known as Supreme Commander. He offered them United States Army uniforms, conducted training exercises on Sundays, led marches in municipal parades and promised a path toward American citizenship.

headline: Behind the Abortion War
text: Part of the price of keeping the government operating this week is another debate over the financing of Planned Parenthood. Whoopee.

headline: Bryant Fined $100,000 by N.B.A. for Gay Slur
text: Hours after the Los Angeles Lakers star Kobe Bryant directed an obscene antigay slur at a referee who had just whistled him for a technical foul, N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern fined him $100,000 on Wednesday and, in a statement, described Bryant’s remarks as “offensive and inexcusable.”

headline: A BlackBerry Tablet, but Where Are the Apps?
text: Listen, I’ll be straight with you. I realize that tablets are crazy hot right now, that 2011 is the Year of the iPad Clone and that every company and its brother is rushing one to market. But I’m sorry. I’m not going to review every one of the 85 tablets that will arrive this year; it’s only April, and I’ve already got Tablet Fatigue. I’m not going to review the Electrolux tablet, the Polaroid tablet, the Sunoco tablet, the Kellogg’s tablet. ...

headline: Diller Scofidio + Renfro to Design Art Building at Stanford
text: The architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro, which seems to get every big commission these days, has been selected for yet another one. Stanford University has chosen the firm to design its new home for the art and art history department, the university is to announce Thursday.

headline: Cairo’s Roundabout Revolution
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Bonds’s Denial, Baseball’s Problem
text: Barry Bonds had virtually no peers in his chosen sport, but in the court of law he had 12 of them. On Wednesday, those peers convicted Bonds of one count of obstruction of justice, which will stay with Bonds forever.

headline: In Budget’s Fine Print, Real and Illusory Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Few financial problems have generated more public attention in the last few years than mortgage fraud, one of the triggers for the nation’s housing collapse. But even government officials seeking to combat a front-burner issue like that one are feeling the sting of the budget deal struck last Friday to avert a federal shutdown.

headline: Iraqi Youths’ Political Rise Is Stunted by Elites
text: BAGHDAD — Inspired by the democratic uprisings around the Arab world to push for change, young lawmakers in Parliament are running up against an ossified political elite still dominated by the exiles who followed American tanks into Iraq to establish a fragile, violence-scarred democracy.

headline: For Bonds Jurors, a Narrow Common Ground
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After weeks of hearing from 25 government witnesses — who often offered dense, scientific testimony — the jurors in the Barry Bonds trial finally looked relaxed Wednesday. They took a long lunch and some of them chatted and laughed together in the cafeteria of the Phillip Burton Federal Courthouse, which has been their second home for the last month.

headline: A Setback for Arizona-Style Immigration Laws
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has upheld a trial judge’s ruling blocking the most egregious parts of Arizona’s infamous immigration law. The three-judge panel said that Arizona intruded onto federal responsibility by requiring that police officers check the immigration status of anyone they have “reasonable suspicion” of being in the state without authorization, demanding that immigrants carry papers and making it a crime for illegal immigrants to work or look for work.

headline: Commission Seeks Safeguards at Open-Water Races
text: A five-member commission headed by Dick Pound, the former International Olympic Committee vice president, released a report Wednesday offering proposals to make open-water swimming competitions safer after the death last October of the American Fran Crippen during a race in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: The Reality of Women at War
text: A Congressional study commission has recommended an end to the Pentagon’s ban on women serving in ground combat — a policy that years of warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan have shown to be impractical. Female soldiers have become involved in de facto combat situations, suffering death and battle wounds. At the same time, their careers are crimped as leadership promotions flowed more to men with combat experience, according to the study.

headline: Surrender
text: Charleston Harbor, S.C., April 14, 1861

headline: The Timid Need Not Apply
text: “I finally scored a job. You’ll never guess where,” my friend Peter announced, his mouth curling in smug anticipation.

headline: Tainting Justice With Politics
text: The furiously contested election of a Wisconsin Supreme Court justice shows, once again, how politics and money can debase the law.

headline: At Carnegie Gala, Cameos by a Canine and a Clinton
text: Poodles, despite their airs, know little of pomp and circumstance. That might account for why Valentina, a little white dog, left a puddle on one of the three red carpets lolling out of Carnegie Hall into the rain on 57th Street on Tuesday night before James Taylor’s gala concert celebrating the 120-year-old hall. No matter; there was a brigade of attendants with vacuum cleaners who swooped in among the uncouth canine, and guests like Bette Midler, Michael Douglas and Steve Martin, to clean up footprints and other little messes.

headline: Corrections
text: FOREIGN

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 13, 2011

headline: China Policy Main Topic for the G-20
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies, frustrated in their efforts to pressure China directly to change its economic policies, are seeking to enlist other developing nations in an international campaign that China may find more palatable.

headline: Densely Populated, but No Shortage of Grisly Dumping Sites
text: In June 1991, a fisherman found a barrel in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. Seven months later, a police officer saw two men leaving the park’s woods. He asked them what they were doing, and they told him they had gone into the woods to bury a dog.

headline: Budget Details Stir Republican Dissent Ahead of House Vote
text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders sought on Wednesday to contain growing conservative opposition to the new 2011 spending deal as the House prepared for contentious back-to-back votes on budget measures.

headline: Harman Family to Keep Its Stake in Newsweek
text: In the weeks before his death, Sidney Harman acted every bit the proud new business owner he was. He took part in meetings. When he could not be there in person, he dialed in by video conference. He answered his own phone when colleagues called. And until last Friday he was still discussing the business affairs of Newsweek and The Daily Beast.

headline: Courting Disaster the E.T.F. Way
text: It didn’t take long for financial engineers to find a new playground. Fresh from dreaming up collateralized debt obligations (C.D.O.’s), structured finance specialists are applying similar techniques to exchange-traded funds. E.T.F.’s are wildly popular with big and small investors who love the liquidity and diversification such investments promise. But derivatives, special purpose vehicles and skewed incentives, hallmarks of the last boom and subsequent bust, have found their way into E.T.F.’s as well.

headline: How to Carve a Leg of Lamb in Three Cuts
text: Mark Bittman presents a technique for carving lamb shank in three easy cuts.

headline: Yale Student Killed as Hair Gets Caught in Lathe
text: As a Yale undergraduate majoring in astronomy and physics, Michele Dufault was used to extreme physical environments. She worked on underwater robotic vehicles last summer as a fellow at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts. She also traveled to Houston as part of a team of undergraduates chosen by NASA to perform a plasma physics experiment in reduced gravity.

headline: Taiwanese Technology Company Is Discussing a Deal With Brazil
text: Foxconn, a Taiwanese technology company, is discussing a $12 billion deal to manufacture displays for computers and tablets in Brazil, Brazilian officials said Tuesday. The technology giant would build a plant in Brazil that would employ about 100,000 workers, including 20,000 engineers, Aloizio Mercadante, Brazil’s minister of science and technology, told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. Foxconn could encounter labor issues in Brazil: the country is facing a shortage of technology professionals estimated at 92,000 this year, according to the Brazilian Association of Information Technology and Communication Companies, or Brasscom.

headline: Thursday: Get Unhitched
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Is it humid in here or is it me?

headline: Particle Hunt Nets Almost Nothing; the Hunters Are Almost Thrilled
text: This could have been the day they discovered dark matter.

headline: Raise America’s Taxes
text: President Obama in his speech on Wednesday confronted a topic that is harder to address seriously in public than sex or flatulence: America needs higher taxes.

headline: High Costs Linked to Gaps Around Air-Conditioners
text: After embracing environmentally friendly construction, Martin Dunn, a developer of affordable housing in the city, made a frustrating discovery: the energy that he hoped to save with improved insulation and efficient boilers was being siphoned off through gaps around the air-conditioners in apartment windows.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,517 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: A Tragedy in Newburgh
text: Lashanda Armstrong’s van rolled off a boat ramp into the Hudson River, killing her and three of her children. Her 10-year-old son survived.

headline: Yanks’ Offense Returns to Support Burnett
text: When mentioned in a baseball context, the phrase “it’s early” usually has a negative connotation. It speaks to a team’s shaky start, a hitter’s slump, a pitcher’s struggles, with the belief — and expectation — that progress is being made. With A. J. Burnett, it seems it is always early — until it becomes too late. There is genuine enthusiasm now surrounding Burnett, whose mediocre personal statistics obscure a more valuable significance.

headline: Frustration Finds Its Way Into the Mets’ Clubhouse
text: Terry Collins came to the Mets last November with a reputation for being passionate and direct, and those characteristics were on display late Wednesday night. Just 11 games into the season, a frustrated Collins addressed his players after their 5-4 loss to the Colorado Rockies, their sixth defeat in seven games, then made his displeasure public.

headline: Michael C. Latham, Expert on Nutrition in Developing World, Dies at 82
text: Michael C. Latham, an expert on international nutrition and tropical health who waged a long campaign against the use of infant formula and for the practice of breastfeeding in developing countries, died on April 1 in Boston. He was 82 and lived in Newfield, N.Y.

headline: States Look to Ban Efforts to Reveal Farm Abuse
text: Undercover videos showing grainy, sometimes shocking images of sick or injured livestock have become a favorite tool of animal rights organizations to expose what they consider illegal or inhumane treatment of animals.

headline: Billy Bang, Jazz Violinist Inspired by Vietnam Experience, Dies at 63
text: Billy Bang, a violinist whose gritty, expressive and spirited playing earned admiration in contemporary jazz circles, died on Monday at his home in Harlem. He was 63.

headline: Abraham Rothberg, Who Wrote of Golem and Stalin, Dies at 89
text: Abraham Rothberg, an author whose works, most of them fiction, roamed from the ghettos of medieval Prague through the counterculture upheavals of America in the 1960s to the machinations of Soviet Communism, died on March 28 at his home in Rochester. He was 89.

headline: An Exhibition in April Goes to the Celtics
text: BOSTON — In a few days, the venom will fly, vocal cords will fray and a half-dozen All-Stars will tangle and tussle under the TD Garden lights, a rivalry renewed. Until then, all are conserving their fervor.

headline: Shakespeare Slept Here, Albeit Fitfully
text: Those pushy Macbeths may be backstabbing social climbers, but you must admit that their new digs are to die for. The Thane of Cawdor and his wife have moved into a deserted hotel in the hinterlands of the West 20s, and my dear, what they’ve done with the place. Don’t be surprised if it shows up soon on the cover of Architectural Digest, bloodstains and all.

headline: Do Cellphones Cause Brain Cancer?
text: On Jan. 21, 1993, the television talk-show host Larry King featured an unexpected guest on his program. It was the evening after Inauguration Day in Washington, and the television audience tuned in expecting political commentary. But King turned, instead, to a young man from Florida, David Reynard, who had filed a tort claim against the cellphone manufacturer NEC and the carrier GTE Mobilnet, claiming that radiation from their phones caused or accelerated the growth of a brain tumor in his wife.

headline: Santorum Forms Presidential Fund-Raising Committee
text: Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania announced on Wednesday that he had opened a presidential fund-raising committee, a step that allows him to explore a bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Rangers Fall in a Tightly Played Opener
text: WASHINGTON — If Game 1 was any indication, the opening-round series between the Rangers and Capitals will be short on goals, long on grit and very evenly matched.

headline: Resistance to Jaitapur Nuclear Plant Grows in India
text: MADBAN, India — When a farmer named Praveen Gawankar and two neighbors began a protest four years ago against a proposed nuclear power plant here in this coastal town, they were against it mainly for not-in-my-backyard reasons.

headline: Word of the Day | chaotic
text: chaotic •\ka-ˈä-tik\• adjective

headline: Details of the Deal
text: The 459-page legislation of the budget plan the Democrats and Republicans agreed to in order to avert a government shutdown shows hundreds of reductions to federal agencies and groups.

headline: In Financial Crisis, No Prosecutions of Top Figures
text: It is a question asked repeatedly across America: why, in the aftermath of a financial mess that generated hundreds of billions in losses, have no high-profile participants in the disaster been prosecuted?

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 14, 2011
text: Test your proofreading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “An Easter Treat From the ‘Cake Boss.’ “

headline: Who Needs a Beach When Life’s a Goof?
text: Kesha began her show at Roseland Ballroom on Wednesday night within a diamond shape of lights, wearing light-emitting sunglasses, singing and playing two synthesizers on a high platform. She didn’t move much, in her torn fishnets and army boots; she was cold, imperious, robotic.

headline: What Song/Artist Pairings Would You Like to Hear?
text: A review describes a recent Carnegie Hall concert in which James Taylor and guests like Sting and Bette Midler sang their versions of classic songs including “Home on the Range” and “Penny Lane.” Is there a song that you love, whether old or new, that you would like to hear a different artist perform? What song would that be, and whom would you like to hear sing it? Why?

headline: NATO Showing Strain Over Approach to Libya
text: BERLIN — NATO’s foreign ministers, showing the strains of fighting two wars at once, tried to play down divisions over the intensity of the air campaign against Libya on Thursday, urging patience and resolve as the alliance carried out what one official called “a significant level” of attacks on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces.

headline: The Default Major: Skating Through B-School
text: This article is a collaboration between The New York Times and The Chronicle of Higher Education, a daily source of news, opinion and commentary for professors, administrators and others interested in academe. David Glenn is a senior writer at The Chronicle covering teaching and curriculum.

headline: Is Goldman Sachs Too Big to Fail?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Conveying the Sadness in Japan’s Stoicism
text: The Associated Press photographer David Guttenfelder, who lives with his wife and two young daughters in Japan, was on assignment in North Korea when a magnitude 9.0 earthquake struck northern Japan on March 11.

headline: Colleagues Rebuke Gaza Report’s Author
text: JERUSALEM — Three members of the United Nations panel that investigated Israel’s Gaza war two years ago rejected on Thursday an essay written by the fourth, the former chairman Richard Goldstone, in which he retracted the panel’s key conclusions, especially that Israel had deliberately made civilians targets.

headline: German Firms Move Toward Postnuclear Economy
text: HANOVER, Germany — Josef Mehrer, a family-owned German company established more than 120 years ago, has survived by adapting with the times. Early on, it made sewing machines, then machines for cleaning beer vats, then it switched to compressors in the 1950s.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: DeMarco Murray, Fourth-Ranked Rusher
text: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: The Early Word: Money, Money, Money
text: In Today’s Times:— President Obama on Wednesday laid out a plan for cutting $4 trillion from the federal budget over 12 years, staking his opening position in a debate that will consume Washington in the coming weeks, as the administration faces off with Congress over raising the national debt ceiling, and into next year, as the president runs for re-election. Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear examine the politics and substance of Mr. Obama’s proposal, a mix of long-term spending cuts, tax increases and changes to social welfare programs. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to lead bipartisan negotiations aimed at reaching a budget deal by the end of June.

headline: What ‘Big Medicine’ Means for Doctors and Patients
text: A colleague described a recent meeting at his hospital by saying that five years ago, most of the physicians in the room had been like him, independent owners of small group practices. Now a majority were employees of the hospital.

headline: Gothic Mansion in London Reopens
text: England certainly has its share of castles, but very few are close to the center of London and even fewer are the inspiration behind an 18th-century novel. Strawberry Hill’s Gothic Mansion is both. Originally built in the late 1700s by Horace Walpole, the politician, historian and novelist, this ornately decorated mansion has recently reopened to the public after an extensive two-year renovation.

headline: A Look Ahead to Reveals in Shanghai
text: The Shanghai motor show was strictly a second-rate affair until a few years ago, when China emerged from the dusty backwater of industrialism into one of world’s premier automobile markets.

headline: Q&A: Taking the Windows 7 Taskbar to Task
text: Q.

headline: In Class of Colorful Freshmen, Meet the Most Contrarian
text: WASHINGTON —Representative Justin Amash does not believe the government should subsidize public broadcasting, vehemently opposes abortion rights and thinks Democrats are wrong about spending. Yet he has voted against every Republican measure that conforms to those views.

headline: How We Decided to Go Global
text: When I first suggested taking TerraCycle’s operations global, there was nearly a mutiny among my board members and executive team. No exaggeration, they thought I’d lost my mind. As quickly as I’d brought up the idea, it was tabled — that is, until I got a phone call in 2008 that set everything in motion.

headline: Obama Speech Defends Liberal Principles
text: In the hours before President Obama‘s 44-minute speech on the nation’s mounting debt, liberal groups were whipped into a frenzy, warning that Mr. Obama was poised to capitulate — once again, in their view — to Republican philosophy on taxes, the deficit and spending cuts.

headline: Vitaly Petrov Describes Crash in Malaysia
text: SHANGHAI — Vitaly Petrov of the Renault team described on Thursday some of the frightening powers that can be unleashed while driving at speed in Formula One — especially during a crash.

text: SHANGHAI — Vitaly Petrov of the Renault team described on Thursday some of the frightening powers that can be unleashed while driving at speed in Formula One — especially during a crash.

headline: North Korea Prepares to Indict American
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean government is preparing to indict an American man it has detained on unspecified charges, saying the man has already “admitted his crime,” the state news agency reported on Thursday.

headline: BP Gets an Extension From Rosneft to Salvage Their Oil Exploration Deal
text: LONDON — The British oil giant BP won a last-minute respite Thursday in its efforts to salvage a share exchange and Arctic exploration agreement with Rosneft, the state-controlled Russian oil company.

headline: Ask the Experts About Autism
text: Half a million children with autism will become adults in the next decade, writes Amy Lennard Goehner in today’s Times Health Guide, and options to care for them are limited. The good news is that many states are providing more support for people with autism who live with their families and giving families greater flexibility and control over budgets.

headline: The ‘Modern Family’ Musical Is Not a Commentary on Anything
text: This is a purely theoretical sitcom subplot, from Wednesday’s episode of “Modern Family,” about a musical challenged by an incomprehensible second act, a supporting cast hobbled by injuries and a leading man left stranded in midair, and a single-minded director who is all but threatened with mutiny. That could only ever happen on television, not in real life.

headline: BP and Rosneft Extend Deal Deadline
text: With the deal looking tenuous, BP and Rosneft agreed to extend the deadline for their share swap agreement — pushing back the date to May 16 from April 14.

headline: Visiting the Festival From Home
text: Along with Sundance, the Tribeca Film Festival is leading the way with online and video-on-demand offerings.

headline: As Tribeca Festival Turns 10, Grumbling Subsides
text: Yikes! Is the Tribeca Film Festival’s 10th year already upon us? It was just the other day, it seems, that the festival barged into the neighborhood and, despite its good will, was greeted with a raised eyebrow by snooty cinephiles for its free-for-all mixture of art, entertainment and community development.

headline: Third British Journalist Is Arrested in Phone-Hacking Case
text: LONDON — Police officials said Thursday that they had arrested a third journalist in connection with an expanding case of phone-hacking by reporters at The News of the World, a British tabloid.

headline: A Reprieve for Western Water Users
text: Not quite five months ago, on Nov. 27, the level of Lake Mead, the massive federal reservoir that serves faucets and fields in Nevada, Arizona and California, hit an all-time low level of 1,081.85 feet above sea level. Seven feet lower, and the first water shortage ever would have been declared in the river’s lower basin.

text: Mark Kurlansky replies to readers’ questions about fishing and the state of the oceans.

headline: Search for Bodies Edges Closer to Crippled Nuclear Plant
text: The Japanese police moved their search for bodies closer to the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Thursday as workers continued to remove radioactive water from the facility.

headline: Critical Reports on Banks Weigh on Financial Shares
text: Financial shares tumbled on Thursday after government reports criticized banks involved in the mortgage crisis, but stocks in the broader market were little changed.

headline: Part 5: Answers to Readers’ Decision-Time Questions
text: All this week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

headline: Profile in Style | Ikram Goldman
text: For the Chicago-based retailer, whose eponymous store stocks the likes of Azzedine Alaïa (a close friend), Comme des Garçons and Nina Ricci, fashion is a family affair. Next month, the shop moves to a sprawling, multilevel space in the city’s Gold Coast area. ‘‘The first floor will feel like your mom’s supergiant closet,’’ Goldman says, while the second floor will contain a cafe and a gallery curated by Goldman and her husband, Josh. The third will house a playroom for their sons. Like the new store, the family’s River North home is filled with vintage and modern pieces, and is as inviting to designer-clad adults as it is to the high-chair set. Go to interactive >>

headline: Higher Energy Costs Push Up Producer Prices
text: Producer prices rose 0.7 percent in March, propelled by higher energy costs, in the third consecutive monthly increase of prices before they reach the consumer.

headline: Medicare on the Table
text: Probably no other federal program aside from Social Security has as much impact on older Americans and their families as Medicare, now front and center in the intensifying argument over the federal budget and deficit reduction.

headline: Almodóvar, Von Trier and Malick in Cannes Competition Lineup
text: We’re still not entirely sure what Terrence Malick‘s generational drama “The Tree of Life” will be, but we can safely say that it will be one of 19 new films contending for the Palme d’or at the Cannes Film Festival that were announced by the festival’s organizers on Thursday. Also on the feature competition slate for this year’s festival, which runs from May 11 to 22, are Pedro Almodóvar’s “La Piel Que Habito” (“The Skin I Live In”), starring Antonio Banderas as a plastic surgeon seeking his daughter’s rapists; “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” a drama directed by Lynne Ramsay (“Morvern Callar”) and starring Tilda Swinton and John C. Reilly; “Melancholia,” from the Danish filmmaker Lars Von Trier (“Antichrist”); “Sleeping Beauty,” from the novelist turned first-time filmmaker Julia Leigh; and “Ichimei” (“Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai”) from the Japanese director Takashi Miike. The festival’s opening night film, which is not shown in competition, is Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris.” Other features that will be shown out of competition this year include “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,” directed by Rob Marshall, and, just to make things interesting, Jodie Foster’s latest film, “The Beaver,” starring Mel Gibson.

headline: Climate, Communication and the ‘Nerd Loop’
text: 4:15 p.m. | Updated |Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and author who’s about as far from the label “nerd” as can be, had his Howard Beale “mad as hell” moment over climate miscommunication last week on his blog, The Benshi.

headline: Iron Mountain Names New C.E.O.
text: Iron Mountain, facing a proxy fight led by the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Thursday that its chairman, Richard Reese, would become chief executive, effective immediately.

headline: Up for Parole? Better Hope You’re First on the Docket
text: A new paper finds that experienced parole judges in Israel granted freedom about 65 percent of the time to the first prisoner who appeared before them on a given day. By the end of a morning session, the chance of release had dropped almost to zero.

headline: Théâtre du Châtelet Aims to Bring Broadway to Paris
text: PARIS — Since his first season as director of the venerable Théâtre du Châtelet in 2006, Jean-Luc Choplin has been seeking to marry the sophisticated with the popular, the daring with the safe.

text: The theory that people’s lives are principally focused on “production, exchange, and consumption.”

headline: Poetry Pairing | April 14, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Judging of Bonds Has Just Begun
text: Barry Bonds’s statistics cannot be erased. Bonds did not get away with his actions in federal court, where he was convicted of a count of obstruction of justice Wednesday. But in his era Bonds was allowed to stay on the field and hit 762 home runs and win seven Most Valuable Player awards.

headline: Questions Remain about ‘Normal Heart’ Staging
text: The producers of the coming Broadway premiere of “The Normal Heart” are referring to the show as a “presentation,” which has prompted more than a few potential audience members to ask whether it will be a staged reading — similar to the one-night-only “Normal Heart” benefit on Broadway last October — or a standard production where the actors will have memorized their lines.

headline: Playoff Preview: Eastern Conference
text: No. 1 Chicago Bulls (62-20) vs. No. 8 Indiana Pacers (37-45)The Bulls finished with 62 wins, the most since Michael Jordan left the organization. The Bulls captured championships in the five other seasons they captured at least 60 wins. Those teams were all led by Jordan. Derrick Rose, who will probably become the league’s youngest M.V.P. winner and would be a college senior at Memphis had he stayed, leads one of the N.B.A.’s most balanced rosters, anchored by the solid defenders Joakim Noah and Luol Deng under the first-year coach Tom Thibodeau. Indiana faces long odds in trying to become the fourth team to beat a top seeded team. The Pacers are in the playoffs for the first time in five years and are the only qualifiers with a losing record, but can still be considered a mild threat. They rallied after firing Jim O’Brien and attaching Frank Vogel as interim coach. Danny Granger is one of the league’s quality wing players, Darren Collison is one of the league’s quickest point guards and the center Roy Hibbert provides scoring and length.

headline: Fantasia in D
text: Nowhere was the contrast in views over health care stronger than on drugs. Obama called for using Medicare’s purchasing power to reduce drug costs; Paul Ryan, in his hissy fit response, held Medicare Part D — which specifically denies Medicare the ability to bargain — as an example of the cost savings that can be achieved through privatization (although he didn’t call it that.)

headline: Ugandan Opposition Leader Wounded During Protest
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — A former presidential candidate and leading opposition figure was shot Thursday by the military police during a modest street demonstration over rising commodity prices here in the Ugandan capital.

headline: Barbour Supports Budget Deal
text: As some conservatives in Congress and Tea Party activists across the country voice their opposition to the budget deal reached last week, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is defending the agreement as a good first step and urging Republicans to look at the bigger picture.

headline: Ready or Not
text: FOR those parents and school administrators who believe it is never too early for students to begin preparing for the PSAT and SAT, the College Board has begun offering a junior version of its marquee college-entrance exams — this one specifically for eighth graders.

headline: Arts Group Calls for Worldwide Sit-In for Ai Weiwei
text: Artists and curators will hold a sit-in outside Chinese embassies and consulates on Sunday to protest the detention of the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei. Mr. Ai was detained on April 3; on April 7, a Chinese official told The Times that he was being held on suspicion of “economic crimes.”

headline: A French Vote for More Bikes in the City
text: If you are cranky about all those bicycle paths popping up around the city, you might as well blame it on the French. City Hall legend has it that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a liking to the green-tinted lanes after seeing a successful bike network in action on a trip to Paris, which has embraced the two-wheeled lifestyle.

headline: Seeing Off the Space Shuttle, One Last Time

headline: Mitt Romney and the Nurdles
text: No sooner had Mitt Romney officially announced his intention to run for president then several commentators noted that the “R” in his newly introduced logo looks quite a bit like the AquaFresh logo.

headline: What Code-Breaking Scoop?
text: In his column “Secrecy in Shreds,” Bill Keller writes that The Chicago Tribune published the fact that the United States had broken the Japanese code and that The Tribune could be successfully prosecuted for such publication. I beg to differ. The Tribune never mentioned that its story was based on broken codes. In order for a successful prosecution, the government would have had to prove that the story was published with guilty knowledge. I do not believe The Tribune had such knowledge.

headline: Uncharitable Advice
text: The Ethicist says that “taking donations that other people made and passing them off as your own” would show an uncharitable spirit. In North Carolina, we call it fraud. There is no difference between defrauding your employer for a charitable reason or for a selfish one. While Ariel Kaminer’s analysis of how world tragedies can eclipse other genuine charitable efforts was enlightening, the real issue your correspondent raised was whether the noble purpose of enhancing contributions sanctions defrauding an employer. It does not.

headline: Bill to Speed Offshore Drilling Clears House Panel
text: Just a week before the one-year anniversary of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, legislation that would greatly speed the pace of offshore drilling permitting has been approved by the Republican-led House Natural Resources Committee.

headline: Ford Widens F-150 Recall by 1.2 Million Trucks
text: Under pressure from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford has agreed to recall an additional 1.2 million pickup trucks because the driver’s air bag may inadvertently deploy.

headline: Walcott Receives Waiver to Be Schools Chancellor
text: Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott was cleared Thursday by the state to become the next New York City schools chancellor.

headline: What Deals Could Glencore Make?
text: Glencore’s long-awaited filing for its initial public offering has ended one topic of speculation, only to stoke another: What deals will the commodities trader make?

headline: Zipcar Soars in Market Debut
text: 8:49 p.m. | Updated

headline: Official in Charge of Air Traffic Control Resigns
text: The official in charge of air traffic controllers for the Federal Aviation Administration resigned Thursday after a series of episodes in which controllers across the country slept as airplanes landed.

headline: Shortages of A.D.H.D. Medications?
text: Is your child taking Adderall or Ritalin? Have you had trouble filling their prescription in recent weeks?

headline: After Game 1, Capitals’ Semin Has a Lot to Talk About
text: WASHINGTON — Alexander Semin is something of an enigma. Semin, 27, a Siberian wing, appears to score at will on some nights while taking unnecessary penalties and being otherwise invisible on others. But if the Capitals are to defeat the Rangers in the first round of the 2011 Stanley Cup playoffs, Semin will almost certainly have to play a pivotal role.

headline: Media Executive to Run New Jersey Performing Arts Center
text: John Schreiber, a media executive, has been selected as the new president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, the center’s board announced on Thursday.

headline: Now Dazzling | Museo Soumaya in Mexico City
text: When the pop star Shakira toured Mexico City’s new Museo Soumaya, her guide was none other than the museum’s founder, Carlos Slim Helú. A labor of love from Slim, the world’s richest man (who is also a creditor and minority shareholder of The New York Times Company), the museum, named after Slim’s late wife, has certainly got the city — and the art world — talking. Since it opened a couple of weeks ago with a gala attended by President Calderón and Gabriel García Márquez, more than 30,000 curious locals and tourists per day have streamed through its doors. (The museum is free to the public.)

headline: Excerpt: 'Wonderland'
text: Janet Dacal and E. Clayton Cornelious in the number "Advice From a Caterpillar," from the new Broadway musical "Wonderland." (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Excerpt: 'High'
text: Kathleen Turner and Evan Jonigkeit in a scene from Matthew Lombardo's new Broadway play at the Booth Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: At Trial, Accuser Recalls, in Pieces, Night of Rape
text: There were certain things that she remembered from that night, and some things that she did not.

headline: J. & J. Unit Recalls Epilepsy Drug
text: For consumers who have been losing trust and patience with Johnson & Johnson over its manufacturing and quality control issues, the announcement of a recall on Thursday from a company unit that makes neurology drugs may seem all too familiar.

headline: Put a Poem in the Pocket of a Poobah
text: This is national Poem in Your Pocket Day. As always, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled a poem from his virtual pocket (his iPad) this morning and read it.

headline: Sony Pictures Classics to Distribute Polanski’s ‘Carnage’
text: If you can’t easily locate a pair of squabbling, overeducated married couples to eavesdrop on, and don’t want to move to New York to do it, you can head to your local movie theater in a few months. “Carnage,” Roman Polanski‘s film adaptation of Yasmina Reza’s play “God of Carnage,” has been acquired for distribution by Sony Pictures Classics, which said on Thursday that it plans to release the film at the end of the year. The stage version of “God of Carnage,” which in 2009 won the Tony Award for best play, chronicles two Brooklyn couples who are brought together by a playground fight between their children, leading to a night of arguing, drinking and vomiting. Its original Broadway cast featured Marcia Gay Harden (a Tony winner), James Gandolfini, Hope Davis and Jeff Daniels (all Tony nominees). The film features a script written by Mr. Polanski and Ms. Reza, and will star Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly.

headline: For Many Chinese Men, No Deed Means No Dates
text: BEIJING — In the realm of eligible bachelors, Wang Lin has a lot to recommend him. A 28-year-old college-educated insurance salesman, Mr. Wang has a flawless set of white teeth, a tolerable karaoke voice and a three-year-old Nissan with furry blue seat covers.

headline: And Now for Our Special Tonight: The Bartender
text: As an owner and principal manager of Mayahuel, an East Village bar and restaurant specializing in tequila and mescal, Philip Ward has his hands full. He’s there all the time, doing everything from staff scheduling to emergency plumbing.

headline: Eighth Graders: Sharpen Your No. 2 Pencils for a PSAT and SAT Scrimmage
text: In a column for this weekend’s Education Life supplement, I write about ReadiStep, a new standardized test from the College Board that is intended, at least in part, to familiarize eighth graders with the style of questions they’ll eventually find on the PSAT and SAT.

headline: Altoona Becomes ‘Pom Wonderful’ — For a Price
text: The documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock has found another catchy way to promote his next release, “The Greatest Movie Ever Sold,” which takes a wry look at product placement and the integration of brands in the plots of movies and TV shows.

headline: Infection Could Force Uncle Mo to Miss Derby
text: Uncle Mo has a gastrointestinal infection and may not run in the Kentucky Derby on May 7. The colt was the undefeated 2-year-old champion and the prohibitive 1-to-10 favorite in Saturday’s Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, but he ran poorly and finished third behind Toby’s Corner and Arthur’s Tale.

headline: Maya Collapse and Modern Society
text: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes about an expedition to Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan excavated the Maya site of Ceibal.

headline: An Outcome With No Winners
text: No matter what you think of Barry Bonds — and an understanding nod to whose who have been trying hard not to think of him at all — it was vaguely possible during his perjury trial to manage a smidgen of admiration for the complete stubbornness with which he approached his unmasking. Could anyone really sit through the revelation of the slimiest side of the steroid scene — his steroid scene — and remain the brick wall that Bonds did? But most likely, he lost even that by flashing a victory sign after it was over. Victory? Really?

headline: David Foster Wallace and the Literary Tax Accountant
text: Edmund Wilson was the leading literary critic of his generation. He was also an accomplished tax delinquent. From 1946 to 1955, Wilson did not file any income tax returns. Taxes were withheld from his salary at The New Yorker, but the proceeds from his best-selling novel “Memoirs of Hecate County” and other freelance work went to pay for his two divorces, three children and various houses. The Internal Revenue Service eventually caught up with him, hitting him with some $68,000 in back taxes and penalties. Even after his death in 1972, his wife was still dealing with the paperwork.

headline: Up Front: Tom McCarthy
text: Tom McCarthy, whose brainy, high-concept novels include “Remainder” and “C,” was among the corps of early readers who seized on “Infinite Jest,” David Foster Wallace’s postmodern masterpiece.

headline: David Foster Wallace: The Last Audit
text: It seems to me there are two ways of understanding the document assembled from a jumble of boxes, disks and printed or handwritten papers that, at the time of David Foster Wallace’s suicide in 2008, ran into the high hundreds of pages — a document that, conscientiously and intelligently whittled down by Wallace’s editor Michael Pietsch to 500-odd pages, is now being published under the title “The Pale King,” and, just as significantly, the subtitle “An Unfinished Novel.”

headline: Popcast: Paul Simon, Pruning the Grammys and More
text: In this week’s Popcast, Larry Rohter unravels the controversy over the decision by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences to narrow its Grammy Awards categories; Ben Sisario delivers a progress report on the celestial jukebox; and Jon Pareles explains Paul Simon’s best record in two decades. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: What’s in Your Belly Button?
text: Scientists at North Carolina State University have launched the Belly Button Biodiversity project, tracking a variety of microorganisms lurking in human navels, reports MSNBC.

headline: Breast Device Recall Made Most Severe
text: The recall of a medical device that left particles of tungsten in women’s breasts has been classified as the most serious type of recall, one involving “situations in which there is a reasonable probability that use of these products will cause serious adverse health consequences or death,” the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.

headline: New York School Districts Challenge State Mandates
text: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y. — A roomy yellow bus waited outside the high school in this affluent Long Island suburb, its door open to students headed home at the end of classes. Ten minutes later, it rolled away with 12 riders scattered among the 66 seats.

headline: Spotify Puts New Limits on Free Streaming
text: Spotify, the popular European streaming music service, is reducing the amount of music its users will be able to listen to for free, a move that may signal a compromise with record companies as Spotify tries to enter the American market.

headline: In Praise of Pink Polish
text: My inbox makes it clear that you want a chance to discuss boys and pink nail polish, aka “How a Photo of a Mom Spending Time with Her Son Fed the Culture Wars.”

headline: Seeing Things | Adam Silverman’s Reverse Archaeology
text: The Los Angeles potter Adam Silverman always dreams big, far beyond the scale of the distinctive pieces he makes for Heath Ceramics (where he is studio director of Heath Los Angeles) and for his own Atwater Pottery label. For most of the last year his latest dream has taken him to Fort Worth, where construction is underway on Renzo Piano’s addition to Louis Kahn’s iconic Kimbell Art Museum. Silverman, who studied architecture at the Rhode Island School of Design, was intrigued by the convergence of Piano and Kahn, two of his favorite architects. Add to the mix Tadao Ando’s new Fort Worth Modern museum next door to the Kimbell, and you have a triumvirate of design giants.

headline: Get Bad Loan Terms? Now You’ll Get Some Clues Why
text: Did you apply for a loan but receive a higher interest rate than you think you deserve? You’re now entitled to receive a few clues about how the lender arrived at its decision.

headline: Budget Deal Cuts Reverse Mortgage Counseling
text: One casualty of the latest federal budget deal: Funds for counseling older Americans seeking reverse mortgages, or loans that let those 62 and over tap their home equity.

headline: The Detroit Pistons’ New Private Equity Driver
text: Chris SchwartzTom Gores coaching a youth soccer team.

headline: Theater Talkback: Are Musicals Losing Their Voices?
text: “We didn’t need dialogue! We had faces!” The famous lines spoken by Gloria Swanson’s decrepit silent-movie goddess Norma Desmond sprang to mind the other night at Avery Fisher Hall during the New York Philharmonic’s concert version of “Company.” I imagined there might be a few old-time Broadway performers in the audience muttering similar sentiments to themselves as they watched Lonny Price’s vocally vacuous presentation of the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical. “Back in my day, we had voices!” I could picture one seething through his or her teeth to a colleague at intermission.

headline: Mayor Shows His Testy Side in Deposition for a Lawsuit
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was patronizing, telling a lawyer who quoted from his memoir that “your reading is good.” He was unsympathetic, saying that as a hard-driving and ultracompetitive boss, he considered those who left his company disloyal and “bad people.”

headline: N.F.L. and the Players Union See the Same Forest, but Different Trees

They do not want to expose their feet, which are covered with festering blisters from the water of the Ting River,” the article began. [The Guardian]

headline: How Parenting Matters

She previously wrote, “What Children Need,” an overview of research on child development. Several of Ms. Waldfogel’s research papers are available from the National Bureau of Economic Research.
