headline: Congress Passes Budget Bill, but Some in G.O.P. Balk
text: WASHINGTON — Congress voted Thursday to keep the government financed through September, putting an end to a raucous first skirmish in this year’s showdown between Democrats and Republicans over federal spending while presaging bigger ones to come.

headline: China’s Case Against Artist Cites Taxes, Paper Says
text: SHANGHAI — Ai Weiwei, the prominent Chinese artist and social critic who was detained by the police this month, is being investigated for tax evasion, destroying evidence and distributing pornography, according to a Hong Kong-based newspaper with close ties to Beijing.

headline: More About the Budget and Health
text: Here’s the article by David Ludwig about the relationship between technology and diet that started me down this path in the first place. Really good reading, and not at all technical. (The clinic that Ludwig runs at Children’s Hospital in Boston is dedicated to the evaluation and treatment of children who are overweight/obese and/or those with type 2 diabetes.)

headline: Phonetic Clues Hint Language Is Africa-Born
text: A researcher analyzing the sounds in languages spoken around the world has detected an ancient signal that points to southern Africa as the place where modern human language originated.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Uganda, Nepal and North Korea.

headline: Knicks Get an Unlikely Proponent: Reggie Miller
text: Reggie Miller, the former sharpshooting guard for the Indiana Pacers, holds no allegiance to either the Knicks or Boston Celtics. Miller, though, caused his share of heartbreak for both franchises, which makes him more than an interested bystander to the approaching first-round series between them.

headline: Libyan Port City Is Filled With Migrants Desperate to Exit
text: MISURATA, Libya — The man pressed close, patting the pockets of a foreigner, repeating a single word: “Food. Food. Food.”

headline: Now Serving | Tiny’s and the Bar Upstairs
text: Three years ago, Matt Abramcyk, 34, was standing around the bar of his now shuttered West Village spot, the Beatrice Inn, with siblings, Jack, 26, and Ana, 29. That night, the fiercely close clan decided to collaborate: Matt had the restaurant experience; Jack was Beatrice’s head bartender; Ana was “chief Champagne drinker,” and their father, Israel Abramcyk, who is known as Ray, held the real estate, a landmark TriBeCa townhouse he had owned for more than 20 years. Thus, Tiny’s and the Bar Upstairs were born.

headline: When the Devil Is in the Installation Details
text: In a story in Thursday’s Times, I write about the energy wasted when air-conditioners do not fit snugly through windows and walls. The dimensions of the problem are described in a report from the Urban Green Council titled ”There Are Holes in Our City’s Walls.”

headline: Medication-Related Injuries on the Rise
text: The number of people treated in hospitals in the United States for problems related to medication errors has surged more than 50 percent in recent years.

headline: Berkley to Run for Ensign’s Senate Seat
text: Representative Shelley Berkley, Democrat of Nevada, announced Thursday that she would seek the Senate seat held by John Ensign, a Republican who announced last month that he would not seek a third term to avoid what he predicted would be an “exceptionally ugly” campaign.

headline: Iraqi Youths Long for Their Own Moment in the ‘Arab Spring’
text: In Iraq, the youth-led uprisings across the Middle East have conjured a range of emotions. Resentment, for the fact that in Egypt and Tunisia and elsewhere the people are seemingly taking control of their future and with their own hands and voices are demanding and achieving change. Iraq, of course, required America’s guns and soldiers to topple an autocratic government. Empowerment, for the events have allowed officials here the confidence to tout their own democracy’s progress, however violent and fragile it still is. And finally, for the youths of Iraq, the inspiration to demand a more perfect country, despite facing an entrenched political elite that has stood in their way.

headline: The Tragic Death of the Flip
text: Day before yesterday, my jaw hit the floor, and I still haven’t managed to get it back up again.

headline: A Good Samaritan Is Accused of a Bad Deed

headline: Weather Satellites on the Chopping Block
text: As my colleagues Eric Lichtblau, Ron Nixon and I report in summary form in Thursday morning’s paper, the budget deal moving through Capitol Hill slashes funds that the Obama administration requested for a satellite program considered vital for the nation’s weather forecasting. That raises the prospect of less accurate forecasts and other problems, some of them potentially life-threatening, starting in 2016.

headline: An Animated City
text: The director Carlos Saldanha discusses setting the animated film "Rio" in his hometown.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: The Tragic Death of the Flip

headline: Pain of British Fiscal Cuts Could Inform U.S. Debate
text: LONDON — In the United States, the debate over how to cut the long-term budget deficit is just getting under way.

headline: YouTube Sentences Copyright Offenders to School
text: In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in the boys room in high school: You’re forced to take an online class at YouTube’s Copyright School.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Quantum of Solace'
text: Marc Forster, the director of “Quantum of Solace,” discusses a scene from the film.

headline: Speed on the Sea
text: Powerboat racing, a sport refashioned in the 1990s to draw spectators and advertisers, was recently showcased in Key West, Fla.

headline: Casting Complete for ‘Porgy and Bess,’ as Henry, Lewis and Grier Join McDonald
text: The American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., has completed the casting for “Porgy and Bess,” which it is presenting in a new adaptation by Suzan-Lori Parks and Diedre Murray. Joshua Henry, who starred in “The Scottsboro Boys” on Broadway will play Jake. Philip Boykin is Crown and Trista Dollison is Clara, who sings the signature song “Summertime.”

headline: Hearts, and Lives, Out of Step
text: LAST May I was like a balloon without a string, in desperate need of some tie to the earth. Set to graduate from college a semester early, I had no job lined up and no prospects. And I was suffering from the kind of acute loneliness that comes from dating college guys for whom the word “girlfriend” does not exist and whose idea of a proposal is sending a graphic, indecent late-night text message.

headline: Figuratively Speaking: Exploring How Metaphors Make Meaning
text: Overview | How are metaphors used in both writing and everyday life? What is the role of metaphors in shaping our reality? In this lesson, students raise their awareness of the prevalence and function of metaphors in our everyday language by investigating common metaphors in poetry and song, analyzing the use of metaphors in a variety of short texts and exploring the metaphors in use throughout their daily life.

headline: Video Shows Defense of Besieged Misurata
text: My colleague C.J. Chivers reports on Thursday from the besieged Libyan city of Misurata, which he reached on an aid ship chartered by the International Organization for Migration. .bbpBox{background:url(http://a1.twimg.com/profile_background_images/184718761/twitterBgroundImage.JPG) #395c3d;padding:20px;}

headline: Wrong Mail
text: I was going through my mail at work when I opened a card that began: “Dear Pooky Bear.” Horrified, I checked the envelope and saw that it was addressed to a co-worker and delivered to me by mistake. It was an affectionate note, probably from his girlfriend (a k a “Princess”), and while hardly pornographic, it was personal enough that he’d be mortified to know I read it. Should I deliver the note, or save us all the embarrassment and toss it?

headline: ARPA-E Is Poised to Put Products on the Grid
text: ARPA-E, the government’s incubator for high-risk energy inventions, has its first graduate in the electricity area — a new energy storage technology — and on Thursday it announced a preliminary agreement to get it tested.

headline: Mitch Daniels Opposes Arizona-Style Immigration Law
text: Is Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana, going to run for president in 2012?

headline: City Unemployment Rate Ticks Down to 8.7 Percent
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dropped to 8.7 percent in March, its lowest level in two years, as hiring continued at a steady pace, the state’s Labor Department reported Thursday.

headline: ‘Idol’ Rules Wednesday Night Ratings, Again
text: The eight remaining “American Idol” contenders performed music from movies on Wednesday as the reality competition lifted Fox to another easy victory in the prime time ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 22.4 million viewers tuned in to the 90-minute episode of “Idol” from 8 to 9:30 p.m. — nearly one full week after the show surprised many faithful watchers with the news that one of this season’s perceived front-runners, Pia Toscano, had been voted off.

headline: Get in the Swim
text: Sure, right at this moment you are probably still wearing a coat. And a scarf. And boots. But if you wait until it’s 70 degrees outside to start shopping for a bikini, chances are what you will find in the stores are next fall’s coats and scarves and boots. To get you started, here is a guide to the season’s splashiest swimwear trends. From Bottega Veneta’s technicolor suits to nautical stripes to retro boy-short styles from SUNO, unleash your inner Gidget — or CZ Guest or Kate Bosworth.

headline: Beating Tumor, Then Live at the Apollo
text: Danion Jones, 6, who used music to get through a 3-year battle with a brain tumor, sang Wednesday night at “Amateur Night at The Apollo.”

headline: An iPhone Case for Gordon Gekko
text: Upholding the belief that bigger is better, Thumbs Up, a British gadget and novelty company, is offering an iPhone case that resembles the “brick,” the infamous chunky cellphone that became a status symbol in the ’80s.

headline: ABC Cancels ‘All My Children’ and ‘One Life to Live’
text: The demise of one of broadcasting’s oldest institutions, the daytime soap opera, crept closer Thursday as ABC announced it would end two of its long-running daily serial dramas, “All My Children” and “One Life to Live.”

headline: My Week With Woody Allen
text: Woody Allen’s new film, “Midnight in Paris,” will be the opening film at the Cannes Film Festival on May 11; looking even further into the future, Alec Baldwin, Penelope Cruz, Ellen Page and Jesse Eisenberg appear to be part of the ensemble for Allen’s next film, which will be shot in Rome to continue his European themes of recent years.

headline: Judge Says Blagojevich Cannot See Notes From Obama Interview
text: CHICAGO – A judge ruled on Thursday that lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, cannot view notes from an interview President Obama had with federal authorities over his former Senate seat.

headline: A Misleading View on Corporate Taxes
text: The Business Roundtable, a group comprising 200 of the largest companies in the United States, is out with a “study” that claims to show that the United States levies excessively high tax rates on companies. It actually shows nothing of the kind.

headline: A Weekend in Amsterdam
text: Exploring the city’s recent pockets of innovation are worth the detour.

headline: 36 Hours in Amsterdam
text: MOST visitors to Amsterdam rarely wander beyond the arched bridges, watery passageways and crooked canal houses of the enchanting city center. But equally fascinating is the development boom around the harbor and in the once gritty areas that lie between the historic center and the surrounding ring road (A10). These pockets of innovation — pioneered Brooklyn-style by young designers and entrepreneurs who cannot afford the rents on the Keizersgracht — are worth a detour. To explore them, just act like a local: hop on a bike and go.

headline: Egyptian Military to Review Cases of Jailed Protesters
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s ruling military council said Thursday it would review court verdicts handed down to hundreds of civilians detained since it took power after President Hosni Mubarak stepped down on Feb. 11.

headline: Sloppy Mets Make a Mess of Their First Homestand
text: On the eve of the 2011 season, Terry Collins, the Mets’ energetic and passionate new manager, said it was vital for the team to get off to a good start in order to instill confidence in the players, and also to demonstrate to the fans that things had changed for the better.

headline: Belarus Officials’ Details on Bombing Raise Questions, Too

headline: Rangers Look to Staal to Shut Down Ovechkin

In the Capitals’ 2-1 series-opening victory in overtime Wednesday, the two crashed into each other, tied each other up, and pushed and shoved angrily before disengaging and preparing for another collision.

headline: Knockouts
text: The brutal beauty of the boxer has long been captured by photographers and filmmakers, most memorably in Bruce Weber’s 1987 cult favorite, “Broken Noses.” Following in this romanticized style comes “Repton Boxing Club,” a short documentary by Alasdair McLellan, the Britain-based fashion photographer. MeLellan’s film — sponsored by Sunspel, a historic English underwear manufacturer — centers on a storied boxing club in London’s East London and in particular on Ryan Pickard, the young, squinty-eyed knockout of a narrator. Pickard and his brother spar and sweat like sprinklers in the sun-drenched ring, wearing singlets, tees and fine cotton boxer shorts from the classic Sunspel line. With training time done, Ryan and his mates head to the local cafe to “get away from the missus,” show off their tattoos and debate who’s the greatest fighter of all time. A day in the life of a fighting lad.

headline: Budget Compromise Slashes Funding for Weather Satellites
text: The budget deal moving through Capitol Hill slashes funds that the Obama administration requested for a satellite program considered vital for the nation’s weather forecasting. That raises the prospect of less accurate forecasts and other problems, some of them potentially life-threatening, starting in 2016. Jane Lubchenco, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, warned at a Senate hearing on Wednesday that the cutbacks would probably lead to a serious gap in satellite data, undermining National Weather Service forecasts. Read more on Green.

headline: ‘The Mountaintop’ Will Come to Broadway
text: “The Mountaintop,” Katori Hall’s play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will make it to Broadway this fall, but with only one of the two high-profile actors who were expected to appear in it. Producers for the play said on Thursday that Samuel L. Jackson, the Academy Award-nominated star of “Pulp Fiction,” would portray Dr. King in the production, to be presented at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, with previews beginning Sept. 22 and an opening on Oct. 13; Kenny Leon, a Tony Award nominee for last year’s revival of “Fences,” will direct. Halle Berry, who was supposed to play Camae, a hotel maid at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis in Ms. Hall’s imagined account of the night before Dr. King’s assassination, will not be participating in the production as had been anticipated. In a statement, producers said, “Ms. Berry would not be appearing in the role due to child-custody issues.” “The Mountaintop,” which made its debut in London in 2009, won Ms. Hall the Olivier Award for best new play last year.

headline: A Country Searching for Engineers to Serve Its Nuclear Needs
text: NEW DELHI — Besides political protests, India’s nuclear energy ambitions face another big roadblock, critics say: a shortfall of trained people to run, repair and regulate power plants.

headline: A Fantasy World of Strange Feuding Kingdoms
text: With the amount of money apparently spent on “Game of Thrones,” the fantasy epic set in a quasi-medieval somewhereland beginning Sunday on HBO, a show like “Mad Men” might have the financing to continue into the second term of a Malia Obama presidency. “Game of Thrones” is a cast-of-at-least-many-hundreds production, with sweeping “Braveheart” shots of warrior hordes. Keeping track of the principals alone feels as though it requires the focused memory of someone who can play bridge at a Warren Buffett level of adeptness. In a sense the series, which will span 10 episodes, ought to come with a warning like, “If you can’t count cards, please return to reruns of ‘Sex and the City.’ ”

headline: An Intimate Setting For a Range of Intensity
text: There is a very particular relationship between dancer and audience in a small space: emotions and expressions are palpable, effort and intensity clear. That’s the advantage of the tiny theater in the basement of the Museum of Arts and Design, where the monthly series Dance Under the Influence began in February. The disadvantage is that the stage is just eight feet deep. As Ronald K. Brown, one of the performers on the program Wednesday night, put it after the show, “You can’t really do a diagonal.”

headline: The Language, and Footwork, of Farewell
text: Dance Theater Workshop’s final season is drawing to a close. Who knows what the future holds for New York Live Arts, as the institution will be called upon merging with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company? But it is a pleasure to report that with “The Making of Americans,” the last workshop commission to have its premiere on the main stage, a very special theater is going out on a very high note.

headline: Frenetic Intimations of, Yes, Positivity
text: TV on the Radio’s frontman, Tunde Adebimpe, liked the view from the stage at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. “Many tiers, many levels,” he said. “Speaking of many, many levels ... ,” he said, trailing off as the band started the hurtling beat and buzzing synthesizer bass line of the next song, “Dancing Choose.” TV on the Radio’s longtime mission has been to pack its songs with as many levels and layers of sound and sense as they can hold. It crams together funk and rock, soul and punk, anthem and noise, insight and rant, apocalypse and dance frenzy, brains and muscle.

headline: Forward-Looking Sculptures by a Man Straddling Two Worlds
text: In the decades before World War II, many artists were thrilled by the steel- and fossil-fuel-based technology embodied in trains, planes and automobiles, and edifices like the Eiffel Tower and the Chrysler Building. Few were more inspired by the promises of industrial modernity than the sculptor John Storrs.

headline: Paradise Is Only Half the Story in a Complex Caribbean Nation
text: Ian Thomson’s book “The Dead Yard,” a bleak and prickly survey of Jamaica’s past and present, takes its title from one of that country’s funeral practices. When someone dies, those who loved him or her gather around the dead person’s house for a wake that can last as long as nine days. These events are often ecstatic; they’re akin to reggae versions of a New Orleans jazz funeral. People dance, the author writes, as if possessed by ghosts.

headline: Italian Activist Kidnapped in Gaza
text: Update | 8:57 p.m. After this post was originally published, a Hamas security official told Reuters and The Associated Press that an Italian peace activist kidnapped in Gaza has been killed. The official said that the Italian activist’s body was found in an abandoned house after midnight local time and two men were arrested. My colleague Fares Akram in Gaza is working to confirm these reports and will have more information soon in his new article.

headline: Two Points of View, Miles Apart
text: IT might be simplistic or a little silly to say that Robert Whitman — the performance pioneer who is probably the least known member of the vanguard that gave birth to the American experimental theater scene in the 1960s — basically foretold the creation of the Internet in his work. But when you consider the evidence, it’s hard not to believe he created it himself. Decades before YouTube and years before the video camera became a common artist’s tool, Mr. Whitman, a kind of junkman of fleeting imagery, extolled the virtues of television “as a great way to collect stuff; besides what’s on the air, a camera on anything brings it in live.” In 1972, in “News,” the first of his telephone pieces, he enlisted people around the city to use pay phones to call in descriptions of what they were doing or seeing at that moment, which the radio station WBAI broadcast live, a kind of aural Twitter stream. In one of his earliest theater pieces, “American Moon,” in 1960, he split the audience apart in separate tunnels to give each person a slightly different sense of the action. In doing so, he fulfilled what the curator Lynne Cook once described as his distinctive desire to work “collectively to construct an experience intended for the solitary individual,” a phrase that could just as well describe a lot of the social and cultural architecture of the Web.

headline: ‘The World’s Largest Dinosaurs’

headline: In Dinosaur Science, Size Is Just the Beginning
text: Before entering the fascinating new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, “The World’s Largest Dinosaurs,” which opens on Saturday, walk through the Hall of Saurischian Dinosaurs where the composite skeleton of the Apatosaurus reigns, the core of its 140-million-year-old frame seeming almost incidental to its stupendously sweeping neck and tail. The weighty immensity of these fossilized bones once earned this creature — one of the largest to have plodded the planet — the name of thunder lizard (Brontosaurus).

headline: ‘The Mountaintop’ Will Come to Broadway, With Jackson but Without Berry
text: “The Mountaintop,” Katori Hall’s play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will make it to Broadway this fall, but with only one of the two high-profile actors who were expected to appear in it. Producers for the play said on Thursday that Samuel L. Jackson, the Academy Award-nominated star of “Pulp Fiction,” will portray Dr. King in the production, which will be presented at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, with previews beginning Sept. 22 and opening Oct. 13; Kenny Leon, a Tony Award nominee for last year’s revival of “Fences,” will direct. Halle Berry, who was supposed to play Camae, a hotel maid at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis in Ms. Hall’s imagined account of the night before Dr. King’s assassination, will not be participating in the production as had been anticipated. In a statement, producers said “Ms. Berry would not be appearing in the role due to child custody issues,” and that an actor for the role “will be announced shortly.” “The Mountaintop,” which made its debut in London in 2009, won Ms. Hall the Olivier Award for best new play last year. The play is produced by Jean Doumanian Productions, Sonia Friedman Productions, Ambassador Theater Group, Jerry Frankel, Ted Snowdon, Bob Bartner and Tom Wirtshafter.

headline: Sketches From the Man Of Steel
text: Few artists have pushed drawing to such sculptural and even architectural extremes as Richard Serra. He has magnified the medium with immense black shapes that sit directly on the wall, their absorptive darkness forcing the space around them to expand or contract. Using black oil paintstick, he has exaggerated drawing’s physical surface, creating expanses of texture that have the rough tactility of bark, or massing dark, roiled spheres as thick as mud pies.

headline: History’s Loose Ends, and a Tightening Noose
text: I happened to see “The Conspirator,” a new historical drama directed by Robert Redford, on the day that the Obama administration, reversing its earlier position, announced that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others would be tried by a military tribunal for their suspected roles in the Sept. 11 attacks. This coincidence underscored the film’s topical relevance, which was hardly obscure to begin with. Its theme is the rule of law in the aftermath of a national tragedy, the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, who died on this date — April 15 — in 1865. What might have been an antiquarian courtroom drama or a belated eruption of Bush-era civil libertarian outrage has been given potent and painful currency by recent events.

headline: Pawn, Prize and Beauty, So Submit She Must
text: There are times when the lights are low and the bodices have been gently loosened that “The Princess of Montpensier,” a rousing amalgam of ambition, moods and genre conceits, looks like one of those old-fashioned diversions in which swords clang as bosoms heave with sweet passion. The pretty bosom of the title character played by Mélanie Thierry tends to swell rather gently, but it also rides so high in her dresses that it evokes the temptations displayed in the windows of Parisian patisseries. The French director Bertrand Tavernier deploys some smart ideas in this film, a period story about wars on the battlefield and those closer to home, but there’s something a bit goatish in his attention to some female charms.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: As Jim Morrison sang, “People are strange.” And no one knows that better than the Coney Island Museum. Its Congress of Curious Peoples, also sponsored by the Morbid Anatomy Library, wraps up on Saturday and Sunday with a symposium featuring experts on the art of curiosities and a visit to Sideshows by the Seashore. “The Fairground and the Museum: Human Anatomy on Display,” “The 19th Century Dime Museum in the Contemporary Imagination” and “Science and Technology for Public Amusement” are a few of the themes that will be discussed by scholars like Norman M. Klein, author of “The Vatican to Vegas: A History of Special Effects,” and Alison Griffiths, author of “Shivers Down Your Spine: Cinema, Museums & the Immersive View.” ($25; sideshow visit, $10; Coney Island Museum, 1208 Surf Avenue, near West 12th Street, Brooklyn; (718) 372-5159, spectacularium.org/congress-of-curious-peoples.)

headline: ‘Something New and Sparkly’
text: HAVING lived primarily in postwar high-rises, Jordan Kingston envisioned a charming brownstone as her next home. An entire ground floor would be best, with a garden out back and a “welcoming door that I could put a wreath on” for the holidays, she said.

headline: Fortunes and Misfortunes of War, From a Danish Perspective
text: The history of modern war is also, in part, the history of the means by which war has been brought home to noncombatants. Certain conflicts became known through — and are now remembered by — specific image-making technologies. The Civil War is identified with the battlefield photographs of Mathew Brady and others; World War II coincided with the maturation of motion pictures; Vietnam came into American living rooms via television. In each case the specific properties of a given medium helped to shape public perception of the war and its effects.

headline: Émigrés in New York Who Aren’t Outsiders
text: The Manhattan subculture of upscale bohemian émigrés examined in “The Imperialists Are Still Alive!” is a world that, so far as I know, hasn’t been explored from the inside with any depth. As you observe its central character, Asya (Élodie Bouchez), an ambitious conceptual artist, zip around New York in cabs and limousines, visiting art galleries and popping into parties, a multicultural vision of urbanity coalesces that is very different from that of a typical movie of impoverished immigrants trying to assimilate in an outer borough.

text: As the trial began last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the lawyers for three West African defendants made a series of highly unusual admissions: One after another, they told the jury that their clients were involved in the global drug trade.

headline: Inaugural Spenders Will Pay Rahm’s Party Tab
text: Big-money donors will pay up to $50,000 for exclusive access to premium events celebrating Rahm Emanuel’s inauguration next month, but the public will benefit, too, because those large contributions will also finance free events open to all.

headline: A Tea Party Congressman Cultivates His Base
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Psychologist Who Cleared Death Row Inmates Is Reprimanded
text: A psychologist who examined 14 inmates who are now on Texas’ Death Row — and two others who were subsequently executed — and found them intellectually competent enough to face the death penalty, agreed on Thursday never to perform such evaluations again. Lawyers for the 14 inmates hope the agreement will help their clients, who they argue are mentally handicapped, to escape lethal injection.

headline: Red State Home Companion
text: POCATELLO, Idaho – It gets pretty lonely out here on the lava beds of the Snake River Plain if you’re looking for something other than a right-wing rant for company on the car radio. From Twin Falls to Idaho Falls, Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity, Laura Ingraham and Glenn Beck rule the airwaves. Beck is on two stations in Pocatello, case you missed one of his conspiracy theories.

headline: Trump Mulls Announcement on ‘Apprentice’
text: Donald Trump acknowledges that he has “a very tough decision” to make regarding his potential run for president as a Republican candidate, but he has a plan for how and when he may make it.

headline: School District Considers Property Tax Increase, and Layoffs if It Is Rejected
text: The Chicago Public Schools are considering an $80 million property-tax increase as they try to close a budget deficit now estimated at $820 million, and they may have to lay off more than 2,000 teachers and increase class sizes without it, according to internal documents obtained by the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Let Us Eat Fish
text: Seattle

headline: The Shrieks Continue
text: Like its predecessors, “Scream 4” replaces the values of storytelling and suspense with the value of being in on the joke. Unfortunately, in the 11 years since “Scream 3,” the joke has gotten pretty old.

headline: The Guns of Academe
text: Los Angeles

headline: A CD-Only Music Store That Plays to Its Own Beat
text: One of these days, Chris Miller is going to run out of space for compact discs at his CD-only music shop, Chicago Digital, in Oak Park. Last week he had to put a second shelf in the restroom. It extends from the top of the toilet’s water tank to the ceiling and accommodates classical composers from Liszt, Franz, through Mozart, W. A.

headline: A Motley Consensus on the Afghanistan Line Item
text: It isn’t every day that liberals like Representative Jim McGovern, a Democrat from Massachusetts, appear at Capitol Hill news conferences with conservative stalwarts like Representative Walter B. Jones, a Republican from North Carolina.

headline: Despite Setbacks, Arizona Sheriff Won’t Yield the Spotlight
text: MESA, Ariz. — It is not uncommon for law enforcement agencies to have helicopters and planes to patrol from above, but Joe Arpaio, the sheriff of Maricopa County, has created what he calls his own air force: a collection of 30 private planes that his “air posse” uses to track illegal immigrants and drug smugglers.

headline: 16 Officers Arrested in Mexico Deaths
text: MEXICO CITY — The authorities have arrested 16 police officers and charged them with protecting a criminal gang suspected of murdering dozens of people and dumping their bodies in farmland about 90 miles south of the Texas border.

headline: In Miami, There is Smoke, but No Fire for the Heat
text: MIAMI — With a roster headlined by LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, the Miami Heat, at least in theory, has enough star power to effortlessly rally a city and pump up a crowd.

headline: Macaw Finds His Wings, and Much More, in Brazil
text: Maybe it was just a longing for warmer climes and spring’s arrival, but Fox’s “Rio” had a killer opening overseas. Maybe it was because this animated feature effort is a significant step forward from the studio’s “Ice Age” films, in the richness of its cast, the exuberance of its music and the vibrance of its palette. Or maybe it was because the director, Carlos Saldanha, is from Rio de Janeiro, the principal setting, bringing a wealth of affection to it. Whichever. It works.

headline: Unruly G.O.P. Puts Boehner to a Test in Budget Vote
text: WASHINGTON — It should have been a moment of victory for Speaker John A. Boehner and fellow members of a House Republican leadership team still learning on the job as they forced through a record level of spending cuts. Instead, it felt a little like defeat.

headline: Spending Agreement Hurts Police and Fire Agencies
text: It may have kept the federal government from shutting down, but the budget agreement that President Obama struck with Congress will make it harder for some struggling cities to keep their police stations and firehouses staffed.

headline: Lincoln Declares War
text: Lincoln’s Proclamation of April 15 is not a literary masterpiece. Nor was it trying to be. There was more urgent business to attend to — namely, the raising of 75,000 volunteers to defend Washington from attack. And yet, like every public document that issued from his pen, it is suffused with the particular phrasings of his mind. When seen in its handwritten version, below, courtesy of the Library of Congress, it is more clearly something that came from him, and not simply the great bureaucracy he personified as president. There are deletions, and inserts, and all the signs of a writer struggling to get it just right.

headline: Ethical Businesses With a Better Bottom Line
text: On Tuesday, I wrote about B Corps, or benefit corporations.  These are companies that have changed their bylaws to take into account the impact of their decisions on the environment, community and employees, as well as profits.  To become a B Corp, a company must also get a passing score on an assessment of its business practices administered by a nonprofit group called B Lab.  About 400 companies have become B Corps, and the idea is spreading fast.

headline: Japan Opposition Leader Urges Premier to Resign
text: TOKYO — The leader of Japan’s largest opposition party called Thursday for Prime Minister Naoto Kan to resign, abruptly ending an uneasy political truce forged after the devastating earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Budget Deal Fuels Revival of School Vouchers
text: In the 11th-hour compromise to avoid a government shutdown last week, one concession that President Obama made to Republicans drew scant attention: he agreed to finance vouchers for Washington students to attend private schools.

headline: Family Portrait
text: The flashback gets so much use in filmmaking that sometimes it just feels like a lazy way to spring a surprise or give a thinly drawn character an excuse for his actions. But in “The First Beautiful Thing,” the Italian director Paolo Virzì gambles his whole film on the well-worn technique and comes out a winner.

headline: This Lady Liberty Is a Las Vegas Teenager
text: As if further proof were needed that New York is not the center of the universe.

headline: Syrian Government Offers Mixed Message to Protesters
text: CAIRO — Ahead of another day of planned antigovernment protests on Friday, President Bashar al-Assad’s government in Syria took several steps — including announcing an amnesty for some prisoners — to try to satisfy the growing numbers of demonstrators who have taken to the streets in recent weeks.

headline: Cellphone Calls May Offer Insight Into Serial Killer
text: Shortly after a 24-year-old prostitute went missing in July 2009, a mysterious male caller used her cellphone to repeatedly taunt her teenage sister, and, in one harrowing conversation, confess to her murder, several people with knowledge of the phone calls said.

headline: Galleon Chief Put Millions Into Fund of Ex-Employee
text: 9:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Arthur Marx, Who Wrote About Groucho, Dies at 89
text: Arthur Marx, who wrote screenplays for film and television and a best-selling book about his father, “Life With Groucho,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: Tangled Verdict Gives Bonds Defense Hope
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The lawyers for Barry Bonds did not consider it a failure that he was convicted Wednesday of obstructing justice for giving evasive answers to a grand jury more than seven years ago.

headline: Randy Wood, Founder of Dot Records, Dies at 94
text: Randy Wood, who started out stocking records in a nook of his electrical appliance store before going on to found Dot Records, a label that found success in the 1950s recording white artists like Pat Boone singing black artists’ rhythm-and-blues songs, died on Saturday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 94.

headline: Stop the Blame Game
text: After more than two weeks under attack by NATO forces, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is still slaughtering his people and showing no sign that he plans to give up. NATO and coalition partners are pointing fingers of blame at each other for this frustrating state of affairs, but what they should be doing is creating a renewed sense of common purpose and direction.

headline: Colorful Lives and Tragic Deaths
text: Yet another love letter to a Hollywood long gone, “Footprints” swoons over its familiar locations so exorbitantly that only those who live close by (like the film’s writer and director, Steven Peros) are likely to share its rapt gaze.

headline: They Gather Secretly at Night, and Then They (Shhh!) Eat
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Along with big-wave surfing and high-altitude ultramarathons, eating is an extreme sport here. Which explains why, on a recent Saturday night, Tipay Corpuz, 21, a technology specialist for Apple, took a break from blogging about her obsession with fried chicken and waffles to join 2,500 fellow food geeks at the Underground Night Market.

headline: An Undemocratic Bailout
text: Portugal needs international help to meet its debt obligations. But the insistence by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund that the caretaker Portuguese government commit to a long-term plan of fiscal austerity and economic reform in exchange for a rescue package is misguided.

headline: The Republican Medicare Reshuffle
text: Representative Paul Ryan and the House Republicans are portraying their budget proposal for the next fiscal year as a courageous effort to finally bring federal spending on Medicare under control. An analysis issued last week by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office finds that the Ryan proposal would sharply reduce federal spending — but at the price of shifting more of Medicare’s costs onto beneficiaries and their families.

headline: At Nursing Homes, Fears of a Budget ‘Armageddon’
text: The Texas Legislature is faced with a budget challenge that has pitted the Republican majority’s desire to cut government spending against a vulnerable target: nursing homes.

headline: Memo to Arizona Republicans: Papers, Please
text: The Republicans who control the Arizona Legislature are back at it. The Senate just passed a bill that would bar presidential candidates from the ballot in Arizona unless they submitted extensive paperwork proving they were natural-born Americans.

headline: A Younger Group for Feminine Products
text: “Some girls get their period as young as 8,” begins a section for mothers on a Web site by Kotex, the feminine products brand. “Have you had the talk?”

headline: Bryant Should Have Been Forced to Sit
text: If the N.B.A. really did care, as its slogan suggests, Kobe Bryant would be sitting out Game 1 of the Los Angeles Lakers’ playoff series Sunday against the New Orleans Hornets.

headline: Arrested Development and Second Chances
text: The title character of Garth Donovan’s “Phillip the Fossil” walks a meandering line between antihero and hero. A superannuated New England townie — at 29 (or so), he might as well be 50 to the teenagers he hangs out with — Phillip sells steroids to the local jocks and has sex with high school girls while also trying to turn his life around by taking over a landscaping business.

headline: Pressure Grows to Unwind CVS Merger
text: CVS Caremark is coming under increasing pressure from consumer groups and shareholders to split up, at the same time that federal and state regulators are looking into accusations of anticompetitive behavior by the merged company.

headline: Equality in Numbers, but Not in Political Clout
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Ex-Mob Boss Tells Jury, Calmly, About Murders
text: The cross-examination of a Mafia turncoat started quietly and predictably enough on Thursday. Joseph C. Massino, the former boss of the Bonanno crime family, spoke matter-of-factly about having to kill one of his closest associates, simply because he had disobeyed protocol.

headline: Price of Tomatoes Has a Lot to Do With These Thefts
text: The high price of produce, especially for tomatoes after the deep winter freezes, has attracted more than heightened attention from consumers. A ring of sophisticated vegetable bandits was watching, too.

headline: The Business Market Plays Cloud Computing Catch-Up
text: The big spenders on technology are businesses and government agencies. They buy about 75 percent of the computing goods and services sold worldwide. Yet it is increasingly evident they are not driving the new ideas, excitement and powerhouse technology companies in ascent these days.

headline: A Boon for Nannies, if Only They Knew
text: Patricia Francois prowled the American Museum of Natural History on a recent afternoon, looking for nannies. She spotted two, with their charges, sitting in the inky gloaming beneath the famous blue whale, and zeroed in.

headline: Rumors of the Democrats’ Demise in the Senate are Slightly Exaggerated
text: Are Republicans favorites to take back the Senate next year?

headline: Obama Goes to Chicago to Talk Money, and Raise It
text: CHICAGO — President Obama, having drawn battle lines with Republicans over how to cut the deficit, returned to his political home here Thursday for a fund-raising visit, bringing the message of fiscal responsibility and core Democratic values he laid out in a speech a day earlier.

headline: World Bank and I.M.F. Discuss Inequality in Middle East
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank once hailed Tunisia’s economic reforms, noting the country’s increasing prosperity over the last decade.

headline: Bankers Named Who Doubted Madoff
text: A new federal bankruptcy court filing on Thursday showed that three current members of JPMorgan Chase’s executive committee had discussed, as early as June 2007, the possibility that Bernard L. Madoff was running a Ponzi scheme — as, indeed, he was — but took no action to protect investors or alert regulators.

headline: Jackson’s Farewell Tour Could End Where It Began
text: When Phil Jackson visited Chicago’s United Center in December for the Los Angeles Lakers’ lone regular-season appearance, he stayed away from the farewells and the reminiscing that the occasion otherwise demanded. Six of his 11 championship banners as a coach hang from the rafters there, but Jackson was not in the mood to go on and on about Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen as he moves toward the conclusion of his coaching career.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 14, 2011

headline: Adventures in the Drug Trades
text: Billy Corben, the director of “Cocaine Cowboys,” continues his adventures in the drug trades with “Square Grouper,” a curiously inert documentary about pot smuggling in South Florida in the 1970s and ’80s. (A square grouper is a bale of marijuana.)

headline: C.I.A. Sued for Failure to Release Bay of Pigs History
text: A group in Washington sued the C.I.A. on Thursday over its failure to release its history of the Bay of Pigs invasion, the United States-sponsored effort to topple Fidel Castro in 1961. The group, the National Security Archive, filed a Freedom of Information Act request for the five-volume history in 2005, but says it never received the required response. Only one volume has been released.

headline: Study Ties Suicide Rate in Work Force to Economy
text: The suicide rate increased 3 percent in the 2001 recession and has generally ridden the tide of the economy since the Great Depression, rising in bad times and falling in good ones, according to a comprehensive government analysis released Thursday.

headline: Iraq: U.N. Says 34 Iranians Killed at Exile Camp
text: The United Nations confirmed the claims of an Iranian dissident group on Thursday that dozens of Iranian exiles were killed by Iraqi security forces last week at a camp north of Baghdad. A spokesman for the United Nations said that 34 members of the group, the People’s Mujahedeen, had been killed near Camp Ashraf, in Diyala Province. The statement contradicted the claims of Iraqi officials, who denied that Iraqi security forces fired on the group.

headline: Russia: Jehovah’s Witness Acquitted of Incitement
text: A Jehovah’s Witness charged in connection with distributing religious literature was found not guilty of “inciting religious hatred and enmity” on Thursday after a six-month trial in the Siberian city of Gorno-Altaisk. The defendant, Aleksandr Kalistratov, said he hoped the verdict “will be useful for my fellow believers, who continue to be persecuted in Russia.” Nearly a dozen other cases are being pursued against Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia.

headline: Friday: Celebrity Guest Blogger Dana Delany
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — If you do the New York Times crossword puzzle every day, you know that some of them are light repasts and some of them are multicourse feasts. Now that it’s Friday, we have survived another week of puzzle challenges, and I consider this one by Patrick Berry a sweet finish to the weekday hustle. An AFTER-DINNER MINT, if you will.

headline: A Boy and His Steed, Far From Humane Society
text: It’s swoon time, ladies and gentlemen. Joey, the current marquee topper at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, is the kind of matinee idol New York hasn’t seen in ages. Tall, high-strung and handsome, with chestnut hair and eyes that catch the light, this strapping leading man is so charismatic you can imagine fans of both sexes lining up at the stage door with bouquets. Or maybe lumps of sugar and handfuls of hay.

headline: Hard Times in Philadelphia
text: Five young job seekers in Philadelphia describe how the current financial meltdown has hurt their prospects.

headline: A Life Rescued
text: Injured in a car accident and near death, a legal immigrant without insurance experienced a medical deportation.

headline: T.V.A. Agrees to Shutter 18 Generators That Use Coal
text: In a sweeping legal settlement, the Tennessee Valley Authority has agreed for the first time to reduce its overall capacity to generate coal-fired electricity, promising to close 18 of its coal-burning generators over the next six years while spending $3 billion to $5 billion on pollution controls on any remaining units that use coal.

headline: Obama Puts Deficit Ball Back in Pentagon’s Court
text: WASHINGTON — When Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates disclosed his new military budget plan in January, he ordered $78 billion in cuts over five years, on top of several hundred billion dollars in savings already found by canceling weapons programs and identifying business efficiencies.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Who’s Serious Now?
text: Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, sounds upset. And you can see why: President Obama, to the great relief of progressives, has called his bluff.

headline: In Her Childhood Dream, a Funeral Home Was the Destination
text: Lisa S. Dozier was 7 when she saw her first dead body.

headline: Subpar 4: Tour Pro Needs 16 Strokes to Finish Hole
text: Kevin Na scored a 16 at the ninth hole of the Texas Open in San Antonio on Thursday, the worst score on a par-4 hole in PGA Tour history. But it could have been worse.

headline: Former Tunisian Leader Faces Legal Charges
text: Former President Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia, who fled the country after a popular uprising forced him out in January, is now facing 18 legal cases, Tunisia’s official news agency said Thursday.

headline: Ultimate Spoiler Alert
text: President Obama and Paul Ryan are two of the smartest, most admirable and most genial men in Washington. It is sad, although not strange, that in today’s Washington they have never had a serious private conversation. The president has never invited Ryan over even for lunch.

headline: ‘War Horse’
text: Photos from the production at Lincoln Center Theater.

headline: Senator Took Remedial Flying Instruction After Landing on Closed Runway
text: A United States senator who landed his twin-engine Cessna on a runway that was closed for construction last October actually touched down, became airborne again and hopped over a group of construction workers and their equipment, and then touched down again, according to information released Wednesday by the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: Under Threat: The Shock of the Old
text: “WHAT happened to Africa?” an art-world friend asked. “It disappeared.”

headline: Underground Market and Pop-ups in San Francisco Draw Foodies
text: An underground market and pop-up restaurants are gaining a following of food enthusiasts in San Francisco.

headline: American Ballet Theater at City Center
text: Over the last few days marvels have unfolded at American Ballet Theater.

headline: Rally Can’t Calm Unease Over Hughes
text: Evidence of Phil Hughes’s pitching aptitude can be found in highlight videos from the 2009 championship season and the All-Star Game garb he received last summer, when he was selected for the first time, at age 24. So, it does exist. He has seen it.

headline: Ex-Chairman of New York Stock Exchange May Run for Mayor
text: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, suggested on Thursday night that he would run for mayor of New York City in 2013 if his longtime nemesis, former Gov. Eliot L. Spitzer, entered the race and the city’s police commissioner sat it out.

headline: Is Sitting a Lethal Activity?
text: DR. LEVINE’S MAGIC UNDERWEAR resembled bicycle shorts, black and skintight, but with sensors mounted on the thighs and wires running to a fanny pack. The look was part Euro tourist, part cyborg. Twice a second, 24 hours a day, the magic underwear’s accelerometers and inclinometers would assess every movement I made, however small, and whether I was lying, walking, standing or sitting.

headline: Red Bull Arena Hosts U.S. Team
text: The United States women’s national team will play its final match before departing for Europe and the World Cup against Mexico at Red Bulls Arena in Harrison, N.J., on June 5. The match will be televised by ESPN2 and Univision.

headline: Sports Replay: April 14
text: The day in sports, from major league baseball to Europa League action.

headline: Word of the Day | obfuscate
text: obfuscate •\ˈäb-fə-ˌskat; äb-ˈfəs-ˌkat, əb-\• verb

headline: Terry Collins Says Mets Need More Practice, and They Do
text: On a day when a ball boy makes the best defensive play of the game, it’s time for some extra defensive work. Late in the second game the ball boy down the right-field line made a great catch of Daniel Murphy’s line drive foul ball, but that was the exception.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Doubling Fun at the Garden
text: Tickets for the Knicks’ first two home playoff games will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. A few hours later, the Knicks and the Rangers will stage a joint rally in Greeley Square to celebrate their simultaneous playoff appearances, the first time that has happened since 1997.

headline: Homer Smith, Innovative College Football Coach, Dies at 79
text: Homer Smith, a football coach whose strategizing enlivened the offenses at U.C.L.A., Alabama and Arizona, and who was the coach at Army in the difficult years at the end of the Vietnam War, died Sunday at his home in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 79.

headline: Lebanon’s Mahdi Scouts
text: The Mahdi Scouts have a reputation of being a feeder for Hezbollah’s armed wing.

headline: News Quiz | April 15, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Nuclear Company to Compensate Evacuees in Japan
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Electric Power Company announced plans on Friday to distribute $600 million in initial payments to 50,000 people evacuated because of the accident at its Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, as technicians continued to struggle to repair cooling and electrical systems at the damaged reactors.

headline: Tim Ream: Chapter 1, New Hope
text: Welcome to the my first effort for the Goal blog. I will be writing once a week throughout the M.L.S. season so be sure to check back. For those of you who don’t know, I’m Tim Ream and I am a central defender for the New York Red Bulls. I am currently in my second year with the team and my second year as a professional. But enough with the background and intro, let’s get started.

headline: A Difficult Family Relationship
text: Treading warily into territory that few dramas dare to explore, “Fly Away” is a defiantly unsentimental look at the complex codependency between a harried single mother and her severely autistic daughter.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Gracioso
text: Today’s word, in association with the legendary Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Thanksgiving Recipes
text: A collection of holiday recipes from the Dining section.

headline: Test Yourself | History, April 15, 2011
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about a famous shipwreck.

headline: ‘One Needle, One Count, One Reputation’
text: WHO is Barry Bonds?WHO are the other “prominent people in sports who break rules” listed in this article?

headline: Mapping the World's Fastest Supercomputers
text: While the U.S. has the world's fastest supercomputers, it faces increased pressure from countries like India and China.

headline: A Civil Rights Headquarters
text: In a small chamber behind the old weight room of a central Harlem gym, the Rev. Al Sharpton runs the National Action Network.

headline: Nature or Nurture?
text: Scientists, psychologists, anthropologists and others have long debated which is more influential in making us who we are: nature (that is, the genetic qualities we inherit and are born with) or nurture (the environment in which we are raised). Which do you think has the greater role in shaping us? Why?

headline: A Light on the People of Western Sahara
text: When the Irish-born photographer Andrew McConnell saw some images from his project “The Last Colony” displayed side by side for the first time earlier this week, even he was surprised by the strength in numbers.

headline: Homes Lost to Fire in California
text: Most of the 600 trailer homes at Oakridge Mobile Home Park in Los Angeles went up in flames, leaving residents to mourn the loss of their homes and of their community.

headline: Gaza Killing of Italian Activist Deals a Blow to Hamas
text: GAZA — For Vittorio Arrigoni, an Italian pro-Palestinian activist who friends said fought peacefully for justice, the end was as violent as it was incongruous.

headline: A Holiday in North Korea Amid Cross-Border Tensions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea celebrated its biggest annual holiday on Friday — the 99th birthday of the late dictator Kim Il-sung — and despite a few recent signs of an easing of tensions between the Koreas, hopes for rapprochement remained dim.

headline: Outrage in Belgium Over Interview of Ex-Bishop
text: LONDON — A year after his resignation plunged Belgium’s Roman Catholic Church into a crisis, the former bishop of Bruges provoked almost universal condemnation on Friday, this time by admitting that he had abused a second nephew and insisting that he was not a pedophile.

headline: How Worrisome Is Student Debt?
text: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

headline: In Berlin, a ‘Long Night’ of Culture
text: Ever seen an opera performed underwater? Or perhaps you prefer puppet theater. Whatever your predilections, the third annual Long Night of Opera and Theater, being held tomorrow, from 7 p.m. to 1 a.m., offers a unique cultural cross-section of what Berlin has to offer.

headline: 1963 Porsche Runs With the Classics, Dude
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. — People talk about cars as rolling sculpture, as art on wheels. But few vehicles have merged the worlds of art and automobile quite like David Duthu’s 1963 Porsche 356 Reutter Sun Roof Coupe, a k a “the Psychedelic Surfer Dude.” The car’s bodywork is an escapist tribute to a bygone era of peace and love.

headline: The Early Word: Looking Ahead
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Indonesian Suicide Bomber Attacks Mosque
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A suicide bomber blew himself up during prayers in a mosque in a police station on Friday, wounding dozens and killing himself, antiterrorism officials said.

headline: Tip of the Week: Enhanced PC Search Features
text: Need to search more thoroughly? Windows 7 and Mac OS X 10.6 include search filters that help you find what you’re looking for if you cannot easily locate specific files with the Windows Start-menu search box or the Mac’s on-screen Spotlight search tool.

headline: One Show Spins Its Last, As Another Takes Shape
text: History is being made on Broadway this weekend: The $70 million museum piece that is Julie Taymor’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the most expensive musical of all time, is on display in its final performances through Sunday afternoon, then disassembled out of existence.

headline: A More Efficient Approach to Hiring
text: To most small-business owners, the terms video clip and impact are more likely to suggest the latest Jackass-style stunt immortalized on YouTube than something important to their bottom lines. But a few new online services are trying to get companies to embrace video in ways that could have a big payoff for very little effort.

headline: New Groups Form to Raise Millions for Democrats
text: 11:30 a.m. | Updated In a city where almost everything seems up for debate these days, Republicans and Democrats in Washington agree on one thing: conservative groups, working outside the normal party structure, outperformed, outhustled and — most of all — outraised Democrats in 2010.

headline: Bank of America Profit Drops 37%
text: Bank of America reported a 37 percent drop in first-quarter earnings on Friday, as the nation’s biggest bank continued to battle the legacy of the mortgage crisis and legal problems linked to the ill-fated acquisition of Countrywide Financial.

headline: Complaint Box | Dog Urine
text: As the new gardener for the recently renovated Washington Square Park, I never suspected that I would be spending such a large part of my day chasing people with dogs away from plant beds. As a dog owner myself, I find it almost impossible to tell something as cute as a French bulldog puppy what to do. But it is absolutely necessary if we want our greenery to thrive.

headline: Rave New World
text: The off-again-on-again Manhattan club night Ghe20 Goth1k is a creative oasis within New York’s flagging night-life scene. Organized by Venus X Iceberg (née Jazmin Venus Soto), it serves as home base to many recently emerged hybrid rave/hip-hop genres. Soto is also producing a documentary called “Shakedown.” Reminiscent of the ’90s cult film “Paris Is Burning,” it traces the intricacies of black lesbian subculture in Los Angeles. Notably, Soto keeps her love of underground and subculture balanced. As a D.J., she has gained notoriety by mixing news clips from Al Jazeera in with her beats — during a New York Fashion Week gig, she interspersed coverage from the Egyptian revolution. As she puts it, “Even club kids should know what’s going on.”

headline: The Horror of Being Wes Craven
text: Since you’re so strongly associated with fear and this is our health issue, could you tell me about your own health concerns? My brother and I both used to worry about dying at 40, because our father died at 40. That probably wasn’t terribly rational since my father led a rather unhealthy lifestyle shall we say.

headline: Riding Along With the Cops in Murdertown, U.S.A.
text: A sign taped to the entrance of police headquarters says it all: “Closed weekends and holidays.” Every weekday, the doors are locked at dusk.

headline: What’s the Single Best Exercise?
text: Let’s consider the butterfly. One of the most taxing movements in sports, the butterfly requires greater energy than bicycling at 14 miles per hour, running a 10-minute mile, playing competitive basketball or carrying furniture upstairs. It burns more calories, demands larger doses of oxygen and elicits more fatigue than those other activities, meaning that over time it should increase a swimmer’s endurance and contribute to weight control.

headline: Block Quote: ‘The Case for Comic Books’
text: Every would-be writer needs comic books. I certainly did. I can still vividly recall my discovery of comic books, followed closely by the revelation that this reading stuff was actually good for something. Because comic books had it all over Readers. Comic books had pictures, and so did Readers, but in comic-book pictures somebody was flying or punching somebody, while in my Reader little Sally was crying about her little red boat. Even in my prepubescent days I had this vague feeling that Wonder Woman had it all over Jane, although I couldn’t put my finger on the reason. I did know that watching Spot run was a real drag when I could watch Krypto the Superdog fly instead. And I knew that if they ever met, Krypto would bite Spot’s head off.

headline: The Waiting
text: I am nothing if not compliant. I held still as I was shuttled back and forth through the wondrous high-tech doughnut, inhaling and holding my breath when instructed. Less than three minutes later, I hopped off the narrow table and put my sweater back on.

headline: The New York Cosmos Want to Take the Field Again

But anyone who walked into Openhouse Gallery in NoLIta one rainy night in mid-February would have seen a young crowd in a huge room celebrating the New York Cosmos, the long-defunct team that briefly turned the world’s most popular sport into a glamorous New York fad.

headline: The Bleak ‘Game of Thrones’ Needs More Light
text: As it turns out, adapting George R. R. Martin’s epic “Song of Ice and Fire” fiction series for premium cable amounts to such good, simple sense that it’s stunning that there aren’t more fantasy series on TV. Considering the falling cost of C.G.I. effects and the rising popularity of the (loosely defined) fantasy genre — like “Heroes” on NBC, “Lost” on ABC and the hit “Battlestar Galactica” on Syfy — it’s remarkable that networks still seem content to mostly loop the same Mobius strip of programming: detectives puzzling, lawyers pacing, sitcom dads making sitcom children roll their eyes.

headline: Driving the Price Up
text: Recently a car backed into my parked car and drove off, leaving my bumper damaged. I was able to track down the culprit thanks to a surveillance camera, and he agreed to compensate me for the cost of the bumper at the lowest estimate I got, which was $576. He provided me with a check for that amount. The mechanic later said that he could probably bang the dent out and repaint it, making it look “almost” new, for just $100. My wife says that I have an obligation to return the balance of $476 to the offending driver. I’m not sure. What says the Ethicist? ARI WALISEVER, WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.

headline: Vettel is Fastest in Shanghai Practice Sessions
text: There may have been a little bit of damage limitation in the second practice session in Shanghai on Friday as the Formula One teams prepared for the Chinese Grand Prix – but I am beginning to be skeptical about it. I’m referring to how in the first session this morning Sebastian Vettel, the winner in his Red Bull of the last four races — the first to this year and the last two last year — set the fastest time, more than two seconds ahead of the next best car and driver, Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes.

headline: Lost in the E.R.: Her Dignity
text: My mother fell in the bathroom and cut her head. The overnight receptionist at the assisted living facility, a dim bulb, phoned me to say an ambulance was on the way. I knew exactly how awful the next however-many hours would be: enduring my mother’s crankiness, masking my own with brittle good cheer, struggling with the medical people. The emergency room ordeal would leave my mother, and to a lesser extent me, limp for days.

So he invited the movie’s young director, Jim Mickle, out for a drink.

headline: Financing the Hand That Slaps (or Nibbles) You
text: HOW ubiquitous is Morgan Spurlock about to be? Well, in addition to the usual marketing and media rollout for a major documentary, his new film, “The Greatest Movie Ever Sold,” is being promoted by 23 sponsors whose wares are shamelessly plugged in the movie, including Mini Cooper, Pom Wonderful and Amy’s Kitchen. His mug is on collectors’ cups at almost 400 Sheetz convenience stores and he is part of a Movietickets.com trailer in theaters. Mr. Spurlock, who came to prominence and the edge of major illness by gorging on McDonald’s in “Super Size Me,” is crisscrossing the country, hawking his movie and his sponsors. He shows up for interviews with a coat — created by Ted Baker — that is festooned with all manner of logos.

headline: Like Busby Berkeley, With Funk

Diddy), who are both on tour; and shot a vacuum cleaner commercial. And lest you think that last job required any less effort: “I’m giving you Busby Berkeley mixed with my own sense of funk and soul,” she said by phone, heaving a sigh before quickly regaining focus.

headline: A Hungry Singer, Consuming His Roles
text: SOME great singing actors vanish into their characters. At the peak of his powers, the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel more typically swallows his alive. It happened in spades at the Metropolitan Opera a year ago when he joined the cast of Puccini’s “Tosca,” late in the run of the new, much-vilified production by Luc Bondy. As Baron Scarpia, the sadistic chief of the Roman police, Mr. Terfel captured the monster’s every facet, now in gallantries of silken delicacy, now in the savage bloodlust of a tiger on the attack. Here was a creation worthy of Dickens, Balzac or Dostoevsky.

headline: Writing About Cancer
text: Siddhartha Mukherjee has a terrific article in this Sunday’s magazine about whether cellphones cause cancer. When he’s not writing, Mukherjee does research and teaches medicine at Columbia University. That makes sense because reading his cellphone story feels a lot like sitting in a riveting college class, where the professor is leading you step by step through the history of what makes for excellent — as well as flawed — scientific research, all the while explaining how to assess the research on brain cancer and cellphones. Mukherjee’s writing is precise and vivid and you feel like you’re in the hands of a very thoughtful, exacting authority. Last fall the magazine published an excerpt from his recent book, “Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer,” which was a finalist last year for the National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the 10-best books in 2010 by our Book Review.

headline: The Truth About Sharon Stone and Wes Craven

headline: Falai Goes Retail; Swedish Fish Spawn
text: Iacopo Falai is on the move again, ready to open Bottega Falai Thursday morning next to his Caffe Falai. Done in his trademark shiny white mosaic tile, and glittering chandeliers, the shop is stocked with mostly Italian products, like dried porcini, sea salts, some herbs and spices, excellent Mancini pasta, olive oils, a selection of Italian cheeses and cured meats, breads, some produce, prepared foods like sandwiches, and the pastries for which Mr. Falai is known. A few tables are available for a snack on the spot but most of the food is to take away. A couple of weeks ago, he also doubled the size of the cafe by taking over an adjacent storefront, adding more seats and a full bar, also done in white tile and sparkle. And for his new Italian cocktail menu, you can watch his bartenders weigh the ingredients for your drink on little scales for better accuracy.

headline: Accentuating the Positive Amid Sports’ Angst
text: In the wake of what felt like an ice bucket full of news this week, with the sobering Barry Bonds verdict, endless squabbling from the characters responsible for the N.F.L. lockout and a cringe-inducing outburst from Kobe Bryant, it seems therapeutic to end the week with a few stories from sports’ warmer, inspiring side. Fortunately, they are always there, sometimes hidden in odd places, and feel particularly welcome this week.

headline: What Makes Literature Literature?
text: Near the end of his life, when he’d mostly given up lobbing oddball provocations at feminists and masturbators, Norman Mailer anointed “The Sopranos” as a cultural successor to the “great American novel.” It was a genuine compliment, though a strange one. Just as Mailer and Truman Capote once advertised the literary intentions of their journalism with the term “nonfiction novel,” Mailer now honored a television show by suggesting that it wasn’t a television show at all, but something else, something literary. The irony was that Mailer had it backward. “The Sopranos” represented the end of whatever remained of television’s status anxiety; it didn’t need to be anything but itself to be taken seriously.

headline: Big Deal | Norman Mailer Apartment for Sale
More Thoughts About Spring Lamb
text: It was deep winter when I began planning this week’s column about holiday lamb, but I didn’t know how exactly I wanted to approach the animal. Tough luck: I got to spend late winter and early spring playing around with the country’s most underappreciated meat. I love roasting shoulder, and I love braising shanks (and neck, which, if you can get it, is one of the best braising meats there is), but as you can see I eventually settled on the leg – roasted leg, to be exact – because after all it seems most appropriate for the holiday table.

headline: Asked & Answered | Philippe Starck
text: Stand C9-D18, Pavilion 13, Euroluce, Fiera-Rho Milan, Italy. Journalists line up in front of a private interview room to meet the perennial French design superstar Philippe Starck. Known for juggling a considerable number of clients (or “editors,” as his team calls them) at once, Starck was in New York just last week to unveil a novelty toilet seat for Duravit, and this week in Milan, he’s presenting a variety of new products with a number of different companies, including Kartell, Dedon, Driade, Baccarat, Magis and Alias. But today it’s all about ultramodern LED-powered lamps he designed for Flos, the high-end Italian lighting manufacturer.

headline: A Gay Former N.B.A. Player Responds to Kobe Bryant
text: After Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant directed an antigay slur at a referee Tuesday night from the bench in a game against the Phoenix Suns, the N.B.A. fined him $100,000. Bryant has apologized, saying his words should not have been taken literally. He said he would appeal the fine.

headline: Shakespeare Subpoenaed
text: Kenji Yoshino is a respected legal scholar (the Chief Justice Earl Warren professor of constitutional law at New York University) who regularly teaches a course on literature and the law. The device he has come up with in “A Thousand Times More Fair” is to match a play of Shakespeare with some modern event or issue. One can see how this might stimulate class discussion, and it seems to succeed, since he tells us that his course on constitutional law is oversubscribed by two to one, but the class on literature and law has more applicants by six to one. The process apparently works. But what of the product? Considered apart from the give-and-take of the classroom, one of three things can be the result. First, the stereo­scopic approach can deepen one’s understanding of both a play and the event matched with it. Second, at least one of the pair can be given new understanding. Third, meaning can be drained, not deepened, on both sides of the matchup.

headline: Geoff Dyer’s Wide-Ranging Curiosity
text: Assembling a collection of reviews and essays is a test of the richness of a critic’s inner life, an echo-sounding exercise that measures the depth of available talent. While a single piece may be impressive in isolation — rehearsed in a glossy magazine or nestled in the review pages — the book-length selection takes us out of the safety of those shallows and asks whether a writer’s reflections still rise beyond the threshold of banality when repeated over several hundred pages. If a critic’s sense of artistic achievement is sclerotically narrow, or based on a single approach applied to every work under consideration, the collection will coolly sketch a relief map of those failings.

headline: What Grief Is Really Like
text: The Christmas that Meghan O’Rourke was 5, her mother gave her a journal — a whole world of blank pages, puzzling to the child but not to the mother. Barbara O’Rourke explained to her daughter that the book was a place for her to put her thoughts: “You’d write something like ‘Today I saw a woman with purple hair crossing Montague Street.’ ”

headline: New York Paternity Fight May Have Millions of Ripples
text: IT is a small case, really, easily lost among the thousands in New York City’s courts.

headline: Francis Fukuyama’s Theory of the State
text: “This book has two origins,” Francis Fukuyama writes in the preface to “The Origins of Political Order.” “The first arose when my mentor, Samuel Huntington of Harvard University, asked me to write a foreword to a reprint edition of his 1968 classic, ‘Political Order in Changing Societies.’ ” Its second inspiration was the decade that Fukuyama spent studying “the real-world problems of weak and failed states” and that inspired his 2004 book “State-Building: Governance and World Order in the 21st Century.”

headline: At Home With Susan Sontag
text: It’s not easy to pick the most unforgettable image from the many that flutter through this memoir like snippets from an overturned wastebasket. Susan Sontag eating a whole package of bacon and calling it dinner? Susan Sontag, passionate friend of the revolution, berating any clerk or waiter who didn’t treat her with proper deference? Susan Sontag perched on a sofa in her son’s room late at night, smoking and soliloquizing about her evening out, while he and his girlfriend lie silently in bed? Truly an embarrassment of riches, emphasis on the embarrassment, but here’s a personal favorite: Susan Sontag choosing to entertain guests in the kitchen.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Beer and bivalves are the theme of Bierkraft’s new backyard and garden space, 191 Fifth Avenue (between Berkeley Place and Union Street), in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Starting at noon on Saturday there will be an oyster shuck fest with 15 special cask beers.

headline: Kate Atkinson’s Unorthodox Mystery Series
text: It’s West Yorkshire not long before the Yorkshire Ripper starts his killing spree, and two police officers make a grisly discovery. Behind a locked door in a block of flats lies the decomposing body of a woman. But that’s not the worst of it. The worst of it is there’s a child locked in with her, “filthy, nothing but skin and bone,” looking “like a famine victim.”

headline: How Language Heals
text: Diane Ackerman and Paul West have combined brilliant literary careers with the most enviable of marriages, a “decades-long duet.” Speculating on their longevity as a couple in “One Hundred Names for Love,” Ackerman writes: “We stayed together for the children — each was the other’s child. And we were both wordsmiths, cuddle-mad, and extremely playful. . . . All couples play kissy games they don’t want other people to know about, and all regress to infants from time to time, since, though we marry as adults, we don’t marry adults. We marry children who have grown up and still rejoice in being children, especially if we’re creative. Imaginative people fidget with ideas, including the idea of a relationship. If they’re wordsmiths like us, they fidget a lot in words.”

headline: The Royal Wedding

headline: Tempest in a Compost Heap: Controversial Comedy Sign Gets a Funny New Home

headline: GroVont Redux
text: Lydia Elkrunner (née Callahan) is not a very nice person. She insults on a whim and delights in temper tantrums. She refuses to repair the brake lights on her decaying BMW because that “would be giving other drivers too much information.” At 58, she acts as if she’s 20 and, of a benign nonagenarian, gleefully quips, “Don’t you admire the Eskimo ritual of leaving their elderly behind on an ice flow.” Really, she’s everything self: self-absorbed, self-important, self-indulgent. “You know why living with you would be so healthy, Grandma?” her down-and-out 28-year-old granddaughter remarks. “Because you are so incredibly wrong that you clarify what is right.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: SAY HER NAME,  by Francisco Goldman (Grove, $24.) Goldman’s passionate, moving novel takes as its subject his tragically short marriage to the fiction writer Aura Estrada, who died in a bodysurfing accident in 2007, when she was 30.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HELLHOUND ON HIS TRAIL: The Electrifying Account of the Largest Manhunt in American History,  by Hampton Sides (Anchor, $15.95.) Sides pieces together a viscerally dramatic account of the last days of Martin Luther King Jr. — including a moment-by-moment retelling of his assassination on April 4, 1968, in Memphis — and intercuts King’s story with the maneuverings of James Earl Ray, the man tried and convicted as his killer.

headline: Inside the List
text: X FACTOR: Manning Marable’s long-awaited “Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention” hits No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week, trailing admiring reviews and eulogies for Marable, who died a few days before the book’s publication. Marable has “done as thorough and exhaustive a job as has ever been done in piecing together the life and evolution of Malcolm X, rescuing him from both the hagiography of uncritical advocates and the demonization of undeterred critics,” the sociologist Michael Eric Dyson told The New York Times.

headline: Qaddafi Troops Fire Cluster Bombs Into Civilian Areas

Muammar el-Qaddafi have been firing into residential neighborhoods in this embattled city with heavy weapons, including cluster bombs that have been banned by much of the world and ground-to-ground rockets, according to witnesses and survivors, as well as physical evidence.
