headline: Reality-TV Originals, in Drama’s Lens
text: WHEN the documentary series “An American Family” was broadcast on PBS in 1973, critical and popular reaction varied, but many viewers, including prominent ones, agreed that it was a watershed of some kind. The anthropologist Margaret Mead proclaimed the show “as new and significant as the invention of drama or the novel.” For a host of commentators, conservatives and liberals alike, the series heralded nothing less than the demise of the nuclear family. Looking back on it in the 1980s, the philosopher Jean Baudrillard described “An American Family” as a symptom of our altered relationship with reality, characterized by “dissolution of TV in life, dissolution of life in TV.”

That city pioneered use of this renewable technology, and gradually biomass evolved from a niche component of its fuel mix to the backbone of its fuel supply.

headline: Spring Theater of the Absurd
text: Fashion is many things: beautiful, frivolous, devout, serious — sometimes all at once. It is performance and craft, in whatever style. In photographs and videos, it supplies us with visual intelligence. On May 2, when Daphne Guinness climbs into a window at Barneys New York to prepare for the Costume Institute gala that evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, I hope I have my own frock ready so I can go and watch. Do I think my friend is nutty? Yes, a little. Brave, definitely. And I am far from confident at this stage that anyone can create a performance-art piece with fashion that will mean anything, least of all in a luxury store window on Madison Avenue, and a time when apparel isn’t selling so well. But I’ll go anyway, just to see.

headline: How I Fell for Milan
text: FOR the first 10 years of our relationship, Milan and I were constantly at odds with each other.  For my part, the list of gripes included the city’s notorious weather — alternately simmering hot or cold as a dungeon and, since much of the city is constructed over filled-in canals, perennially humid; the dearth of contemporary cultural attractions; the fact that the place becomes a ghost town most Fridays, when any self-respecting (there are no other kinds, really) Milanese of means abandons the city for a weekend retreat in the mountains or by the sea.

headline: A Fashion-Forward Guide to Antwerp
text: THERE is something strikingly eccentric about Europe’s historic harbor cities.  Perhaps it’s the centuries of trade and exposure to objects and people from afar; maybe there’s something in the water. But whatever it is, Antwerp, a small Belgian city about 40 miles southeast of the North Sea, with expansive docklands along the wide Schelde River, is a place where — amid the postcard-ready quaintness of old Europe — one finds corners of unusual idiosyncrasy and surprise.

headline: Destination Dining in Department Stores

headline: How to Shop in Paris
text: THERE may be no city that takes shopping more seriously than Paris, the birthplace of haute couture and a place where mere browsers, while welcome, can still be made to feel snubbed in subtle ways. In fact, the French term for window shopping, faire du lèche-vitrine, translates directly as “to go window licking.” To shop more like a local, it helps to know the score at the coolest stores in town. Here are four of them.

headline: Waffles Made, and a Promise Kept, at P.S. 10
text: Dennis M. Walcott, the incoming city schools chancellor, was so excited on Thursday night that he had trouble sleeping. He woke up at 3:30 a.m., then again at 5:20, and went out for a two-mile run. By 7:30, he was at Public School 10 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, waffle batter and electric waffle press in hand.

headline: A Beautiful Mine
text: The only thing clear about diamonds may be the translucent stones themselves. Everything else is murky and vaguely sinister: where they come from, who dug them up and under what conditions, and, more particularly, if they reek of evil. A diamond isn’t like fur, which can’t do much to hide its origins. But there is a lurking suspicion that, like the gold of the Nibelungs, no good can come from this bright rock. It doesn’t help that the one word that rushes unbidden to stand next to diamond is blood. Diamonds are guilty until proven innocent.

headline: Now Online | T Summer Fashion and Beauty
text: T’s Summer Fashion and Beauty issue is loaded with gems. In a “A Diamond in the Roughage,” the photographer Richard Burbridge and the set designer Gary Card transform the model Tati into a floral fantasy worthy of Arcimboldo. (Extra points if you can spot the carats.) For “A Beautiful Mine,” the writer Joshua Levine travels to South Africa with the jewelers behind the Los Angeles line Hoorsenbuhs to look for ethically mined diamonds. But not to be overlooked is our cover star, Cate Blanchett. She is well known, of course, for her portrayals of everyone from Queen Elizabeth I to Katharine Hepburn. In her new film, “Hanna,” she tries the role of ruthless C.I.A. agent on for size. But lesser known perhaps are the slew of roles she plays off-screen, including the co-artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, an eco-activist who works with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the mother of three young boys. That is what we call multifaceted. See more from the issue >>

headline: Viewers Not So Mad About Paul Reiser’s Return
text: Twelve years after “Mad About You,” Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBC’s comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of “The Paul Reiser Show” at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBC’s similarly ratings-starved sitcom “Community” (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by “American Idol” on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for “The Office” (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of “Idol” and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for “Bones.” CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of “Wipeout” at 8 (6.2 million).

headline: Go Down, Moussa

The O.E.D. tells me “hench” is derived from a word for “horse.”) More recently he was Qaddafi’s foreign minister and, toward the end, fear almost shaded into pity as an increasingly desperate looking Koussa tried to convey Libyan policy — that is, to explain the unexplainable.

text: Dr. Laura Oppenheim and George Lewis Armistead were married Saturday evening at the Historic Landmark Building at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. Rabbi Marjorie Berman officiated.

headline: Lesley Rosenbloom, Gregory Ginsburg
text: Lesley Sara Rosenbloom and Dr. Gregory Edward Ginsburg were married Saturday evening at the Omni Parker House hotel in Boston. Rabbi Ronald M. Weiss officiated.

headline: Mary Beth Gallagher, Matthew Solis
text: Mary Beth Gallagher and Matthew Ryan Solis were married Saturday evening at Woodend Nature Sanctuary at the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Mark E. Hoelter, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Michelle Napoli, Craig Kilburg
text: Michelle Lynn Napoli and Craig Justin Kilburg were married Saturday at St. Joseph’s Roman Catholic Church in Babylon, N.Y. The Rev. Seth N. Arwo-Doqu performed the ceremony.

headline: Danielle Sacks, David Gerlach
text: Danielle Jill Sacks, a daughter of Lanie S. Sacks and Steven E. Sacks, both of Boca Raton, Fla., was married Saturday evening in New Haven to David Adam Gerlach, a son of Jill E. Gerlach and Judge Gary A. Gerlach of Milwaukee. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the New Haven Lawn Club, with the assistance of the bridegroom’s father, who retired from the Milwaukee County Circuit Court.

headline: Helen Chung and Anwar Hussain
text: Dr. Helen Kei Fong Chung and Dr. Anwar Ahmed Hussain were married Saturday evening at the Traditions at the Glen Resort and Conference Center in Johnson City, N.Y. Imam Kasim Kopuz performed a ceremony that incorporated Muslim and Chinese wedding traditions.

headline: Sarah Rapawy and Roberto Gonzalez
text: Sarah Gerber Rapawy and Roberto José Gonzalez were married Saturday evening at Hacienda del Sol Guest Ranch Resort, a hotel in Tucson. Frank R. Zapata, a senior judge of the United States District Court in Tucson, officiated.

headline: Susan Hodas, Michael Blumen
text: Susan Leslie Hodas and Michael Joseph Blumen are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Park Hyatt Aviara Resort in Carlsbad, Calif. Rabbi Matthew Earne is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Emily Levin, Mitchell Weiser
text: Emily Jill Levin and Mitchell Charles Weiser are to be married Sunday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Steven C. Kane is to officiate.

headline: Mariecel Pilapil and Matthew Lazarus
text: Dr. Mariecel Christina Pilapil, the daughter of Lillian C. Pilapil and Alfredo C. Pilapil of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married Saturday afternoon to Matthew Samuel Lazarus, a son of Debby L. Lazarus of Manhattan and the late Richard B. Lazarus. Msgr. John A. McGuirl, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with the assistance of Rabbi Jeffrey Gale at Terrace on the Park in Corona, Queens.

headline: Margaret McClory, Christopher Carril
text: Margaret Elizabeth McClory and Christopher Emilio Carril were married Saturday in Medford, Mass. The Rev. David M. O’Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Goddard Chapel on the campus of Tufts University, where he is the chaplain.

headline: Jennifer Jeng, Andrew Tretten
text: Jennifer Chieh Jeng and Andrew Tyler Tretten were married Saturday off Newport Beach, Calif. Clinton P. Acoutin, a Universal Life minister, officiated aboard the Ambassador, a charter yacht, of which he is also the captain. Richard Zuniga, a lay pastor of the Chinese Evangelical Free Church in Monterey Park, Calif., also took part.

headline: Grace Lee and Michael Lee
text: Grace Hee-Jean Lee, a daughter of Sung Ok Lee of Egg Harbor Township, N.J., and the late Robert S. Lee, was married Saturday to Michael Eliot Lee, a son of Diana Lee and Chester Lee of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Paul Smith, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at One Atlantic, a party space in Atlantic City.

headline: Zoe Kiefer, Zeke Phillips
text: Zoe Elizabeth Kiefer and Zeke Mikhail Phillips were married Saturday evening at Round Hill House in Washingtonville, N.Y. Sandra B. Wells, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: TimesCast | April 15, 2011
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces fire cluster bombs into civilian areas; and an Italian activist is captured and killed in Gaza.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Insomnia Edition
text: This was one of those magical weeks of bedtime reading, when the house got perfectly quiet and my books got very loud and I ended up staying up until 2 in the morning just about every night. I was reading: a big, heavy, three-volume hardcover edition of Samuel Johnson’s “Lives of the Poets”; a newfangled iPhone essay (with pictures, audio, etc.) about ants called “Before the Swarm”; “Father and Son,” Edmund Gosse’s 1907 memoir about growing up with evangelical Christian parents (this was also on my iPhone, via the less high-tech Project Gutenberg); and an advance copy of Nicholson Baker’s erotic fantasy novel “House of Holes: A Book of Raunch.” (This won’t be published until August, but — hoo-boy, people, get ready for this book. It is going to be Talked About. There will be fistfights in the hallways of your local public library. I keep describing it to people as “porny Alice in Wonderland” — an impossible combination of crazy, cheerful imagination and industrial-grade filth. It made me hoot out loud every other page or so, and on a few occasions my mouth actually, literally dropped open. Just get ready.)

headline: Wine Country Tribute to Italy’s Fine Vintages
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Showing a Brave Face to Industry Headwinds
text: IN essence, an auto show is just a dealer’s showroom with higher production values — a chance for the local sales force to persuade shoppers that now is the time to buy.

headline: A Republican Praising Obama? Here’s Hand-Written Proof
text: Washington is a town famous for false praise. Lawmakers are often graciously thanking their “good friend” from across the aisle — right before skewering that person as unpatriotic or ill-suited for governing.

headline: Honoring a Famed Italian Race
text: The California Mille takes vintage machines on a spirited 1,000-mile tour of Northern California.

headline: iPad Resellers Now Camp Overnight at Apple Stores
text: On Wednesday morning I stopped by the SoHo Apple store in New York City to purchase an iPad for a family member. As I had anticipated, a store clerk said they were out of stock and recommended that I check back the following morning. When I asked what time I should arrive, the clerk hesitated, looked around as if about to tell me a secret and said: “Well, do you see that group of people outside? They’re already here waiting for tomorrow’s shipment of iPads.”

headline: Clouds Part for U.S. Solar Industry
text: A potentially dim week for the American solar power industry ended on a bright note instead.

headline: Ephemeral Paradise, in Medium Format
text: It was a simple stroll on the outskirts of town that inspired the London-based photographer Hin Chua to pursue “After the Fall,” a project that ultimately took him to more than 40 cities and 15 countries.

headline: A Mezzo Keeps It Simple, and Makes It Profound
text: The mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly was singing “By a Bierside,” a stark reflection on death written in the World War I trenches by Ivor Gurney, when a tendril of hair fell into her face. It happens.

headline: Chicks With Something to Peep About
text: AT Easter time, when the shops erupt in a pastel frenzy of chocolate bunnies, candy eggs and marshmallow chicks, I try hard to resist. Unless I’m buying an artisanal rabbit made from single-origin chocolate, most of the confections look a lot better than they taste.

headline: Christine Baranski: ‘I Was Never Beautiful’
text: CHRISTINE BARANSKI arrived at Michael’s, the media hangout on West 55th Street, at 12:30 p.m. on the dot. A somewhat later arrival would have guaranteed an entrance, a gust of warm curiosity, but as she passed the empty tables at the front, the few patrons nosing their menus, I realized, or perhaps remembered, that such impromptu moments were best not left to chance. I should have reserved for 1 p.m.

headline: Stage Presence Aplenty, the Better to Have Fun
text: There is something slightly (and deliciously) overwhelming about confronting a lineup studded with the likes of Carmen deLavallade, Robert La Fosse, Valda Setterfield and Gus Solomons Jr. The sheer history and stage presence that any one of these dancers represents alone, never mind cumulatively as members and guest artists of Paradigm, take a moment for an audience member to digest.

headline: Mental Redistribution
text: It’s well known from the work of Arthur Brooks and others that conservatives give much more to charity than liberals, especially charities meant to alleviate poverty. That makes sense. Liberals believe in government provisions more and conservatives believe in private provisions more. James Lindgren of Northwestern University recently published a Northwestern Law and Economics Research Paper in which he compared attitudes about income redistribution and other beliefs.

headline: At the Junior Teams, the U.S. Benefits From a Lethal Lead
text: At the White House Junior Teams in the Netherlands last month, the winner, Israel, met the United States in Round 21 of the 23-round qualifying stage.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#147", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: New Police Presence Is Hard to Miss Amid Dodger Blue
text: LOS ANGELES — Greg Baggerly was among the first fans to arrive at Dodger Stadium on Thursday afternoon, unmistakably from out of town in both attire and timing.

headline: A Guide to Smartphone Manners
text: A Modest Proposal for a Digital Détente: 10 Rules to Make Sure Smartphones Don’t Make Us Stupid

headline: Keep Your Thumbs Still When I’m Talking to You
text: YOU are at a party and the person in front of you is not really listening to you. Yes, she is murmuring occasional assent to your remarks, or nodding at appropriate junctures, but for the most part she is looking beyond you, scanning in search of something or someone more compelling.

headline: G.D.P. Estimates Slide Further
text: Earlier this week we wrote that several prominent economic forecasters had lowered their estimates of gross domestic product growth in the first quarter of this year. Today saw even further declines.

headline: Trendspotting | The Interview
text: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: dressing by degrees. Text by Brian Nichols

headline: Lucali’s Owner Stabbed and Is in Critical Condition
text: The Daily News reports that Mark Iacono, owner of the Brooklyn pizzeria Lucali is in critical condition after being stabbed by a man with whom he had been arguing on a street in Carrol Gardens.

headline: Tuition in the News
text: “Admissions stories are a staple of the news business, of course. They have been since the first baby boomer editor realized he couldn’t afford the tuition of the school his kid desperately wanted to go to, and he dispatched his reporters to find out why the hell not.”

headline: Pop Quiz Answers
text: The following are answers to sample questions from the revised Graduate Record Examination, to be offered in August.

headline: Big Blog on Campus
text: COLLEGE campuses have always had their boldface names: professors who’ve logged time in a White House cabinet, opined on “PBS NewsHour” or written Pulitzer Prize-winning best sellers. To this venerated lot we can add the academic blogger. A remarkable variety of scholars have achieved blogosphere fame, particularly those devoted to subjects related to the public sphere — politics, economics, legal affairs. Law school bloggers are practically their own category.

headline: Admissions Tally 2011
text: A few weeks ago, colleges and universities notified millions of restless high school seniors of their admissions decisions for fall 2011. In an environment that becomes more competitive year after year, we asked a sampling of colleges and universities for a sense of how things were stacking up. Over all, admittance rates continued to decline. For example, the Ivy League on average admitted 10 percent of applicants, down from the 11 percent recorded last year. The results shouldn’t surprise. Some 2.2 million online applications have been filed for the fall using the Common Application alone, up almost 22 percent from 2010. The glut of applications means admissions offices must deny an increasing proportion of students. But take heart: when the dust settled on last fall’s freshmen class, the average acceptance rate was 67 percent.

headline: Transferring? Get Schooled
text: ABOUT a third of students change campuses on their way to a degree, but it’s often a bumpier ride than they expect.

headline: A Guide to Branch Campuses
text: STUDY abroad is one thing, a degree abroad another. The movement is nascent, but it is possible to earn a degree from an American university without setting foot in the United States, or by flitting among campuses. American colleges and universities operate about 80 branches that offer full degrees, in English, according to the Observatory on Borderless Higher Education, a British research institute. Nearly 80 percent of them have opened since 1999.

headline: N.Y.U. in the U.A.E.
text: IN a small classroom at New York University Abu Dhabi, Paulo Lemos Horta was pushing his students to explore the difficulties of translation. In some ways, it might have been a class on any American campus — except that virtually everyone was fluent in a second language.

headline: The New G.R.E.
text: EIGHT years in the making, the revised Graduate Record Examination will be introduced on Aug. 1 — really. (The debut was pushed back twice as technicalities overwhelmed.)

headline: Rx: Read to Your Baby
text: IT was another hectic morning in the pediatric clinic of Bellevue Hospital Center, where the clamorous waiting room had been transformed into a reading room. Toddlers sat crowded onto blue mats as volunteers read loudly from children’s books. Dr. Perri Klass weaved in and out of the steady traffic of strollers. She hovered over one mat, where a 1-year-old named Bella used a pincer grip to lift a board book titled “Let’s Go to the Park,” pointed at pictures and then looked at her mother.

headline: Study Abroad in Hot Spots
text: THE world is a perilous place. Just look at Northeastern University’s study-abroad record this past year: starting last April, the university was forced to suspend programs and evacuate students after State Department travel advisories in Thailand (anti-government violence); New Zealand (twice, for earthquakes in Christchurch in September and February); Egypt (revolution); and Japan (earthquake, tsunami, nuclear crisis). The university had planned to team up with an institution in Tunisia but put that on hold after unrest there.

headline: Fragrance Spritzers Hold Their Fire
text: PAMELA VAILE is no fan of the swarm of spray-happy salesclerks who lie in wait at many department stores, all of them eager to douse passers-by with a sample of a fragrance that they are sure the shoppers will totally, absolutely love once they get a whiff. “I myself will not walk through that main aisle where all the spritzers are,” she said. “I can’t stand that.”

headline: Cuba: A Door Ajar
text: THOUSANDS of American college students have been effectively locked out of Cuba since 2004, when the Bush administration tightened restrictions on travel for academic, cultural and religious purposes. Cuba was then the third most popular study-abroad destination in Latin America (after Mexico and Costa Rica); 2,148 United States residents studied there in 2003-4. The number plunged 92 percent in just a year.

headline: Teach, Pray, Live
text: WHEN 10 Jesuit priests moved into their new home at Fairfield University about a year ago, some of them couldn’t fit their old desks into their new bedrooms. And “we live out of our desks,” says the Rev. Mark P. Scalese, who teaches at the university. He was referring to the Jesuits’ penchant for learning, as reflected in a 10-year training period known as “formation” that includes extensive graduate education. Many end up with three or four advanced degrees.

headline: Learning to Listen to Distressed Classmates
text: DAN SULLIVAN, a junior at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, notices the warning signs now, even during finals when most everyone seems stressed.

headline: Sharing the Pain, Online
text: IMalive.org, a new crisis intervention help line, hopes to reach troubled young people where they feel most comfortable — in virtual chats.

headline: Pointers for Professors
text: Last year, a professor at Bryn Mawr College told a story to his class about how, in explaining a concept, he had confused an international student by referring to a candy bar common to Americans.

headline: Test Prep by Text
text: A CONVINCING argument to Mom and Dad for why you need more texting minutes: test prep. The latest entry in the mobile prep industry, SAT Remix, will text one of 300 formidable SAT words precisely at 7 o’clock every night, Sunday to Thursday (teenagers are apparently too tired on Friday). The words, accompanied by breakbeat or house, can be played as an audio file and saved as a ringtone.

headline: Bingo! Not for Seniors Only
text: BRYANT University in Rhode Island recently unveiled its latest acquisition — a $1,500 Gemstone bingo console, with black light — christened by its president, with some 400 students in attendance. This may be a church-lady game, but it’s big at Bryant. And this is bingo for the XBox generation: to break a tie, players bust moves in a dance-off.

headline: Don’t Even Think About Smoking Here
text: THERE’S a new accreditation on the block. Campuses eager to flaunt their smoke-free status can apply for certification by the health-education organization Bacchus Network. The nonprofit offers three levels of certification — silver, gold or diamond.

headline: Yankees Place Hughes on Disabled List
text: Phil Hughes, whose 2011 season has consisted of three disastrous starts and a rub-your-eyes-in-disbelief 13.94 earned run average, was put on the 15-day disabled list Friday. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi declared that Hughes, a 25-year-old right-hander, was going through a “dead-arm period.’’

headline: Editor’s Note
text: Back in early 2002, when Gary Taubes was writing a cover story called “What If It’s All Been a Big Fat Lie?” for this magazine, he and I had lunch every couple of months at Les Deux Gamins, a cafe in the West Village. At the time, I was one of those normal people who ate Cheerios for breakfast, but all that changed as I got to know Gary better. My lunches with him were like meetings with a parole officer, only it wasn’t a life of crime that Gary was steering me away from — it was a life of carbohydrates. The first time we went to Les Deux Gamins, the waitress offered us a bread basket. She never did again.

headline: Secret Tape of Officer and Accuser Is Crucial to Rape Case
text: On the tape played in court, a few moments after Police Officer Kenneth Moreno says “Yes, I did,” when a woman presses him on whether he used a condom when he had sex with her, he asks what she remembers from that evening.

headline: Seaport Museum Seeks Berths for Vessels
text: The Seaport Museum New York is in talks with various maritime centers about taking its working vessels on a temporary or permanent basis to help defer costs. The museum — at 12 Fulton Street and formerly named the South Street Seaport Museum — is struggling financially, and in February it furloughed 32 employees, half of the staff. It has held conversations with the Hudson River Maritime Museum in Kingston, N.Y.; with Schooner Inc., a nonprofit maritime center in New Haven; and the Gloucester Maritime Heritage Center in Massachusetts.  Mary Pelzer, the Seaport Museum’s executive director, did not respond to messages seeking comment. The museum has said that it plans to sell Peking, the museum’s flagship merchant ship.

headline: J.&J. in Deal Talks With Synthes
text: Christian Hartmann/ReutersSurgical power tools made by Synthes, a Swiss-American company.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate Middleton’s Down-Do
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Sex Drive, Idling in Neutral
text: THIS is the story a friend told me: One night at a gathering at an apartment in New York City, a woman blithely announced, “I would pay someone to have sex with my husband.” There were snorts and yips of laughter. I believe one woman even clapped. “What did they mean?” I asked my friend. “ ‘Here’s to no sex with our husbands ever again?’ ‘Here’s to the end of sex?’ ”

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 15
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include an urban garden in Battery Park in Manhattan, a voodoo ceremony in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, and a military homecoming at the Harlem Armory.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra May Seek Bankruptcy Protection
text: Painting a dire financial picture, leaders of the troubled Philadelphia Orchestra said on Friday that bankruptcy protection was vital to its survival.

headline: A Bach’s Lost Passion, From Kiev to New York
text: When a long-lost manuscript by a major composer turns up, expectations can be blown out of proportion. Any scramble to “realize” a freshly found sliver from Mozart’s quill — which is to say, to bring it to exploitable condition — will almost certainly exceed what is ultimately heard.

headline: Finding the Soul of Russia Everywhere
text: Did you know that the sighing first theme of Brahms’s Fourth Symphony is actually a Russian folk song? Or that the mellow chorale played by the woodwinds at the beginning of the slow second movement is obviously inspired by a Russian Orthodox male choir?

headline: Heaven, Love and Water, but No Dreaming
text: “This is an anthem for the individual,” K. D. Lang said on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge, by way of introducing “Sing It Loud,” the title track of her new album. “There’s probably a few people who feel that they don’t fit in here tonight.” The crowd approved with murmurs and whoops. Even if they didn’t fit in elsewhere, they were home here.

headline: David Ferry Wins the Ruth Lilly Poetry Award for Lifetime Achievement
text: Who says poetry doesn’t pay? The Poetry Foundation has awarded the translator and poet David Ferry the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for lifetime achievement.

headline: The Darker Colors of Patriotism
text: To judge solely by one work, Ledoh, the Burmese-born choreographer who heads Salt Farm, is enthralled by tension. In “ColorMeAmerica ,” which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, he explores the disintegration of freedom in the name of patriotism. Just as the words in the title bleed together purposefully, this look at America isn’t always beautiful; rather, it’s all very fraught.

headline: Seaport Museum Seeks Berths for Vessels
text: The Seaport Museum New York is in talks with various maritime centers about taking its working vessels on a temporary or permanent basis to help defer costs. The museum — at 12 Fulton Street and formerly named the South Street Seaport Museum — is struggling financially, and in February it furloughed 32 employees, half of the staff. It has held conversations with the Hudson River Maritime Museum in Kingston, N.Y.; with Schooner Inc., a nonprofit maritime center in New Haven; and the Gloucester Maritime Heritage Center in Massachusetts. Frank J. Sciame, the Seaport Museum’s chairman, said through a spokesman that the museum “is exploring various options regarding the maintenance of its historic vessels.” The museum has said that it plans to sell Peking, the museum’s flagship merchant ship.

headline: Podcast: Good Euros, Bad Euros and Market Worries
text: Gresham’s Law is a centuries-old economic principle that is often defined quite simply as “bad money drives out good money.”

headline: Young, Restless and Glued to Soaps
text: My first, most vivid television memory is of watching the Watergate hearings in 1973 at my rapt mother’s side. My second involves exposure to villainy of another kind — that of Billy Clyde Tuggle, the sort of pimp who drugged his employee base on “All My Children.” For these encounters with Tuggle, my mother was absent. She was then, and remains now, in her late 80s, a largely “news only, no sap, thank you” participant in the experience of American television. She reserved (and reserves) her greatest disdain for soap opera “drivel” and, inevitably perhaps, my addiction to daytime television became my most impassioned act of adolescent subversion.

headline: Capturing a Self-Image
text: KIM KARDASHIAN has cellulite!

headline: When Publicists Say ‘Shh!’
text: CELEBRITY publicists these days should demand hazard pay.

headline: Wine With Character
text: The manga series “The Drops of the Gods” follows Shizuku Kanzaki as he learns about wine, allowing the reader to do the same.

headline: When Soloists Don’t Necessarily Star
text: The composer Petr Kotik is also an adventurous conductor who founded and directs both the S.E.M. Ensemble, based in New York, and the Ostravska Banda, based in Ostrava, in the Czech Republic. Every now and then Mr. Kotik brings his groups together, as he did on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall. As in previous collaborations, their chemistry was just about perfect.

headline: An Uphill Battle, All in the Name of Art
text: Simone Forti’s “Slant Board” was first performed in 1961 in Yoko Ono’s loft on Chambers Street in Lower Manhattan. Ms. Ono was not at the Fitzroy Gallery in SoHo on Thursday night, where this 10-minute piece was presented a single time as part of the exhibition “Shelf Ramp Wedge Bridge/1.” But a host of art world and performance art figures, including Carolee Schneemann, Charlemagne Palestine, Joan Jonas and Dan Graham, were part of a packed crowd on hand for Ms. Forti, a choreographer often associated with the Judson Dance Theater although never formally a part of it.

headline: Sauvignon Blanc Season
text: In spring, one’s thoughts turn naturally to sauvignon blanc, a dry white wine with aromas and flavors that are generally described as grassy, “green,” herbaceous and vegetal. Their zesty acidity yields long finishes.

headline: One Man, Three Hats: A Turkish Experience
text: MIKE SARAC is practically a one-man band at Café Taka in Bay Shore. He is co-owner of the three-month-old Turkish spot with his wife, who does not work there; he is the chef and often the waiter as well. (He has a helper in the kitchen and a part-time waiter on weekends.)

headline: A Fest for the Eyes
text: Kicking off this weekend at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, the Fashion in Film Festival will be showing its third series of quality films, “Birds of Paradise.” Focusing primarily on the role of the costume, the festival aims to serve as a visual history lesson for fashion and film buffs with a timeline of European and American cinematic gems. Films scheduled to screen include the rare (Nino Oxilia’s “Rapsodia Satanica,” Jack Smith’s “Normal Love”) and the already loved (Cecil B. DeMille’s “Male and Female”).

headline: Sweet Luxury
text: The display in the oriel window at Belgique Chocolatier in New Canaan features an arrangement of rabbits, flowers and eggs — a not-too-subtle reminder that Easter is just as much an occasion for chocolates as Valentine’s Day is. But these are not sweets to be scattered around the yard for your children to collect. Belgique’s chocolates are made for more sophisticated palates, and priced that way, too.

headline: Pizza Mecca Gets New Décor and Menu
text: ALFORNO TRATTORIA, marking its 20th year in Old Saybrook this summer, has become something of a shoreline institution, known for its New Haven-style brick-oven pizza.

headline: Above All Else, Monkey Bread
text: At Loaf, a new bakery and cafe, an assortment of breads — ciabatta, dill, whole wheat, raisin, foccacia and rye — line a high wooden shelf, their crusty good looks set off by a vibrant backdrop of buttercup-yellow paint. But the golden-brown monkey bread ($7), a pull-apart bread baked in a cake pan, and still warm from the oven, handily upstaged the others.

headline: Reclaimed Classics, With Flavor Out Front
text: SOME diners may see the intentionally distressed “renovation” at Harper’s, with its flea market portraitures and minimal illumination, as oddly artsy; others may find it appealingly urban. Whichever. There’s no denying that Chris Vergara, the executive chef of this casual Dobbs Ferry bar and restaurant (he also co-owns Meritage in Scarsdale), has done an admirable job of repurposing scrapped wood into useful table tops, wainscoting and handsome wall paneling.

headline: From Four Wheels to Four Walls
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Community Health Faces Inquiry on Medicare Claims
text: Community Health Systems disclosed on Friday that it had received a subpoena by the federal government over possible improper billing of Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: 2 Men With Badges and a Story to Tell
text: “A Steady Rain” is about two regular-guy big-city police officers from the American Midwest, so naturally when the play hit Broadway in the fall of 2009, the producers cast Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman. The worldly, sexy, British-born James Bond. And the worldly, sexy, Australian-born Wolverine. The limited run of “A Steady Rain” made big money in New York, but no one seriously thought that audiences went to see the fine plotting or insightful character development by Keith Huff, the playwright. In fact, some critics declared the play itself weak. The Broadway run was all about the movie stars.

headline: A Spy Comedy, Complete With an Airplane Chase
text: Alfred Hitchcock was famous for turning up onscreen in the movies he directed. His walk-on was a silent little joke, flying right over the heads of the oblivious characters in the film to land smartly in the audience’s lap, a fleeting reminder that what they were watching was a fictional world concocted by the portly fellow who had just stepped out from behind the camera.

headline: On School Buses, Ad Space for Rent
text: Cash-hungry states and municipalities, in pursuit of even the smallest amounts of revenue, have begun to exploit one market that they have exclusive control over: their own property.

headline: Seeger and Friends, Newly Inspired, Will Meet for Benefit
text: WHEN the remaining giants of American folk music and their graying audience gather, the weight of history hangs heavy in the room. Memories of shared civil rights marches and antiwar rallies come flooding back, as do the inevitable questions about how the language of dissent they forged together can remain relevant.

headline: Japanese Carmakers’ Struggles Could Put Customers in Rivals’ Showrooms
text: DETROIT — Facing shortages of some auto parts and dwindling supplies of popular cars later this spring and summer, Japanese automakers hope shoppers looking for a new car will compromise on color or extra features.

headline: Bloggingheads: Fearing Islam
text: Imam Abdullah Antepli, left, of Duke University and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org debate Americans' views of Islam.

headline: At a Jazz Series, a Piano Also Stars
text: RAHWAY, N.J.

headline: Examining the Doctor-Patient Handshake
text: To the Editor:

headline: How a False Conviction Put a Man on Death Row
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Strings Are Paired With Poetry
text: Huntington, N.Y.

headline: It Depends on What the Meaning of ‘Metaphor’ Is
text: To the Editor:

headline: In This Cinderella Story, the Prince’s Ball Was a Robbery in Queens
text: Cinderella: a fairy tale, a plucky young lady, a label for rags-to-riches success. And now, in Queens, the word is also a shorthand reference to criminal case No. Q11610636, and as such, an unfortunate nickname for an inmate in a Riker’s Island jail dorm for men.

headline: The High Stakes of Republicans’ Budget Vote
text: In Manhattan today, federal prosecutors released an indictment against the founders of the two largest companies to offer online poker to Americans, Full Tilt Poker and PokerStars, charging them with fraud and seeking more than $3 billion in penalties.

headline: Unions Woo Airport Security Screeners
text: Public employee unions may be taking a shellacking in Wisconsin and Ohio, but that has not discouraged the unions representing federal employees from vying to recruit 44,000 airport screeners. It is the largest unionization effort of federal workers in the nation’s history.

headline: A New Jersey Native Returns, Anything but Silent
text: KEVIN SMITH, the Red Bank native and director of New Jersey-based films like “Clerks” (1994) and “Jersey Girl” (2004), is under no illusions about his celebrity status in his home state.

headline: Comfort Food, All Day and All Night Long
text: The downtown institutions of late night like Florent and the Empire Diner are gone, but their spirit lives on at Cafeteria, a 24-hour modern diner that opened in 1998 on Seventh Avenue at 17th Street. The sleek, minimalist decor and the menu of updated American comfort food still attract crowds of young partiers, celebrities and neighborhood residents. It is a place where those ending their evenings cross paths with those starting their days, where one table might ask for milk in a sippy cup while another asks for more beer. At 2:30 Sunday morning, the crowd included a table of friends from high school in Port Washington, N.Y., out for a bite after bar-hopping in Midtown.

headline: California May Require Teaching of Gay History
text: LOS ANGELES — In California public schools, students are required to learn about black history and women’s history. And if a bill approved by the State Senate this week becomes law, the state will become the first in the country to mandate that schools also teach gay history.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Young and Younger

headline: Paul Violi, a Poet Both Wry and Sly, Dies at 66
text: Paul Violi, a poet with an easy, conversational style and satiric bent who reworked arcane historical verse forms and invented his own in poems that mimicked glossaries, errata slips, travel brochures and cover letters, died on April 2 in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. He was 66 and lived in Putnam Valley.

headline: Can Teetering Toddlers Find Balance in Yoga?
text: SOMETIMES getting a child into a child’s pose is harder than it sounds.

headline: Four-Wheeled Perk Is Felled by Budget Ax
text: LOS ANGELES — With Gov. Jerry Brown still unable to get agreement on cuts to the state budget, California legislators now have to endure a cut of their own: their vehicles.

headline: In the Beefsteak Revival, Gluttony Is Good
text: EVERY now and then, it seems, some wistful city dreamer gets it into his head to resuscitate an old New York tradition and, before you know it, a newfangled speakeasy or a resurrected stickball league or an up-to-the-minute version of burlesque appears. At present, this seeming need for history has brought about a small rebirth of the classic New York beefsteak: the time-honored, Tammany-era smorgasbord where scores of hungry carnivores would gorge themselves on endless trays of sirloin and bottomless pints of beer.

headline: Sprint C.E.O. Continues Battle Against Wireless Merger
text: AT&T’s proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA threatens competition and innovation in the wireless industry, Dan Hesse, Sprint Nextel’s chief executive, said on Friday.

headline: Builders Group and Executives Admit to Taking Kickbacks
text: A construction-management company and three of its officers pleaded guilty on Friday to a scheme in which its executives stole millions of dollars from clients at condominium and office projects in the New York area by submitting fake invoices and taking kickbacks from its subcontractors.

headline: Immigrants Are Subject of Tough Bill in Georgia
text: ATLANTA — With Gov. Nathan Deal’s acknowledgment that he would sign a tough immigration law, Georgia was thrust on Friday into the center of the national fight over how much control states have in curbing illegal immigration.

headline: Busy, Busy, Busy (Toting Pinky)
text: A former prosecutor and talk show host and an estranged alumna of “The View,” Star Jones, 49, last month published her third book, “Satan’s Sisters,” a roman à clef about a fictitious TV talk show featuring five women of clashing temperaments. Currently a contestant on “Celebrity Apprentice 2011,” Ms. Jones, who underwent open-heart surgery a year ago, has assumed the role of national volunteer for the American Heart Association. She lives on the Upper East Side with her dog, Pinky, a Maltese, and has a house in Wainscott, on Long Island. ROBIN FINN

headline: Zoo’s 4-D Theater Tickles, While Tackling Wallets
text: You’re sitting in a seat that is vibrating ominously, though it’s not one of those coin-operated massage chairs. Someone is spitting on you. Something that might be a rat or a roach or a foot fetishist is flicking or possibly licking your ankles. Where are you?

headline: An Uncivil War
text: With spring holidays upon us, it is perhaps appropriate to recall that there are times at which we must, if we are to be fully human, loose ourselves from the rationalist-materialist bonds of our daily existence and remember that life is about more than money.

headline: From Pay-to-Play to Jail
text: New Yorkers, unfortunately, are all too accustomed to seeing state legislators sent off to jail for their misdeeds. When a court officer slipped handcuffs on Alan Hevesi, the former state comptroller, on Friday morning, however, Mr. Hevesi became the highest-ranking elected official in New York’s modern history to go to prison for corruption.

headline: One Year Later
text: Next week marks the first anniversary of an environmental disaster — the explosion at BP’s Macondo oil well that killed 11 workers, sank the drilling rig, sent 4.9 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and threw thousands of people out of work. Yet Congress is behaving as if nothing at all happened, as if there were no lessons to draw from the richly documented chain of errors and regulatory shortcomings that contributed to the blowout.

headline: Mortgage Woes Stall Bank of America Revival
text: As big banks slowly shake off losses from the financial crisis, Bank of America provided another reminder on Friday of how hard it is to shed the legacy of the past.

headline: Critic of War Effort Does His Homework, Up Close
text: NEWPORT, R.I.

headline: Breaking Through on Trade
text: After two years of dithering, it is good to see the Obama administration championing freer trade. Last week, the United States and Colombia announced a deal that will improve, and we hope finally win passage of, a 2006 trade agreement signed during the Bush administration. The amended version will strengthen worker protections in Colombia while boosting American exports.

headline: An American Romantic Goes to War
text: Just two days after the surrender of Fort Sumter, a crowd gathered at City Hill in Worcester, Mass., to rally for war. Lincoln had called for troops to put down the insurrection the day before, and few responded as passionately as Worcester’s citizens — chief among them abolitionist Thomas Wentworth Higginson. “Tonight we have more than enthusiasm,” announced Higginson. “We have unanimity!”

headline: Mitt! Mitt! Mitt!
text: This was the week we’ve been waiting for! Decades into the future, you will be able to tell your grandchildren where you were when Mitt Romney announced that he had formed a presidential exploratory committee.

headline: The Statue of Liberty Holds Its Own Against Las Vegas Facsimiles
text: LAS VEGAS — For the record, as if that mattered, Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was never a tourist here, having died in 1904, a year before the city’s founding as a whistle stop. But the man and the city are now linked in a way that Bartholdi, a Frenchman, would surely never have imagined — the United States Postal Service, for a new stamp featuring Lady Liberty, chose an image not of the original statue in New York Harbor but of a replica at the traffic-choked corner of Tropicana Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard.

headline: Somali Pirates Release Some Prisoners
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — After receiving more than $3 million in ransom, Somali pirates released a hijacked ship and some of its crew, but kept the Indian crew members to try to win the release of pirates held by India, pirates and residents said.

headline: The Pirates of Capitol Hill
text: Corporations are roaring. Wall Street is rolling in cash. C.E.O. bonuses are going gangbusters. It’s a really good time to be rich!

headline: At Titanic Gala, and Thankful for the Nosebleed Seats
text: The guests had just eaten a sumptuous dinner at the Guggenheim Museum on Thursday night, and an orchestra began playing an eerie dirge. Midway through, the partygoers were marched to their “deaths.”

headline: U.S. Has Plans to Improve Online Business Security
text: The federal government plans to spend $56.3 million on technology intended to safeguard the online marketplace and those who operate in it, including consumers, businesses and government agencies. “The fact is that the old password and username combination we often use to verify people is no longer good enough,” and leaves Internet users “vulnerable to ID and data theft,” Gary Locke, the commerce secretary, said Friday at a conference in Washington. The network would let consumers use devices like “software on a smartphone, a smart card, or a token that generates a one-time digital password,” according to a White House statement.

headline: Defense, Treading Carefully, Questions Accuser in Trial of 2 Officers
text: She had been on the witness stand for some eight hours spanning two days, recounting gruesome, emotional details of an evening in which she said a police officer raped her, when a moment of levity interrupted.

headline: U.S. and China Agree to a Process to Analyze Risks in Economies Worldwide
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and China agreed on Friday to participate in a new international process that will review the risks that major economic powers pose to each other and to global growth and development.

headline: Fans Laugh and Cry for Humbled Pro’s 16 on Par 4
text: Kevin Na, a little-known professional golfer, chased his ball into some woods and brambles Thursday during a PGA Tour event in Texas. About five minutes and 16 frenzied, desperate and comical strokes later, he emerged a folk hero.

headline: A Bunker Sets the Scene for Veterans to Exhibit Art
text: On a tranquil side street in brownstone Brooklyn, where the biggest battles are over takeout menus and strollers, looms a jarringly martial sight: dozens of olive-drab sandbags piled high under a saw-toothed zinc roof.

headline: Man Stabs Restaurateur in Brooklyn, Police Say
text: The owner of Lucali, a famed pizzeria in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, was brutally attacked and stabbed in broad daylight by an acquaintance on Friday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Saturday: Is This Thing On?
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people will do anything for attention.

headline: Ford Transit Connect: New York’s Taxi of Tomorrow?
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Schwartz writes about his time behind the wheel of the Ford Transit Connect, one of three boxy high-top vans competing to become New York’s next official taxi. A decision is expected from the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission within a month.

headline: Uganda: Antigovernment Protest Set Off by Tuition-Increase Report
text: Anti-riot police officers clashed with student protesters at Uganda’s most prestigious university Friday as students demonstrated against tuition increases and widespread government corruption. Students at Makerere University threw stones at the police and burned kiosks as officers shot rubber bullets and threw tear-gas canisters, above, into dormitories and fleeing crowds. The protest began over a report that university administrators planned to double the tuition, which the administration denied, but turned into a protest against President Yoweri Museveni. There have been several small protests over the last week against rising prices and corruption. Protests were also reported in the west on Friday. On Thursday, a former presidential candidate and leading opposition figure, Kizza Besigye, was shot during street demonstrations in Kampala, the capital.

headline: China: 54 Detained in Crackdown
text: At least 54 people have been detained in the current crackdown on progressive thought and speech in China, according to a statement released Thursday by China Human Rights Defenders, an advocacy group. The latest person to be detained is Ni Yulan, a housing activist and former lawyer, after previously being tortured by security officers. Ms. Ni and her husband, Dong Jiqin, were taken on April 7 from a Beijing hotel where they had been living. Ms. Ni has not been charged with a crime. So far, four people have been criminally charged during the crackdown. Ms. Ni is likely to have come under increased scrutiny after Jon Huntsman Jr., the American ambassador, visited her in February. Mr. Huntsman and the United States government are suspected by some Chinese officials of promoting the calls for a so-called Jasmine Revolution to challenge Communist Party rule. The most famous of the 54 detainees is Ai Weiwei, an artist and democracy activist.

headline: Indonesia: Police Station Bombed
text: A suicide bomber blew himself up during prayers in a mosque in a police station on Friday, wounding dozens of people and killing himself, antiterrorism officials said. The bomber attacked the police station in the West Java city of Cirebon while officers and members of the public crowded into the mosque, wounding at least 28 people, including the police chief, said Air Marshal Chairul Akbar, the general secretary of Indonesia’s National Antiterrorism Agency.

headline: Democrats Pounce on Chris Christie’s Blunt Words
text: Using harsh terms to attack his critics has been a regular feature of Gov. Chris Christie’s 15 months in office, and Democratic officials, wary of his and the voters’ wrath, have usually offered only a muted response.

headline: At Mob Murder Trial, Judge Criticizes Defense Lawyers’ Actions
text: A federal judge in Brooklyn chided defense lawyers on Friday for their actions during the trial of a Mafia boss accused of murder.

headline: Yankees Lose to Rangers as Hughes Goes on Disabled List
text: Hours after placing Phil Hughes, their struggling No. 3 starter, on the 15-day disabled list, the Yankees needed something, anything, to add a sense of solidity to a pitching staff that has stubbornly refused to coalesce in the early days of the season.

headline: County Results Find Incumbent the Victor in Wisconsin
text: CHICAGO — David T. Prosser Jr., a Wisconsin Supreme Court justice whose re-election became intertwined with the state’s battle over cuts to collective bargaining rights, won the race by 7,316 votes, results from the state’s counties showed on Friday.

headline: Celtics’ Depth Could Make All the Difference
text: Four summers ago, the Boston Celtics poached Ray Allen and Kevin Garnett, attached them to Paul Pierce and hatched a myth: that championships are built solely on three pillars.

headline: Knicks’ Anthony Insists It’s a Series, Not a Duel
text: There is nothing restrained or subtle about Carmelo Anthony’s offense. He will shoot from anywhere on the court, at virtually any time, with just about anyone in front of him.

headline: G.O.P. Push in States to Deregulate Environment
text: Weeks after he was sworn in as governor of Maine, Paul LePage, a Tea Party favorite, announced a 63-point plan to cut environmental regulations, including opening three million acres of the North Woods for development and suspending a law meant to monitor toxic chemicals that could be found in children’s products.

text: C.J. Chivers reports on the use of cluster bombs in civilian neighborhoods in Misurata.

headline: Second Doubleheader in Two Days Doesn’t Play Well With Mets
text: ATLANTA — After a double debacle on Thursday, the last thing the Mets needed or wanted was another doubleheader to compound their early-season difficulties. But a rainout at Turner Field on Friday left the Mets scrambling to line up pitchers for the rest of the weekend, and angry at the Braves for foisting a doubleheader on them on Saturday.

headline: Walt Frazier — Always in Style
text: In Walt Frazier’s closet hangs a polyester cow-print suit with brown-and-black splotches. However absurd, it fits in a menagerie of 100 or so suits that hang on five racks and with patterns of tiger stripes and leopard spots; designs of bold plaids and checks; and colors of yellow, red, salmon and orange.

headline: Civilian Casualties in Misurata
text: When cluster bombs like those used by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are fired into populated areas, they place civilians at grave risk.

headline: Garry Reigenborn, a Dancer and Influential Choreographer, Dies at 58
text: Garry Reigenborn, a dancer and choreographer who played an influential role in American experimental dance as a leading member of the Lucinda Childs Dance Company and as a teacher of Merce Cunningham’s technique, died on March 10 in Canon City, Colo. He was 58.

headline: The Myth of ‘Playoff-Style Basketball’
text: The system of playoff expectation in the N.B.A. has long been backward: rather than assuming regular season success translates seamlessly into postseason splendor, playoff teams are treated with skepticism unless they’ve “been there before.” 82 games apparently aren’t enough to create a representative sample of a team’s performance, and those who haven’t made extended postseason runs in the past are required to prove themselves once again before earning the respect of media pundits and basketball fans alike.

headline: A House of Glass
text: The cascading public staircase that covers the new TKTS discount booth in Duffy Square is made almost entirely of structural-strength glass: walls, beams, treads and risers.

headline: Come and Meet Those Stepping Feet
text: The newest lights on Broadway are at the new TKTS booth at 47th Street, which offers a kinetic panorama of Times Square.

headline: Blast Kills 9 at Afghan Base, Including 5 From NATO
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in two days, a suicide bomber used an Afghan uniform to elude early detection and approach his target, killing five NATO service members attending an early Saturday meeting at the headquarters of the Afghan 201 Corps in the country’s east. The bombing was one of the worst attacks of its kind, NATO and Afghan military officials said.

headline: Lively, Freaky Qualifying Session in China Despite Vettel Domination
text: We are only three races into the season but we are growing used to seeing the same man dominate everything, and today’s qualifying session for the Chinese Grand Prix was no different. Sebastian Vettel scored the pole position and his Red Bull dominated the session from the beginning – no contest. Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton were second and third fastest, for McLaren Mercedes, and Nico Rosberg was fourth fastest in the Mercedes.

text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — The remarkable lineup of musical events and performers at the Lucerne Easter Festival this week has lived up to every realistic expectation. The trick is, in the face of such rich potential, to remain realistic.

headline: Why So Many Applications for So Few Elite Spots? Continuing the Discussion
text: Earlier this week, NPR’s “To the Point” asked “Who’s Applying to Harvard and Who’s Getting In,” with the program focusing on the surge of applications to the two or three dozen elite colleges and universities.

text: Drug courts give arrested addicts a chance to avoid jail by agreeing to a strict program of drug tests, counseling and addiction treatment.

headline: Civility is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
text: At the beginning of last week, the commentariat was in raptures over the Serious, Courageous, Game-Changing Ryan plan. But now that the plan has been exposed as the cruel nonsense it is, what we’re hearing a lot about is the need for more civility in the discourse. President Obama did a bad thing by calling cruel nonsense cruel nonsense; he hurt Republican feelings, and how can we have a deal when the GOP is feeling insulted? What we need is personal outreach; let’s do lunch!

headline: Bookshelf
text: Bharati Mukherjee’s novel “Miss New India” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25) presents the country’s seismic shifts from the perspective of Anjali, a provincial young woman climbing the class ladder. She falls in with a gay expat English teacher and, later, urban arrivistes who watch “Seinfeld” and tell her that Bangalore is just like Los Angeles, you know, “the poor man’s Bombay.” “Fire and Rain” (Da Capo Press, $25), David Browne’s cultural history of 1970, begins with three Beatles finishing “Let It Be” while John Lennon lams it in Denmark. (Paul Simon, meanwhile, amazes N.Y.U. students when he decides to teach a songwriting class.)

headline: Private Residence Clubs: Anyone Still Buying In?
text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan takes a look at the world of private residence clubs and fractional ownership real estate. The most well-known example is Exclusive Resorts, where a hefty sign-up fee plus other levies earn you the right to bed down in fancy vacation homes in exotic locales for several weeks each year.

headline: Hammer and Tickle
text: Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, that’s not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from Soviet diaspora children, a whip-smart group now in their 20s and 30s that includes Regina Spektor, Mila Kunis, Anton Yelchin, the comedian Eugene Mirman (a childhood friend of Simone’s), and the writers Gary Shteyngart, Keith Gessen and Sana Krasikov.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The Roman Catholic Church is preparing to introduce the most significant changes in the Mass in the more than 40 years since the church permitted English in place of Latin. But thousands of priests complain that the new English-language translation of the Roman Missal, the book of texts and prayers used in the Mass, is awkward, archaic and inaccessible.

headline: Fantastic Fountains
text: WET Designs is the originator of some of the world's most famous fountains. Owner Mark Fuller explains his business vision and gives a tour of the meticulously designed WET Campus.

headline: Prime Number
text: 24: The average debt, in thousands of dollars, of college students who took out loans and graduated last year, according to Mark Kantrowitz, publisher of FinAid and Fastweb, who has compiled the estimates of student debt. Two-thirds of bachelor’s degree recipients graduated with debt in 2008, compared with less than half in 1993. Overall, student loan debt outpaced credit card debt for the first time last year and is likely to top a trillion dollars this year as more students go to college and more borrow money to do so. “In the coming years, a lot of people will still be paying off their student loans when it’s time for their kids to go to college,” Mr. Kantrowitz said.

headline: WET Design and the Improv Approach to Listening
text: This interview with  Mark Fuller, C.E.O. (which stands for chief excellence officer) of WET Design, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Homework Regulators Aren’t Doing
text: “ONE too many times, this court has been witness to the shoddy practices and sloppy accountings of the mortgage service industry. With each revelation, one hopes that the bottom of the barrel has been reached and that the industry will self correct. Sadly, this does not appear to be reality.”

headline: The Budget Debate, Revealed
text: WASHINGTON  —  The air in the capital these days is thick with references to trillion-dollar deficits, debt-to-G.D.P. ratios and mandatory spending. But the budget debate that became fully engaged last week is about far more than accounting and arcane policy disputes. What is under way now is the most fundamental reassessment of the size and role of government — of the balance between personal responsibility and private markets on the one hand and public responsibility and social welfare on the other — at least since Ronald Reagan and perhaps since F.D.R.

headline: Nigerians Vote in Presidential Election
text: A watershed presidential election in one of America’s top oil suppliers, Nigeria, unfolded peacefully on Saturday, a first for a country with a history of rigged and violent votes in the 12 years since the end of military rule.

headline: Cyrus Harvey, an Extravagant Entrepreneur, Dies at 85
text: Cyrus I. Harvey, a quirky entrepreneur who created two significant brands in disparate fields — Janus Films, a distributor of movies by international directors like Bergman, Fellini and Kurosawa, and Crabtree & Evelyn, the purveyor of aromatic soaps and botanicals — died Thursday in Dayville, Conn. He was 85 and lived in Woodstock, Conn.

headline: Nuclear Cleanup Plans Hinge on Unknowns
text: TOKYO — Even before the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has been brought under control, two conglomerates vying for contracts in an eventual cleanup are estimating that the effort could take 10 years — or 30.

text: To the Editor:
