headline: Germany Turns a Death Strip Into a Sanctuary
text: In the days when Germany was divided, East Germany built a barrier of fences, watch towers and minefields to keep its people from crossing over to the west. Stretching 870 miles from the Baltic to Bavaria, the border was patrolled by soldiers and guard dogs — a no-man’s land 100 feet to a few hundred feet wide that few dared to cross.

headline: Euro vs. Invasion of the Zombie Banks
text: IS a euro held in an Irish bank in Dublin, or in a Portuguese bank in Lisbon, as sound and secure as a euro in a German bank in Berlin? That apparently simple question holds the key to understanding why the euro zone may splinter and bring a new financial crisis.

headline: The Wall of Worry Has Never Looked So High
text: THE stock market has been climbing a wall of worry — that’s an old Wall Street adage, and it has certainly rung true lately. Calamities abound and there have been setbacks, but the market has been climbing anyway.

headline: Entrepreneurs on the Fringes of Yankees Inc.
text: The stores, stands and bars around the new Yankee Stadium, now in its third season, can still rely on plenty of household names to lure fans.

headline: Cuban Leader Proposes Term Limits in Sign of New Era
text: HAVANA — For 52 years the Castro brothers have ruled Cuba. But if President Raúl Castro has his way, he may be out of the job as soon as 2013 and definitely by 2018, when he is 86.

headline: Workplace Fiction That’s True to Life
text: I’VE often wondered why there aren’t more strong works of fiction dealing with the business world. Offhand, with the possible exception of Tom Wolfe’s “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” Richard Ford’s real estate dramas, or Michael Crichton’s forgettable “Disclosure,” I can’t think of many novels of recent years that grapple with the kinds of issues most business people encounter.

headline: Serving a Cause, 25 Cents at a Time
text: IN February, Noah Fradin turned 18 — finally. It’s a relief, he says, that he no longer needs his mom to co-sign the nondisclosure agreements and other documents related to his plan to change the world.

headline: Helping Drunken Drivers Avoid Tickets, but Not Wrecks
text: FRIENDS don’t let friends drive drunk. If they can’t take their friend’s keys away, they take their smartphone. Why? The phone may have an app that can help them avoid sobriety checkpoints.

headline: Variety: Ditsy Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams come out only once every few months, so the key here, as they say, is to just relax and enjoy the ride. They also tend to be much easier than cryptics, so they are a good place to start if you find yourself stymied by cryptic cluing.

headline: After Jail, Repairing a Career and a Life
text: EVERYONE makes mistakes, both in their personal life and at work. I committed a felony against a company I worked for, and I’m not proud of it. I served time and I’ll be making restitution for a long time. However, I’m one of the lucky ones; I found another job afterward.

headline: More Than a Famous Name
text: I WAS born when my father, the civil rights leader Andrew Young, was a congressman. I’m always asked what it’s like to be his son. I’m fortunate to have a dad who’s a role model for me and a close friend. His name opened doors for me, but once I got in, I knew that I had to create value.

headline: Who Really Cares How Yuppies Raise Their Kids?
text: First there was Amy Chua, the Yale law professor and author of “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” who sent legions of parents into a tizzy with her exacting standards for piano practice and prohibitions against sleepovers.

headline: Storm Kills 7 Overnight in Alabama
text: A punishing storm system that began Thursday evening continued to pummel parts of the Deep South into the early hours of Saturday morning. Tornadoes and vicious winds left 17 people dead across four states, officials said.

headline: Sweet Valley Twins Are Back, and, Like Readers, Fully Adult
text: In the annals of 1980s young-adult fiction, there were no teenage heroines more loyal, more youthfully wholesome, more impossibly flawless than Elizabeth and Jessica Wakefield of the “Sweet Valley High” series, with their cascading blond hair, aqua eyes, rosy lips and perfect (in the ’80s, anyway) Size 6 figures.

headline: As Inmates 23 and 24, Stunned Mubaraks Adjust
text: CAIRO — The prison is called Tora Farm, but there is nothing agricultural about it. It is a two-story block of poured concrete, and for years its massive gray walls have held those deemed enemies of the powerful.

headline: The Raider in Winter: Carl Icahn at 75
text: CARL C. ICAHN chases deals the way a dog chases cars. The guy just won’t quit. Talk to him for three minutes, and you get the feeling he couldn’t quit if he wanted to.

headline: Distilling the Wisdom of C.E.O.’s
text: This article was adapted from “The Corner Office: Indispensable and Unexpected Lessons From CEOs on How to Lead and Succeed,” by Adam Bryant, author of the weekly “Corner Office” column in The New York Times. The book, published Tuesday by Times Books, analyzes the broader lessons that emerge from his interviews with more than 70 leaders.

headline: Video of Funnel Clouds in Mississippi
text: A vicious storm system that began in Oklahoma on Thursday has been moving across the southeastern United States, leaving 17 people dead in four states.

headline: In the N.H.L., Short and Fast Sizes Up Well
text: Buffalo’s Nathan Gerbe skates into the Philadelphia zone, spinning 270 degrees, stopping on a dime, then backhands home the goal that clinches a playoff berth for the Sabres.

headline: At the Point for the Knicks With Time Running Out
text: The last time a rising Knicks team played an aging championship Boston squad in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs, mortality visited the favored Celtics at a most inopportune moment.

headline: Ups and Downs of Two Top Picks
text: On Thursday, the Mets faced Greg Reynolds, a Colorado Rockies right-hander holding a spot in the rotation for the team’s injured ace, Ubaldo Jimenez. The next night, the Chicago White Sox started another right-hander, Philip Humber, in place of their injured ace, Jake Peavy.

headline: The Mets Do Not Have to Look Far to Find Bidders
text: He is a man in his 40s or 50s and is probably from Long Island.

headline: Freedivers Are Testing the Bounds of Human Endurance
text: LONG ISLAND, Bahamas — Shouts of “Breathe! Breathe! Breathe!” pierced the tropical air and echoed off the limestone precipice around Dean’s Blue Hole, a vertical cavern plunging 660 feet, a cobalt blue pool of seawater surrounded by crystal-clear shallows and white sand.

headline: U.S. and Allies Seek a Refuge for Qaddafi
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has begun seeking a country, most likely in Africa, that might be willing to provide shelter to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi if he were forced out of Libya, even as a new wave of intelligence reports suggest that no rebel leader has emerged as a credible successor to the Libyan dictator.

headline: The Price of Printing Bad Stamps
text: The United States Postal Service admitted this week that its Lady Liberty stamp actually doesn’t show the famous statue in New York Harbor, but a half-size copy standing in front of a Las Vegas casino. But the post office’s assurances that it “loves” the design anyway may have less to do with aesthetics and more to do with the potential cost of replacing the billions of stamps already printed — to say nothing of making instant collector’s items out of the uncounted number already used on mail.

headline: Mets’ Young Goes on the Disabled List
text: ATLANTA — The Mets placed the right-handed pitcher Chris Young on the 15-day disabled list Saturday with biceps tendinitis and called up Pat Misch to cover them in the bullpen for their doubleheader with the Braves.

headline: Weathering a Midlife Crisis In the Haunts of Table Tennis
text: I played table tennis for the first time in a South Bronx cellar in February 1971, when the sport was called Ping-Pong and my opponent was a gangly adolescent wearing a perm and bell-bottoms. Two months later, a United States Ping-Pong team was invited for a weeklong visit to China, which helped restore relations between the countries and elevated the game’s status.

headline: Women Irate at Remarks by President of Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — President Ali Abdullah Saleh’s suggestion that antigovernment protesters in the capital were in violation of Islamic law because women were allowed to mix with men stirred a women’s rights march in the capital on Saturday, as thousands of women in this staunchly conservative country made Mr. Saleh an object of public derision.

headline: Three Veterans Having Impact in Postseason
text: Among the early surprises in the first days of the Stanley Cup playoffs was the play of three veterans whose best days were supposedly behind them: Montreal’s Scott Gomez, Nashville’s Steve Sullivan and Detroit’s Todd Bertuzzi.

headline: Egyptian Court Formally Breaks Up Mubarak’s Party
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Saturday continued the process of dismantling Hosni Mubarak’s institutions of power when it formally dissolved the political organization that ruled the nation for decades, the National Democratic Party.

headline: Sympathy for DiMaggio?
text: In 1941, Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees put together a 56-game hitting streak that was the talk of baseball. For all the attention he received, DiMaggio’s .357 batting average at the end of the season fell well short of the American League lead, as Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox famously batted .406.

headline: The Psychology of Cheating
text: To some it was a fitting end to a pointless witch hunt. On Wednesday, after weeks of graphic testimony about steroid use, a jury in San Francisco could not reach a verdict on charges that Bonds had lied about using performance-enhancing drugs, and the judge declared a mistrial.

headline: In Iraq, Bottoms Up for Democracy
text: BAGHDAD  —  Tariq Harb, who was a military attorney under Saddam Hussein and is now a constitutional lawyer and television talking head, was happy to see the liquor flowing again at the Iraqi Writers Union’s outdoor cafe. But many other Iraqis aren’t. “There are people who want to kill me because I drink,” he said, shuffling prayer beads at the cafe. “We are fighting the religious educators, the imams, the preachers, who are extremists.”

headline: Syrian Leader Says He Will Lift Emergency Law
text: CAIRO — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria addressed his nation on Saturday in a televised speech aimed at appeasing a two-month-old protest movement that has posed an unprecedented challenge to his family’s four decades of rule, according to human rights groups.

headline: The French, the Veil and the Look
text: PARIS  —  Many scholars of Islam will tell you that nothing in the Koran requires a Muslim woman to cover her face — that its rules for proper Islamic dress are ambiguous and limited. “Say to the believing women that they should lower their gaze and guard their modesty,” it says. It adds, “They should draw their veils over their bosoms and not display their ornaments.”

headline: A Shot at a Sane Budget
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Incoming Schools Chancellor Seeks Calmer Debate
text: Dennis M. Walcott said Saturday that he planned to use a softer touch as New York City’s new schools chancellor to ease the bitter rhetorical battles that have caused wide divisions among teachers, parents and bureaucrats. But Mr. Walcott also made it clear that he did not plan any major shifts in Education Department policy.

headline: Afghan and Pakistani Leaders Meet in Peace Bid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Much of Pakistan’s civilian and military leadership flew here Saturday for a meeting with Afghanistan’s president to discuss efforts to forge peace with the Taliban. Although leaders from the two countries have met before to discuss a peace deal, the gathering Saturday was unprecedented because of the number of high-level Pakistani officials in attendance.

headline: You Say Bay of Pigs, I Say ...
text: Havana

headline: Pinned Down in Battered City, Libyan Rebels Endure With Grit and Dirt
text: MISURATA, Libya — Muftah Militan, a rebel with his wounded right arm in a sling and a two-way radio in his left hand, peered from a rooftop at a low-slung skyline. Occasional gunfire chattered below.

headline: Amazon Dolphins in Danger
text: The pink river dolphin is a storied symbol of the Amazon, but local fishermen are slaughtering the animal for catfish bait.

headline: Nature vs. Nurture, as Seen by Economists
text: In a piece for the Week in Review, I take a look at the most recent yin and yang of the parenting world: Amy Chua, author of “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” vs. Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason University who argues in “Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids” that parents should relax, because nature matters much more than nurture.

headline: Fishermen in Amazon See a Rival in Dolphins
text: IGARAPÉ DO COSTA, Brazil — Along the rivers of the Amazon rain forest, people still recount legends in which pink dolphins are magical creatures that can turn into men and impregnate women. Brazilian musicians write songs about them, singing lovingly about the “eye of the river dolphin.”

headline: New York’s Green Grid
text: MANHATTAN’S street grid, which turned 200 years old last month, has long been an easy target for urban romantics. They love to point out how its relentless logic — most blocks are a precise 200 feet by 600 feet — imposed a soulless Cartesian order on a once-lush coastal island, trampling nature and leading to two centuries of real-estate mania.

headline: 30 Seconds With Bill Walton
text: Bill Walton, who won two championships at U.C.L.A. under Coach John Wooden, also won two N.B.A. championships, with Portland in 1977 and with Boston in 1986. He was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993.

headline: How the Credit Crisis Unfolded
text: The extent of the credit crisis that unfolded from the morning of Sept. 17 to the afternoon of Sept. 18. was unseen to the public but spooked policy makers into action.

headline: Testing Heat Distribution
text: An experiment to see how pans of different materials perform.

headline: Scenes From a Ball
text: Photos of Tarell Alvin McCraney’s play “Wig Out!”

headline: Moscow’s Drinking Problem
text: VILLANOVA, Pa. — IN an effort to reduce both its sky-high alcoholism rate and its budget gap, Russia recently announced plans to quadruple the tax on the country’s eternal vice, vodka, over the next three years.

headline: Tiger Beat: Still Squeaky Clean After All These Years
text: Hair floating, skin dewy, eyes free of guile: the boys of Tiger Beat will never hurt you. In crisp photos and squeaky-clean quotes about love, they’ve been practically interchangeable for more than four decades. It’s an archetype that’s survived any number of invasions: the Brits, disco, boy bands, the Brat Pack, more boy bands, the Disney Channel, TMZ and more.

headline: Savvy Start by Garcia Helps Yanks Fill a Void
text: A pitching clinic was offered at Yankee Stadium on Saturday. It had not been advertised, but perhaps it should have been. The price of admission varied, though fans got their money’s worth regardless, rain and chill aside. The lesson lasted a little less than two hours, or as long as it took for the instructor, Freddy Garcia, to work six scoreless innings in his first start for the Yankees, a 5-2 victory against the Texas Rangers.

headline: Chemicals Were Injected Into Wells, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Oil and gas companies injected hundreds of millions of gallons of hazardous or carcinogenic chemicals into wells in more than 13 states from 2005 to 2009, according to an investigation by Congressional Democrats.

headline: Board of Philadelphia Orchestra Votes to File for Bankruptcy
text: 5:22 p.m. | Updated  The Philadelphia Orchestra’s program Saturday night was to include music from the Berg opera “Lulu,” and the ensemble hopes to avoid the protagonist’s tawdry end. The board of the Philadelphia Orchestra’s program voted Saturday to file for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. Unlike Lulu, who died at the hands of Jack the Ripper, the orchestra will live on, rehearsing and continuing to give concerts while a bankruptcy court judges considers the case.

headline: The Power of Mockery
text: The juiciest story behind the Middle East uprisings doesn’t concern Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s “voluptuous” Ukrainian nurse or C.I.A. bags of cash. Rather, it’s the tale of how a nonviolent revolutionary strategy crafted by Serbian students and an octogenarian American scholar came to challenge dictators in Egypt, Tunisia, Bahrain and many other countries.

headline: Justice, Too Much and Too Expensive
text: HABEAS corpus: it is, as Alexander Hamilton suggested, the “bulwark” of a Constitution. A habeas petition gives a single federal judge the authority to decide if a prisoner is being held unlawfully and order his release. At Guantánamo, habeas plays a crucial role: it provides the essential means by which the federal judiciary can ensure that innocent people are not mistakenly held, indefinitely, as enemy combatants. This is an example of habeas at its best.

headline: Wyoming’s Boom Poses Challenges For Obama
text: GILLETTE, Wyo. — Many economic signs are looking bright for Wyoming right now, and this red-knuckled city of coal miners and oil field mechanics is leading the charge.

headline: Atlas Without Angelina
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Westminster’s Wedding March
text: In choosing Westminster Abbey as the site for their wedding, Prince William and Kate Middleton are joining a select group.

headline: For World Champion, Two Uncommon Losses
text: Except for the world’s top players, few people ever have the chance to play a world champion. The exceptions are simultaneous exhibitions, where the champion will play 20 or 30 people at a time. Even then, though the champion has a bit of a handicap, it is a potentially intimidating experience.

headline: Tornado Damages Oklahoma School, but Shelter Beneath Stands Strong
text: TUSHKA, Okla. — For 90 years, people in this small rural community have used an underground shelter next to the public school to escape the tornadoes that frequently wreak havoc in the green and rolling countryside here. So when a major twister hit the town at 7:35 p.m. Thursday, people instinctively rushed toward the Tushka Public School to seek haven.

headline: France Flies, Germany Flops
text: Berlin

headline: Henry Wise’s Pistol
text: By mid-April 1861 Virginia’s secession convention had spent two months deadlocked over the question of whether to leave the Union. The disunionists, including Thomas Jefferson’s grandson, George Wythe Randolph, were outnumbered — but they also knew that events could easily tilt the balance in their favor, especially if the federal government took up arms against Virginia’s slave-holding former neighbors. On April 15, their moment finally arrived: in response to the shelling of Fort Sumter, Abraham Lincoln called up 75,000 troops, including 2,340 Virginians, to subdue the “rebellion.”

headline: Guantánamo, on Trial
text: In bringing justice to those accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, it will never be possible to have military trials at Guantánamo that Americans can be fully proud of, or that the world will see as credible.

headline: The Power of Punk’d
text: My Sunday column is about the ways bottom-up grassroots youth movements can bring about social change, from toppling Hosni Mubarak to curbing teen smoking. I was drawn into the subject out of fascination with the way the Serbian youth movement had developed strategies that spread to the Georgian revolution, the Ukrainian revolution, and the Egyptian revolution. But an equally important application of this approach is in fighting poverty at home and around the world.

headline: Wrongful Foreclosures
text: We were worried recently when we saw an advance draft of legal agreements between federal regulators and the nation’s big banks to address and correct foreclosure abuses. The actual deals were as bad as we feared.

headline: Whitman the Scrivener
text: Kenneth Price is one of many Walt Whitman scholars dedicated to tracking every jot and tittle left by the definitive poet of America. Three years ago, Mr. Price came upon a startling discovery, buried in the National Archives: Whitman’s handwriting and his signature initials on documents he copied during his Washington day job as a government clerk.

headline: Westminster’s Wedding March
text: WHEN Prince William and Kate Middleton marry on April 29, they will join a select group, even among royals. While the site of their wedding, Westminster Abbey, has been the place of every coronation since the Norman conquest, only 15 royal couples have been married there since it was founded in 960.

headline: Women’s Health: What to Believe?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tiger Beat Sampler
text: Selected covers of the teen-girl tabloid across the decades.

headline: Preserving Cowboy Culture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday: Whence Venus?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This one seemed tougher than past Sundays, but for me it was worth it. What’s better than a bunch of punchlines from stand-up comedians, humorists and one iconic horror writer? I am a fan of all of the people who contributed theme entries to Matt Ginsberg’s puzzle (even Anonymous), so I really enjoyed today’s puzzle.

headline: Secretive Ethics Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Qualities in an Astronaut: Who Has the Right Stuff?
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.A.A. to Change Air Traffic Controllers’ Schedules
text: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Saturday that it would change scheduling practices for air traffic controllers in an effort to combat excessive fatigue. The decision was announced after a controller was discovered napping while on duty early Saturday — at least the sixth controller to be caught doing so in recent months.

headline: To Get Back in Series, Rangers Need More From Dubinsky
text: Brandon Dubinsky is getting the playing time and responsibility a team’s leading scorer deserves. But as the Rangers enter Game 3 of their first-round playoff series against Washington on Sunday, Dubinsky will need to put the first two games in his rear-view mirror.

headline: With or Without Stars, the Bulls May Go Far
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Preservationists Fight to Save Prentice Women’s Hospital
text: In a last-ditch effort to block Northwestern University’s demolition of the old Prentice Women’s Hospital, historical preservationists have enlisted a team of architects to imagine three possible futures for the striking cloverleaf-shaped tower: research laboratory, medical office and student housing.

headline: 2010 Bills: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. East:

headline: In Springfield, a Week of Change in Education
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Emanuel Gets Boost, and Challenges, in Schools Bill
text: A sweeping public school reform bill unanimously approved late Thursday by the State Senate gives Mayor-elect Rahm Emanuel a chance to fulfill a campaign promise and lengthen Chicago’s school day, currently one of the shortest in the nation. But first he will have to overcome daunting budget, educational and labor obstacles.

headline: Niles Canyon Railway
text: Steam-powered locomotives still chug passengers on Sundays up a former Southern Pacific railway line from the old town of Niles, now part of Fremont, to Sunol, and back. The track winds through Niles Canyon, which is the site of Alameda Creek, numerous Charlie Chaplin films and the legend of a beautiful ghost.

headline: Willie Brown Academy, Born in 1992 With High Hopes, Will Close in May, a Failure
text: When the school now known as the Willie L. Brown Jr. College Preparatory Academy opened in San Francisco’s predominantly black Bayview neighborhood some 18 years ago, it was at the forefront of an ambitious effort to address school performance and segregation without busing children out of the neighborhood. It was once even part of a Dream Schools program that brought millions of dollars in special aid, along with school uniforms, longer school days and Saturday classes.

headline: A Rocky Day for the Dow
text: The Dow Jones industrial average evolved throughout the day, tracking the news from the House where voting on the $700 billion rescue package was taking place.

headline: After Dow Drops, Tension in Washington
text: The Dow closed down 777 points after the House rejected a $700 bailout package to rescue the financial industry.

headline: ‘Gang of Six’ in the Senate Seeking a Plan on Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Days after President Obama called for forming a bipartisan group in Congress to begin negotiating a $4 trillion debt-reduction package, the parties have not even agreed to its membership. Yet six senators — three Democrats, three Republicans — say they are nearing consensus on just such a plan.

headline: The Idle Rich Should Give Something Back: Taxes
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: City’s Art Is a Victim of Neglect, Damage and Loss
text: San Francisco has a trove of public art that should be the toast of the town. Valued at around $90 million and including more than 4,000 items, including statues, paintings and Edvard Munch lithographs, the Civic Art Collection is one of the richest repositories of city-owned art in the country.

headline: Humanity as Assailant, Earth as Avenger?
text: .TomDispatch, Grist and many other blogs are carrying an essay by Michael T. Klare, a professor of peace and world security studies at Hampshire College, that offers a counterpoint to Bill McKibben‘s account of a planet so marred by human affairs that it requires a distorted name, “Eaarth.” (The video above reflects this notion because it is less “natural” than it appears.)

headline: Stay in Atlanta Costs Mets Two Games and a Pitcher
text: ATLANTA — In the early afternoon Saturday, before the Mets would endure their second doubleheader sweep in less than 72 hours, Manager Terry Collins was discussing the various injuries and roster moves the Mets were facing heading into the day, including the possibility of left fielder Jason Bay being activated by Tuesday. That depended on things falling into place for the Mets, which has not happened very often this season, if at all.

headline: At Coachella, Many Takes on the ’80s
text: INDIO, Calif. — The artist can render any subject in infinite ways. One has to remember this sometimes at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, where bands are revising ’80s pop up, down, and backwards.

headline: Rangers Move On And Fire Away Without Lee
text: Cliff Lee pitched a shutout with 12 strikeouts for the Philadelphia Phillies on Thursday. The two other teams that tried to sign him, the Yankees and the Texas Rangers, met in the Bronx the next night, offering a snapshot of how they have dealt with rejection.

headline: Pastor Who Burned Koran Says He Was Duped Into Holding Back
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — The pastor who stoked violence in Afghanistan earlier this month by burning a Koran in March produced a recording on Saturday that he said proved he was deceived last September when he agreed to cancel plans to burn 200 copies of the Koran.

headline: Rivers Keeps Conversation on Knicks, Not Future
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — There are no lack of story lines for the Boston Celtics heading into the 2011 playoffs. Will Shaquille O’Neal ever play? Which team will show up, the one that started the season 23-4 or the one that finished 10-11?

headline: Mob Link Is Pursued in Fight Involving Owner of Pizzeria
text: The police have revised the account of a Friday fight between the owner of a popular Brooklyn pizzeria and a man whom a senior law enforcement official described as a Genovese mob associate, after finding witnesses who said that both men had wielded knives. The police were investigating whether the encounter had arisen out of a mob attempt to make the pizzeria owner share his profits.

headline: Obama Takes On Congress Over Policy Czar Positions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama issued a signing statement on Friday night saying that he could bypass a provision in the new budget that would prevent him from appointing White House “czars” to oversee major policy initiatives.

headline: Brazilian Criticizes Wealthy Nations’ Policies
text: WASHINGTON — Brazil’s finance minister said Saturday that developed nations like the United States were seeking to solve their own economic problems at the expense of the developing world.

headline: Palin Speaks at Tea Party Rally in Madison
text: MADISON, Wis. — At first, the prospect drew mildly worried looks from people on both sides of this state’s giant political divide: Sarah Palin, the former Republican vice-presidential candidate, was to appear on the steps of this state’s Capitol, the very place that has become a stage for demonstration after demonstration against Wisconsin’s Republican-led efforts to cut collective bargaining rights.

headline: Qi Bangkok Eatery Opens, With Pichet Ong Joining Later
text: Pichet Ong’s debut as a Thai chef at the new Qi Bangkok Eatery, just west of Times Square, will be delayed a little bit so the restaurant can get a propitious head start.

headline: Cartel Violence Complicates Tick Eradication Plan
text: An unexpected casualty of the drug-cartel-fueled lawlessness in Mexico: the cattle industry.

headline: Pat’s Pick
text: The best new restaurant

headline: Seeds of 2011’s Budget Troubles Were Planted, by the Legislature, in 2006
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Heat’s Opening Win Over 76ers Isn’t Without Complaints
text: MIAMI — The N.B.A. playoffs may be a battle of attrition, a test of endurance akin to the Daytona 500, but the Heat’s Eastern Conference quarterfinal opener Saturday against Philadelphia felt more like a drag race.

headline: House Bill on Student Testing Reopens a Familiar Debate
text: When Representative Rob Eissler, Republican of The Woodlands, brought House Bill 500 to the Texas House floor on April 6, he emphasized what it did not do.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Vows: Susan and Michael
text: Within eight months of meeting online, Susan and Michael knew they were meant to be together. Susan made space in her closet, and Michael found a temporary solution for an engagement ring.

headline: The Tea Party Rings In Tax Day
text: Possible Republican candidates for president in 2012 spoke around the country at rallies sponsored by the Tea Party on Saturday.

headline: To Capitals, a 2-0 Playoff Lead Is Rarely a Lock
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Things look desperate for the Rangers, but there is at least one encouraging fact: the Washington Capitals have held a two-games-to-none lead in a best-of-seven series five times — and four times they have lost the series.

headline: "Cinema Verite" Clip
text: HBO turns a PBS 1973 documentary into a new series, "Cinema Verite."

headline: Stoudemire Stands Out and Buys In to Lift Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It was 7:45 Friday morning, and the only sound in the Knicks’ suburban training center was the hum of a hard drive playing game film for the coaching staff. The relative quiet was interrupted by the sound of leather pinging against the hardwood outside the office window.

headline: For the Red Bulls, a Refreshing Burst of Goals
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls served up a heaping portion of revenge in a cold rain Saturday night, five months after the San Jose Earthquakes came to town and ended the Red Bulls’ promising 2010 season in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs.

headline: Sports Replay: April 16
text: A look at the day in sports, from the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs to the Bol d’Or motorcycle endurance race.

headline: 'Cinema Verite' Clip
text: HBO turns a PBS 1973 documentary into a new series, "Cinema Verite."

headline: Off-Duty Officer Injured in Brooklyn Shooting
text: An off-duty Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority officer was shot and injured as he tried to break up an armed robbery at an auto body shop in Brooklyn on Saturday night, the police said.

headline: Regulation of Offshore Rigs Is a Work in Progress
text: WASHINGTON — A year after BP’s Macondo well blew out, killing 11 men and spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the much-maligned federal agency responsible for policing offshore drilling has been remade, with a tough new director, an awkward new name and a sheaf of stricter safety rules. It is also trying to put some distance between itself and the industry it regulates.

headline: The Anti-Immigration Crusader
text: WASHINGTON — Three decades ago, a middle-aged doctor sat outside his northern Michigan home and saw a patch of endangered paradise.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: Rebels of Misurata
text: Libyans in Misurata have managed for almost two months to prevent their city from being overrun, and some of the reasons are visible on the street.

headline: Intiman Theater Cancels Season

His 13 movies — each one, arguably, a milestone of 20th-century American cinema — are celebrated in a retrospective at the Cinémathèque Française (51 rue de Bercy; 33-1-71-19-33-33; www.cinematheque.fr), showing through July 31.

The storms also severely injured 130 other people and leveled or damaged hundreds of homes, demolished a big-box store and a trailer park, plucked trees out of the earth, and left more than 84,000 people without power.

headline: Dig Downtown Unearths an Early Mayor’s Farm

Mirrors, Clowns and Other Visions
text: Alwin Nikolais, a pioneer of multimedia dance, didn’t stop at movement. He was a stagecraft wizard whose love for abstraction — along with lights, projections and electronic music — was strangely life affirming. He drew on a dancer’s musculature, not a dancer’s emotions. “He doesn’t even have to be a person — he can be a thing, a place or a time,” he once said.

headline: Jewish Melodies, Traditional and Not

headline: Unconventional Relievers Help Mets End Skid

headline: A Tale of Two Eight-Card Fits, One Found, One Bypassed
text: If you and your partner, with game values, find an eight-card fit in a major and one of you has a singleton or void, four of your major will normally be the best contract. Three no-trump will be preferable usually only if the short suit is opposite a strong holding. (If you find a nine-card major-suit fit, stop worrying about the right strain; just decide how high to go in that suit. The deals in which that will be wrong are so few and far between that you should leave top experts to try to unravel them.)

headline: Tracking TV Habits by Ethnic Groups
text: Last November, African-Americans watched two hours more television per day, on average, than the national average of 5 hours and 11 minutes, according to a report recently released by Nielsen, the TV ratings agency, which surveyed TV viewing habits by ethnicity. Asian-Americans watched about two hours less than the national average.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Makes Bankruptcy Move

Just hours earlier, its board of directors had voted to send the orchestra to bankruptcy court, declaring the move the only way to survive financial disaster.

headline: Two ‘Passions,’ With Two Very Different Effects
text: During Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival last year, critics at The New York Times debated the concept of spiritual music. I wrote that even a masterpiece needed a majestic interpretation to offer a more spiritual experience than a lesser work. Location would seem a more prosaic concern, but without favorable conditions even the greatest music can flounder.

headline: Avoiding ‘Moderato’ Becomes a Style
text: The composer Christopher Rouse, in an onstage conversation during a concert of his works presented at Zankel Hall on Friday evening, described one of the primary urges in his music with a striking line: “Anything worth doing is worth doing to excess.” He credited the saying to Mark Twain, though evidence points to Edwin H. Land, the inventor of Polaroid instant photography. (Famous quotations, like small children, are irresistible to bring up in conversation and nearly impossible to pin down.)

headline: Verdi, Nuanced and Empowered
text: The conductor Riccardo Muti has always had a big following in New York. So it was no surprise that Carnegie Hall was sold out for Friday night’s concert performance of Verdi’s “Otello,” the first of Mr. Muti’s three programs with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. His hugely anticipated first season as this historic orchestra’s music director has been twice interrupted for extended periods in recent months by serious health crises. But worries about his health vanished on Friday as Mr. Muti, looking calm, fit and rather self-satisfied, conducted an emphatic and insightful account of this challenging Verdi opera, drawing incisive and beautiful playing from the orchestra.

headline: Not Much to Steal but a Heart
text: Beane, the hero of John Kolvenbach’s too-quirky comedy, “Love Song,” has a reality problem: He doesn’t know how to live in it. He sees things from a strange perspective and then is defeated by them. Taking a multiple-choice personality test he can’t get his head around the questions, much less give acceptable answers.

headline: ‘Rio’ Takes Top Spot at Weekend Box Office
text: Hollywood’s parade of cartoon hits continues: “Rio,” above, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with an estimated $40 million in ticket sales. The tale of a Minnesota macaw on the hunt for love in South America, “Rio” cost 20th Century Fox about $90 million to make — cheaper than many animated films — and has already caught on overseas, where ticket sales total about $128 million. “Scream 4,” which cost the Weinstein Company about $40 million to make, was second with $19.3 million. That result was 57 percent less than the opening weekend in 2000 for the last installment of the “Scream” franchise, after adjusting for inflation. (But Weinstein does not have to split any profits with Disney, as it did on the previous “Scream” films.) “Hop,” from Universal Pictures, was third with about $11.2 million for a three-week total of $82.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Soul Surfer” (Sony) was fourth with $7.4 million for a two-week total of about $20 million. “Hanna” (Focus Features) was fifth with about $7.3 million for a two-week total of $23.3 million. Also notable: Robert Redford’s “Conspirator” (Roadside Attractions) sold $3.9 million in tickets in limited release.

headline: United Nations to Host Cooper-Hewitt Show
text: Remodeling can be inconvenient, particularly for museums. But the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, faced with the coming renovation of its historic mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, below, has found a not-inappropriate spot for its fall exhibition, which is focused on design solutions to the problems of global slums. The museum is to announce on Monday that the exhibition, titled “Design With the Other 90%: Cities,” will be at the United Nations. The second of two similarly themed exhibitions, the show will feature roughly 60 projects from 20 countries, aimed at solving problems related to housing, access to clean water, education, waste management and transportation. It will run from Oct. 15 to Jan. 9, and admission will be free. The mansion renovation is part of a $54 million overhaul that will create 6,000 square feet of new gallery space, a new library and additional classrooms for the museum’s master’s program. The museum will reopen in 2013.

headline: Rangers Strike on Late Error by Capitals
text: Four-on-four hockey would seem to favor the Washington Capitals and their superstar, Alex Ovechkin, in their first-round playoff series against the Rangers.

headline: The Rail’s Derby 10

headline: Antiquities Official Sentenced in Egypt
text: An Egyptian criminal court on Sunday sentenced Egypt’s antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, to a year in jail and ordered him removed from his job, Ahram Online, the English language Web site of the Egyptian state newspaper, reported. The sentence arose out of a dispute over the assigning of a contract to run a bookstore at the Egyptian museum, said Farid Atiya, who sued Mr. Hawass in that dispute. By e-mail, Mr. Hawass denied that he was going to jail and said that the antiquities ministry would file an appeal in the case on Monday. Mr. Atiya, who ran a bookstore next to the museum from 2004 to 2010, said that the verdict would be set aside if Mr. Hawass, within 10 days, closed a new bookstore and gift shop, affiliated with the American University in Cairo Press, that Mr. Atiya said had been opened in violation of a court order. Mr. Hawass, who had long been Egypt’s top antiquities official, resigned in March and was reinstated two weeks ago.

headline: Footnote
text: Joely Richardson (“The Tudors,” “Nip/Tuck”) and Cotter Smith (“Kin,” “Next Fall”) have been cast in “Side Effects,” the final play of MCC Theater’s 25th anniversary season. David Auburn (“Proof”) will direct this two-person play by Michael Weller, about a Midwestern couple whose relationship and political aspirations are beginning to crumble; it is a companion piece to Mr. Weller’s “Fifty Words.” Preview performances will begin June 2 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, with an opening on June 19.

headline: Decision Looms for Laos Dam, but Impact Is Unclear
text: HOUAY SOUY, Laos — The Mekong River is so brown with silt as it passes this impoverished village, it could be called liquid dirt. For millions of people downstream this is the color of life: the Mekong, teeming with hundreds of species of fish and rich in minerals, has for centuries been the lifeline of villages and towns stretching from the rocky rapids of Tibet to the lazy meanderings of the river in the Vietnam delta.

headline: Put Yourself in the Story of Passover
text: Though only read once or twice a year, it has probably had more wine spilled on it than any other book ever published. Over the centuries, it has been paraphrased, abridged, translated, transliterated and transformed. It has been sung, chanted, illustrated and supplanted. And in 5,000 or so editions since the invention of the printing press, it has invoked ancient Egypt, Eldridge Cleaver, third-century rabbis, the invention of the sandwich, sixth-century Palestinian poetry, the Holocaust, the ancient Greek symposium, unleavened bread, homosexuality, temple sacrifices, bitter herbs, the civil rights movement and children’s counting songs.

headline: A Faltering Ruble, Long Lines and a Bomb Attack Rattle Belarus
text: MINSK, Belarus — The waiting list outside a currency exchange office at the Korona supermarket here had swelled to 52 people and many were getting desperate. Some had been waiting for three days, sleeping in cars, in an increasingly frantic effort to get dollars and euros.

Geithner said Sunday that Congressional Republican leaders had signaled strongly to the White House that they would vote in favor of raising the national debt ceiling, despite pressure from some lawmakers in the party to use the coming vote as leverage to seek deep spending cuts.

headline: A Year After the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill, a Perfect Day for a Redfish
text: NEW ORLEANS — Near a marina in St. Bernard Parish, slightly south and east of New Orleans, a sign read, “Caution Boaters: Do Not Disturb Booms in Water.” Yet as Gregg Arnold, a fly-fishing guide, navigated his skiff through the labyrinthine channels that slice through this portion of the Biloxi Marsh, there were no signs of booms, or the oil unleashed by the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig last April 20.

headline: In Sometimes Deadly Clashes, Defiant Syrians Protest

Security officers responded with deadly force, witnesses reported, including live ammunition fired at a funeral and the seizure of critically wounded demonstrators from a hospital.

headline: Tornadoes: 3 Days, 14 States
text: More than 240 tornadoes have been reported since Thursday, including a “family” of 92 tornadoes that killed at least 22 people and left 84,000 without power in North Carolina on Saturday. Tornado activity has been heavier this year than last, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: A Line of Brews Draws a Star Endorser, and Critics
text: SINCE the 1980s, the actor Billy Dee Williams has appeared intermittently in advertising for Colt 45 malt liquor, often with a beautiful woman on his arm and accompanied by the slogan, “Works every time.” Now, to celebrate the introduction of a new product, Blast by Colt 45, a potent fruit-flavored beverage, the brand has a new pitchman, the rapper Snoop Dogg.

headline: Christie’s Conservatism Is Not Just Economic
text: In the throes of New Jersey’s financial crisis, Gov. Chris Christie vaulted into office as a strict fiscal conservative. In his first year in the job, he won national attention as a tough-talking manager whose budget-slashing, union-bashing ways seemed to be all about the money.

headline: U.S. Rift With Pakistan Grows Over Drone Strikes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The differences between the United States and Pakistan that broke into the open last week over the scale of C.I.A. operations here signaled a fundamental rift, plunging the relationship, sometimes strained, sometimes warm, to its lowest point in memory.

headline: At Least Walking Won’t Set Fire To the Fairway
text: It’s pretty well established that walking does more for your golf game than riding in a cart. And obviously, it offers more exercise. There is the rare case, however, in which riding in a cart might give you the chance to run for your life.

headline: Arthur Lessac, Holistic Vocal Coach, Dies at 101
text: The human voice is a symphony, Arthur Lessac said, if only one knows what to listen for. With their sustained, purring timbre, the consonants “m” and “n” are stringed instruments. Luxuriant “w” and “zh” are woodwinds, raucous “r” a trombone. “L” is a mellow saxophone; “ch” a clash of cymbals; and the small explosions “p,” “b” and “t” are percussion.

headline: 2 Palestinian Teens Held in Killing of Israeli Family
text: AWARTA, West Bank — Israeli officials announced on Sunday the arrest of two Palestinian teenagers from this village in the northern West Bank who they said were responsible for the killing of five members of the Fogel family in the neighboring Jewish settlement of Itamar last month.

headline: You Get the Judges You Pay For
text: LEGAL elites must come to terms with a reality driven by the grass-roots electorate: judicial elections are here to stay. Given this reality, we should focus on balancing important First Amendment rights to financially support campaigns with due process concerns about fair trials.

headline: Roger Nichols, Artist Among Sound Engineers, Dies at 66
text: Roger Nichols, a recording engineer whose meticulous studio work with Steely Dan and others earned him seven Grammy Awards, died on April 9 at his home in Burbank, Calif. He was 66.

headline: Yanks’ Rodriguez Sits as Precaution
text: A rib-cage injury kept Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez out of the starting lineup Sunday night against the Texas Rangers. And while Rodriguez and the team put a brave face on the injury, no one could say for certain when Rodriguez would play again.

headline: Officer and His Dog Play Key Role in Hunt for Remains
text: Ten sets of human remains have turned up in the thick brush off Ocean Parkway on the South Shore of Long Island since December. All of them have been discovered by the police. Five of them were found by the same officer and his partner.

text: Monday’s sell-off came despite moves by central banks around the world to restore investor confidence by injecting enormous amounts of capital into the financial system.

headline: Monks Embrace Web to Reach Recruits
text: The Benedictine monks at the Portsmouth Abbey in Portsmouth, R.I., have a problem. They are aging — five are octogenarians and the youngest will be 50 on his next birthday — and their numbers have fallen to 12, from a peak of about 24 in 1969.

headline: A Native Son Revitalizes His Paper
text: In 2008, when I last saw Michael Klingensmith, he was sitting in a corner office on the 34th floor of the Time Warner building, one of three powerful executives who controlled Time Inc., the biggest magazine publisher in the world.

headline: Salvadoran in Florida Faces Deportation for Torture

Eugenio Vides Casanova was that nation’s top military officer, a close ally valued by the United States for his implacable battle against Marxist guerrillas, in spite of notorious human rights violations by his forces.

headline: The Middle-Class Tax Trap
text: “Let’s tell the truth,” Walter Mondale said, accepting the Democratic nomination in 1984. “Mr. Reagan will raise taxes, and so will I. He won’t tell you. I just did.”

headline: A Recruit’s Friend, a Team’s Fan and a Headache for Colleges
text: Chris Grace, an ironworker from suburban Chicago, is a Duke fan. A mural in his basement bears the likenesses of the former stars Christian Laettner, Bobby Hurley and Grant Hill, and he regularly checks Web sites to learn which high school basketball players the Blue Devils are recruiting. Then Grace goes a step further: he sends recruits a friend request on Facebook.

headline: Retailers Retool Sites to Ease Mobile Shopping
text: Retailers who once envisioned a vast new market of mobile shoppers eagerly hitting “buy” on their cellphones have run headlong into a harsh reality: their customers are all thumbs.

headline: As Favorites Fall, Others Are Waiting to Fill Their Shoes
text: The only thing certain about the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby is that 20 horses are going to show up at Churchill Downs on the first Saturday in May. Who’s going to win? That is hard to predict after another highly regarded colt turned in an awful performance in his last major prep race.

headline: Let’s Not Be Civil
text: Last week, President Obama offered a spirited defense of his party’s values — in effect, of the legacy of the New Deal and the Great Society. Immediately thereafter, as always happens when Democrats take a stand, the civility police came out in force. The president, we were told, was being too partisan; he needs to treat his opponents with respect; he should have lunch with them, and work out a consensus.

headline: So Much for the Referees
text: Campaigns are delighted at the prospect of a record binge in political spending for next year’s elections. But their lawyers are scratching their heads in wonderment — and potential delight — that the Federal Election Commission has failed to rewrite regulations after the Supreme Court enabled unlimited corporate campaign spending.

headline: For Clemens and Bonds, a Difference in Audience
text: The criminal cases against Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens would appear to have a lot in common — both men are baseball superstars who once seemed destined for the Hall of Fame, and both were accused of lying about whether they had used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Hospitals Shouldn’t Make You Sicker
text: A vigorous quality-improvement program at more than 150 Veterans Affairs hospitals has achieved remarkable results controlling infections over the past several years. It reduced the spread of one of the most deadly bacterial infections, known as MRSA, by 62 percent in intensive care units and 45 percent in other hospital units. If other hospitals could replicate the effort, thousands of patients might be saved from needless infections acquired after they entered the hospital.

headline: A Victory for Cleaner Air, and the Law
text: The new settlement between the Environmental Protection Agency, other plaintiffs and the Tennessee Valley Authority resolving clean air violations at 11 T.V.A. coal-fired power plants is long overdue.

headline: Time to Reconnect With Joys Missed and Tee Shots Lost
text: There is no documented truth to the theory that months of pitiless snowstorms, weeks of subzero wind chills and an early April dose of sleet that froze the dog’s feet to the sidewalk now guarantee that the 2011 golf season will be the best and most satisfying ever.

headline: New York’s Bridges
text: Six lesser-known spans will receive big birthday bashes in the coming years.

headline: President Heads West to Sell His Deficit Plan
text: WASHINGTON — After weeks of tussling and political gamesmanship in Congress over federal spending, President Obama will take his message on the road this week, traveling to the West Coast to promote his deficit-cutting plan.

headline: The New Republican Landscape
text: Six months after voters sent Republicans in large numbers to Congress and many statehouses, it is possible to see the full landscape of destruction that their policies would cause — much of which has already begun. If it was not clear before, it is obvious now that the party is fully engaged in a project to dismantle the foundations of the New Deal and the Great Society, and to liberate business and the rich from the inconveniences of oversight and taxes.

headline: Seeking Clues in Goldman’s Succession Plan
text: From the canyons of Wall Street to the City of London and beyond to Hong Kong, an intense guessing-game has begun: who will succeed Lloyd C. Blankfein when he eventually steps aside as chief executive of Goldman Sachs?

headline: ‘Three Cups of Tea’ Author Defends Book
text: While the publishing industry waited to see whether it faced the embarrassment of yet another partly fabricated memoir, Greg Mortenson, the co-author of the best-selling “Three Cups of Tea,” a book popular with the Pentagon for its inspirational lessons on Afghanistan and Pakistan, forcefully countered a CBS News report on Sunday that questioned the facts of his book and the management of his charitable organization.

headline: After Regular Spring Vacations, D’Antoni Is Where He Likes to Be
text: BOSTON — In his four full seasons on the Phoenix Suns’ bench, Mike D’Antoni presided over 51 playoff games, each spring bringing a new thrill. In New York, the calendar in late April has been depressingly empty.

headline: For Passover, Quinoa Is Popular, but Kosher?
text: The big Passover questions are the same every year, and easy enough to answer, starting with “Why is this night different from all others?”

headline: After Storms, a Widespread Path of Death and Damage

headline: Scrutiny Lags as Jetliners Show the Effects of Age
text: In April 1988, when the cabin roof ripped off an Aloha Airlines 737 and swept a flight attendant to her death, it sent a startling signal to the airline industry about the dangers of metal fatigue. Airlines immediately stepped up inspections of aging jets. Federal regulators cut up old planes to look for the spots under the most stress. And Boeing redesigned the joints that hold its 737s together.

headline: A Battle Over Preservation in a Strip Once Worthy of Admirals
text: Once they were the shipshape town houses of the Brooklyn Navy Yard’s senior officers, but now the gray buildings sit like ruins encountered in a jungle, their facades, roofs and interiors overgrown with ivy, weeds, even saplings.

headline: Illicit Church, Evicted, Tries to Buck Beijing

Last year, the church, called Shouwang, or Lighthouse, collected $4 million from its 1,000 members to buy its own house of worship.

headline: If Trump Runs in ’12, ‘Apprentice’ Is in Limbo

headline: Filling in at Third Base, Chavez Fuels Win and Lets Rodriguez Rest Easy
text: For most 33-year-old veterans, backing up Alex Rodriguez would not be an appealing assignment. Rodriguez is a vital player for the Yankees — a cleanup hitter who used to routinely play more than 150 games a year and who still does not come out of the lineup except when injured. But when the Yankees called Eric Chavez last winter and offered him the job as Rodriguez’s backup, Chavez thought it sounded great. Three weeks into this season, he has not changed his mind.

(Sure, ‘‘Corazon Sin Cara,’’ by Prince Royce, is the No. 1 Tropical single for the week of April 23, 2011. But with Tito “El Bambino” right behind, for how long?)

headline: Report Finds Sri Lanka Attacked Civilians
text: NEW DELHI — A United Nations panel investigating allegations of war crimes by Sri Lankan troops at the end of the bloody battle against Tamil rebels in May 2009 found credible evidence that government soldiers made civilians a target, shelled hospitals and attacked aid workers, according to an unauthorized copy of the panel’s report.

headline: Who Made Google’s Map Pin?
text: Google’s maps have revolutionized how we interact with the world, how we perceive space and even how we navigate through it. Type in a location, and down drops a red marker, or “map pin,” that answers any question of place. Outfitted with its own drop shadow, the small, red bubble with a pointed end not only tells us where we want to be, but what exists in the world around us.

headline: Ask About Red-Tailed Hawks in New York
text: This week, Marie Winn, the author of “Red-Tails in Love: Pale Male’s Story — A True Wildlife Drama in Central Park,” will be responding to readers’ questions about red-tailed hawks in the city as we anticipate the arrival of the chicks of Violet and Bobby, who are perched above the N.Y.U campus.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian:  Leek Tart With Oil-Cured Olives
text: When Katy Sparks, a restaurant consultant and the former executive chef of Quilty’s in Manhattan, was developing a menu for Radish, a takeout place in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, she created a leek tart with oil-cured olives. For the tart shell, she uses store-bought frozen puff pastry. “I love puff pastry, but because I’ve never been a great baker, I like help,” she said. “We buy the Dufour puff pastry.”

headline: Cornell Gas Study Stirs Heated Debate
text: Post updated 11:30 a.m. —  More researchers and policy analysts have had a chance to digest a new study analyzing the climate impacts of unconventional natural gas development, published this week in the journal Climatic Change Letters. Many of the reactions echo earlier complaints that some of the methane leak data on which the study’s conclusions were based are thin (a fact that the authors, including the lead author, Robert Howarth of Cornell University, conceded).

headline: Remembering and Forgetting Milan Kundera
text: When I was a junior in high school, I became obsessed with the Czech novelist Milan Kundera. I would apologize for my pretentiousness, except that it is still an essential part of who I am. I copied a passage from “The Book of Laughter and Forgetting” onto the first divider in my loose-leaf notebook and tried to get as many of my classmates as I could to check it out. This was not no one, but it wasn’t a tremendous number of people either. Repeated reading dug the passage into my mind, and the other day when I was thinking about how hard it is to keep up with the violent pace at which so-called current events are overturning each other worldwide, it popped up unasked for:

headline: Once More, With Feeling: Joss Whedon Revisits ‘Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog’
text: In the pantheon of fantasy and science-fiction projects that Joss Whedon helped create, the Internet musical “Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog” can be easy to overlook: it’s not his beloved television series that ran a healthy seven seasons (“Buffy the Vampire Slayer”), or its beloved spinoff (“Angel”), or his misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time (“Dollhouse”) or his other misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time and spawned a misunderstood movie (“Firefly” and “Serenity”). “Dr. Horrible” is simply a three-act musical about an aspiring super-villain (played by Neil Patrick Harris), his smug do-gooding nemesis (Nathan Fillion) and the woman who comes between them (Felicia Day). Dreamed up by Mr. Whedon, his brothers Zack and Jed, and Maurissa Tancharoen during the 2007-8 writers’ strike and produced on his own dime, it is the pure expression of what they wanted to make at the time, without any outside interference.

headline: Asked and Answered | Deborah Ann Woll
text: The young actress Deborah Ann Woll cut her teeth — err, fangs — as the innocent Christian turned insidious vampire Jessica Hamby on HBO’s “True Blood” (Season 4 starts in June). Woll, 26, hails from Brooklyn but currently lives in Los Angeles, where she recently completed filming on “Someday This Pain Will Be Useful To You,” a coming-of-age story based on a teenage novel of the same name by Peter Cameron. The Moment recently e-mailed Woll to talk work (vampires, snakes) and play (home improvement and carpentry).

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: The Final Season on NBC
text: So the final season of “Friday Night Lights” is upon us, and those of us without DirecTV (where the episodes appeared earlier) have waited a long time. Friday’s fifth-season premiere on NBC had a distinctly elegiac feel. Landry and Julie were each leaving for college — the goodbyes are in motion. Landry is off to Rice in Houston, and Julie is headed somewhere within driving distance, which means that plans have clearly changed since that Northeastern college tour of last season.

headline: Good Tweets Are Nice, but Group Sales Fill Seats
text: More than 55,000 Facebook users “like” the new Broadway musical “Sister Act,” which, like most major theatrical productions today, has its own page, as well a Twitter account (1,300 followers), YouTube channel (30,000 uploaded views) and set of apps. (Photoshop your face into a nun’s wimple and win free tickets!)

headline: Wockah Wockah Bwow-Chcka-Bwow
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed spellings for the sounds that surround us.

headline: S&P
text: OK, so Standard and Poors has warned that it might downgrade the US one of these days. At first read, what it says doesn’t seem too silly: it lays stress, rightly, on political gridlock. The point should be that the US is perfectly capable both of running large deficits now and getting its fiscal house in order over time; but not if the parties cannot agree on any kind of solution. What we do to spending this year or next is irrelevant.

headline: At the Lucerne Easter Festival, Haitink Holds Up a Mirror for Promising Maestros
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — Bernard Haitink and Brahms are big at the Lucerne Festival this year. Mr. Haitink conducted his third and last Brahms program of the Easter Festival with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe at the concert hall of the KKL (Kultur- und Kongresszentrum) on Wednesday evening, and the Brahms cycle concludes in August with two concerts in the summer festival.

headline: The Sounds of Drummers, Handled Gingerly
text: New Yorkers make every effort to block out the sounds made by neighbors: their wails that they don’t want to go to preschool, their contractors’ ear-splitting hammer drills, and their heavy-footed gaits, which to those living below can sound as graceful as an elephant breaking in new pairs of stilettos. Even the most patient New Yorker can break down and plead with neighbors to stop that racket.

headline: Pentagon Inquiry Into Article Clears McChrystal and Aides
text: WASHINGTON — An inquiry by the Defense Department inspector general into a magazine profile that resulted in the abrupt, forced retirement of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal has found no proof of wrongdoing by the general, his military aides and his civilian advisers.

headline: In Lower Manhattan, the Nation’s First Official Monument Is Being Restored
text: Even then, 235 years ago, Congress worried about spending. All right, officially it was still the Continental Congress when it approved the new nation’s first official monument, a monument that ended up in Lower Manhattan. But right there, in its instructions to Benjamin Franklin, it said to watch the cost.

headline: Facebook and Prineville, Ore., Become Friends
text: PRINEVILLE, Ore. — This small town in the high desert of central Oregon has seen better days. The community of about 9,000 once had five saw mills employing some 1,200 people. Today all the saw mills are gone, and so are their jobs. Three years ago, Les Schwab, the town’s best-known business, moved its headquarters to nearby Bend, taking with it about 100 well-paying jobs. In the last 18 months, more than 1,000 residents left the town and the county, which has the highest rate of unemployment in Oregon at roughly 20 percent.

headline: Mazda CX-5 to Be Based on Minagi Concept
text: If only in name, Mazda is reining its Minagi concept into the familial fold. The Japanese automaker announced Monday that the compact S.U.V., which was first shown at the Geneva auto show in March, will be named the CX-5 when it enters production in 2012, slotting below the CX-7 and CX-9 crossover vehicles.

headline: One Soldier’s Experience With One Nation Under Contract
text: We go to war because of the men on our left and right. Since 9/11, we should probably add to that the contractors in the rear providing us food, drinks and organizing basketball tournaments. Maybe we don’t fight for them, but we certainly couldn’t fight without them. This situation isn’t good or bad, it just is.

headline: After Funerals for Protesters, Syrian Mourners Call for Revolution

headline: Exercise: Fewer Healthy Habits for Young Mothers

text: When Speaker John A. Boehner voted on April 14 for a legislative compromise to keep the government financed through September, it was a rare event: he had not voted on the House floor since Jan. 19, when he joined the Republican majority in voting to repeal President Obama’s health care law.

headline: So Far, Our New Pricing Strategy Is Working

Really high concession stand prices!) to direct your attention out west. Because if the Game 1s were any indication, way wilder stuff is happening out there.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: While it is relatively quiet in Washington, with Congress away and no advisory committee meetings scheduled by the Food & Drug Administration, Monday morning still brings some health care news.

headline: (Nature vs. Nurture) x Money
text: To the debate over nature vs. nurture (or, as it has shaken out recently, Amy Chua vs. Bryan Caplan), my colleague Motoko Rich reminds us of a most important factor — money. In the Week in Review yesterday, she wrote, “paradoxically, the kind of parents who follow debates about parenting — typically more affluent and educated — are those who may have the least to worry about.”

headline: Publisher of ‘Three Cups of Tea’ to Conduct Review
text: Viking, the publisher of “Three Cups of Tea,” said in a statement on Monday that it would review the book and its contents with the author, Greg Mortenson, after a CBS News report that called into question the accuracy of part of the book.

headline: How Do You Deal With Neighbor Noise?
text: The sounds of New Yorkers clunking across floors, the peals of construction that stretch from dawn until dusk, the neighbor who takes pleasure singing Fergie songs off key: these are all sounds that New Yorkers tolerate each day from their neighbors. Most New Yorkers don’t want to complain because they don’t want to make enemies of people they have to see at the annual building barbecue. But plenty of New Yorkers have been known to reach the breaking point and speak up.

headline: The 23 Percent Solution
text: As Jonathan Cohn says, American conservatives have a very parochial view of what would constitute crippling levels of taxes. My colleague Ross Douthat cites the possibility of federal taxes rising to 23 percent of GDP (compared with the 19 percent assumed — unrealistically — in the Ryan plan) as something to be deeply worried about. But America is a low-tax country by international standards:

headline: A Note on Median Income
text: My column today includes an estimate, taken from this Congressional Budget Office report, of what a median-income family would pay in taxes over the next few decades under the “current law baseline” — a scenario in which tax rates rise fast enough to cover the budget deficit without any kind of entitlement reform. The median income figure the C.B.O. used (see Table 4-4 on p. 65 of the report) is $94,900 for a family of four, which (as a number of readers have noted) seems much higher than the usual estimates for median income in a four-person household. It turns out that I didn’t catch a crucial footnote in the C.B.O. document: “All income is assumed to be from compensation, which includes employment-based health insurance and the employer’s share of payroll taxes.” That is to say, the $94,900 in income includes the estimated value of the median family’s health care plan as well as their salary, which is not what most people think of when they hear the term “median income.” I apologize for the confusion.

headline: Confronting Your Personal Debt Ceiling
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Frustration and Hope as Oil Drilling Regulator Remakes Itself
text: In Sunday’s Times, we assessed the Interior Department’s progress in revamping the Minerals Management Service, the scandal-ridden agency responsible for regulating offshore oil and gas drilling and collecting royalties from oil development on public lands.

headline: Gannett Earnings Fall
text: Earnings at Gannett, publisher of USA Today and dozens of local newspapers across the country, fell in the first quarter as the print advertising market remained stubbornly soft.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Finally Stumbles, and Hamilton Pounces
text: If Formula One drivers hope to beat Sebastian Vettel, the 2010 overall series champion and winner of four consecutive races before this last Sunday, they might have to wait for the German to somehow sabotage himself, as he did on Sunday at the Chinese Grand Prix.

headline: Volkswagen Beetle: Squeezing a Classic Shape for New Lines
text: After a tightly controlled introductory campaign, in which not even Oprah Winfrey could reveal more than its silhouette for a giveaway on her daytime TV show, the new Volkswagen Beetle was unveiled in lower Manhattan on Monday morning.

headline: Finding Goldman at Fault in the Crisis
text: The exhaustive report on the financial crisis by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations blames various parties, including banks for their risky transactions and federal regulators for their lax oversight. But the subcommittee saved some of its most scathing remarks for Goldman Sachs and its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein.

headline: Everyone Who’s Anyone (and Then Some) on Tribeca Film Juries
text: What do Nora Ephron and the Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales (both at left)  talk about when they get together? Maybe they reminisce about their appearances on “The Colbert Report,” he says he loved “Sleepless in Seattle,” she complains about the accuracy of her Wikipedia entry, and then they get around to judging independent films. That’s what the Tribeca Film Festival would have us believe.

headline: Mother and Daughter Stabbed to Death in Brooklyn
text: A 56-year-old woman and her 28-year-old daughter were found stabbed to death in a Brooklyn apartment late Sunday night, the police said.

headline: Another Palin Book on the Way
text: Another book in the Sarah Palin canon is weeks away from publication. Howard Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, announced on Monday that on May 24 it would publish “Blind Allegiance to Sarah Palin,” an account of Ms. Palin’s time as governor and as a vice-presidential candidate, written by Frank Bailey, one of her former aides. In a statement, Howard Books called it “a chilling exposé of Palin and the story of one man’s slow drift from his most cherished beliefs to his ultimate redemption.” Mr. Bailey’s book will come before a widely anticipated book about Ms. Palin, “The Rogue,” by the author and the journalist Joe McGinniss, which is expected to be released by Crown in September.
