text: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott

headline: Thais Are Shocked, Shocked by Topless Dancers
text: BANGKOK — To millions of tourists, this is a city famous for its tolerance and notoriously wild nightlife.

headline: How Musicians Communicate Emotion
text: A video from Daniel J. Levitin's lab at McGill University explaining a study on music perception, cognition and expertise.

headline: A Brain on Chopin
text: An animation showing changes in brain activity while study subjects listened to a performance of a Chopin etude in E major.

headline: ‘Bouillabaisse’ of Fresh Peas With Poached Eggs
text: In the Provence region of France, it is a peasant tradition to make “poor man’s bouillabaisse” with vegetables. For this soup, only fresh peas will work — don’t try it with frozen.

headline: A Bowlful of Our Daily Bread
text: Soups thickened with fresh or stale bread are ubiquitous throughout the Mediterranean — indeed, wherever bread is a staple. The simplest are made with thick, toasted slices of bread, sometimes rubbed with garlic, arranged in wide bowls and covered with soup. They can be topped with poached eggs for a satisfying meal.

headline: Trust Me, We’re Rich
text: Within the developed world, Danes are the most trusting people and Chileans the least, according to new data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Art Center College of Design, Pasadena, Calif., is honoring a faculty member, Doyald Young, a typeface designer, with the Doyald Young Memorial Scholarship. Mr. Young died on Feb. 28 at age 84. The scholarship will be available to current and incoming students.

headline: Notre Dame Report Spreads Responsibility in Student Death
text: High wind, a lack of current weather information and a hydraulic lift susceptible to tipping each contributed to the death of a student video trainer at Notre Dame in October, the university said Monday after a six-month internal investigation into the accident.

headline: Actually, Jamie Dimon Now Likes New Consumer Bureau
text: Jamie Dimon, it turns out, has a soft spot for the government’s new consumer financial bureau.

headline: For Evian, It’s ‘Baby’ One More Time
text: Evian is introducing a second sequel to its hugely popular 2009 campaign that featured babies who, thanks to the magic of CGI, appeared as if they were roller-skating.

headline: Same Old Garbage, but a Crisp New Slogan
text: Say hello to the latest salvo in the subway’s long-running War on Trash.

headline: Maternal Baggage
text: They say behind every successful man stands a woman. In the case of Michael Kors, it’s his mother, Joan, a former model and Kors’s perennial muse. Now he has designed a bag worthy of carrying not just her wallet and sunglasses but also her name. The Joan, which comes in a variety of colors (including the mocha embossed leather version seen here) and is modestly priced at $398, meets Joan’s strict standards: “I always look for an outside pocket for my phone and keys,” she says, “and I love a zip closure.” But she adds, “I certainly wouldn’t mind being surprised with a crocodile version!” Joan says she plans to celebrate Mother’s Day on the West Coast with a fabulous arrangement of peonies and dinner with Michael. The greatest gift he’s ever given her? “Not having to go shopping for the past 30 years.”

headline: What Makes Music Expressive?
text: What makes music expressive? Quiz yourself based on new research.

headline: "Imagine No Malaria" Ad
text: United Methodist Church's new ad campaign for anti-malaria project.

headline: Populist Advance in Finland Could Endanger Bailouts
text: BRUSSELS — Since the euro zone crisis got under way in earnest a year ago, various Cassandras have warned that the day would come when voters would rise up in revolt against paying for the mistakes of others with costly bailouts.

headline: To Tug Hearts, Music First Must Tickle the Neurons
text: The other day, Paul Simon was rehearsing a favorite song: his own “Darling Lorraine,” about a love that starts hot but turns very cold. He found himself thinking about a three-note rhythmic pattern near the end, where Lorraine (spoiler alert) gets sick and dies.

headline: Janitors and Corporate Executives Have the Same Pay Plan
text: I mean it: both receive a weekly paycheck. So there’s no difference in what they’re offered!

headline: Billups Injury Weighs Heavily on Knicks
text: BOSTON — On the morning after their first playoff game in seven years, the Knicks were still limping, rationalizing and grumbling, and still wondering how to unlock the mystery of the mighty Boston Celtics.

headline: Campaign Seeks to Take a ‘Bite’ Out of Disease
text: Advertising is often meant to stimulate the imagination: Picture yourself behind the wheel of a new car, in a new outfit, reaching out to your friends on the coolest new smartphone. An ambitious campaign is now trying to encourage much more altruistic imaginings.

headline: Peoplescapes
text: Massimo Vitali’s photographs are transporting. When I see one of his pictures, I want to be in it. Partly this is because the settings are so often happy gathering spots: beaches, lakes, pools and other watering holes, ski slopes, gardens and assorted sightseeing sites. Usually there’s sunlight; always there’s color. Above all, there’s clarity — I’m convinced that if I look hard enough, I can see everything and forever.

headline: In Reversal, Poppy Production Expanding in Afghanistan, U.N. Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Driven by soaring opium prices, farmers are expected to plant poppies at a sharply higher rate in parts of Afghanistan that were previously poppy free, the United Nations said Monday in its annual winter survey of poppy cultivation patterns in this country, the world’s leading opium purveyor.

headline: Robot Cousins of Roomba Are Deployed in Japan
text: As The Associated Press explains, the PackBot robots sent in to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant to measure radiation levels there were made by an American company, iRobot, which also makes the Roomba, a robot vacuum cleaner.

headline: On Ship of Evacuees From Libya, Harrowing Tales
text: ABOARD THE IONIAN SPIRIT, off Libya — More than 900 migrant workers were evacuated by sea overnight Sunday from the besieged Libyan port city of Misurata, one further step in the international effort to rescue thousands of foreigners stranded within Libya after the rebellion began.

headline: The Anti-Dowry
text: The burden of student debt which delays graduates from buying property, founding businesses, or starting families.

headline: S&P Can Call Bond Vigilantes From The Vasty Deep
text: Why, so can I, and so can any man. But will they come when S&P does call for them?

headline: Kenyan Runs Fastest Marathon in Boston
text: BOSTON — With a brisk wind at his back and a determined countryman on his shoulder to push him down the stretch, Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya pulled away from Moses Mosop in the final quarter-mile Monday to win the 115th Boston Marathon. His time, 2 hours 3 minutes 2 seconds, was the fastest marathon run by nearly a minute, and it smashed the course record, set last year, by nearly three minutes.

text: Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss are not giving up. The brothers, who claim that they, not Mark Zuckerberg, came up with the idea for Facebook, are asking a federal appeals court in San Francisco to rehear their request that a 2008 settlement between them and Facebook be nullified so that they can pursue their original case against the company.

headline: The Nose May Not Know What It’s Missing
text: Dr. Ronald DeVere, a neurologist in Austin, Tex., was baffled. In 1995, after recovering from a viral infection, something happened to his sense of smell. Fresh milk smelled sour, the dirty dog pen smelled good, and other odors couldn’t be detected at all.

headline: Slow Payers Hinder Trade in Europe
text: ZARAGOZA, SPAIN — In 2001, an agricultural co-op here was supplying truckloads of wheat to an Italian pasta maker. At first, no one at the Spanish co-op, Arento, was much alarmed when the pasta factory in Milan fell behind in its payments.

text: Not surprisingly, banks, in their earnings reports, are quick to highlight the areas of strength and downplay the weak points.

headline: The Beatification of David Foster Wallace
text: However much you admire David Foster Wallace or the people who write so well about him (like our own Sam Anderson, Tom McCarthy in the Book Review or J. J. Sullivan at GQ), there is so much ink being spilled in favor of D.F.W. and his posthumous Great Novel, “The Pale King,” that it’s worth considering the dissenters. At Bookslut, http://www.bookslut.com/blog/archives/2011_04.php#017542 Jessica Crispin counts herself among the less-than-convinced (she prefers Henry James) and links to Geoff Dyer’s allergy to Wallaciana at Prospect. text: Masculine, masculine, masculine. Klaus Bischoff, head of design for the Volkswagen brand, kept returning to the word to describe the design of the successor to the New Beetle, the car Volkswagen calls simply “the 21st century Beetle.”

text: … but there’s plenty to do in the meantime. This week we acknowledge tax day, Passover, Holy Week and Earth Day. We’ve got resources for all of them and more — much more! — below.

headline: Name Your Poison
text: Q. Is it possible to make yourself invulnerable to arsenic poisoning by taking small doses, as sometimes happens in mystery novels?

headline: Eye Candy
text: Even among the Warhol Superstars, Candy Darling was a standout. Her spot-on embodiment of a ’40s-era Hollywood starlet — demure, mysterious, quiet — stood in contrast to the pretty-little-rich-girl routine of Edie Sedgwick, the drug-fueled silver-tongued cheek of Brigid Berlin and the Teutonic otherness of Nico. And the fact that she was a transgendered woman from Long Island only added to her mystique. Her fame spread via the Paul Morrissey films “Flesh” and “Women in Revolt,” and she was immortalized by Lou Reed in the songs “Candy Says” and “Walk on the Wild Side.” She died in 1974, from leukemia connected to unsafe hormone treatments, at the age of 29.

headline: ’60 Minutes’ Leads CBS to Sunday Night Ratings Win
text: The newsmagazine “60 Minutes” delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as CBS won the night’s ratings over its network competitors. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.6 million viewers tuned in at 7 p.m. for an edition that featured an investigation into the accuracy of Greg Mortenson’s book “Three Cups of Tea.” CBS then also won the 8 p.m. hour with its reality show “The Amazing Race” (8.7 million). ABC ranked close behind CBS in second place for the night, leading during the 9 p.m. hour with “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million). NBC placed third over all, garnering an average of 7.4 million viewers for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11. Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup, although “Family Guy” (6 million) earned the night’s highest ratings in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

headline: Expectations Grow for Greek Debt Restructuring
text: The Greeks reject a debt restructuring out of hand. The European Central Bank fears that such a move will spread financial panic. And, meanwhile, the European Union and the International Monetary Fund insist that their recipe of bailouts combined with sharp spending cuts makes restructurings unnecessary.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Is Elected for ‘Veep’
text: She’s not Sarah Palin. She’s not Hillary Rodham Clinton or Michele Bachmann, and needless to say, she’s not Joe Biden or Dick Cheney, either. But Julia Louis-Dreyfus will play a female vice president of the United States in “Veep,” a new HBO comedy series that the network announced on Monday it had picked up.

headline: Syria: Fighting the Fungi That Threaten Wheat
text: Fungi that attack wheat are growing as a threat to the hungry inhabitants of poor countries. At a conference this week in Aleppo, Syria, scientists will be planning a counteroffensive.

headline: For an Exercise Afterburn, Intensity May Be the Key
text: Depending on whom you ask, the answer to this question is either one of the great myths of exercise or one of the great unappreciated truths: Is there an afterburn effect from a workout?

headline: Bobby McFerrin Takes Ice Water Test
text: The singer Bobby McFerrin visited Daniel J. Levitin’s lab and walked through several experiments, including one that tested how music affected one's threshold for pain.

text: And now, another example that no good deed goes unpunished.

headline: Afghan Group Distances Itself From One Under Cloud
text: The ripples created by an explosive television report challenging the veracity of “Three Cups of Tea,” a bestselling memoir dealing with Afghanistan and Pakistan, have reached Queens.

headline: Court Hears Microsoft Patent Case
text: WASHINGTON — Microsoft’s challenge to a $290 million award against it in a patent infringement suit faced significant headwinds on Monday during arguments at the Supreme Court.

headline: 2011 Pulitzer Prizes for Journalism
text: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. Following are the winners in Journalism.

headline: Hotels Turn to Social Media to Connect With Travelers
text: Hotels have begun offering direct bookings through Facebook and smartphone apps, and they hope that the convenience and direct contact will lure back travelers who have been turning to online travel agencies.

headline: Radiation Poses Barrier to Repair Work at Plant
text: TOKYO — Robots deployed inside two reactors at the Japanese nuclear plant overrun by last month’s devastating tsunami have detected radiation levels too high for workers to enter, posing immediate challenges for a new plan to bring the ravaged complex under control by year’s end.

headline: New Mothers Have Worse Health Habits
text: New motherhood apparently takes a toll on a woman’s health. Young mothers of small children exercise less than other women their age and don’t eat as well, according to a new report.

headline: Met Opera Announces Park Series
text: For the third season in a row, the Metropolitan Opera is offering recitals instead of full-scale operas for its free summer parks series. The Met announced in a statement on Monday that the soprano Angela Meade, the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnson Cano and the tenor Dimitri Pittas would perform on July 11 in Central Park and on July 13 in Brooklyn Bridge Park. Three other singers would present programs in Crotona Park in the Bronx (July 19); Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island (July 21); Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens (July 26); and Jackie Robinson Park in Harlem (July 28). Those performers will be Layla Claire, a soprano; Renée Tatum, a mezzo-soprano; and Ryan Speedo Green, a bass-baritone. The pianist Bradley Moore will be the accompanist for all of the concerts. The statement said the Met would also present free outdoor screenings of its high-definition broadcasts from Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5. The last full Met opera in the park was in the summer of 2007. In 2008, the Met presented a lone recital by the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna.

headline: Side Sleeping to Reduce Snoring
text: Today’s “Really?” column explores the claim that sleeping on your side can reduce snoring.

headline: Drug That Stops Bleeding Shows Off-Label Dangers
text: A powerful, costly drug approved in 1999 for a small group of patients who may bleed uncontrollably during surgery is now used in a host of other surgical situations, sometimes with serious negative effects, two new studies report.

headline: Eighty Years Along, a Longevity Study Still Has Ground to Cover
text: After reading “The Longevity Project,” I took an unscientific survey of friends and relatives asking them what personality characteristic they thought was most associated with long life. Several said “optimism,” followed by “equanimity,” “happiness,” “a good marriage,” “the ability to handle stress.” One offered, jokingly, “good table manners.”

headline: Traveling to Jewel Destinations, and the Airplane Antics in Between
text: IT seems as if I built my business around my travel desires. Being in the jewelry business means I get to go to Antwerp, Venice, Istanbul, Hong Kong and a lot of other wonderful places. There’s no downside to this because I get to see such amazing things.

headline: Appreciation Trumps Comparisons Between Stars
text: As Chris Paul jumped in the air, collected a pass, and rocketed a perfectly placed pass into the hands of Aaron Gray for an easy scoring opportunity, you could already hear the whispers.

headline: Nestlé Takes Aim at China
text: Nestlé, the world’s biggest food company, has taken a step toward strengthening its position in China by agreeing to acquire 60 percent of the Yinlu Food Group. The family-owned Yinlu had sales of $829 million last year, and its acquisition gives Nestlé broader access to a fast-growing segment of the Chinese market, Reuters reports.

headline: ‘The Longevity Project’
text: Introduction: The Breakthrough Studies of a Lifetime

headline: TimesCast | April 18, 2011
text: Kim Severson reports from Askewville, N.C., where at least 11 residents were killed by tornadoes over the weekend.

headline: William Rusher, Champion of Conservatism, Dies at 87
text: William A. Rusher, who advanced a rising conservative tide in America for more than 50 years as a political strategist, author, syndicated columnist and publisher of William F. Buckley Jr.’s bible of the right, National Review, died on Saturday in San Francisco. He was 87.

headline: Is the iPad 2 a Lot Better Than the Original?
text: Over the weekend, Chris Dixon, an entrepreneur and co-founder of the social site Hunch, lamented on Twitter that he still had not purchased a new iPad 2. Although Mr. Dixon hopes to buy the highly coveted device soon, he questioned whether it was a “must have” upgrade from the first generation iPad.

headline: The Benefits of Sleep, Follow-Up
text: No doubt having read Maggie Jones’s sleep article in our special health and wellness issue this past weekend and her thoughts on this blog on Friday, the F.A.A. announced Saturday that it was going to change the way it schedules air-traffic controllers.

headline: A Fifth Avenue Co-op Says No: Did It Take Subterfuge?
text: To a certain slice of New Yorkers, it’s the kind of gossip that is whispered over lunches at Bergdorf’s and mentioned during air kisses at fund-raisers: being rejected by a Fifth Avenue co-op board. But a Turkish businesswoman’s story is a bit different. After being rejected by the board at 812 Fifth Avenue, she has spent nearly two years fighting to get back her deposit on the $3 million apartment.

headline: Come On, I Thought I Knew That!
text: Trick question: Is it easier to remember a new fact if it appears in normal type, like this, or in big, bold letters, like this?

headline: Obama Tax Return Shows Income Down
text: Income for the Obama household continued to slip in 2010, tax returns show, as proceeds from President Obama’s best-selling books tapered off. But just as he has said, his income is easily high enough to make the family eligible for a tax increase under his own deficit-reduction proposals.

headline: Three Pulitzers for Magazine Contributors
text: The winners of three Pulitzer Prizes that were announced today have written recently for our magazine, and we would like to offer them special congratulations.

headline: Obamas Report $1.7 Million in Income for 2010
text: The adjusted gross income reported for 2010 is a considerable drop from the $5.5 million reported by Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, in 2009.

headline: A.I.G. to Sell Rail Services Unit to Perella Weinberg
text: The American International Group said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its rail services to an investment arm of Perella Weinberg Partners for $600 million, as part of the insurer’s plan to sell off assets to repay its government bailout.

headline: The Koch Brothers and Climate Science, Redux
text: Last year, Greenpeace, the environmental group, accused the brothers Charles and David Koch of a stealth campaign to attack climate science, setting off extensive media scrutiny of the Kochs and their company, Koch Industries. (A Koch subsidiary is a major oil refiner.) Now Greenpeace is out with an update.

headline: Horseplay in the Water
text: SHORTLY before 8 on Sunday evenings, swimmers doing laps at the Chinatown Y.M.C.A call it a night, and three staff members from the NYC Social Sports Club take over the space, placing 20 yellow and blue inner tubes in the water and putting up goals at each end of the pool.

headline: Rocking the New York Auto Show
text: Playing an auto-show media event can’t be the best gig in the world.

headline: Mothers on the Night Shift
text: “Sleep while the baby sleeps” is the unattainable goal of most new parents.

headline: Opposition Leader Besigye Arrested in Uganda Protest
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — The leading opposition figure here was arrested on Monday and charged with inciting violence, as a third day of street demonstrations in the Ugandan capital ended in shrouds of tear gas and rubber bullets.

headline: Dance, Dance, Dance | Cate Lets Loose
text: The typically placid Cate Blanchett bounces about in this ’80s-inspired clip from Cass Bird’s cover shoot for T’s summer women’s issue.

headline: S.&P. States the Obvious
text: Standard & Poor’s has taken its fair share of criticism in recent years. But at least it isn’t too shy to state the much-needed obvious situation on America’s debt.

headline: A Star Brings Singers and Composers Together
text: For the soprano Dawn Upshaw, mixing styles and interacting with composers have been signature elements since the start of her illustrious career. Since 2004 Ms. Upshaw has shared her insights, training young singers and composers to collaborate during workshops presented under the auspices of Carnegie Hall’s Weill Music Institute. That year she worked alongside the composer John Harbison; in 2007 and 2009 she teamed up with Osvaldo Golijov.

headline: Berlioz, Shostakovich and Gérard Depardieu
text: The main thing a listener wanted from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s visit to Carnegie Hall this weekend was a sense of how this great ensemble was faring under the baton of Riccardo Muti, whose tenure as its music director began in September. You had to have a strong set of mental blinders not to think, in the moments before Mr. Muti walked onstage, about the alarming illnesses that have kept him off the podium much of the season, and that naturally brought to mind the health problems that led James Levine to give up his directorship of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Those concerns were amplified by the news, announced just hours before the Saturday evening concert, that the Philadelphia Orchestra — Mr. Muti’s previous American podium — had declared bankruptcy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Nigeria, Iraq, Libya and Gaza City.

headline: For Montreal Symphony, Shoebox Is a Grand Home
text: MONTREAL — The Montreal Symphony Orchestra, once a storied ensemble that gave blazing performances with the international maestro Charles Dutoit, lost some luster when he left amid acrimony with the players. A bitter five-month strike several years later, in 2005, took a further toll.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Nigeria, Iraq, Libya and Gaza City.

headline: From Belarus, Dynamic Drama With Limited Means
text: The firecracker that is set off in the first seconds of the Belarus Free Theater’s astounding “Zone of Silence,” at La MaMa in the East Village, doesn’t make much noise, at least not as measured in decibels. But there’s a lot of power in the short, sharp pop of this homemade explosive.

headline: Willow Garage Introduces TurtleBot Robot
text: It looks as if I can finally stop trying to train my dog to fetch a bagel and coffee from the kitchen each morning. Instead, I’ll be able to use a new robot, the TurtleBot, which is made by the robotics company Willow Garage.

headline: Noma Again Tops the San Pellegrino List of Best Restaurants
text: The San Pellegrino World’s 50 Best  Restaurants were announced in London today. For the second year in a row Noma, in Copenhagen, was the top-rated restaurant.

headline: Whales’ Grandeur and Grace, Up Close
text: On a warm summer afternoon in 2005, Bryant Austin was snorkeling in the blue waters of the South Pacific by the islands of Tonga, looking through his camera at a humpback whale and her calf swimming less than 50 yards away. As he waited for the right moment, the playful calf swam right up to him, so close that he had to lower his camera. That’s when he felt a gentle tap on his shoulder.

headline: A Cozy Chamber Concert Buoyed by Lapping Water
text: Anyone who has never attended a Bargemusic concert may find it hard to believe that a converted old barge docked at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn is an ideally intimate place to hear chamber music. It is.

headline: At Coachella, Every Note Is Writ Large
text: INDIO, Calif. — The Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival started 12 years ago, a few generations by pop measurements. It’s enough time for more than one broad set of tastes to harden and be pushed aside.

headline: Turkey Disqualifies 12 Pro-Kurdish Politicians From Parliamentary Election
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s senior election board on Monday disqualified 12 pro-Kurdish politicians from running for Parliament in the coming election on the grounds that they are legally unfit to be candidates. The unexpected move is likely to anger Kurds in the country’s restive southeast who have been seeking further representation.

headline: Treading Very Carefully on the Road to Nostalgia
text: Seen from a certain angle, everything was as it should have been at the Orchestre National de France’s concert, conducted by Daniele Gatti, on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Congrats to David Leonhardt

headline: New Palin Web Site Has Pundits Buzzing

headline: Some Dinosaurs Liked the Night Life, Eye Bones Show
text: Paleontologists have generally believed that dinosaurs were active only during the day, preserving their energy at night, when mammals hunted and ate. But an analysis of dinosaur eye structure shows that at least some dinosaurs functioned quite capably in the dark.

headline: Reptiles Eat With the Bones Humans Hear With, Fossil Proves
text: One of the “knowns” in the evolutionary biology of mammals, including humans, is that the three little bones in their middle ear originated in the lower jaw of their reptilian predecessors. The link has been demonstrated in studies of developing mammalian embryos, and two of the three bones are found in the jaw of living reptiles. So reptiles eat with the bones we hear with.

headline: For Elite Teams, Questions of Depth
text: There are a lot of things one expects to hear at Staples Center when a Laker player is shooting free throws. “Who are you?” is not one of them. But when the Lakers’ Trey Johnson was at the free-throw line during Sunday’s game against the New Orleans Hornets, he found himself being asked that question by one very loud fan, and it was hard to blame the fan for asking.

headline: The Reclusive Other Half of Microsoft’s Odd Couple Breaks His Silence
text: Here is an example of billionaire humor, as recounted by Paul Allen in his carefully legacy-minded new memoir, “Idea Man”: Mr. Allen commissioned Octopus, which was to be the largest of his yachts. It would be seven stories high and one-third longer than a football field. Amenities would include a concert stage and recording studio, because Mr. Allen plays the guitar himself and really likes inviting rock stars aboard. Another special feature, because — well, why not? — would be a submarine.

headline: New Lessons to Pave a Road to Safety

headline: Making Mugabe Laugh

They may not disregard the voice of their own people in free and fair elections, and there will be consequences for those who cling to power.”

headline: Talks on U.S. Presence in Afghanistan After Pullout Unnerve Region

Then, the Americans and their NATO allies began to talk about transition, gradually handing over control of the war to the Afghans until finally pulling out in 2014. Now, however, the talk is all about what happens after 2014.

headline: Iceland’s Way

headline: Playoffs’ Bright Lights Vexing for Heat Star Prone to Migraines
text: MIAMI — American Airlines Arena is dressed for spring, with each seatback draped in white and each fan attending a Heat home playoff game encouraged to wear a white T-shirt. The effect on Monday was stepping out of 80-degree heat and, visually speaking, into an igloo.

headline: Real Prisoners, Phantom Residents
text: The New York State Legislature took a stand for electoral fairness last year when it banned prison-based gerrymandering, the cynical practice of counting prison inmates as “residents” to pad the population of legislative districts. The new law required that inmates be counted as residents of their home districts.

headline: What Stories These Lice Can Tell
text: Were there many bird and mammal species while dinosaurs still lived? Or did they diversify only after dinosaurs were wiped out some 65 million years ago? The fossil record hasn’t been much help answering this fundamental question. But a study published recently in the Royal Society’s Biology Letters may have found an answer based on a different kind of fossil: fossilized lice.

headline: The Battle of Baltimore
text: Baltimore had vexed Abraham Lincoln for months. The city was the secessionist heart of slaveholding, nativist Maryland, a state in which the new president had run fourth in the 1860 election, garnering fewer than 3,000 votes. Maryland’s population was one-quarter African-American, evenly divided between slaves and free blacks. And yet Lincoln desperately needed the state: without it in the Union, Washington would be completely within foreign — and, after April 12, enemy — territory.

The trial, after all, marks the witness-stand debut of the first official boss of one of New York’s five Mafia families to testify for the government.

headline: In This Fairy Tale, Not One, but Two Queens in Waiting

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: When a police officer has a complaint or a question, the first person to hear about it is often a police union delegate. Part fixer and part representative, the delegate is always on call to take complaints about a commander not paying overtime, or from an officer unhappy about a transfer to a midnight tour.

headline: As Mets Falter, Everyone Can Sit in the Cheap Seats
text: For the third season in a row, the Mets are not looking like a good team. A miserable 2010 was followed by a winter of frugality that has not inspired a lot of ticket purchasers, which is bad for the embattled owners of the team.

headline: Plant Owner Sues Vermont Over License for Reactor

headline: At 41, Star Closer Hasn’t Lost His Edge

headline: Grete Waitz, Marathon Champion, Dies at 57

headline: Fantasy Focus: Buy Lowest
text: The buy-low, sell-high mantra is one of the most overused in fantasy sports. No one in any league worth playing in will deal you Carl Crawford, Kevin Youkilis or Carlos Gonzalez at a discount just because of two bad weeks. In order to get an actual bargain, then, you need to aim at players whose market values have declined since draft day for good reason and about whom even you are worried. While buying low usually isn’t possible, buying lowest typically is.

headline: In Hong Kong, Men’s Ready-to-Wear

headline: Syria Steps Up Its Crackdown While Promising Reform
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government tried to placate protesters with declarations of sweeping reform on Tuesday while also issuing harsh threats of reprisals if demonstrations did not come to an end, as one of the Arab world’s most repressive countries struggled to blunt the most serious challenge to the 40-year rule of the Assad family.

headline: All My Stories
text: I hadn’t really watched “All My Children” on a daily basis since 2004, when Bianca Montgomery, Erica Kane’s lesbian daughter, finally discovered that Miranda, the baby she thought had died in an accident, was actually Bess, the baby her best friend, Babe, was passing off as her own. Around the same period, I also stopped watching “One Life to Live” regularly, following the heart transplant that Victoria Lord Riley Burke Riley Buchanan Buchanan Carpenter Davidson received thanks to the untimely death of the love of her life and sixth husband, Ben, who lay comatose in a hospital bed for months after being accidentally shot in the head during an attempt to save Viki from a kidnapper. Still, I was taken aback by last week’s news that after more than 40 years of showing them five days a week, 52 weeks a year, ABC was axing both shows, one by September and the other by January 2012, leaving just “The Young and the Restless,” “The Bold and the Beautiful,” “Days of Our Lives” and “General Hospital” to carry on the daytime-serial legacy.

headline: On the Records | The Candidate, the Treasurer and the Gynecologist

headline: Managing the Business Side of the Business
text: Last year at my aunt’s 80th birthday gathering, I talked business with one of my cousins, Phil Ochoa. Phil and his wife, Sharyn, started a company, Federal Defense Industries, out of the garage of their Southern California home. Ten years later, they are the family success story, with eight-figure revenue, and they have traded way up and out of their office with the Genie door opener.

headline: This Spring Break, It’s Party vs. Party
text: House members are home for spring break, and Democrats are determined to make sure that the recess is no day at the beach for the Republicans.

headline: Water Pumping Begins at Japan Nuclear Reactor
text: TOKYO — The difficult task of pumping highly radioactive water out of the basement of a turbine building at a damaged Japanese nuclear power plant began Tuesday, but officials cautioned that the work would be slow and difficult.

headline: Not-So-Secret History
text: At their most functional, co-op meetings are a chance for shareholders to greet their new neighbors and hear about the financial well-being of the building’s corporation. At their least functional, they’re an opportunity for the petty, soapbox style airing of grievances, from the tenants who like to complain about the size of others’ welcome mats. Oftentimes, what should last no more than 30 minutes drags on for two hours or more.

headline: Goldman Sachs Tops Expectations as Revenues Fall
text: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported first-quarter net income of $2.74 billion, down 21 percent from the period a year earlier, as the investment bank took a big one-time hit to pay back the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

text: The Times reports this morning that for the first time in 27 years, Alzheimer’s disease is being redefined in new medical guidelines reflecting mounting evidence that the disease ravages the brain years before symptoms of dementia appear.

headline: When Rationalization Masquerades as Reason
text: It’s awfully hard for human beings to step outside of their predispositions and gut reactions, which may be why it’s so hard to have a rational discussion about the findings of science, which is all about sidelining such distorting biases.

text: Tuesday’s April showers will perhaps yield a bounty of May flowers. Regardless of the weather, Violet, the red-tailed hawk at New York University, will be working hard to keep her eggs warm, which we hope will hatch this week.

headline: Trial in China Tests Limits of Legal System Reform
text: BEIJING — In a case that has galvanized lawyers across China and provided a window into how the next generation of leaders may view the country’s fragile legal system, a defense lawyer went on trial Tuesday charged with fabricating testimony in favor of his client.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Medicare Consumer Site Gets a Makeover
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Dude Records: Jeff Bridges Plans Solo Album
text: When the Dude sought recreation in “The Big Lebowski,” he’d bowl, drive around, enjoy the occasional acid flashback and unwind to some Creedence Clearwater Revival. Now it’s C.C.R.’s turn to unwind to the Dude. Jeff Bridges, the “Big Lebowski” star who played a country singer so well in “Crazy Heart” he won an Academy Award for it, will record a solo album for the Blue Note Records division of EMI, the label said on Tuesday. The album, which does not yet have a title (can we humbly suggest “Careful, Man, There’s A Beverage Here”?) will be recorded with the producer T-Bone Burnett, who first met Mr. Bridges on the set of “Heaven’s Gate,” and selected music for the “Big Lebowski” soundtrack and co-wrote songs for “Crazy Heart,” including the Oscar-nominated track “The Weary Kind.” Blue Note Records said in a statement that Mr. Bridges “will contribute several of his own compositions” and perform songs by Stephen Bruton and John Goodwin, Greg Brown, Bo Ramsey, Tom Waits, and others. Though we wouldn’t hold out much hope for the Dude’s Creedence cassettes, Mr. Bridges’s album is planned for a late summer release.

headline: He Worked for Obama. Can He Beat Him?
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Three months before President Obama nominated Jon M. Huntsman Jr. as ambassador to China, Mr. Huntsman arrived here to introduce himself to three dozen influential Republicans and talk politics with them over dinner at the Palmetto Club.

headline: Iron Mountain Reaches Truce With Elliott
text: Iron Mountain reached a settlement with a dissident shareholder, Elliott Management, on Tuesday, agreeing to give the activist hedge fund a seat on its board and committing to $2.2 billion worth of share repurchases and dividends.

headline: Treasury Takes On Wall Street Lobbyists
text: The Obama administration is fighting back against Wall Street lobbyists and Republican lawmakers, who are trying to delay and dismantle new financial regulations.

headline: Britain Will Send Military Advisers to Libya, Hoping to Tip Balance for Rebel Forces
text: LONDON — Britain’s decision to send experienced military officers to Libya, to advise rebels fighting forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, marks the latest development in the international community’s search for a means to end a bloody military stalemate that has killed hundreds in the contested cities of Misurata and Ajdabiya and left the rebels in only tenuous control of a few major coastal cities.

text: President Obama’s political advisers often talk about how population shifts in the country could create new electoral battlegrounds, pointing specifically to Arizona, Georgia and Texas.

headline: Soul-Searching at a Defiantly Affordable Co-op
text: Amid Chelsea’s glittering landscape of galleries and buildings by Frank Gehry and Jean Nouvel sprawls a stalwart from an era long past: the Penn South co-op, a stretch of brick apartment buildings vaguely evocative of the Soviet bloc.

headline: Venerable Art Dealer Is Enmeshed in Lawsuits
text: PARIS — On a mild day in January, French police investigators poured into the regal Right Bank building of an art research center called the Wildenstein Institute and began sifting through a substantial trove of artworks there.

headline: Geithner Responds to Debt Warning
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner parses comments in a report issued by Standard & Poor’s, which called for a ratings cut for the United States over concerns about sovereign debt. Mr. Geithner disagreed with the finding, saying that there was “no negative outlook” for the economy. In a video interview on CNBC, he sought to assuage concerns about the possibility of a political impasse over current federal restrictions on debt levels, which S.&P. said could lead to defaults.

headline: Israeli Luminaries Press for a Palestinian State
text: JERUSALEM — Dozens of Israel’s most honored intellectuals and artists have signed a declaration endorsing a Palestinian state on the basis of the 1967 borders and asserting that an end to Israel’s occupation “will liberate the two peoples and open the way to a lasting peace.”

headline: Poor Season for Sunshine Is Great One for Spores
text: SEATTLE — There are many ways to measure the relentless precipitation and enduring gloom that have cloaked the Pacific Northwest the past few months.

headline: Now Serving | The Crème Citron Rapide
text: Spring, the Chicago-born chef Daniel Rose’s restaurant in Paris’s First Arrondissement, has made the French give America another look. Manic, wildly improvisational and not at all precious, the 33-year-old Rose himself is a large part of the attraction thanks to a massive open kitchen. One of his favorite desserts on the seven-course prix fixe menu is the oft-reappearing crème au citron. When assembled with a touch of whipped cream and, says Rose, a sprinkle of “whatever cookies we made that ended up broken,” it makes for a perfectly deconstructed lemon tart.

headline: Reuters Brings In New Leadership
text: Thomson Reuters, which is trying to move beyond its roots as a news service, announced several strategic changes on Tuesday that will establish a new leadership structure as it seeks to broaden its reach among general news consumers.

headline: Pull Up a Throne and Let’s Talk
text: Over the past few days I have received hundreds of e-mails and reviewed countless tweets taking issue with my review of the  fantasy series “Game of Thrones”, which began Sunday night on HBO. When I say “taking issue,” I am speaking euphemistically. Most respondents were horrified or furious or both. (“I am enraged and quite frankly disappointed in your unfair review of ‘Game of Thrones’,” wrote one reader.)

headline: Worshipers Sing While in Custody
text: Members of a Christian church, called Shouwang, prayed and sang hymns while in the custody of the police in Beijing.

headline: Remembering Grete Waitz
text: When Grete Waitz won her first New York City Marathon, in 1978, she was a complete unknown. She had never run a marathon. She was not listed in the race program. To those who saw her in the first 20 miles of the race, she was just a woman wearing Bib No. 1173. But at the 20-mile mark, Waitz took the lead, and the public-address announcer at the finish line had to admit that he didn’t know who she was.

headline: In Manhattan, Bentley Shows Off Its Icebreaker
text: What inspired Bentley Motors to take a Continental Supersports convertible to the frozen latitudes of the Bay of Bothnia, roughly 2.5 miles off the coast of Finland? Bentley would tell you it was done ostensibly to establish a new speed record on ice, at which Juha Kankkunen, the Finnish rally champion driver, succeeded, taking the 631-horsepower vehicle up to 205.48 m.p.h.

text: Motorcyclist deaths in the United States fell by at least 2 percent in 2010, the second year of decline, according to a new study.

text: One thing I see here and there — on blogs, in comments, etc. — is the claim that inflation is defined not by the rise in prices but by the expansion of money and credit, with prices just as a symptom.

text: The best place to get your fashion fix this season is not on Madison Avenue but at a museum near you. From London to New York, Yohji to Yves, the 1930s to 2011, these exhibitions spotlight solo designers and give new meaning to the words “just looking.”

text: When it comes to comparing bank fees, shopping around isn’t as easy as it should be.

headline: Sadrists Present Anti-American Message in Photo Exhibition

headline: Yemen Police and Protesters Clash as Deal Is Sought to End Political Crisis
text: SANA, Yemen — At least one protester died in clashes with security forces and plainclothes government supporters here in the capital on Tuesday. Security forces also fired on a demonstration in the central city of Taiz, killing one protester and wounding two others, according to witnesses and a doctor at the demonstration’s field hospital.

headline: The Lives Sports Change Indelibly
text: Basketball as a way to rise above the reservation. Surfing as a way to get off the island (in this case, Papua New Guinea). Cricket as a way to transcend third-world stereotypes. Reaching for a foul ball as a way to ruin your life.

headline: ‘End of the Rainbow’ Producers Aim for Broadway
text: The last time Judy Garland was on Broadway, it was August 1967 and she was back at the Palace Theater performing some of her greatest standards: “The Trolley Song,” “The Man That Got Away,” and, of course, “Over the Rainbow.” Over the 20 months that followed, Garland moved to London, had a five-week nightclub stand, married Mickey Deans and struggled with the pill addiction that would lead to her fatal drug overdose in June 1969.

headline: Goldman Shares Drop; Some Banks Follow
text: Goldman Sachs‘s first-quarter profit may have beaten analysts’ estimates, but it didn’t impress investors.

headline: Day One Highlights From the Shanghai Auto Show
text: In its 14th year, the Shanghai auto show is just a toddler by international auto show standards. Yet this week, as it bumps up against the New York auto show — the first was held in 1900 — the relative upstart is flashing some heavy metal.

text: Patina Miller and members of the cast of the new Broadway musical sing the number "Raise Your Voice." (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Texas Wildfires Rage on With No End in Sight
text: Firefighters in Texas on Tuesday continued to battle raging wildfires that were consuming more than a million acres and showing few signs of abating.

headline: Metropolitan Opera to Make Japan Trip
text: The Metropolitan Opera, after saying its tour this June to Japan was in jeopardy because of safety concerns, announced on Tuesday that it would go ahead with the trip. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, said in a message to the company that its decision was based on a recent advisory from the State Department that “health and safety risks” outside of a 50-mile radius around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant “are low and do not pose significant risks.” The State Department had previously urged United States citizens to defer travel to Japan.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Dominates Ratings for ABC
text: A 90-minute edition of “Dancing With the Stars” dominated the ratings on Monday as 19.6 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC easily led the night over all despite a diminished audience after the dancing competition for its sitcom “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (8.5 million). CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” led at 10 p.m., drawing 10.9 million viewers and outperforming ABC’s “20/20” special (7.6 million). CBS ranked second, earning modest ratings for its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including “How I Met Your Mother” (6.4 million), “Mad Love” (5.6 million) and “Mike & Molly” (9.7 million), while a repeat of “Two and a Half Men” attracted 7.3 million viewers at 9. Fox was third with “House” at 8 (8.6 million) and “The Chicago Code” at 9 (6.4 million). NBC struggled in fourth place with “Chuck” (4.2 million) and “The Event” (3.7 million) followed by the recently rebooted version of “Law & Order: Los Angeles” (4.9 million).

headline: Rich People Still Don’t Realize They’re Rich
text: There’s a movement afoot to mail every taxpayer a “taxpayer receipt,” a breakdown of how the government spends its money. The goal is to educate people about where their taxes go, since Americans are famously unaware about such matters.

headline: Demi Lovato Leaves ‘Sonny With a Chance’
text: The Disney Channel star Demi Lovato is leaving her popular television show, “Sonny With a Chance,” the channel confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Recalling Childhood as a Styron
text: When Alexandra Styron, the youngest of the novelist William Styron’s four children, was growing up, she writes in her new memoir, there was one inviolate rule in the house: “Don’t ask Daddy about his work.”

headline: U.S. Seeks to Shut Down Fake News Sites That Promote Berry Pills
text: The Federal Trade Commission says it will crack down on fake news Web sites that are used to advertise açaí berry weight loss pills and supplements.

headline: T-Mobile Adds Free Calling Through Facebook
text: T-Mobile has 33 million customers in the United States. On Tuesday, the wireless carrier hopes to increase its reach 15-fold with a new application, Bobsled, which lets people call each other free through Facebook.

headline: Q&A: Exploring Amsterdam’s Sights, and Beyond
text: My husband and I are going to the Netherlands for 10 days in May. We’re renting an apartment in Amsterdam, which we found on airbnb.com. We would love to take day trips from there, and would consider an overnight trip to somewhere amazing. We are in our mid-30s, into art history and love to ride bikes. Do you have any suggestions?

headline: Grete Waitz: 1953-2011
text: Waitz was a nine-time winner of the New York City Marathon who inspired runners around the world.

headline: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Marion Cotillard Are Cast in ‘The Dark Knight Rises’
text: The cast of “The Dark Knight Rises,” Christopher Nolan’s third and final entry in his series of Batman movies, is looking increasingly like the cast of his 2010 summer blockbuster “Inception,” with Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Marion Cotillard now officially on board for that superhero film. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Tuesday that Mr. Gordon-Levitt, who played one of Leonardo DiCaprio‘s dream-invading accomplices in “Inception,” will play John Blake, a Gotham City beat cop, in “The Dark Knight Rises”; Ms. Cotillard, who played Mr. DiCaprio’s enigmatic wife in “Inception,” has been cast as Miranda Tate, a board member at Wayne Enterprises who is allied with Bruce Wayne. Tom Hardy, another member of the “Inception” gang, was previously announced to play the villain Bane, and Michael Caine, who had a brief role in that film (or did he? No, wait, he did) has played the butler Alfred in all of Mr. Nolan’s Bat-films.

headline: Worthwhile Canadian Web Site
text: You could get lost for a while in the National Film Board of Canada Web site. It hosts an amazing array of movies, documentaries, animation and experimental film projects, all free for the watching. There is Leonard Maltin’s “animation favorites,” a 1976 Oscar-nominated documentary on the life and death of Malcolm Lowry or this interactive film, nominated for two Webby Awards, on returning to a small town 30 years later.

headline: Video Surfaces Online Showcasing Different iOS Interface
text: A video appeared online Tuesday that shows never-before-seen features of the Apple iPhone iOS. The video was created by Tinhte.vn, a Vietnamese technology blog.

headline: Ann Coulter Follows Up ‘Guilty’ With ‘Demonic’
text: The conservative columnist and author Ann Coulter has vowed to “take on the liberal mob” in her new book, “Demonic,” whose publication was announced on Tuesday. The book is scheduled for release on June 7 by Crown Forum, part of Random House. The publisher says Ms. Coulter will address topics including “the Democratic Party’s coddling of violent mobs,” the “false history of civil rights given by the media” and the “truth about the original Tea Party.” Ms. Coulter’s last book, “Guilty,” spent nine weeks on The New York Times best-seller list. According to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks roughly 75 percent of retail sales, it sold 121,000 copies in hardcover and 16,000 in paperback. Crown Forum’s authors include former Senator Fred Thompson, Joe Scarborough and George F. Will.

headline: Changing Room Rage
text: A dubious affliction of shopped-out women.“Three-quarters of women suffer from ‘changing room rage’ when they are shopping,” Sky News revealed:

headline: Temp Workers in Germany Dismay Unions
text: FRANKFURT — Peter Hintermeier, a 60-year-old pipe fitter, is one of the people who have made Germany competitive again, but he is not too happy about it.

headline: Mug Shot Is Released of Inmate Hevesi
text: The state’s Department of Correctional Services released a mug shot of former Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi on Tuesday. Once a champion of good governance practices, Mr. Hevesi was sentenced last week to one to four years in prison for his role in a corruption scheme involving New York State’s nearly $141 billion pension fund.

headline: Buffett and Sokol Sued Over Trading in Lubrizol Shares
text: A shareholder of Berkshire Hathaway has sued Warren E. Buffett and his former top lieutenant, David L. Sokol, accusing the two of misconduct related to Mr. Sokol’s stock trading.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'South Park'
text: A. O. Scott discusses the satire of the 1999 animated film "South Park: Bigger, Longer, Uncut."

headline: Look Beyond the Box Score for Joel Anthony’s Value
text: We know the traditional box score fails to wholly describe every player’s on-court impact, but few players are held in such unfairly low esteem because of it than Miami’s Joel Anthony. On Monday, Anthony finished with four points on 1-of-3 shooting and six rebounds, though he did also have three blocked shots in his 27 minutes. Even with three blocks, that’s an underwhelming line, and Anthony’s typical lack of points and boards is part of the reason why he’s often incorrectly grouped with Miami’s less-than-productive supporting cast.

headline: Just Looking | ‘L’Amour Fou’
text: If the equivalent of an Academy Award were offered for best performance as a muse to artists, Marie-Thérèse Walter would surely have won one. She was 17 years old in 1927, when she met a strangely charismatic, short man with mesmerizing eyes, sporting a handsome red-and-black striped tie, on the sidewalk outside the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris, where she’d gone to buy a Peter Pan collar and cuffs. “You have an interesting face,” he told her. “I’d like to do your portrait.” The name Picasso meant nothing to her, but she kept the appointment they made at his studio the next day, igniting a passion that would change the course of his art.

headline: Snoop Dogg vs. Joe Camel
text: Two weeks ago, I questioned Nickelodeon’s judgment for involving Snoop Dogg at its Kids’ Choice Awards, saying that Snoop is an adult-themed artist who has no place mingling with young children.

headline: Thor Doesn’t Drive. However …
text: The comedian Jimmy Durante used to say, in mock exasperation, “Everybody’s trying to get into the act!” When it comes to marketers’ involvement in promoting summer movies, that certainly seems true.

headline: Sports at Tribeca
text: A look at the documentaries in the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film series.

headline: On Our Radar: Power Shortages Loom in China
text: Provinces in central and southwestern China may face their worst electricity shortages in years this summer due to intensifying coal shortages and drought, state officials warn. Fuel supplies are dwindling due to steadily rising prices and transportation problems, while meager rainfall during March has left hydroelectric facilities generating significantly below peak capacity. A major copper producing region is already suffering regular power shortages, hampering production. [Reuters]

headline: Labor Puts Executive Pay in the Spotlight
text: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has long been happy to treat executive compensation as a punching bag, and a Web site it put online Tuesday lands a few new punches.

headline: Union Battle Rages at a Central Park Restaurant
text: From its perch on the lake, the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park has long been a favorite for wedding receptions, big-money benefits and twilight dinners for guests who like to watch the rowboats heading back to the shore at sunset. But workers at the Boathouse say it is anything but a pleasant place to work.

headline: Spring at the Manzanares Ranch in New Mexico
text: On the ranch and on the plate, beef cattle are elbowing out sheep by a little more each year. How one family of lamb ranchers is coping.

headline: Twitter Hit with New Spam Apps Overnight
text: A series of third-party apps began filtering through Twitter overnight that intentionally sent spam messages from users’ accounts without their knowledge.

headline: Cuba Lays Foundation for a New Leader
text: HAVANA — Cuba on Tuesday made the most significant change to its leadership since the 1959 revolution, naming someone other than the Castro brothers for the first time to fill the second-highest position in the Communist Party and possibly setting the stage for their eventual successor.

headline: Past Holds Clue to Goldstone’s Shift on the Gaza War
text: JERUSALEM — Two decades ago, Richard Goldstone, a Jewish South African judge, played a vital role in reconciling his country’s white minority government and rising black majority movement by leading a fact-finding mission into black violence that offered a Solomonic conclusion.

headline: ‘SoBro’ and ‘ProCro’ NoJoke to Assemblyman
text: Updated, 3:46 p.m. | It’s one of the oldest tricks in real estate: pretend that a property is in a more desirable neighborhood and demand more rent or a higher sale price. In other words, advertise that an apartment is in, say, Prospect Heights rather than Crown Heights.

headline: Extensions for ‘Sleep No More,’ ‘Born Bad’ and ‘Benefactors’
text: Three new productions in New York have announced weeks-long extensions. “Sleep No More,” an interactive theater piece by the British company Punchdrunk that is performed throughout three renovated warehouses on West 27th Street, has extended through June 25. Ben Brantley called the piece, in which audience members wear masks while exploring some 100 rooms and environments, “a voyeur’s delight, with all the creepy, shameful pleasures that entails.” Two well-reviewed Off Broadway shows have been extended through May 7: the Keen Company’s revival of Michael Frayn’s drama “Benefactors,” at the Clurman Theater, and Soho Rep’s production of Debbie Tucker Green’s play “Born Bad.”

headline: TimesCast | April 19, 2011
text: Syria's government vacillates between crackdown and suggestions of compromise, a formula that destroyed the leadership in Tunisia and Egypt; two generals vie for control of Libya’s rebel force.

headline: In Va., Obama Pitches Debt-Reduction Plan
text: 4:32 p.m. | Updated ANNANDALE, Va. – President Obama on Tuesday made the first of what are likely to be many road-trips to pitch his case for a more “balanced” debt-reduction plan than House Republicans have passed, one that includes tax increases for the wealthy, cuts the military and preserves Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: Blackboard Says It Has Received Takeover Offers
text: Blackboard, an online educational software company, said on Tuesday that it had hired Barclays Capital “in response to receiving unsolicited, nonbinding proposals to acquire the company.”

headline: Waitz and Lebow, a Friendship for the Ages
text: Grete Waitz’s accomplishments go on and on. She won the New York City Marathon nine times, the London Marathon twice, the world cross-country championship five times and the first world championship in the marathon. She ran four world bests in the marathon and two world records at 3,000 meters. And there was more.

headline: Saab’s PhoeniX Concept Makes Manhattan Landfall

headline: Stocks, Flows, and Pimco (Wonkish)
text: I’ve been getting questions about what happens when the Fed wraps up QE2 — related especially to Bill Gross’s public view that interest rates will shoot up. This is related to the question of the extent to which QE2 has kept interest rates low. So a quick exposition of my theoretical position, which also happens to be more or less standard economics.

headline: Reviewing Graffit
And for You, Mr. Dalí?
text: THERE is something old-fashioned about Graffit, a new Spanish-modernist restaurant on the Upper West Side, something conventional despite the loud bar up front, its tall stools, yelpy music and graffiti-covered walls.

headline: Administration Wants Tighter Painkiller Rules
text: The Obama administration said on Tuesday that it would seek legislation requiring doctors to undergo training before being permitted to prescribe powerful painkillers like OxyContin, the most aggressive step taken by federal officials to control both the use and abuse of the drugs.

headline: ‘Spinal Tap’ With Track Marks
text: The aging rocker has become a cuddly cliche in our culture, thanks to “This Is Spinal Tap,” “The Osbournes” and documentaries like “Anvil! The Story of Anvil.” You know: doddering long-haired ex-rocker half-mumbles while stumbling around adorably. And he’s a potent character, this headbanger-gone-to-seed, embodying as he does some easily digestible lessons about chasing your dreams, living every day to the fullest and the often delusional yet somehow admirable pursuit of rock ‘n’roll glory at all costs.

headline: Conceding the Principle (Wonkish)
text: Dave Altig at the Atlanta Fed is a circumspect blogger — as he must be, given his position. He generally understates his points, and gives the benefit of the doubt to those who don’t deserve it; again, that’s the nature of his position, so it’s perfectly OK.

headline: Premium Video-on-Demand Service to Begin Thursday
text: DirecTV says that on Thursday it will begin pumping into living rooms movies that have been in theaters for only about two months.  The new service, which has been expected, has drawn harsh opposition from multiplex chains.

headline: Capitals’ Arnott Has Had a Big Impact in a Short Time
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — As the Washington Capitals ponder how to win their first-round tug of war with the Rangers, their game plan depends heavily on a 36-year-old veteran center who joined the team less than two months ago: Jason Arnott.

headline: Changing Your Account's E-Mail Address
text: Learn how to change the e-mail address associated with your New York Times digital subscription.

headline: Is Capitalism Losing Popularity?
text: Even as Paul Ryan trumpets his free-market populism and the need for cuts to government spending as the only way to help the average American, The Economist reports that, at least according to a poll from the Canadian firm GlobeScan, capitalism as an ideology is actually on the wane. And not just in France (as you might have predicted) where only 6 percent “strongly support the free market,” but almost everywhere in the world except China, Brazil and Germany (the latter remains less than keen on bailing out its southern neighbors).

headline: Milestones: The Life of Obama's Mother
text: A timeline of Stanley Ann Dunham’s personal life and career.

headline: Toyota Plans to Reduce Production for 6 Weeks
text: DETROIT — Toyota Motor said on Tuesday that it would cut production at its North American plants by 75 percent in the next six weeks to conserve its limited supply of parts made in Japan.

headline: Here’s to the Ladies Who Lurch
text: Note to Tony Glazer: This was a cute idea. A group of affluent, white-wine-drinking Westchester County book-club women whose leader sells them to television as a reality show. But almost everything about “Reading Under the Influence: The ‘Real’ Westchester Women’s Book Club” is not cute.

headline: New ‘Gang of Six’ to Take on Deficit
text: Another Gang of Six?

headline: At the Met, a Soprano Ascendant
text: On a recent morning the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky, glamorous in jeans, black jacket and long, glittery earrings, finessed phrasing and diminuendos in excerpts from Verdi’s “Trovatore” at the Upper West Side apartment of Anthony Manoli, her vocal coach.

headline: Hamas Captures Suspect in Italian’s Killing; 2 Others Dead
text: GAZA — Two of the extremists suspected of killing an Italian activist died and a third was captured on Tuesday when Hamas security troops stormed a building in central Gaza where the men were hiding, according to the Gazan Interior Ministry.

headline: I.B.M. Exceeds Earnings Estimates and Raises Its Profit Forecast
text: I.B.M. has become a model of predictably solid financial performance, reporting a modest increase in revenue but a greater increase in profit.

headline: Intel’s Quarterly Profits Are Lifted by Sales of Chips for High-End Servers
text: Despite facing one challenge after another in the first quarter, Intel posted strong profits on higher sales across its product line. The results surprised many investors, as well as Intel executives, who had projected a far bleaker quarter after a product recall, consolidation after two acquisitions and the effects of the Japanese earthquake on production.

headline: Income Slips for Yahoo, but Ads Show Some Promise
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s chief executive, still has work ahead to lift her company out of its slump.

headline: Off Pitch | Muammar Mia!
text: Thanks to whoever sent me this. Would that I could play in Muammar el-Qaddafi’s closet. Sadly, The Times’s editorial policy prohibits me from taking this trip.

headline: The White House Easter Egg Roll: ‘Get Up and Go!’
text: The 133rd White House Easter Egg Roll on Monday will emphasize health and fitness with a little help from the singer Willow Smith and the sprinter Tyson Gay.

headline: Branson: A Man With an Island for Lemurs
text: The businessman and adventure tycoon Richard Branson is taking heat for his plan to bring 30 Madagascar ring-tailed lemurs to his own private island in the British Virgin Islands.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 19, 2011
text: Britain will send experienced military officers to Libya to advise rebels fighting forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, its government said Tuesday.

headline: Approval for Changes to Manufacturers Hanover Trust Building
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission approved controversial changes on Monday to the interior of the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street. Preservationists had objected to revisions of the 1954 building’s interior, which was designated a landmark in February.

headline: Kanye West’s Charity Closes
text: The charity named for the rapper Kanye West that was intended to reduce high school dropout rates has closed mysteriously.

headline: A Post-Spring Break Jaunt to Florida’s Beaches
text: I’d been on the road for barely an hour, but when you’ve got to go, you’ve got to go.

headline: As British Help Libyan Rebels, Aid Goes to a Divided Force
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — As NATO struggles to break a deepening stalemate in Libya, the British announced on Tuesday that they were sending military advisers to help build up a rebel army that has stumbled against the superior forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: A Relationship Forged Through Running, Family and Life
text: We called each other best friends, a friendship forged through running, writing and just being two women of about the same age. For nearly 30 years, and through co-authoring three books, scores of speeches, articles and conversing about sports, marriage and, yes, even death — I knew a Grete few people did. And through her, I learned what it truly takes to have achieved the greatness she did. In addition to her athletic gifts, she was the most focused, disciplined and humble person I have ever known.

headline: BlackBerry’s Bridge to Nowhere
text: The BlackBerry PlayBook, Research In Motion’s first entry in the tablet computing world, arrived in stores on Tuesday. But first-day buyers who use AT&T as their wireless carrier were immediately frustrated when they tried to use a key feature of the PlayBook.

text: Adapted from Natividad Manzanares

text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Henry VIII Didn’t Write This Royal Wedding Menu
text: THE 650 royal wedding guests who have been invited to Buckingham Palace for the reception after the royal wedding next week shouldn’t spend too much time worrying about which fork to pick up for the fish course. That’s because they are probably not going to be served any courses at all.

headline: Caring for Wounded Protesters in Sana
text: Doctors at a makeshift field clinic in the capital care for protesters injured during clashes with police.

headline: The $410 Corkscrew
text: THEY come in all shapes and sizes. Most often, they can be found stuffed into kitchen drawers alongside potato mashers, melon ballers and other seldom-used essentials of the kitchen. Wine lovers take them for granted, except when nobody can find one. Call a Boy Scout! He’s sure to be prepared with a handy multifunction pocket knife that includes one.

headline: Where to Find a Very British Breakfast
text: APRIL 29 will dawn early for American fans of English royalty who would not think of watching the wedding of Kate Middleton and Prince William on TiVo. With most coverage beginning at 4 a.m., it will soon be breakfast time.

headline: Distillers Take a New Approach to Canadian Whiskies
text: PHILIP WARD, a noted Manhattan mixologist, was blunt when asked recently whether he had any thoughts about Canadian whisky. “Sure, I have thoughts,” he said in a deadpan reply. “I think about all the other whiskeys I’d like to drink before I’d drink a Canadian whisky.”

headline: When Digging for Ramps Goes Too Deep
text: FOR Ashton Berdine, a ramble in the woods to dig for the pungent tender-leaved wild leeks known as ramps has been a springtime ritual since he was a teenager. Even today, at 45, as the first buds appear on trees, he takes his family into the woods near his home in Elkins, W.Va., to dig a few ramps to cook with fajitas.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: All About Eggs

headline: Vinegar From France’s Far East
text: Imagine a vinegar that suggests sherry but will not darken your endive salad or fillet of halibut. There you have Vin Jaune vinegar. It’s made from an unusual white wine of the Jura region in eastern France with a dry, sherrylike allure. The honey-colored vinegar made from this wine is at once nutty and spicy, with a hint of musky richness. A vinaigrette or béarnaise will profit from its flavor, as will a last-minute pan sauce for chicken or fish.

headline: TimesCast | Syria's Government Wavers
text: April 19, 2011 - Amid protests, Syria's government vacillates between crackdown and compromise.

headline: The Genius Who Built Central Park
text: You hope that whatever your life’s work is, it will outlast you, but for the huge majority of people, it won’t. The swell job you did as an account manager or hairstylist might have earned you kudos from the boss or tips from customers, but no one’s going to be savoring it generations from now.

headline: Plane With Michelle Obama Aborts Landing
text: WASHINGTON — An Air Force passenger jet carrying Michelle Obama to Andrews Air Force Base early Monday evening had to abort its landing and circle the field because it was following too closely on the tail of a giant military cargo plane arriving ahead of it, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Tuesday.

headline: Van Horn Sandwich Shop
text: 231 Court Street (Warren Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, (718) 596-9707, vanhornbrooklyn.com.

headline: Leader of Big Mortgage Lender Guilty of $2.9 Billion Fraud
text: The founder of what was once one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders was convicted of fraud on Tuesday for masterminding a scheme that cheated investors and the government out of billions of dollars. It is one of the few successful prosecutions to come out of the financial crisis.

headline: In Rival Bids for NYSE, Weighing the Lesser of 2 Evils
text: Harry Campbell

headline: For Brearley Titles, Everything but Your Majesty?
text: Brearley, the private all-girls powerhouse school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, boasts some big-name alumnae. Caroline Kennedy went there. So did Jill Clayburgh, Kyra Sedgwick, Anne and Katie Roiphe and Jessica Tuchman Mathews, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

headline: Should You Worry About a U.S. Default?
text: Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, lowered its outlook for the United States to “negative” on Monday, a warning that the country’s top-notch, triple-A credit rating may be lowered. Credit ratings are supposed to give crucial insight into a debtor’s likelihood of default, so a lot of investors and pundits made a big deal about this announcement.

headline: How to Keep Your Browser Tabs Organized
text: Tabbed browsing is a great invention, but what do you do with too many tabs?

headline: New Earphones for HTC Smartphones
text: HTC has had certifiable hits with it Android phones such as the Incredible, the EVO and now the Thunderbolt. But these phones miss the mark for many people using aftermarket headphones because some have features that don’t work with HTC handsets.

headline: TimesCast | In Libya, a War Within a War
text: April 19, 2011 - A report on the fractious leadership in the Libyan rebel military force, as rival generals each claim command.

headline: Students Hurt as 6-Year-Old Drops Pistol
text: HOUSTON — The kindergarten students were just sitting down in a cafeteria at Betsy Ross Elementary School on Monday when a loaded pistol tumbled out of the pocket of a 6-year-old boy and discharged, injuring him and two other children, school officials said.

headline: Stoudemire Not Forgotten, D’Antoni Says
text: BOSTON — Amar’e Stoudemire was a devastating force for nine minutes of the fourth quarter Sunday night, and an apparent afterthought in the final three minutes. The Knicks’ offense veered elsewhere, the Celtics won the game and a meme was born: that Stoudemire’s teammates had neglected him.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,527 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: WikiLeaks Defendant to Be Moved
text: WASHINGTON—Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking classified government documents to the Web site WikiLeaks, will be moved from near-solitary confinement at the Marine brig in Quantico, Va., to another prison under conditions that may be less restrictive.

text: The Wisconsin board that oversees elections said Tuesday that it found no major discrepancies in one county’s final tally in a close State Supreme Court election this month.

text: She was slender and elfin, a wood sprite in appearance, not the brash and hardy species normally found around New York’s First Avenue.
