headline: Community Health Moves to Dismiss Tenet Lawsuit
text: Community Health Systems moved on Tuesday to dismiss a lawsuit filed against it by Tenet Healthcare, in which Tenet accused Community Health of overbilling Medicare.

headline: South Africa Exults Abroad but Frets at Home
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa has been savoring its new membership in the club of emerging powers now known as BRICS, with that satisfying S in the acronym recently added to prove it belongs with the far more populous nations of Brazil, Russia, India and China. Last week, President Jacob Zuma attended his nation’s first BRICS meeting, in China, and boasted in a speech of South Africa’s “increasingly important position in the international arena.”

headline: On Journey, Young Tunisians Need Only a Final Destination
text: VENTIMIGLIA, Italy — In the American Bar, across the square from the train station here, they have had enough. “The Tunisians are everywhere,” the waitress said. “It’s been like this for a month. They sleep in the station and on the streets, and we’ve lost a lot of customers.”

headline: Justices Skeptical on Role of Courts in Setting Emissions Standards
text: WASHINGTON — A lawsuit by six states and New York City to force major power companies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions was met with seemingly unanimous skepticism from the justices on Tuesday during arguments at the Supreme Court.

headline: Sarasota Police Seek Clues After Tourists Are Killed
text: MIAMI — In a Florida double murder that has consumed the press in England, two British college graduates vacationing in Sarasota were shot dead in the city’s roughest neighborhood Saturday after an evening of drinks at a local bar.

headline: Networks That Stood by N.H.L. Secure Deal
text: Six years ago, the N.H.L. was emerging from a season-long lockout and looked like a bit like a TV orphan. It was spurned by ESPN as a sport that was losing its value and its zest.

headline: Google’s Eric Schmidt Gets a Big Raise
text: Eric E. Schmidt’s new job as executive chairman of Google came with a very nice raise.

headline: Lockout Permitting, N.F.L. Has a Schedule
text: The N.F.L. released the 2011 schedule Tuesday, but perhaps it should be written in pencil.

headline: Republicans Sharpening Online Tools for 2012
text: As part of President Obama’s plan to rebuild the grass-roots movement that propelled him to the White House, he took to YouTube this week to urge his 19.3 million Facebook friends to join him, and invite others, for a town-hall-style chat on Facebook Wednesday with Mark Zuckerberg, the social media site’s chief executive, at his side.

headline: NRG Abandons Project for 2 Reactors in Texas
text: The company planning the largest nuclear project in the United States, two giant reactors in South Texas, announced on Tuesday that it was giving up and writing off its investment of $331 million after uncertainties created by the accident in Japan.

headline: For Derek Jacobi, Now Is the Time for a Certain Role
text: LONDON

headline: The Great Sumter Rally in Union Square
text: April 20, 1861

headline: Rodriguez Pushes Return Back Another Day
text: TORONTO — Alex Rodriguez hit in the batting cages. He threw long toss. He played catch and fielded ground balls at third base. He did everything Tuesday except find a place in the starting lineup against the Toronto Blue Jays, saying he needed another day to rest his sore right oblique muscle.

headline: Dangerous Arts
text: THE great Turbine Hall at London’s Tate Modern, a former power station, is a notoriously difficult space for an artist to fill with authority. Its immensity can dwarf the imaginations of all but a select tribe of modern artists who understand the mysteries of scale, of how to say something interesting when you also have to say something really big. Louise Bourgeois’s giant spider once stood menacingly in this hall; Anish Kapoor’s “Marsyas,” a huge, hollow trumpet-like shape made of a stretched substance that hinted at flayed skin, triumphed over it majestically.

headline: Sharp Edge to Words in Rangers’ Hard-Hitting Series
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The playoff series between the Rangers and the Washington Capitals has been close and contentious, so it was not too surprising that the coaches were sniping at each other on the eve of Wednesday’s pivotal Game 4.

headline: As a Star Elevates His Game, His Teammates Continue to Fall
text: Boston

headline: Checkout Coupon Company Joins Boom in Online Discount Offers
text: A COMPANY long known for providing shoppers with coupons at store checkouts is joining the popular, crowded category of online coupons.

headline: Mixed Feelings for Blagojevich Retrial, None of Them Happy
text: CHICAGO — Rod R. Blagojevich, the governor turned prisoner turned reality television star turned radio talk show host, is scheduled to get a new trial starting as early as Wednesday, eight months after proceedings ended with a jury divided on most of the corruption counts against him.

headline: Goldman’s Sluggish Growth Raises Concern on Wall St.
text: Goldman Sachs gave investors a peek at the new normal on Wall Street — and many are worried.

headline: Police Union Fights Back Against an Inquiry, Calling Ticket-Fixing a Courtesy
text: As scores of police officers, supervisors and union officials are investigated for fixing tickets in the Bronx, the Sergeants Benevolent Association — the powerful union for the Police Department’s 12,000 front-line supervisors — has started a campaign arguing that the practice, while widespread, is one of courtesy, not corruption.

headline: A Rational Budget for the Pentagon
text: In their budget-cutting zeal, Republicans are demanding harsh sacrifices from the country’s most vulnerable citizens. At the same, they are determined to leave one of the biggest areas of wasteful government spending untouched: the Pentagon budget.

headline: Trade Deal With Panama Clears Hurdle Over Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — The White House announced on Tuesday that Panama had satisfied a final condition for a free-trade pact with the United States, smoothing the way for President Obama to seek Congressional approval for three trade agreements inherited from the Bush administration and now central to his own job-creation agenda.

headline: A Shrewd Bet in Galleon Case
U.S. Engineers Cite Lengthy Cleanup in Japan
text: Veterans of the Three Mile Island cleanup said that a much larger task faced the Japanese engineers who are trying contain and secure the damaged Fukushima Daiichi reactors. And Three Mile Island took 14 years.

headline: Good Advice From S.& P.
text: Anything the credit rating agencies say has to be taken with a block of salt. In the run-up to the financial crisis, they were enablers of excess, happily slapping AAA ratings on the toxic assets of their Wall Street customers. The same happened with Enron and other debacles.

headline: Making Campuses Safer
text: Federal statistics suggest that as many as 1 in 5 women will be victims of sexual assault during their college years. Far too many women who report their attackers are then victimized by complaint systems that are difficult to navigate and disciplinary proceedings that are stacked against them. The Education Department’s civil rights office has issued new guidelines for schools with the aim of making campuses safer.

headline: Sam Fuld’s Value to the Rays Goes Beyond Numbers
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Samuel Babson Fuld was 10 pounds at birth, so chunky that the nurse in the delivery room told his parents, Ken Fuld and Amanda Merrill, that their son would grow up to be a football player. They called him Sumo Sam.

headline: Obama Panel to Curb Medicare Finds Foes in Both Parties
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats and Republicans are joining to oppose one of the most important features of President Obama’s new deficit reduction plan, a powerful independent board that could make sweeping cuts in the growth of Medicare spending.

headline: Away From the New York Auto Show, Brands Bask in Their Own Spotlights
text: A spreading trend at auto shows — as inescapable as Rebecca Black’s “Friday” tween video, and possibly as insidious — is the off-site event.

headline: Gov. Brewer Shows Some Moxie
text: A ray of sunshine emanating from a most unlikely source briefly penetrated the gloom of Arizona’s right-wing politics on Monday.

headline: Cuomo Helps Groups Mobilize for Gay Marriage Bill
text: Gay rights groups, which suffered the stinging defeat of a same-sex marriage bill in New York State in 2009, will publicly mount a new campaign for the legislation starting this week, relying on the popular Democratic governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, to overcome Republican resistance and their own history of poor coordination.

headline: The Legend of Sam Fuld
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. – Sam Fuld collected four hits for the Tampa Bay Rays on Monday, becoming the first player this season with two four-hit games. The first was at Fenway Park, on April 11, when he came a single short of the cycle by doubling in his last at-bat.

headline: Many Mediterranean Fish Species Threatened With Extinction, Report Says
text: PARIS — Mediterranean fish, including bluefin tuna, sea bass and hake, are in danger of extinction from overfishing, marine habitat degradation and pollution, according to a report on Tuesday from the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

headline: Revis Lobbies to Sign Moss and Edwards
text: Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis said he would welcome the petulant wide receiver Randy Moss to the Jets, despite Revis’s previous assessment of Moss as a “slouch.” But Revis, speaking from a Range Rover event in Manhattan, also lobbied for the Jets to sign one of their own free agents, receiver Braylon Edwards. “We need to keep Braylon,” Revis said. “He’s made a lot of plays since he’s been here.”

headline: Belarus: Currency to Be Traded
text: Belarus announced Tuesday that it would allow its flagging currency to trade freely between banks, all but ensuring a devaluation of the ruble in an effort to ease an increasingly dire economic situation. The exchange rate had previously been fixed. Economists have said that the move would help jump-start the economy by lowering prices on exports, slowing the outflow of dollars and euros. But the decision will probably cause inflation to spike, further undermining confidence in Belarus’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. Soviet-style economic policies have depleted Belarus’s foreign currency reserves, and people have been waiting in long lines to exchange rubles for increasingly scarce dollars and euros. The sense of crisis was compounded last week by a bombing at a subway station in the capital, Minsk, that killed 13 people.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 19, 2011

headline: Chile: Evidence on Priest Seized
text: The police in Santiago have raided the home and offices of a lawyer representing a Roman Catholic priest found guilty by the Vatican of sexually molesting boys. The authorities seized documents related to the church case for a criminal investigation, a police spokeswoman, Lorena Quiroz, confirmed Tuesday. A judge ordered the raid after Juan Pablo Bulnes, the lawyer for the priest, the Rev. Fernando Karadima, above, refused to turn over documents. Mr. Bulnes on Tuesday called the action an “abuse” of his right to lawyer-client confidentiality. He said Chile’s bar association has asked the Supreme Court to overturn the seizure. An appeals court voted last month to reopen a criminal case into charges of sexual abuse after the Vatican found Father Karadima guilty of abusing minors. The Vatican ordered the priest to retire to a “life of prayer and penitence.” He has appealed the Vatican’s decision.

headline: Italy: Nuclear Plants On Hold
text: Less than three years after embracing nuclear power, the government proposed a measure that would indefinitely delay plans to develop a nuclear energy strategy, including the building of plants. Italy had already announced a one-year moratorium on site selection and the construction of plants, but an amendment presented Tuesday in the Senate would scrap all the rules governing their construction. The Senate was to vote Wednesday on the measure.

headline: Solar on the Water
text: PETALUMA, Calif. — Solar panels have sprouted on countless rooftops, carports and fields in Northern California. Now, several start-up companies see potential for solar panels that float on water.

headline: Sudan: 350 Buildings Burned
text: Large parts of el-Feid, a town in Sudan’s Nuba Mountains, have been burned to the ground, satellite images from a research organization, the Satellite Sentinel Project, show. More than 350 structures were set on fire a week ago, the organization said Tuesday, noting that, according to a local politician, at least 20 people were killed in the attack. It said that many of the structures appeared to be traditional homes and that the attackers’ identities had not been determined. An election for governor is scheduled for next month in the State of South Kordofan, where el-Feid is located. The region has traditionally been aligned with the South, which voted in January to separate from the North. According to a 2005 peace agreement, the region is supposed to decide it’s own destiny by July.

headline: Immigration Is Lead Topic as Leaders Are Gathered
text: President Obama told a gathering of business, labor, religious and political leaders at the White House on Tuesday that he remains committed to an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws and wants to try again in the coming months to push Congress to pass a bill.

headline: Prescription Drug Abuse in Appalachia
text: A generation of young people in Appalachia, who were raised by their grandparents because their parents were addicts, are now becoming prescription drug addicts themselves.

headline: No Accord on Mekong Dam
text: Representatives from the four countries that share the lower reaches of the Mekong River said Tuesday that they failed to reach agreement on plans for a controversial dam in Laos. At a meeting in Vientiane, the Laotian capital, officials from Laos, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam postponed a decision on the Xayaburi dam, which would be the first across the Mekong south of the Chinese border. The dam is the first in a series of large-scale hydroelectric projects on the Mekong that the cash-strapped Laotian government is pursuing in order to sell electricity to other countries. Cambodia and Thailand recommended further studies of the dam’s environmental impact, and Vietnam, which fears deleterious effects to the Mekong Delta, called for a moratorium on dams across the Mekong. The governments did not say when they would meet to decide the issue.

headline: The General in His Study
text: The writing is blurred and the paper nearly translucent, but the scene it portrays is vivid. In a recently discovered letter, Mary Custis Lee, the eldest daughter of Robert E. Lee, describes how her father wrestled with the decision to resign his commission in the United States Army and side with the South. The letter, found in a folder of fragments at the Virginia Historical Society, was written in 1871 to Charles Marshall, Lee’s former aide-to–camp, as he prepared to write a biography of the great general.

headline: Manhattan’s Tech Start-Ups Settle in the Flatiron District and Chelsea
text: New York City’s technology sector has sometimes been called “Silicon Alley,” in deference to its Western big brother, which sprawls across the San Francisco Bay Area. Now, a decade after the dot-com crash stopped the rapid growth of the city’s booming Internet sector, a high-tech corridor has developed in the Flatiron district and neighboring Chelsea.

headline: Stripped of Dignity
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Move on New Jersey Health Plan May Cost Towns but Help Power Broker
text: In the last three years, hundreds of cities, towns and school districts in New Jersey have saved tens of millions of dollars on health insurance by dumping their private carriers and switching to a little-known benefits program run by the state.

headline: Madoff Investors’ Lawsuit Blaming the S.E.C. for Losses Is Dismissed by a Federal Judge
text: Two of Bernard L. Madoff’s investors on Tuesday lost their bid to bring a $2.5 million suit against the Securities and Exchange Commission, blaming the agency for failing to detect and end the Ponzi scheme.

headline: City Vows to Fight Suits in Central Park Jogger Case
text: New York City is refusing to settle lawsuits brought by the five men whose convictions in the Central Park jogger case were overturned after they spent years in prison.

headline: Allan Blakeney, Pioneer of Canadian Health Care, Dies at 85
text: Allan Blakeney, the health minister of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan who helped start North America’s first tax-financed universal health care system in 1962, and was later the province’s premier, died Saturday at his home in Saskatoon. He was 85.

headline: Student Gripes Have a Point: Campus Dining Fails Exams
text: It is as much a college sport as football or beer pong. Whether poking soggy carrots or theorizing about the provenance of mystery meat, undergraduates have always loved to complain about their campus cafeterias.

headline: Cars With Computers Pose New Challenges
text: Sam Grobart, the Times' personal technology editor, tries out three designs for computerized dashboards.

headline: Anything to Avoid Paying a Fine
text: Of the many fevers that can grip the human animal, the desire to fix parking and traffic tickets has few equals for absurdity.

headline: Ohio County Losing Its Young to Painkillers’ Grip
text: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — This industrial town was once known for its shoes and its steel. But after decades of decline it has made a name for itself for a different reason: it is home to some of the highest rates of prescription drug overdoses in the state, and growing numbers of younger victims.

headline: Wednesday: Job For a Snake
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a light repast today, and a healthy one at that. Michael Farabaugh tosses us a puzzle whose theme is revealed in the central 15 at 39 Across. Sharpen your writing implements and pass the vinaigrette.

headline: Assisting Recovery, Craving Redemption
text: Heavy doses of sarcasm are probably not a recommended therapy for recovering addicts. And yet as wielded by Kathleen Turner’s Sister Jamison Connelly in “High,” the sensation-stuffed drama by Matthew Lombardo that opened Tuesday night at the Booth Theater, the withering retort ultimately achieves better results than more soothing approaches.

headline: A Conversation With Ted Danson
text: Mark Bittman talks with actor and "Oceana" author Ted Danson about fish and the world's oceans.

headline: The Sea Turtles’ Plight
text: A year after the BP oil spill, endangered sea turtles still wash up dead on Gulf of Mexico shores in large numbers. A federal investigation suggests that the culprit is likely not oil.

headline: Woman, at Trial, Cites Racism in Son’s Detention by Police

headline: Parking Rules

headline: Obama’s Young Mother Abroad
text: The photograph showed the son, but my eye gravitated toward the mother. That first glimpse was surprising — the stout, pale-skinned woman in sturdy sandals, standing squarely a half-step ahead of the lithe, darker-skinned figure to her left. His elas­tic-band body bespoke discipline, even asceticism. Her form was well padded, territory ceded long ago to the pleasures of appetite and the forces of anatomical destiny. He had the studied casualness of a catalog model, in khakis, at home in the viewfinder. She met the camera head-on, dressed in hand-loomed textile dyed indigo, a silver earring half-hidden in the cascading curtain of her dark hair. She carried her chin a few degrees higher than most. His right hand rested on her shoulder, lightly. The photograph, taken on a Manhattan rooftop in August 1987 and e-mailed to me 20 years later, was a revelation and a puzzle. The man was Barack Obama at 26, the community organizer from Chicago on a visit to New York. The woman was Stanley Ann Dunham, his mother. It was impossible not to be struck by the similarities, and the dissimilarities, between them. It was impossible not to question the stereotype to which she had been expediently reduced: the white woman from Kansas.

headline: Under Rome, a Trip Back to Imperial Times
text: As a rule, digging beneath the surface of modern Rome turns up ancient buildings. Excavations conducted in 2007, just steps from the traffic hub of Piazza Venezia, revealed two Imperial era villas embellished with mosaics, polychrome wall veneers, fountains and frescoes. Dating back to the second and third centuries, these opulent dwellings were abandoned in late antiquity, filled with landfill, and unknowingly used as foundations for the 16th-century Palazzo Valentini, now seat of the Province of Rome’s offices.

The most recognizable pieces in her collection are the starred sweater and mittens that the title character wears in the 2009 animated film “Coraline,” from the animation studio Laika. With the amount of digital effects that go into contemporary movie making, it never crossed my mind that those objects would have been handknit. In an online interview, Crome says:

headline: Q. & A.: Filmmaker’s Path From Rwanda to Tribeca

The film, which has its world premiere on April 21, blends fantasy and reality in its portrayal of the aftermath of the genocide in Rwanda as seen through the eyes of a novice director struggling to make a film called “The Cycle of the Cockroach.” Mr. Ruhorahoza, 28, spoke recently to Arts Beat about the inspiration for the movie and its title, how Flaubert and Norman Mailer piqued his interest in storytelling, and why he chose filmmaking over practicing law. headline: River to River Festival Announces Lineup
text: Downtown mainstays including Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith, Rufus Wainwright and Sean Lennon, and – straight from the Battle of Agincourt – Henry V will all be part of the 10th River to River Festival, the annual celebration of arts in lower Manhattan, its organizers said on Wednesday. The festival of free events, which runs from June 19 through July 16, will begin with the Bang on a Can Marathon at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, with performances by Mr. Glass, top, with the Bang on a Can All-Stars. The Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park will host concerts featuring Vijay Iyer (on June 23); Ms. Anderson, above, with Bill Laswell (June 30); and Ms. Smith (July 14). Rockefeller Park will be the setting of a June 22 tribute to the Bottom Line, featuring Rosanne Cash, Dar Williams and Marshall Crenshaw. Mr. Wainwright and soloists from the New York City Opera will perform excerpts from his opera “Prima Donna” at the World Financial Center Winter Garden on June 28. Mr. Lennon’s band the Ghost of a Saber Tooth Tiger will perform at the Seaport on June 24. And New York Classical Theater will present a two-castle production of Shakespeare‘s “Henry V” at Castle Clinton in Battery Park and Castle William on Governors Island (with free ferry service between the locations). A complete schedule and other information can be found at the festival’s Web site, rivertorivernyc.com.

headline: First We Eat | Hitting the Hay
text: We are not just eating a steak, or an omelet, when our fork lands, tines down, into our food. We, as conscious consumers, are eating all of the resources it took to raise that cow and transport those eggs from farm to fork. So, as trends go, it is somewhat encouraging, if not a bit beguiling, to see such a rudimentary ingredient as hay (yes, plain old barnyard hay) begin to appear on menus around the country, as well as Europe. We have effectively cut out the middleman (the ruminant cow) and gone straight to the pasture.

headline: A Crime Lurks on the Dark Side of a Clairvoyant Realm
text: Stephen Schwartz, the musical-theater composer and lyricist, could hardly be more successful. His credits include “Godspell,” “Pippin” and the long-running “Wicked,” which has been playing on Broadway since 2003. There was no reason for him to write an opera. He had nothing to prove. So “Séance on a Wet Afternoon,” his first work in the genre, which had its premiere in 2009 at Opera Santa Barbara, was a labor of love.

headline: Back in Black, and Brown and Blue
text: The Coach Duffle bag, which was designed in the 1970s by Bonnie Cashin, is just the sort of no-logo, no-hardware, no-nonsense bag that no one is making anymore. Not even Coach, which saw fit to put this workhorse out to pasture in 1997. But starting June 15, Net-a-Porter is bringing back the Duffle, as well as four other seminal styles from that era, as the Coach Classics collection. Fans of the original will notice only one minor adjustment: an ad for Neiman Marcus in The Dallas Morning News from the ’70s listed the Duffle for $36. This summer it will set you back $398.

headline: Everything Returns to Carbon
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

headline: A Passion Play Endures as a Seasonal Miracle
text: WAUCHULA, Fla. — With less than two hours until showtime, a man sits amid the backstage chaos and studies his image in a propped-up mirror. The eyes are grayish blue, the goatee trim, the long dark hair flecked with gray. Not there yet. He scoops another dab of makeup to continue the annual transformation of Mike Graham, now 58, into Jesus Christ, forever 33.

headline: A Passion for Playing Jesus
text: Pastor Mike Graham of Florida has been performing the role of Jesus for more than two decades. His passion play involves more than two hundred participants and one hundred animals.

headline: St. Patrick’s Cathedral, 9:19 A.M.
text: Polishing the Paschal candle stand in preparation for the Easter vigil.

headline: Media Decoder: Library Books on the Kindle
text: On Media Decoder, Julie Bosman reports that Amazon is changing its policy on library books and the Kindle, creating a new feature that would allow Kindle customers to borrow e-books from more than 11,000 libraries across the country.

headline: A New Incentive to Travel Solo
text: Solo travelers going on expeditions often must pay additional fees that can significantly increase the cost of a trip. But the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent has a new solo-savings initiative that reduces, and in some cases waives, extra expenses for those hitting the road on their own.

headline: Are You Ready for the Presidential Primaries?
text: David Brooks: Gail, every few years around this time I get Iowa fever. I get excited at the prospect of going out to Davenport or Pocahontas and riding in the backseat of a van with some second- or third-tier politicians as they shuttle between coffee shops, doughnut shops and community centers trying to get elected president.

headline: Gold’s Price Surge May Mean Your Jewelry Is Under-Insured
text: Gold prices have skyrocketed over the last decade, which means your jewelry may be under-insured if you haven’t had it appraised recently.

headline: Danish Dynamite | Henrik Vibskov
text: What are some of Henrik Vibskov’s favorite pieces in his new store? “I love the socks and hats — that’s at least my personal style,” he says. “I always wear a hat, and every guy should have a nice pair of socks.” The 38-year-old designer, who referred to himself in an interview as “Danish dynamite,” just opened an eponymous boutique last Friday on Broome Street in New York, and it’s filled with plenty of eccentric-looking socks and hats from his line and other indie-Euro imports (Cosmic Wonder, Stine Goya, Ally Capellino and Peter Jensen, to name a few).

headline: Concerns Over iPhone Tracking Data
text: British newspaper The Guardian reported today that Apple’s iPhone stores user-location information and then syncs that data to a file on your PC. We’ve requested a comment from Apple and will update accordingly.

headline: Bacterial Ecosystems Divide People Into 3 Groups, Scientists Say
text: In the early 1900s, scientists discovered that each person belonged to one of four blood types. Now they have discovered a new way to classify humanity: by bacteria. Each human being is host to thousands of different species of microbes. Yet a group of scientists now report just three distinct ecosystems in the guts of people they have studied.

headline: A Treat for Promptness, and Produce at City Hall
text: On account of their good behavior, members of the State Legislature are about to receive a treat: a longer spring break.

headline: Wetlands? What Wetlands?
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has become, for some of libertarian or Tea Party convictions, something of an embodiment of government run amok. Environmentalists see the agency, at its best, as the defender of people’s health and the environment’s welfare.

headline: Obama Marks Anniversary of BP Disaster
text: One year ago today, the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico because of a runaway oil well. The accident killed 11 rig workers and spilled nearly five million barrels of oil into the gulf, the biggest maritime oil spill in United States history.

headline: He’s Handsome — You Noticed? — but Not Just
text: Any discerning reader who gets as far in Rob Lowe’s memoir as the photo on the front cover will notice that Mr. Lowe is good looking. Very good looking. So good looking that it’s almost a liability, and that his memoir, “Stories I Only Tell My Friends,” has to take his appearance into account. He had to decide how to handle this, his boo-hoo problem, in a book.

headline: ‘High,’ With Kathleen Turner, Will Close on Sunday
text: The crowded latter half of the Broadway season has its first high-profile closure: Matthew Lombardo’s play “High,” starring Kathleen Turner as a nun whose faith is tested while working with a young drug addict, will close on Sunday, press representatives for the show said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Restrepo’ Director and a Photographer Are Killed in Libya
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Tim Hetherington, a conflict photographer who was a director and producer of the Afghan war documentary “Restrepo,” was killed in the besieged city of Misurata, Libya, on Wednesday, and three photographers working beside him were wounded, one fatally, when they came under fire at the city’s front lines.

headline: Scenes From a Séance
text: The composer Stephen Schwartz narrates a look at his opera "Séance on a Wet Afternoon," at New York City Opera.

text: THE day after returning from the Paris shows last month, Jade Lai had some pressing business. Her spacious new boutique in NoLIta, Creatures of Comfort, was having its first storewide sale. And she was working the register.

headline: Lighter Winds Help in Battle Against Texas Wildfires
text: Firefighters from 34 states received some help from the weather on Wednesday as lighter winds helped slow the spread of the wildfires burning across Texas, but the respite was not expected to last.

headline: ‘Restrepo’ Director Is Killed in Libya
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Tim Hetherington, the Oscar-nominated film director and conflict photographer who, along with with Sebastian Junger, produced the film “Restrepo,” was killed in the besieged city of Misurata on Wednesday. Three photographers working beside him were wounded, one fatally. Read more from The Times’s correspondent in Libya, C.J. Chivers.

headline: Those Elusive Bond Vigilantes
text: For some reason, I have been thinking that the WSJ first warned about the return of the bond vigilantes in May 2009. But noooo [/end Belushi]: it was May 2008. A year later, the WSJ repeated the claim. And a year after that, it repeated it again.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic: In Search of Fine Dining and Harbor Views
text: The digital carrier pigeon brought questions from married people this week, and from dutiful children and copy editors in search of a reunion meal. I did my best to answer them. You may of course send along your own questions about dining out in and around New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Bid to Recapture the Sleight of Hand
text: IN the end, it was the T-shirt that undid Agnès B., probably. You know the one. Basic white, with the company’s cursive logo in the middle — simple enough to become a visual cliché, a faux-sophisticate brand reduced to a cheap graphic. It was the type of shirt you might see worn by the anonymous floor sweepers at any high-end salon, hoping to one day get a crack at the balayage brush.

headline: Old-School Interactive Books
text: Once upon a pre-e time, the term “interactive book” had an entirely different, unplugged meaning. Dating back at least to the publication of “Pat the Bunny” in 1940, interactive books were ones that encouraged children to open flaps and feel their pages. Read aloud, they elicited call-and-response shouts and audience elaboration. They demanded to be something more than just read.

headline: Finding a Life’s Story in Objects
text: “L’AMOUR Fou,” a new documentary about the venerated (and already well-documented) fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, opens with a scene at a press conference in 2002 when he announced his retirement, which is followed by a scene of his funeral in 2008. Then the camera moves to Saint Laurent’s fabulous apartment on the Rue de Babylone, where all of his possessions are being packed up and prepared for auction.

headline: A Do-It-Yourself Rental in Hollywood
text: THE lead paint from the beams on her apartment’s ceiling sheds gently and constantly, which is why Cynthia Loebe likes to say that when she sleeps with her mouth open, she’s always tasting history.

headline: Remaking a Studio Apartment at the Villa Carlotta
text: A renter with a talent for D.I.Y. projects aggressively redecorated her studio in an old Hollywood building.

headline: Matter Over Mind
text: Over the next few weeks, this blog may have a distinct Harvard bias. This is not only because I am kissing up to the alpha school, but recently I had a fantastic visit to the Harvard Decision Science Lab, run by Jennifer Lerner, and I got to meet several of the researchers there.

headline: Real-Life Lessons in the Delicate Art of Setting Prices
text: Setting prices can be tricky for a small business. If prices are too high, it is usually obvious, and there is an easy solution. But if they are too low, things can get complicated. That is because many business owners find it difficult to raise prices — even if they know they are losing money on every sale.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for April 21
text: A look for those unafraid to wear fluorescent green or acid yellow; a company that makes bondage accessories goes mainstream; and other items.

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Raise Prices?
text: As today’s small-business guide to pricing makes clear, a lot of small-business owners are reluctant to raise prices — sometimes even when they are losing money on every sale. Naomi Poe, who founded Better Batter Gluten Free Flour, initially priced her product to compete with nongluten-free competitors even though her costs were higher than theirs. Eventually, she decided to increase her prices and found her customers were encouraging.

headline: Despite Lower Sales, Musicians Earn New Highs
text: For the most part declining album sales are bad news for the music industry. But there’s one way in which they can benefit musicians: with everybody selling fewer records, it can be easier for an artist to climb higher than ever on the charts.

headline: Airport Screeners Need Runoff to Pick a Union
text: In the largest unionization vote involving federal employees, the nation’s airport screeners voted in favor of unionizing, but federal officials said on Wednesday that there would be a runoff because neither union on the ballot received a majority of the votes cast.

headline: Move Over, State Fish, to Make Room for a State Dog

headline: 3G Apple iOS Devices Are Storing Users’ Location Data

headline: Chris Hondros, at Work in Libya
text: Chris Hondros of Getty Images died in Misurata, Libya, on Wednesday after an attack that killed Tim Hetherington and injured Guy Martin and Michael Christopher Brown. These pictures, taken earlier in the day, show why Mr. Hondros earned the respect of his colleagues for combat images that were gripping and intimate, but not at all melodramatic or forced. Mr. Hondros spoke with Lens in February about the dangers of conflict photography, after he was assaulted while covering the uprising in Egypt.

headline: A Bright Spring Trend Puts Tails Amid the Tresses
text: THE first time Stacey Gersten had feathers put in her hair — while vacationing in Austin, Tex., at the same kind of street-side stand from which you might buy homemade brownies — she panicked. “I thought they were so beautiful,” said Ms. Gersten, 27, a casting director who lives in New York. “Then I thought, ‘What am I going to do when they fall out?’ ”

headline: Dr. Dre Wins ‘Chronic’ Lawsuit
text: Dr. Dre has won a lawsuit against the owners of his former record label, Death Row, over the digital rights and royalties for his hit 1992 album “The Chronic.”

headline: Could the California Aqueduct Turn Into a Solar Farm?
text: In Wednesday’s Times, I wrote about start-up companies developing solar panel arrays that float on water. The companies see a potentially large market to generate electricity from building floating arrays for irrigation and mining ponds, hydroelectric reservoirs and canals.

headline: Obamas to Attend Shuttle Launch
text: 3:22 p.m. | Updated  President Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttle Endeavour, and perhaps join Representative Gabrielle Giffords if she is able to watch as her astronaut-husband, Mark E. Kelly, leads the mission into space, administration officials confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Ford Designer J Mays Shares First Impressions of Beetle
text: J Mays, Ford’s vice president of global design, chatted with the Wheels contributor Phil Patton on Monday night about the redesigned Volkswagen Beetle. Mr. Mays’ opinion is particularly notable, as the Oklahoma native designed (along with fellow Ford designer Freeman Thomas) the Volkswagen Concept One — that car that became the New Beetle — in the early ’90s while working at VW’s advanced design studios in Southern California.

headline: New Swiss Tax Rules Signal Big Changes for Private Banks
text: The Swiss have proposed new banking rules in an attempt to improve relations with their neighbors by making it harder for other Europeans to hide money from the tax collector back home.

headline: Transparent Photovoltaic Cells Turn Windows Into Solar Panels
text: A new class of transparent photovoltaic cells has been developed that can turn an ordinary windowpane into a solar panel without impeding the passage of visible light, scientists said Tuesday.

headline: Documentary Celebrates Olmsted, a Creator of Central Park
text: “Olmsted and America’s Urban Parks,” a documentary by Rebecca Messner about Frederick Law Olmsted, the creator of Central Park and Prospect Park, is being broadcast Wednesday on PBS. (In New York, WNET-TV will carry it at 10 p.m.) In his review, Neil Genzingler says the film “helps you appreciate just how visionary Olmsted and his undercredited partner in Central Park and other projects, Calvert Vaux, were at a time when the idea that cities need parks was not firmly established.”

headline: Still Time to Buy ‘The Clock’ for the Right Price
text: People waited for hours in frigid temperatures to see it; now museums are jockeying to buy it. It is Christian Marclay’s video artwork “The Clock,” which features 24 hours of film and television clips woven together to reference, often with a shot of a watch or a clock face, a fictional moment in time that corresponds to the actual minute of the day in which the viewer is watching the work.

headline: War in Libya Could Drag On, Military Analysts Say

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Earth Day is Friday, and the theme this year is “Billion Acts of Green.” A few ideas from the beauty industry:

headline: College-Bound and Living With Autism
text: Several readers of the Consults blog recently had questions about the long-term course of autism, including succeeding in college and beyond. Our experts Dr. Fred Volkmar of the Yale Child Study Center and Dr. Lisa Wiesner, co-authors of “A Practical Guide to Autism,”  respond. For more on this and other topics, see their earlier responses in “Ask the Experts About Autism,” and The Times Health Guide: Autism. The authors also teach a free online course on autism at Yale University, which is also available at iTunesU and on YouTube.

headline: A New School Professor in Search of a Class
text: Fabio Parasecoli stood on the edge of Union Square Park Wednesday morning, a sheaf of printed notes in his hand. Associates held up signs and tried to recruit anyone who would listen.

headline: Museums Are Finding Room for Couturiers
text: ON a damp evening in late March, at the opening night of the “Balenciaga and Spain” exhibition at the de Young Museum in San Francisco, Dede Wilsey, the philanthropist and president of the museum’s board, was standing by the front door wearing a white satin and black lace dress by Oscar de la Renta. (The show, which began at the Queen Sofía Spanish Institute in New York, was conceived by Mr. de la Renta.) Mrs. Wilsey has given millions of dollars to help rebuild the de Young, and the diamond drop earrings and matching necklace that cascaded into her bodice seemed to make it clear that this had not been a hardship.

headline: After Two Decades, Savoy to Close
text: Savoy, a restaurant mainstay of the SoHo neighborhood for more than 20 years, will close on Saturday, June 18. Peter Hoffman, the chef and an owner, gave the news to the restaurant’s employees in a meeting on Wednesday afternoon. The space will remain shuttered for the bulk of the summer, he said, then reopen in the fall with a new concept and a new name, as yet undecided.

headline: When Prabal Met Maggie
text: There’s no disputing the socialite bona fides of Maggie Betts, the daughter of the film producer and Chelsea Piers developer Roland Betts and a fixture of Gotham’s party scene. But Betts, a 36-year-old Princeton graduate, is also a passionate advocate for AIDS awareness in Africa who has spent long periods on the continent bearing witness to the epidemic. Her first film, “The Carrier,” which premieres Thursday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, is the culmination of five years of research. The documentary tells the story of a Zambian woman, Mutinta Mweemba, who tries desperately not to pass on her HIV infection to her unborn child. Here, Betts is interviewed by the designer Prabal Gurung, her good friend and the recently appointed Goodwill Ambassador for the nonprofit group Maiti Nepal.

headline: A Party for, by and About Art
text: SMALL talk at parties is an art form all its own. But what to talk about if the party is for art?

headline: Scene City: A Party for Bomb Magazine
text: Insiders mix and mingle to celebrate 30 years of Bomb magazine.

headline: The Baby Next Door
text: Adding a newborn to your life changes everything. Your predictable schedule is upended. Your sleep is regularly interrupted. Your quiet home isn’t anymore.

headline: Audience Up, ‘Idol’ Defies TV Gravity
text: LOS ANGELES — When the 10th season of “American Idol” — the first without Simon Cowell — started on Fox three months ago, the handicappers guessed that its ratings would decline 15 to 20 percent, irreversibly tarnishing the top show on television.

headline: Apple Lifted by Verizon iPhone Deal and Updates of iPad and MacBook
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s winning streak extended through another quarter as a new partnership with Verizon for the iPhone — along with updated products like the iPad and MacBook — sent consumers on a shopping spree, the company reported Wednesday.

headline: Papa Doesn’t Preach
text: Does Mario Cuomo have good ideas? I don’t care how old he is. Bring on the smart, reasonable adults, no matter what their age. We have some math problems to solve here.

headline: The Girl With Unexplained Hair Loss
text: An interesting discussion, but this type of article only feeds our obsession with esoteric and unusual conditions. Medical journals and popular TV shows are full of these types of examples. There’s a common saying: When you hear hoof beats, think horses, not zebras. Unfortunately, doctors and the lay public are automatically thinking zebras as a first reaction. What’s the worst-case scenario? What test can we order to rule out a tumor, growth or genetic mutation? It’s a sad state of affairs when we can’t even manage the most basic medical conditions properly, while glorifying rare and unusual conditions.

headline: A Complex Jazzman, Informed by His Classical Side
text: Steve Lehman, a quietly dazzling saxophonist, is the stylistic progeny of at least two imposing modern-jazz masters, Anthony Braxton and Jackie McLean. In a string of potent albums he has shown a proclivity for intense improvisation, a taste for rhythmic entanglements with pianists and drummers, and a penchant for surrounding himself with like-minded performers. So the music Mr. Lehman makes must be jazz, right?

headline: Twelve Polished Chapters Stacked Neatly on His Desk
text: This sort of nonreview review, written in a fittingly self-conscious style that kind of recalls David Foster Wallace is, I think, the best thing I’ve read yet about “The Pale King,” and I’ve read everything I can find. Kudos to Sam Anderson for exploring so thoroughly the challenges when reviewing an unfinished work.

headline: The G.O.P. ’s Dukakis Problem
text: This essay manages to be snarky, insipid and stultifying all at once. The issue is not whether a politician is — in Jonathan Chait’s erudite parlance — a dweeb. The issue is whether the politician maintains a view of American governance that enhances and protects people in this country and globally. My neighbor was a student of Mike Dukakis and notes that he was thoughtful, humane and diligent. If the media would better help voters assess the content of a political hopeful’s message, the coolness of the politician might recede to its proper place.

headline: Former One-Hit Wonder Shows His Staying Power
text: Clint Holmes is an entertainer determined to give the proverbial 150 percent. Or is it a thousand? You get the idea. To the uninitiated, he is an obscure one-hit wonder whose identifying song, “Playground in My Mind,” rose in 1973 to No. 2 on the charts, where he said it got stuck between Paul McCartney’s “My Love” (No. 1) and Elton John’s “Daniel” (No. 3). But under the aegis of Steve Wynn, Mr. Holmes, now 64, has become a major Las Vegas attraction who might be described as the next generation’s Wayne Newton.

headline: King of Front-Wheel Drive and Back-Seat Romps
text: Like Rob Lowe before he materialized on “The West Wing” more than a decade ago, Jason Priestley has seemed to be the kind of fine-vintage pretty boy who might be ripe for resurrection. His era was the ’90s, when he reigned among the troubled affluent on “Beverly Hills 90210.” Since the 2000 conclusion of that series, in which he played the upright and pompadour-possessing Brandon Walsh, Mr. Priestley has made minor appearances on television — as a guest star on NBC’s “My Name Is Earl,” as a principal on the short-lived ABC series “Scoundrels” and Lifetime’s “Side Order of Life” — but he has been given nothing comparable to the vehicle he now has in the comedy “Call Me Fitz.”

headline: Reformed School
text: How many of us would like to change places with Ramón González? Very few, if any, I suspect. Yet, we keep blaming the teachers (and the administrators) for school failure. The real answer is student failure, not teacher failure, and most likely it is brought on by economics, parents and, mostly, peer pressure. Success begins at home.

headline: Baseball Taking Control of Dodgers’ Operations
text: Commissioner Bud Selig said Wednesday that he would appoint someone within days to oversee all operations of the Los Angeles Dodgers because of his “deep concerns” about the state of the troubled marquee franchise, which is owned by Frank McCourt.
