text: Many deals disappoint the purists because someone erred. The diagramed deal is no exception, but it does feature an unusual ending.

headline: In Latvia, a Sleek House Breaks With Tradition
text: RIGA, Latvia — Vita Gaisma grew up in a nondescript Communist-era apartment in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, sharing its one bedroom with her younger brother while her parents slept on couches in the living room. She dreamed of having a space of her own one day.

headline: Riding China’s Growth to Deals Elsewhere
text: Guo Guangchang, one of the most prominent investors in China, is betting big on the fast-growing domestic market.

headline: Floating Along on the Rhythm While Staying Anchored to the Beat
text: The guitarist Bill Frisell receives due credit for many things — his fluidity, his whimsy, his sly mastery of timbre and color — but probably not enough for his rhythm. He’s complicit in the underestimation, if we can call it that. Like a lot of introverts drawn to improvisation he creates a feeling of floating time, phrasing behind or around the beat. He doesn’t come at you with a barrage. He doesn’t make you think of a grid.

headline: Labor Board Tells Boeing New Factory Breaks Law
text: In what may be the strongest signal yet of the new pro-labor orientation of the National Labor Relations Board under President Obama, the agency filed a complaint Wednesday seeking to force Boeing to bring an airplane production line back to its unionized facilities in Washington State instead of moving the work to a nonunion plant in South Carolina.

headline: Yin, Meet Yang: Porsche Panamera Turbo S and S Hybrid
text: Shown on Wednesday: 2012 Porsche Panamera Turbo S and Panamera S Hybrid.

headline: Vibrators Carry the Conversation
text: TOOTHPASTE? Check. Tampons? Check. Vibrator? Check!

headline: Manchester United Tops Forbes List
text: For the seventh consecutive year,  Manchester United is No. 1 on the Forbes list ranking the most valuable soccer teams, with a value of $1.86 billion.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month’s crop of new books seems to confirm that April is the cruelest month. One woman sums up the path of aging as “maiden, mother, crone.” A girl eyes her mother’s bras with a feeling of doom. Also on tap: adultery, murder, incest and spying on people you love.

headline: Invitation to Israeli Leader Puts Obama on the Spot
text: WASHINGTON — A Republican invitation for Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress next month is highlighting the tensions between President Obama and Mr. Netanyahu and has kicked off a bizarre diplomatic race over who will be the first to lay out a new proposal to reopen the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: New York Auto Show
text: Jerry Garrett tours the auto show floor to examine if the auto industry's luxury represents real recovery or just a false start.

headline: A Touch of Bold for the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu
text: Shown on Wednesday: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu.

headline: Parnell to Go on Disabled List With Numbness in Finger
text: Bobby Parnell, a right-handed reliever for the Mets, was told by doctors Wednesday that he might have a blood clot in his right middle finger, an early diagnosis based on the numbness he has been experiencing.

headline: A Jewel of a Spring Festival, Not Selling Out, but Still Sparkling
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — The venerable Lucerne Festival, which originated in a 1938 concert conducted by Arturo Toscanini on the grounds of the villa in nearby Tribschen once occupied by Richard Wagner and his family, is nowadays fond of snappy themes. The festival this summer — opening on Aug. 10 and running six weeks with, as usual, the conductor Claudio Abbado and the composer Pierre Boulez as mainstays — is called “Night,” and you can probably fill in some of the repertory.

headline: The Dress, the Ring, the In-Laws: Navigating the Royal Wedding
text: Rumor has it that a big wedding ceremony is approaching soon.

headline: Stoudemire Is Expected to Play Friday; Billups Is Questionable
text: Medical tests revealed no new concerns for either Amar’e Stoudemire or Chauncey Billups on Wednesday, and their status for Game 3 of the Knicks’ first-round playoff series against the Boston Celtics remains largely unchanged.

headline: TimesCast | A Complicated Role for Italy
text: April 20, 2011 - Italy's long relationship and alliance with Libya complicates its role in NATO's mission.

headline: Illustrating Your Life in Graphs and Charts
text: About five years ago, Nicholas Felton had a cute idea: to create an annual report of his life filled with charts and graphs about the restaurants he had visited and the days he had traveled — just like the annual reports sent out by companies, but with personal details.

headline: Shooting with the Fujifilm X100
text: A look at how the FujiFilm X100 performs.

headline: Patients Are Not Consumers
text: I keep encountering discussions of health economics in which patients are referred to as “consumers”, after which the usual mantra of freedom of choice is invoked on behalf of voucherizing Medicare, or whatever.

headline: ‘Restrepo’ Director Is Killed in Libya
text: Tim Hetherington, a British photographer based in New York who was a director and producer of the film “Restrepo,” was killed in the besieged Libyan city of Misurata on Wednesday, our Times colleague C.J. Chivers reports. Three photographers were wounded in the same attack, and one of them, Chris Hondros of Getty Images, died.

headline: Bachmann Says It’s Time to Move Past ‘Birther’ Debate
text: Representative Michele Bachmann said in a television interview that she believes the conspiracy theories and questions surrounding the validity of President Obama’s birth certificate have been settled and declared that it was time to move onto real problems facing the country.

headline: Niederauer Talks Strategy
text: Duncan Niederauer, chief executive of NYSE Euronext, discusses pending merger bids with rival exchanges, saying his exchange’s strategy is best served by joining with Deutsche Börse.

headline: Thrills, Chills, Roller Coasters? Bloomberg Will Pass
text: It was not Edvard Munch’s “Scream.” It was not Michael Jackson’s “Scream.” And it was not even Howard Dean’s infamous Iowa scream.

headline: Parting Glance: Tim Hetherington
text: To call Tim Hetherington a great photographer would be a mistake. That’s not how he saw it.

headline: TimesCast | Warnings Written in Stone
text: Stone tablets along the coast of Japan, some more than six centuries old, are inscribed with warnings about tsunamis.

headline: Last of the German Big Blocks
text: It’s hard to argue against Mercedes’ new 5.5-liter, bi-turbo V-8, the new engine of choice for Mercedes’ souped-up AMG division. With far more torque than its predecessor — a natural-breathing, 6.2-liter V-8 — and up to 25 percent better fuel economy, the engine is helping AMG avoid gas-guzzler taxes that saddled Mercedes with the industry’s nastiest fines for failing to meet federal mileage standards.

headline: Boudreau’s Accusations Dominate Pregame Talk
text: The main topic of conversation going into Game 4 of the Rangers-Capitals series at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night was the perceived targeting of the head of Mike Green, the Washington defenseman who missed the last 20 games of the regular season with a concussion.

headline: How Healthy Are Our Fisheries?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Kitchen Sinks. Well, Part of It.
text: The Web developer Tim Thaler bought his home in Minneapolis five years ago. He’s hated it from Day 1.

headline: Tribeca Q. & A.: Maggie Betts
text: The director Maggie Betts discusses "The Carrier," a documentary about an H.I.V.-positive Zambian woman trying to care for her child that will show at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Jaguar and Land Rover Bring Their Finest Hides and Horsepower to Javits
text: If a sucker is born every minute, it should take just under an hour to sell out the mere 50 copies of the Land Rover Range Rover Autobiography Ultimate Edition coming to America.

headline: Q. and A. With Chad Spann, Underrated RB Prospect
text: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis.

headline: A Surge in Gold Nears a Limit
text: Worried about the euro zone? Buy gold. Worried about the federal deficit? Buy gold. Fancy a quick speculative bet? Well, you can’t lose with gold or silver, which has almost tripled in price in just over six months. But precious metals can’t be both havens and speculative plays.

headline: Mason Rudolph, Consistent Contender on PGA Tour, Dies at 76
text: Mason Rudolph, a golfer who surged to prominence as a youthful amateur, became rookie of the year on the PGA circuit, then settled into a rock-solid 23-year PGA career, winning five tournaments and almost never missing the cut or hitting a ball out of bounds, died Monday in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 76.

headline: Look at Me, I’m Crying
text: I’ve done it on the subway and at the Museum of Modern Art, in Prospect Park, Tompkins Square Park and leaning against the locked gate of Gramercy Park.

headline: Coming a Long Way and Still Sounding Very Familiar
text: In the mid-1980s Big Audio Dynamite latched onto good ideas early. From its home in London, where its leader, Mick Jones, had been a punk-rock pioneer with the Clash in the 1970s, Big Audio Dynamite checked out club music from across the Atlantic: South Bronx hip-hop, Jamaican dub reggae, Detroit techno, Chicago house. It mingled drum machines and rock guitar, adding synthesizers and samples, with Mr. Jones singing and Don Letts sometimes rapping or toasting, Jamaican-style. Their fractured lyrics took up politics, music, multiculturalism and self-affirmation. If the term hipster had been tossed around the way it is now, Big Audio Dynamite would easily have qualified.

headline: Details Emerge of an Orchestra’s Bankruptcy Plea
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra is blaming the high cost of rent at its home, the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, for at least some of its financial nightmare, along with the money-losing concerts of Peter Nero and the Philly Pops, high labor costs and withering donations.

headline: National Latino Museum Plan Faces Fight
text: Seven years after opening its National Museum of the American Indian, and four years before the scheduled unveiling of its museum of African-American history, the Smithsonian Institution is being urged to create another ethnic museum on the National Mall, this one to recognize the history and contributions of Latino Americans.

headline: Prisoner Pat-Downs
text: To the Editor:

headline: College Admissions
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Crash, Sanitation Driver Faces D.U.I. Charge
text: The driver of a New York City Sanitation truck was arrested and charged with driving that truck while intoxicated early Tuesday evening, the police said.

headline: For Threats of Terrorism, Two Words Will Warn
text: The government’s five-color scheme for terrorism alerts has been reduced to two warnings: elevated and imminent.

headline: Taliban Fan Fears of Infiltration in Afghan Forces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the early afternoon of Nov. 29 at an outpost high in the mountains along the Pakistan border, an Afghan border policeman well thought of by his superiors suddenly opened fire on American soldiers, killing six.

headline: Jerry Zaks on Directing 'Sister Act'
text: The director Jerry Zaks narrates a look at the musical number "Raise Your Voice" from the new musical "Sister Act," at the Broadway Theater.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,438 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Police Discover Bombs Mailed to Scottish Coach and 2 Fans
text: LONDON — The police in Glasgow have revealed that several parcel bombs were sent to the coach of the Celtic soccer team and two of its prominent supporters over six weeks.

headline: Election Financing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Youth, Mobility and Poverty Help Drive Cellphone-Only Status
text: WASHINGTON — It’s not quite the stuff of bragging rights, but Arkansas and Mississippi find themselves at the top of a new state ranking: They have the highest concentrations of people in the nation who have abandoned landlines in favor of cellular phones.

headline: Sentencing Juveniles
text: Number of juveniles serving life in prison without parole.

headline: A Buoyant Milan: New Designs From the Furniture Fair
text: Highlights from the International Furniture Fair in Milan.

headline: For Young Hopefuls, Milan Offers a Place to Break In
text: MILAN

headline: Cautious Hope and Nostalgia at the Milan Furniture Fair
text: MILAN

headline: Mubarak Leaves an Air of Wistfulness
text: CAIRO — Hosni Mubarak is the only leader most Egyptians have ever really known, so while he remains disliked for how he ran the country, there is an undercurrent of discomfort here with how he has been treated since being forced from power.

headline: Rangers Fans Had Something to Prove
text: It was time to don the hard hats and the attitudes and go out and muck in the corners. And that was just the paying customers.

headline: Virginia: Court Upholds Ruling for Ex-Sailor
text: A federal appeals court upheld a ruling overturning the conviction of Derek Tice, 41, one of the “Norfolk Four,” former sailors convicted of rape and murder, who received conditional pardons in 2009. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., affirmed a lower court ruling that Mr. Tice’s right to counsel had been violated. The ruling releases him from probation and from his status on a state sex-offender list, a spokesman for his lawyer said. The other three men were not part of the ruling.

headline: European Union’s Budget Proposal Stokes Anger
text: BRUSSELS — A call by the European Commission on Wednesday for a bigger budget for 2012 set off furious criticism from ministers and lawmakers, who said radical belt-tightening was needed to overcome the European Union’s debt crisis.

headline: Abbott Miller’s New Wallpaper Line, Inspired by an Ink Drop
text: All three patterns in Ink, a line of wallpaper by Abbott Miller, began with a drop of India ink on white paper. It was something of an act of rebellion for Mr. Miller, a partner at the graphic design firm Pentagram.

headline: Sales on Tables, Rugs and Glassware
text: Floor samples of furniture made from reclaimed bowling lane wood are up to 50 percent off during the CounterEvolution Earth Day showroom sale, through April 24 (a Lilly End Table, originally $1,195, is $750; the Kingpin Bar-N-Counter, regularly $3,995, is $2,495); 10 Jay Street (John Street), Suite 610, Brooklyn, (718) 243-2399 or counterev.com.

headline: Sam Ostroff on Making Steel Sculptures for the Home
text: Sam Ostroff, a sculptor and designer of custom steel gates, doors and staircases, is a steadfast romantic who could not care less about trends. His seven-foot stainless steel doors and gates, with their playful, vaguely Art Nouveau swirls and scrolls, look like something one might see at the Père Lachaise Métro station in Paris, not in 21st-century America.

headline: Working With Wood
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Floating Coat Rack
text: Most coat stands sit on the floor, but the Pox coat rack by Laz Ojalde, a Miami product designer, hangs from the ceiling, so it looks like it’s floating.

headline: Bouquets Delivered Regularly, No Reminders Needed
text: Last week, a friend turned us on to a newish flower delivery service, H. Bloom. Open about a year, and serving Manhattan, Jersey City, Hoboken and parts of Brooklyn, for now, as well as Washington, H. Bloom follows the fruit-of-the-month-club model, delivering fresh flowers on a weekly, biweekly or monthly schedule for a range of fees, starting at about $30 for a bunch of loose blooms.

headline: Indian Point Memories
text: To the Editor:

headline: Diller Scofidio & Renfro and Droog Team Up for a One-Day Event
text: New Yorkers are accustomed to having access to a wide range of personal services like food delivery and dog walking. On Saturday, the architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro and the Dutch design group Droog are holding an event to explore creative ways of bringing more of such services to the suburbs, through home-based businesses.

headline: Illustrations From ‘Wicked Bugs’
text: Briony Morrow-Cribbs’s drawings from the new book by Amy Stewart.

headline: Dog Massage? Isn’t Petting Enough?
text: RENEE LANE’S living room had been transformed into a spa. Candles twinkled on the coffee table; lavender oil scented the air; lilting guitar music played softly on the stereo. Grace, Ms. Lane’s 2-year-old caramel-colored toy poodle, leaped onto the sofa and, in response to Ms. Lane’s cooing invitation (“Want to lay down for Mama?”), got into position for her evening massage.

headline: Treating Spot to a Deep-Tissue Massage
text: Some believe that pet massage has the same benefits as human massage: increased circulation, stress relief and comfort at the end of life.

headline: Stink Bugs: It Could Be Worse
text: WHAT could be worse than stink bugs eating all your tomatoes this summer?

headline: Missing in Action
text: By this time a year ago, Justice John Paul Stevens had announced his intention to retire from the Supreme Court. A year earlier, Justice David H. Souter’s retirement announcement was just days away. Those galvanizing mid-spring developments dominated thoughts about the future of the federal judiciary for two successive years.

headline: Black Eyed Peas and Beetles, Together Onstage
text: Along with will.i.am, Fergie and the rest of the Black Eyed Peas, images of Volkswagens flashed across the stage on Monday night at a concert to promote the 21st-century update on the Beetle. But despite the vehicular backdrop and the two new Beetles that stood sentry at Terminal 5, the site of the concert, asking the Peas their thoughts on Beetles — the subject of the event — was apparently not allowed.

headline: Knicks-Celtics a First-Rate Drama, With Second-Guesses
text: The Knicks’ first postseason adventure in seven years has produced powerful doses of exhilaration and anguish, surprises and second-guessing, a bit of artistry and more Jared Jeffries than anyone dared imagine.

headline: In Spain, Women Find a Place in the Procession
text: Seville’s processions of hooded penitents have put the Andalusian capital at the center stage of Catholic celebrations. And this year, the oldest of its brotherhoods is allowing women to join in the march for the first time.

headline: Prosecutors Cite Tapes of Galleon Chief as ‘Devastating’ Proof of Guilt
text: Brendan Mcdermid/ReutersRaj Rajaratnam is accused of making $54 million from illicit trades.

headline: Celtics’ Rivers Is Hoping for Better Play From Bench
text: BOSTON — After only two games, Celtics Coach Doc Rivers would need a couple of legal pads to compile a to-do list for his players as the playoff series with the Knicks shifts to New York. Near the top of any such list would be the play of his bench. It has been borderline bearable in the two games, which the Celtics won.

headline: Slumping Gardner Gets the Night Off
text: TORONTO — When Brett Gardner was 23 and mired in a five-week slump to open the 2007 season at Class AA Trenton, drastic measures helped snap him out of it.

headline: After ‘Black Friday,’ American Poker Faces Cloudy Future
text: In 2003, ESPN significantly expanded its coverage of the World Series of Poker, which was eventually won by a 27-year-old Nashville accountant named Chris Moneymaker, an amateur who had qualified for the tournament on the Web site PokerStars.

headline: Widow of Bus Crash Victim Receives Visa for Funeral
text: In the days after a bus traveling from a Connecticut casino crashed last month in the Bronx, the bodies of 14 victims were laid to rest. But the body of the 15th and final victim, Wang Jianhua, has lain in a funeral home in Chinatown while his widow, in China, has sought permission to come to the United States for his funeral.

headline: Stumbling Into Bad Behavior
text: IT’S easy to look at big names like Warren E. Buffett, and big companies like Ernst and Young, and be judgmental. Of course they overlooked ethical lapses. Why wouldn’t they? That’s business.

headline: Rebels Attack Loyalists in Misurata
text: Rebel forces assaulted the downtown positions of troops loyal to Muammar el-Qaddafi in Misurata, Libya.

headline: N.F.L. Talks Are Stalled With Few Signs of Progress
text: After only four days of court-ordered talks, negotiations between N.F.L. owners and players came to a temporary halt Wednesday with little sign that much progress had been made toward resolving differences that have kept the league in a lockout since March 12.

headline: Beyond the Oil Spill, the Tragedy of an Ailing Gulf
text: NEW ORLEANS — The anniversary has passed, the cleanup goes on, and still southern Louisiana sinks steadily into the sea.

headline: Roommate Faces Hate-Crime Charges in Rutgers Case
text: A New Jersey grand jury on Wednesday indicted the roommate of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University freshman who killed himself in September, on hate-crime charges in using a webcam to stream Mr. Clementi’s romantic encounter with another man on the Internet in the days before the suicide.

headline: The New Anti-Abortion Math
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: Tracking File Found in iPhones
text: Apple faced questions on Wednesday about the security of its iPhone and iPad after a report that the devices regularly record their locations in a hidden file.

headline: Safety Board Plans Inquiry Into Flight of Mrs. Obama’s Plane
text: WASHINGTON — The National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday that it would investigate the episode Tuesday in which an Air Force plane carrying Michelle Obama came too close to a cargo plane.

headline: A Web Edge for Makers of Real Stuff
text: Plenty of people want to build a popular Web site and become the next Mark Zuckerberg. But some technology entrepreneurs have a more old-fashioned goal: they want to make something you can hold in your hand.

headline: SnackWell’s Nudges Up the Portion Pack
text: WHEN introduced in 1992, SnackWell’s, the Nabisco line of nonfat and low-fat snacks, sold so well that there were shortages, and early television commercials featured a frazzled grocer trying to restock the products as women pushing carts stampeded toward him.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 20, 2011

headline: ‘Three Cups of Tea,’ Spilled
text: One of the people I’ve enormously admired in recent years is Greg Mortenson. He’s a former mountain climber who, after a failed effort to climb the world’s second-highest mountain, K2, began building schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

headline: McDonald’s Makes Subtle Play for Children Online
text: McWorld, a Web site for children sponsored by McDonald’s, offers visitors the chance to create characters, decorate digital treehouses and go on a quest in a virtual world.

headline: Marketing to Children Online: What Do You Think?
text: Food companies try to reach children online with Web sites, virtual worlds and video games that may not, at first, appear to be advertising. Children who may think they are simply playing video games are in fact engaging with sophisticated commercials, a practice that is beginning to attract scrutiny from regulators. Matt Richtel has just written an article about the issues raised by these advertisements .

headline: State of Siege
text: On April 21, secessionist William B. Gulick, a clerk in the Interior Department, wrote North Carolina Gov. John W. Ellis to inform him about the precarious state of affairs in Washington. Gulick, who planned to resign his government post but remained in the city to serve the Confederacy, described an anxious Union capital, whose pro-Union citizens feared an attack at any moment, even as its secessionist residents spoke openly of welcoming a Southern assault.

headline: Online Playgrounds With a Message
text: In branded Web sites developed by food companies, entertainment and marketing overlap in ways that may confuse young players.

headline: In Online Games, a Path to Young Consumers
text: HESPERIA, Calif. — Deep into one of her favorite computer games, Lesly Lopez, 10, moves her mouse to click on a cartoon bee. She drags and drops it into an empty panel, creating her own comic strip.

headline: How Not to Plan for the Future
text: The agreement between Congress and the White House to virtually eliminate money for high-speed rail is harebrained. France, China, Brazil, even Russia, understand that high-speed rail is central to future development. Not Washington.

headline: Medical Experts Dispute a Hospital’s Claims on Heart Device Data
text: Several medical experts have disputed the basis for a Las Vegas hospital’s claim that patients benefited when cardiologists there switched to heart devices made by a company that paid it consulting fees, saying data to support that claim did not exist.

headline: Kindle Users to Be Able to Borrow Library E-Books
text: Library books are finally going to be compatible with the Kindle.

headline: A Village With the Numbers, Not the Image, of the Poorest Place
text: The poorest place in the United States is not a dusty Texas border town, a hollow in Appalachia, a remote Indian reservation or a blighted urban neighborhood. It has no slums or homeless people. No one who lives there is shabbily dressed or has to go hungry. Crime is virtually nonexistent.

headline: The Nation’s Poorest Place
text: Kiryas Joel, N.Y., has few outward signs of poverty but some of the lowest household incomes in the country.

headline: Concern Grows Over Window Blind Safety
text: On an idyllic August day in 2009, Kathleen Leeson took her children to church, fed them leftover pizza and planned to take them to the park.

headline: Wildlife at Risk Face Long Line at U.S. Agency
text: In February, the Obama administration declared the Pacific walrus to be at risk of extinction because its Arctic habitat was melting. But it declined to list the marine mammal as an endangered species, saying a backlog of other animals faced greater peril.

headline: M.T.A. Is Planning to Sell Its Midtown Headquarters
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has consolidated departments and reduced its payroll under severe financial pressure, now plans to sell its headquarters and two adjoining buildings on Madison Avenue in a deal that it says could reap more than $150 million.

headline: Ryan, Pushing Budget, Resists Talk of Higher Office
text: CLINTON, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan was deep into an explanation of his deficit reduction plan, which sits at the heart of a contentious debate between Republicans and President Obama, when he called on a constituent raising her hand in the front row of a town meeting here.

headline: Rolls-Royce Reaches for Pure Ecstasy
text: Shown on Wednesday: Rolls-Royce Spirit of Ecstasy Phantom.

headline: Obama, Before Facebook Crowd, Presses G.O.P. on Budget
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — President Obama on Wednesday opened a Western front in his war against House Republicans’ budget, telling an appreciative audience at Facebook headquarters here that the plan is radical, short-sighted and would reduce annual federal deficits at the expense of the nation’s poor and powerless.

headline: Thursday: Subject of Current Thinking
text: Administrivial Broken Comment Thingy Update: Through absolutely no fault of The New York Times, I promise, the independent, off-site servers that host the comment center have apparently gone on walkabout. Yes, there is a whole team working on finding them and we hope they will be back soon. Frankly, we miss them, and we want them to know that all is forgiven, and that if they go back to their proper place in the cloud, there will be absolutely no retribution or punishment, and that we didn’t even mean all the critical things we said to them.

headline: Actors Live Their Double Lives, Both on the Screen and Off
text: Actors never get much respect from scriptwriters. The thespian characters who flounce through classic comedies (“The Royal Family”) tend to be neurotic, self-dramatizing narcissists, while those who show up in darker fare are often neurotic, self-dramatizing narcissists with homicidal streaks (the film “A Double Life,” all those bio-dramas about John Wilkes Booth).

headline: Different Church, More Sequins
text: When the wimples start quivering, the pinched mouths break into sunbeam smiles, and the nuns start rocking to raise the Gothic rafters, all’s right in the kingdom of musical comedy at “Sister Act.” Who could resist the vision of a stage full of saintly sisters flaring their gams in unison like the Rockettes, or swiveling their hips, Supremes style, to the silken beat of an R&B tune? Presumably nobody in the audience at the Broadway Theater, where this latest stage adaptation of a hit movie opened on Wednesday night.

headline: ProCro, SoBro, FiDi, BoCoCa: A Lawmaker Says, ‘Enough’
text: Everyone knows that some of the best people-watching in New York City can be had in Hell’s Hundred Acres. Those on the hunt for a middle-class complex would be well advised to check out the Gas House District. Hankering for bagels and a schmear? Get thee to Bloomingdale, stat.

headline: No Indictment for Teacher Over Remark on Mass Shooting
text: A grand jury on Wednesday declined to indict a Brooklyn teacher who was arrested earlier this month after making a remark about carrying out a mass shooting at her school, her lawyer said.

headline: Raising Vegetables in an Edible Schoolyard
text: A green thumb is a vital attribute for David W. Daly, a vegetarian with a passion for sustainable agriculture and an appetite for nasturtiums. Mr. Daly, 27, has been the coordinator at the half-acre children’s garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden since July 2009, where he plays a kind of hybrid role as both teacher and farmer. He lives within biking distance in Crown Heights with his girlfriend, Penny Krakoff, a social worker.

headline: China’s Plan to Cut Taxes Puts Burden on Wealthy
text: BEIJING — China is considering an income tax cut, but its impact may be smaller than expected.

headline: For Madrid, Winning Ugly Is Still Winning
text: LONDON — Round 2 to Madrid. A fine headed goal just as midnight struck in Spain won the Copa del Rey, the King’s Cup, for Real Madrid against Barcelona.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will

headline: The Revolution’s Missing Peace
text: Ankara, Turkey

headline: Libyan Rebels’ Nonstandard Issue
text: Often outmatched, and always outgunned, in their fight against forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, many of the ragtag Libyan rebels carry old, homemade or modified munitions. Here is a small sampling.

headline: Inferior Arms Hobble Rebels in Libya War
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — A PKT machine gun, a weapon designed to be mounted on a Soviet tank and fired electronically by a crew member inside, has no manual trigger, no sights and no shoulder stock. That does not prevent many Libyan rebels from carrying it as if it were an infantryman’s gun.

headline: Latinos and Democrats Press Obama to Curb Deportations
text: With prospects for an immigration overhaul looking dim, President Obama is facing increasing pressure from Latinos, Democratic lawmakers and immigrant groups to use his executive powers to offer relief from deportation to broad groups of illegal immigrants.

headline: Time for Plan B
text: A 14-year effort to negotiate an international treaty banning the production of nuclear weapons fuel is getting nowhere. Under the terms of the United Nations’ Conference on Disarmament, all 65 participants must agree. Pakistan, which is racing to develop the world’s fifth largest arsenal, is refusing to let the talks move forward.

headline: Alfred Freedman, a Leader in Psychiatry, Dies at 94
text: Dr. Alfred M. Freedman, a psychiatrist and social reformer who led the American Psychiatric Association in 1973 when, overturning a century-old policy, it declared that homosexuality was not a mental illness, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 77 Cents on the Dollar Isn’t Fair
text: In a disappointing defeat for women, Senate Republicans worked overtime in December to ensure that a measure addressing gender-based wage discrimination never reached the Senate floor where it likely would have passed by a sizable majority. Fortunately, supporters of the Paycheck Fairness Act have not given up.

headline: Yankees’ Colon Throws Back Clock and Pushes Past Blue Jays

headline: A Good Law That’s Working
text: After years of overfishing, many fish populations have begun to recover. On Monday, Commerce Secretary Gary Locke announced that New England’s fishermen will be allowed to increase their catch of 11 commercially important fish stocks in Atlantic waters this summer.

headline: With Mail Bombs, Old Firm Rivalry Crosses the Line
text: In a season of unprecedented tension in Scottish soccer, the threshold of tolerance looks to have finally been crossed after the police intercepted nail bombs sent to Celtic Manager Neil Lennon.

headline: Parting Glance: Chris Hondros
text: Conjure a combat photographer in your mind’s eye — fatigues, a whiskey flask and a fondness for rude pastimes. Now discard the cliché and conjure Chris Hondros of Getty Images instead. A tweed blazer with elbow patches. A taste for martinis. A love of Mahler. And a passion for chess.

headline: Bloggingheads: Planned Parenthood War
text: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate the battle over Planned Parenthood.

headline: China: Documentary Film Festival Is Canceled
text: A prominent independent documentary film festival in China, scheduled this year for May, has been canceled because of the tense atmosphere created by the continuing government crackdown on freedom of speech. The English edition of Global Times, a populist newspaper, published an article on Wednesday about the cancellation in which it quoted Zhu Rikun, the festival’s art director, saying the organizers had decided to cancel it themselves. “The overall situation was tense, and we had received a lot of pressure,” Mr. Zhu said. “We worried that the films to be shown would meet some problems in this environment and decided to cancel it.” Another festival organizer, Li Shanshan, told Global Times that about 20 overseas guests, 10 directors and around 40 fans had registered to attend the festival. The cancellation of the festival, which is usually held every year in Songzhuang, on the outskirts of Beijing, was first announced Monday on the festival’s microblog on sina.com.

headline: Zimbabwe: Jailed Politician Is Released on Bail
text: Moses Mzila Ndlovu, co-minister of national healing and a leader of a faction of the Movement for Democratic Change, was released on $500 bail on Wednesday after five nights in jail. He was charged with attending a meeting that was held without police approval, a prayer service to commemorate the thousands of civilians killed by the North Korean-trained Fifth Brigade in the 1980s. His arrest has worsened relations in the power-sharing government that includes the M.D.C. parties and President Robert Mugabe’s ZANU-PF party. Since the M.D.C., the party founded to fight Mr. Mugabe’s rule, accepted the power-sharing arrangement in 2008, about 30 of its 109 members of Parliament have been arrested at one point or another, according to human rights lawyers and the M.D.C.

headline: Russia: Putin Boasts but Avoids a Burning Question
text: In his annual speech to Parliament on Wednesday, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia , left, detailed his achievements in three years in that office and predicted an era of steady prosperity while giving no insight into the burning question of what he would do at the end of his term next year. Speculation is rife in Russia over who between the country’s two leaders — Mr. Putin or his protégé, President Dmitri A. Medvedev — will run in presidential elections next year. In his speech, Mr. Putin said Russia had weathered the worst of the economic crisis and predicted that its economy could rank among the top five worldwide by the end of the decade.

headline: Duck, Duck, Anchovy
text: “You’ve got to try this.”

headline: BP Sues 3 Companies Over Oil Spill
text: BP has already paid billions of dollars in the massive Gulf of Mexico oil spill. On Wednesday, it filed court papers in hopes that those billions of dollars, and more to come, will not be paid out of its pockets alone.

headline: The Crash and Burn of an Autism Guru
text: As people streamed into Graceview Baptist Church in Tomball, Tex., early one Saturday morning in January, two armed guards stood prominently just inside the doorway of the sanctuary. Their eyes scanned the room and returned with some frequency to a man sitting near the aisle, whom they had been hired to protect.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Managing Your Online Image
text: How much personal information about you is available online? You might be surprised — and you might want at least some of it to disappear. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein chats with Riva Richmond, a technology writer and New York Times contributor, about how to fix (or kill) Web data about yourself. The process can be time-consuming, Ms. Richmond says; some people pay a company to clean up their image and monitor mentions of them. But, she notes, it’s not always possible to expunge information.

text: For Rangers fans, Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden started in a caldron of defiance. Soon it became a raucous celebration. It eventually turned anxious and, finally, ended in shocked silence.

Not so fast, says John Mighton, whose nonprofit organization, Jump Math, is the subject of a recent Times blog post about finding better ways to reach kids who think they aren’t — and never will be — good at anything involving numbers. Are you one of these so-called mathphobes? Or are you someone for whom this subject comes easy — or someone in between?

headline: Pakistan Top Court Upholds Acquittals in Notorious Rape Case

headline: The Early Word: And in This Corner….
text: In Today’s Times:— Again and again, Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, has said he’s not interested in challenging President Obama by seeking the Republican nomination for president. But Jeff Zeleny writes that Mr. Ryan’s unchanging answer doesn’t deter voters from pressing him to run as he crisscrosses the country to discuss his budget proposal, which is at the heart of a spending debate between Republicans and President Obama. As the author of the plan, Mr. Ryan has emerged as one of the president’s most visible Republican rivals in a budget fight that will help frame the nation’s politics for the next year and beyond.

headline: Film Festival Blends French and Hong Kong ‘Noir’
text: France and Hong Kong are both known for art-house films stuffed with sex, crime, violence and dark humor. These two cinema traditions come together in June for Noir, a retrospective of 27 films that is part of Le French May, a major annual cultural festival held in Hong Kong that runs this year through June 23.

headline: A Kid-Friendly iPad Case
text: Ugly but effective, The Big Grips Frame ($35, www.biggrips.com) tightly encapsulates your iPad in an inch-thick wrapper of squishy, high density foam, without blocking important ports, controls or sensors. For a preschooler, the frame makes the rather slippery iPad much more toy-like, especially when used with apps that demand shaking or tilting the screen.

headline: A Plan for Working on (Not in) the Business
text: Lots of business owners wish they could be less involved in the day-to-day operations of their businesses (see “It’s Never the Employee“). When you have 10 or even 20 employees, you can be intimately involved in all aspects of the business from sales to finance to operations to purchasing. But if you want the company to grow and perhaps get to that elusive “next level” everyone’s always talking about, you have to build an organization that can get the job done without you managing every detail.

headline: Tribeca Video Interview: Maggie Betts
text: The documentary film “The Carrier” follows a Zambian woman in a polygamous marriage who is pregnant and is H.I.V.-positive. The director Maggie Betts traces the woman’s struggle, examines her family life and highlights her efforts to prevent transmission of the virus to her child. In this video, Ms. Betts discusses her goals in making the film and talks about how an initiative like the prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) can make a difference in controlling the spread of H.I.V. in Zambia and throughout Africa.

headline: Remaking Alzheimer’s: A Few Questions
text: The newly revised criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, the first change since 1984 in how this dementia is diagnosed, are likely to be most valuable at first to scientists and researchers. The guidelines spring in part from novel research into biomarkers and imaging techniques that may not reach family medical practices for some time.

headline: Sporting Goods
text: Rendering gym bags nearly useless, many designers built athletic components into everyday sportswear this season, eliminating the need for a change of clothes come P.E. time. From a windbreaker snapped on with an aerodynamic hood (its reflective quality is also conducive to biking) to trousers cut with flexible, reinforced knees and brogues fit with a runner’s tread sole, these clothes are ready to embrace a sudden outburst of fitness. When worn, they’re added incentive to exercise more often.

headline: When Pushed, Automakers Can Deliver Cleaner Cars, Says Engineer
text: Jim Kliesch, a senior engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group, pointed at the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu Eco, one of his favorite cars on the floor of the New York auto show. Like a surprising number of cars unveiled here this week, the Eco — with a mild hybrid system, direct injection and subtle efficiency tricks like active grille shutters — is expected to achieve nearly 40 miles a gallon on the highway when it reaches the public next year.

headline: Poetry Pairing | April 21, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: T in China | Art and Fashion in Beijing
text: Two of the best art shows in Beijing at the moment aren’t necessarily the newest. “The Unknown,” which opened April 1 (at the tail end of China Fashion Week) at the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, is the fashion photographer Peter Lindbergh’s first solo exhibition in China. “The Unknown” is not a Lindbergh retrospective,” says the museum’s director, Jerome Sans, “but a body of work specifically assembled to mark his first experience with China.” A gigantic remix without order or chronology, the installation is a visual journey through decades of the photographer’s career, including photos of supermodels like Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington and Linda Evangelista, most of which were commissioned for Italian Vogue by Franca Sozzani (who was present for the opening). Visitors enter the exhibition in a space surrounded by video images from Lindbergh’s recent cinematic series, “Invasion,” a film that depicts a crowd in slow motion moving into a cloud of smoke. Visitors to the exhibit suddenly realize they have become part of the silent choreography, as they watch their own shadows entering and exiting the images projected onto the walls.

headline: Blackstone Says Plain L.B.O.’s Are Too ‘Pricey’
text: While the Blackstone Group reported its best quarterly earnings since going public in 2007, the investment firm’s big gains came once again from its big real estate division.

headline: Quake and Fuel Expense Cut Into Carriers’ Revenue
text: The first quarter is always weak one for airlines, as travel drops with the start of the new year. But this one was especially difficult, the airlines reported Thursday, as fuel prices spiked and Middle East unrest and the earthquake in Japan cut into demand for international flights.

headline: Mazda USA Design Boss Speaks Kodo, Not Nagare
text: Last time we talked to him, Derek Jenkins, head of Mazda’s advance design studio in Irvine, Calif., was talking about Nagare, the company’s design language based on the wave patterns of wind and water. Now Nagare is history, and the new word is Kodo.

headline: Soap Operas Are Not Dead
text: You just have to look for them in different places, like Major League Baseball. The news that the league has taken over operations of the Los Angeles Dodgers is the latest installment of a gloriously debauched family saga. For years, the big worry in baseball was that small-market teams would be squeezed out of the national pastime by the big-market gorillas. But look what’s happening: the big teams are imploding. Texas, New York and Los Angeles, each a tale of epic bungling and good ol’ hubris.

headline: Morgan Stanley Alters Deal With Mitsubishi
text: Moving to shed a huge drag on its earnings, Morgan Stanley has renegotiated its deal with the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the Japanese bank that provided a $9 billion lifeline during the financial crisis.

headline: Space Invaders
text: “Home Show, Revisited,” opening this month at the Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum in California, puts a new spin on the expression “mi casa, su casa.” Now in its third iteration, the site-specific exhibition pairs 10 Los Angeles artists with 9 area residences, inviting the artists to explore the notion of home. Some of the work, like the circular swimming pool that Piero Golia built in the yard of an updated Spanish-style gem or Jennifer West’s experimental surf films, which will screen at sundown at a Carpinteria surf shack, makes direct references to life in Southern California. Other installations play with personal space: the sculptor Ry Rocklen’s tiled floor piece speaks to the work of the mosaic artist who is hosting him, and Bettina Hubby (above) has created curtains — depicting her “living” inside a Montecito Tudor — that will hang outside the windows, “providing privacy for the owners but exposing me,” she says. For info on self-guided tours, go to sbcaf.org.

headline: From Ad Agency to Art and Design College

text: On Wednesday morning just outside the General Motors display at the Javits Center, a crew with the TLC cable show “Cake Boss” struggled to unload a 2,000-pound cake molded into the form of the Bumblebee Camaro from “Transformers: Dark of the Moon.” The third installment in the Transformers series opens on July 1.

headline: Delaware Law Gives NYSE an Edge in Battle With Nasdaq
text: In Wednesday’s Deal Professor column about the Nasdaq OMX-IntercontinentalExchange bid for NYSE Euronext, I discussed the antitrust risk of a Nasdaq/NYSE tie-up and the countervailing national interest, if any, in preventing a combination of NYSE and Deutsche Börse. Following up on that column, I want to highlight how the law provides a significant advantage to NYSE as long as it prefers a combination with Deutsche Börse.

headline: Jennifer Egan Discusses TV Plans for ‘A Visit From the Goon Squad’
text: Monday, you’d have to imagine, was a pretty exciting day for Jennifer Egan, when her novel “A Visit From the Goon Squad” won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. The rest of the week hasn’t been a letdown either: on Wednesday evening the agency International Creative Management, which represents Ms. Egan, said that the novel, a sprawling series of stories about interlocking characters connected to the San Francisco punk-rock scene, has been optioned by HBO, which plans to adapt it into a television series.

headline: For Dodgers Fans, Selig Offers Happy Talk
text: Very seldom does a statement from Bud Selig inspire joy. Many days, the best that baseball’s commissioner can shoot for is fans not rolling their eyes at the sound of his name. But when Selig announced on Wednesday that he was stepping in to stabilize the mess that is the Dodgers under the owner Frank McCourt, Dodgers fans had to squelch the urge to form a conga line through downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Kiss Recreates ‘Detroit Rock City’ at Mini Stand

The signed cars and other Kiss memorabilia will be auctioned for Unicef.

headline: Your iPhone Is Tracking You. So What?

headline: The Miracle Worker
text: Some people get ready for swimsuit season with Pilates. Others do it the old-fashioned way: by lying down on a comfy bed while a highly trained French aesthetician gives you a soothing “miracle” treatment that promises to ease away stress, fatigue and excess fat. The first venture below the décolletage for the celebrity facialist Isabelle Bellis involves a sophisticated Swiss machine (exclusive to Bellis in New York) that simulates cupping, an ancient Chinese technique that purportedly helps to rid the blood of toxins. “But there’s no bruising, like with traditional cupping,” Bellis says of the two-hour treatment called Bio Body Detox. “It’s ideal for people who feel sluggish, retain water or are prone to storing fat.” According to the soft-spoken Bellis, a Brittany native, clients notice increased suppleness and feel lighter after only one session ($310). Who needs bikini boot camp? Call (212) 966-3262 or go to isabellebellis.com.

headline: UnitedHealth Group Reports Strong Earnings
text: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest commercial health insurers, reported robust profits on Thursday. The company, which is the first of the major insurers to make public its quarterly earnings, is viewed as something of a bellwether for the rest of the industry.

headline: In Syria, Protesters and Government Mobilize for Friday
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria deployed police officers, soldiers and military vehicles in two of the country’s three largest cities on Thursday ahead of a call for nationwide protests that will test the popular reception of reforms decreed by President Bashar al-Assad as well as the momentum that organizers have sought to bring to a five-week uprising.

headline: Lyric Opera of Chicago Names New Director
text: The Lyric Opera of Chicago has named a new general director, Anthony Freud, who has been running the Houston Grand Opera for the past five years. Mr. Freud, 53, will take over in the fall for William Mason, 69, the general director since 1997, who said in July he would retire after this season. Mr. Freud, a onetime record company executive and former chairman of the jury for the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, ran the Welsh National Opera before coming to Houston in 2006. A Londoner, he has become a key insider in the American opera world and is chairman of the Opera America service organization. In Houston, he was credited with increasing attendance and fund-raising; overseeing premieres by Jake Heggie and André Previn; programming a survey of Benjamin Britten operas; and planning for the company’s first “Ring” cycle, which is scheduled for 2014.

headline: Valeant Pharmaceuticals Sets Deadline

headline: Injured Performer Heading Back to ‘Spider-Man’ Early
text: At first Christopher Tierney’s doctors said that he wouldn’t be able to rejoin the cast of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” until midsummer at the earliest, only after he had pins removed from his lower back and finished physical therapy to recover from a 30-foot fall off a platform during the musical’s Dec. 20 performance. Yet Mr. Tierney, who managed to be up and walking two weeks after sustaining four broken ribs and three fractured vertebrae, had the pins taken out two weeks ago and is healthy enough to return to rehearsals for “Spider-Man” on Monday, his father, Tim, said in an interview on Thursday.

headline: What Gary Taubes Eats
text: Gary Taubes, the author of last week’s cover story (“Is Sugar Toxic?”) as well as an anti-carb cover story from 2002 (“What If It’s All Been a Big Fat Lie?”) and the book “Why We Get Fat,” has plenty of critics. But no one could accuse him of failing to practice what he preaches. His is a steak-and-egg-heavy diet, without the pasta and potatoes. If you fear for his arteries, you can check out an analysis of his blood lipids posted on his blog. When I talked to Gary this morning, he was in Los Angeles, visiting family for spring break, and (in addition to answering hundreds of sugar-related e-mails) was preparing breakfast: scrambled eggs and bacon for his wife; scrambled eggs, bacon, Italian sausage and black coffee for himself; Cheerios, raisins and Italian sausage for the kids. He did cop to this rare, vacation-related indulgence: last night he ate a chocolate macaroon. It’s Passover, after all. He reports that it was delicious.

headline: Mitsubishi Announces Pricing of i Vehicle
text: The Mitsubishi i electric car, scheduled for delivery in January 2012, will carry an M.S.R.P. of $27,990. The E.V. is already on sale in some markets as the i-MiEV.

headline: Artistic Director of Seattle’s Troubled Intiman Theater Is Departing
text: Kate Whoriskey, picked by Bartlett Sher to succeed him as artistic director of Intiman Theater in Seattle, is parting ways with that beleaguered institution, at least for now. Faced with a cash crisis, the Intiman board voted last weekend to cancel the rest of the season, which started just last month, and to lay off the theater’s staff. While the board hopes to reopen Intiman next year, Ms. Whoriskey said in a telephone interview that she is returning this weekend to New York, where she has an apartment, and will resume her freelance directing career.

headline: Coffee Drama

headline: Locavore Lobby Snacks Don’t Wait for the Curtain
text: A SONGWRITER sips a latte while composing music on a laptop. His companion is so engrossed in a novel that her mouth is frozen midbite into an almond croissant. It sounds like a typical morning at Starbucks, but it’s actually a scene from the lobby of the Classic Stage Company, one of a handful of New York theaters that have discovered how concession stands can extend the life of their spaces beyond that night’s curtain to become community-building places where patrons are encouraged to sit awhile, often during the day.

headline: High Browse
text: Pick up a book about a young New York artist these days, and you’re likely to spot Brendan Dugan’s name in the fine print. As the founder of the graphics firm and indie publishing imprint An Art Service, Dugan has become a go-to designer for galleries like Gagosian and Hauser & Wirth, or for virtually anyone in Dan Colen’s crowd. Now he’s slowly making his presence known with Karma (21 Downing Street; open Thursday-Sunday from noon to 7 p.m. or by appointment), a tiny shop in the front of his office where he sells his own catalog of gritty pop-minimalist art books and posters alongside books and objects that inspire him. Dugan started the publishing arm of his business in 2009 as an additional platform for the artists whose Web sites, books and ephemera he was already designing. “Allan Kaprow, Ed Ruscha and a lot of the Fluxus artists were designing all these amazing objects to help support their projects,” he says. “I guess I think of us as trying to help continue that lineage.”

headline: Keith Richards’s Daughter Gets Community Service (and Hearts Her Sister)

headline: 36 Hours in Panama City, Panama
text: AT the crossroads of two oceans and two continents, Panama City is a dynamic metropolis. That’s never been truer than it is today. Everywhere in this steamy, tropical town are foreign investors talking shop in upscale cafes, expat fortune-seekers toasting their fates in wine bars, cranes stalking the rooftops of a skyline that seems to grow before your eyes and — on the downside — traffic that puts even the most congested American city to shame. Central America’s capital of international finance is in the midst of a prolonged boomtown fever. Right now, there are more than 30 skyscrapers under construction — among them the Trump Ocean Club and The Panamera, which will be Latin America’s first Waldorf-Astoria Hotel (both are set to open later this year). All of this building and hype has local residents calling Panama City the “Dubai of the Americas.” They’re only half-joking.

She was watching “Baby Face,” a delectably sordid 1933 studio film about an Übermensch in silk stockings played by Barbara Stanwyck, who climbs to the top one bed at a time.

headline: A Few Minutes With Marco Zanini
text: I sometimes think there’s a cult of Zanini — Marco Zanini, the creative director at Rochas. He is someone with a solid base of knowledge, a light hand with details and an ego that rarely intrudes. We first met in 2008, when he took over Halston. Hardly anyone knew him; he had been Donatella Versace’s assistant for many years. But Mr. Zanini brought a clean vitality to Halston, especially to the day clothes. That show remains a favorite of mine, and it was his only Halston collection because he and the owners parted ways within a few months. Then he got the gig at Rochas, and he’s taken a completely different approach with the sporty French label. Mr. Zanini was in New York recently and we chatted about the business, Dior’s next move — what everybody is talking about.

headline: Media’s Spotlight Shines Less Brightly on Palin
text: One of the few pieces of statistical evidence that we can look toward at this early stage of the presidential campaign is the number of media hits that each candidate is receiving. Apart from being interesting unto itself, it’s plausible that this metric has some predictive power. At this point in 2007, Barack Obama and John McCain were receiving the most coverage among the Democratic and Republican candidates respectively, and both won their races despite initially lagging in the polls.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: At first listen it can be hard to put your finger on what exactly Mucca Pazza is. A 30-member music ensemble from Chicago, it includes the usual brass and percussion, with what it calls its “freak” section — guitars, mandolins, violins and accordions amplified with speakers in the musicians’ helmets. The band’s name means “mad cow” in Italian and is what one member, Sharon Lanza, described as “silliness that stuck.” But don’t be fooled: these mad hatters with instruments deliver, banging out unique renditions of 20th-century music, television-show themes, car-alarm melodies and original tunes with skill and the help of a couple of cheerleaders. (Thursday, 7 p.m., $12; Santos Party House, 96 Lafayette Street, Lower Manhattan; 866-777-8932, santospartyhouse.com.)

headline: Oklahoma City Has Stars, and Depth
text: The Oklahoma City Thunder’s Game 2 performance was marked by a familiar dominance, albeit one achieved outside the Thunder’s typically effective formula. Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook took up their standard roles as offensive focal points, but the Thunder’s overall production was more balanced than usual; James Harden, Serge Ibaka, and Nick Collison were productive and efficient scorers, and though Durant and Westbrook both topped 20 points for the game, the balance of play efficiency within the Thunder offense had undergone a noticeable shift.

headline: Indoor Runs, as if You Were Out
text: AS a crazed working mom who needs regular exercise to stay sane, I find the treadmill a time-saving staple. It provides a cathartic, climate-controlled run supported by escapist Black Eyed Peas videos and E! reality television. Yet unsupervised treadmill running comes with a caveat: I am my own coach, so I run only hard enough to sweat and feel virtuous. But am I pushing myself?

headline: Uptown, a Jumble of Treasures
text: At the southeast entrance to Central Park stands a colorful, tubular structure resembling a swing-set frame designed by spiders on LSD. Touching ground at 10 points on the cobbled plaza, its red, green and black striped posts rise at different angles into an airy web more than 18 feet high at its tallest. A playful riff on the ancient form of the triumphal arch, “Empire,” by the Irish sculptor Eva Rothschild, may be viewed for the purposes at hand as a metaphorical gateway to the entertainingly illogical array of new and old artworks awaiting Midtown and Upper East Side gallery hoppers.

headline: SoHo, Steadfast Bastion for Alternative Works
text: SoHo was once the hub of the New York art world; now it’s a satellite, but a vital one: some of the city’s oldest alternative spaces are there, along with new ones, like Third Streaming. Several of these spaces, within blocks of one another on either side of Canal Street (those to the south are technically in TriBeCa), have impressive spring shows that keep a spirit of experimentation alive, and that are, by coincidence, thematically connected.

headline: The First Airing of Dirty Laundry
text: In 1973, when PBS broadcast “An American Family,” that documentary series about the Loud family of Santa Barbara, Calif., seemed like television engagé: a camera-armed rebellion against the scripted contrivances of canned and conventional television.

headline: Rising and Regrouping on Lower East Side
text: What a difference two years make. When The New York Times last surveyed Lower East Side galleries, in 2009, my fellow critic Ken Johnson observed that “the Lower East Side is not the new Chelsea and probably never will be.” He pointed to the lack of “big-box commercial vendors showing internationally acclaimed talents.”

headline: Bay Returns, Looking for Better Days
text: Jason Bay arrived at Citi Field on Thursday ready to play in his first game since July 25, but hoping he will not be the same player he was before a concussion sustained two days earlier ended his disappointing 2010 season.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for April 22-28
text: EARTH DAY AT THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN

headline: Tribeca’s Taste of All Things Grim and Gory
text: This year, as always, the Tribeca Film Festival is putting plenty of famous faces on display. Filmgoers can get early looks at movies starring Will Ferrell, Keira Knightley, Orlando Bloom, Don Cheadle, Vera Farmiga and Kathleen Turner, among many others.

headline: In a Slow Economy, Rentals Zoom
text: THE uncertain economy, combined with a depressed housing market and tight credit standards, has fostered an increase in residential leasing in Westchester and nearby counties — a trend so pronounced that at least one agency, Better Homes and Gardens Rand, recently introduced a rentals-only Web site for its clients.

headline: Obama Sets Up Team on Oil-Price Fraud
text: 7:41 p.m. | Updated President Obama sought again to show his concern for high gasoline prices, announcing on Thursday at a public event in Reno that the Justice Department is forming a team to investigate possible fraud in oil markets.

headline: Spare Times for April 22-28
text: Around Town

headline: Deep in the Past, a Link to Bind Us
text: JEFF and I met speed-dating at the gay and lesbian center in New York. Later I told him I was a little disappointed with our “how we met” story, as I had a vision of meeting my future partner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art over a painting or a dropped glove. But the reality was we met with numbers stuck to our chests while facing each other in metal chairs.

headline: First an Outcast, Then an Inspiration
text: IN the fall of 1932, fresh out of high school, Elizabeth Catlett showed up at the School of Fine and Applied Arts of the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh, having been awarded a prestigious full scholarship there. But she was turned away when it was discovered that she was “colored,” and she returned home to Washington to attend Howard University.

headline: Increased Security Seen in Videos From Syria
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, the Syrian government “deployed the police, soldiers and military vehicles in two of the country’s three largest cities Thursday ahead of a call for nationwide protests” on Friday. In phone calls on Thursday, residents of Damascus, the Syrian capital, and Homs, Syria’s third-largest city, described stepped-up security.

headline: On Not Doing Your Homework
text: Jonathan Chait is annoyed with Jacob Weisberg, who wrote a ludicrously adulatory column about Paul Ryan, then admitted that he was wrong — and in the process once again gave Ryan credit that isn’t due. Chait:

headline: Scavenger Hunt for Family Secrets Across Time and Geography
text: Denis Villeneuve’s “Incendies,” a film very much occupied with some of the grisly realities of recent history, nonetheless has the structure, and some of the atmosphere, of an ancient folk tale. It is a quest narrative, about children searching out the mysteries of their parentage, and also the story of a resourceful heroine, the mother of those children, surviving an almost unimaginable series of ordeals.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for April 22-28
text: Classical

headline: A Chinatown Fire, One Year Later
text: It was the city’s worst fire in years, an enormous blaze that raced through one century-old building in Chinatown and jumped to another and then another.

text: Art
