headline: More ‘Ask the Film Critics’
text: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. (In this week’s Arts and Leisure section, they talk about the importance of understanding cultural differences in reviewing movies, the beauty of character actors and the films of Michael Mann.) For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

headline: Libya Could Become Stalemate, Top U.S. Military Officer Says

headline: Her Decorators? Flotsam & Jetsam
text: DEBORAH LUTZ, an assistant professor of English with a passion for the Victorians, lived for a decade in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. And during those years she did something that the nature-loving Victorians would have understood.

headline: The Delectable Pairing of Bread and Soup
text: Many diners enjoy bread with their soup. But in the Mediterranean, it’s common to serve soups thickened with fresh or stale bread, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Ex-Workers Sue Restaurant; New Law Firm Is Formed

headline: Master Mind
text: David Lynch is best known as a director, but it was the paintings he made in Philadelphia as a young art student that gave him the idea to make his first film. The work he is showing nearly 50 years later at the William Griffin Gallery in Santa Monica, Calif., straddles both genres — illuminated light bulbs protrude from the canvases, and abstract figures dance across them. The installation includes eerie watercolors and a number of lamplike sculptures. Lynch’s proclivity for “shape and light” drew him to another project, Silencio, a nightclub set to open this summer at 142 rue Montmartre in Paris, for which he designed the interiors and the furniture. “I enjoy how architecture and design create mood,” he says. The club was named for the spooky theater in “Mulholland Drive,” so no telling what that mood will be.

headline: In a Data-Heavy Society, Being Defined by the Numbers
text: I HAVE a confession to make. I started using Twitter about six months ago and eagerly watched my “followers” rise — 20 to 30 to 40. I made it to 60 and suddenly plateaued — a few would follow and then (heartbreak) “unfollow.”

headline: A Life Digging for Veins of Gold

headline: Even Vampires Beat Paul Reiser
text: Going from seven to six contestants on Thursday, Fox’s “American Idol” remained as dominant as ever in the ratings with 19.6 million viewers tuning in to the results episode, which also featured a performance by Katy Perry and Kanye West. Twenty-one-year-old Stefano Langone, a soulful singer from Washington, was eliminated after he received the lowest share of 52 million votes cast by fans. According to Nielsen’s estimates, Fox easily won both the 8 p.m. time slot with “Idol” and the 9 p.m. hour with “Bones” (11.1 million). CBS ranked second for the night despite a lineup of repeats including “CSI” (8.4 million) and “The Mentalist” (11 million). NBC finished in third as its new sitcom “The Paul Reiser Show” struggled badly at 8:30 p.m., attracting just 2.5 million viewers and lagging behind even CW’s “Vampire Diaries” (2.7 million). NBC’s later comedies fared a bit better with “The Office” (6.8 million) leading the way for the network at 9 p.m. and “Parks and Recreation” earning 5.1 million viewers at 9:30. A special hourlong 100th episode of “30 Rock” averaged 4.6 million viewers at 10 p.m. ABC was fourth on the night with reruns.

headline: Senate Resignation May Not Halt Release of Evidence
text: WASHINGTON — Senator John Ensign’s resignation letter allows him to leave office just one day before he was to have to answer questions under oath about whether a $96,000 payment to the family of his former lover was illegal and designed to keep the affair from becoming public, according to people familiar with an investigation of Mr. Ensign’s activities.

headline: It’s Love at First Kill
text: THIS is a love story. It began on a hot summer night in Santa Barbara, Calif., when Tamara Langman helped kill the yellow-eyed demon known as Prince Malchezaar. She was logged into World of Warcraft, the multiplayer fantasy game, and her avatar — Arixi Fizzlebolt, a busty gnome with three blond pigtails — had also managed to pique the interest of John Bentley, a k a Weulfgar McDoal.

Carmakers floated burly S.U.V.’s just as consumers decided they wanted hybrids; hybrids arrived just as consumers decided it was safe to re-up with an S.U.V.

Mr. Hetherington, the conflict photographer and director of the Afghan war documentary “Restrepo,” and Mr. Hondros, one of the top war photographers of his generation, were killed Wednesday in Misurata, Libya.

headline: More About Disappearing Fish
text: In my column this week I wrote about the highly troubled state of our oceans – but of course there’s more to say. A new study by the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature), for example, suggests that over forty species of fish in the Mediterranean could disappear in the next few years.

headline: Vines Thrive Once Again in Moravia
text: “IN the Middle Ages, the water was unsafe to drink, so we Moravians drank wine,” said Petr Ocenasek, a wine merchant, as he sipped a sauvignon blanc from a long-stemmed tasting glass on the veranda of Vinny sklep u Hrdlicku, a hilltop restaurant and wine cellar in the Mikulov wine region of southern Moravia in the Czech Republic (Mala kozi, Mikulov; 420-777-021-681).

headline: Restaurant Review: Gigi, in Miami
text: Many restaurants are born when a chef has a concept. Gigi in Miami’s Wynwood district started with a concept in need of a chef. Last year, the restaurant’s owner, Amir Ben-Zion, placed an ad on Craigslist seeking a chef who could turn out “cutting edge, high performance, Asian-inspired and freshly prepared cuisine” that is “affordable, innovative comfort food for the modern, educated, discerning palate.”

headline: Rambling With W. G. Sebald in East Anglia
text: ON an August morning in  1992, Winfried Georg Sebald —  known as W. G. to the literary world and Max to his friends —  set out from his home in Norwich, England, to travel more than 80 miles on foot to the once-important towns and villages around Suffolk County, in East Anglia, a region of expansive wheat fields, green wetlands and medieval churches. Sebald — who died in a car accident in 2001  — had lived in this pocket of England with his wife, Ute, since 1970, after leaving his homeland, Germany, as a young man.

headline: Louisiana’s Zydeco Trail
text: I HAD never noticed how closely the syncopated rhythm of zydeco music echoes the rollicking stumble of horses on rough terrain. But on a September afternoon in the piney woods of Evangeline Parish, in Louisiana’s Cajun country, with hundreds of dusty horseback riders moving down a narrow trail, the kinship was impossible to miss. As the horses followed a tractor towing a D.J. and a zydeco-blaring sound system, they bucked and swayed in a cadence fit for the barroom floors of Lafayette, 70 miles away.

headline: Peruvian Chefs Add Flavor to Quito, Ecuador
text: IN 2003, when Santiago Jarrin opened   Theatrum, a restaurant on the second floor of the newly refurbished national theater in Quito, the Ecuadorean capital, he hoped to create a dining destination in the city’s Old Town — a long troubled neighborhood then on the verge of a tourist revival.

headline: A Party Blooms in Bogotá
text: EARLY one evening in Bogotá, Colombia, late last year, a tall brunette in her mid-20s, with a Joan Jett shag and in heels, walked with her girlfriends along the desolate streets of La Candelaria, the city’s historic neighborhood. A decade ago, when this country was the kidnapping capital of the world, strolling anywhere after dark would have been reckless.

headline: Breathe Into Your Infringement
text: You’d have to be in a permanent state of savasana (corpse pose) not to realize that yoga is big business. For those of us who relish the little bit of peace and quiet it offers from what sometimes feels like the relentlessness of our days, that can be a bit of a drag. Apparently, the government of India feels the same way. The country recently created a database of 1,300 yoga poses for use by international patent offices, the Times of India reports, apparently in an effort to reclaim the ancient practice from western “yoga gurus.”

headline: Happiest Places Post Highest Suicide Rates
text: Does being around happy people make an unhappy person feel even worse?

headline: Winning a Cup? It Helps to Have a Cup Winner

headline: Reassuring Deficit News
text: The Congressional Budget Office is out with a new study that should quell some of the deficit hysteria that seems to be taking over the national discourse. It points out that a major part of the current budget deficit is caused by what it calls “automatic stabilizers” that respond to economic weakness.

headline: Ethan Stiefel to Withdraw From American Ballet Theater’s Spring Season
text: Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will withdraw from performances with the company this spring. In a statement released by the company on Friday, Mr. Stiefel, 38, said he had decided to withdraw so that he could focus on his duties as dean of dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. This is Mr. Stiefel’s final year as dean. He is to take on the role of artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in September. “Leading the U.N.C.S.A. School of Dance through a critical period of transition has required the type of energy and attention that has kept me from properly focusing and physically preparing for my upcoming performances,” Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. “I am truly disappointed not to be performing with my colleagues at ABT and for the New York audiences.” This season he was scheduled to dance opposite Alina Cojocaru in “Giselle” in May and Natalia Osipova in “Coppelia” in June. Mr. Stiefel, who joined Ballet Theater in 1997, has also withdrawn from American Ballet Theater’s tour of Japan in July.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Dates, Heroes and Fairies
text: The new titles in the lists this week are another example of the diversity of graphic novels. There’s literally something for everyone. On the hardcover list is “Mister Wonderful,” by Daniel Clowes, about the search for human connection as seen through a blind date. The story was originally serialized in the Sunday magazine of The New York Times. Those installments are available here, but the hardcover collection, at No. 1, contains 40 pages of new material. Also on the hardcover list is “Invincible: Ultimate Collection,” Vol. 6, by Robert Kirkman and Ryan Ottley, who created the critically-acclaimed comic book series “The Walking Dead,” which became a critically-acclaimed AMC television series. Invincible, at No. 10, is about a young super-hero learning about himself, his father (another super being) and life (college, relationships, work).

headline: Prehistoric Cave With a Hornet on the Wall
text: THE director Werner Herzog remembers being about 12 years old when he saw, and was transfixed by, a picture of a horse on the cover of a book about Paleolithic art, displayed in the window of a bookstore in the isolated Bavarian village where he lived. Ever since, even as he was making films like “Aguirre, the Wrath of God” and “Nosferatu,” that image “has engaged me and haunted my mind,” he said. “It has never left me.”

headline: Making Standards Swing, With a Wink for Jack Benny
text: The up-and-coming jazz violinist Aaron Weinstein has two secret weapons. One is a mandolin that he brings out in the middle of a set to change the mood and on which he plays meticulously sculptured arrangements with a sweet plinkety-plink verve. The other is a deadpan sense of humor that he sneaks into his patter. At the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening Mr. Weinstein introduced his show, “Have Strings, Will Swing,” by describing the intimidating piece he wasn’t going to perform: a six-movement, 52-minute work inspired by James Joyce’s “Ulysses.”

headline: A Warm-Weather Guide to the City
text: The great outdoors calls, and even without counting Central Park, there’s a great deal of it in New York City. There are more than 1,700 parks in the five boroughs, according to the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation. (Though with the 0.04 acre Septuagesimo Uno Park, on 71st Street between West End and Amsterdam Avenues, on that list, it’s a number best taken with a grain of asphalt.) Here, a baker’s dozen’s worth of sites to enjoy the warm weather, when it arrives.

headline: An Ode to Spring, Whenever It Comes
text: ACCORDING to the calendar, it’s been spring for the past five weeks. But you could have fooled me. Since the vernal equinox on March 20, the official start of the season, we’ve had nearly two weeks’ worth of days on which the temperature has not yet reached above 50 degrees. On average, this spring is two and a half degrees colder than usual. And it has rained almost 20 of those days, making the season thus far 27 percent wetter than in most years (not to mention March 24, the day that shall live in infamy, when there was measurable snowfall).

headline: Jaguar E-Type, Still Glamorous at 50

headline: The Politics of Naps
text: Last month, while reporting my article on sleep, I attended the National Sleep Foundation conference in Washington, where the transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, had been invited as keynote speaker. Instead, another government official presented. Had LaHood been there — and had he attended a couple of the sessions on sleep deprivation and shift work — he might be a bit more sympathetic to the sleepy air traffic controllers who have been in the news.

headline: Rumbling and Rambling Amid a Blistering Storm
text: Secret Mountains closed out its Thursday night show at Cake Shop with a furious squall. Beginning with the dry, desert ache of “High Horse” and swelling into “Golden Blue,” the band built the rush one piece at a time — lonely, aerated guitar; firm bass; jangling tambourine; keyboards adding thickness; and a second guitar, more frenzied than the first, slashing through everything else, abrasive and urgent.

headline: In a Tale of Deliverance, It’s Moses to the Rescue
text: Immediacy is the goal of the Passover Seder, commemorating the biblical story of the Jews’ deliverance from slavery in Egypt. Through the retelling of that story and the explication of rituals and symbols, Seder participants are supposed to become convinced that the Exodus happened to them. Tradition relates that the wicked child asks on Passover, “What does all this mean to you?,” distancing himself from what should be utterly personal.

headline: At Gaumont in France When All Was Possible
text: TWO years ago Kino International offered “Gaumont Treasures: 1897-1913,” a three-disc set adapted from a superb seven-disc collection, “Gaumont: Le Cinéma Premier,” issued by the French studio that is probably the oldest continuing filmmaking concern in the world. Gaumont struck again with a second volume, and now Kino has imported and adapted that anthology under the title “Gaumont Treasures, Vol. 2, 1908-1916.” For anyone interested in how the movies came to be what they are, it’s essential viewing.

headline: A Registry Explores Dog Deaths by Breed

headline: Big Bang’s Echoes, 50 Years Later
text: The legacy of Impulse Records has hardly lacked for commemoration. The label keeps repackaging albums, even as its parent company, the Verve Music Group, slouches away from instrumental jazz. Five years ago Ashley Kahn published “The House That Trane Built: The Story of Impulse Records” (W. W. Norton), an aficionado’s history and, in essence, a corporate biography. This week brought the release of a CD boxed set, “First Impulse: The Creed Taylor Collection” (Hip-O Select/Verve), that gathers the six albums produced for the label by its founder, under the banner of a 50th anniversary.

headline: Brutal Battles and Raging Melodrama
text: A lack of familiarity with the byzantine history of China during the Warring States Period, from the fifth to the third centuries B.C., is a handicap when it comes to following the story of “The Warring States,” which is extremely loosely based on parts of that history. The writer, Shen Jian, and the director, Jing Chen, have made no concessions to the non-Chinese viewer in their compressed, chaotic narrative.

headline: Swirling Tensions, Surging Passions
text: Since 1961, the estimable Young Concert Artists, which celebrates its 50th anniversary this season, has offered performance opportunities, mentorship and management to promising musicians, mostly solo instrumentalists and singers. Ensembles, including the Tokyo String Quartet in 1970 and the Borromeo String Quartet in 1991, are also sometimes recruited.

headline: Sacred Vivaldi, Somber and Elegant
text: During the early part of his career Vivaldi mostly wrote instrumental works, which were often tempestuous and virtuosic. In his mid-30s, while working as a music teacher at a girls’ orphanage in Venice, Vivaldi (nicknamed the Red Priest because of his hair) was commissioned to write a Stabat Mater, probably his first sacred piece.

headline: This Sunday: Feast on Riff

headline: The Memory of Holocaust, Fortified
text: SKOKIE, Ill. — Before the $45 million Illinois Holocaust Museum & Education Center opened here two years ago, there was some urgency in completing its 65,000-square-foot building, which now stands so incongruously monumental in the midst of Chicago’s suburban landscape. At one time, 7,000 Jews bearing the scars of the Holocaust had lived in Skokie with their families, and they were aging. Many had contributed artifacts to the museum; some participated when it was just a storefront on Main Street; some had their oral histories recorded for its exhibition and their lives chronicled in the institution’s imposing companion book, “Memory and Legacy.”

text: To prevent police officers from fixing traffic tickets, the Police Department has come up with a system that would be familiar to any grocery store checkout clerk doing inventory.

headline: Upscale Looks, With a Down-Home Feel
text: CEDAR CREEK American Bar and Grill in Glen Cove is the newest venture of the Mim’s Restaurant Group. Its older siblings, Mim’s in Syosset and Mill Creek Tavern in Bayville, are both casual neighborhood spots. Cedar Creek, which opened in early March, is much larger and more upscale-looking.

headline: Corrections

headline: St. Cloud State Second Baseman Takes Reins of His Hometown
text: LORETTO, Minn. — The late-afternoon baseball practice was over and Kent Koch, the second baseman and senior captain at St. Cloud State University in central Minnesota, was in a hurry.

headline: As Old as Stairs, a Thief Who Is Comfortable With Heights
text: Somebody broke into a ground-floor apartment at 176 Thompson Street in Greenwich Village, home to tenants in their 30s and their obligatory gear, and got away with three laptops, a mobile phone and an Xbox. And a taste for adventure, for from there, he moved up, and in doing so joined a particular rank of thieves who have lurked above the streets of New York ever since the installation of the first flight of stairs.

headline: Try Some Cheese?
text: When Fawn Nebinger ran a gallery several years ago, she named it after a favorite kind of flower. The moniker, Foxglove, has lingered on, even as her business evolved from paintings, to bath and beauty items, to cheese.

headline: Bistro Fare That Pleases Appetite and Wallet
text: OF the many Italian restaurants in this state, Sal e Pepe in Newtown, a contemporary Italian bistro that Angelo Marini opened in late 2005, is one of the better ones — largely thanks to its chef, Carlos Pineda, a Guatemalan who honed his Italian cooking at Sole in New Canaan.

headline: A Cheese Movement
text: The name American Cheese might suggest processed slices wrapped in plastic, but that’s the last thing you’ll find in this charming shop in West Sayville.

headline: Warding Off Hunger, and the Evil Eye
text: SEEN from the parking lot in the nondescript strip mall where Cinnamon Indian Restaurant sits wedged between the Kosher Korner Deli and the Eastern Dental Family Practice in Morris Plains, the restaurant’s giant orange sign beckons like one of those epically unhealthy fast-food joints you might find at a highway rest stop. But inside, the sweet aroma of Indian spices signals a vastly different experience.

headline: Macarons of Her Own
text: Keum Sook Park is as nonchalant about making macarons, the delicate French filled cookies — not to be mistaken for chewy coconut macaroons — as you would expect from an alumna of Payard Patisserie and Bistro in Manhattan. “Macarons are easy and fast to make,” said Ms. Park, 44, who opened Sook Pastry in Ridgewood, a French-inspired bakery and cafe, in March.

headline: The Disappearing Family Doctor
text: Dr. Ronald Sroka has practiced family medicine for 32 years in a small red-brick building just six miles from his childhood home, treating fishing buddies, neighbors and even his elementary school principal. But doctors like him are a dying breed, as rising health care costs are driving thousands of doctors in small private practices out of business, reports Gardiner Harris.

headline: Mets Don’t Just Blame Their Tools, They Beat Their Toolbox to a Pulp
text: The order to destroy Stanley, the rolling toolbox that had become a bullpen mascot for the Mets in spring training, came right from the top. Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, who is in charge of the daily operations of the team, ordered the demolition Thursday as a way to turn around the team’s atrocious luck.

headline: A 150,000-Pound Hand-Me-Down. Yay?
text: Imagine that someone offered to dump 1,100 busted washing machines onto a prime piece of riverfront property in Midtown Manhattan, pitching the idea as a potential tourist draw and educational attraction. New Yorkers are smart. Many — perhaps even most — of them would say: “Are you kidding me? You’re just looking for an easy way to get rid of 150,000 pounds of junk.”

headline: The Family Practice
text: Changes in the health care landscape have left Dr. Ronald Sroka with a family practice he cannot sell.

headline: Meet the Extreme Hobbyists
text: These hobbyists don’t just accumulate memorabilia, they define their existence by it. Occasionally, they overdo it, and that’s just fine with them.

headline: Family Physician Can’t Give Away Solo Practice
text: CROFTON, Md. — “So there we are, miles from shore, fishing since 11 o’clock at night, and we haven’t gotten one single bite until finally we gaff one that’s about this big.”

headline: Ex-Blackwater Guards Face Renewed Charges
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday reopened the criminal case against four former American military contractors accused of manslaughter in connection with a shooting that killed at least 17 Iraqi civilians in Baghdad in 2007.

headline: Refusing to Surrender to the Dark Side
text: The specter of doom pervaded the Mets’ clubhouse on Friday, but not for the reasons you might think. R. A. Dickey brought a full Darth Vader costume to Citi Field, complete with helmet and voice modulator, and he wore it around the locker room, startling teammates and attendants.

headline: Alabama: Guilty Plea in Bribery Scheme
text: Ronald E. Gilley, who was developing an entertainment and casino complex in southeastern Alabama, pleaded guilty in federal court in Montgomery on Friday to participating in a bribery scheme that has led to the arrests of powerful businessmen, lobbyists and four state lawmakers. Two of the lobbyists who worked for Mr. Gilley have also pleaded guilty. Mr. Gilley’s plea leaves nine remaining defendants, including the four lawmakers and a racetrack owner, Milton McGregor, one of the state’s top campaign donors.

headline: Police Shoot Man Holding a Fake Gun
text: A man armed with what turned out to be a fake gun was shot and critically wounded by police officers in the Bronx on Friday after he refused orders to drop it, the police said.

headline: Judge Approves Bonus Plan for Executives of the Borders Group
text: The Borders Group won approval of an amended executive bonus plan after a judge sought changes to resolve objections from the federal agency that oversees bankruptcies.

headline: Camouflaging Price Creep
text: The Easter special at many retailers this year involves higher price tags.

headline: Amazon’s Trouble Raises Cloud Computing Doubts
text: As technical problems interrupted computer services provided by Amazon for a second day on Friday, industry analysts said the troubles would prompt many companies to reconsider relying on remote computers beyond their control.

headline: In Media’s Wedding Frenzy, Hints of Viewer Fatigue
text: LONDON — When Prince William and Kate Middleton emerge from Westminster Abbey as a married couple next Friday, they will be greeted by hundreds of reporters from around the world. But as the day draws near, there are signs that the media frenzy may outpace interest in the United States, and some disdain is appearing among the British as well.

headline: Sleep at Work? Not for Them
text: AARON BYRD

headline: Staying Sharp in Wee Hours, Unlike Some Air Traffic Controllers
text: PHILADELPHIA — At 2 a.m. Friday, in a cavernous 24-hour fitness center here, Bobby Boyle, the owner of Boyle’s World Gym, sprinted across a basketball court and then hit the weight machines when he felt his energy sag. Lonely for companionship, Mr. Boyle, who works the graveyard shift, started up a conversation (mostly one-sided) with the gym’s mascot: his 22-year-old macaw, Terese.

headline: ‘Spring City’
text: The long-awaited demise of an extraordinary winter has released a pent-up spring. The days are longer and softer. Flowers are opening, the birds are back and the courting season has begun in earnest. Spring’s sprung and New York City is giddy with it. I imagined every structure in every borough suddenly being freed from its stodgy, frozen-at-right-angles shackles as well. Straight lines are for winter. Spring is all about curves and things that wiggle and grow — like everything in “Spring City.”

headline: 13 Years Later, a $2 Million Award
text: In March 1998, a 6-week-old girl named Shannell Coppage died of malnutrition even though she had been regularly breast-fed by her mother in their Park Slope, Brooklyn, home. Her mother, a 21-year-old named Tatiana Cheeks, was arrested and charged in the infant’s death, prompting an outcry from women’s health advocates.

headline: Cuomo’s Home? The Address Says One Thing, the Map Another
text: NEW CASTLE, N.Y. — When asked last fall to name his favorite restaurant, Andrew M. Cuomo picked a popular diner in the middle-class Westchester County suburb of Mount Kisco.

headline: Royal Wedding Wine May Be Bubbly and English
text: DITCHLING, England — In January, Michel Roux Jr., a London chef who is on the tasting committee that recommends wines to be served by the royal family, made a suggestion that would have been unthinkable not long ago. Wouldn’t it be nice, Mr. Roux asked a reporter for The Telegraph, if at the wedding reception for Prince William and Kate Middleton the glasses were filled not with Champagne but with English sparkling wine?

headline: Washington: First Lady’s Plane Was Warned of Turbulence
text: The air traffic controller who sent a jet carrying Michelle Obama too close to an Air Force cargo plane on Monday did warn the pilot of the passenger jet to beware of the bigger plane’s wake turbulence, the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday. The radar controller handed off the two planes approaching Andrews Air Force Base to a tower controller with only 3.08 miles between them, instead of the five required when a VIP jet, a military version of a Boeing 737, is following a heavy cargo plane. The radar controller incorrectly told the jet’s pilot that they were four miles apart, the safety board said. The tower controller told the jet’s pilot to follow an “S” pattern to increase spacing, but the planes actually got closer — to 2.94 miles apart — as the cargo plane slowed for landing. Mrs. Obama’s jet was instructed to break off the approach and return for another try.

headline: Wanna Buy a Turnpike?
text: Right now you’re probably asking yourself: How are all the angry new governors doing?

headline: Hobnobbing From the Ground Floor Up
text: As a private cocktail party clinked and murmured on the first floor of the David H. Koch Theater, home to the New York City Opera and New York City Ballet, on Thursday night, we felt a glimmer of what it must have been like to be a gladiator on the floor of the Colosseum. On the tiers above the party we were attending, operagoers not invited to the private reception hung over the balustrade. They watched the hobnobbing of guests like Kristin Chenoweth and Isaac Mizrahi as if it were theater. One rapt spectator even ate a snack.

headline: Mubarak Faces More Questioning on Gas Deal With Israel
text: Persistent public suspicions about corruption and mismanagement that swirl around Egypt’s secretive deal to sell natural gas to Israel prompted Egypt’s public prosecutor on Friday to extend the questioning of former President Hosni Mubarak for 15 days, judicial officials said.

headline: Lewis Binford, Leading Archaeologist, Dies at 79
text: Lewis R. Binford, one of the most influential American archaeologists of the last half-century and an early advocate of a more scientific approach to investigating ancient cultures, died on April 11 at his home in Kirksville, Mo. He was 79.

headline: Lies and Videotape
text: FACEBOOK, Twitter and other social media have revolutionized the global press landscape, helping to dislodge dictators in Tunisia and Egypt and foment protests in Bahrain and Syria.

headline: New Jersey Transit Worker, Fired After Burning Koran, Wins Back His Job
text: A New Jersey Transit worker who was fired after burning pages of a Koran during a demonstration in Lower Manhattan on Sept. 11 last year has been reinstated, reimbursed for lost wages and benefits, and awarded $25,000 in compensation for the pain and suffering caused by his dismissal.

headline: Hazel Dickens, Folk Singer, Dies at 75
text: Hazel Dickens, a clarion-voiced advocate for coal miners and working people and a pioneer among women in bluegrass music, died on Friday in Washington. She was 75.

headline: Dangerous Games
text: The debt limit is supposed to make Congress think twice before passing tax cuts or spending increases that add to the national debt. Instead, lawmakers routinely support policies without paying for them — like the Bush-era tax cuts and two wars — and then posture and protest when their decisions require raising the debt limit.

headline: Saturday: Inclined to Strike Out
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Fun, fun, fun.

headline: For 2 Days, an Opportunity to Dismiss Minor Offenses
text: They came for spitting, loitering and littering. They came for noise violations and for consuming alcohol in public. Blake Bullard, 18, came on a cold and gray afternoon of his high school spring break for disorderly conduct.

headline: Shielding the Privacies of Life
text: The Supreme Court has never heard a case challenging the government’s authority to search a computer. It is time, after a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit opened the way last month to vast government intrusion. It ruled that, without good reason to suspect evidence of a crime, border agents could seize a laptop and open a dragnet search of files, e-mails and Web sites visited.

headline: Vincenzo La Scola, Italian Tenor, Dies at 53
text: Vincenzo La Scola, an Italian tenor known internationally as both an opera singer and a crossover artist, died on April 15 in Turkey, where he was giving a master class. He was 53.

headline: Acquittal in Conflict With Officer
text: A retired New York City police officer was acquitted on Friday of charges that he punched a female officer in a station house in Harlem last year during a confrontation over the police’s decision to detain his son.

headline: Democrats and Gun Control
text: Months after Al Gore’s defeat in 2000, Terry McAuliffe, then the Democratic Party chief, urged Democrats to steer clear of gun control, warning of the “devastating impact on elections” wrought by the gun lobby’s monied campaign attacks. Far too many Democratic politicians have since followed that cynical doctrine. The gun lobby’s power has only grown while 30,000 Americans die each year by gun violence.

headline: Senator Ensign May Go, but the Questions Remain
text: Senator John Ensign abruptly announced his resignation on Thursday night, hoping to head-off a public airing of the ethics investigation into sordid misdeeds that destroyed his political future.

headline: Rained Out Again, the Yankees Know They’ll Pay the Price
text: BALTIMORE — Derek Jeter kept checking his cellphone for the night’s forecast. Curtis Granderson asked reporters for weather updates. A. J. Burnett climbed the steps leading to the Yankees’ clubhouse and said with a shrug, “Still raining.”

headline: Of Donald, Dunces and Dogma
text: I told myself that I wouldn’t be dragged into Donald Trump’s “birther” cesspool, yet here I am.

headline: Cup Got Crushed by a Tire? Real Madrid Gets a Spare
text: Real Madrid put its most recent trophy on display Friday in its museum at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium. No, not the one that was crushed under the wheels of the team bus during the celebrations for its Copa del Rey victory over Barcelona.

headline: Celtics Light Up the Garden
text: The dream, as conceived by Amar’e Stoudemire last summer and reimagined at midseason by Carmelo Anthony, at last came into vivid focus Friday night at Madison Square Garden, where the Knicks were eager and the fans were primed.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Rejects a Higher Takeover Bid
text: Tenet Healthcare said on Friday that its board had rejected a revised $3.3 billion takeover offer from Community Health Systems. Community revised its offer on Monday, saying that it would convert its bid of $5 cash and $1 in stock to an all-cash offer of $6 a share. The original unsolicited offer, announced in December, represented a premium of 40 percent to Tenet’s stock price at the time. The revised proposal, Tenet said on Friday, still “grossly undervalues” the company. In a letter to Wayne T. Smith, the chief executive of Community, Trevor Fetter, the chief executive of Tenet, said that the bid undervalued Tenet and that he had concerns about disclosure and regulatory compliance. Community said it was disappointed by Tenet’s rejection but was “ready to engage in constructive discussions to move this transaction forward.”

headline: A Turn to the Right and a Second Look Is What the Mets Need
text: Ike Davis and the Mets benefited Friday night from two changes. One happened more than a year ago, when the Mets reconfigured Citi Field’s center-field fence to make it easier to hit home runs to that area. The other happened in the bottom of the seventh inning, when Diamondbacks Manager Kirk Gibson replaced his left-handed starting pitcher, Joe Saunders, with the right-hander Esmerling Vasquez.

text: It happens in apartments all the time: BUZZ!

text: Workers make it through the night shift using different tricks and tactics.

text: RICHMOND, Ill. — In this distant Chicago suburb, a builder has finally found a way to persuade people to buy a new house: he throws in a car.

headline: A Profession in Transition
text: American medicine is steadily shifting away from small, privately owned clinics and becoming an industry dominated by larger groups of doctors in salaried jobs.

headline: Resignation Has Nevada Sorting Out the Fallout
text: LAS VEGAS — Even before Senator John Ensign announced last month that he would not seek re-election, Representative Dean Heller was working feverishly to make sure he was seen as the inevitable Republican nominee.

headline: With Rondo at Point, Celtics Show Knicks What They Lack
text: Just as reality intruded on Butler last month in Houston, it descended on the undermanned Knicks on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, neatly camouflaged in the 6-foot-1, 170-pound point guard persona of Rajon Rondo.

text: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen on the challenges ahead in forming a new government.

text: The Celtics routed the Knicks behind the strong play of four of their starters and took a 3-0 lead in the series.

headline: Lakers Back in Control Against Hornets
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Los Angeles Lakers regained their homecourt advantage Friday night with a 100-86 victory against the Hornets in Game 3 of their first-round playoff series, but they hardly looked like the well-oiled machine that has rolled to the past three N.B.A. Finals.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Adam Froman, Fourth-Ranked Quarterback
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: Syrian Forces Open Fire at Protesters’ Funerals
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces fired their weapons into crowds of mourners in at least three towns on Saturday as tens of thousands of people buried protesters who were killed a day earlier in the worst bloodshed since the uprising began last month. Human rights activists and witnesses said at least 11 people were killed on Saturday.

headline: Beer Drinking and What It Says About China’s Economy
text: 04/25/11 | Updated to correct figures on beer consumption in China and the Czech Republic.

headline: In Ominous Sculpture, the Tap, Tap of a Pending Emergency
text: A couple of months ago I attended an art opening at the Marina Gallery in Cold Spring, N.Y., the little river town that counts as our urban center. While milling with the crowd, my ears became attuned to a regular “tap.” I found the source, a work of art consisting of a hammer banging metronome-style on the framed words, “Break Glass in Case of Emergency.”

headline: Redefining the Sexes in Unequal Terms
text: The good news is that the International Olympic Committee and the International Association of Athletics Federations, the governing body for track and field, have worked hard to come up with a new policy to deal with athletes whose sex development is unusual.

headline: Jackson Leaves a Legacy of Big Talk and Bigger Horses
text: Jess Jackson looked like the longshoreman he once was. He was a big man with white hair and a sonorous voice. Wine was his primary business — he was the founder of Kendall Jackson Winery. Thoroughbreds were his passion, however, a lifelong one first sparked watching the great Seabiscuit run when he was a boy in Depression-era San Francisco.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photographs of news and features in business.

headline: Recognizing a More Important Meaning of Being There
text: Elizabeth Grace Lewis, the newborn daughter of the Texas Rangers right-hander Colby Lewis, has a unique distinction in baseball history. She is the first baby whose father was placed on the paternity leave list to witness her birth.

headline: Libyan Forces Withdraw From a Besieged City, and the Rebels Wonder Why
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — In a sudden shift after nearly two months of heavy siege, government forces withdrew from the western city of Misurata on Saturday.

headline: Rookie Aiming High
text: Baseball is a sport rich in statistics, and consumed by debate over the meaning of virtually each and every one of those numbers.

headline: Mommy’s Helper, in Red and White, and in the Courtroom, Too
text: It’s come down to this in the battle to win over beleaguered, stressed-out moms: Rival vintners are fighting over the use of the word “Mommy” on their wine labels, Reuters reports.

headline: Back Then: 2005
text: Grete Waitz, who won the New York Marathon nine times, died last week of cancer at 57. Harvey Araton of The Times spoke to her in 2005, the year she disclosed the diagnosis.

headline: Prime Number
text: 585: The estimated number, in the thousands, of people in China who this year will have more than 10 million renminbi — or about $1.5 million — in investable assets, according to a study by the consulting firm Bain & Company. That number is twice what it was in 2008. Most of those individuals are first-generation entrepreneurs, according to Bain. The fastest growth has been among those worth more than $15 million. Justin Yifu Lin, the World Bank’s chief economist, last year named growing income disparity as one of China’s biggest economic problems.

headline: Tornadoes Tear Through St. Louis, Shutting Down the Airport
text: ST. LOUIS — Several tornadoes ripped through this area Friday evening, and one of them touched down right by Lambert-St. Louis International Airport, blowing out windows, panicking airline passengers and filling once-orderly terminals with flying glass and ferocious winds.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is facing an avalanche of lawsuits and petitions from environmental groups to add new animals and plants to the endangered species list.

headline: Vermont Exercising Option to Balance the Budget
text: MONTPELIER, Vt. — Technically, Vermont could play fast and loose in this season of fevered budget-chopping: it happens to be the only state with no budget-balancing requirement.

headline: The Humanity of the Long-Distance Runner
text: Grete Waitz, the most private of individuals, ended up excelling in the most public of sports, marathon racing. She ran past millions of cheering, hand-extending New Yorkers on the way to breaking the finish line tape in Central Park nine times. Moments later, she faced the swarming news media.

headline: In Jackson’s Finale, Lakers’ Parting Gift Challenges His Skills
text: NEW ORLEANS — Life has come full circle for Phil Jackson, who seized on basketball as a youngster to escape the rhythms and rigors of the church life ordained by his parents, who were Pentecostal ministers.

headline: A Group of Conflict Photographers Runs Out of Luck
text: It was the photographer Joao Silva, lying in a hospital bed in Washington, his legs blown off in Afghanistan, who confirmed that my close friend was dead.

headline: Variety: A Run-On Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon is about just one of the unique qualities of a language I won’t name for fear of giving too much away. The book itself is a wonderful trip into the culture behind this language, and the author’s immersion into both while living abroad.

headline: An N.B.A. Rival Offers a Message of Hope for Knicks Fans
text: Encouragement often comes from the most unexpected sources. On Friday, Grant Hill, the Phoenix Suns forward, delivered a message to the Knicks and their fans: Do not be dismayed.

headline: A Royal Wedding, a Tarnished Crown
text: LONDON — Outwardly, at least, this week’s royal pageant will bear a strong resemblance to the last of the great royal weddings, when Prince Charles married Lady Diana Spencer in 1981. Now, as then, a tall, slim young man in a crisply tailored military uniform will wed a bride so striking she has launched 10,000 magazine covers, offering to Britain and the world the promise of a monarchy alluringly renewed.

headline: Shanghai Truckers’ Protest Ebbs With Concessions Won on Fees
text: BEIJING — A three-day protest by truck drivers that disrupted Shanghai’s sprawling port appeared to ebb on Saturday after the local government promised to cut some transport fees and abolish others, meeting some of the drivers’ demands.

headline: Scenes From the Madoff Masquerade
text: This article was adapted from “The Wizard of Lies: Bernie Madoff and the Death of Trust,” by Diana B. Henriques, a reporter for The New York Times. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Times Books, analyzes Mr. Madoff’s rise and fall.

headline: Mail Bombs Are Prelude to a Soccer Showdown
text: LONDON — In Scotland, they call it the Old Firm rivalry — more than 100 years of fierce encounters between Glasgow’s top soccer clubs, Rangers and Celtic, who have made almost a closed shop of their pursuit for supremacy in the Scottish game.

headline: Tribeca Q&A: Lee Hirsch
text: Lee Hirsch, the director of “Bully,” discussed his film about the issue of bullying in schools during last year’s Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: For Longtime Fans of the Knicks, a Garden View Is Clouded by Green
text: Long before he claimed what most would consider a prize courtside season ticket for Knicks games at Madison Square Garden — one with a direct view of the back of Woody Allen’s head — Lewis Dorf was spoiled with the best seat in the house.

headline: India Finds Corruption in Fast-Growing Aviation Industry
text: NEW DELHI — More than a dozen commercial pilots in India have been stripped of their licenses and a top airline safety official has been suspended after a government investigation uncovered widespread fraud and corruption in the booming aviation industry.

headline: It’s Showtime, So Take That Deep Breath
text: This interview with  Caryl M. Stern, president and chief executive of the U.S. Fund for Unicef, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Do It Yourself, or With the Help of Tinkerers Everywhere
text: HANDS-ON kits offer great ways to learn about science and engineering. But the joys of making a small robot or a crystal radio set have long eluded those who can’t get past Step 2 in the instruction manual.

headline: Letting Others Lead in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — When the battle for Libya seemed to be slipping into stalemate last week, the British, French and Italians sent “military advisers,” a phrase that to much of the world suggests the first step on the slippery slope to ground forces.

headline: World Bank Faults Itself for East Timor’s Struggles
text: WASHINGTON — A frank evaluation by the World Bank’s internal auditors of a decade of efforts to help East Timor underscores the challenges facing international organizations trying to assist struggling nations.

headline: Why the King James Bible Endures
text: The King James Bible, which was first published 400 years ago next month, may be the single best thing ever accomplished by a committee. The Bible was the work of 54 scholars and clergymen who met over seven years in six nine-man subcommittees, called “companies.” In a preface to the new Bible, Miles Smith, one of the translators and a man so impatient that he once walked out of a boring sermon and went to the pub, wrote that anything new inevitably “endured many a storm of gainsaying, or opposition.” So there must have been disputes — shouting; table pounding; high-ruffed, black-gowned clergymen folding their arms and stomping out of the room — but there is no record of them. And the finished text shows none of the PowerPoint insipidness we associate with committee-speak or with later group translations like the 1961 New English Bible, which T.S. Eliot said did not even rise to “dignified mediocrity.” Far from bland, the King James Bible is one of the great masterpieces of English prose.

headline: Warren Buffett, Delegator in Chief
text: “He picked the chorus line but didn’t attempt to dance.”

headline: Off the Menu: Gravy
text: The idea behind Gravy, which has had some dinners for friends of the restaurant and is opening Saturday, is to bring Southern touches to New York food. For Michael Vignola, the executive chef who worked at Michael Jordan’s The Steakhouse NYC, the culinary definition of the South goes beyond hush puppies and gumbo. “There are all the African, Spanish and French influences and all the ingredients involved,” he said. The a la carte menu has Louisiana crawfish gumbo fritters, oysters with chayote mignonette, scallops with honey grits, and cornflake-crusted chicken stuffed with andouille and cheddar. For a more New York approach there are also red snapper served like sashimi, black-eyed pea hummus, Long Island duck with green tomato relish and blackened king crab legs.

headline: When There’s No Such Thing as Too Much Information
text: INFORMATION overload is a headache for individuals and a huge challenge for businesses. Companies are swimming, if not drowning, in wave after wave of data — from increasingly sophisticated computer tracking of shipments, sales, suppliers and customers, as well as e-mail, Web traffic and social-network comments. These Internet-era technologies, by one estimate, are doubling the quantity of business data every 1.2 years.

headline: Show Us the Data. (It’s Ours, After All.)
text: “NO one knows what I like better than I do.”

headline: Beyond the Surge in Corporate Profits

headline: Teams That Score First in Playoff Games Are Tough to Beat
text: The most eye-catching theme in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs has been the comebacks staged on three consecutive nights by the Sharks (from four goals down to beat the Kings), the Capitals (from three goals down to shock the Rangers) and the Bruins (from three goals down to defeat the Canadiens).

headline: From a Crisis, Opportunity
text: I  GREW up in Savannah, Ga. When I was 10, I entered an essay contest on why I loved the city. It was a promotion for the opening of its convention center. I won for the elementary school category and appeared at the opening. Diahann Carroll was also part of the celebration. I still remember having butterflies in my stomach.

headline: Behind the Rising Cost of Food
text: The plate has always been a great fortifier. Soup to heal, stew to comfort, escape delivered in a good piece of chocolate.

headline: 30 Seconds With Mike Schmidt
text: Mike Schmidt, a three-time National League most valuable player, is remembered primarily as a slugger. In 18 seasons with the Philadelphia Phillies, he hit 548 home runs and led the league in home runs eight times. But he also had a keen sense of plate discipline (.380 career on-base percentage) and was a stellar third baseman (10 Gold Gloves).

headline: The Shifting Definition of Worker Loyalty
text: IS loyalty in the workplace dead?

headline: Tribeca Video Interview: Lee Hirsch
text: Following five families over the course of a school year, the documentary “The Bully Project” tackles the issue of bullying and how it affects students, their families, the schools and society at large. The director Lee Hirsch filmed in Georgia, Mississippi and Oklahoma, and was given access to shoot in two schools in Sioux City, Iowa. In this video, he discusses his ideas behind “The Bully Project,” what the process was like filming moments of bullying as they were happening and what he hopes the film will achieve.

headline: A Customer Who’s Always Satisfied

headline: In an Afghan Village, Living in Fear of Both Sides
text: TOWDABAY KALAY, Afghanistan — The American soldiers knew little about this farming village in the rugged foothills of Paktika Province in eastern Afghanistan, but they were told the Taliban moved through regularly.

headline: Maybe Just Drunk Enough to Remember
text: Drunken recollections, especially in rape trials, rarely play well to jurors. In a society that can be quick to turn a skeptical eye toward women who say they were raped — she was scantily dressed, she’s promiscuous, she’s just angry at him — prosecutors of sex crimes say one of their biggest obstacles in the courtroom is alcohol.

headline: Brünnhilde’s Trials Beyond Wagner’s Dreams
text: Two scenes in the Metropolitan Opera’s highly anticipated new production of Wagner’s “Walküre,” which opened on Friday night, showcased what is both captivating and exasperating about Robert Lepage’s production, the second installment in his staging of the complete “Ring” cycle.

headline: Two Schools in Afghanistan, One Complicated Situation
text: The schoolhouse at the end of the world is a simple affair. Made of concrete and painted gray, it bears the white star of the Central Asia Institute, the nonprofit group co-founded by Greg Mortenson. The group says it has built more than 170 schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

text: Matt Yglesias has a good question, but I don’t think that I agree with his answer.

headline: Social Media Accounts of Protests in Syria
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, the uprising in Syria continued on Saturday, as the security forces attacked crowds of mourners in at least three towns, during funerals for protesters killed a day earlier.

headline: Rebels Take Control in Misurata
text: Troops captured in Misurata, Libya, said Saturday that they had been ordered to retreat from the city, in what appeared to be a significant setback for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces.

headline: Who Debased the Dollar?
text: Barry Ritholtz makes an obvious but strangely unnoticed point: right now we have all these people hysterical about the debasement of the dollar, but where were they when the real devaluation was taking place?

headline: Stoudemire Is Doubtful for Game 4
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — At full strength, Amar’e Stoudemire could salvage the Knicks’ playoff run, or at least delay their elimination. But he is nowhere near full strength. And it may not be worth risking his health to delay what appears inevitable.

headline: President of Yemen Offers to Leave, With Conditions
text: CAIRO — Yemen’s embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, said Saturday that he accepted a proposal by Arab mediators that would shift power to his deputy 30 days from the signing of a formal agreement and grant him and his family, who occupy key positions in Yemen’s security apparatus, immunity from prosecution.

headline: Afghan Police Seek to Stop Illicit Trade in Uniforms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The police on Saturday ratcheted up enforcement on stores and tailor shops that illegally make and sell military and police uniforms after a string of attacks by insurgents dressed as Afghan service members that have cast suspicion on the country’s security forces.

headline: Majestic Views, Ancient Culture and a Profit Fight
text: GRAND CANYON WEST, Ariz. — Think of a Caribbean glass-bottomed boat hung out over the edge of the Grand Canyon and you have the idea behind the Skywalk, a modern, vertigo-inducing moneymaker that is drawing hundreds of thousands of people annually onto the Hualapai Indians’ reservation to stare down beneath their feet at the distant canyon floor.

headline: Hold the Halo

headline: Reports of 2 Tibetans Killed by Chinese Officers
text: BEIJING — A Tibet advocacy group based outside China said in a report released Friday that two Tibetans were killed Thursday night by Chinese paramilitary officers who were raiding a monastery in Sichuan Province to detain rebellious monks.

headline: What About American Girls Sold on the Streets?
text: When we hear about human trafficking in India or Cambodia, our hearts melt. The victim has sometimes been kidnapped and imprisoned, even caged, in a way that conjures our images of slavery.

headline: For Many Chinese, New Wealth and a Fresh Face
text: BEIJING — Even in a blue-striped hospital bathrobe, her face wiped clean of makeup and marked with purple lines by her surgeon, the young woman who called herself Devil embodied an image of beauty widely admired in China: large, luminous eyes, a delicate nose and softly sculpted cheekbones.

headline: A Real Choice on Medicare
text: We know it is not how most people want to spend their time, but Americans need to give a close reading to the Democrats’ and Republicans’ plans for Medicare reform. There are stark differences that will profoundly affect all of our lives — and clear political choices to come.

headline: Union Proud
text: It seemed like all of New York turned out for the April 20, rally in support of the Union. The event, which appropriately took place at Union Square, prompted diarist George Templeton Strong to suggest that “[f]ew assemblages have excelled it in numbers and unanimity.” Men, women and children carried flags or wore cockades, the Stars and Stripes hung from buildings and impromptu renderings of “The Star-Spangled Banner” echoed through the streets. “The city,” observed Strong, “seems to have gone suddenly wild and crazy.”

headline: With ‘Coolest Job Ever’ Ending, Astronauts Seek Next Frontier
text: What happens when you have the right stuff at the wrong time?

headline: The Bipartisan March to Fiscal Madness

headline: Violet Cowden, Wartime Plane Pilot, Is Dead at 94
text: The problem was simple, but would have disastrous consequences if left unsolved. The United States had entered World War II, and military aircraft were barreling off the assembly lines. But with many military pilots deployed overseas, or soon to be, there was no way to transport the planes from the factories to the airfields where they were urgently needed.

headline: Human Trafficking in the United States
text: My Sunday column looks at human trafficking — but in America. This is a subject I’ve written about a good deal in Cambodia, India, Pakistan and elsewhere abroad, and there’s sometimes a tendency to think that the problem just exists overseas, or just among foreign women smuggled in the the U.S. It’s true that the worst places in the world for forced prostitution maybe Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Cambodia, Burma, and so on. But we also have significant problems in the United States — particularly among home-grown young teenagers — and we don’t have the credibility to address the problems abroad unless we clean up our act at home.

headline: A Slogan, Not a Plan
text: REPUBLICANS have an effective slogan for their health care agenda: “repeal and replace.” The problem is, they can agree only on the first half; agreeing on what to put in place of last year’s health care law is the hard part. Even Representative Paul Ryan’s bold budget proposal avoids the issue.

headline: Quick Help for the Gulf
text: The agreement announced Thursday under which BP will make a $1 billion down payment on its obligation to restore the Gulf of Mexico to good health is such welcome news that it seems almost churlish to offer caveats. But caveats there are.

headline: Pastor Is Accused of Helping to Kidnap Girl at Center of Lesbian Custody Fight
text: Federal authorities last week arrested and charged a Tennessee pastor with aiding in the “international parental kidnapping” of a girl who has been missing since late 2009 and is at the center of a lengthy custody battle between her two mothers — a onetime lesbian couple who were in a civil union.

headline: Jesus Christ Rock Star
text: East Lansing, Mich.

headline: What the Season Returns
text: I’ve just opened up the hive of bees that died over the winter. For several years, I’ve left all the honey for them in hopes of making a hard season easier to bear. In a winter as cold as this past one, it’s possible for bees to cluster so tightly, trying to keep warm, that they’re unable to move to their stores of honey a few inches away.

headline: Rebels Gain Ground in Misurata
text: Map of areas taken by rebels around Misurata.

headline: Be Love Farm
text: Café Gratitude, a small California chain of raw food and vegan cafes and restaurants, gets much of its organic “live food” menu items from Be Love Farm near Vacaville. Matthew and Terces Engelhart, who own the restaurants and the farm, reside on the 21-acre property, nurturing abundant produce for their expanding franchise.

headline: Sunday: Use It or Lose It
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Caleb Madison is one of the Young Turks of crossword construction, but don’t think for a second that his head is swelled. Just because he was one of the youngest people to have a crossword puzzle published in The New York Times for a very long time doesn’t mean that he doesn’t give back. One of his pet projects is teaching a class in crossword construction at the Jewish Association of Services for the Aged called, appropriately, “Get A Clue!”

headline: Exiles Shaping World’s Image of Syria Revolt
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — On the bloodiest day of Syria’s uprising, Rami Nakhle’s fingers drifted over the keyboard in a room silent but for the news bulletins of Al Jazeera, yet filled with the commotion on his computer screen.

headline: Picking on the Competition
text: IT was Pulitzer Prize Day at The New York Times on Monday. Hundreds had gathered in the third-floor newsroom and around the atrium balcony one floor above. Spouses, parents and children of the winners were there, the mood festive, almost like graduation day. I’m told this is how it goes every year when The Times assembles to receive its annual laurels.

headline: ‘Hopefully, All This Rubbish Can Stop’
text: Celtic and Rangers will renew their ancient rivalry Sunday in Glasgow, days after the revelation that package bombs had been sent to several prominent Celtic supporters and the Celtic manager, Neil Lennon. John F. Burns of the Times checks in with Lennon, who has called the mail bombs “a tipping point,” and with Ranger Manager Walter Smith, who says the Old Firm’s bitter environment has become too toxic to enjoy. Read the full article, and come back here to comment.

headline: Survivors of Priest Abuse Make Proposal to Church
text: At a quiet church in the Sunset district of San Francisco last weekend, about 15 sexual abuse survivors gathered for what they said they thought would be a climactic meeting with the three bishops of the Roman Catholic Church’s Archdiocese of San Francisco.

headline: From Poland, Satellite TV Tries to Pierce the Belarus Media Muzzle
text: WARSAW — It is called Belsat TV, and it is the first and only independent satellite television channel for Belarus, broadcasting news and current affairs as well as cultural and children’s programs like “The Adventures of Uszatek the Bear.”

text: “Quarterback is the highlight of the draft because you’ve got so many teams that would have filled quarterback needs in the off-season,” Casserly said. “Now that they don’t have it, do they become more aggressive trading up? I don’t see the conviction by people with these quarterbacks.”

headline: Cuts Are Threatening Job-Training Efforts
text: Financial struggles forced Brenda Williams to close the small soul food restaurant she had owned on the South Side for six years. Aside from a one-month stint on a construction site, she hasn’t been able to find work in the four years since.

headline: Max Mathews, Pioneer in Making Computer Music, Dies at 84
text: Max Mathews, often called the father of computer music, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 84.

headline: In a Rain of 3-Pointers, the Celtics Come Together
text: Near the end of Boston’s practice Saturday, Paul Pierce lobbed a shot from halfcourt. The ball snapped through the net. “Let’s get out of here,” Pierce said before checking with a cameraman to make sure the moment had been filmed.

headline: Peter Lieberson, Composer Inspired by Buddhism, Dies at 64
text: Peter Lieberson, a searching, inventive American composer whose works were often inspired by his Tibetan Buddhist practice, died on Saturday morning in Tel Aviv, where he had gone for medical treatment. He was 64 and lived in Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: Escaping Violence via the Drill Team, but Not Completely
text: As his team pulled into Dayton, Ohio, at 4 a.m. one day in early April, the head coach of the South Shore Drill Team was confident that his sleepy squad of 15 teenagers from some of Chicago’s toughest neighborhoods had a shot at glory for the first time in nearly 20 years.

headline: Iranian Leader Asserts Power Over President
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Saturday that he remained ready to intervene in the country’s political affairs if the nation’s interests were being “neglected,” continuing a rare public flexing of his power days after a disagreement with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad flared into the open.

headline: Bloggingheads: Growing Pains in Gas Country
text: 8:21 p.m. | Updated The producers of Bloggingheads.TV invited me to join Abrahm Lustgarten of ProPublica in a discussion of the drilling boom aimed at the vast deposits of natural gas identified in deep shale layers and other deposits around North America and, increasingly, the world. Lustgarten is a lead reporter and writer in ProPublica’s ongoing Buried Secrets project on environmental problems related to the gas boom.

headline: In Baltimore, Cano Hits Second to Almost None
text: BALTIMORE — When it was relayed to Robinson Cano on Saturday that he had the second-highest average at Camden Yards since the ballpark opened in 1992, curiosity overcame him. Wondering who surpassed him, Cano correctly guessed the answer — Ichiro Suzuki of Seattle — and then brushed off his success here.

headline: Resistance to Gas Drilling Rises on Unlikely Soil

headline: Special Handling for a Gift in a Fragile Package
text: DOES anyone eat eggs for breakfast anymore? With early risers favoring a regimen of whole grains, fruit and yogurt, eggs have moved to the dinner menu. In local restaurants of the farm-to-table persuasion, eggs are enjoying a kind of vogue as the must-have accessory — served sunny-side up as the sun goes down.

headline: Deferred Dreams Still Resonate in ‘Raisin’ Revival
text: The opening scene of “A Raisin in the Sun” is about waking up in the morning, not wanting to make your bed, politely answering your mother when she asks what you’d like for breakfast and getting into the bathroom fast, because other family members are waiting for it. It’s about your mother telling you to “get your car fare and milk money” out of her purse.

headline: In Vivid Portraiture: Boldface Names of Bygone Era
text: The drama grabs you from across the room: three men confer around a table spread with documents, intent on matters of the utmost urgency and import. Are they contracting a marriage? Planning an insurrection? Concluding a peace treaty?

headline: Gold-Hearted Dames and Benign Crooks
text: When Andréa Burns struts across the stage as the nightclub chanteuse Miss Adelaide in “Guys and Dolls,” now playing in Northport, it’s like trumpets blaring. And when the veteran actor Ken Jennings, as Arvide Abernathy, delivers grandfatherly advice in the ballad “More I Cannot Wish You,” his singing can bring tears to the eyes. The brassy Ms. Burns and the gentle Mr. Jennings embody the heart and soul of the production at the John W. Engeman Theater.

text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Painters and Musicians, Improvising Simultaneously
text: CONCERTS in art museums are nothing unusual, but one in which musicians improvise while an artist creates a painting is a twist on the standard offering. That will happen next Saturday night at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.

headline: The Lure of Green Spaces
text: Every day is Earth Day, in a sense, for Bill Ulfelder, the director of the Nature Conservancy in New York, a job that combines management and fund-raising. He and his family moved to Manhattan, where they live on the Upper West Side, from Denver about two years ago. On Sundays Mr. Ulfelder, 42; his wife, Natalie Aristy, 38, a writer; and their daughter, Isabella, 7, bounce between Riverside Park and Central Park, often with their dog, Willow, a mixed-breed rescue. ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

headline: A Stage Full of Chapins, All Honoring Harry
text: IF the public sometimes gets Tom Chapin’s music mixed up with that of his musical siblings — his brother Steve and his late brother Harry — it comes with the territory, he said. That’s what happens when families gravitate toward a similar sound.

headline: Two-Out Hits and Solid Relief Propel the Mets
text: Daniel Murphy was already receiving applause from a thin crowd on a gray afternoon at Citi Field, but he lustily slammed his hands together eight times when he reached first base in the eighth inning Saturday, as if he were trying to rid his batting gloves of every speck of dirt.

headline: Big Cuts for Magnet Schools in Dallas Stir Conflict Over Spending on Education
text: DALLAS — On a muggy afternoon in mid-April, Mary Ruiz, an animated 18-year-old, bounced through the air-conditioned corridors of her South Dallas high school.

headline: As Usual, Baltimore Brings Out Best in Yanks
text: BALTIMORE — Before Saturday, it had been nine days since the Yankees last glimpsed that elusive celestial body known as the sun, and all the rain and gloom in the interim had made them question its existence.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Some Holes a Prospect Can’t Fill
text: Mike Tanier will provide live analysis of the N.F.L. draft, starting Thursday night. He notes that N.F.L. teams talk about drafting quarterbacks or pass rushers, but they may have more pressing needs:Bills An inhabited region to play in. When future archaeologists excavate the Buffalo area, the pottery shards will reveal that the population disappeared in 1974.Dolphins Some retro-chic offensive gimmick to distract us from how boring the rest of the team is. How about the wishbone option?Patriots Anything except comeuppance. They received plenty of that in the last four years.Jets A Cone of Silence that fits snuggly over team headquarters.Ravens They must draft Pittsburgh running back Deon Lewis and Texas Tech receiver Detron Lewis to fill the roles Jamal Lewis and Jermaine Lewis used to play. For the Ravens, the Super Bowl comes with a three-Lewis minimum.Bengals A magic lantern that grants Carson Palmer wishes. With his luck, the genie will emerge and demand the ball.Browns Peyton Hillis must win the Madden 12 video game cover contest because he is the Butler Bulldogs of meaningless fan balloting.Steelers Videographers for Ben Roethlisberger’s bachelor party. Come to think of it, “The Hangover Part II” opens next month.

headline: Stimulus by Fed Is Disappointing, Economists Say
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s experimental effort to spur a recovery by purchasing vast quantities of federal debt has pumped up the stock market, reduced the cost of American exports and allowed companies to borrow money at lower interest rates.

headline: Palestinian Police Kill Israeli Visiting West Bank Holy Site
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian police shot and killed one Israeli and wounded four others early Sunday after the Israelis surreptitiously visited a Jewish holy site inside a Palestinian-controlled area, officials on both sides said.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 24
text: After President Obama’s authorization of the use of predator drones there, Libya is high on the agenda of the Sunday talk shows. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, appears live from Cairo on CNN’s “State of the Union” and NBC’s “Meet the Press” to discuss his meeting with rebel leaders in Benghazi, Libya. And the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Susan Rice, adds her thoughts on the unrest in Libya on Bloomberg’s “Political Capital.”

headline: In Prague, a Witches’ Night for the Whole Family
text: It would  be easy to mistake April 30 in Prague for a mad, mistimed Halloween, or perhaps even a return to the Middle Ages. Witches cackle through the parks, and effigies are burned atop blazing pyres. But the annual Carodejnice, or Witches’ Night, is a far less sinister tradition than you might think, one rooted in pagan rituals. Burning the effigy witch means goodbye to winter, and the costumed festivities that take place in Prague’s parks are a frantic welcome to spring, featuring concerts, children’s games, and, of course, lots of beer and sausages. Here is a selection.

headline: How to Take Concert Photos That Rock
text: If you think it’s hard to play a Stevie Ray Vaughan-style guitar solo, try photographing one.

headline: QE2 Disappointment (Wonkish)
text: People have been asking me about this article on the disappointing results of the Fed’s quantitative easing. What I would say is that QE2 has been implemented in such a way that there was no reason to expect a lot of traction on the economy; the only channel through which we might have had large effects was via expectations. And that part mainly happened before the policy actually began.

headline: Thailand and Cambodia Clash Again in Border Dispute
text: BANGKOK — Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for a third day on Sunday in the first major territorial encounter since an informal cease-fire that followed four days of fighting in February. At least 10 people were killed and thousands of residents were evacuated from border areas, according to reports from both sides.

headline: Excerpt: 'Born Yesterday'
text: Nina Arianda and Robert Sean Leonard in a scene from the new Broadway revival of the play "Born Yesterday," at the Cort Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: ‘Die Walküre’

headline: China Detains Church Members at Easter Services
text: BEIJING — The authorities stepped up a three-week campaign against an underground Christian church on Sunday, detaining hundreds of congregants in their homes and taking at least 36 others into custody after they tried to hold Easter services in a public square, church members and officials said.

headline: More Syrians Are Missing, Hinting at a Wider Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Dozens of residents have disappeared in Syria since Friday, many of them from the restive city of Homs and towns on the outskirts of the capital, Damascus, human rights activists said Sunday, amid signs that the Syrian government may widen its crackdown on a five-week uprising that has already killed hundreds.

headline: Meaningfully Shopping for Insurance is Next to Impossible
text: That’s the title of a blog post by Nathalie Martin at Credit Slips. It describes just how hard it is for even sophisticated buyers to figure out which company is offering the best deal on such things as home insurance.
