headline: Money Madness
text: I’ve been fond of quoting the late Charles Kindleberger, who used to say that anyone who spends too much time thinking about international money goes mad. (By the way, that’s just what I recall from class; if anyone has an actual reference, I’ be grateful).

headline: The Morning After, Yankees Still Upset
text: BALTIMORE — In a sleepy clubhouse, a burst of excitement came when ESPN showed highlights from the Yankees’ game Saturday night. The image of Joe Girardi standing on the top step of the dugout pumping his fist, in slow motion, after Brett Gardner’s two-run homer in the ninth prompted Nick Swisher to put down his cellphone and seek out his manager — for a hug, a fist bump, something.

headline: Bloomberg Advises Trump to Drop ‘Birther’ Issue
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who once harbored presidential aspirations himself, had some advice on Sunday for another billionaire considering national office: Stay away from the “birther” issue.

headline: Interview: Dennis Lee
text: The director Dennis Lee discusses his film "Jesus Henry Christ," about a child prodigy on the search for his biological father.

headline: Stoudemire Starts Game 4
text: Amar’e Stoudemire started Sunday’s playoff game against the Boston Celtics, despite a sore back that limited him severely in Games 2 and 3 and that threatened to keep him out of Game 4.

headline: McCain Raises Specter of Libyan Stalemate
text: Senator John McCain warned on Sunday that he feared the conflict in Libya was heading toward a “stalemate” and threatened to create a vacuum that could result in Al Qaeda gaining control of the North African country.

headline: A Boozy Word Slinger and His Obscure Objects of Desire
text: Austin McCormick, who runs Company XIV, is a choreographer far less interested in the particularity of movement than in a rambunctious theatricality that deploys dance as part of a sexy, colorful mix of narrative and stage genres. His new “Lover. Muse. Mockingbird. Whore.” at the 303 Bond Street Theater is no different in that way from his “Judgment of Paris” or “Le Serpent Rouge!,” which riffed on various mythological figures and stories.

headline: Tribeca Video Interview: Dennis Lee
text: The comedy “Jesus Henry Christ” provides an offbeat take on the contemporary family. The story revolves around a 10-year-old boy genius (Jason Spevack) who is raised by a single mother (Toni Collette) and goes in search of his biological father.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Role Models Unite
text: So it looks as though the groundwork is being laid for some intriguing final-season plot developments on “Friday Night Lights.” Even though our introduction to her has been brief, Epyck already compels with what is a very clear sense of pained defiance. The Taylors’ role in Dillon, Tex., has always been to serve as de facto parents to all the lost children, and Epyck, with her 46 school absences and other issues, seems to be presenting herself as a master challenge.

headline: Baseball According to Beckett: A Game That Wouldn’t End
text: In April 1981, in a dumpy stadium in blue-collar Pawtucket, R.I., two minor-league baseball teams played one of the strangest games in history: 32 unbroken innings beginning in twilight on Holy Saturday and pausing, more than eight hours later, near dawn on Easter Sunday. The Pawtucket Red Sox and the Rochester Red Wings were tied 2-2 when the umpires were finally ordered to set aside the rule book — which, because of a preseason clerical error, omitted the usual curfew — and suspend play until a later date.

headline: Italy’s Team Brings Home the Yeh Cup
text: The 20th Yeh Bros. Cup, a prestigious invitational team tournament, was held in Wuxi, China, about a 90-minute drive from Shanghai, last Monday to Friday.

headline: Play That Funky Laptop, Wiry Boy
text: There have been fewer more bizarre, more distracting and more of-the-moment musical artifacts in the last year than the videos of Nike7UP. Haze, collage, abstraction: all the central tenets of the recent array of Internet-centric and Internet-native electronic music were captured therein. His clips are either goofy, mashed-up nostalgia or careful pieces of cultural assemblage. They jump among cats pounding at computers, girls in soft focus, conflagrations, metal-heads, war footage and flying birds. It’s all soundtracked with heavily chopped-up samples of R&B and pop songs, overlaid with rumbling drones and percussion. What does it all mean? Has the need for meaning been obviated altogether?

headline: Conductor Says Orchestra Is a Phantom
text: The Web site photograph depicted an elegant array of orchestra musicians in a glowing hall. A video clip showed an earnest young conductor leading players in a Tchaikovsky symphony. Below the picture, an official biography described the “Tschaikowski” St. Petersburg State Orchestra as “an ensemble with unlimited musical possibilities.”

headline: Bloomberg Warns Trump on ‘Birther Issue’
text: The Times’s City Room blog reports that New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has some advice for Donald Trump: don’t keep pushing the “birther” issue raising questions about whether President Obama was born in the United States.

headline: Disaster, Disasterer, Disasterest
The Warrior, the Maiden, the Whole Schmear
text: You would think we had enough 19th-century-style ballets with incomprehensible stories and unbelievable characters, in which war is an excuse for dancing in hot pants, exotic maidens bare their midriffs, and love conquers all. But apparently not. On Saturday night, at the Baruch Performing Arts Center, the Lumière Ballet presented “El Cid,” choreographed by its director Venti Petrov, and set to a compilation of music by Jules Massenet.

headline: He’s a Bit Old-Fashioned
text: There are many good things about the ballet programs put on by Avi Scher, whose mission is to present world-class dancers in intimate, affordable settings. Saturday night’s program at the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater boasted reasonably priced student tickets, live music and the chance to be feet away from the likes of Carla Körbes, Misa Kuranaga, Tyler Angle and Sofiane Sylve.

headline: Treasures Pose Ethics Issues for Smithsonian
text: Amid mounting calls by scientists for the Smithsonian Institution to cancel a planned exhibition of Chinese artifacts salvaged from a shipwreck, the institution will hold a meeting on Monday afternoon to hear from critics.

headline: Diving Into the Past, but Definitely Still in the Present
text: Sean Combs was dancing: slow, deliberate, slightly awkward movements on a big stage, illuminated only by angelic light from the screen above, which was flashing slow-motion clips of the Notorious B.I.G., a k a Biggie Smalls.

headline: Well-Connected Evacuees of Texas Wildfire Turn to Internet
text: MINERAL WELLS, Tex. — When wildfires threatened the upscale community at Possum Kingdom Lake just west of here a week ago, the residents were desperate for, among other things, better cellphone service.

headline: Lover and Muse
text: Scenes from Austin McCormick’s dance-theater piece.

headline: A Fractious Family With Cancer on the Agenda
text: Spike Lee may have a problem with Tyler Perry — the two have been having a public war of words — but Mr. Perry’s longtime studio, Lionsgate, certainly doesn’t. It just signed him to another three years. It’s not surprising: Mr. Perry has consistently shown Hollywood the magnitude of an underserved black female audience as no other director has, and now studios are struggling to keep up (for example the coming “Jumping the Broom”). The relationship between Mr. Lee and Mr. Perry is fascinatingly inverse: male-skewing perspective versus female; Northern sensibility versus Southern; jazz-rap orientation versus gospel-R&B. Fortunately it’s a big movie tent. But in box office Mr. Perry is winning.

headline: Honoring a Composer and His Wide-Ranging Interests
text: It is easier said than done to organize a tribute concert for Gunther Schuller. What exactly will you pay tribute to?

headline: All Guitar, and a Little Comic Relief in Unexpected Places
text: The Cuban composer Leo Brouwer has written prolifically for orchestra and chamber ensembles as well as for film. (His most famous work, to American filmgoers, is the score for “Like Water for Chocolate.”) But he is also an accomplished guitarist, and he has contributed a huge number of inspired works to his instrument’s repertory. By the mid-1970s several of his pieces — “Elogio de la Danza” (1964), “Canticum” (1968) and “La Espiral Eterna” (1971) — were part of the canon, and he has continued to write generously for colleagues.

headline: MoMA Competition Seeks Better American Housing
text: Five teams of architects will rethink housing in the United States in light of the foreclosure crisis in a 14-month program to be announced on Monday by the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA P.S. 1. Each team will focus on a “megaregion,” a metropolitan area between two major cities. Amale Andraos and Dan Wood of Work Architecture Company will focus on Portland, Ore.; Michael Bell of Columbia University on Temple Terrace, Fla.; Jeanne Gang of Studio Gang on Cicero, Ill.; Hilary Sample and Michael Meredith of MOS on the Oranges in New Jersey; and Andrew Zago of Zago Architecture on Rialto, Calif. The program, “Foreclosed: Rehousing the American Dream,” was organized by Barry Bergdoll, MoMA’s chief curator of architecture, and Reinhold Martin, director of Columbia University’s Temple Hoyne Buell Center for the Study of American Architecture. A four-month workshop phase is to begin May 7 with a public symposium at MoMA P.S. 1, where the public can view the work in progress on June 18 and Sept. 17. Completed proposals will be exhibited at MoMA from Jan. 31 through July 31, 2012. “New paradigms of architecture and regional and transportation planning could well be the silver lining in the crisis of home ownership,” Mr. Bergdoll said in a statement. “Foreclosed” is the second part of MoMA’s “Issues in Contemporary Architecture” series. The first, in 2009, was “Rising Currents,” which addressed New York City’s water levels.

headline: Party Continues for ‘Rio’
text: North American audiences spent about $138 million on movie tickets during the Easter weekend, a 39 percent increase from the same three days last year (which were not a holiday), according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. “Rio,” an animated 3-D film from 20th Century Fox, was No. 1 for the second weekend in a row with an estimated $26.8 million in sales ($81.3 million total). “Tyler Perry’s Madea’s Big Happy Family,” released by Lionsgate, underperformed in second place with about $25.8 million, about 38 percent lower than the opening weekend in 2009 for the previous entry in this franchise, “Tyler Perry’s Madea Goes to Jail.” (But “Big Happy Family” cost only about $25 million to make.) The $40 million drama “Water for Elephants” (Fox) did better than some analysts had predicted, at $17.5 million for third place. The Easter-bunny-theme film “Hop” (Universal Pictures) was fourth with an estimated $12.5 million for a four-week total of about $100.5 million. “Scream 4” (the Weinstein Company) rounded out the Top 5 with about $7.2 million for a two-week total of $31.2 million.

headline: To Be in 3-D: Alec Baldwin in ‘Hamlet’
text: Alec Baldwin is set to appear in August at one of the theater world’s leading events, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, playing the ghost of Hamlet’s father. But he won’t be there to deliver his performances. With a busy summer that includes filming the movie version of the Broadway show “Rock of Ages” and preparing for a sixth season of “30 Rock,” Mr. Baldwin, above, will tape his scenes as Old Hamlet’s ghost for the New York-based Fundamental Theater Project’s fringe production “3D Hamlet: A Lost Generation,” said Fundamental’s artistic director, Sam Underwood. Mr. Baldwin and Mr. Underwood starred in a production of “Equus” last summer in East Hampton, N.Y. Mr. Underwood, who will alternate in the role of Hamlet with Anthony Rapp (“Rent”), said in an interview that “3D Hamlet” would blend multimedia elements with Shakespeare’s text “to create an interactive perspective for the audience and a feeling that they are part of the action.” Mr. Underwood said he was looking into using a 3-D camera to record Mr. Baldwin’s scenes, which audience members would watch through special glasses. Kate Mulgrew (“Star Trek: Voyager”) will also star in the production as Hamlet’s mother, Gertrude. Mr. Underwood, who said he was directing and producing the work with fellow Fundamental members, said the play would have a short run in New York in July.

headline: Monday: Old Spice Alternative
text: Congratulations to Jeffrey Schwartz of New York City, winner of the third annual Boston Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and to Matt Matera and Jan O’Sullivan, the 2nd and 3rd place finalists in the overall division!

headline: Powerhouse Announces Next Season of New Plays
text: Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater, the creators of “Spring Awakening,” will team up with the director Moisés Kaufman (“33 Variations”) for a workshop production of “Nightingale,” a new musical based on the classic story by Hans Christian Andersen, as part of Powerhouse Theater’s 27th season. New York Stage and Film and Vassar College produce this festival of new plays, which begins on June 29 with “F2M” by Patricia Wettig, best known for her television roles on “Thirtysomething” and “Brothers and Sisters.” “F2M,” the story of Parker, a college freshman whose search for her identity is stalled when her famous parents show up for an unexpected visit, will feature a cast that includes Phoebe Strole (“The Metal Children”), Keira Keeley (“The Glass Menagerie”), Deirdre O’Connell (“Circle Mirror Transformation”) and Ken Olin, one of Ms. Wettig’s “Thirtysomething” co-stars. Other season highlights include a workshop of “Margaret and Craig,” by David Solomon, with Mario Cantone (“Sex and the City,” “Assassins”) and Marin Ireland (“reasons to be pretty”); and readings of new plays by Mona Mansour, whose “Urge for Going” just finished a run at the Public Theater’s Lab series, and John Patrick Shanley.

headline: Footnote
text: Paul Reiser’s return to network television ended quickly last week when NBC canceled “The Paul Reiser Show” after two episodes, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The debut episode attracted only 3.3 million viewers, and the second one did even worse. At a news conference last week Mr. Reiser told The Hollywood Reporter that the show had been rushed. “This was the shortest ramp-up in the history of television,” he said.

headline: Protesters Distrust Deal for Yemen Leader to Quit
text: Street demonstrators and youth leaders voiced skepticism on Sunday over an offer by President Ali Abdullah Saleh to leave office in 30 days after agreeing to a plan that would grant him and his sons immunity from prosecution for any crimes, saying they did not trust his intention to step down and would continue their protests.

headline: Lawmakers Seek to Unclog Road to Confirmation
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to unclog the Senate and spare scores of presidential appointees from what is often a grueling confirmation process, leading lawmakers in both parties are moving to cut the number of administration posts that are subject to Senate approval.

headline: Deficit Cutting: Who Bears the Burden?
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Eventful Day, Yankees’ Offense Does Just Enough for the Victory
text: BALTIMORE — Call it a coincidence, but storm clouds started forming above Camden Yards on Sunday just about the time the Yankees’ game against Baltimore started losing all semblance of normalcy. An exasperating, exhilarating final two and a half innings followed, and after a series of dramatic moments and a 40-minute rain delay, the ending to the Yankees’ 6-3 victory proved rather anticlimactic.

headline: Wrong Lady on the Stamp
text: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks Fall, but Not Without a Fight
text: A cold inevitability fell over Madison Square Garden late Sunday afternoon. The Knicks protested, pushed back against it and nearly chased it off for one more day, until their last burst of bravado finally buckled under an unforgiving avalanche of green.

headline: Homering at Home, Wright Powers the Mets
text: David Wright certainly hit the baseball hard enough in his third at-bat Sunday, but he was sure it would curve foul. Wright, the Mets’ third baseman, has become the foremost expert on how many home runs Citi Field takes away, on how no one can start a home run trot early.

headline: Election Fuels Deadly Clashes in Nigeria
text: The death toll and destruction from a wave of election-related violence in Nigeria last week may exceed similar outbursts of the past, though the underlying causes remain the same, experts said.

headline: Helping the Fishermen
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wal-Mart Tests Service for Buying Food Online
text: Wal-Mart has begun testing an online grocery delivery service, called Wal-Mart to Go, in the San Jose, Calif., area.

headline: Struggling St. Louis Airport Takes a Shot to the Chin, but Recovers
text: ST. LOUIS — The gleaming Gateway Arch that presides over the downtown riverfront may be the architectural symbol for this Midwestern metropolis, but its true gateway was built a decade earlier just outside city limits — the Lambert-St. Louis International Airport.

headline: A Voice for N.F.L. Retirees Amid the Din
text: NEWARK — George Martin, an 11th-round draft pick, played 14 seasons for the Giants, made captain, won a Super Bowl. Martin the philanthropist raised millions for charity, even walked across the country, through 3,000 miles and 24 pairs of shoes, from the George Washington Bridge to San Diego. Martin the businessman never held a position lower than vice president.

headline: Message on the Subway
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Galleon Case, Spotlight on Rajat Gupta
text: Throughout Raj Rajaratnam’s trial, which could go to the jury as soon as Monday, there has been an elephant in the courtroom: Rajat K. Gupta.

headline: The Thinking Man’s Slugger
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The most dangerous fastball hitter in baseball came to the plate as the go-ahead run with two outs in the ninth inning last Tuesday at Tropicana Field. Paul Konerko of the Chicago White Sox fouled off four pitches from the Tampa Bay Rays’ James Shields, who commanded his repertory all night.

headline: Effect of Oil Price on Earnings Fades
text: First-quarter earnings, due this week for several big United States oil companies, are set to emit a positive glow. But even the stocks that should be most responsive to oil prices, like Chevron and Hess, no longer seem to be tracking higher.

headline: Flying the Flag, Fleeing the State
text: Leeds, England

headline: Corporate Taxes Enter Debt Debate
text: The Obama administration is preparing to inject an unpredictable new variable into its economic policy clash with Republicans: a plan to overhaul corporate taxes.

headline: Berber Rebels in Libya’s West Face Long Odds Against Qaddafi
text: DHIBA BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia — For decades, the remote mountains of western Libya have simmered with resentment. An enclave of the Berber minority, mistrusted and neglected by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s Arab nationalist government, the region’s isolated hamlets were among the first to join the uprising, raising the rebel flag on the first day of the revolt.

headline: Let’s Take a Hike
text: When I listen to current discussions of the federal budget, the message I hear sounds like this: We’re in crisis! We must take drastic action immediately! And we must keep taxes low, if not actually cut them further!

headline: Islam and Democracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Libyan Rebels Say They Have Control of Misurata
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Rebel leaders said they had consolidated their control of the western city of Misurata on Sunday, taking over the last two government outposts there even as government forces continued to shell the city from its outskirts.

headline: In a Life Filled With Firsts, One More
text: WESTON, Fla. — Open lunchboxes are sprawled on the kitchen counter. Four dogs dart in and out. And three children rummage through backpacks. With the predawn bedlam at its height, the harried mother asks: Do you have your baseball glove? What do you want for a snack? How about the form I have to sign?

headline: For Students Raised on iPods, Lessons in Bridge
text: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y. — Four bridge players stared down at their cards, trying to determine which team would play the role of the so-called declarer and dummy.

headline: Private Barnes and the Saviors of Washington
text: With President Lincoln looking on from the White House portico, a crack regiment of volunteer Northern soldiers marched along Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, D.C., with parade-ground precision, resplendent in tailored gray uniforms trimmed in black. Nearly 1,000 bayonet-tipped muskets pointed into the spring sky and glimmered in the sun. Lincoln smiled.

headline: Rangers Assess a Season to Grow On
text: Are the Rangers a young team on the upswing? Or are they the same mediocre team in a new guise?

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Truck Drivers in Shanghai Plan to Resume Protests
text: SHANGHAI — A group of truck drivers who helped stage a three-day strike here last week over rising oil prices and high government fees said Sunday that they planned to resume their demonstrations this week, despite this city’s promise to eliminate some freight transportation fees and reduce others.

headline: Google, a Giant in Mobile Search, Seeks New Ways to Make It Pay
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In early 2008, in the early days of the iPhone era, Google engineers began noticing something unusual in the search engine’s logs. Owners of these new phones were doing a huge number of Web searches.

headline: Norio Ohga, Who Led Sony Beyond Electronics, Dies at 81
text: Norio Ohga, a onetime opera singer who plunged into consumer electronics, shaped the development of the compact disc, and rose to become chairman and chief executive of the Sony Corporation, died on Saturday in Tokyo. He was 81.

headline: Classified Files Offer New Insights Into Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — A trove of more than 700 classified military documents provides new and detailed accounts of the men who have done time at the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba, and offers new insight into the evidence against the 172 men still locked up there.

headline: President Obama and the Peace Process
text: President Obama began his presidency vowing to negotiate an Israeli-Palestinian peace. He backed off in the face of both sides’ obstinacy and after a series of diplomatic missteps. Since then, the stalemate, and the mistrust, have only deepened, and it is clear that nothing good will happen until the United States fully engages.

headline: Multiple Inequities
text: For a generation, in one of the law’s gross inequities that has fallen unduly on African-Americans, 1 gram of crack cocaine was treated the same as 100 grams of powder cocaine in federal courts. It didn’t matter that the theory behind the law that crack — cocaine cooked in baking powder — was somehow more addictive and led to more violent crime soon proved false.

headline: A Note to Readers: The Background
text: The articles published today are based on more than 700 classified files on past and present detainees at the Guantánamo Bay prison, including the government’s assessment of the dangers the individuals represent. The files are from February 2002 to January 2009, and some of the information may have been superseded by later, still undisclosed assessments made by the Obama administration or by more highly classified documents.

headline: A Statement by the United States Government
text: “It is unfortunate that The New York Times and other news organizations have made the decision to publish numerous documents obtained illegally by Wikileaks concerning the Guantanamo detention facility. These documents contain classified information about current and former GTMO detainees, and we strongly condemn the leaking of this sensitive information.

headline: Judging Detainees’ Risk, Often With Flawed Evidence
As Acts of War or Despair, Suicides Rattle a Prison
text: WASHINGTON — By October 2004, two years into his detention at the Guantánamo Bay prison, Ali Abdullah Ahmed had established a corrosive reputation among prison officials. Mr. Ahmed’s classified file said he was a hunger striker, “completely uncooperative with interrogators,” and “had a history of aggressive behavior in the camp, often defiantly failing to comply with instructions.”

headline: Libyan, Once a Detainee, Is Now a U.S. Ally of Sorts
text: DARNAH, Libya — For more than five years, Abu Sufian Ibrahim Ahmed Hamuda bin Qumu was a prisoner at the Guantánamo Bay prison, judged “a probable member of Al Qaeda” by the analysts there. They concluded in a newly disclosed 2005 assessment that his release would represent a “medium to high risk, as he is likely to pose a threat to the U.S., its interests and allies.”

headline: U.S. Networks Add Britons to Royal Wedding Coverage
text: In November, when the “save the date” was circulated for Prince William and Kate Middleton’s wedding, Elena Nachmanoff immediately booked a trip to London. She was going shopping — for royalty experts.

headline: App-omattox: The Civil War Goes Virtual
text: It’s Day 10. The North has sustained 52 casualties; the South 3. I’m not exhausted at all. Nor hungry. What I am is entertained and slightly anxious. I may even have a touch of “period rush,” as Civil War re-enactors call the intoxication of time-travel. I’ve become spellbound by the History channel’s brilliant-creepy Civil War Today app.

headline: The House Strikes, and Wins, Again
text: In another House-engineered setback for the environment, the compromise budget approved by Congress and the White House prohibits the Interior Department from spending any money to carry out a policy protecting unspoiled federal lands.

headline: Good Enough to Please Dolan, if Not to Win
text: While no miracle resurrection, the overall result was not all that dissatisfactory for the Knicks from the organizational point of view. Behind their emotional leader, Amar’e Stoudemire, they pushed the Celtics on Sunday just enough to earn a season-ending ovation in the dying seconds of a four-game sweep.

headline: Follow the Really Big Money
text: Things are going well for the wealthy. The top income tax rate is lower than at nearly any time since the 1930s. President Obama, who promised to repeal Bush-era tax cuts for the wealthy, agreed to extend them for another two years. And Republicans are pushing to slash trillions in public programs in order to cut the top rate more.

headline: For Celtics, Big Tests Are Yet to Come
text: Doc Rivers handled his seasoned roster last year like a jalopy that was hiding a new engine. He carefully rested the core as losses piled up before pulling back the hood in the playoffs, unveiling an energized and united group, and arriving at the doorstep of another championship.

headline: Civic Group Says Concessions Are Needed From the Construction Unions
text: A prominent civic group has joined builders and real estate executives in calling for major concessions from the unions that dominate the construction industry, saying cuts are needed to allow major projects to move forward.

headline: Syrian Crisis Tests the Mettle of Its Autocratic Ruler
text: CAIRO — For years, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has nourished a reputation as a youthful and forward-looking leader in a region full of aging autocrats, a man who might yet reform the repressive police state he inherited from his father, given time and opportunity.

headline: Pursued All Season, Heat May Encounter One Battle Too Many
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: War, in Life and Death
text: Tim Hetherington was a war photographer in every regard. Tall, brutally handsome and modest, he had a British accent plucked from a Graham Greene novel and the body fat of a Diet Coke.

headline: On Easter, a Sermon of Rebirth, and a Rally for Rights
text: Packed inside St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Sunday, nearly 3,000 people from around the world gathered to hear Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan deliver his Easter homily.

headline: A Case for Hell
text: Here’s a revealing snapshot of religion in America. On Easter Sunday, two of the top three books on Amazon.com’s Religion and Spirituality best-seller list mapped the geography of the afterlife. One was “Heaven Is for Real: A Little Boy’s Astounding Story of His Trip to Heaven and Back,” an account of a 4-year-old’s near-death experience as dictated to his pastor father. The other was “Love Wins: A Book About Heaven, Hell, and the Fate of Every Person Who Ever Lived,” in which the evangelical preacher Rob Bell argues that hell might not exist.

headline: Who Gave Amen Corner Its Name? Read On
text: If returning to the golf course in sun and warmth is the greatest joy of a new golf season, then an attendant delight is welcoming the latest contributions to the legacy of elegant, instructive, engaging books on golf.

headline: Charter School Space: Free of Rent, Maybe, but Not of Hurdles
text: After Matthew Greenberg had spent 18 years as a New York City teacher, he wanted a school of his own and decided to try opening a charter.

headline: Risks Aside, Ticket-Fixing Has Persisted for Decades
text: In 1951, police officers in Manhattan’s 20th Precinct were investigated for sabotaging paperwork to kill traffic citations, as favors for politicians. In the middle of the inquiry, the ledger recording all the precinct’s summonses mysteriously disappeared.

headline: In Sing Sing’s Hometown, Many Dream of Day ‘the Big House’ Closes
text: OSSINING, N.Y. — In economically ailing communities in upstate New York, residents and lawmakers are bracing themselves for bad news: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s list of prisons that will be closed to save money.

headline: English-Language Press Flexing Its Muscles in Eastern Europe
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Brian Bonner, the editor of The Kyiv Post, a small English-language newspaper here in the Ukrainian capital, received the first phone call even before his journalists had returned from their interview with the minister of agriculture. Other calls followed, growing increasingly shrill.

headline: Early Birds Less Likely to Catch the Birdies
text: Do you love being the first one on the golf course? Are you delighted to send that first tee shot into the glow of a rising sun?

headline: In a Place of Fragile Alliances, a Romance Endures
text: ALBANY — Spring is in the air in the capital. A budget is in hand. Lawmakers have fled for their districts. And Jeffrey D. Klein has taken a State Senate colleague, Diane J. Savino, home to meet mom.

headline: Daffy Blonde Gets Wise to Washington
text: A piercing squawk ricochets around the theater, followed by bright peals of girlish giggling. In counterpoint comes a rumbling bellow at a volume requiring no help from the electronic listening devices that are almost as ubiquitous as cellphones in Broadway theaters.

headline: A Trial Run for School Standards That Encourage Deeper Thought
text: Until this year, Ena Baxter, an English teacher at Hillcrest High School in Queens, would often have her 10th graders compose papers by summarizing a single piece of reading material.

headline: Civic Group Says That Concessions Are Needed From the Construction Unions

headline: Holiday Parking Rules
text: Because of the seventh and eighth days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: One Size Fits Nobody: Seeking a Steady 4 or a 10
text: In one store, you’re a Size 4, in another a Size 8, and in another a Size 10 — all without gaining an ounce.

headline: Scuffle Over On-Demand Movies Portends Battles to Come
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood is picking sides for its first all-out brawl since its writers’ labor feud in 2007. And oddly, Christopher J. Dodd, once a powerful senator from Connecticut and now the film studios’ chief spokesman, has mostly been out of the fray.

text: April 24, 2011

headline: The Battle for Libya
text: Rebel leaders said they had consolidated their control of the western city of Misurata on Sunday, taking over the last two government outposts there even as government forces continued to shell the city from its outskirts.

headline: A Fight Over How Drugs Are Pitched
text: Before pharmaceutical company marketers call on a doctor, they do their homework. These salespeople typically pore over electronic profiles bought from data brokers, dossiers that detail the brands and amounts of drugs a particular doctor has prescribed. It is a marketing practice that some health care professionals have come to hate.

headline: DVRs Give More Shows a Lifeline
text: The digital video recorder was supposed to lay waste to network television. Instead the playback device is offering some shows a lifeline — so much so that network programmers now factor in ratings a full week after a show’s scheduled appearance.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 23, 2011

headline: Knicks Replay: April 24
text: Images from Game 4 of the Knicks-Celtics playoff series.

headline: The Travel Channel Invests $7.5 Million in Oyster.com
text: The Travel Channel may inspire a viewer to book a weekend on Martha’s Vineyard or a getaway to Monaco. But when that trip is taken, the transaction fees wind up in some other pocket.

headline: Filtering the Social Web to Present News Items
text: SAN FRANCISCO — News events as varied as the commercial jet landing in the Hudson River and the uprisings in Egypt have demonstrated that people armed with cellphones — not professional reporters — are often the first source of breaking news, uploading Twitter posts, photos and video to the Web. But the result can leave people drowning in too much information.

headline: The Government’s Guide to Assessing Prisoners
text: These three documents were designed to guide military intelligence interrogators and analysts at Guantanamo as they attempted to assess what detainees had done in the past and what risk they might pose in the future. The “Assessment of Afghanistan Travels” — which lists the online encyclopedia Wikipedia as one source — offers background on Afghanistan and Islam and examples of how some detainees may have been trained to resist interrogation. The two “Threat Matrix” documents were aids to gauging whether a prisoner, on release, might pose a a high, medium or low risk to American interests.

headline: Taliban Breach Afghan Prison; Hundreds Free
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Taliban leaders carried out an audacious plot on Monday to free nearly 500 fighters from southern Afghanistan’s largest prison, leading them through a tunnel dug over more than five months and equipped with electricity and air pipes, which suggested that the insurgents remained formidable and wily opponents despite recent setbacks.

headline: Why Do Doubts Persist About Where President Obama Was Born?

Why do you think doubts about Mr. Obama’s status as a natural-born citizen of the United States persist despite factual evidence?

headline: Syria Escalates Crackdown as Tanks Go to Restive City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army stormed the restive city of Dara’a with tanks and soldiers and helped detain dozens in towns across the country Monday in an escalation of the crackdown on Syria’s five-week-old uprising, according to residents and human rights activists. They said at least 25 people had been killed in Dara’a, with reports of bodies strewn in the streets.

headline: Great Little Magazines
text: For years, Robert Scholes,  a professor in the department of modern culture and media at Brown University, has led a project to put Modernist journals online,  which means you can have access to many of the period’s wonderful journals without being a student at a university with great archival holdings. So far, Scholes and his team (which includes Sean Latham at the University of Tulsa) have digitized 18 magazines: all 47 issues of The Freewoman and all 13 of The New Freewoman, an early feminist journal that espoused free love; the first nine volumes of the Little Review, which published 13 episodes of Joyce’s “Ulysses,” before being forced to stop due to obscenity charges, and, under the aegis of Pound as “foreign editor,” such writers as Djuna Barnes, Gertrude Stein and T.S. Eliot; the two issues of  Wyndham Lewis’s vorticist zine Blast;  the more visual Rhythm, which published several designs for the Ballets Russes, among them “L’après-midi d’un faune”; as well as such well-known journals as Scribner’s Magazine. Currently, the MJP is working on digitizing  The Crisis, the journal founded by W.E. B. Dubois for the then fledgling N.A.A.C.P. It ran from 1910 to 1924, with many hiatuses, but had an unusually wide audience for a little magazine: its circulation peaked at 100,000.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review ‘Jerusalem’
text: Readers’ reviews of Jez Butterworth’s new play “Jerusalem,” which opened on Broadway on Thursday night, were sharply divided. While Mark Rylance received almost across-the-board praise for his portrayal of the carefree, trailer-dwelling Johnny Byron (a performance Ben Brantley called “seismic”), many readers said the script failed to match its star’s wattage. headline: Café des Artistes Is Back, as Leopard des Artistes
text: Gianfranco and Paula Bolla Sorrentino, who own Il Gattopardo in Midtown, took no time deciding to acquire the Café des Artistes when George and Jenifer Lang announced in August of 2009 that they were closing it  after nearly 25 years. Now, after a mega renovation, including expert restoration of the nine Howard Chandler Christy murals, “Fantasy Scenes with Naked Beauties,” that were painted from the late 1920s to 1935, the restaurant is poised to open on May 2 as the Leopard at des Artistes.

headline: Speaking of International Money (Wonkish)

Now, Pearlstein isn’t crazy the way the goldbugs are — but he does seem to share the common tendency to exaggerate the importance of owning a global currency.

headline: Reaction to ‘The Guantanamo Files’
text: In a package of articles called The Guantánamo Files, a team of my colleagues reports today on the release of more than 700 classified military documents that provide new and detailed accounts of the men who have done time at the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba, and offer new insight into the evidence against the 172 men still locked up there. The Guantánamo files were part of a huge trove of documents leaked last year to the anti-secrecy organization WikiLeaks. They were made available to The New York Times by another source on the condition of anonymity. National Public Radio and the British newspaper The Guardian are also producing reports based on the documents. Read more about the background in this Note to Readers.

headline: Tribeca Q&A: ‘The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye’
text: Love may come in many forms, but it has never quite taken the shape seen in Marie Losier‘s documentary “The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye,” which makes its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday. This film chronicles the lives of Genesis P-Orridge, the experimental artist and musician from the bands Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, and her partner, Lady Jaye, who expressed their unity by becoming near-duplicates of each other. The art experiment, in which the couple underwent plastic surgery to create a single, androgynous sexual identity, began in 2003, and continued even after Lady Jaye died in 2007.

To be fair, some of the supportive comments have also gotten too ugly for the Times. So while there won’t be any banning of commenters, I’m going to try to delete comments whose tone goes over the line.

In addition to regulars like Garth Fagan Dance, Momix and Complexions Contemporary Ballet, and flamenco and tango performances, the season will feature a Martha Clarke work, “Angel Reapers,” created in collaboration with the playwright Alfred Uhry (Nov. 29-Dec. 11), and the return of a Christopher Wheeldon-less Morphoses, with the premiere of “Bacchae,” from the company’s new resident artistic director, Luca Veggetti (Oct. 25-30). The Houston dancers will bring a new work by Jorma Elo (Oct. 11-16), while the Washington-based Farrell company will be dancing an all-Balanchine program (Oct. 19-23). More information is available at joyce.org.

headline: Bold Type | Sofía Sanchez Barrenechea
text: It is fairly safe to assume that Sofía Sanchez Barrenechea’s apartment is the only one in the West Village with a floor-to-ceiling view of Patagonia. Sanchez Barrenechea, a 25-year-old graphic designer who grew up in Buenos Aires, decorated an entire wall with a mural she created from a photo of the lake where her family spent their summers. “It’s the first thing I see when I wake up,” she says. The rest of the apartment is best described as urban eclectic — furnished with things scavenged from flea markets or, in the case of a favorite chair, found on the street. An art director at Lloyd & Company working with beauty and fashion brands, Sanchez Barrenechea nearly had a career as a model, but she’s more content to operate behind the scenes. “Friday nights when I’m bored, I play with Photoshop,” she says.

headline: For a Sex Survey, Privacy Goes a Long Way
text: It is not easy to ask people about their sex lives, and getting honest answers may be even harder. But there are ways to do it. One good method is to have a computer ask the questions, while the interviewee listens through earphones and enters the answers on the screen — without the intervention, or even the presence, of another human.

headline: For the Record
text: Indie record shops generally look like Championship Vinyl, the music-geek hangout owned by John Cusack in “High Fidelity,” which is to say the closest they get to décor is the album covers on the wall. “Everyone asks why we don’t have records on the wall,” says Ian Marshall, the co-owner, along with his wife, Jade Gordon, of L.A.’s Wombleton Records. “It’s like it’s some sort of requirement. But when we opened the store we knew we’d be spending a lot of time here and that’s not really the kind of environment we wanted to be in.” Instead, the couple has created a used-record shop that resembles a Victorian parlor, right down to the embossed wallpaper and potted plants. Marshall, a self-described Anglophile who grew up outside of Toronto but spent his school holidays visiting family in Britain, wanted the Highland Park store to have an English feel, a conceit that extends to its name, a play on the popular British children’s books (and later a BBC series) about the Wombles. To get Wombleton’s 19th-century ambience just right, the couple spent hours trawling eBay for vintage furniture and prevailed upon friends like David Donohue, a graphic designer and surf board builder who made the harpsichord-shaped record bins, and Nic Taylor and Jennifer Brandt-Taylor of Thunderwing Press, who created the store’s logo, a stagecoach on LP wheels. “Which is very apt,” Marshall says. “We spend a lot of time in foreign countries, driving around in rental cars looking for records.” But perhaps the most refreshing quality about Wombleton is its lack of snobbery. Unlike Barry and Dick (Jack Black and Todd Louima), “the musical moron twins” who staffed Championship Vinyl, Marshall and Gordon, who stock an eclectic mix of British pop from the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s, won’t deride your taste. “I’m a bottom feeder,” Marshall says, laughing. “I like crap. I’m not afraid to buy the 50-cent disco album that nobody wants.”

headline: After 3-0 Deficit, Blackhawks Believe

Jay, partner and global executive creative director at Wieden & Kennedy; and Joe Pytka, the commercial director and filmmaker. headline: Warning, Warning: Alternate-Side Returns Wednesday
text: As the Passover season draws to a close, we need to clear something up about the 11th plague, also known as alternate-side parking rules. They are suspended Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Who Made Those Colors?
text: Hot pink, bright blue and fluorescent green, among other vivid tones, denote a palette reminiscent of psychedelic posters, subversive fashion and the majority of all things created between 1980 and 1989. Although fluorescent colors exist naturally with certain minerals, it wasn’t until the 1940s that those colors were developed so that they could be seen as vividly during the day as they could under an ultraviolet light.

headline: Campaign Says ‘Cheers’ to Expanding a Regional Favorite

headline: HSBC Drops Out of Retail Banking in Russia
text: MOSCOW — HSBC on Monday became the latest foreign bank to pull out of retail banking in Russia as large state-owned banks have come to dominate a business that had been expected to provide a rich growth opportunity for foreign institutions.

headline: High School Classes May Be Advanced in Name Only
text: More students are taking ambitious courses. According to a recent Department of Education study, the percentage of high school graduates who signed up for rigorous-sounding classes nearly tripled over the past two decades.

headline: Beyond the Climate Blame Game

headline: Thyroid Fears Aside, That X-Ray’s Worth It
text: It doesn’t take much to scare people when it comes to cancer, especially when the cause, unlike smoking, seems beyond one’s control.

headline: Nostalgia Wrapped In Steel
text: Architecture is a notoriously slow profession. Mastering all the elements that go into designing a building — scale and context, material and form, the structure needed to hold the building up — takes a lifetime. And clients investing millions of dollars in a project tend to feel safer around someone with a little gray around the temples.

headline: RBS Executive to Join Bank of America
text: Jennifer Hill, a top executive at the Royal Bank of Scotland and a former Goldman Sachs managing director, will soon become the chief financial officer for Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s investment bank, according to people familiar with the decision.

headline: On First Day Back, Injured ‘Spider-Man’ Performer Says He Can’t Wait to Fly Again

It was his first day back in the show.

headline: Study of Vision Tackles a Philosophy Riddle
text: If a blind person were suddenly able to see, would he be able to recognize by sight the shape of an object he previously knew only by touch? Presented with a cube and a globe, could he tell which was which just by looking?

headline: The School of Ohne Titel
text: Jessica Yuen is the 25-year-old designer behind Bedford Street Laundry. Genevieve Fernety, also 25, designs Agamic with her partner Mikey Wydra. Yuen gravitates toward the architectural but with a feminine touch, as in a crisscrossing vest or body-conscious corset with a flouncy skirt. Fernety’s line, which is unisex, is built on pieces like color-blocked jersey leggings and track jackets. So what do the two designers have in common? They both interned for Flora Gill and Alexa Adams of Ohne Titel, finalists for last year’s CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Award. “I was mentored by Ingrid Solomonson,” Adams says. “She took me under her wing in the same way that we do with our interns. It allows you to learn so much and pushes yourself to creatively express your ideas.”

headline: All About the Invidious Irritants That Irk Individuals
text: If there’s anything I can’t stand, it’s somebody kicking the back of my chair. That, and the public clipping of fingernails. And loud gum chewing. Oh yes, and the neighbors’ muffled stereo, and people who are habitually late, and there are actually 20 or 30 other little problems I have with the world at large. But now on to you.

headline: Mary Berner Is Out at Reader’s Digest
text: After four years as president and chief executive of Reader’s Digest Association, Mary Berner has been replaced by the company’s chief financial officer, Tom Williams, who was appointed by the board of directors. The announcement on Monday follows a previous announcement a week ago of a new board of directors at the parent company RDA Holding Company.

headline: Watching for the Galleon Verdict
text: Legal experts contend that if Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group, is convicted, it will have little if any impact on the culture or practices of Wall Street.

headline: On Our Radar: Migrating Songbirds Vanish in Britain
text: British ornithologists record dramatic declines in the population of songbirds migrating from Africa. Since 1995, the number of turtle doves arriving in spring has dropped by 71 percent, while nightingales have declined by 53 percent. The reason for the losses is unknown, but scientists suspect that land-use changes could play a leading role. “The real problem is that there are so many different possible causes for these losses, which makes it difficult to tease out the factors involved in their decline and to prepare plans to put things right,” a scientist says. [The Guardian]

headline: Tribeca Video Interview: Jerry Ensminger
text: The documentary “Semper Fi: Always Faithful” follows Jerry Ensminger, a retired Marine who served in the military for 25 years. After his daughter died of a rare leukemia at the age of 9, Mr. Ensminger sought to learn the disease’s cause, eventually discovering that there were contaminants in the water at Camp Lejeune, the military base in North Carolina where he lived when his daughter was born. His research found that the water had been contaminated for a 30-year period between 1957-1987. The documentary, being shown at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells his story as as he works to gather more details about the water contamination and to reveal the issue to those affected, to Congress and to the public at large. In this video, Mr. Ensminger discusses how he found out about the incident, what some of its effects have been and his struggle with the Marine Corps to get a resolution.

headline: Chinese State Media, in a Show of Openness, Print Jet Photos
text: BEIJING — The J-15 Flying Shark is China’s newest attack jet, a sinuous fighter with the folding wings, shortened tail cone and bulked-up landing gear it needs to serve on China’s first aircraft carrier, which is expected to start sea trials soon. It is indisputable evidence of China’s growing mastery of military technology.

headline: Where to Lose Weight on Vacation

Haley Barbour of Mississippi said Monday that he had decided against seeking the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, an announcement that instantly shook up the party’s field of candidates and set off a scramble among rivals to court donors who had been planning to support his candidacy.

headline: A Tire Engineer’s Tips for Better Gas Mileage
text: Gas is nudging toward $4 a gallon or more in some parts of the country. You can search online to find the cheapest gas in your town. But you also can take steps to boost your mileage, says Forrest Patterson, lead engineer on Michelin’s most fuel-efficient tires. He spoke with me this week and shared some tips for squeezing as many miles as possible out of increasingly pricey tanks of gas.

headline: On the Market: Thinking Critically About Advertising
text: Overview | How are food and beverage marketers blurring the line between advertising and entertainment to engage young consumers, and why does this concern nutrition experts and children’s advocates? To what extent are product-related games, quizzes and apps making children both recipients and tools of marketing? In this lesson, students consider various forms of advertising, then keep logs of the ads and other branded content they encounter in a specified period, and reflect on their experiences with marketing.

headline: The ‘King of Fruits’ Commands Respect

Often called the “king of fruits” elsewhere in the world, the mango is not high in calories, and it is an excellent source of beta carotene, vitamin A and potassium. Now is the time to get acquainted with them: although they’re in season from January to August, mangoes peak in May and June.

headline: Migrating Sea Turtles Pick Up More Pollution

headline: With Trump in News, Show Stays Strong
text: Benefiting from buzz about Donald Trump’s possible White House bid, the latest installment of NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” remained strong in the ratings on Sunday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the reality show attracted an average of 8.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., up from 7.7 million a week ago and tied with ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” (9.9 million) as the night’s top-rated show among viewers 18 to 49. Although CBS’s made-for-TV movie “Beyond the Blackboard” earned slightly more viewers in the same time period (8.5 million), the audience for “The Apprentice” grew by more than 2 million from its first half-hour to its last. But in total viewers for the night NBC trailed in third place, struggling with “Dateline” at 7 (4.3 million) and “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8 (3.6 million). CBS led over all thanks to “60 Minutes” (10.3 million) and “The Amazing Race” (9.3 million), while ABC placed second, broadcasting new episodes of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (7.8 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (6.6 million). Fox was a distant fourth, earning 5.5 million for an encore showing of “The Simpsons Movie.”

headline: Imprint for Chopra
text: The guru and best-selling author Deepak Chopra will run his own small imprint at Random House, called Deepak Chopra Books, the company said on Monday. Dr. Chopra’s imprint will be part of Harmony Books, the division of the Crown Publishing Group (itself a division of Random House) that publishes books on health, wellness and spirituality. Using his “broad network of contacts,” Dr. Chopra will “initiate, recommend and submit” roughly six nonfiction books each year, Crown said in a statement. Crown is the publisher of many of Dr. Chopra’s own books.

headline: Out of Doors Lineup
text: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival will open on July 27 with Billy Bragg, the British punk-folk musician, and the United States premiere of his “Big Busk,” in which he invites audience members to sing as well as play along on their own guitars to some of his most popular songs, Lincoln Center announced. Mavis Staples, above, who won her first Grammy Award in February after a career spanning more than 50 years, will follow with a performance on July 31. Mr. Bragg and Ms. Staples recently traveled the West Coast together on their Hope, Love and Justice Tour. Another Grammy winner, the flutist and composer Robert Mirabal, will accompany the premiere of a new work by the interdisciplinary artists and dancers Eiko and Koma. “Water,” a site-specific work commissioned by Lincoln Center, will take place in the Paul Milstein reflecting pool in Hearst Plaza. The festival, which will present more than 100 free performances in Lincoln Center’s plazas through Aug. 14, will feature other collaborations, including “The Big Easy,” a work from the Trey McIntyre Project, a dance group, and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, from New Orleans; “Ponderosa Stomp: She’s Got the Power!,” a celebration of the girl groups of American pop music in the 1950s and ’60s; and “Prophets of Funk,” a world premiere from the choreographer David Dorfman and musicians from the band the Family Stone. A full schedule of events is at LCOutofDoors.org.

headline: A Passion for Nature, and Really Long Lists
text: “Dinochelus ausubeli” was the name conferred earlier this year on a strange deep sea monster, a lobster discovered off the Philippine coast whose right claw is elongated into a fearsome pincer. The new species was named not after its discoverer, but in honor of the person under whose auspices a fleet of 540 ships from 80 nations has found the lobster and 6,000 other new marine species in the last 10 years.

headline: Dorothy and the Tree: A Lesson in Epistemology
text: At one point in “The Wizard Of Oz,” Dorothy (Judy Garland) picks an apple and the tree she picks it off protests: “Well, how would you like to have someone come along and pick something off of you?” Dorothy is abashed and she says, “Oh, dear — I keep forgetting I’m not in Kansas,” by which she means she’s now entered an alternate universe where the usual distinctions between persons and objects, animate and inanimate, human beings and the natural world that is theirs to exploit do not hold. In Kansas and, she once assumed, everywhere else, trees are things you pick things off (even limbs) and persons are not. Persons have an autonomy and integrity of body that are to be respected; trees do not. A person who is maimed has a legal cause of action. A tree that has been cut down has no legal recourse, although there may be a cause of action (not, however, on behalf of the tree) if it was cut down by someone other than the owner of the property it stood on.

headline: Post-Mortem on Madoff’s Fraud While Scandal Is Still Quivering
text: By 1992 at the latest, and probably by 1987, Bernard Madoff had started the largest Ponzi scheme in history, whose existence was revealed only in December 2008 when, amid the devastation of the global financial crisis, Mr. Madoff ran out of money, confessed and was turned in by his dumbfounded sons. The fraud’s collapse revealed paper losses of over $60 billion, cash losses to investors of over $20 billion and the hollowness of a financial industry idol.

headline: If Only All We Wanted Was Expert Advice
text: I have a dishwasher problem that’s lasted several years. Here are the symptoms: every fourth or fifth wash, the dishes come out much dirtier than when I put them in. You can see little black flecks of something when you hold a glass against the light. My theory is that the problem lies in the pipes downstream from the dishwasher — once in a while, perhaps something makes the dirty dishwater kick back and mess up the dishes.

headline: Sonos Music System Comes to Android
text: Sonos, the heralded music system that allows users to send music tracks to units placed throughout the house, has long had a soft spot for Apple. Apps developed for both the iPhone and iPad allow Sonos owners to choose which music they’d like to have streamed from their PC or the Internet, and control the volume of that music on each device independently.

headline: Strumming Solo, With the Reverb of a Full Band
text: “I feel a rumblin’ in her ground,” Neil Young sang, alone onstage at Avery Fisher Hall, playing his Gretsch White Falcon, sounding the low notes of a strummed chord, muting them a little with the heel of his hand. The song was generally about planet earth but could have been specifically about where he stood. As he struck those low notes, the metal fixtures in the room talked back: the exit signs, the lighting plates and possibly the balcony railings all rattled like rivets in a cymbal.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Last Picture Show’
text: While coming-of-age films often look at the pain and disappointment that come with growing up, A. O. Scott sees something more in his Critics’ Pick this week, “The Last Picture Show,” directed by Peter Bogdanovich. The 1971 film explores the passage of time and fleeting youth, but it also “connects these feelings to a particular moment in history and the gradual disappearance of a way of life,” Mr. Scott says.

headline: Was Gareth Bale the Best Choice as Player of the Year?

headline: A Century-Old Love Story With Fire as a Backdrop

A handful of survivors and bystanders recount the ghastly events that resulted in 146 deaths a century ago. These are by far the most powerful moments in Jack Gilhooley and Daniel Czitrom’s historical drama. They also make up maybe 5 percent of the play.

text: The broad-brush conclusion of a new federal report on the future impact of climate change on water in the West is a bit familiar. Throughout the West, there will be less snow, and what snow there is will melt faster. The dry Southwest is going to get drier, and the wet Northwest wetter, as a diagram in the report (above) shows.

headline: Annoying: The Science of What Bugs Us
text: There's nowhere to hide and no one is immune. Can science explain life's annoyances? NPR's Joe Palca and Flora Lichtman investigate in Annoying: The Science of What Bugs Us (Wiley, 2011).

headline: For White Sox’ G.M., a Bad Day to Be Stuck at the Airport
text: Kenny Williams flew commercial to New York on Monday, and his flight was delayed for two and a half hours. That is dangerous for the general manager of a team that has lost 10 of its last 11 games. Williams, the architect of the Chicago White Sox, got an earful from fans.

headline: Peace of Mind, From a Dubious Threat
text: Years ago, a veteran advertising executive told me that “hitting the fear button” is a good way to drive sales.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,440 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,532 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Anthony’s Choice Becomes the Knicks’ Conundrum
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Yemen’s Opposition Accepts Deal for Transfer of Power
text: Yemen’s opposition coalition on Monday accepted a proposal for a transfer of power, bringing the country closer to a resolution of months of political turmoil and countless demonstrations calling for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down.

headline: News Aggregator Zite Wants to Play Nice With Publishers
text: Zite, a news aggregator for the iPad whose app has irked major news publishers, said Monday that Mark Johnson, a longtime adviser to the company, would become its new chief executive.

headline: Japan’s Cherry Blossoms Bloom, but Nuclear Fears Keep Tourists Away
text: MIHARU, Japan — This weeping cherry tree has stood here for a thousand years, local farmers say, blossoming every year despite blizzards, earthquakes and, now, a nuclear disaster.

headline: Iran Discovers New Cyberattack
text: TEHRAN — Iran has discovered a new hostile computer virus designed to damage government systems, an Iranian official who heads a cyberdefense agency said in comments reported Monday.

headline: For Late ‘Mr. Mayor,’ a Last Tour of Town
text: BALTIMORE — Even after his death, William Donald Schaefer was still performing. The former mayor of Baltimore was ushered through the city on Monday like a head of state, his coffin on a whirlwind tour of this city that he loved, and that loved him.

headline: Joe Perry, 49ers Hall of Fame Fullback, Dies at 84
text: Joe Perry, the San Francisco 49ers’ Hall of Fame fullback who was one of the first black stars in modern professional football, died Monday in Tempe, Ariz. He was 84.

headline: Bloggingheads: Right Wing Buffoonery
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Ramesh Ponnuru of National Review debate whether Republicans should be worried about the conservative fringe.

headline: Letters to New York
text: By the morning of April 25, 1861, residents of Washington had been expecting a Confederate attack for almost two weeks; for the last five days, the city had been completely cut off from the rest of the nation. No trains. No traffic into the city. No telegraph. No mail. Only the morning before at the White House, a despondent President Lincoln had greeted the wounded soldiers of the Sixth Massachusetts — the last reinforcements to arrive since April 19 — telling them, “I don’t believe there is any North. The Seventh Regiment is a myth.”

headline: Arcade Fire: Haiti
text: No particular reason to post this, except to provide something cheering after a tough day. I’m ashamed to say that I wasn’t even aware of the band until the Grammys — but hey, I’m 58! And as I suspect is happening with Brad, as an aging baby boomer I find it vastly reassuring to see that there are honest, creative artists still making their way up amid the commercialization. And their live performances are truly addictive. So:

headline: Crowd to Join as Giffords Views Shuttle Launching
text: PHOENIX — Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who has been given the green light by doctors to attend her astronaut-husband’s shuttle launching on Friday afternoon, will be joined at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida by family, friends, aides and health workers — not to mention President Obama and his family — as the space shuttle Endeavour lifts into space.

headline: Tornado Season Intensifies, Without Clear Scientific Consensus on Why
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — All the warning sirens echoing across the Great Plains, Midwest and Southeast this month leave little doubt that the tornado season — which has plowed a trail of destruction through communities from Oklahoma to Wisconsin to Georgia — is off to an unusually busy start.

headline: Netflix’s Profit Rises Amid a Rush to On-Demand
text: Netflix posted a first-quarter profit of $60.2 million on Monday and said it had added 3.3 million subscribers in the United States in three months’ time, its fastest rate of growth yet.

headline: Poll Finds Egyptians Full of Hope About the Future
text: Egyptians are looking forward with extraordinary confidence and enthusiasm to their first free and fair elections this fall after the defining revolution of the Arab spring, according to the first major poll since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. But they remain deeply divided over the role of Islam in their public life.

headline: Taking Pickles Out of the Afterthought Aisle
text: THE typical habitat for the Vlasic brand character, the stork, is of course in the pickle aisle, where he perches on the labels of kosher dills and sweet gherkins. But Monday he began migrating to other sections of supermarkets, too.

headline: Change in Giggs’s Role Brightens the Twilight of His Career
text: Growing old gracefully is very difficult for athletes. Just to drop a few American names who face it: Favre, Roddick, Jeter and Woods (obviously, in very diverse circumstances).

headline: Facebook Is Latest Rival to Groupon and LivingSocial
text: Facebook said late Monday that it would introduce Deals, an effort by the social networking giant to tap into the consumer frenzy over online discounts. With Deals, which had long been expected, Facebook is entering a crowded market led by overnight sensations like Groupon and LivingSocial.

headline: Law Firm Won’t Defend Marriage Act
text: WASHINGTON — The law firm hired by Republicans in the House of Representatives to defend the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act withdrew Monday amid pressure from gay rights groups. The decision prompted the resignation of a prominent partner, who said he intended to take the case with him to another law office.

headline: Status of Rangers’ Drury, Prospal and Avery Is Tenuous
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It sounded as if the end was near for the Rangers careers of Chris Drury, Vinny Prospal and Sean Avery, based on the veiled language Coach John Tortorella used about them on breakup day here Monday.

headline: Many Clashes, Few Kind Words Between Mayor and Comptroller
text: Within minutes of boarding his private jet last November, destined for Hong Kong, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg dispensed with the pleasantries and confronted his main guest, John C. Liu, the city comptroller: Why are you blocking a crucial city contract?

headline: The Big Disconnect
text: On one level, American politics looks amazingly stable. President Obama’s approval rating is about 47 percent, and it hasn’t changed much in well over a year. Health care reform is mildly unpopular, and the public’s view hasn’t shifted much since before it was passed.

headline: Paul Shows Fans Way to Beat Lakers, and Other Teams Are Watching, Too
text: NEW ORLEANS — Chris Paul cupped his hand to his ear, as if he could not hear the thundering applause of the capacity New Orleans Arena crowd. The gesture, which came Sunday night in the waning seconds of the Hornets’ 93-88 playoff victory against the two-time defending N.B.A. champion Los Angeles Lakers, was as close as Paul gets to showboating.

headline: A Journal’s Statement May Aid a Harvard Researcher Accused of Misconduct
text: In a positive development for Marc Hauser, the Harvard researcher whom the university accused last year of eight charges of scientific misconduct, the journal Science said Monday that he had replicated an experiment he published in 2007.

headline: Walsh’s Status May Be Resolved Soon With a Contract Offer
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Donnie Walsh and Mike D’Antoni stayed behind closed doors Monday and might remain there for some time, at least until questions about Walsh’s future are settled.

headline: Governor of Mississippi Won’t Run for President
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi had hired a campaign manager, lined up influential Republican activists in early-voting states and secured commitments from donors across the country, but he surprised them all on Monday by announcing that he was abandoning his effort to join the Republican presidential race.

headline: N.F.L. Ruling Is a Victory for Fans
text: Amid the din of the arguments between N.F.L. players and owners, maybe the fans have been heard, if only a little. When Judge Susan Richard Nelson issued her 89-page decision Monday that lifted — if only temporarily — the N.F.L. lockout, she cited the needs of a third party in the dispute: the public.

headline: Life and Death of the Trading Floor
text: The New York Stock Exchange's trading floor has survived for more than a century. With a takeover war by rival exchanges looming, traders are trying to survive in a computerized world.

headline: Robberies Chill an Underground World of Chinese Gambling
text: Clad in black and speaking Chinese, the three men entered a mah-jongg parlor hidden in a building on Hester Street in Chinatown. They pulled out a pistol and a knife and stripped gamblers of more than $5,600, the police said.

headline: Preserving a Market Symbol
text: When it comes to keeping the New York Stock Exchange’s trading floor open, Robert Greifeld makes a very unlikely savior.

headline: On the Largely Irrelevant News About Barbour Not Running for President
text: I haven’t spent very much time writing about Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour, who  announced today that he would not be a candidate for president. But the record will show that I noted both directly and indirectly that I thought Mr. Barbour’s chances were overstated.

headline: Better Hand-Washing Through Technology
text: Why can’t hospitals get health care workers to wash their hands?

headline: Before Manny Was Manny
text: Manny Ramirez has retired from baseball, but for some he will always be the young phenom blasting home runs for his high school team in Washington Heights.

headline: Before Manny Became Manny
text: Hero. Cheat. Prodigy. Ingrate. Free spirit. Knucklehead. Hall of Famer. Pariah. Enigma. Manny Ramirez, one of the great right-handed hitters of his generation, who retired from baseball this month after once again testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs, was many things to many people — fans and family and teammates from Santo Domingo to Washington Heights to Cleveland to Boston. Sara Rimer, then a reporter for The New York Times, met Ramirez in 1991 at George Washington High School in Manhattan. Over two decades, she enjoyed a memorable and mystifying acquaintanceship with Ramirez.

headline: 3 Children Drowned by Mother Are Buried
text: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. — The three white coffins were so small that they needed to be lowered into the ground by hand. The little girl in one, not even a year old when she died, wore a white Easter dress, and the two young boys wore dark suits.

text: Jin Lee/Bloomberg NewsThe New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Apple and Google Use Phone Data to Map the World
text: SAN FRANCISCO — You may not know it, but if you carry a smartphone in your pocket, you are probably doing unpaid work for Apple or Google — and helping them eventually aim more advertising directly at you.

headline: The Limits of School Reform
text: I find myself haunted by a 13-year-old boy named Saquan Townsend. It’s been more than two weeks since he was featured in The New York Times Magazine, yet I can’t get him out of my mind.

headline: The Guantánamo Papers
text: The internal documents from the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, published in The Times on Monday were a chilling reminder of the legal and moral disaster that President George W. Bush created there. They describe the chaos, lawlessness and incompetence in his administration’s system for deciding detainees’ guilt or innocence and assessing whether they would be a threat if released.

text: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on gender equity in college sports.
