text: When it comes to keeping the New York Stock Exchange trading floor open, Robert Greifeld makes a very unlikely savior.

headline: Guest List Prompts Talk of Royal Snubs
text: LONDON — Just as all appeared to be going smoothly for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, recriminations set in on Monday over who has made the list of 1,900 wedding guests — and perhaps more significant, those who have not.

headline: Gender Games: Roster Management
text: Colleges commonly use the law on gender parity in sport in ways in which it may not have been intended.

headline: Public Pensions, Once Off Limits, Face Budget Cuts
text: When an arbitrator ruled this month that Detroit could reduce the pensions being earned by its police sergeants and lieutenants, it put the struggling city at the forefront of a growing national debate over whether the pensions of current public workers can or should be reduced.

headline: College Teams, Relying on Deception, Undermine Gender Equity
text: Ever since Congress passed the federal gender-equity law known as Title IX, universities have opened their gyms and athletic fields to millions of women who previously did not have chances to play. But as women have surged into a majority on campus in recent years, many institutions have resorted to subterfuge to make it look as if they are offering more spots to women.

headline: Witness Says Inspectors Neglected Risk at Deutsche
text: A thud rattled through the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in the fall of 2006 with such force, Adolpho Ortiz testified Monday, that he thought someone might have been hurt.

headline: A Player Is Back at Home With Dreams of a Recovery
text: JACKSON, N.J. — In his dreams, Eric LeGrand is surrounded by family, friends, his Rutgers football teammates, the same support system that cared for and inspired him the past six months. But there remains one difference. In his dreams, LeGrand can walk.

headline: Bronx House Fire Kills Boy, 12, and His Parents
text: A 12-year-old boy and his parents were killed when a fire raced through a row house in the Bronx early Monday, fire officials said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Boeing and the N.L.R.B.
text: It may be a difficult case to prove, but the complaint filed last month by the National Labor Relations Board against Boeing is a welcome effort to defend workers’ right to collective bargaining.

headline: So Much for That Ounce of Prevention
text: House Republicans are so bent on blocking any and all aspects of health care reform that they have passed a bill that would eliminate a farsighted program — the Prevention and Public Health Fund — intended to help states and communities prevent diseases. Eliminating the fund would save roughly $16 billion over the course of a decade, a small amount in the context of a trillion-dollar health care reform. The loss to states and local communities would be considerable.

headline: Marriage Equality in New York
text: There are good reasons to believe that legislation legalizing same-sex-marriage in New York State is fated to fare better in Albany’s current legislative session than it did in 2009 when the State Senate voted, 38 to 24, to continue the state’s discriminatory policy of denying gay and lesbian couples the freedom to marry.

headline: U.S. Faces a Challenge in Trying to Punish Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The White House said on Monday that it was exploring new sanctions against Syria — mostly involving the assets of top officials around President Bashar al-Assad — but officials acknowledged that the country was already under so many sanctions that the United States held little leverage.

headline: Tuesday: Humdinger
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s an interesting surprise in today’s puzzle that you may overlook because it’s a very low-key entry. On the other hand, we’ve all been doing Brendan Emmett Quigley’s puzzles for so long (Solution, Note: There is no blog or Across Lite file for this puzzle) and enjoyed them so much, that I feel compelled to point it out.

headline: A Papal Visit Has Dreamers Dreaming
text: What do you get when you take the “sur” out of “surrealism”? That sounds like a question in search of a punch line. But few laughs emerge from the answers provided by the somber new revival of John Guare’s “House of Blue Leaves,” which opened on Monday night at the Walter Kerr Theater.

headline: Mauritania: Police Break Up Antigovernment Protest
text: Using tear gas and batons, the police broke up an antigovernment demonstration of several hundred youths in the capital, Nouakchott, on Monday. Echoing protests elsewhere in the region, young people have been rallying against President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz since the end of February. Mr. Aziz, left, a former general, was elected in 2009 after seizing power in a coup the year before. A rallying cry of the protesters has been that Mr. Aziz used the election merely to legalize his coup, and on Monday the protesters demanded he relinquish power. “At about noon they were savagely attacked by the police with batons and tear gas grenades,” said an opposition member of Parliament, Mohamed El Moustapha Ould Bedreddine.

headline: Preliminary Injunction Ruling: Brady et al. v. National Football League
text: United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson gave professional football players a significant victory Monday, granting an injunction to stop the N.F.L.’s six-week-long lockout.

headline: Germany: Protesters Demand Stop to Nuclear Power
text: An estimated 120,000 people demonstrated across Germany on Monday, protest organizers said, demanding an end to the use of nuclear power and increasing pressure on Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government to speed up the closing of the country’s 17 nuclear plants. Last month, after the nuclear accident in Japan, Mrs. Merkel imposed a moratorium on new nuclear plant construction and temporarily closed seven existing plants.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Court Ruling Fosters Questions, Not Answers, for Players and Teams
text: When the news broke Monday afternoon that United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson had lifted the N.F.L. lockout, confusion overtook a league known for micromanagement. Players called their agents. Agents called teams. Teams called the league office. Reporters called everyone. Yet all those questions yielded more confusion, at least initially.

headline: A Fitting Tribute to a City’s Faithful Servant
text: William Donald Schaefer, the former mayor of Baltimore, was ushered through the city Monday like a head of state, his coffin on a whirlwind tour of this city that he loved.

headline: Last Chance for Flyers Is Latest One for Boucher
text: VOORHEES, N.J. — Brian Boucher, the Philadelphia Flyers’ first-string goaltender as of right now, said he planned to spend Monday afternoon at his 8-year-old son’s baseball practice. Boucher said he would wait until Tuesday to consider the difficulty of his next job assignment.

headline: After School in Brooklyn, West African Girls Share Memories of a Painful Ritual
text: In a high school classroom in Brooklyn with walls adorned with algebra problems, a 15-year-old girl born in the West African nation of Guinea was talking recently with her friends, after the school day had ended.

headline: Former Mets Prospect Shuts Down the Yankees
text: On a night when A. J. Burnett became the first Yankees starter to pitch eight complete innings, he was overshadowed by a failed Mets prospect playing for his fourth organization in 16 months.

headline: Marie-France Pisier, New Wave Darling, Dies at 66
text: Marie-France Pisier, a French actress who was discovered by François Truffaut and appeared in three of his films, including “Love on the Run,” and who worked with notable directors like André Téchiné and Luis Buñuel, died on Sunday at her home in Saint-Cyr-sur-Mer in the South of France. She was 66.

headline: Washington: New Head for University
text: Michael Young, who has headed the University of Utah since 2004, will be the next president of the University of Washington, starting July 1. Mr. Young, 61, is a graduate of Brigham Young University and Harvard Law School, and a direct descendant of the Mormon leader Brigham Young. He has been dean of George Washington University Law School, served on the faculty of Columbia Law School, and clerked for Justice William Rehnquist of the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Dossier Shows Push for More Attacks After 9/11
text: WASHINGTON — He peers out from the photo in the classified file through heavy-framed spectacles, an owlish face with a graying beard and a half-smile. Saifullah Paracha, a successful businessman and for years a New York travel agent, appears to be the oldest of the 172 prisoners still held at the Guantánamo Bay prison. His dossier is among the most chilling.

headline: Funds Down for Pre-K Programs
text: The recession took its toll on early childhood programs across the nation in the 2009-10 school year, with total spending by states decreasing for the first time since experts began keeping track, according to an annual survey by the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University. State funding for pre-kindergarten programs decreased by nearly $30 million, about one half of 1 percent, and would have fallen by $50 million if states had not received federal stimulus dollars, the survey said. Ohio, which eliminated one program, saw its enrollment of 3- and 4-year-olds drop by nearly 15,000, to about 5,700.

headline: Previewing the Champions League Semifinals
text: Rob Hughes looks at this week’s first-leg matchups in the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League — at whether Schalke has a shot against Manchester United after a middling league season, and at whether Real Madrid will risk getting rough with Barcelona. Read the full article here, and come back to this post to comment.

headline: Gym Class: Antigravity Yoga
text: The Times's fitness guinea pig, Karen Barrow, reviews a gravity-defying form of yoga.

headline: Gym Class: AntiGravity Yoga
text: Did you ever see an interesting class at the gym that you were too intimidated to try? Or maybe you need to freshen up your current workout routine?

headline: Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf Earn Top Marks in First U.S. Crash Tests
text: In the first independent crash tests of mainstream electric vehicles conducted in the United States, the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf have been named Top Safety Picks by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: Aspiring Authors Get Help Online
text: In the old days of publishing, getting your manuscript into the hands of an editor often meant mailing the unsolicited finished product to the offices of literary agents or editors, where it would receive a cursory look from an editorial assistant — or none at all.

headline: Ballpark Memories
text: As the last homestand is played before the Yankees move to their new stadium, this is a time for South Bronx residents to reflect on their neighborhood.

headline: Police Officer Pleads Guilty in Robberies of Drug Dealers
text: A New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Monday to charges that he participated in a ring that robbed drug dealers, an operation that officials say yielded more than 550 pounds of cocaine and $1 million in drug proceeds.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

text: assumption •\ə-ˈsəm(p)-shən\• noun

headline: Report Urges Storing Spent Nuclear Fuel, Not Reprocessing It
text: Experts on nuclear power predict that Japan’s Fukushima crisis will lead to a major rethinking of how spent nuclear fuel is handled in the United States but have cast doubt on a proposed solution: reprocessing the fuel to recover plutonium and other materials for reuse.

headline: Photo Replay: April 25
text: A look back at the day in sports, from the women’s hockey world championships to the N.B.A. playoffs.

text: A government-organized tour in Tripoli showed buildings damaged by NATO bombs, and shelling in Misurata was fatal for two families.

headline: Lollapalooza Headliners Include Eminem, Foo Fighters and Coldplay
text: Here’s a simple rule of thumb for determining if a particular band is probably on the lineup for the 20th anniversary edition of Lollapalooza: does it play music? If the answer to that question is yes, there’s a good chance that it is. Artists who fit that description, including Eminem, Foo Fighters, Coldplay, Muse and My Morning Jacket, are among the 130 acts who are scheduled to perform at that long-lived festival, which runs from Aug. 5 through 7 at Grant Park in Chicago. Also on the bill this year are deadmau5, A Perfect Circle, Cee Lo Green, Damian “Jr. Gong” Marley & Nas, the Cars and Ween, as well as (deep breath) Bright Eyes, Arctic Monkeys, Big Audio Dynamite, Deftones, Beirut, Explosions in the Sky, Death From Above 1979, Ratatat and Crystal Castles, the festival’s organizers announced on Tuesday.

headline: News Quiz | April 26, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Minmetals Withdraws Equinox Bid After Barrick Offer
text: Minmetals Resources, the state-controlled Chinese mining company that made an unsolicited bid for Equinox Minerals this month, said on Tuesday that it had dropped its offer after being outbid by the Barrick Gold Corporation.

headline: International Outcry Grows Over Syria Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s bloody crackdown on protesters — which seemed to signal a new, harrowing chapter in a conflict that has already killed nearly 400 people — provoked growing international concern on Tuesday with calls for the violence to stop and talk of possible sanctions.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 26, 2011
text: Test your proofreading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the blog post “Yahoo Will Keep Search Queries for 18 Months.”

headline: Afghan Officials Try to Limit Damage From Prison Break

headline: An Overview: Guantánamo Bay and the Classified Files
text: Note: Today’s 6 Q’s About the News pulls from multiple Times sources to help students understand the basics of this complex topic. Each question links to a resource in which they can find an answer, including the Times Topics page that features a short overview of Guantánamo Bay and its history. In some cases the link will take students directly to the page or paragraph from which the information comes.

headline: Is Your Generation More Self-Centered Than Earlier Generations?
text: Is narcissism, or excessive fascination with oneself, increasing? A psychologist, Nathan DeWall, analyzed the language in three decades of hit songs to answer this question, and he thinks it is. “Late adolescents and college students love themselves more today than ever before,” he says. Do you think this is true? Read the related Science Times article to learn about his research, then respond below.

headline: Remembering Joe Perry, Pioneering Running Back
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Joe Perry died Monday at age 84.

headline: A Romani Festival on the Streets of Istanbul
text: The spring festival of Hidrellez, celebrated in Istanbul and throughout the region during the first week of May, may be attributed to the ancient prophets Ilyas and Hizir, but its rituals, venerating fire and water, reach back to the roots of Anatolian civilization. In Istanbul today, particularly in Romani districts, Hidrellez comes in the form of a memorable street party.

headline: Scenes From Ryan McGinley’s Opening
text: Earlier this month, Ryan McGinley had an opening in Amsterdam at Galerie Gabriel Rolt. The show included color photography shot in nature along with black-and-white studio portraits of nudes and animals.

headline: What It Means to Make a Profit
text: I went back and reread my post about becoming profitable. I laid out the factors that I believe turned around my company’s financial state: six actions and circumstances that allowed me to survive the recession and put my company on the right path. What I neglected to discuss is my personal reaction to the idea that I might finally be able to breathe easier about money.

headline: Why Republicans May Be Skipping 2012 Presidential Run
text: Haley Barbour’s decision to forgo a run for the presidency in 2012 puts him in the company of a half-dozen top Republicans who have considered — and rejected — a challenge to President Obama next year.

headline: Smaller Cars Lift Ford’s Profit to $2.55 Billion
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — The Ford Motor Company on Tuesday reported its best first-quarter earnings since 1998, even as its sales shift to smaller, more fuel-efficient cars.

headline: Departing Amalgamated Bank Chief to Join Weil Gotshal
text: Derrick D. Cephas, who is stepping down as chief executive of Amalgamated Bank at the end of April, will soon join Weil, Gotshal & Manges as head of the law firm’s financial regulatory group.

headline: Gimlet Eye Observes Murder Case
text: In his best book, the nonfiction collection “Killings” (1984), Calvin Trillin described what attracts him — and so many other writers — to murder stories. “When someone dies suddenly shades are drawn up,” Mr. Trillin wrote. Lives are laid bare. A murder “gives us an excuse to be there,” he said, “poking around in somebody’s life.”

headline: Sale of Oil Leases Planned for Gulf of Mexico
text: An oil and gas lease sale covering more than 28,000 square miles in the western Gulf of Mexico could take place as soon as the end of the year, federal regulators quietly announced last week.

headline: Can’t Get No Satisfaction?
text: Today David Brooks argues that there is a disconnect between the improving economy and the increasingly despairing public, pointing to a deeper malaise. But is the economy really improving in a way that matters to voters?

headline: Lawson Software Agrees to $2 Billion Buyout
text: Lawson Software announced on Tuesday that it would be acquired by the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, in a $2 billion buyout deal.

headline: Barrett-Jackson Changes Tune on Reserve Sales for Collectible Cars
text: At collector car auctions, it takes guts to raise a paddle and buy a car based on first impressions or a catalog description. But what about the anxious seller who consigns a car and lets the marketplace of interested parties decide what it’s worth?

headline: The Nannies’ Norma Rae
text: It’s the most intimate class divide in human civilization, or at least in such relatively civilized places as Manhattan and Park Slope, Brooklyn. On the one side, there is the professional couple bringing in six figures a year; on the other, the nanny or maid without whom the couple wouldn’t be able to practice their professions. Conditions of employment are as variable as the individual employers are — from respectful and considerate all the way to criminally abusive. On average, a domestic worker is likely to get less than $15 an hour, no benefits and none of the credit or glory. To my knowledge anyway, there has never been a successful career woman — or man, for that matter — who’s responded to being praised for “doing it all” by saying, “Actually, Manuela (or Angelica or Harriet) does most of it.”

headline: One on One: Peter Semmelhack of Bug Labs
text: Peter Semmelhack founded Bug Labs in April 2006 with the intention of making it easier for people to create innovative electronic devices. The company makes a product called a Bug, which is a series of modules — GPS systems, cameras, motion sensors — that can be snapped onto a small computer and programmed to create products that would otherwise take years of development and millions of dollars to build. The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Mr. Semmelhack.

headline: Raising the Medicare Age
text: Jonathan Cohn rightly slams a little-noticed feature of the Republican plan — a rise in the Medicare eligibility age.

headline: French and Italian Leaders Seek Tighter Controls on Migration
text: ROME — Facing a surge in undocumented migrants from North Africa, the leaders of France and Italy on Tuesday called for changes in the Schengen Agreement, which grants free passage across national frontiers in most of Western Europe.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Lawsuits Don’t Improve Nursing Home Care
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Real Estate Remains in Distress as U.S. Home Prices Fall Again
text: Housing prices slid back in February to their lowest level of the downturn, fresh proof — as if any were needed — that real estate remains one of the most troubled sectors of the economy.

headline: Deadly Storms Leave Arkansans Battered and Bracing for More
text: VILONIA, Ark. — A barrage of severe weather sweeping across Arkansas has brought flash floods to some parts of the state, wrecked this small town and left 10 dead. Residents braced for more damage on Tuesday evening as violent storms washed across the state.

headline: Tribeca Q&A: Jack Osbourne on ‘God Bless Ozzy Osbourne’
text: Though Ozzy Osbourne was a reality-television fixture for three years — and, oh yeah, a pioneer of heavy-metal music for some four decades — there is more to be said about rock ‘n’ roll’s Prince of Darkness in “God Bless Ozzy Osbourne,” a documentary making its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival. The movie, directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, chronicles Mr. Osbourne’s life — 62 years, if you can believe it, and counting — from his upbringing in Birmingham, England, through his years with Black Sabbath and as a solo performer, through his grieving for the accidental death of his guitarist Randy Rhoads, to the aftermath of his reality show, while a cloud of alcohol and drug abuse hangs over him. In addition to interviews with Mr. Osbourne and his band mates past and present, the film offers candid testimonials from his wife, Sharon, and children Jack and Kelly, as well as his little-seen daughter Aimee (who declined to be part of the reality series) and children Louis and Jessica (from a previous marriage).

headline: Updates on the Unrest in Syria and Libya
text: On Tuesday, The Lede is compiling reports on the war in Libya, protests in Syria and uprisings against governments across the Middle East from journalists, bloggers and activists in the region.

headline: Britain to Close a Consulate With a View
text: FLORENCE, Italy — It has seen the rise of the Grand Tour and the package tour, the romance of E. M. Forster’s “Room With a View” and the tensions of two world wars. And now, after five centuries, the British Consulate in Florence is closing its doors, a victim of budget cuts and the currents of history.

Bloomberg at the Metropolitan Museum of Art recently, trying to sell the foreign visitors on his next big idea: a top-flight applied sciences school for the city.

headline: The ‘Wet House’ Where Alcoholics Can Keep Drinking
text: In a sterile 12-by-12 concrete room on the second floor of St. Anthony Residence, a 60-year-old man with glassy eyes and a stomach full of cheap vodka sits at the end of his twin bed, a cigarette resting between his chapped lips. “Ballerinas dance, and alcoholics drink,” Dave tells me with a chuckle. It’s 10:30 on a Monday morning, and he has already been to a nearby liquor store and back.

headline: Game 7 Preview: Buffalo at Philadelphia
text: Here are five keys to Game 7 between the Flyers and the Sabres, to be played Tuesday night in Philadelphia at 7:30, courtesy of the analyst Kevin Weekes of “Hockey Night in Canada” and the NHL Network:

headline: New York Philharmonic Hires Ricardo Morales
text: Ricardo Morales and the New York Philharmonic have finally closed the deal. The orchestra back in October offered Mr. Morales — one of the stars of the Philadelphia Orchestra — the job of principal clarinetist, a key position that had been open since the end of the 2008-9 season. A spokesman said today that Mr. Morales had signed a contract and would officially start in New York in September 2012 once his obligations end in Philadelphia. The orchestra hopes to have Mr. Morales play some weeks on an ad hoc basis next season and possibly as early as this summer. The loss of Mr. Morales will be another blow to the Philadelphia Orchestra, which this month filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. New York operagoers may be familiar with his sound. He was a principal in the Metropolitan Opera before going to Philadelphia.

headline: Phoebe Snow, Bluesy Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 60
text: Phoebe Snow, whose signature hit, “Poetry Man,” established her as a leading light of the singer-songwriter movement and whose swooping vocal acrobatics transcended musical genres, died on Tuesday in Edison, N.J. She was 60.

text: Manchester United is a club with a strong heritage, and a club with a strong heritage of great strikers. Denis Law, Mark Hughes, Eric Cantona, Ruud Van Nistelrooy — just to name a few.

headline: Asked & Answered | Laszlo Jakab Orsos
text: Last September, Laszlo Jakab Orsos, 46, assumed the directorship of the PEN World Voices Festival, New York’s first literary festival, now in its seventh year. Started by Salman Rushdie, the festival regularly features readings and conversations with more than 100 writers from more than 40 countries. Local literary heroes like Jonathan Franzen and Ben Greenman share billing with Nobel Prize winners like Wole Soyinka, of Nigeria, and newcomers like Rula Jebreal, author of “Miral.” This year’s festival opens today with a party at the Standard Hotel and will continue throughout the week with unusual events at unusual sites: poetry readings on the Highline, dance performances in the laundry room of Westbeth and a discussion of David Foster Wallace’s “The Pale King” by Rick Moody and others in the grungy St. Patrick’s gym on Mulberry Street.

headline: With Barbour Out, Hill Republicans Lose Big Voice in Budget Battles
text: With Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi out of the 2012 presidential race, Republican leaders in Congress are losing a key supporter as they head into the fights over the next budget and raising the national debt ceiling.

headline: NATO Says It Is Stepping Up Attacks on Libya Targets
text: WASHINGTON — NATO plans to step up attacks on the palaces, headquarters and communications centers that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi uses to maintain his grip on power in Libya, according to Obama administration and allied officials.

headline: Optimistic Socialists
text: In Tuesday’s column, I wrote about the American public mood. Last December, Jodie T. Allen of the Pew Research Center had the smart idea of comparing the views of today’s Americans with the views of Americans during the Great Depression. The results remind you how much public opinion has shifted in a pro-capitalist direction over the past 80 years.

headline: Forget Frugality: Focus on Earning More
text: Once you’ve cut on the basics, the single best way to improve your personal finances is to earn more money.

headline: Few Americans Familiar With Title IX, Though Most Approve of It
text: Most Americans say it is very important for boys and girls to have the same opportunities to participate in high school sports, but few are very familiar with Title IX, the federal law that prohibits sex discrimination in federally funded education programs including athletics, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Exit Barbour
text: So Haley Barbour, who seemed like a near-lock to join the Republican field in 2012, has decided to join the ranks of Republican Mario Cuomos instead. It’s an understandable decision: Barbour’s strengths as a politician notwithstanding, his personal profile — a corpulent ex-lobbyist and quintessential Washington insider who’s also the governor of a deep-red state identified with secession and segregation — made him perhaps the least electable of the various would-be establishment candidates, and his famous political acumen was apparently acute enough to recognize that thick rolodexes alone do not a credible candidacy make. (See Gramm, Phil and Connally, John, among others.) Still, his departure leaves a thin G.O.P. field looking thinner (no pun intended), and it removes a candidate who had the wisdom to greet our Libyan intervention with a blunt: “What are we doing in Libya?” For that alone, he will be missed.

headline: Making Do With a Plywood Spaceship
text: The Museum of Flight in Seattle had anticipated for years that it would receive for its new $12 million, 15,000-square-foot Space Gallery one of four space shuttles that NASA was to give away. But when the winners were announced this month, Seattle was not among them. Instead, the museum will get a shuttle trainer used by astronauts before they went into space. It is made of plywood and does not have wings. Douglas R. King, the museum’s chief executive, discusses.

headline: Making the Most of an Unlikely Stop in Chinese Basketball League
text: DONGGUAN, China — It’s a chant normally reserved for Chinese players, who are the only ones eligible for the Chinese Basketball Association’s most valuable player award. But as Quincy Douby stepped to the free-throw line recently with his team’s Game 3 victory in the finals guaranteed, the home crowd was glad to make an exception. As Douby swished his two foul shots, the roars of “M.V.P.!” filled the arena.

headline: R.N.C. Chairman Stays Out of Trump-Birther Issue
text: Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared Tuesday that while he has no doubt that President Obama is an American citizen, it was not his place to tell Donald Trump to drop the issue.

headline: On Ethics, Humor, “Thelma and Louise” and Toonces the Driving Cat
text: The description of this blog is “Eavesdropping on the Times Magazine,” and, were you to truly eavesdrop on our offices, you would find we don’t just sit around debating high-literary assessments of famed New Yorker writers or the political ramifications of accidental allusions to nurdles. Sometimes we talk about the magazine and what will be in the magazine and what should or should not be in the magazine.

headline: For Many Michigan Applicants, a Long Wait at the Mailbox
text: While most applicants to the nation’s selective colleges have been weighing their acceptances (and salving the wounds of their rejections) since April 1 or earlier, more than 10,000 applicants to the University of Michigan had to wait until last Thursday to receive their notifications. That delay, in turn, left those who were accepted with fewer than two weeks to compare Michigan (and perhaps its offer of financial aid) to other institutions.

headline: Olivier Rousteing Named New Designer at Balmain
text: The new era at Paris’s sex-charged fashion house Balmain is beginning to take shape, with 25-year-old Olivier Rousteing being tapped as the label’s new designer. Rousteing, who joined Balmain in 2009 and is currently in charge of women’s wear, replaces Christophe Decarnin, who left earlier this month due to strategic disputes with chairman Alain Hivelin. Before joining Balmain, Rousteing worked for five years at Roberto Cavalli, which should serve him well in delivering the decadent rock-inflected glamour that became the label’s trademark under Decarnin.

headline: Private Equity’s Love Affair With China
text: Private equity has long had its eye on Asia, and China in particular, as the land of opportunity. But few buyout magnates have forcefully spoken about the inverse, the declining fortunes of the United States.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Jughead’ in Spanish?
text: The modernization of Archie Andrews, that lovable redhead from Riverdale, continues. Archie Comics announced that the company would start offering some of its titles available for digital download in Spanish, The Associated Press reported. “I’ve been thinking about it for quite a while,” said Jon Goldwater, the co-chief executive of Archie Comics. “When you talk about globalizing through digital, you can’t really do that if you’re only in English.”

text: American Apparel confirmed on Tuesday that it had secured $14.9 million in financing from a group of Canadian investors.

headline: Public Theater Unveils Its 2011-2012 Season
text: With our hearts still broken in a hundred thousand flaws following the cancellation of “Law & Order” last year, fans of the series’ longtime star, Sam Waterston, will see the actor trade his district attorney’s suit for the royal garb of King Lear in a new production at the Public Theater as part of a coming season that includes works by Mike Daisey, Nathan Englander, David Henry Hwang, Richard Nelson, and Stew and Heidi Rodewald.

headline: Someone Else’s Headache
text: You don’t want to go out to dinner with me. Really. I’m no fun at all. Not even if I know the owner and get a free drink or a special meal. That happens. Restaurant people are good about that, professional courtesy and all. Still, going to dinner with me is like attending a college basketball game with an advance scout. All work and no fun. Lots of notes interrupted by an occasional drink and a high-five.

headline: T-Mobile’s New Plan: Deal or No Deal?
text: It’s hard to know what to focus on first concerning T-Mobile’s new rate plan. The savings you’ll get, the saving you thought you’d get, or download speeds.

headline: David E. Patton Named Federal Public Defender
text: David E. Patton, a visiting law professor at Stanford, has been named the new head of New York’s influential federal public defender‘s office.

headline: Spurs Pushed to Brink by Grizzlies
text: This wasn’t supposed to be so hard for the San Antonio Spurs. They appeared poised for a long, hopefully fruitful, N.B.A. playoff run, bolstered by a veteran team that posted the best regular-season record in the Western Conference.

headline: Disorder Rules the Day
text: Proponents of sanity and order in sports are not having a good day. These are the people who like knowing that Tim Duncan will be predictably solid and stoic in the N.B.A. playoffs every year, an idea coming undone before our eyes. And while the N.F.L. lockout complicated matters for these folks, the N.F.L. was trying to help by pretending everything was perfectly normal (Hey, watch us draft players and then immediately lock them out! Make sure you buy their jerseys!) — until Monday.

headline: Faced With Declines, McClatchy Weighs Digital Subscriptions
text: The newspaper industry continues to take a major hit as reflected by earnings reported on Tuesday by The McClatchy Company, the parent company to newspapers like The Kansas City Star, The Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald. The latter publications were nominated for a Pulitzer Prize for breaking news for their coverage of the Haiti earthquake this year.

headline: The Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare
text: “PARDON me,” said César Ramirez. Thus begins every meal at one of the more extraordinary restaurants in New York City.

headline: Reviewing Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare
Players Punch In, But Quickly Punch Out
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The coming and going of each player’s car on Jets Drive signaled the back-and-forth uncertainty about the short-term meaning over the end — probably a temporary one — of the N.F.L. lockout.

headline: With Lockout Lifted for Now, Questions on How to Proceed
text: From the players who showed up for a workout, only to be told they could not get into the weight room, to the lawyers who asked a federal judge to clarify exactly what she wanted them to do now, the N.F.L. was stuck in a state of confusion Tuesday, one day after an injunction to stop the six-week-long lockout was issued.

headline: Teaching Teen Drivers
text: This afternoon my son will head to the DMV to trade in his junior driver’s license for an unrestricted senior one. This evening we will go out to dinner to celebrate his 17th birthday. We’re planning to take two cars, and we will stay at the restaurant past 9. Then he will drive himself home — the first time the State of New York has allowed him to do so at that hour without an adult in the passenger seat.

headline: Springtime Underground
text: Springtime in my New York doesn’t begin on the equinox. And it has little to do with forsythia. It is instead that moment when the subway is suddenly, discernibly cooler than the sidewalks above; when descending into a station feels like a pleasant immersion in a sturdy old cellar whose masonry walls are still infused with winter.

headline: Aflac Finds Its New Duck on the … Web
text: A Minnesota radio executive who auditioned online has been selected by Aflac to provide the voice of its duck character in commercials.

headline: Balmain Taps an Inside Man
text: The Paris fashion house announced on Tuesday that Olivier Rousteing will succeed Christophe Decarnin. In a briefly worded statement that seemed intended to suggest that little would change, Balmain said that Mr. Rousteing has been in charge of the brand’s women’s design studio since 2009. His previous job was at Roberto Cavalli, where he spent five years. Dependable inside talent offers continuity — why rock those Balmain beads? — and a new person a chance to surprise and lead. Will we see more such moves?

headline: Balloon-Borne Messages to North Korea Have Detractors on Both Sides of Border
text: IMJINGAK, SOUTH KOREA — On a pleasant spring day, with the wind breezing up from the south, the quirky little tourist outpost of Imjingak — with its Peace Land amusement park, some souvenir sheds and a Popeye’s chicken stand — hardly seemed like a possible flash point for violent hostilities between North and South Korea.

headline: Much Ado Over Royal Wedding in Secular Republic of France
text: PARIS — For a country proud of its republican streak, France is making quite a fuss over the British royal wedding.

headline: European Champions League (Graphically Speaking)
text: Fresh off the production of a novel way to view the 2010 World Cup, some of the soccer-obsessed folks at Hyperakt, a New York-based design firm, have come up with a similar representation for the European Champions League semifinals, which began Tuesday in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, with the match between Schalke 04 and Manchester United.

headline: Aeromotional
text: A car design that combines aerodynamics and nostalgia.

headline: A Fresh Look at Fighting Global Poverty
text: Dean Karlan, a Yale economist, and Jacob Appel, a former field researcher in West Africa, are the authors of a new book about fighting global poverty, “More Than Good Intentions.” Richard Thaler has described the book on the Nudge blog, and Tyler Cowen has called Mr. Karlan “one of my favorite young economists.”

headline: Style Map | Turin, Italy
text: Locals might scoff at the idea of Turin being convenient to Milan, but a fairly efficient recent high-speed railway link from Milano Centrale to Torino Porta Nuova has brought the two Italian cities within an hour’s reach. Which means that should you find yourself in Milan, it’s entirely possible to pop over for a leisurely lunch, stroll Turin’s elegant city center and even take in some art — and still make it back by curtain time at La Scala. View interactive feature >>

headline: The Library Hands Out Menus to Thousands of Volunteers
text: If Rebecca Federman and Ben Vershbow of the New York Public Library get their wish, they will have thrown an epic party for tens of thousands of people who visited, enjoyed the food and then, like perfect guests, did all the dishes.

headline: Couric Confirms Departure From CBS
text: 7:46 p.m. | Updated | Katie Couric confirmed on Tuesday what has been widely reported for weeks: that she will leave her job as the anchor of the “CBS Evening News.”

headline: Dancing Past the Reruns
text: With mostly reruns on CBS and Fox, “Dancing With the Stars” dominated Monday night in the ratings, attracting 21.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That ABC reality competition easily led its 90-minute time slot from 8 to 9:30 p.m. while boosting ABC’s sitcom “Better With You” at 9:30 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night with repeats of its sitcoms, including “How I Met Your Mother” at 8 (5.3 million), “The Big Bang Theory” at 9 (7.7 million), and “Mike & Molly” at 9:30 (7.8 million). A new installment of “Mad Love” garnered 5.6 million viewers at 8:30. Fox edged past NBC for third place, earning 4.8 million for a rerun of “House” at 8 followed by a repeat of “The Chicago Code” (4.1 million). NBC finished in fourth despite broadcasting new episodes of “The Event” at 9 (4.4 million) and “Law & Order: Los Angeles” at 10 (5.8 million), which trailed behind repeats of CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (7 million) and ABC’s “Castle” (7.6 million) in its time slot.

headline: The Confidence Fairy Has Taken a Leave of Absence
text: Was it only last June when Alan Reynolds was holding Ireland up as a role model, not just for troubled European economies, but for the United States? Yes, it was:

headline: Dungeons and Zombies, Sure, but Here the Trade’s the Thing
text: IRVINE, Calif. — Writing about a game that hasn’t been released to the public can be risky. It might end up as vaporware or simply not live up to the awesome impression that publishers can gin up in a short, canned demonstration. But when it comes to a new game from Blizzard Entertainment, perhaps the world’s most accomplished and prestigious developer, an exception seems merited.

headline: Culture of Complicity Tied to Stricken Nuclear Plant
text: TOKYO — Given the fierce insularity of Japan’s nuclear industry, it was perhaps fitting that an outsider exposed the most serious safety cover-up in the history of Japanese nuclear power. It took place at Fukushima Daiichi, the plant that Japan has been struggling to get under control since last month’s earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Donations at the Checkout Counter Are Often Deductible
text: If you find yourself inside a big chain drug store once or twice a week, you’ve probably been asked whether you want to donate $1 or so to a particular cause at the checkout counter.

headline: Data Misconceptions
text: Just a quick note on three misconceptions I often see in comments:

headline: On Plankton, Warming and Whiplash
text: A new study in Nature Climate Change, “Revaluating ocean warming impacts on global phytoplankton,” has shown that the method used to calculate phytoplankton loss in the 2010 research greatly overstated plankton losses because of a missing vital factor. Read New Scientist for the details.

headline: Greek Deficit Exceeds Target Set by Bailout
text: BRUSSELS — Almost a year after it adopted sweeping austerity measures as a condition of an international rescue package, Greece has failed to get a grip on its public finances, according to new data released on Tuesday, increasing fears that the country may have to restructure its mountain of debt.

headline: TBS Orders Its Third Tyler Perry Series
text: If artistic achievement can be measured by the number of shows one has on TBS, Tyler Perry leads Spike Lee in that category, 3-0. On Tuesday that network announced that it was picking up a third television series from Mr. Perry, the actor-writer-director, mini-mogul and sometime nemesis of Mr. Lee, to be adapted from his “Why Did I Get Married?” movies. The new series, to be called “For Better or Worse,” will be a comedy-drama produced by Tyler Perry Studios and will star Michael Jai White (“The Dark Knight”) and Tasha Smith (“Couples Retreat”) as the husband-and-wife couple they have portrayed in the “Married” films. The new series, which will start with a 10-episode order and does not yet have a premiere date, joins Mr. Perry’s TBS comedies “Meet the Browns” and “House of Payne,” which is coming to the end of its run. In a statement, Mr. Perry said: “Working on ‘House of Payne’ taught me a lot about what it takes to make a successful television series and I’m looking forward to applying that experience to ‘For Better or Worse.’ ”

headline: Despite Transmission Failures, Agency Will Not Require Further Action from Honda
text: Although hundreds of Honda owners have reported failures of their vehicles’ automatic transmissions, in some cases saying they were unable to safely cross a busy street or merge into traffic, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it found no reason to take action.

headline: Obama Calls for Repeal of Tax Breaks for Oil Firms
text: With gasoline at the pump costing well over $4 a gallon, President Obama on Tuesday urged congressional leaders to repeal tax breaks for oil and gas companies, and to use the money to reduce the country’s dependence on foreign oil.

headline: Gender Games: Answering Questions About Roster Management and Title IX
text: With 270 comments and counting, New York Times readers reacted to my article in Tuesday’s paper about roster management with passion, insight and numerous personal stories about how Title IX had affected their lives, whether good or bad. Many readers questioned why so much attention is paid to female athletes and argued that the fact that 57 percent of college students are now female is proof of discrimination against men by colleges and universities. Others asserted that Title IX overlooks the fact that men and women have different interests, and raised the question of whether fewer women want to play sports. Still others said the examples cited in the article showed that, 40 years after it was passed, Title IX needs to be rewritten.

headline: Fete Accompli | Chanel’s Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#584", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Acts of Remembrance: Reflecting on How the Holocaust Is Taught
text: Overview | Does the abundance of Holocaust analogies in contemporary society affect the way that we remember the Holocaust? How can we both foster understanding of the Holocaust and encourage young people to draw personal connections? In this lesson, students take a critical look at the ways in which the Holocaust is both referred to in popular culture and taught in school, and consider how teachers and museums can help students understand the Holocaust for the atrocity that it was.

headline: Could Ron Paul 2012 Outperform Ron Paul 2008?
text: As Representative Ron Paul of Texas begins his third presidential campaign by announcing the formation of an exploratory committee, there are reasons to think the blunt congressman might wield more influence over the shape, direction and conversation of the Republican contest this time around. (Compare Mr. Paul, circa 2008 and 2012.)

headline: A Glimpse of the Le Mans 24-Hour Race
text: There is a three-week gap between the Chinese Grand Prix and the Turkish Grand Prix. This gave the organizers of the world’s most famous 24-hour endurance race a chance to bring back their annual test day, which had been canceled the last two years because of the economic crisis.

headline: A Glimpse of the Le Mans 24-Hour Race

headline: Garment Union Chief Resigns Under a Cloud
text: Facing internal charges that he had abused his expense account, Bruce S. Raynor, the president of the nation’s main garment workers’ union, Workers United, announced on Tuesday that he had resigned as president.

headline: Vouvrays With an Element of Surprise
text: PERHAPS you have not yet been bitten by the chenin blanc bug and transported to a world of luminous wines made in an astounding range of styles. If so, then opportunity is about to pull a cork for you.

headline: Pairings: Thai-Style Scallops and Asparagus
text: Asian restaurants should pay more attention to dry Vouvrays. Like rieslings, which are frequently poured with Thai, Vietnamese and Chinese dishes, Vouvrays knit bright acidity into their alluring canvas of citric and floral aromas and flavors, sometimes kissed with spice or sugar. They are ready for action the minute the fragrances of ginger, coriander and lemon grass waft from the kitchen.

headline: As Wall St. Firms Grow, Their Reputations Are Dying
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Field Not Set for First Republican Debate
text: Another hiccup from the Republicans’ nascent presidential nominating contest: With not much more than a week to go before what was to be the first big debate of the campaign season (after the first, first big debate was postponed until September) it is still unclear how many candidates will show up.

headline: Deal Made to Repair Bronx Apartment Buildings
text: The cascading leaks, runaway rats and tumbledown ceilings that have bedeviled 10 foreclosed apartment buildings in the Bronx will be repaired under an enforcement agreement that the city forged with the new owner, city officials announced Tuesday.

headline: Learning About Loss
text: “You have learned something” George Bernard Shaw wrote. “That always feels at first as if you have lost something.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Turkey, Philippines and Russia.

headline: ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” Returning to Broadway
text: George and Martha are coming back to Broadway in 2012, seven years since their last rounds of Get the Guests.

headline: TimesCast | April 26, 2011
text: April 26, 2011 - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's daughter Aisha gives rare insight into her family's struggle to hold on to power in Libya; and NATO broadens its attacks on Tripoli.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Turkey, Philippines and Russia.

headline: Gaming Executive Jumps to Zynga
text: Monday was the last day at Electronic Arts for John Schappert, the company’s chief operating officer. Mr. Schappert has taken a post at Zynga, the social gaming company and a competitor of Electronic Arts, according to a person briefed on the move who was not authorized to talk about personnel changes.

headline: Upgrading the Districts API With RGeo
text: Last year we launched the Districts API, which enables users to retrieve political districts for a location within New York City. The Districts API had its roots in a web application called Represent, which was built using a Python framework with spatial capabilities. At the time Represent was launched, the options for building Ruby mapping applications that used PostgreSQL’s spatial features were fairly few, and when we built the Districts service we chose a Ruby adapter that supported many of the most common geometrical features supported by PostGIS.

headline: This Little Piggy Built a Glass House
text: Steven Guarnaccia’s twists on “Goldilocks and the Three Bears” and “The Three Little Pigs” (Abrams, $19) recast the fairy tales as only a design dork could. So Papa Bear’s chair has a ladder back (by Charles Rennie Mackintosh). Goldilocks eats out of an Eva Zeisel bowl. The Three Little Pigs are (above, from left) Philip Johnson, Frank Gehry and Frank Lloyd Wright. And the house before which the Big Bad Wolf hopelessly huffs and puffs is none other than Fallingwater.

headline: Of Maidens and Monks, in a Cozy Concert
text: The spontaneity of the 19th-century German Liederabend, an “evening of song” usually held in a parlor setting, is hard to recreate in a large, formal concert hall. But the genial stage presence of the superb German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff added a touch of coziness to a recital of works by Brahms and Schumann for vocal ensemble and two pianists at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening.

headline: A Kentucky Museum of Coca-Cola Memorabilia Closes
text: A family-run Coca-Cola museum alongside a turnpike ramp in Elizabethtown, Ky., closed without warning late Tuesday, and its 80,000 artifacts will be cataloged for auctions starting in September.

headline: Do You Have a Question for Mr. Bernanke?
text: The Federal Reserve enters the age of television Wednesday afternoon. Chairman Ben S. Bernanke will hold a news conference after the regular meeting of the Fed’s policy-making committee, breaking with the central bank’s tradition of issuing nothing more than a brief, carefully worded statement describing its decisions.

headline: Anti-Sprawl Anthems
text: Dear Brad: Mountains Beyond Mountains is very fine, but if forced to choose I’d still go for Chrissie Hynde.

headline: ‘Sister Act’ and ‘Anything Goes’ Lead Outer Critics Circle Nominations
text: No nominations for Signature Theater Company’s revival of Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America”? Or for Broadway’s “Driving Miss Daisy”? No outstanding new play nod for “Jerusalem,” and no outstanding musical shout-out for “Catch Me If You Can”?

headline: Madame Nhu, Vietnam War Lightning Rod, Dies
text: Madame Nhu, who as the glamorous official hostess in South Vietnam’s presidential palace became a politically powerful and often harshly outspoken figure in the early years of the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Rome, where she had been living. She was 86.

headline: Amazon Earnings Hurt by Spending as Revenue Increases 38%
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon.com’s expansion of its online retailing and cloud computing businesses has eroded profits.

headline: Excerpt: 'The People in the Picture'
text: Megan Reinking, left, and Donna Murphy sing the number "Oyfen Pripitchik" from the new Broadway musical. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: A Summertime Arts Structure for Governors Island
text: The sponsors of the year-old City of Dreams Pavilion Competition, in which designers compete to create a temporary space for summertime arts activities on Governors Island with minimal environmental impact, have announced this year’s winning entry. “Burble Bup,” by the design team Bittertang, will consist of a dome made from inflatable components and mounds made of soil and bark-filled fabric tubes for sitting and climbing; it will be open to the public from May 27 to Sept. 25. According to a statement released by Figment, one of the sponsors, the project was selected from among some 80 competitors and is intended to encourage visitors to lie back and “enjoy the shifting colors as light plays through the translucent skins of the Bups.”

headline: Pink for the Boys, Blue for the Girls
text: In light of the recent flap surrounding the J. Crew ad depicting designer Jenna Lyons painting her son’s toenails pink, I enjoyed reading this Smithsonian.com article by Jeanne Maglaty, “When Did Girls Start Wearing Pink?”

headline: In Endeavour’s Final Act, the Supporting Cast Draws Outsize Attention
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — Capt. Mark E. Kelly, the commander of the space shuttle Endeavour, said Tuesday that his wounded wife, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, was “more than medically ready” to travel to Florida for the launching.

headline: Technology Advances; Humans Supersize
text: For nearly three decades, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Robert W. Fogel and a small clutch of colleagues have assiduously researched what the size and shape of the human body say about economic and social changes throughout history, and vice versa. Their research has spawned not only a new branch of historical study but also a provocative theory that technology has sped human evolution in an unprecedented way during the past century.

headline: Sony Says PlayStation Hacker Got Personal Data
text: Christopher Miller’s PlayStation Portable game console had been broken for most of two years. So when his parents got him a new one for his 25th birthday on April 18, he was elated — but only briefly.

headline: Low Tide and Lower Ambitions
text: LIKE a stray piece of driftwood, a James Perse outpost has washed up on a well-trafficked corner of SoHo, facing the Gourmet Garage, formerly the very apex of Manhattan discount gastronomy, with its shrink-wrapped Camembert. The new shop is a mere mile or so from Mr. Perse’s New York headquarters in the West Village, where the windows once displayed large white typeface reading: “No returns. No refitting. No exchanges. Just kidding.”

text: A few things worth mentioning about core inflation:

headline: A Distinctive Voice, No Matter Who Is Performing
text: John Hollenbeck composes so much music for his own bands — Refuge Trio, the Claudia Quintet and his Large Ensemble, each unmistakable in its identity — that you could go a long time before wondering about the transferable aspects of his style.

headline: Interview: Chris Paine
text: Chris Paine, the director of "Revenge of the Electric Car," discusses making this follow-up to his 2006 documentary.

headline: Star Chef, Facing a Suit, Files for Bankruptcy
text: GEOFFREY ZAKARIAN has made all the right moves for a celebrity chef. He is a fixture on four Food Network programs, including “Chopped.” Over the years, he has operated a number of high-profile restaurants, three of which have won three stars from The New York Times. He now has two places in fashionable New York hotels and a hand in hotels in Miami Beach and Atlantic City.

headline: Injured and in the Hospital, but Liberated by Caravaggio
text: Sure, the great Houdini wiggled his way out of all sorts of complicated contraptions. But could he have found a path through the misery, fear and boredom that ensnare a person during an emergency hospital visit?

headline: Putin Criticizes West for Libya Incursion
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday delivered his most passionate critique to date of the Western intervention in Libya, underlining a rare open disagreement between him and his protégé, President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

headline: In Store | Unknown Union
text: With a killer kaleidoscopic interior and labels that range from hipster (Warriors of Radness, Naked and Famous Denim) to heritage (Pendleton, Penfield), Unknown Union, Cape Town’s newest men’s store — curated by Sean Shuter, one of its owners — is also its coolest. headline: A Doctor in Just About Every Theatrical House
text: As an executive producer on the NBC series “Cheers,” Cheri Steinkellner spent years rewriting dialogue when scripts didn’t snap with sufficient Sam-and-Rebecca repartee. So she was unfazed, she said, upon learning last fall that her own script for the musical “Sister Act” — six years in the making — would have “additional text” by the playwright Douglas Carter Beane for the show’s Broadway debut this spring.

headline: Refillable Jugs to Satisfy That Iced-Coffee Craving
text: Serious about iced coffee? The best way to make it is using the cold-brewing method that takes about 12 hours overnight. Now a couple of places in New York are not only cold-brewing coffee, but also selling it in 64-ounce growlers.

headline: More Changes at Universal Music: Renzer Out
text: In the latest change among the top management at the Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music company, the head of the company’s music publishing unit for the last seven years is stepping down.

headline: Poll Finds Most Americans Uncertain of Trump’s Birthplace
text: A new Gallup/USA Today poll finds significant doubt about whether Donald Trump, the real estate mogul and television personality who is considering a bid for presidency, was born in the United States.

headline: When Refrigerators Warm the Planet
text: The kitchen refrigerator is an obvious contributor to global warming because it usually sucks in electricity that was made by burning fossil fuels. But it turns out that the refrigerator does harm to the environment before it is even plugged in because the insulating foam in its innards is made with a gas that is more than 1,000 times worse, molecule for molecule, than carbon dioxide.

headline: Columbia Professor’s Retirement Is Big News in Japan
text: The spring semester is ending at Columbia University and work crews on Tuesday were busy sprucing up the campus and preparing for commencement.

headline: After Quake in Japan, a Toyota Dealer Slowly Regains Its Footing
text: ISHINOMAKI, Japan — As soon as the ground stopped bucking under the small Toyota dealer in this port city on March 11, the staff scattered to survey the quake’s damage. Nothing drastic: cracks in the showroom walls, fallen display lights.

headline: A Playwright’s Legacy, Kindled by Addiction and Neglect
text: Our introduction to “The Arbor,” Clio Barnard’s tightrope-walking experiment with fact, fiction and the spaces in between, is the sight of two mangy curs nosing through trash. Their appearance is our first clue that the leafy green serenity suggested by the film’s title is unlikely to materialize.

headline: The London Candy Company Opens in New York
text: Some of the brightly wrapped bars, boxes and sacks that fill the shelves and bins in this store, which specializes in English candy, might come as a surprise. Along with Aeros, Toffee Crisp Clusters and Minstrels, there are M & M’s, Snickers and Twix. What’s so Brit about those? But Jigs Patel, who opened the store about two weeks ago, said that those candies with the familiar names are made for the English and European market. The sweetener is cane sugar, not corn syrup, making them taste a tad less sweet, as a comparison of domestic and imported M & M’s showed.

headline: A Chef Who Is Vegetarian in Fame if Not in Fact
text: “VEGETARIANS in general don’t like me,” Yotam Ottolenghi said ruefully.

headline: A Book of Recipes Gathered From Holocaust Survivors
text: Recipe books based on the memories of Holocaust survivors might seem to trivialize the horror. But Dr. Ruth Westheimer, one of the survivors featured in “Recipes Remembered: A Celebration of Survival,” said that food represents identity for these people who did not have a real homeland. June Feiss Hersh interviewed more than 100 survivors and their relatives for the book, and recorded their stories, food memories and recipes, which she also tested. When the dish called for ketchup or canned tomato soup, that’s what the recipe included.

headline: Lobbyist Fires Warning Shot Over Donation Disclosure Plan
text: WASHINGTON — So much for détente.

headline: Thinking Outside the Canvas
text: WASHINGTON — As art mediums go, painting is both intractably consistent and endlessly malleable, and perhaps never more so than now. While it continues to renew itself in its traditional paint-on-canvas incarnations, there’s also a well-established maverick branch that is constantly stretching the medium, extending it into installation art or questioning its status as a precious, high-skill commodity, sometimes by eliminating paint altogether.

headline: City Ways Tried, a Market Finds Rural Works Best
text: Country stores like you imagine still exist. With old farmers sitting on a bench in front and glass bottles full of cold soda that you open with that little metal doohickey on the side of the cooler.

headline: Government in Yemen Agrees to Talk Transition
text: Yemen’s government on Tuesday formally agreed to a plan that would pave the way for a peaceful transition of power, saying that a delegation from the governing party planned to travel to Saudi Arabia early next week to seal the deal.

headline: House G.O.P. Members Face Voter Anger Over Budget
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In central Florida, a Congressional town meeting erupted into near chaos on Tuesday as attendees accused a Republican lawmaker of trying to dismantle Medicare while providing tax cuts to corporations and affluent Americans.

headline: A Blinky Palermo Retrospective
text: Paintings in the first American retrospective of the German painter’s work.

headline: Arizona: Judge Rules Against Maricopa Deputies
text: A federal judge ruled Monday that the Maricopa County Sheriff’s Department violated the constitutional rights of Julio Mora, an American citizen, and his father, Julian, a legal resident, in 2009 when deputies stopped their truck and took them to a business where an immigration raid was under way. The Moras were detained along with others arrested in the raid. A trial is expected this year to determine whether the detention was racially motivated and whether Sheriff Joe Arpaio and the deputies should be held individually liable.

headline: Texas: Power Failures Cause Refineries to Shut
text: School was canceled and residents were told to stay indoors in Texas City on Tuesday after power failures forced three large oil refineries and a chemical plant to shut operations and burn toxic gases that spewed from smokestacks, officials said. Just after noon, city officials lifted the order to stay indoors. It remained unclear, however, how much pollution had been released during the night, Bruce Clawson, the city’s emergency management director said. A BP refinery and a Dow Chemical plant lost power about 10:30 p.m. on Monday. A second power failure at 4:30 a.m. forced two other refineries belonging to Marathon and Valero to shut down. The cause of the power failures was still being investigated.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Text Messages Proliferate as Threats in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — When he returned to his native Kurdistan in February to join the flickering of a protest movement, Dr. Pishtewan Abdellah, a hematologist who lives in Australia but also carries an Iraqi passport, suspected that the demonstrators might face harsh treatment from the Kurdish authorities. At several protests during the last two months security forces have opened fire, and an estimated 10 people have been killed and dozens wounded, according to human rights activists.

text: Oh, my. Rather than answering my question — where are these big new Obama programs? — he points to CBO projections showing that spending on mandatory programs is expected to remain high in 2021.

headline: Throw Your Arms Up and Hope
text: Ian Kennedy had it all planned, he said last Friday in the Arizona Diamondbacks’ clubhouse at Citi Field. His wife, Allison, was due to deliver their first child May 8, and the timing was pretty much perfect. The team would be close by on the due date, in San Diego, and if Allison went into labor early, that would be fine. The Diamondbacks had 11 days at home as soon as they left New York.

headline: YouTube Is Said to Be Near a Major Film Rental Deal
text: LOS ANGELES — A two-year effort by YouTube, owned by Google, to get major Hollywood studios to offer their new-release movies for rental is coming closer to reality.

headline: Friendster to Erase Early Posts and Old Photos
text: Long before there was a Facebook, or even a MySpace, there was Friendster, a Web site that gave many people their first taste of the socially networked world to come.

headline: Durkin Will Not Call the Derby
text: Tom Durkin, the signature voice of American horse racing, will not call the Kentucky Derby or any other Triple Crown race this spring. He said his mental health was more important than his participation in telecasts of three of the sport’s most significant races.

headline: Syria Tries to Defend Its Record to United Nations
text: UNITED NATIONS — Syria, facing mounting global pressure over its decisions to move tanks into cities against its own citizens and to shoot unarmed demonstrators, tried to defend its record against blunt denunciations from the United States and others on Tuesday at the United Nations, where the Security Council is struggling to forge a collective response.

text: Last week, the U.S. Department of Transportation announced that it would begin requiring airlines to “prominently disclose all potential fees on their Web sites.” Great. Now, can we just get rental car companies to do the same?

headline: Government, Too, Has Trouble Selling Buildings
text: For more than six years Akridge, a developer in Washington, had its eye on a 10-story office building in Bethesda, Md., which had been vacant since the National Institutes of Health moved out in 2002.

text: FACEBOOK is looking to make some new friends on Madison Avenue.

headline: A State Manager Takes Over and Cuts What a City Can’t
text: BENTON HARBOR, Mich. — Every first and third Monday of the month for as long as anyone can remember, this city’s elected commissioners have gathered in their musty second-floor chambers to contend with issues large and small — reports of gaping potholes, proposals to sell city land, an annual budget plan.

headline: TimesCast | NATO Expands Libyan Targets
text: NATO allies are stepping up attacks in Tripoli in an effort to weaken Muammar el-Qaddafi's power.

headline: A Conspicuous Absence at Berkshire Meeting
text: David L. Sokol was treated like a rock star at last year’s annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett. Shareholders lined up for autographs and snapshots of the executive considered by many to be Mr. Buffett’s successor.

headline: New Jersey Official Halts Carl Lewis’s Bid for the Legislature
text: Carl Lewis’s career in politics may have lasted about as long as one of the Olympic races that made him famous. On Tuesday, the New Jersey lieutenant governor ruled that he had not lived in the state long enough to run for a seat in the State Senate.

headline: The Republican Threat to Voting
text: Less than a year before the 2012 presidential voting begins, Republican legislatures and governors across the country are rewriting voting laws to make it much harder for the young, the poor and African-Americans — groups that typically vote Democratic — to cast a ballot.

headline: Making the Cut for Bernanke’s News Conference
text: Readers of my column this week — which suggests questions for reporters to ask of Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, during his groundbreaking news conference on Wednesday — may wonder why I can’t simply ask the questions myself. There’s a simple answer: I’m not invited.

headline: Projects Shelved in the Downturn Spring Back to Life
text: During the recession the developer Brookfield Office Properties shelved plans to build several office towers on a 5.4-million-square-foot property that runs from Ninth Avenue to Dyer Avenue, between West 31st and West 33rd Streets. But Brookfield did not ignore the project in the downturn.

headline: A Bridge Under Scrutiny, by Plotters and the Police
text: Al Qaeda has long had a fascination with suspension bridges, especially the Brooklyn Bridge. New documents reveal that before Sept. 11, 2001, methods for bringing down bridges were being taught at a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan.

headline: Exchange Risks Without Mergers
Atheists Seek Chaplain Role in the Military
text: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — In the military, there are more than 3,000 chaplains who minister to the spiritual and emotional needs of active duty troops, regardless of their faiths. The vast majority are Christians, a few are Jews or Muslims, one is a Buddhist. A Hindu, possibly even a Wiccan may join their ranks soon.

headline: A Court Battle Over a Husband’s Rage and a Wife Who’d Had Enough
text: During their son’s freshman year at college, Barbara and Raymond Sheehan had a weekend ritual of driving to Connecticut from Howard Beach, Queens, to watch him play football, take him to dinner and deliver clean laundry. On Feb. 17, 2008, they made the trip, ate a meal, then headed home.

headline: Justices’ Debate Turns to Privacy for Doctors
text: WASHINGTON — A somewhat esoteric Supreme Court case on Tuesday about data mining by drug companies turned into a debate over a fundamental First Amendment principle that has much engaged the justices lately: What role may the government play in regulating the marketplace of ideas?

headline: Who Protects the Animals?
text: Getting caught is a drag.

headline: After Fatal Fire, City Vows Crackdown on Illegal Apartments
text: Fire officials determined on Tuesday that the Bronx row house where a 12-year-old boy and his parents died in a fast-moving fire a day earlier  had been illegally subdivided, leading city officials to pledge a crackdown on a practice that can impede firefighters and imperil lives.

headline: Poly Styrene, Punk Singer of X-Ray Spex, Is Dead at 53
text: Marianne Elliot-Said, who as Poly Styrene, the pioneering, braces-wearing frontwoman of the 1970s British band X-Ray Spex, made a place for feminine brashness in punk, died on Monday in East Sussex, England. She was 53.

headline: Judge Declares Mistrial in Police Altercation Case
text: A Manhattan judge declared a mistrial Tuesday on a single count of resisting arrest against the wife of a former police officer after the jury said it was deadlocked on the charge.

headline: Seeking an Answer, Hughes Goes for More Tests

headline: Detainees’ Lawyers Can’t Click on Leaked Documents

headline: Wednesday: Adorable One
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen a puzzle from William I. Johnston since 2003 (Across Lite, Solution), but as you can plainly see, he’s baaaack. And it’s about time.

headline: Deportation Halted for Some Students as Lawmakers Seek New Policy
text: Olga Zanella, a Mexican-born college student in Texas, should have started months ago trying to figure out how she could make a life in Mexico, since American immigration authorities were working resolutely to deport her there.

headline: Power Struggle Led to Melee at Sikh Center in Queens
text: A bloody melee among worshipers at a Sikh temple in Queens over the weekend was only the most public and violent episode in a roiling power struggle marked by frequent confrontations, death threats and a lawsuit, members of New York’s Sikh community said on Tuesday.

headline: This Year’s Hospital Trip Shows Only Mets’ Unity
text: WASHINGTON — Less than a year after one of the most distasteful incidents in recent Mets history, the team made a return visit to Walter Reed Army Medical Center here Tuesday, this time led by Sandy Alderson, the team’s general manager and a Vietnam veteran.

headline: The Milk of Resistance

headline: Can You Make Money on Small Customers?
text: We just published a case study that explores whether Big D Custom Screen Printing can become profitable by taking small orders — even ones for a single T-shirt.

headline: Briere Helps Flyers Oust the Sabres
text: PHILADELPHIA — A year after an improbable run to the Stanley Cup finals, the Philadelphia Flyers may be off on another magical postseason ride.

headline: In WikiLeaks’ Growth, Some Control Is Lost
text: WikiLeaks, the Web site responsible for publicizing millions of state secrets in the last year, has tried to pick its media partners carefully. But the site has become such a large player in journalism that some of its secrets are no longer its own to control.

headline: Between Torment and Happiness

headline: An Ardent Friend Forever; Then Came the Theft Charges
