headline: Soriano Lets One Get Away; White Sox Don’t
text: Paul Konerko, a veteran first baseman for the Chicago White Sox, hit one of Rafael Soriano’s pitches with such a sharp crack Tuesday that the only two questions were how far the ball would travel into the left-field seats and how loudly Yankees fans would boo Soriano.

headline: Hundreds Protest Hiring of Katonah Superintendent
text: Drawing protests from teachers and parents, a Westchester County school district has offered its top job to a superintendent from the Milwaukee suburbs who endorsed the Wisconsin governor’s efforts to limit collective bargaining rights for teachers.

headline: Diplomat Is Expected to Receive Afghan Post
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will most likely soon nominate the veteran diplomat Ryan C. Crocker to be the next United States ambassador to Afghanistan, an administration official said Tuesday.

headline: Young’s Rocky Return Yields to Smooth Relief in a Fifth Straight Win
text: WASHINGTON — When Jayson Werth, the power-hitting right fielder for the Washington Nationals, walked to the plate in the fifth inning Tuesday night, he had already dented the Mets’ pitching once by smashing a home run. Now, with the score tied, he was in position to do even more damage.

headline: Hiding the Truth About Factory Farms
text: A supermarket shopper buying hamburger, eggs or milk has every reason, and every right, to wonder how they were produced. The answer, in industrial agriculture, is “behind closed doors,” and that’s how the industry wants to keep it. In at least three states — Iowa, Florida, and Minnesota — legislation is moving ahead that would make undercover investigations in factory farms, especially filming and photography, a crime. The legislation has only one purpose: to hide factory-farming conditions from a public that is beginning to think seriously about animal rights and the way food is produced.

headline: Long After Microsoft, Allen and Gates Cast Shadows Over City
text: SEATTLE — Perhaps at some point there will be one final screaming match between Paul Allen and Bill Gates, the Microsoft founders who transformed this city into a computer capital more than 30 years ago and whose vast fortunes, and different tastes, have been reshaping it ever since.

headline: Cynical Games With Title IX
text: The number of women who participate in college sports has more than quintupled — from fewer than 30,000 to 186,000 — since 1972, when Congress banned sex discrimination in federally financed education programs. But as Katie Thomas reported in The Times on Tuesday, as women have become a majority on many campuses, some schools are trying to evade Title IX and undermine the goal of gender equality by cooking the books when they report statistics to Washington.

headline: Irked at Democrats, Firefighters Suspend Federal Contributions
text: The nation’s main firefighters’ union, long a strong supporter of Democratic candidates, announced on Tuesday that it would indefinitely suspend all contributions to federal candidates out of frustration with Congressional Democrats who, union officials say, have not fought harder against budget cuts and antiunion legislation.

headline: Bad Numbers
text: If there was any lingering doubt, the latest data confirm that housing is still in a deep and broad recession. In the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price report for 20 large cities, house prices in February fell to a level last seen in April 2009 — their lowest point in the bust. In a Census Bureau report, new home sales in March remained near their lowest levels since records were first kept in 1963.

headline: No Prosecution Seen for Official in N.S.A. Leak
text: WASHINGTON — A former Justice Department official who told Newsweek that he was one of the sources for a 2005 article in The New York Times about the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without warrants will not be prosecuted for leaking secret information, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Nobody Puts Condoleezza Rice in a Corner
text: Much has been written about your unique relationship with George W. Bush. You’re a history buff — are you aware of any relationships like it? Not really. I think there have been other secretaries of state who were close friends, like James Baker and George H. W. Bush. But when you’re in those positions, you always have to remember that he’s the president, he’s the elected one. The president can never quite be your friend. The fact that you have been friends before he was president just gives you a level of trust and a level of comfort that I think is very helpful. I could be very direct with him.

headline: Walsh Seen as Returning if Autonomy Is Assured
text: The future of Donnie Walsh and several other key Knicks officials should become clearer soon, after a meeting between Walsh, the team president, and James L. Dolan, the Madison Square Garden president.

headline: Word of the Day | dirge
text: dirge •\ˈdərj\• noun

headline: Does Exercise Really Boost Your Mood?
text: There exists a large and soothing body of scientific literature suggesting that regular exercise can improve someone’s mood and fight anxiety. And then there is this experiment from Germany, in which researchers placed running wheels in the cages of a group of laboratory mice and let them exercise at will.

headline: A Weekend in Malibu
text: This slice of coast is a laid-back beach town with top-notch beaches, restaurants and museums.

headline: Beyoncé Makes Video in Support of Michelle Obama Effort
text: 10:49 a.m. | Updated A sweatless Beyoncé Knowles appears in a new workout video in support of Michelle Obama’s campaign against childhood obesity that was released late Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Max van der Stoel, Diplomat Who Uncovered Hussein’s Abuses, Dies at 86
text: Max van der Stoel, a career Dutch diplomat who used his appointment as the United Nations’ official watchdog on Iraqi human rights abuses in the 1990s to paint searing portraits of Saddam Hussein’s murderous government, died on April 23 at his home in The Hague. He was 86.

headline: Video: Beyoncé Dances for Michelle Obama
text: Ashley Southall writes on the Times’s Artsbeat blog about the release of Beyoncé’s video on behalf of Michelle Obama’s campaign to combat childhood obesity in the United States.

headline: Shelled, Idled and Battling On in Libya
text: NATO intensified its strikes against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s assets as the port of Misurata was closed due to shelling.

headline: Mexico: Body Counts Increase as Authorities Search Mass Graves
text: The number of bodies found in mass graves in northeastern Mexico has risen to 183, officials said Tuesday as investigators continued searching a rural region of Tamaulipas State about 90 miles south of the Texas border. The authorities have detained 74 people, including 17 police officers from the municipality of San Fernando, on suspicion of involvement in the killings, Mexico’s attorney general, Marisela Morales, said. Many of the victims were believed to be migrants traveling to the United States on long-distance buses who were kidnapped by the Zetas drug cartel. Officials searching through another mass grave in the north-central state of Durango said Tuesday that the toll there had risen to 75.

headline: New Zealand: Christchurch Facing 20 Years of Earthquake Repairs
text: Christchurch, New Zealand’s second-largest city, faces up to 20 years of rebuilding as a result of an earthquake in February that destroyed one-third of its central business district, according to a business official involved in the project. “There will not be a finite day on which this is finished,” said Jonathan Ling, chief executive of Fletcher Building Ltd. “There will be new buildings going up” in the central business district, Mr. Ling said, “on empty blocks probably for 10, 15 or 20 years.” Fletcher Building was appointed by the government as project manager for the reconstruction of homes damaged in Christchurch after a magnitude 7 temblor on Sept. 4. It is also directing some repairs in the business district after another quake, on Feb. 22, killed more than 170 people and destroyed much of the city.

headline: News Quiz | April 27, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: J.&J. to Buy Synthes for $21.3 Billion
text: Johnson & Johnson said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the medical equipment maker Synthes for $21.3 billion in cash and stock, in one of the biggest deals ever in the health care sector.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 27, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Lack of Data Heightens Japan’s Nuclear Crisis.”

headline: Chernobyl, 25 Years Later
text: Note: All the questions below can be answered by using the short article “Ghost Town Bears Witness to Lasting Nuclear Scourge,” but other resources have been provided in case students would like to read more.

headline: BP Profit Falls as Costs of Gulf of Mexico Spill Outweigh Higher Oil Prices
text: LONDON — An increase in oil prices over the last year helped BP’s first-quarter earnings, but not enough to outweigh the costs of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: J.D. Power: Fuel-Pump Savings, Not Environmental Benefits, Inform Most Alternative-Powertrain Purchases
text: For most car shoppers, a green vehicle’s ability to save an owner money at the pump is a greater motivator for purchase than its lower environmental impact. That is one of the primary findings of the inaugural 2011 U.S. Green Automotive Study by J. D. Power and Associates, released Wednesday.

headline: What Annoys You?

headline: Chris Hondros in New York
text: Africa and Asia were the settings of the photos for which Chris Hondros of Getty Images will be best remembered. But Brooklyn was his home, as his friend Todd Heisler recalls.

headline: Credit Suisse Profit Drops 45%
text: Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that its net income fell significantly in the first quarter, as the wider banking sector struggled to maintain profit levels.

headline: Pipeline Blast in Sinai, Said to Be Sabotage, Cuts Gas Supply in Israel and Jordan
text: JERUSALEM — An explosion early Wednesday at a gas pipeline in the northern Sinai Peninsula cut supplies of Egyptian natural gas to Israel for the second time this year in what Israeli and Egyptian officials said was an act of sabotage.

headline: Long Repressed in Syria, an Internal Opposition Takes Shape
text: Syria’s nascent opposition movement, organized by an amorphous group of young activists operating mainly online, now faces its biggest test: whether it can sustain protests in the face of a brutal government crackdown.

headline: At Maison Rouge in Paris, Body Art (Literally)
text: The current exhibition at Maison Rouge, an art space in the Bastille area, is not for the faint of heart. The curator of the “Tous Cannibales” exhibition, Jeanette Zwingenberger, takes you on a journey through the history of art and across continents, on the way taking in every possible variant on the theme of cannibalism.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Christian Ponder, Second-Ranked Quarterback
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: Tibetan Exiles Elect Scholar as New Prime Minister
text: NEW DELHI — Tibet’s exiled government announced the election of a Harvard legal scholar as its new prime minister on Wednesday, a choice signaling a generational shift within the Tibetan movement as the Dalai Lama moves to relinquish political power.

headline: Papa’s in the House of Windsor
text: Thus begins my parody of “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds” now that I’ve seen the Papa John’s royal-wedding pie, which apparently is available only in England … and there’s only one, which will be raffled off to some lucky (I guess?) winner as part of William and Kate’s big day.

headline: Mitzvah Tanks Roll Again
text: “We go out there like soldiers, with a mission to conquer the world with light, with goodness, with kindness,” said Yishai Eliefja, 23, a Hasidic Jew who works for the Chabad Lubavitch’s “mitzvah tanks,” or “synagogues on wheels.”

headline: 'Are You Jewish?'
text: Mitzvah tanks, or "synagogue on wheels'', operated by the Chabad Lubavitch group of Hasidic Jews, are set to hit city streets.

headline: Afghan Military Officer Kills 8 U.S. Service Members
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Eight American service members and a contractor were shot and killed by an Afghan military officer on Wednesday while they attended a meeting of foreign and Afghan officers on the military side of Kabul International Airport, according to statements from Afghan and NATO spokesmen.

headline: New Art at Lincoln Center: Lawn Care
text: Lincoln Center has long cultivated audiences and donors. Now the country’s largest performing arts complex is learning how to cultivate grass.

headline: How We Hired a Web Developer
text: Several months ago, I wrote about my revelation that I needed (as opposed to wanted) to redo all of my Web sites. Two are e-commerce and three are informational. Like many companies, I have tried to keep up with the Internet revolution, and I think I’ve done O.K. My revelation was that O.K. is no longer good enough if you are in an industry that has seen shopping behaviors change because of the Internet. Are there any industries that haven’t?

headline: Gas Pumps Become Battleground for Obama and Republicans
text: President Obama offered top donors in California last week a peek into what he saw as one of his own vulnerabilities: the price of gas at the pump.

headline: CenturyLink Set to Acquire Savvis for $2.5 Billion
text: CenturyLink, the nation’s third largest telecommunications company, announced on Wednesday that it would buy the information technology firm Savvis for $2.5 billion, in a play on so-called cloud computing.

text: OK, a calmer followup on Taylor. Originally he claimed that there had been a huge expansion in government under Obama; I pointed out that about half the rise in the ratio of spending to GDP reflected low GDP, not high spending, and that the other half was basically safety net programs:

headline: New York Should Get a Kick Out of King Eric
text: There are lots of reasons why it’s going to be fun tracking the New York Cosmos in the coming years as the resurrected soccer team tries to make itself matter again. Above all, the characters. The flamboyant new owner, Paul Kemsley, the main subject of David Segal’s piece in the magazine a little over a week ago, seems like a good fit for a club whose roll call has included the likes of the late Steve Ross (flamboyant head of Warner Communications) and Giorgio Chinalgia (flamboyant former striker for the Cosmos, current international ambassador for the Cosmos and wanted man by the Italian authorities a couple years ago for trying to influence the share prices of S.S. Lazio). And the Wilpons might get involved.

headline: David Leonhardt is Shrill
text: He keeps pointing out that inflation is not a problem, but unemployment is, and that the Fed’s real failure has been doing too little, not too much.

headline: A Beast in the Heart of Every Fighting Man
text: Last May, in the small village of Qualaday in western Kandahar Province, a young Army lieutenant and his sergeants met with several elders to discuss the recent killing of a local mullah. The desert heat was fierce, and the elders led the soldiers across their village to sit under the shade of nearby trees. Three days had passed since they were last there; during that interval the place appeared to have been abandoned. When they sat down, some of the soldiers removed their helmets, and a few elders their sandals and turbans. A freelance photographer was permitted to make an audio recording of the discussion. The lieutenant wanted to know where everyone had gone. One elder explained: People left because they were afraid.

headline: An Insurance Company With An Army
text: A general reminder whenever budget issues are discussed: the U.S. government is — this isn’t original — best thought of as a giant insurance company with an army. When you talk about federal spending, you’re overwhelmingly talking about Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and defense. And the bulk of the insurance — all of Social Security and Medicare, about 2/3 of Medicaid — is for the elderly and disabled.

headline: A Second Life for the Electric Car Battery
text: As I wrote in a recent Times article on electric car batteries, scientists are expecting big breakthroughs in battery technology over the next five years that will increase the range of electric cars while reducing their cost. But even with these advances, researchers acknowledge that any rechargeable battery will gradually lose its capacity to store energy after repeated cycles of charging and discharging.

headline: Panetta and Petraeus in Line for Top Security Posts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will reshuffle his national security team on Thursday, naming Leon E. Panetta, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, as defense secretary and Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan, to lead the C.I.A., administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: Morning Buzz | Building That Burned Had Troubled Past
text: Alas, not quite the perfection that was Tuesday; instead, a high of about 71 degrees with some overcast skies.

headline: Wednesday Reading: How to Avoid Rental Car Fees
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: India Puts Tight Leash on Internet Free Speech
text: MUMBAI, India — Free speech advocates and Internet users are protesting new Indian regulations restricting Web content that, among other things, can be considered “disparaging,” “harassing,” “blasphemous” or “hateful.”

headline: NATO Officials Acknowledge Frustration in Libya Campaign
text: WASHINGTON – Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates stood on the steps of the Pentagon late Tuesday alongside Liam Fox, his counterpart from Britain, America’s closest ally. Questions swirled here, in Europe and across North Africa whether NATO was specifically trying to find and kill Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, with airstrikes.

headline: Big Changes to American Express’s Blue Cash Card
text: American Express is altering the rewards formula on its popular Blue Cash card, but current users will be grandfathered in under the old program for now.

headline: Boeing Chief Says Rivet Flaws Appear Limited to One Jet
text: The riveting flaws in the roof of the Southwest Airlines jet that recently tore open in flight appear to be poor manufacturing work on that one plane rather than a broader design failure, Boeing’s chief executive said Wednesday.

headline: Road-Going ‘Chitty Chitty Bang Bang’ Is Up for Auction
text: The auctioneers are calling it “The Most Famous Car in the World.” In truth, there are multiple Chitty Chitty Bang Bangs, beginning with aircraft-engined racing cars that inspired the Ian Fleming children’s book and subsequent 1968 movie.

headline: Gosh, Sweetie, That’s a Big Gun
text: THE summer season brings the usual cavalcade of testosterone-fueled action heroes, including Thor, the Green Lantern, Captain America and Conan the Barbarian. But action-movie derring-do is not always an exclusively male preserve, and in the last year some women and girls — Evelyn Salt, Lisbeth Salander and the lingerie-clad avengers of “Sucker Punch,” among others — have been shooting and not just clawing their way into macho territory. Is this empowerment or exploitation? Feminism or fetishism? The chief film critics of The New York Times, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, discuss the new pow, crash and splat.

headline: High Fiber
text: It sometimes feels as if no aspect of American midcentury modern design has been left unconsidered, unexhibited, unreissued. But there is undiscovered territory. You’re sitting on it.

headline: Bloomberg and Cuomo Meet, Over Pasta and Fish
text: The mayor ordered the fettuccine ($25). The governor had the yellowfin tuna steak ($35). Ever-vigilant about waistlines, they skipped dessert. And despite the chasm that separates their net worth, they split the bill.

headline: Orders for Manufactured Goods Rise for a Third Month
text: Businesses in the United States increased their orders for heavy machinery, computers, autos and steel in March, and raised demand for long-lasting manufactured goods for a third consecutive month.

headline: Schlesinger Letters Will Be Collected in New Book
text: The letters that Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. wrote over a career of nearly seven decades in public life, including correspondence with John F. Kennedy, Henry A. Kissinger, Katharine Graham and Reinhold Niebuhr will be collected in a new book that Random House has acquired. And while it will contain documents like Schlesinger’s critique of Kennedy’s manuscript for “Profiles in Courage,” it will not include the donkey that William F. Buckley Jr. sent to Schlesinger.

headline: UK, Not OK
text: The bad GDP number for the UK isn’t a surprise — in fact, judging from market response, investors seem to have expected something even worse. Still, if you step back and look at what has been happening, it’s doubleplusungood: zero growth over the past 6 months, with every reason to be worried on the downside looking forward, as Cameron’s austerity bites deeper.

headline: Who Made Those Emblem Health Commercials?
text: Emblem Health, a New York-based insurance company, has been running commercials for a while now with quirky, black-and-white line drawings. The campaign “revolves around using the logo as a patch to create other hand-drawn, line-art shapes” according to an article from the design site Under Consideration that was written when the commercials were first aired. Some piano music starts and ends each vignette. The effect is casual, fun and somewhat surprising for a health insurance company.

headline: Game 7 Preview: Tampa Bay at Pittsburgh
text: The Penguins are exuding a carefree attitude about the two consecutive losses that have led to a Game 7 at home tonight at 8:00 p.m. against the Lightning, and you cannot blame them. Without leading men Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin, two months ago Pittsburgh would have been pleased with hosting a Game 7 in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Obama Releases Long-Form Birth Certificate
text: President Obama on Wednesday posted online a copy of his long-form birth certificate from the State of Hawaii, hoping to finally end a long-simmering conspiracy theory among some conservatives who have asserted that he was not born in the United States and was not a legitimate president.

headline: Everyone Is ‘Middle Class,’ Right?
text: I’ve been complaining lately about how how surprisingly little Americans know about income distribution and their own place within it. Americans all seem to think they’re “middle class,” even those in the top 5 percent of all earners. As a result they frequently misunderstand what political mantras like “let’s tax the rich” really mean.

headline: Jobs Says Apple Made Mistakes With iPhone Data
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hoping to put to rest a growing controversy over privacy, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, took the unusual step of personally explaining that while Apple had made mistakes in how it handled location data on its mobile devices, it had not used the iPhone and iPad to keep tabs on the whereabouts of its customers.

headline: The Many Shapes of Climate Knowledge
text: After I gave a talk at Pennsylvania State University not long ago, a professor there asked if I could share the slide I use to describe one source of confusion and disputes when people are yelling about “global warming” or “climate change.” Here’s an improved version of the slide, which I hope helps reveal that the issue can’t be meaningfully discussed without getting into some more specifics:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: On Our Radar: Big Profits for Big Oil
text: A sharp run-up in oil prices since January will produce a windfall for major oil companies, which are expected to report their biggest quarterly profits since 2008 this week, analysts said. Leading the pack is Exxon Mobil, whose profits are expected to approach $10 billion for the first three months of the year. [MarketWatch]

headline: Ristretto | Santa Cruz Comes to Queens
text: Verve Coffee Roasters is in a small stucco shopping center on 41st Avenue, a sun-baked Santa Cruz street that surfers use to get to the beach. I first stopped by Verve in 2009 because David Kinch, the Michelin-starred chef of Manresa, is a regular, and after downing an immaculate macchiato and picking out a couple of bags of whole beans I was reminded of how the Left Coast still has it, that a roaster in a tiny storefront that’s a five-minute walk from the ocean and just down the block from a destination taqueria can turn out some of the country’s most remarkable coffee.

headline: MOOSE
text: Acronym for expenditure on information and communications technology: Maintain the Organization, Operation, Systems and Equipment.

headline: A Child Regresses. Is Autism to Blame?
text: If a young child suddenly stops speaking, is autism to blame? That is among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Fred Volkmar, director of the Yale Child Study Center, explores the issue of regression in children and the diagnosis of autism. For more information on autism, see the additional responses in “Ask the Experts About Autism,” and The Times Health Guide: Autism.

headline: Tribeca Video Interview With Chris Paine
text: The documentary filmmaker Chris Paine follows up his 2006 film “Who Killed the Electric Car?” with a profile of some of the individuals who have worked to bring electric cars back into the mainstream. Among the subjects of “Revenge of the Electric Car” are Bob Lutz, a former vice chairman of General Motors; Carlos Ghosn, the Renault-Nissan chairman; and Elon Musk, the chairman of the electric car manufacturer Tesla Motors.

headline: Marathon Organizers Highlight City’s Economic Gain
text: The New York City Marathon produces about $340 million in economic activity for the city, 25 percent more than it did in 2006, according to a new study produced by the New York Road Runners, which hosts the event.

headline: Self Esteem
text: Years ago, a friend of mine observed that 80 percent of the people in this country have way too much self-esteem and 20 percent have much too little. That struck me as pretty accurate, but psychologists will tell you that self-esteem is not a constant. People’s appraisal of their own worth varies.

headline: Sheepshead Bay Steeples to Be Stabilized, Not Removed
text: The congregants were prepared for something completely different: the removal of their beloved steeples, not the arrival of cables to hold them in place.

headline: Scores Die in Storms Across South; Tornado Ravages City
text: Devastating storms swept through the South on Wednesday, killing at least 60 people and spawning a tornado that tore through downtown Tuscaloosa, Ala. The evening twister flattened homes and buildings and brought further damage and death to a region already battered by storms.

headline: Trump Takes Credit for Release of Obama Birth Certificate
text: 12:39 p.m. | Updated  PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Donald Trump arrived here Wednesday morning, stepped off a helicopter emblazoned with his name and flashed a wide smile as he took credit for the release of President Obama’s long-form birth certificate.

headline: Ryan O’Neal to Write of Life With Farrah Fawcett
text: Someday, Ryan O’Neal might write a memoir that takes in the entirety of his career, from breakthrough films like “Love Story” and “Paper Moon” to under-appreciated works like “Barry Lyndon.” But his first book will not be that book.

headline: Light Fantastic | Olafur Eliasson in Iceland
text: On May 4 the Icelandic capital will celebrate the opening of the Harpa-Reykjavik Concert Hall and Conference Center, a stunning monolith whose shimmering glass facade was designed by the artist Olafur Eliasson. The building will be the new home of the Icelandic Opera and the Iceland Symphony Orchestra (which previously had to make do with performing in movie theaters), and for the opening celebration there will be concerts by local bands like Mammút and Agent Fresco as well as screenings of nature movies and documentaries. Many Icelanders hope the building, conceived of as a new cultural hot spot for the city, will also be a tourist draw during the long, dark winters — a fact of life that was central to the design. “In Iceland, 30 percent of the day is twilight. One third of people’s lives are lived in this transitional zone,” says Eliasson, whose facade reflects the low northern light in bewitching variation, as though it is lit from within. “The relationship people in Iceland have to the landscape is like the relationship you have to a close family member. It has to do with the way the light gives the landscape a constantly changing personality. It speaks to you with such finesse.”

headline: President Obama’s ‘Long Form’ Birth Certificate
text: President Obama on Wednesday posted online a copy of his “long form” birth certificate from the state of Hawaii, hoping to finally end a long-simmering conspiracy theory among some conservatives.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Boards Take On Lives of Their Own
text: It has been more than three months since the last meaningful college football game, but N.F.L. prospects have kept busy. They have been working out, attending pro days for scouts, meeting with teams and climbing up and down the draft rankings like children on a jungle gym.

headline: Older and Colder
text: I was oddly excited to read that a couple of scientists at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, Calif., had published a huge study of the relationship between age and body temperature. Here at last, I thought, might be the answer to one of life’s most enduring mysteries: Why do assisted living facilities and nursing homes always feel like Phoenix in August? Do old people really prefer, or need, such relentlessly toasty temperatures?

headline: A Weekend in Istanbul
text: The Turkish city is full of restaurants, cafes and galleries.

headline: A Killing in Brooklyn Is Caught on Video
text: The police have released a surveillance video of a fatal shooting Saturday night in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, in the hope of finding the killer.

headline: Test of Eye Drug Is Said to Show Success in Elderly
text: A far less expensive alternative proved roughly as effective as Genentech’s costly drug Lucentis in preserving or improving vision in elderly people with a common eye disease, according to two people familiar with the results of a closely watched clinical trial.

headline: Team Lotus Buys Caterham, Maker of the Seven
text: One of the most recognizable British sports-car manufacturers has been acquired by one of the most controversial Formula One outfits.

headline: Lopez and Fuller to Start Latin Music Talent Search
text: Now that Jennifer Lopez has been acquainted with the singers on “American Idol,” she’s going to search for singing talent throughout the Americas.

headline: WikiLeaks and the Cable Guys
text: The diplomat and strategist George F. Kennan was a marvelous connoisseur of his own bitterness, and some of the funniest passages in his “Memoirs: 1925-1950″ concern just how little interest the State Department had in his various cables and memorandums. On one sad occasion he was in Washington helping to sort backlogs and pulled out some of his own unread dispatches, confronting him with the choice of trashing them forever or saving them for the files. Kennan was a great writer and knew it; he kept them, unopened, for the files, marked “of interest.”

headline: The White House, the Democrats and the Deficit
text: During the health care debate, it was fair to argue that the Democratic Party was more serious than the Republican Party about the underlying policy questions. By this I don’t mean that the Democrats necessarily had the correct approach to our dysfunctional health care system, or that the final legislation deserved to pass. (I don’t think it did.) But the proposals that eventually became the Affordable Care Act/Obamacare at least took the the system’s pathologies seriously, drew on some of the smartest liberal health care wonkery, and tried to grapple with the scale of the problems they were confronting. The Republicans, on the other hand, never coalesced around a substantial alternative, declined to embrace the best proposals from conservative policy thinkers, and generally made a purely negative (and sometimes cynical) case against the Democratic bill, rather than setting out a convincing and rigorous alternative.

headline: Chris Young Pitches Again but Uncertainty Remains

Young was tagged for three monstrous home runs, two by Wilson Ramos and one by Jayson Werth, but he did not have a lot of base runners clogging the base paths. So the three home runs were all solo, and that enabled the Mets to stay in the game and eventually win, 6-4.

headline: Fresh From the Oven
text: Don’t expect to find baguettes and pastries at Grand Street Bakery. Come May, the space will be transformed into a shop for delicious goods of the vintage variety: heritage butcher stripe shirts will hang from the baking racks, a scattering of leather purses will reside on the wooden tables, and bangles and beaded necklaces will be displayed on bagel holders. The idea for the space was cooked up by Neal Mello, the former buyer for What Goes Around Comes Around and Urban Outfitters, who hounded the previous owner every day for two months before it finally became his. Mello artfully retrofitted the décor to its new use: the large metal ovens now double as changing rooms for cool garb like neon swimsuits, and the flour silos provide spacious storage. He’s also added furniture, art books and records to sell alongside his finely selected apparel collection. There are plans to have a lounge and espresso bar on the back patio and host art shows in the basement. But one thing remains the same: “I am going to keep the name The Grand Street Bakery here. It’s been here 25 years, and I told the landlady I was going to leave this sign.”

headline: Small Budget Airlines Zoom Between Small Cities

So when she saw that a carrier called Vision Airlines was advertising $49 one-way nonstop flights between the two places, she snapped up a ticket. By comparison, “filling up my gas tank now costs like $62,” said Ms. Pickens, a community association manager for a beachfront condo.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Queen for a Day
text: Would you like to be queen for a day? Too bad, the Samurai Shopper got here first, and today — and only today — I am your sovereign. Long may I rave. Instead of adding more palaver about how the two future queens of England — Camilla and Catherine — may or may not deserve their exalted stature, I’m reveling in mine. “Queen for a Day,” you may remember, was a stupefying TV show of the late 1950s and early 1960s bestowing refrigerators, wheelchairs and whatnots on needy women, most of whom hated being charity cases.

headline: Asked & Answered | Edwina Alexander
text: Equestrian fashion is nothing new — Hermès, after all, started out as a saddle maker for the czars of Russia, and Ralph Lauren has been catering to the horsy set for decades. Gucci’s signature snaffle added some equine elegance to the brand’s men’s moccasins when it first appeared in 1953. In the ’80s, Gucci in fact hopped in the saddle and created an annual jumping competition, the Gucci Trophy. Participants clad in Gucci red and green stripes and the house’s signature crest took to the ring in style. The technically correct riding gear was available in Gucci stores, affording non-blue-bloods the opportunity to look like blue ribbon winners.

headline: Is the Protest Song Dead?
text: Can pop music change the world? At their worst, protest songs can be “didactic, crass or plain boring” — as the British music critic Dorian Lynskey puts it in his new book “33 Revolutions Per Minute: A History of Protest Songs, From Billie Holiday to Green Day.” But when the stars align, a song can capture a moment in time and speak volumes about the world we live in. Think Billie Holiday singing “Strange Fruit”; the Plastic Ono Band and “Give Peace a Chance”; or Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young and “Ohio.” These are songs that send chills down your spine.

headline: Shane! Come Back! We Appreciate You!
text: If the Memphis Grizzlies defeat the San Antonio Spurs tonight in Game 5 of their first-round playoff series, it will be only the second time that a No. 8 seed has defeated a No. 1 seed in a best-of-seven-games N.B.A. series. That means a few things are likely. First, we’ll hear a lot about what a huge upset this is, given that the Spurs, who had the second-best record in the league this year, have won four championships in the last dozen years and the Grizzlies have never won a playoff game before this series began. Second, we’ll get lots of analysis about how the Spurs let things get away from them. And third, what attention is given to the Grizzlies and what they did right won’t include much about the contributions of their player Shane Battier.

headline: Deficit Complicates City Ballet Labor Talks

headline: Court Rules Against V.A. on Fiduciaries
text: A federal appeals court has told the Department of Veteran’s Affairs to loosen its grip on benefits decisions for veterans who have been declared incompetent.

headline: Camera Whimsy on iPhones
text: “The best camera,” the saying goes, “is the one you have with you.”

headline: Buried at the Beach
text: The Times's Corey Kilgannon takes a trip to a lonely highway in southern Long Island, where 10 bodies have been found around the area since December.

headline: 16 Tips to Take Your iPhone to the Next Level
text: The iPhone has been around for nearly four years. And in that time, millions of people have bought and used iPhones, swiping and tapping their way through life. Most of those people believe they know how the iPhone works.

headline: A Voice, Something for Flinging Around
text: Melba Moore is a one-woman sound machine. This singer, who made her name in the Broadway productions of “Hair” and “Purlie,” is now a 65-year-old theatrical jazz diva. At Tuesday’s opening-night performance of her show, “Forever Moore,” at the Café Carlyle, she turned songs into sonic exhibitions in which emotion was superseded by extreme vocal display.

headline: Two Arrested in Attack on Deliveryman Caught on Tape
text: Two teenagers were arrested Wednesday in an attack on a Chinese-food deliveryman in the hallway of a Harlem apartment building that was caught on videotape, the police said.

headline: A Perilous Double Comes Close to Backfiring
text: There were 28 teams competing in the Yeh Bros. Cup in China last week. There was an initial qualifying stage of 10 10-board matches, followed by the knockout phase. Italy (Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa) qualified in first place and won all of its knockout matches to take the top prize.

headline: PlayStation Security Breach a Test of Consumers’ Trust
text: When Sony designers made the PlayStation 3, they lavished attention on the hardware. And when their shiny new machine was finished, Sony executives basically said, “Hmm, we’d better figure out an online system for this thing.” So they tacked one on.

headline: A Wandering Talent Grows Roots in Country
text: The last song Darius Rucker played on Tuesday night had significance: “I’ve adopted it as my theme song,” he said. “They get on me and want to know/‘Why do you drink?’ ” he sang in an exaggerated twang. “To get drunk!” the audience shouted. “ ‘Why do you roll smoke?’ ” he rejoindered, and the audience replied, “To get high!”

headline: Jester Returns to Test a Guest Conductor
text: As Fabio Luisi, the principal guest conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, becomes increasingly essential to the company, he will surely pick up more assignments like the one he had on Tuesday night.

headline: Banter Is Cheery, but Songs Are Not
text: Kate Cooper and Damon Cox, who work together as An Horse, had their interplay locked down tight at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn on Tuesday night. This was admittedly a modest achievement — between them, there isn’t all that much to coordinate — but effective, even in its modesty. The band was celebrating the release of its second album, “Walls,” on the Mom + Pop label, and low-key charm was only true to the cause.

headline: ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Author Repudiates Journalist’s Memoir About Her
text: Harper Lee, the tight-lipped author of the Pulitzer-Prize winning novel “To Kill a Mockingbird,” issued a short statement through her sister’s law firm on Wednesday saying that she had nothing to do with a coming book written about her by a former Chicago Tribune reporter.

headline: Eating With Friends | Morrell & Company
text: Tarajia Morrell and Sebastian Sergeant live in a carriage house in Brooklyn’s Boerum Hill, the ideal setting for their groovier-than-thou dinner parties. The interior is the vision of Sergeant, 34, a set and furniture designer. In their living room, simple Milo Baughman sofas surround an ornate 18th-century mantel topped with one of Sergeant’s creations, a mercury mirror in a torched frame. When it comes to the food, Morrell — the 31-year-old daughter of Cathy and Peter Morrell of the Morrell & Company wine shop and restaurant — takes over. View interactive feature >>

headline: Shades of ‘Godot’ and Zombies, Not to Mention Balanchine
text: It’s impressive how motivated the performers of Armitage Gone! Dance always look. At every point in the three works choreographed by Karole Armitage for the company’s first program in its current Joyce season, which opened Tuesday, the stage is occupied in complex ways by people who know where, how and why they belong in their elaborate, intricate and sophisticated stage worlds. I only wish that, for even a moment, I could believe in either them or their worlds.

headline: Mideast Private Equity Pioneer Looks Beyond the Unrest
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Arif Naqvi isn’t spooked by turmoil.

headline: Allergies Can Be Natural, Too
text: WENONAH MADISON-SAUER, 36, co-owner of a farm and take-out restaurant on Martha’s Vineyard, tries to be eco-conscious about not just food but also cosmetics. For her firstborn son, Waylon, she used biodynamic calendula-based products anointed by NaTrue, an international third-party certifier of natural and organic skincare and cosmetics. But her second, Amos, now 2 1/2, is gooped up with Hydrolatum, a creamy petroleum-derived, non-organic cream that comes in a large plastic tub. Amos has food allergies, which have resulted in atopic dermatitis and eczema. Much of what he is allergic to (tree nuts, peanuts, seeds and coconut) is found — in oil form as emollients — in organic products.

headline: Exelon Nears Takeover of Constellation Energy
text: 8:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tales From a Hard-Hat Zone: The U.S.A.
text: The set designer Neil Patel has filled the Dance Theater Workshop stage with construction props for SITI Company’s current production. Charles L. Mee’s script is presented as a malleable mash-up of scenes, “like America,/permanently under construction.” And the play’s title, just for good measure, is “Under Construction.” There is a serious thematic point being made by the director Anne Bogart and her ensemble, over and over again, with no room for miscommunication.

headline: Girls in Action
text: A look at some of the women and girls in action movies.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for April 28
text: Red shoes work anywhere this spring; Alexander Olch and Michael Williams collaborate on hand-sewn rep ties; store openings, sales, pop-ups and more.

headline: Desolate Part of Long Island Seems to Fit Serial Killer’s Needs
text: Local and federal investigators are still searching for bodies along Ocean Parkway on the South Shore of Long Island, where the police say that as many as 10 bodies dumped in the sand and brush may be the work of a serial killer.

headline: Tapes Reveal a President Frustrated With the Opposition
text: At the White House, the president was lamenting the prospect that Congressional Republicans were digging in against an increase in the federal debt limit.

headline: Devoting Attention to a Child and a Phone, All at Once
text: I always feel a pang of pity for children who are out in public and looking lonely as their parents direct their full attention at a smartphone screen.

headline: The Fed’s Statement on Interest Rates
text: The following is the full text of the statement released Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

headline: J.&J. May Have More Acquisitions in Mind
text: Johnson & Johnson may have more on its overseas shopping list. The health giant’s $21.3 billion purchase of the Swiss-listed Synthes is its largest ever. A big deal seemed like a way for J.& J. to deploy its $28 billion of cash, largely trapped overseas. But as it turns out, it is paying mostly in stock.

headline: Scene City: Chanel Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
text: The menu included a roster of the city’s elite from the fashion, film and art worlds.

headline: Garden Stools
text: NO one has to tell Michael Devine about the virtues of garden stools.

headline: Shopping for Garden Stools With Michael Devine
text: The fabric designer and avid gardener shopped for clever stools that provide compact seating, indoors and out.

headline: Pakistan Urged Afghanistan to Distance Itself From the West, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With Afghan discussions under way about the future involvement of the United States in the country and the prospect of long-term military bases, the Pakistani government has urged Afghanistan to distance itself from the West and tie its future more tightly to that of China and Pakistan, according to Afghans and Americans who are knowledgeable about a meeting between the leaders of Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: Film Festival’s Elite Mixes It Up
text: ONLY in New York would scaffolding become party décor. That was the inventive solution, anyway, at the Chanel Tribeca Film Festival dinner at the Odeon, where the metal bars were draped with ivy and white roses to form a blossoming entranceway.

headline: Moby’s Castle in the Hollywood Hills
text: The musician spent $2 million restoring a 1920s house with views of Beachwood Canyon and the Hollywood Reservoir.

headline: As Buds Open, So Do Doors: Home and Garden Tours, 2011
text: The season of spring is also the season of house tours, when long-closed doors and garden gates unfurl like flowers for a quick and happy peek. Throughout the Northeast and beyond, there are mansions, studio apartments, bungalows and row houses to suit every taste, filled with antique china and contemporary paintings, stainless steel stoves and iron-grilled fireplaces, and parquet floors and historic wallpaper. The outdoor spaces include urban gardens hemmed in by brick walls, terraces with grand vistas and lush backyards with sturdy perennials. Show houses remain open for a few weeks, but some house and garden tours slip by in an afternoon – unless otherwise noted, all events are self-guided.

headline: A Castle for the King of Techno
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Cooking With Children
A Stackable Chair With an Artistic Bent
text: The term “stackable chairs” usually conjures up a certain elementary-school utility. L’Eau, a new chair from the Italian company Calligaris, aims to change that — in fact, to “elevate the standard stackable chair to become the artistic focus of a room,” said Mauro Mosca, the company’s design and brand director.

headline: Sales at Ligne Roset, John Robshaw and Others
text: Floor samples are on sale at the Ligne Roset store in SoHo through Sunday (the leather Harry armchair, originally $3,750, is $2,195; the Eaton 63-inch table, regularly $3,540, is $2,479); 155 Wooster Street (Houston Street), (212) 253-5629, ligne-roset-usa.com.

headline: Lisa Occhipinti, Author of ‘The Repurposed Library’
text: Lisa Occhipinti is a fine artist with a background in bookbinding whose medium is orphaned books, mostly the linen-bound novels printed in the early to mid-20th century that you can find by the box load at thrift stores and flea markets.

headline: New York Region, Long Island and New Jersey Home and Garden Tours
text: WESTCHESTER AND PUTNAM COUNTIES

headline: Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland and Washington Home and Garden Tours
text: PENNSYLVANIA

headline: New York City Home and Garden Tours
text: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance and intricate, original moldings, and an artist’s townhouse and studio with a backyard treehouse. The tour will be followed by a reception. Advance tickets, $150 for the tour and $300 for the tour and the reception, at (212) 475-9585, and gvshp.org/benefit. Advance tour-only tickets will also be offered at two for $250. Same-day tickets, if available, $175 for the tour and $350 for the tour and reception, will be sold starting at 12:30 p.m. at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street (between Bleecker and Bedford Streets).

headline: A Photo Exhibit That Honors Trees With a Past
text: “Landslide: Every Tree Tells a Story,” an outdoor photo exhibition, opens Saturday at LongHouse Reserve in East Hampton, N.Y., in homage to some of the country’s most venerable (and vulnerable) trees. Inspired by the Cultural Landscape Foundation’s 2010 Landslide, the most recent list of endangered landscapes released by the nonprofit preservation group, the show includes such heroic trees as the American elms of East Hampton (photographed by Garie Waltzer), which still form a leafy canopy over village streets despite disease and the ravages of time. Others include thousands planted by Frederick Law Olmsted Sr. and his sons in the 1890s, in Louisville, Ky. (photographed by Bob Hower, above), many of which have been lost to pollution, development and tornadoes.

headline: Southern, Central and Western United States Home and Garden Tours
text: SOUTH

headline: Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island Home and Garden Tours
text: CONNECTICUT

headline: LED Bulbs That Try to Please the Eye
text: For years, experts have predicted that LEDs, the technology used in digital clocks, would eclipse compact fluorescents as an energy-saving alternative to traditional incandescent bulbs. Now Switch Lighting, a venture capitalist-financed company in San Jose, Calif., says it has come up with an LED bulb that emits light eye-pleasing enough to make that happen.

headline: The Kips Bay Decorator Show House, Room by Room
text: Spaces by a dozen of the designers featured in the show house.

headline: A Manhattan Pop-Up for F. P. Victoria & Son
text: Frederick P. Victoria & Son, a 78-year-old company known for antiques, reproductions and custom pieces made for decorators like Billy Baldwin, hasn’t had a shop in Manhattan since 2009. It is now based in Long Island City, Queens, and most of its business is online.

headline: Kips Bay Decorated, and Curated
text: AAKASH NIHALANI is a 24-year-old Brooklyn-based street artist who uses electrical tape to sketch three-dimensional shapes on public surfaces like sidewalks or brick walls. His work is playful, even joyous, and suggests all sorts of possibilities. Imagine a bright yellow doorway on a pocked concrete wall, or an enormous pink cube careering along the pavement.

headline: The Man Who Made Working Out Cool
text: ON a recent Thursday night, the 38,000-square-foot David Barton Gym on Astor Place was throbbing to the Scorpions’ “Rock You Like a Hurricane.” Up the white-plaster staircase, candles flickered in the virgin springwood-paneled yoga room. Down below, a line of porcelain doll heads grinned over the moodily lighted lobby as lithe young things churned past the reception desk, designer gym bags in tow.

headline: A Japanese Plant Struggles to Produce a Critical Auto Part
text: HITACHINAKA, Japan — A modern car is a computer on wheels. The window openers, the dashboard navigation maps, the fuel injectors — these and many other operations are controlled by some of the 100 or so electronic systems in a typical car.

headline: Misurata Falls More Fully Under Rebel Control
text: While still cut off overland by pro-Qaddafi forces, the rebels were fighting stray Qaddafi holdouts at the city’s edge.

headline: Messi’s Goals Worthy of Praise
text: LONDON

headline: Tech Talk: Mobile Shopping
text: Mobile shopping hasn’t taken off in a big way, and retailers are still looking for ways to get consumers to shop from their phones or tablets. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a Times technology reporter, about the challenges retailers face in getting smartphone users to buy on the fly. Though consumers do want to use their mobile devices for shopping, Ms. Miller said, they don’t like entering their information on a tiny screen. Successful mobile shopping apps, she said, streamline the process.

headline: Yankees Keeping Faith With Soriano
text: In the words of his manager, Rafael Soriano has had a bad month. A 7.84 earned run average and two costly eighth-inning meltdowns — including one in the Yankees’ 3-2 loss Tuesday night against the White Sox — makes Joe Girardi’s appraisal irrefutable.

headline: May Release Schedule
text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Director Petraeus to Face Different Culture at C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. David H. Petraeus will be taking on familiar challenges when he arrives at the Central Intelligence Agency this summer: the terrorist threat from Yemen and Pakistan; the Taliban insurgency in Afghanistan; the Arab uprisings and their uncertain outcomes.

headline: For All Those Who Aren’t on the Royal Guest List
text: SINCE her invention in 1921, Betty Crocker has symbolized mainstream American kitchen values. So why then is a section of the Betty Crocker Web site devoted to celebrating the wedding of a member of the British royal family?

headline: Smoltz Is Set to Challenge a Lurking ‘Beast Within’
text: VALDOSTA, Ga. — He has practiced with Atlanta’s W.N.B.A. team, and this week John Smoltz, the retired pitcher, will make his first start in a PGA Tour co-sanctioned event.

headline: Huckabee’s Doings Raise More Questions of Intent
text: While Donald Trump was vacuuming up so much political oxygen this afternoon, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas was making some noise of his own, keeping alive speculation that he will enter the still ill-defined field of Republican presidential candidates.

headline: As Illness Hits, Mets Keep Gee as Backup Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The minor mystery surrounding the Mets’ decision to keep the right-hander Dillon Gee on the roster and move him into the bullpen was at least partly answered on Wednesday.

text: AUGUST

text: To the Editor:

headline: Beware ‘Mission Accomplished’ on Budget Debate
text: The consensus of political reporters — including yours truly — was that Republicans were taking a significant risk by voting for Paul Ryan’s budget proposal. Mr. Ryan’s plan contains some potentially unpopular elements, such as significant reforms and cutbacks to Medicare and Medicaid, and a reduction in tax rates for high-income earners. President Obama critiqued the proposal — although without mentioning Mr. Ryan’s name — in his address on the budget two weeks ago. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is already running commercials on the subject, claiming that Republicans have “voted to end Medicare”.

headline: Most States Seen Raising Jobless Tax on Businesses
text: As persistently high unemployment has drained the funds that are used to pay jobless benefits, more than two-thirds of the states expect to raise taxes on businesses this year to replenish them, according to a survey of labor agencies released Wednesday.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Case for Cursive
text: For centuries, cursive handwriting has been an art. To a growing number of young people, it is a mystery.

headline: Monitoring Painkillers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Galleon Jurors Review More Taped Phone Calls
text: For the second time since they began deliberations on Monday, the jurors in the trial of Raj Rajaratnam were able to listen to secretly recorded phone calls between Mr. Rajaratnam and his supposed associates.

headline: Besieged in Misurata
text: Migrant workers found passage out of Misurata, Libya, aboard a chartered ship as shelling and fighting continued.

headline: Department of Good News
text: Well, I just don’t see how things can get better than this when it comes to current affairs. Prince William is about to get married and President Obama has released his long-form birth certificate.

headline: Designer Stationery, Made by You
text: I have more than 22 gigabytes of photos stored on my computer. That translates to roughly 3,000 pictures gathering dust on my hard drive. Sure, the majority are throwaways, but there are a few gems in the bunch I would love to see outside my LCD.

headline: Some Kind of Month for Brent Lillibridge
text: I’ll admit it. I didn’t know much about Brent Lillibridge before he saved Tuesday’s game for the Chicago White Sox with two phenomenal catches at Yankee Stadium. All I really knew was that he was a utility man for the White Sox who had somehow hit the 10,000th home run in franchise history this month. Lillibridge has four home runs in parts of four seasons.

headline: Chrysler Expected to Erase Its Debt to Government
text: DETROIT — Of the three Detroit carmakers, Chrysler was in the worst condition when the recession hit. And even with a taxpayer bailout, it has been slower to recover than its rivals.

headline: The Best Punishment for Tressel? Let Him Stay
text: Here’s a suggestion to the power brokers at Ohio State University as they contemplate the fate of their Teflon football coach, Jim Tressel. Don’t fire him.

headline: Storms Rock the South and Midwest
text: Severe weather in parts of the South has killed several people and left thousands more without power from East Texas to Memphis and up through Illinois.

headline: At This Fete, The Room Was Packed With Power
text: In the song “Billionaire,” the pop singer Bruno Mars sings a line about making it big: “I want to be on the cover of Forbes magazine.” At the Time Warner Center on Tuesday night, onstage at the Time 100 spectacular, celebrating the year’s most influential people according to the magazine, Mr. Mars swapped in the host publication’s name fittingly. But with a wide-ranging list of influentials including Martha Stewart and Amy Chua, the “Tiger Mother,” it seemed that just about anyone could land in its pages.

headline: Mayor, Aiming at Police, Takes on a Pet Peeve
text: This week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg found himself in a suddenly familiar place: taking aim at the Police Department.

headline: Little-Known Sub Makes Highlight Plays
text: Brent Lillibridge was born near Seattle on Sept. 18, 1983, when the local major league baseball team was playing the White Sox in Chicago. Harold Baines started in right field that day, hitting a home run to help beat the Mariners.

headline: President Heads to New York to Try to Thaw Wall Street Donors
text: President Obama, seeking to mend fences with big New York donors to the Democratic Party, came to New York to headline three back-to-back fund-raisers on Wednesday night, casting his re-election campaign as the next step in the effort to speed up the economic recovery.

headline: Great Leap Backward
text: SHANGHAI

headline: Helping Students Find the Right Path
text: Maria Rodriguez, an associate professor of psychology at Hunter College, has been working with students in CUNY’s career-conscious SEEK program — the acronym stands for Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge — since joining the faculty in 1982. SEEK’s mission is to provide academically and economically disadvantaged students access to a college education and to help them find appropriate career opportunities. In addition to teaching, Dr. Rodriguez, a licensed psychologist, offers academic, career and personal counseling. She is 57 and lives in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Honoring Those Who Said No
text: IN January 2004, Spec. Joseph M. Darby, a 24-year-old Army reservist in Iraq, discovered a set of photographs showing other members of his company torturing prisoners at the Abu Ghraib prison. The discovery anguished him, and he struggled over how to respond. “I had the choice between what I knew was morally right, and my loyalty to other soldiers,” he recalled later. “I couldn’t have it both ways.”

headline: Panetta Comes Armed With Background in Budget Fights
text: WASHINGTON — Leon E. Panetta is set to take over leadership of the Defense Department while the United States is fighting on three fronts, but he was selected for the job in no small part because his war at home will be with Congress over the Pentagon budget. And in that battle, defense budget analysts said Wednesday, he comes unusually well armed.

headline: Judge Denies N.F.L. Petition as Injunction Stays, for Now
text: A federal judge late Wednesday night denied the N.F.L.’s request for a stay on the injunction that ended the lockout, sending the league scrambling to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals to try to keep the lockout in place.

headline: Besieged in Misurata
text: Migrant workers found passage out of Misurata, Libya, aboard a chartered ship as shelling and fighting continued.

headline: Pain at the Pump? We Need More
text: GASOLINE prices are above  $4 per gallon in much of the country, a reminder that our dependence on oil carries a great cost. President Obama has promised that the Justice Department will be vigilant in pursuing price-gouging at the pump, but what we really need is to address the full set of energy-related problems, with a focus on spurring clean energy innovation.

headline: City Council Questions Distribution of Park Officers
text: The City Council held a hearing on Wednesday to investigate what one council member said were disparities and inequalities in the deployment of officers in city parks.

headline: A Certificate of Embarrassment
text: With sardonic resignation, President Obama, an eminently rational man, stared directly into political irrationality on Wednesday and released his birth certificate to history. More than halfway through his term, the president felt obliged to prove that he was a legitimate occupant of the Oval Office. It was a profoundly low and debasing moment in American political life.

headline: Panic of Final Stretch Stills Voice of Triple Crown
text: Tom Durkin is no longer studying photos of Uncle Mo, Dialed In or any of the probable contenders to win next month’s Kentucky Derby. He is not packing his binoculars and notebook of more than 2,000 adjectives and phrases, the palette and paints of the track announcer’s craft, for his annual trip to Churchill Downs.

headline: Solar Panels Rise Pole by Pole, Followed by Gasps of ‘Eyesore’
text: ORADELL, N.J. — Nancy and Eric Olsen could not pinpoint exactly when it happened or how. All they knew was one moment they had a pastoral view of a soccer field and the woods from their 1920s colonial-style house; the next all they could see were three solar panels.

headline: City Shelves a Plan to Legalize Hailing Livery Cabs
text: An ambitious attempt by the Bloomberg administration to legalize hailing livery cabs on streets outside of Manhattan has been shelved after criticism from the taxi industry and lukewarm support from key lawmakers.

headline: Video of the Tornado in Alabama
text: Videos of the tornado that tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., on Wednesday afternoon began appearing online soon afterward. In the video above, posted on Vimeo by Crimson Tide Productions, the storm can be seen tearing through the trees near an office complex and parking lot as the clearly terrified videographer looks on.

headline: In Trying to Debunk a Theory, the News Media Extended Its Life
text: The facts about Barack Obama’s birth never wavered. But the more the fraudulent theories were debated and dispelled in major news media outlets, the more people seemed to believe them.

headline: Just Don’t Connect
text: The other day I got on the L train at Third Avenue, hair still wet from the gym, molars cemented together by the last bite of my post-workout protein bar. Grabbing a pole, I quickly scanned the occupied seats, knowing that if I parked myself in front of the nearest pair of Converse sneakers, I’d probably get a seat in Brooklyn at Bedford or Lorimer. Then I spotted her. The ex-girlfriend of an ex-boyfriend of mine.

headline: Students at Rutgers Occupy a Building
text: Demanding a tuition freeze, better wages for workers and a greater voice for students, about a dozen undergraduates at Rutgers University on Wednesday occupied Old Queens, the historic administration building in New Brunswick, N.J., where the president, Richard L. McCormick, has his office.

headline: A Syrian Beacon Pays Price for Its Dissent
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the besieged city of Dara’a, which has become a symbol of Syria’s uprising, residents on Wednesday told of shortages of bread and even baby formula. Some stick a pole wrapped in a scarf out the door to see whether snipers are lurking. Doctors in a mosque have resorted to using sewing needles to stitch wounds, amid shortages of bandages and disinfectant.

headline: The Limits of Fed Policy
text: For too long policy decisions by the Federal Reserve were cloaked in secrecy and Alan Greenspan, the longtime chairman, was notoriously Delphic. So it was good to see the current chairman, Ben Bernanke, meeting the press on Wednesday, in the first of what are to be quarterly question-and-answer sessions. It shows that the Fed has learned, albeit the hard way, that it must build understanding and support for its policies.

headline: A 9/11 Judge Sets a Month as Time Limit for a Trial
text: For almost nine years, the family of Mark Bavis, a passenger on the second plane to hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, has been waiting for a trial in a wrongful-death lawsuit it filed against United Airlines and other defendants.

headline: Advisers on Interrogation Face Legal Action by Critics
text: Critics are taking legal action to seek punishment for psychologists who, they say, designed and consulted on abusive interrogation techniques used on suspected terrorists.

headline: In a Mother’s Case, Reminders of Educational Inequalities
text: NORWALK, Conn. — The tale outlined outside court by the defendant’s supporters had a heartbreaking story line — a child tossed out of school, a homeless mother charged with felony theft for the crime of sending him to a better school than the one available to her, the inequalities that define America’s schools.

headline: With Deal, J.&J. Tries to Change Discussion
text: In announcing on Wednesday Johnson & Johnson’s biggest acquisition ever, on the eve of its annual shareholder meeting, the company’s chief executive tried to pivot from a year of manufacturing lapses, product recalls and a disappointing share price.

headline: Foundations Join to Offer Online Courses for Schools
text: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the world’s largest philanthropy, and the foundation associated with Pearson, the giant textbook and school technology company, announced a partnership on Wednesday to create online reading and math courses aligned with the new academic standards that some 40 states have adopted in recent months.

headline: Recidivism’s High Cost and a Way to Cut It
text: Corrections costs for the states have quadrupled in the last 20 years — to about $52 billion a year nationally — making prison spending their second-fastest growing budget item after Medicaid. To cut those costs, the states must first rethink parole and probation policies that drive hundreds of thousands of people back to prison every year, not for new crimes, but for technical violations that present no threat to public safety.

headline: Protests and Strikes Grow in Yemen as Deal on Ouster Advances
text: Protests and work strikes escalated across Yemen on Wednesday, leaving at least 12 dead on one of the country’s most violent days in a month, even as opposition and government officials were moving toward an agreement to usher President Ali Abdullah Saleh out of office in a month.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 27, 2011

headline: Ms. Dix Comes to Washington
text: Hundreds of thousands of Northerners were mobilizing for war in April 1861, but few with the speed and initiative of Dorothea Dix. When news of President Lincoln’s call for three-month volunteers reached her home in Trenton, the middle-aged reformer set out immediately for Washington. She arrived in Philadelphia just in time to catch the last train through Baltimore before the bridges north of the city were burned, cutting off Washington and temporarily suspending travel to the capital from points north. Undeterred by what must certainly have been a harrowing ride, Dix arrived in Washington on April 19th and headed straight for the White House.

headline: Hughes Could Have a Circulatory Condition
text: Two days of testing for Phil Hughes revealed a disconcerting clue that may explain his mysterious lack of arm strength. The Yankees will follow up by sending him for further evaluation in St. Louis, where a specialist will determine whether he has thoracic outlet syndrome, a circulatory condition common in athletes who use their upper extremities extensively.

headline: Limited in Free Agency, Knicks Retain Billups
text: The Knicks are keeping Chauncey Billups for another season, opting for stability over payroll flexibility, and the chance to play a full season with a three-star lineup.

headline: TimesCast | New Appointments Defense
text: David E. Sanger discusses how the career experiences of Leon E. Panetta and David H. Petraeus may impact their performances in new roles.

headline: In Tense Seesaw Series, Bruins End on Up Side
text: BOSTON — It was a scene only the hearty loyalists could have envisioned after the first two games of this Stanley Cup playoff series. In the same building in which they had been lustily booed 11 days earlier, the Boston Bruins left the ice Wednesday triumphant and to an ongoing chorus of cheers, defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 4-3, in overtime to win the back-and-forth series in seven games.

headline: Thursday: Tales of the Round Table
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — On Friday, a very special event will take place across the Pond, and today’s puzzle celebrates that fact. You might not have heard about it on any of the television stations, or in the various newspapers or magazines, or online, or anything, so I’ll just go ahead and spoil it for you: PRINCE WILLIAM of WALES and KATE MIDDLETON are getting hitched. You’ll need that tidbit of information to get through the puzzle.

headline: A.I.G. to Sue 2 Firms to Recover Some Losses
text: The American International Group, the giant insurer rescued by the federal government during the financial crisis, on Thursday will file the first of what could be a series of lawsuits against Wall Street firms, contending that it was the victim of fraud.

headline: ‘The Normal Heart’
text: Photos from the Broadway production of Larry Kramer’s play.

headline: Girl Group Tale Is Reharmonized
text: Mama said there’ll be shows like this. But she didn’t tell me there would be quite so many, or that any one of them could be this dismal.

headline: Raw Anguish of the Plague Years
text: More than a quarter of a century after it first scorched New York, “The Normal Heart” is breathing fire again. The passionately acted new Broadway production of Larry Kramer’s watershed drama from 1985 — an indictment of a world unwilling to confront the epidemic that would come to be known as AIDS — blasts you like an open, overstoked furnace. Your eyes are pretty much guaranteed to start stinging before the first act is over, and by the play’s end even people who think they have no patience for polemical theater may find their resistance has melted into tears. No, make that sobs.

headline: Tom Durkin's Famous Calls
text: Tom Durkin, who has called the Kentucky Derby 13 times, said he did not renew his contract with NBC because of the anxiety the race had caused. Watch some of his favorite calls.

headline: The Duty of Counsel
text: We strongly oppose the federal statute known as the Defense of Marriage Act, which bans recognizing same-sex marriage. House Republicans should not have used taxpayer money to hire outside lawyers to defend it. But the decision of those lawyers, the law firm of King & Spalding, to abandon their clients is deplorable.

headline: José Mourinho’s Persecution Complex
text: The best part of José Mourinho’s postgame diatribe on Wednesday was that he claimed he wouldn’t say how he really felt because he feared it would get him in trouble.

headline: In New Hampshire, Trump’s Rolling Media Circus
text: With the 2012 presidential campaign slow to evolve, Donald Trump’s arrival in New Hampshire was greeted with high anticipation.

headline: McCourt Criticizes Takeover of Dodgers
text: Frank McCourt, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ owner, said defiantly Wednesday that Commissioner Bud Selig’s decision last week to take control of his team amounted to an unfair, un-American seizure of his property. And he did not rule out challenging Selig in federal court.

headline: Organic Wine Country in Oregon
text: Willamette Valley wineries are on the leading edge of sustainable practices.

text: The Santa Catalina Island Company is looking to entice a new generation of visitors.

headline: Visiting Arizona’s Desert Foothills
text: The northern Sonoran Desert features a 2,800-acre lake and a nearly three-million-acre forest.

headline: Nora Roberts Romances Civil War Country
text: A 1790s-era hotel in Maryland was designed with women and romance in mind.

headline: Embattled Arab Leaders Decide It’s Better to Fight Than Quit
text: CAIRO — Arab leaders facing public revolt have increasingly concluded that it is better to shoot to kill, or at least to arrest and imprison, than to abdicate and flee.

headline: Energy or Eyesore?
text: To some New Jersey residents, the thousands of solar panels being installed on utility poles are an eyesore, to others they're evidence of the state's commitment to green energy.

headline: Bloggingheads: Obama Saved the Economy?
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether Obama saved capitalism.

headline: Reconciliation Deal by Rival Factions Forces U.S. to Reconsider Aid to Palestinians
text: WASHINGTON — The announced reconciliation on Wednesday between Fatah and Hamas, the estranged Palestinian movements, puts the Obama administration in the uncomfortable position of having to reconsider its financial support for the Palestinian Authority, including millions of dollars the United States has spent to train and equip Palestinian security forces, officials and members of Congress said.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee’s Lawyer Seeks a Voice on WikiLeaks Documents
text: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for a Pakistani prisoner at Guantánamo Bay went to court on Wednesday for permission to read and discuss publicly classified government documents about his client that were obtained by WikiLeaks and published by The New York Times and other publications this week.

headline: Push in U.N. for Criticism of Syria Is Rejected
text: UNITED NATIONS — An attempt by the United States and its European allies to condemn Syria in the United Nations Security Council was rebuffed on Wednesday, as the willingness to intervene in the region — strong enough to lead to military action against Libya under similar circumstances just weeks ago — appeared to evaporate.

headline: Hubert Schlafly, Who Helped Build Teleprompter, Is Dead at 91
text: Television actors, newscasters and politicians who worry far less these days about fumbling their lines, stalling as cue cards are flipped or shuffling typewritten pages on the podium owe much to Hubert J. Schlafly Jr.

headline: Sidney Michaels, Playwright, Is Dead at 83
text: Sidney Michaels, a playwright who was nominated for Tony Awards in three consecutive seasons in the 1960s, died Friday in Westport, Conn. He was 83.

headline: Court to Decide Validity of Olympic Doping Rule
text: The sporting world’s highest court will decide the validity of a relatively new International Olympic Committee rule regarding the Olympic eligibility of athletes who serve doping bans leading up to the Games.

headline: CNBC’s Burnett Is Said Ready to Jump to CNN
text: The CNBC anchor Erin Burnett is poised to sign a long-term contract with CNN, according to three people with knowledge of her plans.

headline: Mets Lose an Argument but Win Their Sixth Straight
text: WASHINGTON — Jose Reyes is known for his passion for baseball and the flair with which he plays the game. Almost every day of his nine-year career, he has demonstrated those characteristics with a smile. But on Wednesday night, his generally happy demeanor exploded into a rage previously unseen from him.

headline: The Voice of Excitement
text: The Times’s Joe Drape offers commentary on some memorable calls from Tom Durkin, who quit as the voice of the Kentucky Derby, and Larry Collmus, who will replace him.
