text: NATIONAL

headline: Orlando Bosch, Cuban Exile, Dies at 84
text: Orlando Bosch, a Cuban-American pediatrician and militant Cuban exile leader who was accused, and then acquitted, of masterminding the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner in which 73 people were killed, died Wednesday in Miami. He was 84.

headline: Shortcuts for Quicker iPhone Use
text: The Times' personal technology editor discusses a few ways to use your iPhone more efficiently.

headline: Video of 4 French Hostages Is Released
text: PARIS — Al Qaeda’s North African affiliate has released a video containing recorded messages from four French workers who were kidnapped last year in Niger.

headline: The Fusion Kings of Little Italy
text: At Torrisi Italian Specialties, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi add some new accents to Italian classics.

headline: Steamed, Roasted, Stir-Fried, Grilled
text: It takes effort to maintain a sense of seasonality with asparagus, given that it has become a year-round product. But right now even the stuff in supermarkets may come from a local source — so that the stalks snap rather than bend when you apply pressure and the aroma and flavor are fresh rather than simply strong.

headline: Fried Rice With Prosciutto
text: From the chefs of Torrisi Italian Specialties.

headline: Devil’s Chicken (Chicken fra Diavolo)
text: From the chefs of Torrisi Italian Specialties.

headline: Cooking Up a Big Idea in Little Italy
text: On a recent morning in a Greenwich Village studio apartment with little natural light and minimal décor beyond a cactus and a bookcase crammed with volumes about food, the chefs Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone plotted the future of their lavishly acclaimed restaurant — and, just maybe, of Italian food in America.

headline: Report Faults Border Screeners
text: Immigration authorities are failing to screen unaccompanied Mexican children who cross the border illegally to determine if they are victims of domestic abuse or human trafficking, according to a report based on two years of research by Appleseed, a nonprofit justice organization. The report examined how Mexican children have been handled by the Customs and Border Protection agency after Congress passed a law in 2008 requiring that minors be questioned to determine if they agreed to be returned to Mexico voluntarily. “On the whole, that law is not being followed,” said David Nachman, a lawyer who helped conduct the research. More than 30,000 Mexican children traveling alone have been apprehended at the border in the last two years, according to the report.

headline: Misuse of Official Parking Placards Is Widespread, Report Finds
text: In neighborhoods frequented by official vehicles, more than 40 percent of cars displaying official city-issued parking placards were parked illegally, according to a report issued Wednesday by the clean-transportation advocacy group Transportation Alternatives. And a quarter of cars displaying what appeared to be official placards used forged or otherwise invalid credentials, the group said.

headline: Nevada: Heller to Replace Ensign
text: Gov. Brian Sandoval appointed Representative Dean Heller to the Senate seat that John Ensign plans to leave next week. The appointment was widely expected from the governor, a Republican who endorsed Mr. Heller after he announced last month that he planned to run for the Senate in 2012. The appointment will prompt a special election in the state’s Second Congressional District. It remains unclear how such an election will proceed, and several county registrars are worried about its cost.

headline: Arizona: Psychologist to Evaluate Medical Records of Massacre Suspect
text: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered that Jared L. Loughner’s medical records be sent to a psychologist who is evaluating his competency to stand trial in the Tucson shooting spree in which Representative Gabrielle Giffords was injured. Mr. Loughner’s lawyers had opposed turning over the records, which date to his childhood, but the judge, Larry Burns, said they would assist the psychologist, Dr. Christina Pietz, in her evaluation of Mr. Loughner. The judge said the records should also be turned over to Dr. Matthew Carroll, a court-ordered psychiatrist. Mr. Loughner, 22, faces 49 federal charges and is due back in court on May. 25.

headline: Word of the Day | deterrent
text: deterrent •\di-ˈtər- ənt, de\• noun/adjective

headline: Harper Lee Denies Link to Memoir
text: Harper Lee, the tight-lipped author of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” issued a statement through her sister’s law firm on Wednesday saying that she had nothing to do with a forthcoming book written about her by a former Chicago Tribune reporter. On Tuesday, Penguin Press announced that it had acquired the book, “The Mockingbird Next Door: Life With Harper Lee,” a memoir by Marja Mills that it said was “written with direct access to Harper,” her sister Alice Lee “and their friends and family.” Alice Lee’s law firm Barnett, Bugg, Lee & Carter in Monroeville, Ala., issued a statement signed by Harper Lee saying: “Contrary to recent news reports, I have not willingly participated in any book written or to be written by Marja Mills. Neither have I authorized such a book.” Late Wednesday, Miriam Altshuler, Ms. Mills’s literary agent, said that Ms. Mills “has the written support of Alice Lee and a lifelong family friend, and prior to Harper Lee’s stroke in 2007, she had the verbal support of Harper Lee.”

headline: Obama’s Pentagon and C.I.A. Picks Show Shift in How U.S. Fights
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to send an intelligence chief to the Pentagon and a four-star general to the Central Intelligence Agency is the latest evidence of a significant shift over the past decade in how the United States fights its battles — the blurring of lines between soldiers and spies in secret American missions abroad.

headline: South Assesses the Toll After a Deadly Barrage of Tornadoes
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — A day after enduring a terrifying bombardment of storms that killed hundreds across the South and spawned tornadoes that razed neighborhoods and even entire towns, people from Texas to Virginia to Georgia searched through rubble for survivors on Thursday and tried to reclaim their own lives.

headline: TimesCast | Hamas and Fatah Agreement
text: April 27, 2011 - Ethan Bronner reports on the Hamas and Fatah agreement to a temporary unity government and elections.

headline: Japanese Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
text: HONG KONG — The Bank of Japan slashed its economic growth forecast Thursday in the aftermath of the natural disasters that hit the country last month but refrained from announcing fresh steps to stimulate the economy — a sign that the central bank expects rebuilding activity to lead to solid growth again later this year.

text: When we asked Christoph Bangert to write a journal-style account of his trip through Japan in late March and early April, he hesitated at first, thinking that his life was not the story. However, because he is so frequently asked for details about his travels, he gave it a try.

headline: Deutsche Bank Posts Strong Profit, While Santander Slips
text: Deutsche Bank on Thursday reported  first-quarter profit of 2.1 billion euros, up 17 percent from the period a year earlier, on solid investment banking performance. Its shares rose 1.68 euros, or 4 percent, to 43.48 euros in midmorning trading in Frankfurt.

headline: Roadside Bomb in Karachi Hits Navy Bus
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least five people were killed early on Thursday when a roadside bomb hit a bus carrying employees of the Pakistani Navy in the southern port city of Karachi, a senior naval officer said.

headline: Digital Diary: Will Netflix Curb Movie Piracy?
text: For the past few weeks, I’ve been on a retro television bender. I’ve watched the first seasons of “Ally McBeal,” “The X-Files,” “Veronica Mars” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Torrential downpours have kept me couch-bound, so I’ve also been able to catch up on a few movies I missed in the theaters: “The Runaways,” “Hot Tub Time Machine” and a few classics like “The Graduate.”

headline: Should Your Doctor Be on Facebook?
text: When I was a third-year medical resident, an attending physician handed me his business card so that I could contact him about a patient. Printed below his phone number was something I hadn’t seen on a business card before: an e-mail address.

headline: American Plays, in English, at Berlin Theater
text: With as many as 300 theater and dance groups, and state spending of millions of euros a year on the city’s three main opera houses and seven major theaters alone, there’s no shortage of stages in Berlin. But if you’re itching for some English-language thespian action, there’s one place to go: English Theatre Berlin, which has been operating under various names since 1990.

headline: Tom Brady’s Tears, and Today’s Draft
text: Even with labor trouble in the N.F.L., it’s hard to ruin the draft. But the draft’s ultimate importance usually needs to be put into perspective.

headline: A Lifetime of Automobilia Finds a New Home
text: NAPLES, Fla. — Mark Patrick has his hands full. As the librarian and archivist at the Collier Collection here, on the Gulf Coast in southwest Florida, he and his small staff face the daunting task of sorting through the 7,000 automotive books and 300,000 photographs and files that the Collier recently bought from Karl Ludvigsen, the prolific author, journalist and former auto executive.

headline: Daniel Murphy Says Mets Shooting for 100 Wins
text: WASHINGTON – After an eventful game that extended the Mets’ winnings streak to six consecutive victories, one of the central figures of the game expressed a sentiment about the team’s expectations that had not been heard publicly before.

headline: Carter Criticizes U.S. for Withholding North Korea Aid
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Former President Jimmy Carter, after a 48-hour visit to North Korea, sharply criticized the United States and South Korea on Thursday for their refusal to send humanitarian assistance to the impoverished North, saying their deliberate withholding of food aid amounted to “a human rights violation.”

headline: The Runneth Overing of Cups
text: If you’re a connoisseur of “oops!” stories (wardrobe malfunctions, newscaster bloopers, presidential pratfalls and the like), you probably already saw the mishap involving the Copa del Rey (The King’s Cup) trophy last week. A player from Real Madrid, which had just won Spain’s century-old national soccer tournament for the first time in nearly two decades, dropped the trophy from the top of the team’s bus, which was on a sort of post-match celebratory tour. The bus crushed it under its wheels.

headline: Helping Small Businesses That Really Know About Ups and Downs
text: This month, a group of Rwandan female entrepreneurs traveled to the United States to learn from their American counterparts. The women, survivors of the 1994 genocide, were graduates of a three-year program created by the Business Council for Peace, a nonprofit network of professionals who provide pro bono business services to entrepreneurs in countries with conflicts  — Rwanda and Afghanistan, so far, and El Salvador soon. The organization, known as BPeace, was built on the beliefs that more jobs mean less violence and that entrepreneurs are best positioned to create employment opportunities.

headline: Profit Jumps at Exxon and Shell
text: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported huge increases in their first-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by higher oil prices and earnings from refining.

text: Exelon announced on Thursday that it would buy Constellation Energy in a $7.9 billion deal, the latest in a wave of consolidation among energy companies, particularly utilities.

headline: Germany’s Low Unemployment Rate Stokes Inflation Fears
text: FRANKFURT — German unemployment fell to its lowest level in two decades in April, according to data released on Thursday. The figures provide some of the strongest evidence yet of the comeback of Europe’s largest economy.

headline: Panasonic to Cut 17,000 Jobs
text: Panasonic, the biggest Japanese maker of consumer electronics, announced a major reorganization Thursday under which it will cut thousands of jobs as it adapts its business to a changing global environment and absorbs recent acquisitions.

text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. Today’s post concludes his series counting down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

text: It’s a concept that takes Warhol one bold step further: Receive $100,000 in prize money, and instead of spending it, tack 100,000 used $1 bills to the walls of a museum.

headline: Bringing Petraeus to C.I.A. Offers Benefits for Obama
text: In a tribute to the Army’s top general in Afghanistan, the outgoing Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates wrote last week in Time magazine that “in many respects the Petraeus story is still being written.”

headline: Britain Bars Syrian Envoy From Royal Wedding
text: LONDON — Just 24 hours before the event, Britain said Thursday that it had revoked the Syrian ambassador’s invitation to the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, turning the ceremony into an unlikely focus of protest against violent repression in the Arab world.

headline: U.S. Economic Growth Slows to 1.8% Rate in Quarter
text: American economic expansion slowed to a crawl in the first quarter, but economists are hopeful that the setback will be temporary. Total output grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent from January through March, the Commerce Department said Thursday, after expanding at a 3.1 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 2010.

headline: Berkshire Fires Back Against Sokol’s Lawyer
text: Berkshire Hathaway has escalated its war of words with its former executive, David L. Sokol, who resigned last month after buying shares in a specialty chemicals manufacturer while orchestrating a potential takeover of the company.

headline: Creating a God, With Links to Olivier
text: LOS ANGELES -- As he finished postproduction work on “Thor” here at Building 29 on the 20th Century Fox lot, Kenneth Branagh could often be found laboring in any of its massive chambers, from the pitch-black subterranean color-timing suite to the Howard Hawks audio-mixing theater, as cavernous and majestic as Valhalla. But when he needed a personal work space, Mr. Branagh retreated to a closetlike office he described as his “little hole of cubbyness,” whose only clue to its occupant was a temporary sign on the door bearing the initials “K. B.”

headline: David Sokol, the Deal Maker
text: David L. Sokol had been portrayed in recent years as Berkshire Hathaway’s Mr. Fix-it. But Mr. Sokol had also become a crucial player in Warren E. Buffett‘s deal-making machine, serving as a point man for Berkshire on a number of possible transactions, particularly during the financial crisis.

headline: Stanford Debates R.O.T.C.’s Return
text: April 29, 10:18 a.m. | Vote Results After two hours of debate, the Stanford faculty senate voted to bring ROTC back on campus: 28 members voted for its return, 9 voted against it and 3 abstained. During the faculty senate meeting, Former Secretary of Defense William Perry discussed how bringing ROTC back to Stanford could help the military by providing better trained and educated leaders. Much of the debate was centered on the military’s posture toward transgendered people and also on whether academic credit would be granted to ROTC courses. An amendment to the resolution of bringing ROTC back to campus was added that stated the faculty senate’s objection concerning the military’s treatment towards transgender people.

headline: Wall Street Higher After G.D.P. Report
text: Shares rose, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to the highest level since June 2008, as better-than-estimated corporate earnings tempered investors’ concern over slowing economic growth.

headline: Seeing Things | Weaving New Mexico
text: When I visited Santa Fe, N.M., the week before Easter, I saw lots of pilgrims walking the High Road to Taos on their way to El Santuario de Chimayó, a 200-year-old chapel on a site that is sacred to many for the purported healing powers of its soil. But I was on a different kind of pilgrimage. New Mexico is a mecca for anyone interested in weaving, and many studios are clustered near Chimayó, a small village north of Santa Fe.

headline: BRYuKI
text: Dmitry Medvedev’s alternative to the BRICS countries – in Russian, Bryuki means trousers. [The Yu denotes Yuzhnaya Africa (South Africa), and the K stands for Kitai (China).]

headline: For Now, N.F.L. Players Can Return to Work
text: As they walked out of the klieg lights and off the stage Thursday night, the N.F.L.’s newest players left the celebration of the college draft behind and were plunged into football’s surreal off-season.

headline: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Projected to Grow Slowly
text: Even if the United States takes no explicit action to regulate greenhouse gases, emissions of carbon dioxide and other climate-altering substances will grow slowly over the next two decades, not returning to 2005 levels until 2027, according to a new projection from the Energy Information Administration, the research branch of the Energy Department.

headline: Poetry Pairing | April 28, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Busy Day
text: Little if any posting.

headline: Bomb Strikes Moroccan Cafe, Killing Mostly Foreigners
text: A powerful bomb blast in a crowded Moroccan cafe killed at least 14 people, wounded dozens of others and shattered the relative calm in a corner of the Arab world overwhelmed by uprisings and deadly government crackdowns.

headline: Rough Homecoming for a Washington Lawmaker
text: Audience members yelled at one another to stop yelling. The moderator talked over Representative Michael G. Grimm to ask the crowd to please stop talking over him.

headline: Thursday Reading: Should Your Doctor Be on Facebook?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: For Xanadu Mall, Stalled and Scorned, Deal May Offer New Life
text: It has been called “the ugliest damn building in New Jersey and maybe America,” has bedeviled three governors and has burned through two developers. Despite $1.9 billion spent, it is still an unfinished pile of concrete, steel and garish pastel panels.

headline: New Charlie Ahearn Film Will Make Its Debut at BAMcinemaFest
text: A New York artist well known for capturing street culture and people in cool clothing — as seen through the lens of a documentarian who knows a thing or two about those topics — will be the subject of “Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer,” a new feature from the “Wild Style” director Charlie Ahearn that will have its premiere at this year’s BAMcinemaFest, the festival’s organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Ahearn’s new film chronicles Mr. Shabazz, the Brooklyn photographer whose work is collected in the book “Back in the Days,” with help from Fred Brathwaite, aka Fab 5 Freddy, and KRS-One, both rappers who have figured prominently in Mr. Ahearn’s previous work.

headline: Bahrain Sentences 4 Protesters to Death
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A military court in Bahrain sentenced four Shiite Muslim protesters to death on Thursday in the killing of two policemen last month during demonstrations against the Sunni Muslim-ruled government, Bahrain’s national news agency reported.

headline: Harry Jackson, Artist Who Captured the West, Dies at 87
text: Harry Jackson, a Marine combat artist who turned his back on a promising career as an Abstract Expressionist painter to become a prominent realist artist known for his paintings and bronze sculptures of cowboys and Indians, died on Monday in Sheridan, Wyo. He was 87 and lived in Cody, Wyo., and Camaiore, Italy.

headline: Cellphones and Cancer
text: We need to quit worrying about cellphones (“Do Cellphones Cause Cancer?” by Siddhartha Mukherjee) and focus our collective energy on the known, significant causes of cancer: tobacco, sun exposure, hepatitis, etc., while continuing to research other possible causes. We should also focus on the one proven danger of cellphones, which is use (even hands-free) while driving.

headline: 9/11 Movie Pushes 8th-Grade Director Into Spotlight
text: It was February 2002, and 5-year-old Brook Peters and his mother, Michelle, were walking through Public School 150 in TriBeCa for the first time since Sept. 11, a few days before the school was set to reopen.

headline: Sweet and Vicious
text: Like everyone else on earth, I have a 100 percent chance of dying. The only unknowns are when and how it will happen. I don’t smoke because I’m not interested in dying of a heart attack at 50 or of emphysema at 60. This increases my chance of dying from something else. Gary Taubes makes a strong case that sugar causes some kinds of death (“Is Sugar Toxic?”), but he doesn’t tell me what I get to die of if I give it up. Will my new risk of death be better or worse? If going without sugar means that I get to die of complications from Alzheimer’s at 95, in a nursing home, unable to eat, use the bathroom or recognize anyone around me, then please, let me eat cake.

headline: Playoffs Make James More Careful With the Ball
text: The Miami Heat wrapped up its first-round series with the Philadelphia 76ers on Wednesday night, in yet another relatively pedestrian case of a superior team taking care of business in a timely manner. The Sixers were competitive for their five-game stint in the postseason, but their playoff run was expectedly short; few gave Philadelphia more than five games to live against Miami, making the 4-1 outcome a development straight from the script.

headline: America’s Got Talons
text: The nails really came out at the fall shows, with cutting-edge manicures being the order of the day. At Mugler, Lady Gaga sported a matte black, clawlike Minx design. Cushnie et Ochs introduced us to textured “caviar nails” made out of black seed beads. And rain-forest-inspired and gold-tipped nails emerged on Jen Kao’s catwalk. For a toned-down, off-the-runway take on the trends, show a bit of bare nail this summer and choose a classic red lacquer to highlight a nude half moon. Or, if Jason Wu’s gold-and-burgundy take on the classic French manicure is not exactly your speed, try a black and white reverse French with Japanese calligraphy on a nail or two.

Even on the track, scheduling variances preclude them from training regularly as a foursome. Still, this infrequent collective has produced something sublime.

headline: 36 Hours in Singapore

In the last few years, casinos and hotels have sprung up; museums and galleries in former colonial landmarks have flung open their doors; and international designers have staked out prime real estate alongside up-and-comers just starting to make their fashion mark. Throughout the city, street vendors and sleek restaurants — new and well-established — serve up the city’s renowned mix of Malay, Chinese and Indian ethnic cuisines. And, best of all, sexy lounges and rooftop bars are helping the city-state shake off its formerly staid image.

headline: Video Exclusive | Werner Herzog Interview
text: When Werner Herzog was a boy, he saved his pocket money to buy a book about cave drawings. When he finally held it in his hands, he had an almost spiritual experience viewing the pictures inside. Over half a century later, the always enthusiastic German director, 68, captures his enduring fascination with cave art in a new film, “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” coming out in theaters tomorrow. The French government and scientific community gave him unprecedented access to the contents of the fragile 32,000-year-old Cave of Chauvet-Pont-d’Arc in southern France, which he shot stunningly in 3-D. In this five-minute video, above, Herzog goes in depth about the ecstatic truth behind man’s first attempts to produce art. Related: Herzog Finds His Inner Cave Man, a film review by Manohla Dargis.

headline: Boston’s Huntington Theater Receives $10 Million Gift
text: A decades-long relationship between Boston’s Huntington Theater Company and Stanford and Norma Jean Calderwood has yielded a $10 million gift to the endowment of the theater, its leaders announced on Thursday. The gift from the Calderwood Charitable Foundation, by far the largest in the theater’s 29-year history, doubles the size of the Huntington’s endowment.

headline: In Praise of Monarchy
text: I appreciate the small-r republican ardor with which Mark Oppenheimer assails America’s royal wedding obsessives, but he’s fighting a losing battle. “Americans are supposed to loathe and reject monarchs,” he writes, but it’s telling that all his examples of that loathing (“In the earliest years of English settlement, this land was a proud haven for king killers … [we] fought a bloody war for the privilege to ignore the king of England … Anti-monarchism was then written into our Constitution …”) are centuries old, dating from a time when republicanism was an exciting cause rather than a somewhat-ossified assumption. Since those days, we’ve regressed to the (very human) mean: We’re fascinated by the royal family that we once overthrew, we have our own hereditary dynasties (and the slobbering coverage to match), and we’ve gradually turned our presidency into a quasi-imperial office, complete with coronations and cultic devotions and all the rest. True, by the standards of modern history, with its parade of strongmen and caudillos and presidents-for-life, our republican institutions have been impressively resilient. But even the American experience suggests that the anti-monarchical temper Oppenheimer invokes is ultimately artificial and unnatural, a triumph of theory over instinct and idealism over human nature. In their hearts, most people want a king and queen.

headline: Art for Sale, No Introduction Needed
text: FOR decades now auction houses have sold challenging works of art. There have been arcane, ancient sculptures, canvases by little-known artists and bizarre objects like glass cabinets filled with medical supplies or cigarette butts. But at Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips de Pury, the art for sale at the big auctions this season, beginning Tuesday, requires little thought. Even those without much knowledge of art history will recognize Andy Warhol’s haunting self-portrait with his spiky fright wig or Jeff Koons’s lovable sculpture of a Pink Panther being hugged by a buxom blonde or the classic pink-and-red abstract canvas that shrieks Mark Rothko.

His character, a professional tough guy bluntly named Hobbs, has just found his fugitive bad twin, Dom, the gnomic guru of the “Fast and Furious” franchise, played by Vin Diesel. They are the fast and, yes, the furious. Yet as these giants grasp each other’s bulging muscles, their bald heads rearing in the frame with tumescent vigor, it’s easy to imagine that they’d like some alone time.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: Wrapping Up the Apple Location Brouhaha
text: Well, for better or worse, Locationgate is over. On Wednesday, Apple responded with a statement explaining the presence of a file in the hard-drive backup of every iPhone and cellular iPad. “Apple is not tracking the location of your iPhone,” it said. “Apple has never done so and has no plans to ever do so.” So basically, Apple is saying that the researchers were wrong on both counts. First, the “secret file” contains information about nearby Wi-Fi hot spots and cell towers, not your exact location. And second, your device is sending information to Apple, although in an anonymous, encrypted form. One part of Apple’s response is a little unconvincing, says David Pogue. Read the rest of post at Pogue’s Posts.

headline: In ‘Little Britain,’ Awaiting Big Royal Wedding
text: It was late Thursday morning, with a full day to go before the Royal Wedding, and at least one business owner on a certain block in the West Village appeared to be tipping toward madness.

headline: Topped With Wrong
text: A delivery guy dropped off two pizzas at my daughter’s house. Her husband signed the preprinted charge slip, tipped him and ate slices from both pies. When his wife came home, he thanked her for ordering them, but she hadn’t! Soon, the delivery guy returned for the misdelivered pizzas. They told him they had eaten part of each, so he asked them to pay. My daughter refused, pointing out that it was his error. He asked for the pizzas back, and she refused again, claiming he would deliver the half-eaten pizzas to someone else. When he told them he was going to have to pay for the pies from his $8 an hour wage, they asked him to leave. Was this right?

headline: A Score To Praise A Prophet
text: Last week the prophet Elijah made a personal appearance at every Passover Seder around the world, or so we are told: most people are unable actually to see him, although parents have traditionally found ways to convince their children that Elijah sipped from the wine cup left for him. Taking all that on faith, you have to think that Elijah is one knackered prophet just now, so it seemed fitting that on Wednesday evening — barely 24 hours after the conclusion of Passover — the Oratorio Society of New York offered “Elijah,” Mendelssohn’s tribute to that itinerant biblical firebrand, at Carnegie Hall.

headline: ‘ART/SEWN’: ‘Tradition, Innovation, Expression’
text: Five Myles

headline: ‘IN A PERFECT WORLD’
text: Meulensteen

headline: MARIO GARCIA TORRES: ‘Cover Letter’
text: 45 Orchard Street (between Hester and Grand Streets), Lower East Side

headline: JULIA JACQUETTE: ‘Water, Liquor, Hair’
text: Anna Kustera

headline: THE SPRING SHOW
text: Art and Antique Dealers League of America

headline: Developers Create Neighborhood Feel With Condos and Shops
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Keeping Score: The Most Important Leadoff Skill? Not So Fast
text: Generally regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter ever, Rickey Henderson thrilled baseball fans for a quarter century by stealing a major league-record 1,406 bases. Along the way, his feats on the base paths fueled the stereotype that speed is the leadoff man’s defining tool. But it wasn’t his base stealing that made him so effective in the leadoff spot; rather, it was his ability to get on base to begin with.

headline: London Underground | Urban Narratives
text: It may not be the catchiest title around, but “Whiteonwhite:algorithmicnoir” is an incredible film and accompanying exhibition by the artist Eve Sussman and Rufus Corporation, her loose collective of collaborators, at the Haunch of Venison gallery until May 14. Since London is currently immersed in nostalgia — from the celebrations of the 1951 Festival of Britain at the Southbank Center to an abundance of Union Jack bunting across the city — this glimpse into the future is most welcome.

headline: Chrysler Says Government Loans Are Now Unnecessary
text: DETROIT — Chrysler will soon pay back its government loans because they have become “redundant and unnecessary” now that the automaker is more financially stable, its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said Thursday.

headline: PC Sales Off, Games Buoy Microsoft
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft, once the dominant technology company, saw revenue from its core operating system software slip in the first three months of the year as consumers begin to shift to buying tablet computers that do not run on Microsoft software.

headline: Media Decoder: The Royal Wedding
text: In the lead up to the royal wedding, news organizations found almost every angle to cover the story.

headline: Donation for a Lucerne Opera House Is in Dispute
text: On the surface the interlocking worlds of music festivals and arts philanthropy might seem as placid as the preternaturally transparent, swan-rich waters of Lake Lucerne in Switzerland. But officials of the renowned Lucerne Festival there took action on Thursday akin to a Loch Ness monster’s rearing its head and clamoring for recognition.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for April 29-May 5
text: ‘SNOW WHITE’

headline: Herzog Finds His Inner Cave Man
text: What a gift Werner Herzog offers with “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” an inside look at the astonishing Cave of Chauvet-Pont-d’Arc — and in 3-D too. In southern France, about 400 miles from Paris, the limestone cave contains a wealth of early paintings, perhaps from as long ago as 32,000 years. Here, amid gleaming stalactites and stalagmites and a carpet of animal bones, beautiful images of horses gallop on walls alongside bison and a ghostly menagerie of cave lions, cave bears and woolly mammoths. Multiple red palm prints of an early artist adorn one wall, as if to announce the birth of the first auteur.

headline: Big Appetite for the Royals’ Big Day
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss how in the days before the royal wedding, news organizations have found almost every angle to cover the story.

headline: Spare Times for April 29-May 5
text: Around Town

headline: In Aftermath of Storms, Production Stops at Mercedes-Benz and Toyota Plants
text: The series of deadly thunderstorms and tornadoes that struck the Deep South on Wednesday evening has led at least two automakers in the region to cancel production shifts at their plants.

headline: No Tweeting From the Ice Bath
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — I tell my body to do a lot of things: Run one more sprint. Strike 50 balls. Push through just 15 more minutes. Warm up. Cool down. Sit in an excruciating ice bath. But sometimes it’s not about what I tell my body, but what my body tells me. Sometimes it’s not about doing, but instead listening.

headline: Way Uptown in Hospital Country
text: YOU might call them the North Pole of the Gold Coast, a luxury enclave of Fifth Avenue apartment houses at 101st and 102nd Streets. Hemmed in by Mount Sinai hospital and other institutions, 1200, 1212 and 1215 Fifth Avenue were stranded high and dry after 1930, and the hospital is still growing.

headline: Russia Is Set to Propose Stricter Rules for Reactors
text: MOSCOW — Pointing contritely to the example of their own industry’s failures at Chernobyl, Russian officials have announced details of what is emerging as their main response to the disaster in Japan: a proposal to create an international regulatory framework for nuclear power.

headline: A Pied-à-Terre for East Coast Sojourns
text: WHAT Claire Baiz craved was a cabin in the woods.

headline: Q & A
text: The Consequences of Eviction

headline: Financing a Vacation Home
text: IT might be easier if you just paid cash for that vacation house.

headline: Sleep Can Wait. The Birds Are Angry.
text: YOU didn’t play Donkey Kong with your dad.

headline: East End Homes Prepare for Guests
text: AS soon as school ends and prime season on the East End heats up, William Stoecker, with his wife and two children in tow, will head to Prince Edward Island.  And for the fourth summer in a row, another family will be moving into the Stoeckers’ six-year-old four-bedroom East Hampton house with built-in pool. Do the Stoeckers miss summer in the Hamptons? They would rather enjoy it from afar and collect $100,000 in rent for the season.

headline: Condo Market Shows Improvement
text: Hackensack

headline: Board Scales Down Plan for Reader’s Digest Site in Chappaqua
text: CHAPPAQUA

headline: Evan Stein
text: Mr. Stein, 39, is the president of the J.D. Carlisle Development Corporation, which was started by his grandfather, Harry Feldman, and the M.D. Carlisle Construction Corporation.

headline: Dusting Off the Maid’s Room
text: THE idea of a maid’s room in New York City may conjure “Upstairs, Downstairs” images of cell-like spaces tucked away behind the kitchen, but spaces for the help are leaving behind the claustrophobic feel of the early 20th century and making a comeback. Several new developments have incorporated maid’s rooms into their larger apartments, and while the rooms are separate from family sleeping areas, they are generously sized and have standard en-suite bathrooms. The apartments recall the Classic 6s, 7s and 8s of prewar buildings along Park and Fifth Avenues, but this latest iteration of servant quarters has a distinctly 21st-century feel.

headline: Mrs. Whitney’s All-American Salon
text: On May 24 the Whitney Museum of American Art will break ground at the site of its future home in the meatpacking district. And in anticipation of its move there in 2015, the museum has cooked up a series of six back-to-back permanent-collection shows at its present location. The first of them, “Breaking Ground: The Whitney’s Founding Collection,” is up and running, and what a curious thing it is.

headline: Objects of Operatic Desire: Abundant Money and Men
text: Instead of pairing Puccini’s comic “Gianni Schicchi” with one of its somber siblings from “Il Trittico” (“The Triptych”), Juilliard Opera programmed it with “L’Heure Espagnole” (“The Spanish Hour”) by Ravel to create a double bill of amorous and avaricious lust.

headline: App Smart Extra: Major-League Apps
text: Sports fans are entering the high point of the year, with hockey and basketball playoffs sharing airtime with baseball, and the start of the National Football League draft on Thursday night.

headline: Investment Firm Buys Most of the Former Times Building
text: The Blackstone Group, the giant investment firm, is buying the top 11 floors of the former New York Times Building, on West 43rd Street, for $160 million, just four years after the 15-story building sold for $525 million.

headline: Two Jilted Lovers Sharing a Stage, but Not Their Men
text: At the heart of both “El Amor Brujo” and “La Vida Breve,” striking works by the Spanish composer Manuel de Falla, is a woman of low social standing, jilted in love. Each incorporates the influence of flamenco music and Gypsy culture. Where they part ways drastically is in how each central character deals with betrayal: one bedevils, the other expires.

headline: New Jersey School Budgets Pass in 80% of Districts
text: Faced with modest tax increases and fewer program cuts, New Jersey voters approved 80 percent of school budgets this week in an election that was largely free of last year’s turmoil.

headline: Burkina Faso Police Join in Popular Unrest
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Police officers in Burkina Faso joined a growing wave of popular unrest on Thursday, firing their weapons in the air and shooting tear gas as discontent over high prices, low wages and the 24-year-rule of President Blaise Compaoré spread in the landlocked West African nation.

headline: Apps for Photographers
text: The quantity and quality of photography apps for the iPhone are closing the gap between pictures taken with phones and those taken with cameras.

headline: Up Front: Stephen Greenblatt
text: A few years ago, the Harvard professor and noted Shakespeare scholar Stephen Green­blatt found himself struggling to cook up a fraudulent piece of Shakespeare.

headline: Shakespeare and the Will to Deceive
text: Somewhere buried under the floorboards of this splendidly devious novel is a real-life event. In 1794, a young Englishman, William Henry Ireland, came across something astonishing that he hurried to show his father: an old mortgage deed, with its seal intact, signed by none other than William Shakespeare.

headline: Could a Leaking Ocean Current Keep Europe Toasty?
text: Climate scientists have long theorized that global warming, by increasing precipitation and melting Arctic ice, could eventually destabilize the Gulf Stream, the ocean conveyor belt that carries tropical waters into the North Atlantic and warms Western Europe. The paradoxical result would be a cooling trend for the region, even as the rest of the globe continued to heat up.

headline: Lines, Loops And a Skyline Spectacle
text: Since the singer and guitarist Tyondai Braxton quit Battles last summer, it has become an instrumental group, outsourcing its vocals. But it’s still something to watch, as well as hear. On Wednesday, at Le Poisson Rouge, Battles made its stage into a skyline, with three peaks along the front: a cowbell, a cymbal and a microphone, each about six-and-a-half feet off the ground.

headline: Editor Vows George R. R. Martin Has Finished ‘A Dance With Dragons’
text: Whether you have been a long-time fan of George R. R. Martin’s “Song of Ice and Fire” fantasy novels or were only recently introduced to the HBO series “Game of Thrones,” adapted from the books, you’re probably aware of two details about this author: it has been six years since the publication of the last novel in the series, “A Feast For Crows,” and Mr. Martin is very aware of how much his readers would like to see the planned follow-up, “A Dance with Dragons.” In a recent interview with The New York Times, Mr. Martin acknowledged he was still putting his finishing touches on that book – even though a July 12 publication date had already been announced. A profile of him in The New Yorker was titled “Just Write It!”

headline: The Economic Consequences of Mr. Paul
text: Kash Mansori pursues the same line of thought I followed after Bernanke’s press conference, and fleshes it out.

headline: Crime Series to Continue Despite Author’s Death
text: Two popular series created by Robert B. Parker, the prolific mystery writer who died last year at the age of 77, will continue under two new authors, his publisher said. G. P. Putnam’s Sons, Mr. Parker’s publisher, said the Spenser series, whose first-person hero is a tough Boston private detective, would now be written by Ace Atkins, a crime novelist, and that the Jesse Stone series, featuring a former athlete with a drinking problem, would be taken over by Michael Brandman, producer and screenwriter of the “Jesse Stone” movies on CBS. Joan Parker, Mr. Parker’s widow, to whom most of the author’s more than 60 books were dedicated, said in a statement that she was “delighted that the worlds of Spenser and Jesse Stone will live on in the capable, talented hands of such gifted writers.”

headline: Instagram Spawns a Photo Ecosystem
text: Instagram, the social-meets-photos app for the iPhone that transforms plain cellphone pictures into vintage-looking works of art, has attracted millions of users. In recent months, it has also begun to draw entrepreneurs who are eager to capitalize on its growing popularity.

headline: Inspiring Comparisons With Vermeer
text: WASHINGTON — The 17th-century Dutch painter Gabriel Metsu is best known today as a lesser Vermeer, an also-ran genre painter who flattered the Amsterdam elite with comely courtship scenes set in well-appointed interiors. His paintings have yet to bait blockbuster crowds, or to inspire a novel along the lines of Tracy Chevalier’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring.”

headline: Swords Drip Red With Revenge
text: A stirring, unexpectedly moving story of love and blood, the samurai movie “13 Assassins” opens with a dignified man seated alone in a large courtyard. Perfectly centered in the shot, he says nothing, his face a ferocious mask. But words are immaterial given his open shirt and the blade in his hand. The Japanese director Takashi Miike has no qualms about letting the red run down the screen. Here, though, instead of showing the blade sinking in, he moves in closer, letting the scene play out in the man’s crumbling face, the gray sky framing him as the moist, tearing sounds of the knife doing its terrible work fill the air.

headline: Keynes vs. Hayek: A Rap Battle Renewed
text: Round 2 of the great economics smackdown is now available on video. In the impressively produced rap video “Fight of the Century” by the economist Russ Roberts and the producer and director John Papola, Friedrich Hayek and John Maynard Keynes square off to argue over such questions as whether the government should spent less or more, the source of prosperity, and whether war or natural disasters be a blessing in disguise. (Part 1 came out last year.)

headline: Writhing, Hissing and, uh, Biting
text: How much, really, do average, non-reptile-obsessed people need to know about snakes? Not nearly as much as is covered in “Wild About Snakes,” a block of shows this weekend on Nat Geo Wild. And that makes you wonder who is actually likely to watch this stuff. Is this slithering mass of programming, though it includes some tsk-tsking about the cult of illegal snake trafficking and ownership, really more interested in encouraging it? “Have a smoldering fascination with exotic or poisonous snakes?” it seems to say. “Let’s see if we can fan it into a full-fledged mania.”

headline: Feel the Hyperinflation
text: Just for a moment, let’s not do core inflation; let’s just look at the CPI — and let’s do it in levels, not rates of change. Here’s the last 10 years:

headline: A Family’s Legacy, Afro-Cuban Jazz
text: IF there is such a thing as a first family of Afro-Cuban jazz, the O’Farrill clan has a right to claim that distinction. Its members helped invent the hybrid genre back in the 1940s, when Chico O’Farrill came to New York from Havana, and in recent years they have worked to reinvigorate the music despite barriers in both Cuba and the United States.

headline: For the Fed, a Narrowing of Options
text: The American economic revival stumbled in early 2011. Could that be more than the “transitory” phenomenon that Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called it at his news conference this week?

headline: Lincoln Center to Venture Into China as Adviser for a Performing Arts Project
text: Venturing into a possible new area of revenue, Lincoln Center has agreed to serve as a paid adviser to the developers of a proposed performing arts complex in Tianjin, China’s fifth largest city, the center announced on Thursday.

headline: Bookshelf
text: Justin Martin’s “Genius of Place” (Da Capo, $28) is about Frederick Law Olmsted — yes, the Central Park landscape designer, but also the abolitionist, early-adopter environmentalist and roving journalist.

headline: Photo Replay: April 28
text: A view of the day in sports, with a pairs final on the ice in Moscow and cyclists passing pastures in Switzerland.

headline: A Fraught Mother-Daughter Drama
text: NEW HAVEN — Watching the stage adaptation of “Autumn Sonata” at the Yale Repertory Theater is a bit like looking at the Ingmar Bergman movie through the wrong end of a telescope. Moments that pulsate with oversize emotion in the movie tend to shrink into a clammy pallor in this studied but chilly production directed by Robert Woodruff. “A gray film was settling over my existence,” a character says at one point, and you know exactly how he feels.

headline: Seven Arrested in Gambling Raids in Flushing
text: Seven people in Flushing, Queens, were arrested in connection to underground gambling parlors in the Chinese community, the police said on Thursday.

headline: For Their Next Act ...
text: WHEN Adam Gertsacov and Stephanie Schwab were married three years ago, she was a vice president at a New York social media agency and he ran a small start-up from their house in Yonkers. A very small start-up: the Acme Miniature Flea Circus.

headline: Rebels Repel Assaults By Loyalists in Libya
text: ZAWIT AL MAHJOUB, Libya — Rebels opposed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi clashed with loyalist troops on Thursday in this village several miles west of the besieged city of Misurata on Thursday, as the rebels withstood a loyalist ground assault.

headline: Bringing Heavy Metal to the Met’s Roof
text: No one in the 1960s produced livelier, more infectiously playful sculpture than the British artist Anthony Caro, five of whose works now grace the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s rooftop garden.

headline: Social Largess Speeds Rise in Oil Prices
text: There’s no mystery in why all the unrest in North Africa and the Middle East would cause oil and gasoline prices to soar. Libya’s high quality sweet crude is almost off the market entirely, and it’s anyone’s guess when the next oil producer is going to suffer a revolution that could cripple production.

headline: BlackBerry Maker Cuts Its Forecast
text: OTTAWA — When executives at Research in Motion were faced with skepticism last month about the company’s ability to compete against Apple and Android devices, they consistently pointed to its still-robust financial performance.

headline: Despite Bipartisan Support, Nuclear Reactor Projects Falter
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to encourage nuclear power, Congress voted in 2005 to authorize $17.5 billion in loan guarantees for new reactors. Now, six years later, with the industry stalled by poor market conditions and the Fukushima disaster, nearly half of the fund remains unclaimed. And yet Congress, at the request of the Obama administration, is preparing to add $36 billion in nuclear loan guarantees to next year’s budget.

headline: A Skate Shop With a Focus: Roller Derby
text: It’s an unassuming spot for the mecca of East Coast roller derby, this small, narrow shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, beside the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. A handwritten sign on the door reads, “We are not the bike shop,” and directs cyclists to nearby King Kog.

headline: The Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball
text: A look inside the party at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: ‘Breaking Ground’
text: Images from the new exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: ‘Night Vision’
text: Photos from a new photography exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Simpson Thacher to Add Hong Kong Law Practice
text: Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the American law firm, plans to add a Hong Kong law practice to supplement its existing operations there later this year. The firm has hired Celia Lam from Linklaters and Christopher Wong from Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer as partners to lead the practice.

headline: Keynes vs. Hayek: The Fight of the Century
text: Round 2 of the great economics smackdown is now available on video. In the impressively produced rap video “Fight of the Century” by the economist Russ Roberts and the producer and director John Papola, Friedrich Hayek and John Maynard Keynes square off to argue over such questions as whether the government should spent less or more, the source of prosperity, and whether war or natural disasters be a blessing in disguise. (Part 1 came out last year.)

headline: In Shuttle’s Waning Days, One of the Last Reasons to Cheer
text: TITUSVILLE, Fla. — As it has many times before, sometime Friday afternoon the stretch of Route 1 in front of Chris Galorneau’s restaurant will turn into a parking lot.

headline: The Battle for Libya | April 28
text: In recent days, since the Qaddafi forces withdrew under pressure from central Misurata, the fighting has shifted to the city’s outskirts.

headline: China’s Exports Perch on Uncertain Truck System
text: SHANGHAI — For years, China’s export juggernaut has been fed by highly efficient factories, low-cost labor and a fleet of container ships capable of transporting huge volumes of toys, textiles, electronics and other goods to every corner of the world.

headline: The Latest from the N.R.C. on Fukushima, and More
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has not yet said what changes it will order at American reactors in response to the Fukushima disaster, but at a briefing on Thursday morning, some clues emerged about areas that might require further study.

headline: Couple Admit to Their Roles in Kidnapping of 11-Year-Old
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Ending a sordid criminal ordeal that began two decades ago with a kidnapping on a South Lake Tahoe street, a convicted sex offender and his wife pleaded guilty on Thursday to the abduction, rape and imprisonment of Jaycee Lee Dugard.

headline: Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us
text: CURLED up at the foot of my bed, my face inches from the laptop screen, I stared anxiously at the Google chat box. “Will is typing,” the box told me, helpfully.

headline: Modern Love: College Essay Contest
text: IN February, Sunday Styles asked college students nationwide to tell us — through their own stories, in their own voices — what love is like for them. When we first held this contest three years ago, the most popular essay topic was hooking up: the “no strings attached” sex that for many wasn’t turning out to be so carefree. The question that seemed to hover over hundreds of such accounts was: How do we get the physical without the emotional?

headline: From Ringside, Gay Man’s Play Packs a Punch
text: In a boxing gym in San Francisco on a recent Sunday afternoon, a trainee and his coach sparred, verbally and physically.

headline: In a Small Town, Big Life-Changers
text: “Lebanon, Pa.” retells the old story of the city mouse and the country mouse while meticulously applying it to America’s simmering culture wars. Written, directed and edited by Ben Hickernell, the movie avoids making any grand statements or raising emotional temperatures more than necessary.

headline: A Quick Note on Gas Prices and Presidential Approval
text: A six-hour flight delay has scuttled my plans for a longer post today (and perhaps changed my opinion on the government’s new rules about how long planes can idle on the tarmac). But I wanted to point you to a little bit of research on the link between gas prices and presidential performance.

headline: Shareholders Give Thumbs Up to J.&J. Executive Pay
text: At Johnson & Johnson’s annual meeting on Thursday, shareholders voted, on an advisory basis, to approve the compensation package being awarded to the company’s chief executive.

headline: Thai Protest Photos Earn a Capa Medal
text: The convulsive political protests in Thailand last year were the first violent breaking news story that Agnes Dherbeys has covered. She sought to bring the same empathy that characterizes her feature work to the often bloody street scenes in Bangkok.

headline: A Closer Look at the Destruction in Tuscaloosa
text: Zoom in on images and examine some of the damage from a mile-wide tornado that tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., on Wednesday.

headline: No Shortage of Social Media for the Royal Wedding
text: Don’t want to watch the royal wedding alone in the predawn darkness? Not to worry. The major television and cable networks invite you to join them in the conversation about the dress, the flowers, the first kiss. All you need is your computer, tablet or smartphone and a Twitter or Facebook account.

headline: A Thief With Less Need for a Getaway Car
text: If you like the “Bourne” movies but wish they were more cerebral — not to mention quiet, cryptic and withholding — you might be the perfect audience for “The Robber.”

headline: Man’s Best Friend’s Best Friend
text: On the patio at the Park Chow restaurant in San Francisco last month, while other diners grazed on salads and veggie lasagna, Douglas Wilkins took a glob of cream cheese from a container and fed it to Thisbe, a white fluffy Eskie that he and his wife had just adopted.

headline: Video: Mark Ingram’s Draft Day
text: Former Alabama running back and Heisman Trophy winner Mark Ingram has yet to make a play in the N.F.L., but he has already had a sculpture made in his honor, made out of chicken salad.

headline: Business Leaders Endorse Same-Sex Marriage
text: New York State business leaders characterize marriage equality legislation as good for the economy.

headline: This Just In: Obama Born in the U.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Excerpt: 'The Normal Heart'
text: Ellen Barkin and Joe Mantello in a scene from Larry Kramer's play, which opened on Broadway at the Golden Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: A Whim, a Book, and, Wow!
text: When Adam Mansbach, author of “Angry Black White Boy” and “The End of the Jews,” posted on Facebook last June to “Look out for my forthcoming children’s book, ‘Go the — to Sleep,’ ” he was not serious. He was just tired: his then-2-year-old daughter, Vivien, refused to acknowledge bedtime.

headline: Jury Convicts 2 and Acquits 2 in Cocaine Scheme
text: There had been testimony about Colombian terrorists, drug shipment flights from South America to West Africa and a government sting that featured the covert participation of the Liberian president’s son.

headline: Live Blog: The 2011 N.F.L. Draft
text: If you want real N.F.L draft wisdom, do not ask a team executive. Do not ask a prospect, reporter, or “draftnik” either.

headline: Party Leaders and Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lenovo Aims a Campaign at the Apple Crowd
text: QUICK. How many Chinese brands can you name? Probably not many. While China has been known for its manufacturing prowess, branding its own products has not been its strength.

headline: G.O.P. Pledge on Taxes
text: To the Editor:

headline: High-Speed Rail
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Cynical Faith Healer Who Can’t Fix Himself
text: Dean O’Dwyer (Christopher Thornton), a k a Delicious D, the paraplegic turntable artist turned faith healer at the center of “Sympathy for Delicious” is a paradox in a wheelchair. A cynical nonbeliever who discovers that he has a faith-healing gift that works 75 percent of the time, Dean is understandably miffed when he can heal others but can’t make himself walk.

headline: Saying No to Torture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giving Juveniles Who Kill a Chance at Redemption
text: To the Editor:

headline: Home-Buying Trends
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Crises Cut the Bottom Lines at Some Concerns
text: When the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan in March, economists and corporate leaders knew it was only a matter of time for the financial effects to reach American companies.

headline: School Districts Look to Parcel Taxes for Aid
text: Bay Area school districts, facing increasingly severe budget problems, are turning en masse to one of the few revenue-raising tools at their disposal: the parcel tax. These levies, a form of property tax, require approval by two-thirds of district voters, and they will be on the ballot in 11 different Bay Area school districts in a mail-in election next week.

headline: Unease in Chatham, but Who’s at Fault?
text: It has been asserted so widely for so long that it is accepted as fact: When Chicago’s public housing projects came down, many of their former residents moved into middle-class South Side neighborhoods and brought crime with them.

headline: Puppy Love and Bullies and a Bow-Tied Teacher
text: You can trust Ed Harris to locate the essence of every character he portrays. And in “That’s What I Am,” Mike Pavone’s righteous reflection on bullying and tolerance, Mr. Harris’s depiction of a saintly, soft-spoken, bow-tie-wearing middle-school teacher lends the movie a moral weight it probably couldn’t have summoned had another actor played the role.

headline: New Chicago School Board Tackles Familiar Worries
text: The final meeting for Mayor Richard M. Daley’s Board of Education was marked by a tiny ripple of resistance among the ranks of a group that has largely marched in step since Mr. Daley took control of the city’s public school system in 1995.

headline: Mark Ingram's Draft Day
text: The former Heisman Trophy winner has yet to make a play in the N.F.L., but he has already had a sculpture made in his honor, out of chicken salad, courtesy of Subway.

headline: A Utopian Society Made Up of Business Moguls in Fedoras
text: Could anyone have guessed, way back when it was published in 1957, that “Atlas Shrugged,” Ayn Rand’s grandiloquent doorstop of a masterwork, would one day reach the big screen as high-camp comedy? Because stilted prose and silly plotting notwithstanding, Rand’s unrelentingly popular book has exerted a powerful ideological hold on the culture, an influence that has only intensified in recent years with the emergence of the Tea Party. Still, for unintentional yet somehow boring hilarity, the novel can’t touch the cinematic adaptation, which shifts the action to 2016 and presents Rand’s ham-fisted fable of laissez-faire capitalism as something C-Span might make if it ever set out to create a futuristic, proto-libertarian nighttime soap. In the 1980s.

headline: A Shuttle Town’s Glory Days
text: The launching of the space shuttle Endeavor is expected to be one of the biggest ever, jamming the roads in Titusville, Cape Canaveral and other nearby Florida towns.

headline: The Monarchy Earns Its Keep
text: Egham, England

headline: Rare Footage Indeed: Tornadoes, in Real Time
text: The deadliest tornado outbreak in decades unfolded live on local television stations Wednesday across much of the Deep South — and, remarkably, some of the tornado touchdowns were shown live, as well.

headline: Discussions Outside Court Are Raised at Fire Trial
text: The public rarely gets a peek into the out-of-court discussions between prosecutors and the witnesses who testify for them.

headline: Son of Advocates Makes Education His Mission
text: When the Chicago Board of Education meeting changed into a mutual admiration society on Wednesday, the members resembled fatigued relief workers celebrating after slightly diverting a flood.
