headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Winners
text: The Tribeca Film Festival announced its winners Thursday night, with films from Sweden, South Korea, Rwanda and Norway among those taking prizes.

headline: The Other
text: To watch Mitt Romney these days, he of the creased blue jeans and family that looks like it came from a Betty Crocker mold, circa 1957, it’s hard to see a product of one of the most radical social and sexual experiments in American history.

headline: Rev. David Wilkerson Dies at 79; Started Times Square Church
text: The Rev. David Wilkerson, an evangelical minister and author who founded the Times Square Church to minister to the downtrodden in one of Manhattan’s seedier precincts, but whose later writings included apocalyptic predictions for New York City and beyond, died on Wednesday in an automobile accident in Texas. He was 79 and lived near Tyler, Tex.

headline: To Lead Afghan War, Obama Chooses Marine Known for Swaying Sunnis in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — Lt. Gen. John R. Allen was called to the White House on Thursday for the formal announcement that he would take custody of the war in Afghanistan, now the focus of attention as the Obama administration moves toward withdrawing troops and handing over responsibility to the government in Kabul.

headline: The Family Show-Off, Offering More for Less
text: INGRATITUDE and a grating impertinence are something many parents have come to expect from their high-maintenance subunits, but challenging one’s parent is less common in the automotive world.

headline: County Was Struggling Even Before the Storm
text: There are few places in America with more precarious finances than Jefferson County, Ala., the scene of some of the worst devastation from this week’s deadly tornadoes.

headline: The Intimidated Fed
text: Last month more than 14 million Americans were unemployed by the official definition — that is, seeking work but unable to find it. Millions more were stuck in part-time work because they couldn’t find full-time jobs. And we’re not talking about temporary hardship. Long-term unemployment, once rare in this country, has become all too normal: More than four million Americans have been out of work for a year or more.

headline: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus in Conflict With Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The appointment of Gen. David H. Petraeus as director of the Central Intelligence Agency puts him more squarely than ever in conflict with Pakistan, whose military leadership does not regard him as a friend and where he will now have direct control over the armed drone campaign that the Pakistani military says it wants stopped.

headline: Trying to Stir Up a Popular Protest in China, From a Bedroom in Manhattan
text: From a pair of computer screens in a lime green bedroom in Upper Manhattan, a 27-year-old man from China is working to bring about a popular uprising.

headline: Art of the Soil, on the Upper West Side
text: Imagine spending an afternoon watching a bunch of vagrants putter around on an abandoned city lot, and you’ve pretty much nailed the viewing experience of “Earthwork,” a painfully dull account of a year in the life of the Kansas crop artist Stan Herd.

headline: Role Reversal for 2 Teams in This Year’s Playoffs
text: It’s hard to tell the players without a scorecard or two at the United Center these days. The 2011 postseason continues a role reversal that has been under way for the building’s two major tenants.

headline: A Chaotic Flurry of Twisters That Spread Devastation Fast and Wide
text: PLEASANT GROVE, Ala. — William Cannon, 46, a maintenance worker in this Birmingham suburb, said everyone knew on Wednesday that a big storm was coming. “The news had been telling us about it for two days,” he said.

headline: Consultant to the Schools Stole Millions, Officials Say
text: Aided by lax oversight and by corporations that profited from his scheme, a former technology consultant stole $3.6 million over six years from the Department of Education to finance flashy cars and real estate speculation, federal authorities said on Thursday.

headline: What Government Does
text: We in the commentariat spend a lot of time reporting on the White House and the U.S. Capitol, but relatively little time reporting on the dozens of federal buildings around them where public policy actually gets executed. We engage in debates about the size of government but spend little time directly observing what government is and isn’t good at.

headline: Conservative Congressman’s Star Power Extends Beyond Florida District
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Often, the most interesting thing about a person is the characteristic that lies beneath, that hidden thing that bobs up along the waves of time.

headline: A TV Series Lost in Translation
text: Phil Rosenthal, the creator of “Everybody Loves Raymond,” is a successful television producer who’s perhaps best known for being a frustrated actor and comedian. Now he has essentially cast himself as the star of “Exporting Raymond,” a documentary he wrote and directed about the frustrations of adapting his creation for Russian TV. It has the structure and some of the pleasures of a well-made sitcom or docu-reality show, despite the nervous-looking, unhappy guy at its center; it could have been called “Nobody Understands Phil.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,540 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: The Mortgage Was Like a Shell Game; So Is Responsibility in 3 Deaths
text: The promise made by a mortgage company in San Diego could not have been more blunt. “Accredited Home Lenders offers an unusually broad line of subprime mortgage products for wholesale mortgage brokers,” the company’s Web site boasted in its heyday.

headline: 2 Russians Guilty of Killing Rights Lawyer and Journalist
text: MOSCOW — A young Russian nationalist and his common-law wife were convicted Thursday in the particularly brazen murders of a prominent human rights lawyer and a journalist two years ago, as the jury sided with prosecutors who argued that the ideologically driven defendants considered their victims enemies of Russia.

headline: President Assad’s Crackdown
text: When Bashar al-Assad succeeded his father, Hafez, as Syria’s president in 2000, the United States and many others hoped that Syria might finally stop persecuting its people and become a more responsible regional power.

headline: Red Riding Hood, the Spy Caper
text: From the Department of Needless Sequels comes “Hoodwinked Too! Hood vs. Evil,” another Weinstein Company bid to crack the overcrowded field of children’s digital animation. A successor to the lackluster “Hoodwinked!,” with a cast of formidable voice talents, the film takes fairy-tale characters — Little Red Riding Hood, the Wolf, the Grandmother — and drops them into a comic web of fantastical espionage.

headline: Speaking Up for Patient Safety, and Survival
text: On Tuesday, I wrote about a new technological system that might help hospitals to accurately track whether health care workers are washing their hands, and remind them to do so in real time. The reason hospitals might want to spend the money to install such an expensive fix is that so far, very few hospitals have been able to get their hand-washing rates above 50 percent.

headline: Working Up a Sweat, and That’s Well Before the Draft
text: The N.F.L. draft has become a lot like a football practice, for prospects and fans alike: a grueling, seemingly never-ending series of events and obstacles, conducted in pouring rain and stifling humidity.

headline: The Subway’s Elevator Operators, a Reassuring Amenity of Another Era
text: John Petruzzi’s office is, all things considered, not a terribly unpleasant place to work. It could use a window, and an Internet connection might be nice, but colorful art hangs on the walls, and the subway access is unbeatable.

headline: A Disney Take on the Big Night — Review
text: Some moviegoers and critics will probably dismiss “Prom” as just another predictable offering from the Disney formula factory. Which is precisely what it is. But here’s the thing: There are new tweeners every year. To them, the characters and plot devices in this perfectly competent film might well seem fresh.

headline: Saving the Doha Round
text: After a decade of frustratingly little progress, it is easy to conclude that the negotiations to reduce global trade barriers have failed. But letting the so-called Doha round of world trade talks collapse could spur a protectionist backlash and deal a huge blow to international cooperation on even bigger challenges, including global warming and financial reform.

headline: Storms Leave Destruction in Their Wake
text: The death toll continued to climb Thursday from a barrage of severe weather that ripped through the South, leaving behind a trail of flattened homes and buildings in a region already battered by storms.

headline: Homers Are Just a Part of the Yanks’ Big Night
text: Their first three games against the Chicago White Sox transported the Yankees into this bizarro alternate universe, a place where all accepted certainties about the team were refuted. A potent lineup went silent. Their lockdown bullpen faltered. The rotation, supposedly shaky, thrived.

headline: A Stronger and Clearer Clean Water Act
text: The Obama administration’s new guidelines for the Clean Water Act are an important first step in restoring vital legal safeguards to wetlands and streams threatened by development and pollution.

headline: In the Wake of Wednesday’s Tornadoes
text: The violent storms that struck the South on Wednesday may break one of nature’s grimmer records. On April 3, 1974, 148 tornadoes touched down on a single day and left behind a trail of wreckage nearly 2,500 miles long. As many as 135 tornadoes were reported on Wednesday, wrecking homes, towns and lives.

headline: Berkshire Gets Tough With Sokol as Meeting Nears
text: After Warren E. Buffett disclosed last month that David L. Sokol was resigning from Berkshire Hathaway amid the revelation that he had bought a $10 million personal stake in Lubrizol while promoting a takeover of the company, Berkshire was quiet for weeks. Now, on the eve of Berkshire’s annual shareholders meeting, the company has come out fighting.

headline: Can Kristen Wiig Turn On the Charm?
text: Kristen Wiig shows up seven minutes into the movie “Knocked Up,” an assassin in a junior executive’s suit, meeting with the television production assistant played by Katherine Heigl, who their boss has decided is ready to go on the air. Wiig’s character is every middle manager who clings to her authority by association; she shows her boss small reassuring smiles while revealing subterranean loathing toward the young woman with the promotion. She tells Heigl’s character that they cannot legally ask her to lose weight. “We would just like it if you go home and step on a scale and write down how much you weigh,” she says. “And subtract it by, like, 20.” “Knocked Up” is a movie filled with slapstick, screaming and shtick, and yet Wiig, with nothing more than her small, tight smile and death-by-platitude lines, practically stole the show with that two-minute scene. “After I saw how much people loved it in the movie,” says Judd Apatow, who wrote and directed the film, “I instantly asked her if she had any plans to write a script for herself.”

headline: Sooner or Later, the Celtics Were Expecting to Face the Heat
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — A playoff series between Boston and Miami seemed preordained, almost inevitable, once LeBron James took his considerable talents (along with Chris Bosh) to South Beach and the Celtics responded by signing every available O’Neal.

headline: When Past and Present Collide
text: A letter from the past prompts present-day pain in “We Go Way Back,” a gentle survey of the chasm between youthful dreams and adult reality.

headline: Predicting Tornadoes: It’s Still a Guessing Game
text: The cruelty of this particular April, in the number of tornadoes recorded, is without equal in the United States. The record for the month has been shattered, and preliminary assessments say that of the four biggest clusters ever recorded, two have occurred in the last three weeks.

headline: In Shift, Egypt Warms to Iran and Hamas, Israel’s Foes
text: CAIRO — Egypt is charting a new course in its foreign policy that has already begun shaking up the established order in the Middle East, planning to open the blockaded border with Gaza and normalizing relations with two of Israel and the West’s Islamist foes, Hamas and Iran.

headline: A Cosmic Comeuppance for the Dodgers
text: Be careful. Be very careful what you wish for. And whatever you do, never underestimate the power of negative thinking.

headline: On to Round 2 After a Round 1 That Had Everything
text: The first round of this year’s Stanley Cup playoffs is a tough act to follow, but the show went on Thursday night, with Nashville visiting Vancouver to start the second round.

headline: The Deadliest Years
text: A map of tornado deaths from 1950 to 2011.

headline: Business Leaders, in Letter, Will Urge Albany to Legalize Gay Marriage
text: Two dozen high-profile New York business leaders plan to release an open letter on Friday urging state lawmakers to legalize same-sex marriage, arguing that the measure would help companies attract and retain employees.

headline: China: Sentence Reduced for Hong Kong Academic
text: The sentence of a Hong Kong political scientist who was jailed on espionage charges in 2001 after he was accused of giving secret documents to a South Korean scholar has been reduced by five months, an American human rights organization said Thursday.  The researcher, Xu Zerong, was a senior fellow at the Guangdong Academy of Social Sciences when he was accused of illegally photocopying military documents from the Korean War and “illegally providing intelligence to foreign entities.” Mr. Xu said that he thought the five-decade-old documents had long since been declassified. The Dui Hua Foundation, a human rights group, said Mr. Xu had already served 10 years of a 13-year sentence and that with two previous reductions for good behavior, he could be released in June.

headline: Friday: It May Be Assumed
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s talk about the days of the week. Today is Friday, and as we all know, today’s puzzle should be one of the two brain breakers of the week, along with the Saturday puzzle. There is a lot of discussion among solvers and constructors about whether this means that there should be more SAT type words, or that the cluing should be fairly opaque. I’m going to give you my opinion, and I realize that your mileage may vary.

headline: Bid to Limit Benefits Plan in New Jersey Is Dropped
text: A statewide employee-benefits program that has enabled hundreds of local governments and school districts in New Jersey to save tens of millions of dollars on health insurance has averted a potentially crippling legislative threat.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 28, 2011

headline: What Bubbie Did During the War
text: When Donna Murphy time travels, she packs light. A pair of glasses, a shawl, maybe some lipstick: that’s all this chameleon actress requires to step over the chasm that divides two chapters of one woman’s life in “The People in the Picture,” a sincere and queasy new musical about mother love, Yiddish theater and the Holocaust that opened on Thursday night at Studio 54.

headline: Hernandez Puts Aside Concerns About Investigation and Halts Mets’ Streak
text: WASHINGTON — Washington Nationals pitcher Livan Hernandez has made 452 consecutive starts over the last 15 years without going on the disabled list, a remarkable string of durability, focus and resilience. Surely there were times he did not feel quite right, when his arm ached or a personal issue nagged at him.

headline: The Causes of the Civil War, 2.0
text: A new poll from the Pew Research Center reports that nearly half of Americans identify states’ rights as the primary cause of the Civil War. This is a remarkable finding, because virtually all American textbooks and prominent historians emphasize slavery, as they have for decades. Even more striking, the poll shows young people put more stock in the states’ rights explanation than older people. The 38 percent of Americans who believe slavery was mainly to blame find themselves losing ground.

headline: Storms Leave Destruction in Their Wake
text: The death toll continued to climb Thursday from a barrage of severe weather that ripped through the South, leaving behind a trail of flattened homes and buildings in a region already battered by storms.

headline: Giants’ Pick Is Surprise; Jets Get What They Were Looking For
text: The Giants favored talent over needs Thursday night when they selected Nebraska cornerback Prince Amukamara at No. 19 of the N.F.L. draft.

headline: Cheaper Drug to Treat Eye Disease Is Effective
text: A drug that costs about $50 a dose is just as effective at preserving and improving vision in elderly people with an age-related eye disease as one that costs $2,000 a dose, according to the results of a government-sponsored clinical trial released Thursday.

headline: A Big Question for Berkshire
text: Warren E. Buffett has many unpleasant questions to address at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting on Saturday. The stock dealings of David L. Sokol, a former heir apparent, have raised concerns over the company’s internal controls — even about Mr. Buffett’s judgment. But one subject may be a step too far for the Buffett faithful congregating in Omaha: isn’t it time to break up the company?

headline: Vincent O’Leary, Who Revived Albany University, Dies at 86
text: Vincent O’Leary, who invigorated the State University of New York at Albany after a period of decline, died on April 22 in Gaithersburg, Md., where he lived. He was 86.

headline: London Readies for Royal Wedding
text: LONDON — As last-minute preparations drew to a close, London braced Friday for a royal wedding that promises to be one of the largest and most widely watched events here in recent memory.

headline: Proposal Seeks to Expand List of Organ Donors
text: In 2010 almost 600 Texans died while waiting for organ transplants, a byproduct of the state’s paltry offerings on its state-run organ-donation registry.

headline: After Fire, Wind and Drought, Something Good Will Follow
text: These are strange days in Texas. A severe drought gripping the entire state, unseasonably high temperatures, unusually low humidity and exceptionally gusty winds have created a perfect storm for wildfires, which have erupted statewide like never before. Horrible images of homes burned to the ground, property destroyed, and livestock, wildlife and human fatalities are impossible to escape.

headline: For Accused, Long Waits to Appeal Child Abuse Allegations
text: It has been more than a decade since Child Protective Services entered Gary and Melissa Gates’s home in the Houston area and removed their two biological children and 11 adopted ones, after an allegation that the pair had emotionally abused one of the children. Within three days, a judge had returned all the children to their parents; within eight months, the child welfare agency had dropped its case.

headline: Arrest of a Bronx Prosecutor Is Said to Uncover Possible Favored Treatment in Past
text: An assistant district attorney in the Bronx who was arrested last summer on drunken driving charges may have received preferential treatment in a possible earlier case in which she was also suspected of drunken driving, according to a law enforcement official.

headline: Red Bulls to Play in London This Summer
text: The Red Bulls will take advantage of a two-week lull in their M.L.S. schedule in late July and early August to play in the Emirates Cup against Arsenal, Paris St. Germain and Boca Juniors in London.

headline: Quarterbacks Go Fast in Draft
text: A draft unlike any in N.F.L. history began Thursday night inside Radio City Music Hall. At first glance it felt like any other, the first of three days steeped in spectacle, with fans decked out in jerseys, players strolling the red carpet and interviews conducted in platitudes.

headline: Storms’ Toll Rises as Scale of Damage Becomes Clear
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — On Friday, as President Obama came to this partly ruined city to witness the destruction wrought by this week’s monstrous storms, the full scope of the damage was becoming more apparent.

headline: A Traditional Royal Wedding, but for the 3 Billion Witnesses
text: LONDON — In the end, Friday’s wedding between Prince William and Kate Middleton may not have ushered in a new dawn for the frayed royal family or brought a renewed era of optimism to a country beset by financial woes, as some predicted in the overheated countdown to the big day. But it proved that the British still know how to combine pageantry, solemnity and romance (and wild hats) better than anyone else in the world.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

text: Susan Krause, 57, born with cerebral palsy, has lived in Stuyvesant Town all her life. With the help of The Neediest Cases, she escaped eviction and was able to stay in her home that she considers a leafy sanctuary within the city.

headline: Daimler Profit Nearly Doubles in First Quarter
text: FRANKFURT — Daimler said Friday that it nearly doubled its profit in the first quarter as sales in China continued to show big gains and the market for heavy trucks recovered.

headline: Chinese Currency Rises Above Key Level
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese currency hit a milestone Friday by rising beyond a level closely watched by analysts — the strongest since Beijing began allowing the currency, the renminbi, to rise in 2005 and a sign that the authorities might be using the appreciation as a weapon against inflation.

headline: Do You Write in Cursive?
text: Some say it’s the constant typing on computers and smartphones. Others believe it’s the increased pressure to prepare students for standardized tests. But what’s clear is that fewer kids are mastering–and practicing–the art of cursive. How about you? When you pick up a pencil or pen, do you print or use cursive–or your own special blend of the two?

headline: Live Updates: The Royal Wedding
text: From the opening fanfare to the final photographed kiss, The Lede tracked Friday’s royal wedding in London between Prince William, the son of the heir to the British throne, and his longtime girlfriend, Kate Middleton.

headline: Web Site Connects Parisian Cooks and Diners
text: In a city famous for its cuisine, it can sometimes be difficult to find a decent meal in Paris with a price that’s easy to stomach. Olivier Desmoulin, a co-creator of Super Marmite, is trying to make it a little easier, via the magic of crowd-sourcing and GPS.

headline: Elliott Raises Danisco Stake on Eve of DuPont Deadline
text: Elliott Advisors, the activist investor, now owns just over 5 percent of Danisco, the Danish food ingredient company said Friday, making it one of the Danisco’s largest shareholders next to the Danish pension fund ATP.

headline: Web Tools for the Flexible Flier
text: I’m one of those people who can get a little carried away when trying to find a slightly better or cheaper flight or hotel for a business trip. Kayak is my obsessive tool of choice — I haven’t found a site that matches it for comprehensive coverage of airlines and hotels and for its ability to play with variables.

headline: Syrian Forces Shoot at Protesters in Dara’a Siege
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Soldiers fired on protesters carrying olive branches and seeking to break the military’s siege of a rebellious town in Syria on Friday, killing at least 16 people, as thousands took to the streets in what organizers proclaimed a “Friday of Rage” against the government’s crackdown on a six-week uprising, witnesses and activists said.

headline: Has the Trump Show Run Its Course?
text: Has the Trump show run its course?

headline: Democrats Form Fund-Raising Groups
text: A group of leading Democrats, including some with close connections to the White House, are officially forming what are expected be the major outside groups to combat Republicans — and support President Obama — in the 2012 elections with help from huge donations from big money donors and corporations who will have the legal ability to stay in the shadows that Mr. Obama has previously so vocally criticized.

headline: European Regulators Investigate Banks for Credit Swaps
text: Ever since the financial crisis, when derivatives were blamed for exacerbating the panic, regulators have been looking for ways to make these complex financial instruments less risky. Now, regulators are also considering whether a small network of big banks unfairly controls the derivatives market itself.

headline: The Wedding of Lady Diana Spencer and Prince Charles
text: A look back at the royal wedding of 1981 that was filled with pomp and circumstance of the time.

headline: Clip: 'Beautiful Boy'
text: Maria Bello and Michael Sheen in a clip from "Beautiful Boy," in theaters June 3.

headline: Incident on a Train
text: The guy behind me on the train was whispering into his phone, something about his soon-to-be-ex demanding the house on the river. Something about how he wakes up nauseated, almost as if he were undergoing chemo, which he would prefer because at least cancer would be an enemy he could commit to hating instead of being conflicted the way he was, still loving his pre-ex but needing to fight her as hard as he could. With my head against the window in the seat ahead, I was feeling vaguely nauseated myself, when I became conscious that a woman’s voice was calling out weakly from the front of the crowded compartment. “Help. Someone help me.”

headline: The Year That TV Actually Got It Right
text: Sports-stats nerds (who are, statistically speaking, the jockiest of all nerd subcastes) love to debate the “perfect draft.” A recent ESPN.com study concluded that the 1983 N.F.L. draft was just that; players drafted that year racked up a total of 142 Pro Bowl appearances, and six of them went to the Hall of Fame. Even if you factor out John Elway, Dan Marino and Jim Kelly, the class of ’83 still finishes in a virtual tie with the study’s second- and third-place drafts, 1996 (Ray Lewis, Terrell Owens) and 1981 (Lawrence Taylor, Ronnie Lott).

headline: Abuse of ‘Power’?
text: My sister recently seized my 82-year-old father’s assets under her decade-old power of attorney, after he became engaged to a 63-year-old woman with a history of unpaid bills and an affinity for Atlantic City slots. He was running around with multiple testosterone patches in anticipation of his nuptials to this gal, who refused to meet with us after we traveled cross-country. Now he says he promises not to marry her, and we feel terrible for humiliating him. Should we give him back control of his money or would that be setting him up to be fleeced? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

headline: Eating Your Cultural Vegetables
text: “Do you watch ‘Phineas and Ferb’?”

headline: What if Sanity Prevails In Washington?
text: My colleague David Leonhardt, an economics writer who somehow makes common sense seem provocative, won a Pulitzer Prize the other day. I have no doubt the judges who reviewed his work were particularly impressed by one feat of analytical genius, an online puzzle called “O.K., You Fix the Budget.” With help from some of our techno-genies, David devised an interactive graphic that lets you choose from a menu of tax increases and spending cuts and benefit tweaks until the budget balances. In short, he crowd-sourced the deficit.

headline: Marine Le Pen, France’s (Kinder, Gentler) Extremist
text: Step inside an office building in the town of Nanterre, just west of Paris, and you are confronted by what the nostrils register as an odor of the past, for it’s a rare thing these days to encounter the lingering taint of cigarette smoke in public spaces. The trail of it leads upstairs to a corner office and to the woman who has, in the past few months, come to dominate French newspapers and chat shows, where she is depicted variously as the new face of European bigotry or a herald of a new European political realignment.

headline: For ‘Modernist Cuisine,’ Errata Commensurate to the Task
text: For those of us who don’t have the $625 (or the upper-body strength) to buy “Modernist Cuisine,” the six-volume, 40-pound high-tech food encyclopedia released with great fanfare last month, the 12 pages of corrections and clarifications that went up on the book’s Web site last week is worth a read for its own sake.

headline: Debating Legacy Admissions at Yale, and Elsewhere
text: True or false: Admitting legacies to colleges and universities is, a) unconstitutional b) unethical c) smart business practice or d) legitimate, because legacies perform better at certain elite institutions?

text: John Petruzzi’s office is, all things considered, not a terribly unpleasant place to work. It could use a window, and an Internet connection might be nice.

headline: Europe Investigating Banks Over Derivatives
text: 11:05 a.m. | Updated European Union antitrust regulators announced on Friday two sweeping antitrust investigations into the world’s largest banks and their roles in a market for derivatives where a small number of companies control trillions of dollars of financial instruments.

headline: Richie Sambora to Miss Bon Jovi Tour

headline: Magic Lanterns
text: The young designer Marco Dessí, who was born in Italy and who is based in Vienna, has a knack for clarity. A recent case in point is his Basket chandelier for the venerable Viennese manufacturer Lobmeyr. Dessí took as its starting point the glass-tube arms of an 18th-century chandelier but employed them in a new way, bending them into hexagons, stacking them in a shape inspired by mosque lanterns and the glass-tube windows of Frank Lloyd Wright’s S. C. Johnson Administration Building, and weaving them together with jewel-toned silk cords. The result is an alluring combination of the industrial and the glamorous. Go to lobmeyr.at.

headline: Leading Off: Get Your Quarterbacks Here
text: In this most bizarre of N.F.L. off-seasons, the first round of the draft did not disappoint. There were boos. There were tears. There was Cam Newton going from most hotly debated prospect to most hotly debated No. 1 pick. There was Commissioner Roger Goodell hugging players like that creepy uncle you really wish would let go already. And there was a run on quarterbacks so irrational you wonder if the N.F.L. circulated a memo that Goodell would start hugging you if you didn’t pick one.

headline: Tales From the Global Sex Trade
text: Opponents of immigration often prefer to ignore the tragic forces that compel people to risk death in order to reach our lands of plenty, not to mention the horrors that often await the “lucky” few, once they do arrive. Imagine an Underground Railroad in which the conductor robs and rapes his passengers, and the station porter, once they’ve disembarked, ushers them into a new form of slavery. This unholy traffic in impoverished strivers, imported to service needs Westerners don’t want to think about, is the subject of Chika Unigwe’s novel “On Black Sisters Street.”

headline: China: Canceled Music Festival Raises Concern
text: A music festival scheduled for this weekend in the city of Suzhou has been canceled, making some musicians and organizers of music festivals in China increasingly nervous that the continuing government crackdown on dissent could have a significant impact on them. Organizers of the Suzhou music festival, called Strawberry, said in messages on the Internet this week that the event was canceled for reasons related to recent rainstorms. But artists and observers of the music industry in China have speculated that Strawberry was canceled because of official pressure after a political incident at a music festival last weekend in Jiangsu Province. At that festival, called Zhouzhuang, the name of the detained artist Ai Weiwei was flashed on a big screen. Days later, Zuoxiao Zuzhou, a Chinese rock musician who expressed support for Mr. Ai at that festival and in a newspaper article, was temporarily detained by police officers. Another music festival, Midi, is scheduled to take place this weekend in a suburb of Beijing; its organizers have privately told people that they are anxious.

headline: Superman Renounces His U.S. Citizenship
text: For much of his career, Superman has fought for truth, justice and the American way. In the landmark Action Comics No. 900, which was released on Wednesday, Superman decides he has to stand for something bigger and he renounces his United States citizenship.

headline: Russia: 10 Militants Said to Be Killed in North Caucasus
text: Russian security forces said on Friday that at least 10 Islamist militants had been killed in a special operation in Russia’s volatile and mostly Muslim North Caucasus region. At least two women were killed in the operation, which was spurred by a shootout between security forces and militants in the village of Progress on the border with the Stavropol Region and the mostly Muslim region of Kabardino-Balkaria, Russia’s Investigative Committee said in a statement. It was the latest in an intensified campaign to eliminate Islamist fighters and their bases in the North Caucasus after a deadly terrorist attack at a Moscow airport in January that was linked to militants there. No one on the side of the security forces was wounded in the operation, officials said.

headline: A Bracing Breath of Spring Air From All Directions
text: FOR many American orchestras, especially those in smaller cities with regional reputations, a concert at Carnegie Hall is only a dream. When such ensembles decide to take the financial risk of renting Carnegie Hall for a concert, their conductors often let their marketing departments talk them into playing it safe. The idea of performing a new work by a hometown composer or Schoenberg’s Five Pieces for Orchestra or an overlooked piece like Prokofiev’s Fifth Piano Concerto is vetoed in favor of a program that will show New York audiences and critics how well the visitors can play Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony or Tchaikovsky’s “Pathétique.” With no real news happening, these concerts often attract negligible audiences and are given a pass by critics.

headline: A Voice Where Romance and Dysfunction Meet
text: “ARE you really going to ask me that?” the composer and vocalist Corey Dargel inquired near the end of a sprawling conversation one recent evening, his measured tone briefly betraying impatience and resignation. What bothered him was being asked how he felt about his constant characterization as an artist whose work concerns bridging the gap between classical and popular music. Though not inaccurate, the description has become convenient shorthand, warding off deeper investigation of his work.

headline: Finland Turns to the Right. Is France Next?

Shorto notes that these kinds of nationalist, anti-immigration political groups are back on the rise not just in France but also across Europe, and he describes how Marine Le Pen is trying to reconcile her mainstream ambitions for the party with its extremist history.

Or at least that’s what app developers claim they’ll do — our columnist, Joshua Brustein, will be putting them to the test every other week.

headline: The Tina Fey Subliminal Effect

Gross asked Fey about her time writing for “Saturday Night Live” and which guest hosts she particularly liked. Fey talked about how much she enjoyed John McCain when he was on the show in the early 2000s. In 2004, Life magazine photographed the two of them together in Washington for a get-out-the-vote cover.

headline: The Society of Surfaces

I generally gave a positive answer (Facebook supplements friendship, it doesn’t supplant it) while adding that what matters are the qualities the user brings to Facebook, not the technology itself.

headline: The Novel as Puzzle
text: Some books beg to be interpreted. Built for close scrutiny, they invite critical strategies — and almost abandon narrative pleasure. Think of the reader who, in 1853, was the first to crack “Bartleby, the Scrivener,” turning page after page, flipping back, then ahead, then back again, hoping for some insight into that pallid Wall Street copyist. Or think of the reader who first encountered the opening of “The Sound and the Fury”: “Through the fence, between the curling flower spaces, I could see them hitting.” By the end of Faulkner’s first page, that reader surely wondered if there had been some problem at the printing press. Could the pages have been scrambled? Neither of those readers had the blasé contemporary comfort of classifying such work as postmodern, post-postmodern, image fiction, metafiction, experimental or millennial. The text itself held all the answers, if there were any answers.

headline: The King’s Men, After the American Revolution
text: Only a tiny fraction of the books written on the American Revolution are devoted to the loyalists — the residents of the 13 colonies who chose to leave their homes rather than become citizens of the new republic. Such a nation-bound approach to the writing of American history implies that the lives of those who left were not significant. Yet they were, and Maya Jasanoff, who teaches history at Harvard, has provided a richly informative account of those who made the choice to embrace imperial Britain. As earlier historians of the Revolution have pointed out, the loyalists tended to have strong connections to the imperial administration, belong to the Anglican Church and possess close business or family ties to Britain. But not all who left fitted such a profile. Escaped slaves had obvious reason to depart, and so did those whose property was confiscated by the revolutionaries. Most pervasively, of course, the loyalists shared a loyalty to the king.

headline: Lost in the Meritocracy
text: In June 2008, The Atlantic published an essay by an adjunct instructor of English, identified only as “Professor X,” whose job filled him with despair. Although the courses he taught were introductory, success was beyond many of his students, who, he wrote, were “in some cases barely literate.” X found giving F’s to be excruciating — “I am the man who has to lower the hammer,” he lamented — in part because he identified with his older students, who seemed to have lost their way in their careers much as X himself had.

headline: Why the North Fought the Civil War
text: Among the enduring mysteries of the American Civil War is why millions of Northerners were willing to fight to preserve the nation’s unity. It is not difficult to understand why the Southern states seceded in 1860 and 1861. As the Confederacy’s founders explained ad infinitum, they feared that Abraham Lincoln’s election as president placed the future of slavery in jeopardy. But why did so few Northerners echo the refrain of Horace Greeley, the editor of The New York Tribune: “Erring sisters, go in peace”?

headline: How Writers Build the Brand
text: As every author knows, writing a book is the easy part these days. It’s when the publication date looms that we have to roll up our sleeves and tackle the real literary labor: rabid self-promotion. For weeks beforehand, we are compelled to bombard every friend, relative and vague acquaintance with creative e-mails and Facebook alerts, polish up our Web sites with suspiciously youthful author photos, and, in an orgy of blogs, tweets and YouTube trailers, attempt to inform an already inundated world of our every reading, signing, review, interview and (well, one can dream!) TV ­appearance.

headline: Inside the List
text: LIBERTY BELLS: It’s only a few weeks since Barack Obama declared his candidacy for re-election, and already the right is winning the best-seller list. “Liberty Defined: 50 Essential Issues That Affect Our Freedom,” the latest from Ron Paul, lands at No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Jesse Ventura’s “63 Documents the Government Doesn’t Want You to Read” is at No. 6. And Andrew Breitbart storms to No. 14 with “Righteous Indignation: Excuse Me While I Save the World!” In a recent interview with “The O’Reilly Factor,” Breitbart — the gadfly proprietor of the Web sites Big Government, Big Journalism, Big Hollywood and Big Peace (which has called for Congressional hearings into “the religion of peace”) — exhorted the dull but serious Republican contenders to neutralize Donald Trump before it’s too late. “Celebrity is everything in this country,” Breitbart said. “And if these guys don’t learn how to play the media the way that Barack Obama played the media last election cycle and the way that Donald Trump is playing the election cycle, we’re going to probably get a celebrity candidate.” Shirley MacLaine in 2012? Her latest memoir, “I’m Over All That,” is floating above the fray at No. 5.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Paperback Row
text: TRUE COMPASS: A Memoir,  by Edward M. Kennedy (Twelve, $16.99.) In this affecting autobiography, Kennedy (1932-2009) illuminates his personal and public life. He lovingly recalls his father, Joseph P. Kennedy (Edward was the youngest and most underestimated of the family’s nine children), and ruminates about Chappaquiddick (which “haunts me every day of my life”) and his crusades for health care and civil rights during his 47-year grind in the Senate.

headline: Oscar Wild
text: More dancing queen than demure, the Times Square, Oscar de la Renta’s new metallic-print lamé, crystal-studded double platform sandal ($1,595), marks a revamp of the designer’s footwear business. While Mr. de la Renta hasn’t abandoned the ladylike kitten heels and pretty pumps his mature customers have come to expect, his latest collection is peppered with the kind of sky-high satin stilettos and sexy platforms his younger fans have been clamoring for. Another sign of the youthquake at the atelier: the designer has just reintroduced his classic fragrance, Esprit d’Oscar, with fresh, zingy notes that are sure to seduce his ladies in waiting. Go to oscardelatrenta.com.

headline: A Weekend in Vienna, Austria
text: Where museum-worthy beauty may once have felt untouchable, there is a palpable sense of a city loosening up.

headline: Janet Malcolm’s Cross-Examinations
text: Two decades ago, Janet Malcolm published “The Journalist and the Murderer,” her classic story of the story of a murder trial. Her subject was the relationship between the writer Joe McGinniss and the Army doctor Jeff­rey MacDonald, who gave McGinniss full access to his defense team when he stood trial for the death of his wife and children — and then discovered that over years of apparent friendship, McGinniss was writing a future best seller portraying MacDonald as a psychopathic killer. In her brilliant dissection of this betrayal, Malcolm exposed the “morally indefensible” nature of the work of her journalistic tribe.

headline: Francine Prose’s Immigrant Novel
text: The great grinning tradition of American satire has always been healthy because this confounding country provides an abundance of jaw-dropping moments every day, moments that don’t need rewriting or amplification to reveal their comic craziness. All you need is the ability to see them and then present them plainly, as if you were born yesterday, with nothing but big eyes and a sense of right and wrong. O.K., maybe born the day before yesterday and in Albania, but still with that sense of right and wrong. Francine Prose has just such a sharp protagonist in her wry novel, “My New American Life,” a book that brims with smart surprises.

headline: The Berlin Scene
text: Visit the chic restaurants and museums, both traditional and eccentric, in what could be Europe's most cultured city.

headline: A History of Protest Songs
text: What is protest music? In April 1966, Bob Dylan arrived in Stockholm as part of his controversial “electric” world tour, and a local interviewer asked him why he was no longer writing and performing protest songs. Dylan, irritated and more than a little out of it, objected to the question’s premise and called one of his new rock ’n’ roll compositions the very height of protest music: “Very, very protesty. And, uh, one of the protestiest of all things I ever protested against in my protest years.”

headline: Retreating From a Ruptured Marriage
text: One little word — “pause” — sets off the chain of events in which Mia Fredricksen, the 55-year-old poet and professor who narrates Siri Hust­vedt’s fifth novel, retreats for the summer to the “backwater” Minnesota town where she grew up. Her husband, a neuroscientist named Boris Izcovich, has asked for a “pause” in their marriage so he can take up with a younger colleague, “a woman with whom he had no past.” After a short, agonizing stay in a psychiatric ward, Mia decamps from her Brooklyn apartment to tiny Bonden, seeing no choice but to wait out the “cruel crack of hope” in her husband’s request. There she finds herself immersed, somewhat accidentally, in an all-female world that includes her mother’s five lively geriatric friends, the seven adolescent members of a poetry workshop and the young mother next door, whose husband travels often for work. Over the course of the summer, Mia confronts, with the help of phone sessions with her (female) therapist, her own history as a willing second-class citizen, “a scribbler of the stolen interval” who “hadn’t fought for myself.” Along the way, she re-examines everything she’s believed about the differences between men and women and the possibility of married love.

headline: The Nanny at the Wedding
text: I didn’t see her in any of the photos of the celebrities and family members entering Westminster Abbey this morning, but somewhere in that crowd was Tiggy Pettifer, formerly Tiggy Legge-Bourke, William’s long-ago nanny. I did see countless photos of her son — 8-year-old Tom Pettifer, who was one of those scarlet-clad pageboys.

headline: Jennifer Bartlett’s Epic ‘Rhapsody’ Back on View at the Modern
text: “Rhapsody,” Jennifer Bartlett’s epic polymorphous post-painting painting in nearly 1,000 parts is once again on view at the Museum of Modern Art, wrapped around three long walls and looking tailor-made for the museum’s giant atrium. The work was first shown here five years ago, as part of an exhibition of works given to the Modern by the collector Edward R. Broida. At that time, the piece’s appearance was an early indication that the atrium might serve as something other than a large, alienating event space.

headline: ‘The Office’ Helps NBC, but Can’t Save It
text: As Michael Scott (Steve Carell) said goodbye on “The Office” on Thursday, the NBC sitcom delivered Thursday night’s second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, falling behind “American Idol” on Fox. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Office” drew approximately 8.3 million viewers from 9 to 9:53 p.m., ending just short of the hour and the start of an extended version of “Parks and Recreation” (4.6 million). Although ratings for “The Office” were the highest since January, NBC still lagged behind the other networks. It was a distant fourth place for the night in total viewers, garnering just 4 million for “30 Rock” at 10:30 p.m. and 3.6 million for “Community” at 8.

headline: Libyan Forces Chase Rebel Convoy Into Tunisia, a Rebel Fighter Says

headline: Tracking Swine Flu Cases Worldwide

headline: Letters: Getting VAT Refunds
text: To the Editor: Regarding “When the VAT Refund is Worth Your Time” (Practical Traveler, April 17): The way the system works in England (I’m a shopkeeper in London) is that the onus is on retailers to make the refund, but in order to do so they must receive the relevant form back from the customer once it has been stamped by Customs.

headline: The King Yin Lei Mansion in Hong Kong Is Saved
text: A CHINESE mansion in Hong Kong that was defaced by its owner with an eye to knocking it down is instead opening its doors to the public for the first time, after a multimillion-dollar restoration. It is one of a handful of historic homes in this city that have been spared destruction.

headline: In Virginia, Touring Lesser-Known Civil War Sites
text: APRIL 12 was the 150th anniversary of the attack on Fort Sumter, which ignited the Civil War. Over the next four years, Fort Sumter, as well as Fredericksburg, Manassas and other major Civil War battlefields, will see heavy foot traffic. Gettysburg alone is expecting more than four million visitors in 2013, the 150th anniversary of that battle and the Gettysburg Address.

headline: A New Act for Manchester
text: A COUPLE of decades ago, if you were visiting Manchester you were probably there for business, or perhaps because of familial commitments. But while staggering unemployment and urban decay didn’t inspire much in the way of tourism to this post-industrial English city, it did inspire a movement of disaffected youth whose music still resonates. Indeed, while the grim years that inspired the depressive romanticism of bands like Joy Division and the Smiths have made way for large-scale urban development, Manchester’s prolific musical energy hasn’t dissipated.

headline: Restaurant Review: Spring Restaurant, in Paris
text: For a while there, Daniel Rose had a pretty sweet gig. Spring, the young Chicago-born chef’s restaurant in the Ninth Arrondissement of Paris, was booked months in advance. A darling of the press, he was also the dauphin of his tiny open kitchen, which allowed him to chat with his 16 diners as he prepared the market-driven menu on his own slightly disorganized time. Your appetizer might have landed around bedtime, but you felt lucky to be there. (And you were.)

headline: In a Quiet Corner of Italy ... Trieste
text: A MEDIUM-SIZE seaport teetering on the edge of what we recognize as Italy, Trieste is a mysterious and puzzling place. Its iconic central square, the Piazza dell’Unità d’Italia, bounded on three sides by comically pompous 18th- and 19th-century buildings, most of them decorated like big, boxy wedding cakes, is wide open to the Adriatic, as though the ever-changing seascape were an entertainment staged for the city’s benefit. This vast, glorious piazza promises all sorts of civic delights, but in fact it’s one of the few immediately gratifying spots in Trieste. The rest takes time — exactly what most of us are unwilling to give up.

headline: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
text: ON April 3, along with the essay by Paul Theroux titled “Why We Travel,” readers were asked to submit essays of their own to answer this question. Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. We will publish 10 online; in the meantime, here are four that illustrate the vast range of our readers’ experiences. Thanks to everyone who responded; it was a pleasure to read of your travels. The Editors

headline: Video of Syrian Forces Firing on Protesters

headline: Cheaper Treatment for Macular Degeneration

headline: Oh, Kahuna, What Became of That Endless Summer?
text: CALIFORNIA has fallen on grim economic times, but there was a period not long ago when, in popular culture at least, the Golden State seemed like the best idea America had ever had. In the 1950s and ’60s, even with the Gold Rush a century past, California still had its sand and its sun and its surf to beckon the hopeful westward, and of course it had the movies too, on screens as big — and sometimes as loud — as giant waves. After the gloom and horror of the Second World War and in the midst of the cold war’s nagging anxieties, all those bright blue skies and that warm Pacific water and that clean, soft, shimmery sand looked mighty inviting. “Catch a wave,” the Beach Boys sang, “and you’re be sittin’ on top of the world.” They sounded as if they meant it.

headline: What Was Condoleezza Rice Playing on ’30 Rock’?
text: Of the many bizarre plot lines running through last night’s episode of “30 Rock,” Condoleezza Rice’s sly cameo as the ex-girlfriend of Alec Baldwin’s character, Jack Donaghy, was by far the highlight. In the scene, shown above, Ms. Rice, a former secretary of state and classically trained pianist, challenged Mr. Baldwin, a Lincoln Center regular himself, to a musical face-off. (Mr. Baldwin does not actually perform in the episode.) We asked Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The Times, who interviewed Ms. Rice about her chamber music experience in a profile in 2005, to identify the pieces. “They are all by Mozart,” he said. “The first is the opening of the third movement, the Rondo, from the Piano Quartet in G minor. The second is the opening of the first movement, the Allegro, of that same Piano Quartet in G minor. The third, and this gets complicated, is the slow movement, the Romanze, of the Piano Concerto No. 20 in D minor, not the opening of the movement, but the beginning of the fast middle section of that movement. Whew.” For insiders, Mr. Tommasini said, “the joke is the snippets of pieces played are not at all pieces for flute.” He added, “He tried to match her playing this music on the solo flute, an unfair match.”

headline: Fox Postpones Animated Comedies With Hurricane Story Line
text: Though the animated Fox comedies “Family Guy,” “The Cleveland Show” and “American Dad” are occasionally known for courting controversy, the network has decided to hold off on broadcasting episodes of those shows that were too close to current events for comfort. Fox was planning on Sunday to show new installments of those series with an interconnected story line about a hurricane on the Eastern Seaboard. These episodes were planned several months ago, before the recent storms that have killed nearly 300 people in the South. But on Friday, Fox said in a brief statement, “In light of the recent storms that have affected the nation, Fox has decided to postpone the crossover episodes of ‘Family Guy,’ ‘American Dad’ and ‘The Cleveland Show’ that were originally scheduled to air this Sunday.” A spokeswoman for the network said these episodes will instead be shown next season.

headline: Needle Work
text: Building a first-class art collection takes a lot of time and a lot of money, but the latest show at the Berlin gallery Arratia Beer, “As Long As It Lasts…,” demands a whole other level of commitment from its prospective buyers. The curators, Josée Lepage and Aric Chen (who has written for The Times), and the gallery have created a pop-up tattoo parlor, engaging one of the city’s best tattoo artists, Sarah Bolen from AKA Berlin, and offering designs from a diverse group of artists and designers, including heavyweights like Lawrence Weiner and Wim Delvoye, as well as fashion favorites like the architect Peter Marino and the German conceptual pranksters Bless. One of the most compelling designs comes courtesy of Olaf Nicolai, who suggests that collectors mark the initials of someone they love or hate using his codified variation on the alphabet. In designing his alphabet, Nicolai says that he “found [a] minimalistic style more interesting,” which didn’t function “like a billboard.” (In other words, you’re out of luck if you’re looking for hearts pierced by daggers or busty mermaids.) His design emphasizes “not just information, but also communication. You have to ask the person [what the tattoo means] if you want to understand it.”

headline: A Journey Into the Past, Drinks Included
text: It was surely one of the great scientific adventures of the modern age. For several years in the middle of the last decade, a group of eminent climate scientists fell under the patronage of a billionaire philanthropist named Gary Comer, who turned his luxury yacht into a scientific platform for exploring the Arctic. Spending Mr. Comer’s money and riding in planes and helicopters that he procured, the researchers managed in just a few years to turn up intriguing new evidence about the potential for abrupt climate change.

headline: Biography of Royal Newlyweds Due May 17
text: Andrew Morton, who has written biographies of Diana, Princess of Wales, Monica Lewinsky and Tom Cruise, has turned to a familiar subject for his next book: the newly wedded royal couple Prince William and the former Kate Middleton. St. Martin’s Press said on Friday that it would publish “William & Catherine: Their Story” on May 17, promising that Mr. Morton will tell “the full story” of the couple, including their time at university together, the prince’s proposal in Kenya and the wedding itself, with all its pomp and circumstance. “I have drawn on 30 years of experience covering the royal family to bring perspective and insight into the life of a young man I have watched develop from a toddler and schoolboy into a soldier — just as I have tried to discover more about his bride,” Mr. Morton said in a statement. The book is not an authorized biography, however, and Mr. Morton did not interview William or the Duchess of Cambridge, as she is now known.

headline: Cooking Lamb With (Shh) Anchovies

They act as flavor enhancers, bringing out the character of the other ingredients while adding a salty, complex nuance but with none of the fishiness that the anchovy-averse might expect.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making Notes in iBooks
text: Like other e-book readers, the iBooks app for the iPad (and iPhone or iPod Touch) allows you to make margin notes inside digital books. To make a note in an open iBooks file, press down on the iPad’s screen to select the word or phrase you want to annotate. In the menu bar that appears above your selected text, tap the Note button to create a digital sticky note and use the iPad keyboard to type in your thoughts. When you tap the text behind the note, the note file shrinks to a small square on the edge of the book’s page, near the highlighted text you originally selected. Tap the shrunken note to expand it so you can review your annotations.
