text: BUENOS AIRES — A former member of the Chilean secret police who was involved in killing a former Chilean army chief during that country’s dictatorship was found stabbed to death in his apartment in Argentina, Argentine officials said Friday.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Tulips in the Netherlands, BP’s earnings, trucking’s role in China’s export industry, rising fuel prices and more.

headline: Wind Power vs. Nuclear
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pastor Witherspoon Goes to War
text: Pastor Dwight Witherspoon burned with passion for God and country as he preached his farewell sermon to a flock of the faithful on April 30, 1861. The 25-year-old clergyman spoke on a Bible chapter and verse appropriate to the occasion: Psalm 20:7, “Some trust in chariots, and some in horses; but we will remember the name of the LORD our God.” Fittingly, after the sermon he left the church and joined a company of North Mississippi farm boys and students preparing to go to war.

headline: Immigration Opponent Withdraws From Group
text: WASHINGTON — On this much, both sides agree: John Tanton, the provocative architect of a national movement to reduce immigration, has quietly left the board of the group he started and helped guide for 32 years.

headline: Don’t Worry, Census Says, but the U.S. Is Shrinking
text: This land is still your land, pretty much the way it was for most Americans in 1940 when Woody Guthrie immortalized the gamut of the United States, from California to the New York Island and all the redwood forests, diamond deserts, wheat fields and golden valleys in between.

headline: As League Starts and Stops, Draft Picks Keep Coming
text: The second day of the strangest draft in N.F.L. history continued with the same patterns as the first. Fans showered Commissioner Roger Goodell with boos. Quarterbacks went flying off the board. Da’Quan Bowers and Ryan Mallett continued their waits, with Tampa Bay landing Bowers late and Mallett headed to New England to apprentice under Tom Brady.

headline: Father and Son, Bunking in G Block
text: SCOTT PETERS and his father, Bernard, eat dinner together at night, then watch bowling or classic boxing matches on television together into the evening. They have an extremely close relationship: They have seen each other for at least part of nearly every one of the last 5,455 days. Every night, they sleep together in an 8-by-12-foot room, where the alarm bell rings in the morning but also at 10:30 p.m., when the guards turn off the lights in G Block, at the Elmira Correctional Facility.

headline: China: Fears of Crackdown on Music Events
text: The cancellation of a music festival this weekend in Suzhou has some musicians and festival organizers fearing they may be swept up in the government crackdown on dissent. Organizers of the Strawberry music festival said this week that the event was canceled because of recent rainstorms. But artists have speculated that it was canceled because of official pressure after the name of a detained artist, Ai Weiwei, was flashed on a big screen at a music festival last weekend in Jiangsu Province. Days later, Zuoxiao Zuzhou, a rock musician who expressed support for Mr. Ai at that festival and in a newspaper article, was detained by police officers.

headline: Fighting Sex Trafficking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harvard Gives Christie’s Education Plans a Warm Welcome
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Conservatives may see Harvard as the heart of liberal darkness, but on Friday it gave a warm, even enthusiastic reception to Gov. Chris Christie and his ideas on education overhaul.

headline: Russia: 10 Suspects Killed in Caucasus Raid
text: Russian security forces said Friday that at least 10 Islamist militants had been killed in a special operation in the volatile and mostly Muslim North Caucasus region. At least two women were killed in the operation, which was spurred by a shootout between security forces and militants in the village of Progress on the border between the regions of Stavropol and Kabardino-Balkaria, Russia’s Investigative Committee said. It was the latest raid in a campaign to eliminate Islamist fighters and their bases in the North Caucasus after a deadly terrorist attack at a Moscow airport in January that was linked to militants there.

headline: Landmarks Are Called a Hardship, Setting Off a Fight
text: A landmark has an aura of permanence about it. So it is a fair bet most New Yorkers believe that if their building has been declared a landmark, it will remain untouchable, like the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty.

headline: Ex-Journeyman Carves Out Role as Top Slugger
text: Paul Lehner was a first baseman and outfielder for seven major league seasons after World War II. He went by the nicknames of Peanuts or Gulliver, presumably for his travels. Lehner bounced to four teams in 1951, playing no more than 23 games with any of them. A year later his career was over.

headline: Braves Are Hit Twice by Off-Field Matters
text: ATLANTA — Frank Wren could have done without the drama. Wren, the Atlanta Braves’ general manager, had watched his slightly remodeled and upgraded team go 6-4 on a recent West Coast trip and batter two imposing pitching staffs in San Francisco and San Diego.

headline: As the Careless Order a Latte, Thieves Grab Something to Go
text: Distraction and extraction. These are the skills, timeless, of thousands of thieves who work in New York, without a weapon and without attracting notice.

headline: Concrete Farm Grows Chard (Callaloo, Too)
text: We here at the Incompetent Gardeners Association of Greater New York can only dream of making a patch of land look as good as the Hoyt Street Garden did last Sunday. The garden, a postage-stamp-size community effort at Hoyt Street and Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, had about 250 yellow daffodils in full bloom that day against a pachysandra background, with five benches beckoning. The word “oasis” certainly came to mind.

headline: Memories Lost to a Whirlwind Alight on Facebook to Be Claimed
text: The tornado that killed Emily Washburn’s grandfather this week also destroyed his Mississippi home, leaving his family with nothing to remember him by — until a picture of him holding the dog he loved surfaced on Facebook, posted by a woman who found it in her office parking lot, 175 miles away in Tennessee.

headline: Girardi Shuffles Order Against Blue Jays’ Romero, Leaving Out Posada
text: Six of Jorge Posada’s nine hits have landed over the fence, and for a time those home runs somewhat obscured a season-long funk. But now that he has sunk deeper into his slump, Posada can expect more frequent days off as Manager Joe Girardi rotates his designated hitters during the Yankees’ stretch of 32 games in 33 days.

headline: Gift to M.I.T. from Bose Founder Raises Tax Questions
text: The founder of the Bose Corporation, a privately held company that makes high-end audio products, has donated the majority of the company to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the university said Friday.

headline: In Mississippi, Little Town Is Staggered by a Tornado’s Direct Hit
text: SMITHVILLE, Miss. — When Darwin Hathcock, the police chief, saw the funnel cloud beyond the tree line just a couple of miles away, he knew that his town would not be spared.

headline: A Delicacy on Chinatown Plates, but a Killer in Water
text: The walls in the basement of a building in Brooklyn’s Chinatown were whitewashed, and boxes of cleaning supplies were stacked on the red tile floor. But beneath the disinfectant smell, the unmistakable odor of fish lingered as the flimsiest calling card of a former tenant.

headline: Dithering on Redistricting
text: Very quietly — with a lot of the usual stupid Legislature tricks — New York State lawmakers are conspiring to keep their jobs for life.

headline: Not a Political Tool
text: The United Nations’ World Food Program is warning that without more international help, six million people in North Korea — one quarter of the population — may be at serious risk of malnutrition or starvation. A harsh winter, severe flooding and an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease have once again slashed domestic food production, and rising food prices have made imports more costly.

headline: New Jersey Must Return $271 Million Spent on Hudson Tunnel, U.S. Insists
text: The next stop for New Jersey in its debt collection fight with the federal government may be federal court.

headline: Podcast: The Fed, Law Schools and Black Swans
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, held the first news conference this week in what is to become a regular event, and he used the occasion to explain some of the constraints under which the central bank is now operating.

headline: Co-Victims Against the Death Penalty
text: As the country has increasingly turned against capital punishment as barbaric and horrifyingly prone to legal abuses, defenders are pointing to the emotional needs of the families of murder victims — “co-victims” to those who study crime — as justification. Many family members, however, have said they want no part of that.

headline: Learning to be a ‘Country Boy’
text: At the age of 6, Benjamin Nwachukwu left his home in the South Bronx and took a bus to New Hampshire, to a place, he thought, called Friendly Town. He would later learn that the town was Bradford and Friendly Town was the name of the Fresh Air Fund program that sponsored his trip. But the term would prove fitting.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 29, 2011

headline: The Blank Line on Bryant’s Playoff Résumé
text: Kobe Bryant has carved his way to the N.B.A. championship every imaginable way — through sweeps and seven-game series, in shootouts and defensive struggles, with and without Shaquille O’Neal. The only thing he has not done is beat the Dallas Mavericks. Or, for that matter, even seen them in the postseason.

headline: Tornado Puts an End to a University’s School Year
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — From the crimson flags in store windows to the hotels that swell on football weekends, this city lives and breathes the University of Alabama. So when a tornado tore through Tuscaloosa this week — killing at least 36 and leaving hundreds homeless a few miles from campus — shock replaced the excitement that was building for graduation.

headline: A System to Speed Up Forecasting Tornadoes
text: Governments in the Dallas-Fort Worth region are nearing a deal that would make it the first urban area to test a new approach to weather forecasting.

headline: From Playoffs to Rumor Mill
text: In this Twitter-accelerated, agent-fueled, speculation-soaked era, when next year’s issues become today’s headlines, no N.B.A. star can end the season without some version of the question: So, are you leaving?

headline: In Florida, G.O.P. Help for Unions
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — When State Senator John Thrasher introduced a bill to weaken the political clout of Florida’s public employee unions, he expected that it would pass fairly easily, not least because Republicans held 28 of the Senate’s 40 seats.

headline: Massachusetts House Seeks to Limit Collective Bargaining
text: BOSTON — Union leaders in this traditionally labor-friendly state are fuming over a plan passed by the Massachusetts House of Representatives this week to curtail bargaining rights for municipal workers, a highly unusual move by Democratic lawmakers.

headline: Guests of Honor
text: Rick Santorum Former senator from Pennsylvania; attended a house party at Ovide Lamontagne’s house on Jan. 11.

headline: What the Wind Carried Away
text: Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Testimony on Alcohol Is Heard in Rape Case
text: The woman who claims she was raped by a police officer may have had a blood-alcohol level on the night of the episode that was as much as four times the legal limit for driving in New York State, a toxicologist testified on Friday.

headline: Saturday: Toward der Orient
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The first indication that we were in for something interesting was at 17 Across: “A cowboy may have a big one.” Ten letters, and this isn’t The Onion, so the answer must be BELT BUCKLE. I liked the fact that it crosses BUCKAROO.

headline: Facing Game’s Top Arms, Mets Are Hoping for the Best
text: PHILADELPHIA — During the Mets’ recent six-game winning streak, they faced J. A. Happ, Joe Saunders, Barry Enright, Armando Galarraga, Jordan Zimmerman and Tom Gorzelanny, six starting pitchers with a combined record of just seven games over .500 (151-144). Four of those pitchers have career losing records, and none them are household names.

headline: Jury Rejects Missouri Hospitals’ Case Against Tobacco Firms
text: Tobacco companies are not liable to Missouri hospitals for money spent on patients with smoking-related illnesses who could not pay their medical bills, a St. Louis jury said.

headline: Chevron Profit Rises as Unrest Lifts Oil Prices
text: The Chevron Corporation said Friday that its first-quarter profit rose 36 percent as economic growth and supply disruptions drove crude prices above $100 a barrel.

headline: Stock Cars and Chicken Wings
text: S. E. Cupp (she dumped the “Sarah Elizabeth” 10 years ago for a gender-free byline) is a conservative commentator, columnist and author whose second book, “Losing Our Religion: The Liberal Media’s Attack on Christianity,” was released last month in paperback. Ms. Cupp, a professed atheist with a master’s degree with a concentration in religious studies from the Gallatin School of Individualized Study at New York University, writes an online column for The Daily News and hosts a program on Glenn Beck’s Mercury Radio Arts. She is 32 and lives in the financial district. Her three Sunday essentials are Nascar, Buffalo wings and Bravo.

headline: Indiana Bill Cuts Funds for Clinics for Women
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana said Friday that he would sign a bill cutting off Medicaid financing for Planned Parenthood, a move that lawmakers in several states have begun pondering as a new approach in the battle over abortion. Indiana becomes the first state to go forward.

headline: The Party’s Over for Buffett
text: It’s D-Day for the World’s Greatest Investor.

headline: This Town Is Big Enough for Both of Us
text: MY crosstown self, as I suppose he could be called, was — in the endlessly exotic manner of Manhattan — a right-wing nudist socialite. Of course, I didn’t know that when the phone calls first began.

headline: After Arrest, Possible Favored Treatment of Bronx Prosecutor Was Not Investigated
text: As police officers came upon an apparently drunken Bronx prosecutor standing beside a three-car accident on the Major Deegan Expressway last summer, she told them she would “get out of this,” as she had before, according to a person briefed on her statements to the police.

headline: Total Acquires 60% of a Solar Panel Maker
text: Total SA, the European oil producer, agreed to buy as much as 60 percent of the SunPower Corporation for $1.38 billion, taking advantage of increased global interest in renewable energy. SunPower, a solar panel maker based in San Jose, Calif., described the acquisition price of $23.25 a share as a “friendly tender offer” in a statement after the close of regular trading on Thursday. SunPower’s stock rose $5.62, or 36 percent, to $21.40 a share on Friday. “The fact that a global oil and gas giant like Total has made such a significant investment in a solar company is extremely encouraging for the entire solar industry,” said Shawn Qu, the chief executive and founder of the China-based Canadian Solar. “Total’s investment demonstrates that solar is really coming into its own as a viable energy market, and traditional energy conglomerates want to be part of that burgeoning growth.”

headline: Doubts About Schools Consultant Charged in $3.6 Million Fraud Dated to ’02
text: Sometime in 2002, a manager at I.B.M., which was working on a large project to wire New York City schools for the Internet, noticed something unusual about payments the company was making for some workers.

headline: In Second Round, Giants Get First-Round Potential
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the second night of the draft, the Giants again received more value than their position on the board, taking defensive tackle Marvin Austin of North Carolina with the 52nd pick.

headline: Silliness and Sleight of Hand
text: President Obama buckled.

headline: Death Toll From Storm Rises
text: On Friday, President Obama went to Tuscaloosa, Ala., to witness the destruction wrought by this week’s monstrous storms.

headline: New Jersey Native Says He’s Thrilled to Join Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Muhammad Wilkerson, the defensive lineman who was the Jets’ first-round draft choice Thursday, was not academically eligible to play college football after he graduated from high school in Linden, N.J., so he spent a year at Hargrave Military Academy in Virginia.

headline: Jose Bautista Keeps Rolling
text: C.J. Nitkowski played with Jose Bautista for a few weeks in 2006, with Class AAA Indianapolis in the Pittsburgh Pirates’ farm system. Bautista, then 25 years old, had 101 at-bats and hit two home runs.

headline: Baseball, Tabloids and the Mad Bomber
text: PETE HAMILL and Jimmy Breslin, who worked with me at The Daily News, were polar opposites in their column-writing routines. Mr. Hamill would sweep into the newsroom, dash off 800 or so words that could be pure poetry, and disappear. Mr. Breslin would amble in after trudging forlornly through some public housing project, stare at his typewriter for hours and pray for any distraction — a telephone headset resting on its cradle usually sufficed — that would justify the belated delivery of his equally poetic prose to the city desk.

headline: Who’s on the Mound Matters Little in Rout
text: PHILADELPHIA — In the days leading to Friday’s game against the Phillies, Mets Manager Terry Collins and his pitching coach, Dan Warthen, had a decision to make about their scheduled starting pitcher, the ailing Mike Pelfrey. Since his previous start April 22, Pelfrey had been battling a stomach illness so severe that he lost 11 pounds.

headline: Michigan: Koran-Burning Pastor Draws a Boisterous Crowd
text: Tensions flared Friday as Terry Jones, the Florida pastor whose burning of a Koran sparked violence in Afghanistan, demonstrated Friday on the steps of City Hall in Dearborn, home to one of the largest Muslim communities in the nation. In rambling remarks over three hours, he mostly spoke against what he called "extremist Muslim influences" in the United States. Dearborn police made three arrests for misdemeanors. The department estimated the crowd at 700 people. Mr. Jones’s comments were often drowned out by the horns of passing cars and the boos and chants of protesters, some of whom carried signs saying, “Terrorist Go Home” and “Leave Us Alone.”

headline: Introducing the Things of Spring
text: Springtime Progress Report: Early this year, we learned that Utah was considering a bill to name a Browning pistol its official state firearm. Meanwhile in Washington, Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey was pushing for a bill that would make it more difficult to sell guns to people on the terror watch list. I am excited to report that one of these pieces of legislation finally has been passed into law.

headline: Port Authority Police Fire at Car During Pursuit in Holland Tunnel
text: Officers from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pursued a car into the Holland Tunnel on Friday night and opened fire when the driver refused to stop, the authorities said.

headline: In Position to Put Away Blue Jays, Yankees Throw Away Their Chance
text: It being a Friday night and all, a fair amount of children were milling about Yankee Stadium to watch the Yankees play Toronto, and the timing was fortuitous. There were plenty of moments that held great instructional value, important lessons for aspiring Mark Teixeiras and Mariano Riveras. The most incisive example occurred in the sixth inning, a pivotal sequence of events that by night’s end played as much of a role in the Yankees’ 5-3 loss as their persistent failures to convert scoring opportunities into runs.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Birtherism Racism?
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate whether the "birther" conspiracy theory is fueled by racism.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The World This Week
text: A discussion of Friday's royal wedding.

headline: Bob McDonnell, the Entire Conversation
text: Michael D. Shear's entire conversation with the Virginia Governor.

headline: Photo Replay: April 29
text: A view of the day in sports, from cycling in Switzerland to figure skating in Moscow.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Family Relations
text: We are covering the final season of ‘Friday Night Lights’ according to the NBC schedule. We ask that readers who’ve already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section.

headline: ‘Cuomo 2014’ Gifts Announce His Intentions
text: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. — Let it be known: New York’s 2014 gubernatorial race is officially under way.

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Defends Handling of Crisis
text: TOKYO — Japan’s embattled prime minister, Naoto Kan, defended his government’s handling of the nation’s nuclear crisis on Saturday, a day after an adviser resigned during a tearful news conference in which he charged that the government was not adequately protecting the population from radiation.

headline: The Weekend Word: If You Can’t Beat ‘Em…
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Belichick and Ryan Mallett Find Connection
text: Bill Belichick and Ryan Mallett seem to be an odd coupling.

headline: The Fine Print on a Wedding Insurance Policy
text: Wedding bells rang Friday for Prince William and his bride, Kate Middleton. Fireman’s Fund Insurance Company took the opportunity promote its wedding insurance policies by writing a “tongue in cheek” letter to the happy couple.

headline: Survey Says Small-Business Lending Is Surging
text: Some small-business owners will surely disagree, but signs continue to show that more small businesses are seeking — and getting — loans. The latest evidence comes from Greenwich Associates, which does market research for major banks. A survey of small businesses released in April found that 59 percent had applied for a loan within the preceding 12 months, and demand grew with each quarter.

headline: Live Blogging the Berkshire Meeting
text: OMAHA — It is time once again for Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholder meeting, the two-day frenzy of Warren E. Buffett aficionados who have descended here to listen to his latest musings. This meeting promises to be even more interesting than ever, given the controversy over David L. Sokol, whose recent resignation cast a pall over the normally jovial proceedings.

headline: Urban Forager | Dead Nettle, Where Is Thy Sting?
text: I was walking across the College of Staten Island campus recently when I spotted purple dead nettle creeping from out under a log. Then I saw several patches of the plant some yards away.

headline: Qaddafi Is Said to Survive NATO Airstrike That Kills Son
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said he survived an airstrike in Tripoli late Saturday night that killed one of his sons and three grandchildren, in the sharpest intensification yet of the NATO air campaign intended to pressure the Libyan leader from power.

headline: The Next Cruyff? Check Back in 15 Years
text: The club VVV-Venlo may be headed for relegation from the Dutch Eredivisie but it still knows how to attract attention.

headline: For Jeter, Plot Twists in Final Chapters
text: Apparently no question can freeze Derek Jeter like a fastball under the chin, no probe can penetrate his shield without being fouled away like a two-strike slider.

headline: Player’s Dream Job Is Fighter in Uniform
text: LAWTON, Okla. — It was 5:30 a.m., too early even for the birds in this southwest Oklahoma town, when the former Army running back Collin Mooney walked to an open field, lighted by a lone streetlight, about 100 steps from his home. In a ragged gym bag held together by duct tape, he carried equipment like weights and plastic cones.

headline: Government’s Disaster Response Wins Praise
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — It has been the deadliest natural disaster on American soil since Hurricane Katrina. But the government response to the tornadoes that devastated the South last week has, at least in the first few days, drawn little of the searing criticism aimed at federal agencies back in 2005.

headline: Notes on the Evolution of Economic Ignorance
text: Brad DeLong weighs in, not for the first time, on a theme I’ve written about a lot: the way in which modern graduate-level macroeconomics has managed to bury and forget what earlier generations knew, so that what was billed as intellectual progress ended up being, in crucial ways, intellectual regress. DeLong:

headline: Ryan and Heritage
text: Jonathan Bernstein says something I’ve been meaning to say, about the relationship between the Ryan plan and the ludicrous Heritage economic projection.

headline: Amukamara’s Availability for Giants: ‘It Was a Shock’
text: Other teams weren’t necessarily surprised that Nebraska cornerback Prince Amukamara was dropping on the draft board Thursday — some of those teams were the ones passing on him. But the Giants weren’t just surprised; they were stunned. Or shocked might be a better word — see the transcript below, as provided by the Giants.

headline: Bernanke’s Stock Answer
text: A rather technical (but important point) from Bernanke’s press conference. From Floyd Norris’s live blog:

headline: Moderation Update
text: I’ve actually been very permissive in comment moderation; I’ve used the “Attack on author” criterion for rejecting a comment very rarely, if ever.

headline: Syrian Forces Seize Mosque That Was Uprising’s Symbol
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Backed by tanks, helicopters and snipers, the Syrian military seized a landmark mosque that had become a center of protests in the besieged southern town of Dara’a on Saturday, killing at least six people in an escalation of a weeklong crackdown, residents and activists said.

headline: Losing Everything, Except What Really Matters
text: COTTONDALE, Ala.

headline: Separating Free Speech From Hate in South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — It seemed like a throwback to the days when a white minority ruled South Africa. Inside a colonial-era courthouse that was once a stage for the political trials of anti-apartheid activists, a white lawyer in robes and frilly bib accused a black leader of being a Communist and fomenting hatred of whites.

headline: Free Speech Controversy in South Africa
text: The Times's Celia Dugger looks at the hate speech trial of A.N.C. youth leader Julius Malema, who has been using controversial former anti-apartheid songs to spur political change.

headline: Protests in Syria
text: Protests emerge from many corners of Syria’s diverse population.

headline: Revisions to the Class Act?
text: In The Times on Saturday, Ron Lieber, Your Money columnist, revisits the Class Act, the government insurance program for long-term care included in the landmark health care law passed last year. Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, is considering ways to make the program, which has not yet begun, both affordable and actuarially sound — no small task. Writes Mr. Lieber:

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Split Decisions don’t come along too often, but when they do, they always surprise me. On the surface they look simple: just fill in the blanks and make words that cross. How hard could it be?

headline: Graham Motion: The Horseman as Homebody
text: ELKTON, Md. — He was late for his morning coffee and missed Jane and Marcus before they went to school. Bentley and Sasha, a couple of Labradors, were waiting at the door and his wife, Anita, was in the kitchen. Six minutes away at a European-style equine oasis, the Herringswell Stable was humming along. Graham Motion is a horse trainer, a stay-at-home one.

headline: Football’s Absolute Power Corrupts Colleges Absolutely
text: When Stanley McClover went college shopping, he was handed money by several big-time football factories. And Ohio State, he contended, introduced him to female escorts with the rather explicit suggestion that they were available.

headline: Wherever James Goes, The Celtics Are There
text: LeBron James has been wearing the villain’s mask for nine months, long enough to absorb the persona, perfect his wicked sneer and prepare for a final showdown with his archenemy.

headline: Who Benefits From Bubbles?
text: One of the more interesting documents published by the IRS — I know, I know, not the hardest criterion in the world — is its report on the income and taxes of the top 400 taxpayers (pdf). A lot of attention gets focused, rightly, on the remarkably low average tax rate these people pay — less than 17 percent in 2007, the lowest on record.

headline: Taliban Say Offensive Will Begin Sunday
text: KABUL — The Taliban announced that the insurgent group’s spring fighting season would begin officially across Afghanistan on Sunday in an unusual news statement that aimed to project an image of strength and concern for civilians, even as NATO warned the public to expect insurgent efforts to launch a major attack.

headline: College Sports and the Title IX Debate
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Hotel Group’s Program to Welcome Gay Guests
text: The Preferred Hotel Group, made up of more than 800 independently owned properties worldwide, is rolling out a program to help its members welcome gay guests.

headline: M.L.S. Must-See TV? Absolutely.
text: United States national team supporters eager to keep tabs on the best and brightest American players tend to spend a lot of time looking overseas. Whether it’s to track Clint Dempsey’s amazing season at Fulham or gauge Michael Bradley’s status at Aston Villa or perhaps catch Timmy Chandler’s rising star at Nuremberg, the most zealous fans usually have to turn to — and tune into — matches played in European leagues.

headline: Republicans Are Pursuing a Wider Field for 2012 Race
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Republican leaders, activists and donors, anxious that the party’s initial presidential field could squander a chance to capture grass-roots energy and build a strong case against President Obama at the outset of the 2012 race, are stepping up appeals for additional candidates to jump in, starting with Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana.

headline: Nets Invite Their Rental to Stay for Their Move
text: The Nets are again idle in the postseason. But there are growing indications that they are actively pursuing plans to turn Deron Williams from an expensive rental into a franchise cornerstone before their move to Brooklyn.

headline: A Former Yankee Applies Big-League Lessons at Alabama
text: Andy Phillips was on a recruiting trip Wednesday when tornadoes ravaged his hometown, Tuscaloosa, Ala. Phillips, a former Yankees infielder who is the hitting coach at the University of Alabama, said his family and his players were accounted for. But some players lost everything, he said, and friends told him the campus had been devastated.

headline: Prime Number
text: 1.8: The annual growth rate for the economy in the first quarter of the year. When 2011 began, economists expected growth of about 4 percent. But that was before turmoil in the Middle East drove up oil prices, housing prices fell sharply and winter blizzards closed businesses and delayed construction. Economists expect the economy to pick up later this spring as those problems fade. Investors, meanwhile, were bullish. Corporate earnings propelled the broader stock markets to their highest levels since 2008.

headline: American Ice Dancers Tango to Gold, Nation’s First on World Stage
text: MOSCOW — With a gold medal dangling from his neck, Charlie White was laughing near the sheet of ice where he and Meryl Davis had just made figure-skating history — laughing at the improbable circumstances that accompanied the first world championship by an American ice dancing team.

headline: Killer Fungus Is Gold to Yak Herders
text: On the Tibetan plateau, the roof of the world, a caterpillar fungus is transforming the lives of nomadic yak herders, John Roach reports on National Geographic’s Web site. The fungus takes over the bodies of caterpillar larvae, then shoots up like grass out of the dead insects’ heads. As unappetizing as that may sound, the nutty-tasting fungus is highly valued as an aphrodisiac and for its purported medicinal benefits. Demand has soared in Beijing, Shanghai and other faraway cities.

headline: Eyeing the White House After Service in China
text: BEIJING — The United States defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, did not expect to be greeted with open arms when he arrived in Beijing last January on a mission to defrost relations with the People’s Liberation Army. But neither did he expect the welcome he got: the maiden flight of China’s first stealth fighter, to all appearances a carefully timed and public thumb in the Pentagon’s eye.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: The Dodgers, the Mets and the Commissioner
text: Frank McCourt, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ owner, was seething Wednesday as he argued that Commissioner Bud Selig had improperly seized his team. He had just come from meeting Major League Baseball officials and was aggrieved that he would not be going home with his team back in his hands. As he spoke, Steve Soboroff, the Dodgers’ vice chairman, patted his boss on the back for moral support.

headline: Back Then: 1982
text: Government researchers said last week that about a third of the 150 to 250 leprosy cases that arise each year in the United States result from contact with infected armadillos, which are native to the Southwest. In 1982, Carol Levine wrote in The Times about the role armadillos were playing in developing a leprosy vaccine.

headline: Protesters Demand President’s Ouster in Burkina Faso
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — A whiff of North African-style protest came to this sun-baked sub-Saharan capital on Saturday as about a thousand demonstrators descended on a central square to demand the departure of President Blaise Compaoré, who has held power for 24 years in one of the world’s poorest countries.

headline: Law Students Lose the Grant Game as Schools Win
text: LIKE a lot of other college seniors, Alexandra Leumer got her introduction to the heady and hazardous world of law school scholarships in the form of a letter bearing very good news. The Golden Gate University School of Law in San Francisco had admitted her, the letter stated, and it had awarded her a merit scholarship of $30,000 a year — enough to cover the full cost of tuition.

headline: Fighting Words
text: In a surprise announcement, Fatah and Hamas, the two main Palestinian factions, said they were putting aside years of bitter rivalry to create an interim unity government and hold elections within a year.

headline: In China, Art Is Making a Commercial Statement
text: IT isn’t the familiar Adidas look — that bold and basic three-stripe logo. Instead, it’s a design meant to evoke blowing wind, flowing water and flapping wings.

headline: German Terrorism Arrests Disrupt Qaeda Inquiry
text: KARLSRUHE, Germany — For six months, dozens of German police officers and federal agents had been following and electronically eavesdropping on three young men suspected of planning a bomb attack in the Düsseldorf area, building a case that they felt could tie the men to a wider network of operatives for Al Qaeda. Then, on Thursday, they were suddenly presented with a painful choice.

headline: Needed: A Clearer Crystal Ball
text: THERE were relatively few persuasive warnings during the 1920s that the Great Depression was on its way, and few argued convincingly during the last decade that the most recent economic crisis was near. So it’s easy to conclude that because we didn’t see these events coming, nothing could have been done to prevent them.

headline: A Sidewalk Mr. Fix-It, Now Missing a Few Parts
text: Tossing an empty soda cup between his hardened but unusually clean repairman’s hands, Natividad Zirate, the homeless bicycle doctor of Second Avenue, smiled darkly as he described how the parks department had shut down his bustling sidewalk repair shop this week.

headline: Syrian Businessman Becomes Magnet for Anger and Dissent
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When protests erupted in March in the forlorn Syrian border town of Dara’a, demonstrators burned the president’s portraits, then set ablaze an unlikely target: the local office of the country’s largest mobile phone company, Syriatel, whose owner sits at the nexus of anger and power in a restive country.

headline: Data Privacy, Put to the Test
text: BIG OIL. Big Food. Big Pharma.

headline: Thirteen (Plus) Years of Asparagus
text: I’m making an executive decision: we’re no longer going to call the rectangular array of 12 recipe ideas — like the one in this week’s asparagus column — “matrices.” Instead, we’re going to call them “charts.” The reason for this is that while everyone can pronounce “matrix,” no one can agree on how to pronounce “matrices,” and “matrixes” (another acceptable option, according to my dictionary) doesn’t exactly roll off the tongue, either.

headline: Where to Live to Avoid a Natural Disaster
text: Weather disasters and quakes: who’s most at risk? An attempt to assess a combination of those risks in 379 American metro areas.

headline: For Posey Family, the Highlights Keep on Coming
text: VALDOSTA, Ga. — The last time Samantha Posey spoke with her brother Buster, he lamented that in every interview lately, he had been asked about her. It made her laugh.

headline: A Candidate in Peru Tacks Toward Brazil’s Course
text: LIMA, Peru — In his failed 2006 bid for Peru’s presidency, Ollanta Humala donned red T-shirts, boasted of plans to assert state control over energy resources and blasted opponents for warming to the United States, using elements from the playbook that was then helping propel leftist political allies of Venezuela to electoral victories in Latin America.

headline: The Benefits of Telling the Ugly Truth
text: YOUR stock portfolio has been climbing like a rocket, and you’re beginning to think that your financial adviser is a genius.

headline: Steve Stone’s New Book Reveals Details of the Game
text: Steve Stone wears a ring to commemorate his magical season of 1980, when he captured the American League Cy Young Award and set a Baltimore Orioles record for victories in a season, with 25. But that performance was the exception over 11 workmanlike years.

headline: Grizzlies’ Rise Is Rooted in Much-Criticized Trade
text: Michael Heisley lived in Chicago at the dawn of Michael Jordan’s era. He saw the arena full and the championships celebrated, and he envisioned his own dynasty when he bought the Vancouver Grizzlies in 2000.

headline: Girardi Shuffles the Lineup After a Loss
text: Manager Joe Girardi continued to shuffle his lineup after Friday night’s 5-3 loss to Toronto, in which the Yankees stranded a season-high 11 runners.

headline: 30 Seconds With Jim Brown
text: Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight: football star, lacrosse legend (some consider him the best lacrosse player ever), actor, social activist and more. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him — not by name or face, but by weight, height, years in the league, skill rating and skin color — on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series. The suit was dismissed in district court but is being considered by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Brown, 75, spoke by phone about the case, the lockout and his wearing yet another hat: pole-vaulter.

headline: Order Is Great. It’s Bureaucracy That’s Stifling
No Action on Walsh Is Announced
text: The deadline for picking up Donnie Walsh’s contract option was expected to pass Saturday without any action and without comment from Knicks officials. Still, all signs point to Walsh continuing as team president on a new contract.

headline: No. 1 Over All Doesn’t Assure Success Under Center
text: For all the pertinent and impertinent questions surrounding Cam Newton before the Carolina Panthers chose him No. 1 over all in the three-day grab bag of college talent, the only question now is this: What will he accomplish as an N.F.L. quarterback?

headline: Letters: What Became of Loyalty?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: The Deed to the Data
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alumni Group Has Plan to Track Brain Health of Former Players
text: With Sidney Crosby revealing Friday that he had to curtail his light skating because of the return of concussion symptoms, the question of head trauma in hockey was thrown back into the spotlight.

headline: Be Careful Wishing for the Fed’s End
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, faces a crisis of confidence. He is excoriated on the right for debasing the currency, and blasted on the left for failing to stimulate more than he has. It has gotten so bad that last week Mr. Bernanke, who prefers to discuss monetary policy with erudite professors like himself, submitted to the indignity of a news conference. Among the uninvited was Representative Ron Paul, who is flirting with a presidential run, and who, if he took office in 2013, would like nothing more than to celebrate the Fed’s centennial by ... abolishing it.

headline: Where to Live to Avoid a Natural Disaster
text: More than 300 people were killed last week by monstrous storms that swept through the South. Flattened communities resembled scenes from war zones. “I have never seen devastation like this,” President Obama said Friday after visiting a neighborhood blown apart by a tornado in Tuscaloosa, Ala.

headline: Bearing the Family Torch
text: I’M the 11th generation in our family business, which started in Austria. I grew up in a village called Langkampfen, near our factory there. It was a mountainous area and I skied and snowboarded with my sister and our friends.

headline: My Libya, Your Libya, Our Libya
text: BAYDA, Libya

headline: Call Her the Worrier in Chief
text: I’M the director of care and emergency response at JetBlue Airways. I was the 29th person hired at the airline and have been there for almost 12 years. I’m responsible for developing the airline’s emergency response plan, assembling the response team and training employees to prepare for an accident, or for a crisis like a natural disaster. If something happens, we send out a high-speed alert and have the response team members report to a command center.

headline: Lightning Round With Robert McDonnell
text: Gov. Robert F. McDonnell of Virginia, a Republican, sat down for an interview with The Caucus on Friday, and answered several questions in a Lightning Round. Here are his answers.

headline: The Persistence of Conspiracy Theories
text: No sooner had President Obama released his long-form birth certificate than Orly Taitz, the doyenne of the “birther” movement, found reason to doubt it.

headline: Opt-In Rules Are a Good Start
text: FACEBOOK seems to have finally learned its lesson: Permission is everything.

headline: Drugs in Ozarks Town Infect Even Sheriff’s Dept.
text: ELLSINORE, Mo. — Growing up in the rugged foothills of the Ozarks, Tommy Adams always dreamed of carrying a badge. He realized his wish through grim happenstance: the incumbent sheriff, dogged by rumors of corruption, killed himself weeks before votes were cast, and Mr. Adams slipped past him by a single vote.

headline: The Aging of America, as Opportunity
text: WE all know — and some of us may feel it in our own bones — that the population is aging. Still, a look at the raw numbers of America’s graying can be startling.

headline: The Four Stages of Falling in Love With a Candidate
text: WASHINGTON — With the first debate of the 2012 election just four days away, Republicans have entered what could be thought of as Stage 1 in the cycle of presidential primaries: dissatisfaction.

headline: A Bad Day for Star Third Basemen
text: On the same day the San Francisco Giants lost third baseman Pablo Sandoval for 4-6 weeks with a broken bone in his right wrist, the Washington Nationals revealed that Ryan Zimmerman, who has been on the disabled list since April 12, will miss at least an additional six weeks.

headline: With Liposuction, the Belly Finds What the Thighs Lose
text: The woman’s hips bulged in unsightly saddlebags. Then she had liposuction and, presto, those saddlebags disappeared.

headline: Doctor Focuses on the Minds of the Elderly
text: MIAMI — The Merry Widows, as they call themselves, were blinged out, Florida-style, to celebrate Elayne Weisburd’s 79th birthday at a sprawling community for seniors. Mylar balloons levitated above their table, and sparklers twinkled from a cake.

headline: The Governor Likes Alligators in Only One Size
text: Gov. Rick Scott was praising Florida’s many outdoor pleasures — fishing, hunting, bird-watching — when he let slip that he did not have much fondness for alligators.

headline: Sleeping on the Job
text: To the Editor:

headline: Healthier Food in College
text: To the Editor:

headline: Halladay, With 18 Straight Strikes, Tops Niese
text: PHILADELPHIA — Roy Halladay has made 326 starts in his 14-year major league career, which means that a multitude of cameras, radar guns, charts and eyeballs has been dedicated to observing and dissecting each one of his 34,215 pitches.

headline: Fighting Continues in Libya
text: NATO and the rebels rejected Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s call for a cease-fire and negotiations on Saturday, saying they needed “actions, not words,” and aid ships were prevented from docking in a besieged coastal city while the alliance swept the port for mines.

headline: The Ryan Plan for Medicaid
text: With Washington looking for ways to rein in costly entitlement programs and state governments struggling to balance budgets, conservatives have revived an old nostrum: turning Medicaid into a block grant program.

headline: A Tipping Point for Gay Marriage?
text: WASHINGTON — It’s not every day that a leading law firm fires a client for holding a position so extreme that it may be said to be unworthy of a defense. And it is rarer yet — unheard of, really — when that client is the House of Representatives and the position in question is a federal law.

headline: Mr. Geithner’s Loophole
text: Until recently, the big threats to the Dodd-Frank financial reform law came from Republican lawmakers, who have vowed to derail it, and from banks and their lobbyists, who are determined to retain the status quo that enriched them so well in the years before, and since, the financial crisis. Now, the Obama Treasury Department has joined their ranks.

headline: Some Sunshine for the Campaign Jungle
text: When the Supreme Court legalized a new era of unrestrained corporate campaign spending, the court made a point of upholding disclosure of donors as an alternative safeguard for voters and the democratic process.

headline: Voice of the Derby Steps Down
text: In the theater world it’s called flop sweats. In thoroughbred racing, where Tom Durkin has been the signature voice of the Triple Crown for years, it was his fear of breaking down in the homestretch.

headline: Where China Outpaces America
text: SHANGHAI

headline: The High Cost of Low Teacher Salaries
text: San Francisco

headline: In Search for F.B.I. Director, Administration Seeks a Shared Philosophy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, having settled on his choices for the next leaders of the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, is now turning toward filling a third major national security position: director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: When Bad Things Happen to Do-Good People
text: I’VE not read “Three Cups of Tea,” Greg Mortenson’s best-selling book about his life building schools for Afghan girls, nor “Three Cups of Deceit,” Jon Krakauer’s powder keg of a takedown, which accused Mr. Mortenson of malfeasance and appeared on the Web site Byliner. What interests me is not the details of what happened, but that implicit in the lack of sympathetic hand-wringing over Mr. Mortenson’s exposure is a kind of righteous vindication.

headline: Unsafe at Any Dose
text: Sydney, Australia

headline: Portrait of a Despot
text: I SAT across from President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in his newest palace overlooking Damascus, on a hill at the end of a gently twisting road.

headline: David L. Hackett, Led Efforts on Poverty and Juvenile Crime, Dies at 84
text: David L. Hackett, who led the Kennedy administration’s efforts to stem juvenile crime and helped create a domestic equivalent to the Peace Corps, died on April 23 in Rockville, Md. He was 84 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

headline: A New Measure for Classroom Quality
text: Baltimore

headline: That ’70s Energy Crisis
text: Riverside, Calif.

headline: Portland, Ore., Votes to Rejoin Task Force After Terrorism Scare
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — It has been nearly a decade since the terrorist attacks of 2001 and nearly a decade since this liberal city first established its reluctance to assist in many of the wide-ranging federal terrorism investigations that have followed.

headline: Pawlenty Wants More Opponents (for a Debate)
text: Former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota made a plea on Saturday for more of his likely Republican presidential rivals to join him next week in what was to be the first big debate of the 2012 campaign season — but is now threatening to be a relatively sparsely attended affair.

headline: R.A. Dickey’s Well-Named Arsenal
text: Naming a baseball bat is not a new phenomenon. Shoeless Joe Jackson’s beloved Black Betsy sold for $577,610 in 2001, and the fictional Wonder Boy made Roy Hobbs famous. But leave it to a pitcher, the Mets’ R. A. Dickey, to come up with the most creative names of all.

headline: Sunday: Look on the Bright Side!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I thought this was a really cute concept. The title only gets you part of the way to the theme, as good titles usually do. Hang in there, and remember to keep a positive attitude. Oh, and you get some extra help from 110 Across.

headline: Looking Into the Minds of the Elderly
text: A rare breed, Dr. Marc E. Agronin is a psychiatrist who sees depression, grief and anxiety in aging brains.

headline: Looking In on Other Papers’ Problems
text: Re “Picking on the Competition” (April 24):

headline: Who Married Up: The Women or the Men?
text: Once upon a time, Cinderella fell out of favor.

headline: Buffett Takes Sharper Tone on Sokol’s Actions
text: OMAHA — The billionaire Warren E. Buffett offered on Saturday his sharpest criticism yet of a former top lieutenant at his investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, saying that David L. Sokol had violated company trading policy and calling Mr. Sokol’s actions “inexplicable and inexcusable.”

headline: Sokol Says Buffett Is ‘Transparently Scapegoating’
text: OMAHA — Saturday was the first time Warren E. Buffett had spoken publicly at length about David L. Sokol, criticizing his former lieutenant for violating Berkshire Hathaway‘s policies about trading.

headline: Veterans Battle to Regain ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Losses
text: For Anthony Loverde, the fight against “don’t ask, don’t tell” is not over.

headline: The Small-Time Landlord Versus Tenant Protection
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Water Is Plentiful, but Rates for Bay Area Customers (and Conservation) Are on the Rise
text: Bay Area water agencies seem to be winning their long battle to harangue customers into consuming less.

headline: Readers Comment on My China Column
text: The Chinese expression for “contradiction” is “maodun,” based on the characters for spear and shield, like this: 矛盾 . And these days no place seems fuller of 矛盾than China. They’re also the backdrop of my Sunday column.

headline: The International Hotel
text: Anyone can schedule a tour of the resurrected International Hotel, known as the I-Hotel, the retirement home  that doubles as a monument to a historic single-room occupancy building that once stood at the same spot. The stories of the elderly Asian residents who were forcibly evicted in 1977 are told through old photographs etched on the glass windows of the new building. ASHLEY HARRELL

headline: Children’s Hospitals See Peril in Proposed Budgets
text: When Steve Woerner, president and chief executive of Driscoll Children’s Hospital in Corpus Christi, looks at the budget that state lawmakers are debating, he sees red — profit-dashing, service-slashing red.

headline: State’s Top Universities Offer New Opportunity
text: To lawmakers — at least those who know about it — the addition tacked onto an omnibus public education accountability bill in the 2009 legislative session is known as the “Doogie Howser” or the “Let My People Go” amendment.

headline: What Were the Women Doing?
text: When my great-grand-aunt Maritcha Lyons recalled in her memoir that the backroom of James McCune Smith’s store served as a “rallying centre” for public-minded black New Yorkers, she was quite specific about those who came and went. Smith’s room, she wrote advisedly, was “visited daily by men, young and old.” It was these men, she continued, who constituted the “constructive force that molded public sentiment which had much to do in bringing about a more favorable state of things affecting the colored people of the State.”

headline: 'Buffettpalooza' Rolls On
text: As the serious business of explaining Berkshire Hathaway's strategy and policies gets underway in Omaha, thousands of people gather to celebrate the mystique of legendary investor Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Senators Ensnared in Budget Politics
text: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

headline: A Hill Country Town With Hollywood Credentials
text: When passing through the Texas Hill Country on Route 281, Blanco seems like just another sleepy town with a historic courthouse, a handful of churches and a population smaller than most urban high schools. Then why, one might wonder, was the 10-by-13-block grid the backdrop for the Coen brothers’ remake of “True Grit”? And why do weekenders drop in every spring and summer by the busload? Here’s a hint: Sometimes the smallest destinations are the most rewarding, even for big-thinking Texans.

headline: Your Aunt Is Crazier Than My Grandmother
text: Tourists still flock to the observation deck of the Empire State Building, which turns 80 on Sunday, for views of a city rushing toward its future. But on the 33rd Street side of the lobby, they join New Yorkers at the Empire Room, a paean to its swankier past. Opened a year ago in a former post office by Mark C. Grossich — who is also behind the Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal — the Art Deco-inspired lounge offers specialty cocktails and Frank Sinatra amid plush banquettes, crystal chandeliers and Madagascar ebony walls. At cocktail hour on Wednesday, two business associates talked men’s socks and family relationships. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Sheriff Points the Way to Ending the Mess With Patronage Hiring
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: For Council, a New Test of Strength
text: Mayor-elect Rahm Emanuel has said he does not want the City Council to be the rubber stamp it has been under Mayor Richard M. Daley. In one of their first opportunities for independence, some aldermen are hoping to follow Mr. Emanuel’s lead.

headline: Return to Fundamentals Pays Off for the Yankees
text: They had no home runs, just timely singles and sacrifice flies. There was no eye-popping defensive wizardry, just crisp plays executed in key situations. There was no dominant pitching performance, just a gutsy one.

headline: Polishing Her Star on Gridiron in Chicago
text: Jessica Springer left a lasting impression on Linda Bache three years ago in a women’s football championship game.

headline: A Love Story, Whatever the Book Is
text: What quality is it that makes the sight of another person silently immersed in a book so attractive? Self-possession? Inaccessibility? Unguardedness? Hard to know, but it’s obviously the case — at least according to the following poems “found” recently in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They have been reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings.

headline: In Schools, a Push to Pedal
text: THEY say you never forget how to ride a bike.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. While enjoying a snack near the ’Wichcraft food kiosk at the northwest corner of Bryant Park, we noticed that a gray rock in the garden next to our table (right) appeared unnaturally uniform in color. On closer inspection, we saw it was made of plastic and had an electrical cord coming out of it. What is it, really?

headline: Inside the White House Correspondents’ Dinner
text: Celebrities, journalists and the political class gathered in Washington Saturday night for the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, an annual affair that has become one of the biggest social events in the nation’s capital. We’ll try to give you a sense of the evening by selecting some of the best messages from Twitter and other social networks.

headline: A Menu That’s Seasonal and Understated
text: HAVEN is one of a handful of restaurants that have responded enthusiastically to a growing demand for seasonal offerings that are healthful, creative and reasonably priced. Judging by weekend crowds especially, Daniel Petrilli, the owner and chef of this Pleasantville dining spot, has been successful in giving diners what they want.
